title: Writer Resurfaces After Disappearing in China
description: BEIJING  An Australian spy novelist and pro-democracy blogger who went missing in southern China on Sunday publicly resurfaced on Thursday night, speaking to a reporter for The Associated Press and posting messages on Twitter. The writer, Yang Hengjun, was most likely detained in secret by Chinese security officers, his supporters say.

title: Outsourcers Are Criticized on Visa Use
description: Major outsourcing companies from India have been the biggest recipients of visas in recent years under a program intended to allow American companies to bring highly skilled foreign workers temporarily to the United States, an immigration scholar testified Thursday before a House of Representatives judiciary panel.

title: Collins Says Fast Start Is Important
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  On the eve of his first game as a major league manager since 1999, the Mets Terry Collins met with his team before a workout and stressed the importance of winning frequently early in the season.

title: Jim Seymour, Receiving Star for Irish, Dies at 64
description: Jim Seymour, a speedy, lanky, glue-fingered end who helped lead Notre Dame to a national championship in 1966 and who became a prototype for a new breed of wide receiver as college football teams began to rely more on the passing game, died on Tuesday in Highland Park, Ill. He was 64 and lived in Deerfield, Ill.

title: Big Top as Family Business
description: Paralleling the death throes of a marriage and a 100-year-old tradition, Circo takes to the earthen roads of rural Mexico to document one of the Ponce familys many traveling circuses.

title: Liberia Uneasily Linked to Ivory Coast Conflict
description: PH-KANHOUBLI, Ivory Coast  Standing by a burned-out house on a road speckled with spent ammunition casings, Brig. Gen. Gueu Michel, the commander of rebel forces in western Ivory Coast, outlined his plan to stem an influx of Liberian mercenaries he said were fighting for Ivory Coasts embattled strongman, Laurent Gbagbo.

title: Syria Offers Changes Before Renewed Protests
description: CAIRO  As Syria braced for renewed antigovernment demonstrations, the government announced new measures on Thursday seemingly aimed at addressing the protesters demands.

title: When a Parent Dies
description: We can only hope that the actors in Alistair Banks Griffins Two Gates of Sleep werent being paid by the word.

title: Deal Is Made for Future Seasons of Mad Men
description: 9:27 p.m. | Updated |  Lionsgate, the studio behind the critically acclaimed AMC drama Mad Men, said Thursday that it had signed a long-term deal with the creator of the series, Matthew Weiner.

title: Nixon Library Opens a Door Some Would Prefer Left Closed
description: YORBA LINDA, Calif.  Most presidential libraries are as much celebrations of a president as historical repositories. They are packed with official papers, photographs, limousines, proclamations and baby shoes representing the presidents life and times; dark chapters are traditionally ignored or at least understated.

title: F.B.I. Seeks Help Cracking Code in Victims Notes
description: It sounds like the beginning of a good whodunit, or at least a Law and Order episode: A body is found. In the victims pants are two notes written in some sort of code. The F.B.I. is called in and concludes the man was murdered.

title: The Myth of Syrian Stability
description: Damascus, Syria

title: A Brief History of Primary Polling, Part I
description: Im going to be doing a short series, probably in three parts, on the question of how much we can tell from polls conducted during the very early stages of a presidential primary campaign.

title: U.S. Panel Suggests Research Into Causes and Prevalence of Health Issues Facing Gays
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government should systematically collect demographic data on gay, lesbian and transgender people and should conduct biomedical research to understand why they are more likely to have certain chronic conditions, the National Academy of Sciences said Thursday.

title: Fools of a Long-Ago April
description: Philadelphia, April 1, 1861

title: Dope and Glory
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Opening Day of the major league baseball season finds Barry Bonds in criminal court, with the bloated head, a passel of lawyers and testimony about how steroids shrink one part of a man but inflate another.

title: The Ways of the Predator
description: The mantle of social relevance can be a heavy one, but Trust, a smooth drama about a girls seduction and rape by a middle-aged Internet predator, is neither preachy nor hysterically overreaching.

title: Gil Clancy, Boxing Manager and Trainer, Dies at 88
description: Gil Clancy, the Hall of Fame boxing manager and trainer who guided Emile Griffith to the welterweight and middleweight championships and later worked as a boxing matchmaker and TV analyst, died Thursday in Lynbrook, N.Y. He was 88.

title: The Jobless See a Lifeline at Risk
description: PALM COAST, Fla.  With his worn black canvas briefcase at his feet, Richard Dudenhoeffer, a cabinet maker, stood at a computer at the one-stop employment center and scrolled through Floridas employment listings before settling on three applications: Custodian for the Flagler County School Board. City meter reader. Assistant manager at a tractor supply company.

title: The Mellon Doctrine
description: Liquidate labor, liquidate stocks, liquidate the farmers, liquidate real estate. That, according to Herbert Hoover, was the advice he received from Andrew Mellon, the Treasury secretary, as America plunged into depression. To be fair, theres some question about whether Mellon actually said that; all we have is Hoovers version, written many years later.

title: Mets Paulino Expected to Miss Most of April With Anemia
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  The Mets backup catcher Ronny Paulino was found to have anemia, according to General Manager Sandy Alderson. But Alderson said that recently performed biopsies came back negative and that the diagnosis was better than it could have been.

title: The Defection Track
description: Everybody has questions and anxieties about our policy in Libya. My own position is this: I oppose the policy the Obama administration has described in various public statements. I support the policy the administration is actually executing.

title: Praise From Those Whove Run in His Shoes
description: STORRS, Conn.  Outside Gampel Pavilion on Tuesday afternoon, Connecticut students honked horns and screamed out car windows at the mere sight of Kemba Walker, college basketballs most electrifying player since early March. Walker ducked inside for a scheduled news media session, only to find about two dozen reporters waiting.

title: Quakers and Elite School Share Uneasy Ground
description: When tensions rise at a Quaker meeting, the room is immediately brought to silence  the Quaker form of worship. In recent New York gatherings, when the subject of Friends Seminary comes up, there has been a lot of quiet.

title: Former Assistant Testifies She Saw Trainer Inject Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Soon after taking the witness stand in Barry Bondss perjury trial Thursday, Kathy Hoskins started dabbing her eyes with a tissue. Then she started wiping her forehead and cheeks. But the tears simply would not stop, so she eventually reached for the whole box of tissues.

title: When UConn Meets Notre Dame, the Fourth Time Will Be the Charm
description: It was a shock to Baylor and a warning for Connecticut.

title: Cleanup Questions as Radiation Spreads
description: As it struggles with the crisis at the Fukushima nuclear power plant, the Japanese government now faces another problem spawned by the disaster: whether and how to clean up areas that have been heavily contaminated by radioactivity.

title: Wounded by Terrorism, Teenagers From 5 Nations Share Stories
description: Naor Abutbul, a burly 17-year-old Israeli, wrestled with his emotions. Emotions had the upper hand.

title: Despite Assurances on Milk, Radiation Fear Lingers
description: SAN FRANCISCO  By scientific standards, the radiation found over the last week in batches of milk on the West Coast was minuscule and, moreover, not dangerous to humans.

title: Losses in Pakistani Haven Strain Afghan Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan Taliban are showing signs of increasing strain after a number of killings, arrests and internal disputes that have reached them even in their haven in Pakistan, Afghan security officials and Afghans with contacts in the Taliban say.

title: Mr. Obamas Energy Vision
description: It was instructive and depressing this week to watch President Obama and Congressional Republicans marching in completely different directions on energy policy. Mr. Obama reminded us that charting a clean energy future is not a pipe dream and that America can reduce its dependence on foreign oil. The Republicans reminded us how hard it will be to get there.

title: Standards Set for Joint Ventures to Improve Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration proposed long-awaited regulations on Thursday encouraging doctors and hospitals to band together, coordinate care and cut costs.

title: 4 Studios Plan to Put New Movies on Home Screens Sooner
description: LOS ANGELES  Four major movie studios plan to let some of their biggest new films play in living rooms just two months after their theatrical debuts, and theater owners are livid.

title: S.E.C. Said to Weigh Inquiry of Sokols Lubrizol Trades
description: Mario Anzuoni/ReutersDavid L. Sokol, above, and Warren E. Buffett say he has done nothing wrong.

title: Failure of Empathy and Justice
description: When President Obama listed empathy as a valuable trait for a justice during his 2009 search to replace David Souter, the idea drew scorn from some conservatives who saw it as an excuse for being soft. But a Supreme Court ruling this week provides evidence of how useful empathy is, and of how not using it can lead to glaring injustice.

title: When Ailments Pile Up, Asking Patients to Rethink Free Dialysis
description: Of all the terrible chronic diseases, only one end-stage kidney disease  gets special treatment by the federal government. A law passed by Congress 39 years ago provides nearly free care to almost all patients whose kidneys have failed, regardless of their age or ability to pay.

title: Top State Court Backs Findings of Retaliation Against 2 Police Supervisors
description: The states highest court on Thursday upheld lower courts findings that two former New York City police supervisors had been retaliated against after a disagreement with a commander who now heads the departments entire patrol force.

title: Report Criticizes High Pay at Fannie and Freddie
description: Regulators have approved generous executive compensation at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the taxpayer-backed mortgage finance giants, with little scrutiny or analysis, according to a report published Thursday by the inspector general of the Federal Housing Finance Agency.

title: On the Web, a Revolution in Giving
description: On Tuesday, I wrote about how crowdsourcing Web sites are allowing people to contribute knowledge and ideas to bring about social change. But virtually every social change organization will say that what it needs most is money. Giving to charity did not start with the Internet. But crowdfunding offers donors new ways to get more involvement and impact for their charity dollar.

title: Chancellor Merkels Shellacking
description: Even after pandering to voters fears about nuclear power, the euro and NATO operations in Libya, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany got a shellacking in her Christian Democratic partys traditional bastion of Baden-Wrttemberg. We hope Mrs. Merkel, whose term runs until 2013, draws the right lessons and hews more closely to her own principles and Germanys larger interests.

title: As Budget Talks Continue, Hard-Liners Get Support From Tea Party
description: WASHINGTON  As House Republican leaders worked to cobble together a spending plan for this year that can win bipartisan support, their more conservative members made increasingly clear on Thursday that they consider a proposed $33 billion budget cut to be insufficient.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 31, 2011

title: New Book on Google Shows Gaffes in China
description: When Google opened for business in China in 2006, Eric E. Schmidt, its chief executive, said, Google has 5,000 years of patience in China. But its divorce from the country just four years later was inevitable because operations there were troubled from the start.

title: The Giants Start Over, Adjusting to the Glare
description: LOS ANGELES

title: A Fresh Season for Managing Regret
description: Its never easy getting back into the baseball season, what with the sports self-generated scandals and star-crossed narcissists. Fans yearning for the plain nine-inning deal  bat, ball, glove and hopes under open skies  lately had to wince at testimony about the monstrous side effects of illicit hormones taken by batters obsessed with hitting even more home runs. All Babe Ruth ever was reported abusing were hot dogs and beer.

title: Justice Department to Review Seattle Polices Use of Force
description: SEATTLE  The Justice Department said Thursday that it would conduct a comprehensive investigation of the Seattle Police Department after a series of episodes in which police officers have been accused of using unnecessary force and discriminating against minorities.

title: Many Low-Wage Jobs Seen as Failing to Meet Basic Needs
description: Hard as it can be to land a job these days, getting one may not be nearly enough for basic economic security.

description: Mustafa Quraishi/Associated PressWarren E. Buffetts carefully cultivated image risks being tarnished.

title: For Fifth Avenue by the Park, 2 East Sides
description: Fifth Avenue has never divided the city quite like this.

title: Face of the New Yankees Leads Off
description: The father walked into the house a few minutes before noon after a morning of tending to the farm. Jerry Gardner has about 2,600 acres in Holly Hill, S.C., a two-stoplight town of about 2,500, where he has grown corn, soy beans, wheat, cotton and his prize harvest, an outfielder named Brett.

title: Contractor Agrees to Pay $19.6 Million in Fraud Case
description: A subsidiary of one of the nations largest construction companies will pay $19.6 million to settle criminal allegations that it committed fraud against government programs on more than a decades worth of public works projects, including the $1.4 billion Fulton Street Transit Center, according to court papers unsealed on Thursday.

title: First Win in Hand, German Pro Tries to Pick Up Something Bigger
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Confidence can make a person stand taller, as if the spine itself has been stretched, but that alone doesnt explain why Sandra Gal of Germany towered over most of the field during the first round of the Kraft Nabisco Championship.

title: Friday: Hunky-dory
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Buckle up, its going to be a bumpy puzzle. Thats not a bad thing. This was a really intriguing theme, and I wasnt even expecting one on a Friday. Bonus. It kind of reminds me of this one (Across Lite, Solution, blog)

title: Ghostly Beast Burning Bright in Iraq
description: An exotic beast is stalking Broadway. No, Im not referring specifically to the man-eating title character played by Robin Williams in Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo. Im talking about the play itself: Rajiv Josephs smart, savagely funny and visionary new work of American theater, whose presence on Broadway invites fanciful comparison to the titular beast. A Pulitzer Prize finalist last year, Bengal Tiger is like a majestic cat serenely striding through a litter of cute-as-can-be kittens ready for their YouTube close-ups.

title: F.B.I. Investigations
description: To the Editor:

title: Top Earning Hedge Fund Managers 2010
description: The 10 highest-earning hedge fund managers earned more than $17 billion in 2010.

title: Missouri Halts Extension of Pay for Unemployed
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Citing concerns about the national debt, a handful of conservative state legislators have blocked a vote to accept federal money to extend unemployment benefits, effectively cutting financial assistance for more than 10,000 out-of-work residents next week.

title: Even Funds That Lagged Paid Richly
description: Ten years ago, when the hedge fund industry was much smaller than it is today, it took 25 hedge fund managers to earn a combined annual payday of $5 billion.

title: Minaya Still Watches the Mets, Who Failed on His Watch
description: The real test will come Friday night, when the Mets open their season. Omar Minaya plans to watch at home.

title: After an On-Time Passage of a Pared-Back Budget, Bracing for the Pain to Come
description: ALBANY  After the State Legislature on Thursday adopted one of the leanest budgets in recent years, thousands of workers are facing the threat of layoffs, school systems across the state are preparing teacher cuts, and prison guards face losing their jobs as the state decides which prisons to close.

title: Ohios Anti-Union Law Is Tougher Than Wisconsins
description: After Wisconsins labor battle seized the nations attention, after nearly 100,000 people rallied in Madison to protest a bill to curb public-sector collective bargaining, the Ohio legislature has, with far less fanfare, enacted a bill perhaps even tougher on unions.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,504 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:ADAMSKI, Frank E. III, 26, Staff Sgt., Army; Moosup, Conn.; 101st Airborne Division.

title: Report Finds Lax Monitoring of Wildlife Trade
description: Efforts to eradicate the illegal trade in wildlife depend heavily on compliance by the 175 signatories of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, or Cites. But a new report has now thrown some light on the problems linked to monitoring and regulating wildlife trade by looking at official trading records supplied to Cites.

title: Creator of Mad Men Agrees to Deliver Multiple Seasons
description: Lionsgate, the studio behind the critically acclaimed AMC drama Mad Men, said on Thursday that it had signed a long-term deal with the creator of the series, Matthew Weiner.

title: A Conversation With Henry Kissinger
description: The former secretary of state sat down with Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, in 2011 to talk about the perils of diplomacy past and present.

title: Wichita State Wins N.I.T. and Hopes Best Is Ahead
description: Everyone knows not to run with scissors. But how about dancing?

title: Islanders Batter the Rangers, and Slow Their Playoff Push
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Rangers find themselves in a perilous playoff position with 10 days remaining in the regular season, and leave it to the hated Islanders for perhaps having a hand in ruining their season.

title: In Japan, Seawall Offered a False Sense of Security
description: TARO, Japan  So unshakable was this towns faith in its sea wall and its ability to save residents from any tsunami that some rushed toward it after a 9.0-magnitude earthquake struck off the coast of northeast Japan on the afternoon of March 11.

title: Gaza Man Says Israel Kidnapped Him
description: Dirar Abu Sisi, a Gaza engineer who disappeared in Ukraine in mid-February and surfaced in an Israeli prison, spoke to reporters for the first time while attending an Israeli court hearing to extend his detention. He said he had been kidnapped by Israel for no reason. Most details of the case are subject to a court-imposed rule of silence, but Israeli leaders say Mr. Abu Sisi, 42, is a member of Hamas who holds valuable information.

title: Mexico: Woman Picked to Fight Cartels
description: President Felipe Caldern appointed Mexicos top prosecutor against organized crime, Marisela Morales, left, to be attorney general, which would make her the countrys first woman in that post if approved by the Senate. The departing attorney general, Arturo Chvez Chvez, resigned after less than two years, during which he was accused of being ineffective in fighting the powerful drug cartels.

title: India: To 1.21 Billion, but More Slowly
description: Indias population has grown to 1.21 billion, second to only China, according to new census data. And despite a decade of slower population growth  it was 17.6 percent from 2001-2011, down from 21.5 percent in the 10 years before that  India still gained 181 million new people over that period, roughly the entire population of Pakistan. The governments efforts to improve conditions for Indian women seemed to be borne out in some of the data, including an increase in female literacy that was higher than the countrys overall improvement, up about 9 percent to a nationwide literacy rate of 74 percent. But Indian officials expressed alarm about one statistic: the ratio of young girls to young boys (counting those 6 years or younger) fell over the past 10 years, from 927 girls per 1,000 boys in 2001 to 914 per 1,000 in 2011. That raised worries that despite laws to prohibit it, many families are still using abortion to ensure that they have sons.

title: Report Says New York City Overlooked More Children in Danger
description: A city review made after the death of a malnourished 4-year-old in September found at least 10 more instances in which child welfare workers missed signs that children were in imminent danger, a report by the citys Administration for Childrens Services and the Office of the Public Advocate said on Thursday.

title: Yale Is Subject of Title IX Inquiry
description: A group of 16 people who filed a Title IX complaint against Yale University last month said on Thursday that the federal Department of Education had launched an investigation to review Yales policies for dealing with sexual harassment and assault cases.

title: Controversy Follows New Execution Drug
description: A decision to change one of the drugs Texas uses for lethal injections in its busy execution chamber has sparked anew the controversy over the states death penalty.

title: China: Police Break Up Rural Protest
description: A protest by more than 2,000 residents of Suijiang County in Yunnan Province that lasted for five days was dispersed on Tuesday by paramilitary police officers and armored vehicles, according to Chinese news reports and a posting on the Web site of the countys government. The protest, one of the largest in China in recent memory, erupted because of heated disputes between residents and the government over compensation for seized land, a common source of conflict in China. The Internet post by the government said the protesters blocked roads and threatened businesses, and so the government had to call in hundreds of riot police officers to intervene. Injuries were reported.

title: In Hunt for New Revenue, Options Are Limited
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Child-Only Insurance Vanishes, a Health Act Victim
description: Only months from their 65th birthdays and the switch from employer-offered health coverage to Medicare, Phillip and Diann Green of Forney realized they had a problem. After retirement, none of the states insurance companies will cover their 12-year-old granddaughter, Aria, whom they have raised since her infancy.

title: Notre Dame Professor Leads Effort to Keep Asian Carp Out of Great Lakes
description: When the United States Fish and Wildlife Service decided in March to ban the import and transport of bighead carp  one of the infamous Asian carp  under a century-old law called the Lacey Act, David Lodge had one reaction. Its about time, he said.

title: Appropriately, Cubs Season Starts With a Stumble
description: The Cubs decision to feature Albert Pujols and Derek Jeter on some of their marketing billboards has provoked disbelieving indignation throughout Cubdom. What were they thinking?

title: Words for Savings: Simplify and Coordinate
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Teaching Little Fingers New Math Tricks
description: Gabi Bagley, 5, dug through a box of Kid KNex toys, bypassing rods and cylinders until she found a purple, teardrop-shaped object about four inches long. Does that fit your hand just right? said Cyndi Lopardo, her Preschool for All teacher. Bring it over.

title: School Lunches in Affluent Districts Emerge as Moneymakers
description: Children spilled into the courtyard of Havens Elementary School in Piedmont one recent day as a cluster of mom-volunteers sorted through box lunches of sushi and edamame and grabbed hot meals from a portable warming oven.

title: Gun Issue Is Troubling Berkeley High
description: Berkeley High School, a high-achieving institution that embodies the citys liberal politics, is seeing those values tested at gunpoint.

title: The Haight Pays a Price for Sit/Lie News Coverage
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: Airport Art Is Not an Oxymoron, at Least Not at SFO
description: Even in these hard economic times, the Bay Area overflows with vibrant art institutions, among them the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, the Cartoon Art Museum, the Oakland Museum of California and the San Francisco International Airport. Yes, that last one is correct.

title: Billionaire Wyly Brothers Lose an Effort to Dismiss Insider-Trading Charges
description: Two billionaire brothers from Texas, Charles and Samuel Wyly, lost a bid to have claims of fraud and insider trading dismissed from a lawsuit brought against them by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Bringing Home to the Hospital
description: Some patients cope with long hospital stays by bringing in a few books and a favorite pair of slippers. For others, an incandescent lamp can offer light that looks more like home. A favorite Steelers blanket may adorn a bed. The mother of one young woman brought in a sewing machine and worked happily and busily during her daughters monthlong hospitalization.

title: 5 Questions About Todays Jobs Report
description: The Labor Department will release the March jobs report at 8:30 a.m. My colleague Michael Powell posted his preview of the report earlier this evening. These are the five things Ill be looking for first:1. Has the latest turmoil  oil prices, Europes debt problems, state and local cutbacks  spooked employers?

title: Bessemer Venture Partners Closes $1.6 Billion Fund
description: These days, owning a slice of Facebook or Groupon  two of the most popular and valuable companies on the Web  is worth at least some bragging rights in Silicon Valley.

title: After Months of Growth, Signs of Weakness in the Manhattan Real Estate Market
description: After more than a year of slow but steady growth, the Manhattan real estate market saw declines in price and sales volume in the first three months of 2011, raising the question of whether the city may finally be following the rest of the nation into a double dip in housing prices.

title: Happy Motoring: Traffic Deaths at 61-Year Low
description: It may not seem that way when some knucklehead speeds past you on the right, but driving is getting much, much safer: last year the United States recorded the fewest traffic deaths in more than 60 years, according to federal data released on Friday.

title: News Quiz | April 1, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Afghans Avenge Florida Koran Burning, Killing 12
description: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan  Stirred up by three angry mullahs who urged them to avenge the burning of a Koran at a Florida church, thousands of protesters on Friday overran the compound of the United Nations in this northern Afghan city, killing at least 12 people, Afghan and United Nations officials said.

title: Qaddafi Envoy Visits London as Tensions Mount in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A senior aide to one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis sons has held secret talks in London with British authorities, a friend of the aide said Friday, as his government dismissed rebel talk of a cease-fire as a thinly veiled invitation to surrender.

title: Gbagbo Is Said to Be Close to Defeat in Ivory Coast
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Reeling from mass defections among his soldiers and security forces, Ivory Coasts strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, deployed a dwindling but determined band of loyalists on Friday to defend his residence, the state television station and the presidential palace in an effort to hold on to power.

title: Test Yourself | History, April 1, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about an epidemic that first came to light in the 1980s.

description: WASHINGTON  Energy Secretary Steven Chu said Friday that roughly 70 percent of the core of one reactor at the crippled Fukushima nuclear plant in Japan had suffered severe damage.

Do you agree? Do you or people you know have trouble with spending? What about distinguishing between needs and wants? What is your familys policy, in general, concerning giving out money? How much do your parents give you?

title: Glass in Front, Clouds Below
description: If Slide 1 doesnt make your heart skip a beat, you are either beyond fearless, a professional window washer or both. And if it doesnt make your heart ache a bit, you may not remember that Roko Camaj, an Albanian immigrant who adored his job washing windows at the World Trade Center  so infectiously that he became the subject of a childrens book  was killed on Sept. 11, 2001.

description: Last December, Neil Young played a venue opposite the offices of the Brooklyn Motorized Corporation, an electric-motorcycle start-up situated among the red brick warehouses of Gowanus, Brooklyn.

title: Syrian Protesters Clash With Security Forces
description: CAIRO  Antigovernment protesters in Syria, unsatisfied with yet more vague promises of reform from President Bashar al-Assad, marched by the thousands in numerous cities on Friday, only to be met with gunfire and other violence that killed at least 10 people, according to residents and human rights groups.

title: Is Janet the Next Cher?
description: More than a week has passed since I saw Janet Jackson at Radio City Music Hall, and Im still smiling, much to the chagrin/surprise of a friend who asked me, the day before the show, why I was bothering. Hed seen her a couple of times, the most recent in 2002, and seemed to be saying, What has she done for us lately?

title: Rubio Steps Into Spotlight on Debt Fight
description: The political advisers working for Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, had always envisioned that he would eventually speak out forcefully in Washington on the issues that animated his campaign: the debt, government spending, entitlements and taxes.

title: Complaint Box | Sidewalk Spitting
description: Since I moved to New York six years ago, I have toned my tolerance muscles. If I allowed myself to get cranky every time someone barreled down the wrong side of the sidewalk or had a way-too-personal phone conversation on the M15 bus, Id be one unhappy New Yorker. But the one thing I still cannot abide in this city is spitting.

title: Dueling Protests Grip Yemeni Capital
description: SANA, Yemen  Vast, dueling protests gripped this dusty, divided city on Friday as tens of thousands of people prayed in the streets for the end of President Ali Abdullah Salehs rule, while his supporters staged even larger demonstrations of their own warning of the chaos that would come to Yemen if he were driven from power.

title: Herms in Talks for Potential Sale of Gaultier Stake
description: Herms  the French maker of Birkin and Kelly handbags that is fending off advances from the LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton luxury conglomerate  said Friday it had begun talks to sell its 45 percent stake in the Jean Paul Gaultier fashion house.

title: Rubber
description: Camp-horror fans, check out this preview from the movie Rubber, which opens today  April Fools Day. The main character is a tire (!) that awakens one day and finds it can blow up peoples heads with telekinetic powers. The film, the first feature by Quentin Dupieux (a Frenchman who is also known in the house music world as Mr. Oizo and for the track Flat Beat; but thats a different story), has received mixed reviews so far.

title: Laura Bush Tames the Ranch
description: A look at her home in Crawford, Tex.

title: Arianna Huffingtons Next Move
description: Youve called your father a newspaperman. What did he do?  I grew up with my father starting small newspapers in Greece. None of them survived. Maybe this has something to do with the fact that Ive never had any desire to have Huff Post have a print component.

title: The Enthusiast
description: This weeks enthusiast: Mark Blankenship, editor of The Critical Condition (www.thecriticalcondition.com)

title: Five Ways of Looking at the Legend of Derek Jeter
description: Prologue: A Native American Legend

title: Does the Mediterranean Diet Even Exist?
description: Every Saturday, a fleet of cars and trucks pulls into a windswept parking lot just off the Mediterranean. Under flapping white awnings, women slit open eggplants the size of a large mans thumb and stuff them with a mix of chopped garlic, red peppers and walnuts. This is Souk el Tayeb, the farmers market that has helped make Beirut a hot destination for globe-trotting foodies. But if you want to see how the new generation of Lebanese really wants to eat, you have to go somewhere else. You have to go to Roadster Diner.

title: An Imperfect Match
description: I work for a large corporation that has a foundation that matches qualifying charitable contributions dollar for dollar, up to $50,000 a year. Would it be ethical for me to consolidate the contributions of friends, neighbors and family members and submit that bigger donation to, say, the American Red Cross with the view of getting the doubling effect on the donation? BRUCE PELLEGRINO, FAR HILLS, N.J.

title: How Slavery Really Ended in America
description: On May 23, 1861, little more than a month into the Civil War, three young black men rowed across the James River in Virginia and claimed asylum in a Union-held citadel. Fort Monroe, Va., a fishhook-shaped spit of land near the mouth of the Chesapeake Bay, had been a military post since the time of the first Jamestown settlers. This spot where the slaves took refuge was also, by remarkable coincidence, the spot where slavery first took root, one summer day in 1619, when a Dutch ship landed with some 20 African captives for the fledgling Virginia Colony.

title: Secrecy in Shreds
description: Last year, Gabriel Schoenfeld, a veteran of the conservative magazine Commentary, published a book that explained how The New York Times could be prosecuted under the Espionage Act. The book said a lot of other things too, but youll understand why that particular proposition stuck in my mind. At one point Schoenfeld conjured an image of authorities frog-marching a shackled Bill Keller into court.

title: Terrible Twins
description: Strangers often ask if my twins are natural. No, I tell them. Astroturf. They want to know if I used I.V.F. None of their business. I didnt, but that hasnt made the experience of having multiples any more normal, or anything close to natural.

title: Laura Bush Is Back at the Ranch
description: GOOD RIDDANCE, WASHINGTON: There is a stark contrast between life in the White House and life at home. I didnt really know I was stressed until I moved home and wasnt.

title: An American Cleric
description: The fact that Yasir Qadhi says, in Andrea Elliotts words, that he hopes that the world will someday fully adhere to his faith says it all. We in the United States for the most part are a tolerant people. When his goal as stated in the article is a Muslim world, we become intolerant of him and people who think like him.

title: Styled to a T | Charlotte Macaux Perelman
description: The Architect: Charlotte Macaux Perelman, who founded Studio CMP in Paris after stints with the hotel-world heavyweights: Philippe Starck and Andre Balazs.

title: Offshore Wind Backbone Begins to Take Shape
description: The company planning a transmission backbone for wind farms off the Atlantic coast has broadened its sights slightly and asked the Interior Department to give it a right-of-way of hundreds of miles.

title: Morning Buzz | More Children in Peril
description: Rain, rain and maybe a little snow today, with highs in the mid-40s: perfect baseball weather. The weekend should be nicer, though, with considerable sunshine, especially Sunday (hence the name) and highs in the mid-50s.

title: His Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy: George R. R. Martin Talks Game of Thrones
description: There are wunderkinds, there are late bloomers, and then there is George R. R. Martin, who at 62 is on the verge of the most prominent visibility  and possibly the greatest success  of his literary career. Though Mr. Martin has worked steadily in fantasy and science-fiction since the 1970s, with a detour into television writing that hell discuss momentarily, he gained a wider following beginning in the 1990s with the publication of his Song of Ice and Fire series: an epic fantasy, starting with A Game of Thrones in 1996, that takes place on a fictional continent called Westeros. Mr. Martin envisions it as a seven-book cycle.

title: Job Growth Suggests Resilience of U.S. Recovery
description: The United States economy showed signs of kicking into gear in March, adding 216,000 jobs and prompting President Obama to proclaim a corner finally turned.

title: The Potential Heirs to Buffetts Throne
description: The resignation of David L. Sokol  a leading candidate to succeed Warren Buffett at Berkshire Hathaway  has called into question the companys succession plan.

title: The Insider | Athena Calderone
description: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts.

title: Inflation? Not in Wages
description: One of the big questions facing the Federal Reserve is whether the recent rise in oil and food prices will turn into an inflationary spiral. Todays jobs report suggests that the answer, at least so far, is that there is little reason to worry about such a spiral.

title: What to Do When You Cant Read the Fine Print
description: EVERYTHING seems to stiffen up as people age, and our eyes are no exception. As the years go by, the lens of the eye becomes harder and less elastic. The result is a gradual worsening of the ability to focus on objects up close, called presbyopia.

title: Embedded Water
description: Water used in the production of food.

title: April 1 Updates on Libyan War and Mideast Protests
description: On Friday, The Lede is following the war in Libya, unrest in Syria and protest movements across the Middle East and North Africa. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read the frequently updated main news article from our colleagues there.

title: Lives of the Laureates
description: Thats Doris Lessing on the left, and Albert Einstein by the food bowls.

title: Been Down So Long
description: There has been some celebrating over the jobs report, and for sure 200,000 jobs is better than 100,000, or none at all.

title: Shares Rise on Report Of Jobs Growth
description: Stocks rose Friday after the governments monthly report on the labor market showed job growth was picking up, helping the major indexes gain more than 1 percent for the week.

title: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: Providence Equity Buys Government Consultant
description: 1:54 p.m. | Updated

title: Determinants of Business Investment Spending
description: This used to be a big topic of empirical research, but seems to have largely faded out since the mid-1990s  probably because macro had shifted away from structural estimates in general, and also possibly because of the rise of real business cycle stuff.

title: Family Style
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#1000", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Tips on Having Twins
description: My first daughter was only 2 when I learned I was having twins, and so I still remembered clearly how giddy people were when I was pregnant with her. Theyd gleefully tell me tales of 30-hour labors, leaky bladders, struggling marriages. Not so with multiples. From the beginning, people reacted badly to the news. It was as if I had the plague and were coughing in their living room. One friend was openly angry. Some wanted to know exactly what to do to avoid this happening to them. Others just wrinkled their noses as if Id stepped into a dog-deposited mess. No, they said. Really?

title: Columbus Park, Brooklyn, 7:11 A.M.
American Apparel Warns of Bankruptcy
description: American Apparel is losing its appeal among young urban shoppers.

title: Fix Xanadu? The Problem May Be Where to Begin
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  A state official declared this week that the ill-starred, long-stalled Xanadu mall would be renamed. But by any name, it will still be the building that Gov. Chris Christie has called an offense to the eyes as you drive up the turnpike.

title: 5 Answers From Todays Jobs Report
description: The latest jobs report was a solid one, as I mentioned in an earlier post. Job growth is picking up speed, reaching 216,000 in March. Rising oil prices dont seem to be spooking companies, at least not by the week of March 12, when the Labor Department conducted its survey. All that is very good news. Unlike last years recovery  which petered out in the spring  this years remains alive.

title: Father of 5 Browns Is Sentenced
description: Keith S. Brown, the father and former manager of the 5 Browns, the sibling quintet of classical pianists, was sentenced on Thursday to at least 10 years in prison after pleading guilty to sexually abusing his daughters when they were children, The Associated Press reported.

title: Fte Accompli | Ruben Toledos Cityscapes
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#169", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: Making The Killing, AMCs New Nordic Noir
description: The next season of Mad Men may have been stalled in a contractual netherworld, but AMC has at least one angst-filled new offering to fill the void.

title: Obama Pushes Energy Savings From Clean Fleets
description: President Obama is joining with FedEx, U.P.S. and several other major companies whose vehicles are familiar sights on Americas roadways to promote a new administration initiative encouraging businesses to operate commercial fleets that burn less gasoline and diesel fuel.

title: The Week in Pictures, April 1
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Friday Reading: Are You Your Childs A.T.M.?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: New David Mamet Play Set to Premiere in London This Fall
description: David Mamets new play, The Anarchist, about a female inmate who was once part of a Weather Underground-like group and is now pleading for parole before the prisons female governor, will have its world premiere in London this fall, a team of American and British producers announced on Friday.

title: 2 City College Students Are Named Truman Scholars
description: The City College of New York is crowing after two of its undergraduates were chosen Thursday as Truman scholars, a prestigious recognition bestowed on just 60 college students nationwide. The public college, part of the City University of New York, even bested Yale, which had one scholar.

title: G.M. Sells Delphi Stake for $3.8 Billion
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: It Was a Happy Month, Mostly, for Modernists
description: OPIONEERS! From Isadora Duncan to Martha Graham, American theatrical dance amazed the world with bold women who addressed space and time in ways that expressed aspects of womanhood  of, indeed, humanity  and that showed why the 20th century was, in Henry Luces words, the American century.

title: VW Recalls 2011 Jettas in Which Horn Can Make Engine Stall
description: 12:04 p.m. | Updated Volkswagen is recalling about 71,000 Jettas from the 2011 model year because a wiring problem with the horn could cause the engine to stall (and, no, this is not an April Fools joke).

title: Our Second Annual Found Poem Challenge
description: Update | June 11, 2011: We received over 650 entries to this challenge. You can view the 10 we chose as favorites here.

title: Keep Going, Keep Going, Even at the Met
description: ON Halloween night in 1996 the sometime soprano, sometime mezzo-soprano Waltraud Meier got what you get, if you are lucky, when you are one of the great artists of your time: the starring role in a new production of a classic work at the Metropolitan Opera. Bizets Carmen was far from the Wagner characters Ms. Meier was famous for, but shed had success with the part in her native Germany. Conducted by James Levine and directed by the crowd-pleasing Franco Zeffirelli, the production, which also featured Plcido Domingo and Angela Gheorghiu, had all the makings of a success.

title: April 3  9
description: Theater

title: Why Buy? You Can Spend Tons Renting
description: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, as filmgoers at the AMC Loews Lincoln Center settled in with their tubs of popcorn and vats of soda to see the new thriller Limitless, what seemed like a traditional movie trailer began.

title: School Official Finds Retirement Is Just A Higher Pay Grade
description: PHOENIX  Carlos Bejarano, a local schools superintendent with more than 30 years in education, is nearing retirement, but his plans include neither long afternoons on the golf course nor extended road trips with the family. His retirement, in fact, will closely resemble the workaday life he has been living.

title: Leading Off: Season All Figured Out on Day 2
description: After all the fanfare of baseballs opening day  which included massive fan-thawing efforts in many cities  the festivities of Day 2 include jumping to instant conclusions about the season. Never mind that the season will last longer than some marriages, but by the time we hit August, March 31 will be as distant a memory as the first season of Seinfeld. No, its never too early to figure everything out.

title: Average Length of Unemployment Rises Again
description: As weve noted before, the length of time the typical unemployed person has been out of work has been getting longer and longer. And in March, the duration of unemployment again rose, to an average of 39 weeks:

title: Giving Strategically, When the Government Cant Help
description: THIS is a season of fiscal austerity for governments, and state and local officials across the country are threatening to cut programs that aim to help the less fortunate. With tax revenue down and budgets constrained, they say they have little choice.

title: Ford Tops G.M. as Auto Sales Rise for All but Toyota
description: DETROIT  Ford Motor outsold General Motors in the United States last month for only the second time since 1998, and overall new-vehicle sales increased 17 percent despite concerns about high gasoline prices and production stoppages in Japan.

title: Window Washers of New York
description: Very few other laborers report to work at such tenuous precipices. They clear panoramas for the rest of us by putting their lives and limbs on the line, wrote our colleagues on the Lens blog. This week, they bring to you a collection of archival images taken by intrepid photographers for The New York Times who leaned out windows, hung over rooftops and sometimes joined their subjects on window-washing rigs. See a slide show and read more on Lens

title: Artifacts | Michael Stipes Collapse Into Film
description: R.E.M. has a new album. Its called Collapse Into Now, and its 12 rockers show the band in peak form. But the record isnt just about music. It also has a visual component: 12 short films that R.E.M.s frontman and creative mastermind Michael Stipe commissioned from 11 different artists. They include Sam Taylor-Wood, Sophie Calle, James Franco (who made two) and the unstoppable 84-year-old documentary filmmaker Albert Maysles.

title: The Talented but Erratic JaVale McGee
description: Players dont get much more intriguing than JaVale McGee. McGee is a true 7-footer with a 7-foot-6 wingspan who can run the court like a deer and jump out of the gym  in fact, he is capable of playing so far above the rim that the Wizards installed a special above-the-rim camera his rookie year to capture how much amplitude he gets. He can be a dunking and shot-blocking machine, and had the most impressive dunk of the 2011 Dunk Contest as well as the most impressive in-game block of the season.

title: Look Back at a Legend, Then Revisit Disco
description: Aretha Franklin

title: Jim Shepard, Master of the Historical Short Story
description: Its unclear why Jim Shepard tends to collect his short stories under titles that seem more like shrugs: his latest, You Think Thats Bad, follows a 2007 volume called Like Youd Understand, Anyway. The contents are anything but lackadaisical. Shepards taut, high-concept, research-dependent fiction covers a bracing, career-long range of hobbyhorses and obsessions. Nazis, horror movies, aircraft and explorers abound. Historical fiction is typically so ample and epilogic that the historical short story may seem a contradiction in terms, but Shepard has made himself, in particular, a master of this small, tricky subgenre. (His colleague at Williams College, Andrea Barrett, is another.)

title: For a Team Player, the Solo Moments Are Secondary
description: AMBROSE AKINMUSIRE, a 28-year-old trumpeter on the verge of jazz stardom, has a penetrating gaze, a compact frame and the wary poise of someone at home with his own thoughts. He was bundled up one recent afternoon, surveying his favorite spot to practice: a park bench on a promontory jutting into Spuyten Duyvil Creek, at the northern tip of Manhattan. The bench faces the Henry Hudson Bridge and the river beyond. I like the way it sounds out here, he said. When hes practicing, people usually leave him alone.

title: When Aging Eyes Cant Read the Fine Print
description: Last night I had to interrupt my daughters homework to ask her to read the instructions on a package of fresh pasta. Try as I might, even with reading glasses, I couldnt decipher the tiny print.

title: Rose, Fetch Her Ladyship a Sequel
description: LONDON

title: Into a Lunar Training Ground
description: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from New Mexico, where he is measuring sand particle sizes, layer thicknesses and angles to address questions about volcanoes and rock patterns on Mars.

title: Dialysis in Elderly Patients
description: The Times reports today on the frequent use of dialysis in elderly patients.

title: For Butlers Stevens, a Career Change Paid Off
description: HOUSTON  Years before he stood on the sideline, Brad Stevens stood on a stage in St. Petersburg, Fla., speaking about employee compensation to a gathering of almost 400 of his co-workers from Eli Lilly. Not yet 25, he was an up-and-comer.

title: Step 1: The Roquefort Filling
Grand Marnier Souffl
description: You can use any flavored alcohol for this recipe. (Cointreau, framboise, even creme de menthe).

title: Frozen Passion Fruit "Souffl"
description: Not actually a souffl, this frozen concoction is really a mousse. But it uses meringue, the same base as a souffl, and, the parchment-paper collars give the dish a distinctly souffl-ish look.

title: Chocolate Souffl
description: This recipe uses dark chocolate pistoles (little button-shaped pieces) that are readily available. You can also use chocolate that has been broken up into small pieces. Dutch-process cocoa powder (cocoa that has been alkalized to remove some of the bitterness) is best.

title: Introduction
description: You may be shocked to learn that making souffls does not take a degree in the culinary arts. The reason so much mystique hovers around these playful cups of whipped egg is not the level of talent required to conquer them, but their ephemeral nature. At restaurants, a souffl usually must be ordered at the beginning of the meal and the wait staff then faces the challenge of getting it to the table before it deflates.

title: Roquefort Souffl
description: If you haven't ever had a savory souffl, you're in for a delightful surprise. You can use any strong-flavored cheese here (a sharp cheddar, a strong goat cheese, Gruyre, or another blue cheese).

title: The Assembly
description: The final key to a great lasagna is to use real, quality Parmesan cheese, most preferably the genuine, imported variety known as Parmigiano-Reggiano.

title: Roquefort Souffl
description: You can use any strong-flavored cheese in this recipe (a sharp cheddar, a strong goat cheese, Gruyere or another blue cheese).

title: Step 2: Piping and Presentation
Sarah Vowell Does Hawaii
description: Sometimes I loved the disruptive student in class who livened up lectures with wisecracks  it put a spin on things, added flavor, made me laugh. Other times I wished the heckler would just shut up so I could learn something. Such were my thoughts while reading Sarah Vowells latest book, Unfamiliar Fishes.

title: Good Jobs News, but Not Great
description: The jobs numbers keep getting better. They are not that good yet, but there are signs they will keep improving.

title: Planes, Trains, and No Automobiles
description: Atrios links to this piece on transit at Asian airports, then lists some US airports with fairly good rail links to the city.

title: Portugal Stages Surprise Bond Auction; Ireland Is Hit With New Downgrade
description: Portugal, which is struggling with its debt, successfully sold bonds on Friday in an auction some analysts said was a sign that the country was trying to avoid any bailout before a new government was elected in June.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Brooklyn Flea moves outdoors this weekend and finds a new home on Sundays. All the vendors will still open at the flagship Fort Greene location, 176 Lafayette Avenue (between Clermont and Vanderbilt Avenues) on Saturdays, but the Flea will be located in Williamsburg on the waterfront, 27 North Sixth Street (Kent Avenue), on Sundays. Among the food vendors making a debut are Brooklyn Bangers, a sausage-sandwich concept from Saul Bolton, the chef of Saul and the Vanderbilt, and Fany Gersons Dough, where a variety of her doughnuts with hot chocolate will be sold on both days. Christina Tosi from Momofuku Milk Bar also joins the mix with sweets like grapefruit and hibiscus jam. Oystergirl, from the folks behind Marys Fish Camp, will shuck oysters, for $1.50 to $3 each, Saturday only. The Kings County Jerky stand and pies from Rachels Pies will also operate on Saturdays. The new Sunday-only vendors at the waterfront include Sam Masons Empire Mayonnaise, where he will debut artisanal-made mayonnaise served with fries; organic handmade pastas from Rochester, N.Y.-based Flour City Pasta; sweet and savory Czech-style pastry pies from Frgal; smoked meats from Mile End; sandwiches from Saltie and various soups from Sea Bean Goods. The Flea will move back indoors at the former Williamsburgh Savings Bank in November.

title: Stewart ONan Tells a Widows Tale
description: Who is Stewart ONan? Over the past 17 years, hes written 11 novels  well turn to the 12th in a moment  as remarkable for their precise, economical language and depth of characterization as for the fact that each is as different from its predecessor, in style, tone and narrative approach, as if it had come from a different author.

title: Prematurity Drug Price Jumps Wildly
description: Jennifer Campbell is 39 years old and is 26 weeks pregnant with her second son. Her first, who is now two-and-a-half, was born prematurely at 29 weeks (28 weeks, six days to be exact), and her high-risk obstetrician is using the tools available to keep that from happening again. One of those tools is a drug called 17P, which, until recently, cost $10 for each weekly injection. But a few weeks ago the name of the drug changed to Makena and the price went up to more than $1,500 per shot, which would have brought the cost to $30,000 for Ms. Campbells four-month treatment, she explained to me in an e-mail.

title: Why Auto Repair Bulletins Arent on Regulators Web Site
description: FOR years, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has declined to post on its Web site reports from automakers about problems with their cars and about specialized warranty extensions that could save consumers large sums on repairs.

title: Quieting Clicks, Grinds and Rattles
description: CHEVROLET Camaros with clanking torque converters and Chrysler minivans with noisy wheel bearings are among the topics covered in automakers recent technical service bulletins.

title: Recalling a Slight but Towering Figure at Bronx Science
description: He taught in a school that in those years was peppered with the children of liberals, socialists and communists, where the students themselves vigorously refused to crouch during air-raid drills and protested outdoor nuclear testing. Yet Arnold Canell stood at the front of the classroom quoting William F. Buckley Jr. and his National Review, slyly enjoying the provocative disparity of views.

title: Explaining Congos Endless Civil War
description: Some months ago, in a ditch beside one of the main streets of Bunia, a dusty, war-battered city in northeastern Congo, I noticed a small, broken-down, dull green armored car, the gun barrel in its turret tilted awkwardly toward the sky. Removing war debris can be an expensive luxury in a poor country, and the wreck seemed an apt symbol of the indelible mark that 15 years of intermittent conflict has put on this nation.

title: The Pathos of Robert Gates
description: In his testimony on Capitol Hill yesterday, Secretary of Defense Robert Gates made what amounted to an eloquent, even impassioned case against United States involvement in Libya. He highlighted the weakness of the rebel forces: Calling them an opposition is a misnomer, he suggested, describing the rebels as very disparate, very scattered, lacking command and control and lacking organization, and pretty much a pickup ballgame at this point. Their governance capacity for a post-Qaddafi Libya, he added, is limited, if not nonexistent. He put great stress on Americas pre-existing commitments: I am preoccupied with avoiding mission creep, avoiding an open-ended, very large scale commitment in this respect  The last thing this country needs is another exercise in nationbuilding. And he basically threatened to resign if the White House somehow decided to send ground forces into Libya: Not as long as Im in this job, he said, when asked about the possibility of putting (non-C.I.A.) boots on the ground.

title: E. L. Doctorows Stories
description: For writers of a certain age  my age, that is: born in the 1970s, around the time of E. L. Doctorows greatest triumphs  Doctorow is familiar more by reputation than by any direct influence. Certainly weve heard of him; probably every college-educated, newspaper-reading person in America has heard of him, and has a vague sense that he is, as his press kit puts it, Americas Pre-eminent Novelist. But what kind of novelist? And what does his considerable body of work  11 novels and more awards than you can count on one hand  represent? Judging from my own experience and that of my peers, a generation later his literary descendants havent gotten the memo.

title: Jennifer Thomas, Noah Shamosh
description: Jennifer Joanne Thomas and Noah Alexander Shamosh were married Saturday evening in the State Room, an event space, in Boston. Christopher K. Thomas, an uncle of the bride and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: The Illustrator of I Stink! Shows Off his More Elegant Work
description: Parents of small children probably know James McMullan as the creator (along with his wife, Kate) of the popular picture book I Stink! about the nightly rounds of a profoundly disgusting but hard-working New York City garbage truck. He is also enshrined in disco lore for the paintings he did more than 30 years ago for New York magazine that became the visual inspiration for Saturday Night Fever. But these days Mr. McMullan is much better known for the elegantly expressive show posters he makes for Lincoln Center Theater. And this week a large selection of those posters  for plays and musicals like Ah! Wilderness, Carousel and South Pacific  went on display near the theater they helped promote, at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, on Lincoln Center Plaza off Amsterdam Avenue near 64th Street. The posters, as well as preliminary sketches, photographs and watercolor and gouache studies, will remain on view at the library through June 11, and on April 4, Mr. McMullan will join fellow theatrical graphic artist Frank Verlizzo, known as Fraver, at the library for a discussion about the living art of poster-making.

title: Rachel Wood-Rome, Garrick Trapp
description: Rachel Devorah Wood-Rome, a daughter of the Rev. Virginia L. Wood of Greensboro, N.C., and David Rome of West Hartford, Conn., was married Saturday afternoon in Manhattan to Garrick Alexander Trapp, a son of Elizabeth A. Trapp and Frederick P. Trapp of Long Beach, Calif. The Rev. Stephen G. Kendrick, a Unitarian Universalist minister, led the ceremony on Cherry Hill in Central Park.

title: Yoomi Lee and Benjamin Steele
Growth Industry
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#242", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Weekend Competition: April Fools
description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab invites co-vocabularists to share their favourite April Fools Day japery.

title: Spaghetti Farming
description: I love this. On April 1, 1957, the British show Panorama pulled a fast one on viewers with this little news report on the Swiss spaghetti harvest. According to the blog Food Section, hundreds of viewers contacted the BBC after they watched it to find out where they could buy such a plant.

title: Richard Feynman, the Thinker
description: In the heyday of the physicist Richard P. Feynman, which ensued after his death in 1988, a publishing entrepreneur might have been tempted to start a book club of works by and about him. Offered as main selections would be Feynmans autobiographical rambles (as told to Ralph Leighton),  Surely Youre Joking, Mr. Feynman!  and  What Do You Care What Other People Think?  For alternate selections, readers could choose from his more serious works, like QED: The Strange Theory of Light and Matter  a spirited account of the counterintuitive behavior of the quantum world  and the legendary Feynman Lectures on Physics. Whatever the man said had swagger. For those who would rather listen, there are recordings of the lectures and of Feynman playing his bongos.

title: An Enclave With Rustic Charm
description: ITS not hard to understand why Puritan settlers in Connecticut slapped the Devils name on so many ridges, rivers and gorges. These barren areas were probably so difficult to farm or even traverse that they might have seemed cursed.

title: Sovereign Wealth Funds Buy Stake in TPG
description: The private equity firm TPG has agreed to sell nearly 5 percent of itself to two sovereign wealth funds in a transaction that values the firm at about $10 billion, according to a person briefed on the deal.

title: Jewish Refugees in the Eternal City
description: Its not easy for a refugee to retain his dignity, nor is it necessarily a goal. Like a hermit crab that has outgrown its shell, a refugee must seize the best shelter he can before another needy creature is able to grab it. Nevertheless, in David Bezmozgiss first novel, The Free World, set in Rome in 1978, a proud Soviet Jewish migr couple, seeking visas, take offense when a clerk in the briefing department asks for their Persecution Story. What do we need this for? the wife asks. Nobodys saying you need it, the clerk explains. The Americans need it. Youre claiming refugee status. To be a refugee you need to have been persecuted. To which the wife indignantly retorts: The entire country was persecuted.

title: Les Murray and the Poetry of Depression
description: The signature quality of a Les Murray poem is anger  a visceral smoldering that freshly lights up the tired old landscape and turns conventional pieties inside out. A lifelong outsider and champion of the underdog, Murray grew up among impoverished farmers in rural Australia, where, as an overweight redneck teenager, he was mercilessly tormented at school. Today he is the closest thing Australia has to a national poet. A sui generis autodidact (he now suspects he has Aspergers syndrome) equipped with a fierce moral vision and a sensuous musicality, he writes subtly about postcolonialism, urban sprawl and poverty and, in his most intimate poems, reminds us of the power of literature to transubstantiate grievance into insight. (His admirers have argued he ought to be considered for a Nobel.) But he is equally capable of writing emotionally simplistic and strangely soured poems in which the enraged adolescent emerges all but unmediated. This mercurial doubleness can make his work hard to categorize or describe: this is a mind at once revolutionary and reactionary. Or maybe just a poet whos willing to show more id than most.

title: Casualties of Chinas One Child Policy
description: In 1989, the Chinese writer and broadcaster Xinran was in a remote mountain village in Shandong Province having dinner with the headman when she heard cries from an adjoining room, where his daughter-in-law was giving birth. A while later, as the midwife collected her fee, Xinran noticed a movement in the slops bucket. To my absolute horror, she recalls, I saw a tiny foot poking out of the pail. But she was the only one who was shocked. Its not a child, the headmans wife told her. If it was, wed be looking after it, wouldnt we? Its a girl baby, and we cant keep it.

title: Helping Refugees After World War II
description: Military victory  to adapt Oscar Wilde  is rarely pure and never simple. The Allied triumph in Europe at the end of World War II was a case in point. The war and the Holocaust forced millions of civilians across national frontiers. Afterward, multitudes of ethnic Germans were expelled from Eastern Europe and many of the Jews in Poland fled from a new wave of persecution there. Those lucky enough to survive these migrations faced months and years in limbo as the authorities wrestled with the logistical, political and moral difficulties involved in returning them home  or in finding them a new one.

title: Our False Beliefs About Language
description: For nearly a century, linguists have been struggling to unseat the accumulated dogma that masquerades as common sense, as the American linguist Leonard Bloomfield put it in 1933. Thats the challenge that faces every developing science, but linguistics seems to have had a harder time than most. People who readily accept the principles of modern economics, psychology and biology still cling to notions about language that are as antiquated as a belief in physiocracy or leeching.

title: Julia Childs Life as a Spy
description: In late August 1945, with the work of the Office of Strategic Services, the United States wartime intelligence agency, winding down, Col. John Coughlin, commander of the O.S.S. detachment in Ceylon, called a field agent named Jane Foster to his bungalow. Foster assumed she was in trouble, since she usually was. (She liked to say she was the organizations most-threatened-with-court-martial person.) Instead Coughlin poured her a drink and asked if she would volunteer to report on the postwar transition in Java. Wouldnt she! Foster, who spoke Malay and had lived in Batavia, had already told a friend about her confidential plan to infiltrate a small Indonesian island and emerge as the Great White Queen of Bali. The friend half-believed her. With Foster, she recalled, you could never tell.

title: A Woman Goes Missing in Seoul
description: Please Look After Mom, by the South Korean writer Kyung-sook Shin, opens with a family in disarray. Mom is missing, separated from Father by the closing doors of a subway car in a busy train station in Seoul. A day, a week, then nearly a month goes by. Moms husband and adult children are not only worried, but crippled with guilt and regret, fumbling in confusion, as if they had all injured a part of their brains. Are you punishing me? each privately wonders.

title: Katherine Kempner, Robert Miller
description: Katherine Lauren Kempner and Robert Bennett Miller were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Lawrence M. Schuval officiated at the Smith & Wollensky restaurant in Miami Beach.

title: Jessica May, Carl Gold
description: Dr. Jessica Lynn May and Carl Aaron Gold were married Saturday evening in Scottsdale, Ariz. Rabbi Dennis Eisner officiated at the Four Seasons Resort Scottsdale at Troon North.

title: Jillian Borman, Jason Hochfelder
description: Dr. Jillian Leigh Borman and Dr. Jason Patrick Hochfelder were married Saturday evening at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Susie Heneson Moskowitz performed the ceremony.

title: Emily Israel and James Pluhar
description: Dr. Emily Frelinghuysen Israel and James Andrew Pluhar were married Saturday evening at the Harold Pratt House and Peterson Hall, an event space in New York. The Rev. Mark Bozzuti-Jones, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Joanna Baker, Peter de Neufville
description: Joanna Johnson Baker, the daughter of Marianna Johnson Baker of New York and the late George F. Baker III, was married Saturday evening to Peter Bayon de Neufville, a son of John P. de Neufville of Mendham, N.J., and the late Suzanne Bayon de Neufville. The Rev. Kirkland H. Russell Jr., an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at St. Johns Anglican Church on Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

title: Going Green for Spring With Chard
description: Chard is a leafy green vegetable thats hearty enough to withstand the cold of a chilly spring, but more delicate in flavor than kale and collards, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Michele Siegel, Joshua Rosenblum
description: Michele Terry Siegel and Joshua Daniel Rosenblum are to be married Sunday evening at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York. Rabbi William M. Plevan is to officiate.

title: Stephanie Miller and Jonathan Peled
description: Stephanie Elena Miller and Dr. Jonathan Uriah-Chaim Peled are to be married Sunday by Rabbi William Berman at Temple Chaverim in Plainview, N.Y.

title: Up Front: Meghan ORourke
description: This week, Meghan ORourke reviews two new books  a poetry collection and a memoir of depression  by the Australian poet Les Murray.

title: Our Predictions for the 2011 Season
description: While Tyler Kepner, who covers baseball for The Times, made his American League picks and National League picks last weekend in his league outlooks, and selected the Boston Red Sox to beat the San Francisco Giants in the World Series, Ben Shpigel, who covers the Yankees, and David Waldstein, who covers the Mets, join him out on the limb today.

title: Inside the List
description: GOING HAWAIIAN: Sarah Vowell hits No. 5 on the hardcover nonfiction list with Unfamiliar Fishes, her wry account of the annexation and Americanization of Hawaii. What other writer would describe the first encounters between Hawaiians and missionaries as like some sort of clunky prequel to Footloose ? Vowell also includes an exegesis of the cheesy 1987 surf flick North Shore, but insists she approaches wave-riding as a purely spectator sport. I do love watching surfers, she said in an e-mail. Im especially entranced by that moment they gather together offshore waiting for a wave. Maybe theyre out there talking trash, but from the sand its the perfect image of camaraderie. In the book I quote a hula scholar friend who calls surfing, like hula, quintessentially Hawaiian. The missionaries thought hula was satanic. They were less offended by surfing. I read one missionary diatribe that predicted it would die out once the Hawaiians became accustomed to being fully clothed.

title: Editors Choice
description: GREAT SOUL: Mahatma Gandhi and His Struggle With India,  by Joseph Lelyveld (Knopf, $28.95.) While Gandhis tenets (a Muslim-Hindu alliance, an end to untouchability) remain largely unfulfilled, it is his role as a social reformer that most interests Lelyveld.

title: Paperback Row
description: A TICKET TO THE CIRCUS: A Memoir,  by Norris Church Mailer (Random House, $15.) The author, who died of cancer in 2010, was a 26-year-old high school art teacher and divorced mother named Barbara Jean Davis when she met Norman Mailer in 1975. With candor and wit, she reflects on her Arkansas upbringing and on becoming Mailers sixth wife: managing his career and family life over three decades (Mailer died in 2007 at 84) while carving out her own niche as a writer.

title: Marie-Adele Sorel and Jeremy Kress
description: Dr. Marie-Adele Sorel and Jeremy Coltan Kress are to be married Sunday by Rabbi Eytan N. Kenter at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

title: Katherine Boone, Joshua Geltzer
description: Katherine Nancy Boone and Joshua Alexander Geltzer were married Saturday evening in an outdoor ceremony at White Oak Plantation in Yulee, Fla. Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner officiated.

title: Paul Kim and Derek Brown
description: Derek Allen Brown and Paul Kang Yoo Kim were married Saturday morning at Meridian Hill Park in Washington. Hayden E. Windrow, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Popcast: Portuguese Fado, Britney Spears and More
description: This week: Larry Rohter talks to Ben Ratliff about the new wave of Fado music from Portugal; Jon Caramanica on Britney Spearss new album Femme Fatale; and Nate Chinen on jazz trumpeter Ambrose Akinmusire.A new wave of old-style Portuguese music; a new album from Britney Spears (mp3)

title: TimesCast | Libyan Envoy in London
description: April 1, 2011 - Mohammed Ismail, a senior aide to Seif al-Islam, one of Colonel Qaddafi's sons, held secret talks in London with British authorities.

title: Way Back in Time With Two Friends Who Go Way Back
description: IN the 15 or so years it took them to get from Winston-Salem to Hollywood, Danny McBride and David Gordon Green found ways to pass the time. Since meeting as undergraduates at the North Carolina School of the Arts, Mr. McBride, who plays the mullet-haired, showboating pitcher Kenny Powers on HBOs Eastbound & Down, and Mr. Green, the director whose films include the stoner comedy Pineapple Express, have established a tradition of brainstorming preposterous titles for hypothetical film and television projects, then inventing premises to fit those titles.

title: The Definitive Slang Dictionary
description: Back in 1937, when Eric Partridges groundbreaking Dictionary of Slang and Unconventional English was first published, The New York Times Book Review ran a glowing notice. The lost words of the language have finally come to roost, it began. The unmentionables are mentioned and carefully placed in proper alphabetical form.

title: On the Street | Springtime Fox Fur Scarf
description: Out of the past comes the springtime fox fur scarf, which glamorized fashion from 1910 to 1950, when the show was stolen by the mink stole.

title: What Comes Next in the Battle for NYSE
description: Nasdaq OMXs not-so surprising proposal to acquire NYSE Euronext sets off an intricate series of decisions that the NYSE Euronext board must make in the coming weeks.

title: Family Lines Meet in a Cube
description: IF you ask a young man to name a possession he is extraordinarily fond of, you will be surprised how often the answer is something that belonged to his grandfather: a gold watch, a fur-felt fedora, a dresser box for collar stays.

title: Oregon Frontier, From Under a Bonnet
description: IN 1845 a new trail across the wilds of Oregon was blazed by a wagon train under the guidance of one Stephen Hall Meek. Or to put that another way, in 1845 desperate settlers followed a notorious mountain man on a journey marked by death, confusion and varying degrees of upheaval. The route came to be known as the Meek Cutoff (a k a shortcut), but a new film by Kelly Reichardt inspired by the events joins the travelers midjourney, when the outcome remains in terrible doubt.

title: Big Deal | A Prized Piece of Art for a Buyer to Call Home
description: To hear Robert Marc, the luxury eyewear designer whose sunglasses are worn by a host of celebrities, talk about his apartment at 165 Charles Street, its a little hard to understand why he is selling. He bought the three-bedroom on the 10th floor of the 16-story Richard Meier tower five years ago for $7.32 million. Now he is listing it with John Burger of Brown Harris Stevens for $7.95 million.

title: A Drink With a Kick, but No Alcohol
description: More than a dozen competing trays of chili were laid out, smackdown style, at last weekends Grillin on the Bay event in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. To drink with their bottomless bowls, many folks snagged a pint cup of beer. But others crossed over to the City Lasses table, which featured its new drink, the switzel.

title: Who is Gabriel Osmonde? A French Literary Mystery is Solved
description: PARIS  Andrei Makine, one of Frances most celebrated novelists, whose books, including Dreams of My Russian Summers, have been translated into English, revealed this week that he has published four novels under the name Gabriel Osmonde, the newspaper Figaro reported.

title: Whos Got the Best April Fools Pranks?
description: Ah, its April Fools Day. Youd think the Web world would run out of clever ideas for pranks after all these years, but no such worries; the 2011 assortment is hilarious.

title: Microsofts Antitrust Volley and Googles Way Forward
description: Business and law are pragmatic vocations. So where a company stands on some principle typically hinges on the circumstances in which it sits.
