Just ask Microsoft, long the worlds No. 1 antitrust defendant, that on Thursday filed a formal antitrust complaint in Europe against Google, as we reported.

title: Downsizing Made Easy: Increase Size, Power and Space
description: RISING fuel prices and earthly calamities have many citizens donning Jimmy Carters metaphorical cardigan, facing up to energy conservation as they rarely have since the 1970s.

title: In Every Way, This Buick Is a Family Car
description: WHEN Joseph La Vache, known to everyone as Lenny, bought a Buick Wildcat coupe in 1963, he made a promise to his bride-to-be, Maria.

title: The K-Car as a Limousine? Thats a Stretch
description: WHAT WERE THEY? 1983-86 Chrysler Executive Sedan and Limousine.

title: Napolitano Defends Administration on Border Enforcement
description: Obama administration officials, embattled on all sides on immigration, are pushing back to defend their record on border enforcement and deportations of illegal immigrants.

title: Patrice Covington and Elijah Bland
description: WHEN Patrice Covington tells people she found her husband on Craigslist, she is quick to clarify that it was on Gigs and not Men Seeking Women.

title: Inflation and Reality
description: The Off the Charts column this week takes a look at inflation and tries to adjust the reports by including home prices. Existing indexes estimate the housing costs for homeowners by measuring the rental value of their homes, not their prices.

title: Look of The Moment | Katie Holmes
description: The Look: Polished Prairie  a chic spin on the new homespun trend.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Super-Hero Central
description: No. 1 on our hardcover list this week is Justice League of America: Dark Times, written by James Robinson and illustrated by Mark Bagley. It features a matchup between two teams of costumed heroes: the Justice League and the Justice Society of America. This adventure has links to Brightest Day, the latest event story from DC Comics about 12 resurrected heroes and villains. One of those heroes, Jade, has ties to both teams. She is the daughter of the Golden Age Green Lantern, one of the founders of the Justice Society, the first comic-book super-team who have had adventures since 1940. Jade was also the significant other of a modern day Green Lantern (Kyle Rayner), a former member of the Justice League.

title: Protesters Rally Into Night in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Hundreds of demonstrators calling for reform rallied late into the evening in the Jordanian capital on Friday, a week after riot police officers and government supporters violently broke up a rally and a protest camp, leaving one man dead and scores injured.

title: Calorie-Counting Rule to Leave Out Movie Theaters
description: Movie theaters dont hesitate to wag a stern finger at their patrons: Shhh! Turn off your cellphone. Dont talk during the movie.

title: Pole Dancing With a Big Difference: The Clothes Stay
description: The link was sent to me last week by my friend Rachel, a civil liberties lawyer. I clicked on it and found a local TV news report.

title: The Battle Over the Budget Continues
description: Jennifer Steinhauer, a Times reporter covering Capitol Hill, discussed whether both political parties can deliver the votes to finalize a deal and avert a government shutdown a week from Friday.

title: Video: Budget Battles on Capitol Hill
description: Read Jennifer Steinhauers related story, As Budget Talks Continue, Hard-Liners Get Support From Tea Party, published in Fridays Times.

title: Diane Gives a Party
description: SHANGHAI  Last December, the American fashion designer Diane vonFurstenberg promised to give an outrageous Red Ball in China thisyear, just ahead of her retrospective art and fashion show, Journey ofa Dress, which opens this Saturday at Pace Gallery in Beijing.

title: 2 Rig Firm Workers Decline To Appear at Oil Spill Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Two employees of Transocean are refusing to appear before a federal panel investigating last years Deepwater Horizon blowout and oil spill, federal officials and lawyers for the company and its employees said on Friday.

title: The Dulpickles and Nigmenogs of 1699
description: In this weeks Book Review, I consider the most recent  and most ambitious  effort to compile a dictionary of English-language slang. But such efforts have been underway for centuries. Several months ago, Oxford Universitys Bodleian Library republished the earliest known foray: The First English Dictionary of Slang, 1699, with an introduction by John Simpson, chief editor of the Oxford English Dictionary. (To see a facsimile of the original edition, please click here.)

title: Material Man
description: The fashion designer Reed Krakoff tends to wear his interests in art, architecture and design on his sleeve. His love for the work of Le Corbusier, for example, finds direct translation in his recent collections. Here, Krakoff gives T a list of the books and films that have lately caught his eye.

title: Dolce and Gabbana Tax Case Is Dismissed by Judge in Italy
description: MILAN  A judge ruled Friday that two fashion designers, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana, would not have to stand trial for tax evasion and fraud.

title: A Proper Name for a Wayward Cobra
description: Sneaky. Skippy. Slinky. Runaway Sue. SSSSSSSybil. Asperanza the Asp. Heidi (get it?). Tahrir  for an Egyptian who clearly values her liberty.

title: Disparities: Illness More Prevalent Among Older Gay Adults
description: Older lesbian, gay and bisexual adults in California are more likely to suffer from chronic physical and mental health problems than their heterosexual counterparts, a new analysis has found. They also are less likely to have live-in partners or adult children who can help care for them.

title: Strongman and Stability Guide Kazakhs in Vote
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  On the eve of a presidential election in this oil-rich Central Asian nation, students and faculty at the Kazakh University of the Arts filed into an auditorium for a meeting that was, according to fliers posted in the hallways, strictly mandatory!!!

title: Morgan Stanleys Latest Setback
description: Morgan Stanleys turnaround story has encountered another setback.

title: The Royal Wedding
description: The Times' Christine Haughney talks with British expatriates and New Yorkers about the upcoming royal wedding.

title: Kazakhs Schedule a Rare Presidential Vote
description: During a season of collapsing authoritarian regimes, Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, Kazakhstans 70-year-old president, stands as testament to the forces protecting the strongmen of the former Soviet states.

title: A Royal Wedding? Shes Been There
description: IT is dreadful, declared India Hicks, the model and former Top Design host, in a supremely proper English accent that made the phrase a symphony of syllables. She was sitting in a room at the Mark hotel on the Upper East Side, gazing out her window at rain squalls so thick they disguised the adjacent maze of apartment buildings.

title: A Long, Slow Slog Back to Normal
description: While the 216,000 net jobs that the economy added last month were certainly welcome, the growth wasnt nearly fast enough to get the country back on the path to full employment anytime soon.

title: Slow Compounding
description: American Express has a full-page ad in todays Times offering a savings account yielding 1.15 percent.

title: State Police Investigating E-Mail to Lawmakers
description: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | ALBANY  The State Police are investigating a threatening e-mail sent to several state lawmakers on Friday that promised violent attacks on state officials, schoolchildren and journalists.

title: New York Theater Workshop Announces Two More Productions for 2011-12 Season
description: Off Broadways New York Theater Workshop on Friday announced two additional productions for its 2011-12 season: a play about a Palestinian family preparing for a wedding in the politically volatile West Bank, and a modern retelling of Homers Illiad that will feature, on alternating nights, the Tony Award winners Denis OHare (Take Me Out) and Stephen Spinella (Angels in America) as the pieces sole actor.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Ivory Coast, Libya and Egypt.

title: In Hong Kong, in Pursuit of the Perfect Dress
description: CHEONGSAMS have long captivated me.

title: Restaurant Review: Mesob, in Rome
description: In a spruced-up former garage on a bleak section of the Via Prenestina in Rome, diners use injera, the traditional Ethiopian sourdough bread, to scoop up richly spiced stews. Is it an atypical Roman meal? Yes and no.

title: On the Island of Jersey, Fortifications Turned Lodging
description: ITS in the details, said Dave Bull, the caretaker of a former military bunker on the island of Jersey in the English Channel. He heaved open a cast-iron door and ran a hand over its bolts and heavy wrench-like handle. This was all built by slave labor, by prisoners the Nazis marched here from Europe.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Seven in Paris
description: BASICS

title: Four Paris Restaurants Worth a Metro Ride
description: FOUR years ago, writing in these pages about Paris restaurants, I mentioned one called Au Boeuf Couronn, called it terrific and added that traveling to its location in the 19th Arrondissement was the rough equivalent of going deep into Brooklyn.

title: Why We Travel
description: IN the bungling and bellicosity that constitute the back and forth of history, worsened by natural disasters and unprovoked cruelty, humble citizens pay the highest price. To be a traveler in such circumstances can be inconvenient at best, fatal at worst. But if the traveler manages to breeze past such unpleasantness on tiny feet, he or she is able to return home to report: I was there. I saw it all. The travelers boast, sometimes couched as a complaint, is that of having been an eyewitness, and invariably this experience  shocking though it may seem at the time  is an enrichment, even a blessing, one of the life-altering trophies of the road.

title: Riverside Lynchburg, Va., Builds on Its History
description: Developers have preserved the historic feel of the downtown area, as new loft apartments, art studios, restaurants and a tearoom now fill the hulking warehouses and factories along the banks of the James River.

title: On an Island East of Bali, a Backpackers Hideaway Goes Upscale
description: THE blaze of white sand licked by the surf was dotted one recent sunlit afternoon with fishing boats and their local owners, a pack of bored men in flip-flops who each kept one eye on their hand of cards and the other on the pale tourist cargo streaming from the docked speedboat onto the main road of the island of Gili Trawangan, east of Bali, in search of beach, beer and bungalow.

title: Traveling When Some Say Stay Home
description: Throughout history, the traveler has been forced to recognize that the fact of leaving home means encountering uncertainty.

title: Glorious Gili Trawangan
description: Luxury villas spring up on an island once more famous for its magic mushrooms.

title: Letters: Seeing Asia in Detail
description: Seeing Asia in Detail

title: Good Value in Northeast Paris
description: Mark Bittman explores dining alternatives in far-flung neighborhoods.

title: College Plans You Thought Were Safe
description: The predicament of state workers has drawn a great deal of attention recently, and rightly so. The health of their pension plans and their right to organize are fundamental issues.

title: The House Next Door
description: Paul Graziano had long admired the house next door in Flushing, Queens. He bought it and its eclectic contents and is now restoring it.

title: The Mars Connection
description: Jeffrey Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, writes from New Mexico, where he is measuring sand particle sizes, layer thicknesses and angles to address questions about volcanoes and rock patterns on Mars.

title: Concerning St. Jeter
description: Sam Andersons Riff column this week addresses the canonization of the New York Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter in five parts, without disparaging ol flat-top. Instead, it turns a spotlight on the news media and on the Yankees fans who have built him up to mythic proportions without any help from Jeter, who has always behaved as a baseball player, first and only. The 459-word final part is as creative as anything I have read since Ive been here.

title: A Queens Home Wallpapered With Memories
description: FOR 86 years the white colonial with the black trim on 32nd Avenue near 146th Street in Flushing, Queens, was known as the Bruce house. The two-story house had been built in 1923 by Thomas Atkinson, a master plasterer, and his son-in-law, John Bruce, a carpenter. Johns son, John David, known universally as Bud, moved in with his parents as a child of 9.

title: For 9/11 Museum, Dispute Over Victims Remains
description: In one of the haunting legacies of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center, the remains of 1,123 of the victims, 41 percent of the total, have not been identified, leaving many of their relatives yearning for closure. At the same time, nearly 10 years later, 9,041 pieces of human remains  mainly bone fragments but also tissue that has been dehydrated for preservation  are still being sorted through by the citys medical examiner for DNA, though the last time a connection was made was in 2009.

title: Councilwomans Newest Constituent
description: On Monday and Tuesday, Jessica Lappin, a member of the City Council, was making last-minute calls urging that the Albany budget deal would, indeed, provide the money to keep 105 senior centers in New York open.

title: When the Fortunate Can Help Those Less So
description: Theres certainly been a lot written about the troubled finances in many states. Programs that help the needy are among those at risk. In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about a new book Give Smart that examines ways that wealthy philanthropists can help when governments no longer can.

title: An Entreaty to Readers: Your Stories
description: In this weekends Travel section, author Paul Theroux writes about traveling to unconventional places, and to conventional places at unconventional times:

title: The Caucus Click: Mitt Romney in North Las Vegas, Nev.
Dear FloFab: A Customer Is Using My Restaurant As Her Office
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: African Leaders Pressure President of Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwes neighbors, long accused of being soft on its autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, are putting an unusual amount of public pressure on him to halt the political violence, intimidation and arrests that have surged since his party began agitating for elections in recent months.

title: How Bad Does a Song Have to Be Until Its Good?
description: Its Friday. Friday. Fun, fun, fun, fun.

title: Satellite Operators May Not Renew YES and SNY
description: The Mets and Yankees networks are in parallel battles with satellite operators.

title: This Weekend, Let the Rider Beware
description: Updated, April 3 | There are 24 subway lines in the city, counting shuttle trains. This weekend, 14 of them will be altering their regular routes in some way for repairs: the 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, A, C, D, F, G, J, Q and the Rockaway Park shuttle. Most notably, there will be no Q from Atlantic Avenue to 57th Street from midnight to early morning. Mta.info has the full picture.

title: If Home Prices Counted in Inflation
description: AFEW years ago, the Federal Reserve remained complacent about inflation even as a housing bubble inflated. The Fed did not take the kind of action that would have seemed reasonable if it had been alarmed by rising prices.

title: March Political Best Sellers
description: Revolt! by Dick Morris and Eileen McGann makes its debut at No. 4 on the political best-sellers list. The husband and wife team advises that Republicans use their power to force President Obama to accept their terms of debate and to insure that he doesnt get re-elected in 2012.

title: Pitt Criticizes Sokols Lubrizol Trades
description: Harvey Pitt, a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, weighs in on David L. Sokols sudden resignation from Berkshire Hathaway and the quick criticism of Mr. Sokols investments in Lubrizol, a Berkshire target. On CNBC, Mr. Pitt called Mr. Sokols actions terrible and said his initial assessment was that the investments were not legal. He also criticized what he described as a public relations campaign to play down the seriousness of the allegations.

title: Hot Pants
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#651", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Books Podcast and Video: Henry Kissinger
description: This week: A special conversation with Henry Kissinger about Otto von Bismarck; the linguist Ben Zimmer on a new dictionary of slang; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news.

title: New Questions About Prepaid 529 Plans
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I review the curious case of the College Illinois prepaid 529 college savings plan.

title: For Japanese Coast, Seawalls Provided a False Sense of Security
description: So unshakeable was one towns faith in its seawall that some residents rushed toward it after the earthquake struck on March 11.

title: With Sale, Orlando Station to Leave PBS
description: 6:25 p.m. | Updated The primary public television station in Orlando, Fla., WMFE-TV, said Friday that the station was being sold to an undisclosed buyer, in a sign of the continuing financial strains in public broadcasting.

title: Facebook Fires Employee for Insider Trading
description: 4:53 p.m. | Updated  Adding comment from Michael Brown and revisions throughout.

title: April Fool: From the Subtle to the Outrageous
description: The auto-themed April Fools Day pranks ranged from subtle to outrageous, with some actually capable of taking in the unwary or coffee-deprived. Perhaps the most elaborate was the convertible Volt from Road & Track, but others are scattered around the blogosphere. Heres a summary:

title: Dont Just Throw Him Crumbs
description: BRIDEGROOMS often joke that in their own weddings their roles are blissfully simple: show up on time, in freshly pressed tuxedos. Please.

title: Manning Marable, African-American Studies Scholar, Has Died at 60
description: Manning Marable, the author of a long-awaited new biography of Malcolm X to be published Monday and director of the Institute for Research in African American Studies at Columbia University, died Friday at the age of 60, his wife, Leith Mullings, has confirmed.

title: Finding an Original Heroine
description: FOR a director who made his name with the literary adaptations Pride and Prejudice and Atonement, Joe Wright has a surprising view of the essence of cinema. Drama can be presented onstage, and beautiful pictures can be presented in a gallery, but really action is pure cinema, Mr. Wright said on the phone recently.

title: A Place for Everything
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#279", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Fighting Continues in Libya
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces stormed the western rebel outpost of Misrata with tanks and artillery on Friday, a Libyan rebel spokesman said, while insurgents marshaled defenses in their eastern heartland.

title: TimesCast | April 1, 2011
description: At least 12 people are killed at a U.N. compound in Afghanistan; Syria's regime targets social media in an effort to quell dissent; and competing protests divide Yemen's capital.

title: Big Deal | The White Gloves Are Off
description: Everyone loves a good rivalry, and in this case the competition has pitted one fancy New York City address against another: The mighty 15 Central Park West, a relatively new architectural star, and the Plaza Hotel Residences, which come with the white-glove cachet of being located at the century-old Plaza.

title: Idol Attracts 22 Million Viewers
description: Two finalists were eliminated from American Idol on Thursday, Naima Adedapo and Thia Megia, as a results episode of the Fox reality show attracted an impressive 22 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The audience for Idol lifted Fox far ahead of its network rivals on the night and provided a boost to Foxs hidden-camera special with Howie Mandel, Mobbed, which delivered a solid 10.8 million viewers at 9 p.m. following Idol. ABCs Greys Anatomy (12.7 million) edged past CBSs CSI (12.5 million) to lead that time slot, but CBS ranked second for the night over all, earning its best ratings at 10 with The Mentalist (13.9 million) and strong results at 8 and 8:30 for the sitcoms The Big Bang Theory (11.7 million) and Rules of Engagement (8.2 million). ABC was third as 6.3 million tuned in to Wipeout at 8 and 7.6 million at 10 for Private Practice. NBC placed a very distant fourth with mostly repeats of its comedy line-up. On Bravo on Wednesday, the eighth season finale of Top Chef delivered 2.8 million viewers, slightly more than the audience who watched the series prior season conclusion (2.7 million).

title: Ilana Schachter and John Feuerstein
description: Ilana Lazar Schachter and John Meyer Feuerstein are to be married Sunday in Brooklyn. Rabbi Serge A. Lippe is to officiate at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in Brooklyn.

title: Kristen Carey, Thomas Rock
description: Dr. Kristen Nicole Carey and Dr. Thomas Andrew Rock were married Saturday afternoon at the Cathedral Basilica of SS. Peter and Paul in Philadelphia. The Rev. F. G. Hank Hilton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Michele Molochkovsky, Michael Cohen
description: Michele Molochkovsky and Michael Craig Cohen were married Saturday night by Rabbi Marvin Antosofsky at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.

title: Janice Chyou, Matthew Tomey
description: Dr. Janice Yu-Hsin Chyou and Dr. Matthew Ian Tomey are to be married Sunday by Catherine L. Bordeau, of the Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Kristin Fisher and Walker Forehand
description: Kristin Anne Fisher, a daughter of Dr. Anna L. Fisher and Dr. William F. Fisher, both of Houston, was married Saturday to Walker Harrison Forehand, the son of Margaret Peters Stalnaker of White Stone, Va., and Judge V. Thomas Forehand Jr. of Chesapeake, Va. The Rev. James H. Burch of the Catholic Diocese of One Spirit performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy City in Washington.

title: Naomi Schneider, Adam Cohen
description: Naomi Susan Schneider and Adam Philip Cohen are to be married Sunday evening at Marina del Rey, a catering hall in Throgs Neck, the Bronx. Rabbi Yaacov Lerner is to lead the ceremony.

title: Hanne Anderson and Jack Vaughn Jr.
description: Hanne Lynn Anderson and Jack Hood Vaughn Jr. were married Saturday evening at the Housing Works Bookstore Cafe in New York. Max Cannon, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: A Thinking Womans Detective
description: Sergio Leone gave cinema the spaghetti western, but there isnt yet an equivalent term for Scandinavian riffs on the classic hard-boiled detective yarn. The Killing, a fantastic new AMC adaptation of a popular Danish television series, certainly qualifies as a smorgasbord thriller. Its unnerving how well the Nordic sensibility fits a genre that for a long time seemed indisputably and inimitably violent and American, particularly given that Sweden, Norway and Denmark have homicide rates that suggest that they have more mystery writers per capita than murders.

title: All in the Family
description: Mary Jane La Vache of Brooklyn is now driving the 1963 Buick Wildcat her father, Joseph, owned when she was little.

title: Will Jobs Come Back By the Time Obama Faces Voters?
description: As the unemployment rate ticks down  to 8.8 percent as of Friday morning  the 2012 clock on the wall of President Obamas new campaign headquarters will soon start getting louder and louder.

title: In the Mets Tradition, a Few Encouraging Words
description: Mets fans, I believe, are often misportrayed as hand-wringing pessimists who have been beaten down by years of incompetence to always expect the worst.

title: Shutdown Watch: Seven Days Out
description: With seven days left until the federal governments spending authority runs out, there appeared to be plenty of cautious optimism. Lawmakers headed home Friday and the House speaker, John A. Boehner, said he would not be in Washington over the weekend to continue negotiations. But both sides appeared less eager to call the other out.

title: Stargazing
description: Since the jewels designed by Diane Kordas, based in London, began appearing on influential people across the pond (Madonna was her first client; a Rolling Stone is reportedly a fan), British stores like Dover Street Market and Matches cant keep the delicate pieces in stock. Luckily, theyre now available stateside as well. This black gold and diamond ring, inspired by a shooting star, is about $2,200 at netaporter.com.

title: Shiites in Iraq Support Bahrains Protesters
description: BAGHDAD  The violent suppression of the uprising in Bahrain has become a Shiite rallying cry in Iraq, where the American war overturned a Sunni-dominated power structure much like the one in place in Bahrain.

title: Romney Talks Economy in Nevada
description: NORTH LAS VEGAS, Nev.  Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts hailed the latest unemployment numbers as good news, but he said in an appearance here Friday that the nations economic picture is far gloomier than the 8.8 percent jobless rate would suggest.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Ivory Coast, Libya and Egypt.

title: Obama Talks Up Clean-Energy Vehicles
description: LANDOVER, Md.  President Obama on Friday joined with U.P.S., FedEx and several other major companies whose vehicles are familiar sights on Americas roadways to promote a new administration initiative for encouraging businesses to build commercial fleets that burn less gasoline and diesel fuel.

title: Holding Syria Together
description: My cigarette days are well over but the name Latakia still brings up physical memories of Turkish tobacco. The Syrian port city was part of the Ottoman empire, is very near the Turkish border, and has a long connection with the tobacco trade. Its in the news now for protests against the government of Bashar al-Assad. Latakia is particularly interesting because the town and province are the heartland of the Alawites, a Shiite sect that produced the ruling Assad family and much of the current governing elite. (In the wake of the Ottoman collapse in the early 20th century, there was an on-again-off-again Alawite state based in and around Latakia until 1944, when it integrated with Syria.)

title: All the Time in the World
description: Wakefield

title: Bribery and the Gathering Storm Over Compliance
description: While insider trading cases have been attracting much of the financial headlines, there is another issue that will have a much greater effect on corporate bottom lines: bribery.

title: Tea Party Express Opens 2012 Campaign Against Obama
description: The Tea Party Express became the first organization to buy national advertising to oppose the re-election of President Obama, filing a report on Friday with the Federal Election Commission disclosing more than $40,000 in ad buys on Fox News Channel and Fox Business Network. The group, which became the largest independent backer of Tea Party candidates during last years election, also aired an ad opposing Obama in March on local television in Madison, Wis.

title: Yankees Burnett Faces a New Set of Expectations
description: On April 2, 2001, the Florida Marlins were opening their season against the Philadelphia Phillies with a roster full of emerging stars, including a rotation with two potential aces in A.J. Burnett and Brad Penny, and a sense of hope missing since their championship run of 1997.

title: Revisiting the Vanishing Urban Factory
description: A new exhibition at the Skyscraper Museum in Battery Park City looks at an array of groundbreaking factory buildings.

title: Accel Raises $1.3 Billion in Funds for China
description: Accel Partners has closed two new funds for China, totaling $1.3 billion, the company said on Friday.

title: The Free World
description: JULY

title: Inaugural Sentence of the Month Bonanza Throwdown
description: As promised, the time has come for Shamblandersons First Inaugural Sentence of the Month Bonanza Throwdown  the ultimate contest to determine, once and for all, the very best sentence I read in all of March 2011. (Well: the best sentence I read that would fit into my tiny little Twitter box.)

title: Rude and Crude Behavior Stains Italian Parliament
description: ROME  The Italian Parliament has long been a three-ring circus, but analysts here say that the events of the past few days have plunged the country into its worst institutional crisis in decades.

title: Now Online | Spring Design 2011
description: The spring issue of T Design celebrates the lived-in look, starting with the cover story, Family Style, in which a young family shakes up a grand English manor house. A Los Angeles garden designer sows the seeds of her fertile imagination in Growth Industry, and in A Place for Everything, a production designer shows us a few thousand of his favorite things. Plus, the up-and-coming designers Big-Game, Todd Bracher and Courtney Applebaum; Gerhard Steidls one-publisher town; and the Edible Selby at the Dock Kitchen. See more from the issue

title: Surviving a Gut Renovation
description: Victoria Robinson and Nicole Eisenman spent more than $200,000 on a gut renovation that included opening up the warren of tiny rooms to create an inviting layout.

title: Jazz Evangelists Borrow Some of Stevie Wonders Cool
description: It says a lot about SFJazz, the San Francisco-based organization, that its house band would make a project out of the music of Stevie Wonder. Not that jazz musicians havent long since gotten to Stevie Wonder as material: plenty have, from tentative, cred-building, bell-bottomed experiments by Ella Fitzgerald and Woody Herman, to newer and deeper versions of his songs by Marcus Strickland and Vijay Iyer. Its that Mr. Wonders music is generally not part of an official representation of jazz, the kind of thing put forth by a performing-arts institution like SFJazz.

title: Hemingways Women
description: To the Editor:

title: The Information
description: To the Editor:

title: No Easy Answers
description: To the Editor:

title: Worth Remembering
description: To the Editor:

title: What a Workout
description: I have a cordial relationship with my neighbor. Shes single with two young children, so she has her hands full; Im a married woman with no children yet. Lately, every time she sees me, she comments about how often I go to the gym, and how infrequently she does. I feel as if shes judging me. No matter what I say, she brings the conversation back to my gym-going. How can I change this?

title: U.S. Rule Aimed at Letting Big Tuna Off the Hook
Mad Men Creator Says 7 Seasons Will Be Enough
description: Matthew Weiner, the creator of AMCs Mad Men, now knows how his beloved show will end.

title: 1921 and All That
description: Every once in a while I get comments and correspondence indicating that the right has found an unlikely economic hero: Warren Harding. The recovery from the 1920-21 recession supposedly demonstrates that deflation and hands-off monetary policy is the way to go.

title: Another Great Way to Cook Fish
description: In this weeks Eat (another matrix  I just love these and am planning to do one a month), I offer 12 ways to cook white fish fillets: three ways each to broil, saut, roast and poach.

title: In-Car Cameras Protect Teenage Drivers, Study Finds
description: Researchers have found an effective way to curb distracted driving among teenagers: capture video of them behind the wheel.

title: Baselworld 2011 | Adventureland
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#385", 592, 470, true, chameleonData);

title: 47 Years Later, a Chance for a Rare Endplay
description: The Whitehead Womens Pairs was won by Marjorie Michelin of Laguna Woods, Calif., and Diana Schuld of Glen Head, N.Y., at the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., last month.

title: A Day of Lacrosse at the Meadowlands
description: There was an initial concern when the 2011 Konica Minolta Big City Classic schedule came out last year that there would be overlap between this Sundays college lacrosse triple-header at New Meadowlands Stadium and this weekends college basketball Final Four.

title: Not the Owner, Prosecutors Say, but Still Trying to Sell
description: It might have seemed like a good deal: three adjacent commercial buildings in Midtown Manhattan for sale for $6.5 million. The sellers agent, prosecutors said, was only too happy to accept a down payment of $1.66 million.

title: 2011 BMW X3
description: BMW gives its once-groundbreaking compact luxury S.U.V. a redesign.

title: When DeMille Parted the Red Sea
description: CECIL B. DeMILLE would probably have approved of the concept behind Paramount Home Entertainments 55th anniversary gift set edition of The Ten Commandments, an appropriately colossal undertaking that includes three Blu-ray discs and three standard DVDs, a commemorative book, reproductions of the original program and assorted documents and costume sketches. Its all packaged inside a dictionary-size box with a lenticular 3-D image of the Red Sea on the front; when the sea is parted on a built-in hinge, a plastic reproduction of DeMilles sacred tablets rises majestically into view.

title: N.C.A.A. Needs More Control Over the Bowl System
description: As fans gather in Houston this weekend to celebrate college basketballs finest hour, college football is reeling from the aftershocks of a scandal involving the Fiesta Bowl, which has renewed questions about who should control big-time postseason football.

title: A Woman Goes Crazy: An Early Version
description: Opera is madness. We love it because we love watching women fall apart mentally and physically because of the tension between female singers, who must be in total control, and their female characters, who keep losing control.

title: Mango-Rose Water Lassi
description: 2 cups diced ripe mango

title: For Everything There Is a Season, Even Mangoes
description: IN spring, its so easy to become wrapped up trolling the farmers market for the first skinny blades of rhubarb or pungent ramps, that you can forget there is an entire world out there, where seasons can differ from ours. In warmer climates, tasty things are ripening, just waiting to be called lunch.

title: Stomach-Churning Date in Love Life Full of Bumps
description: Its not clear in Mike Birbiglias My Girlfriends Boyfriend whether Mr. Birbiglia is still leaping out of hotel windows while sleepwalking. But it is clear that hes still ridiculously enjoyable to listen to.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 1
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Glorifying the Chickpea
description: At the Hummus Bar, which opened in January on Washington Street in Hoboken,the chickpea gets both classic and creative treatments. The shops smooth and creamy hummus, with a good dose of garlic,is served in a multitude of platters, some with unusual twists.

title: Where First-Timers Feel Like Regulars
description: IN many ways, Gelone is the ideal neighborhood restaurant  an unassuming place where the fare is inexpensive enough that you can eat out once a week or more, the portions plentiful enough to send you home groaning, the staff efficient and friendly enough to make you feel like a regular on your first visit.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, April 1
description: More Photographs

title: Kentucky Freshman Is Student of the Game
description: HOUSTON  While the Kentucky freshman Brandon Knight has stood out because of his play in March, his on-court ability is only the public side to him. The other side is erudite.

title: Is a Pesticide Harming All Those Bees?
description: For several years, Tom Theobald, a beekeeper in Boulder, Colo., has been trying to check out his suspicions that a relatively new class of pesticides has been interfering with the normal breeding and development of his stock.

title: Culinary Neighbors, Mixed
description: The six-month-old food court in the upper level of the H Plaza mall in Great Neck is anchored by two adjacent stalls owned by Daniel Kim.

title: The Onion Uses HTML5 in New iPad App
description: The satirical Onion newspaper has recently struggled with the same problems as other less-jocular print news outlets in America: a dwindling print readership and evaporating local advertising.

title: Peruvian Specialties, With Platters Piled High
description: EL PIO has what many diners are looking for: good food served in enormous portions at very reasonable prices. On the debit side at this seven-month-old Peruvian spot are staccato service and a less-than-stunning dcor.

title: A City Winner Now Competes Against the World
description: One of the high school science fair competitors we featured a few weeks ago was a winner at this weeks New York City Science and Engineering Fair (the one that President Obama visited) and will be one of 15 students representing the city at the finals of the Intel International Science and Engineering Fair in Los Angeles next month.

title: The Senate as a Work in Progress
description: Hello? Hellooooooooo?

title: Old-Fashioned and Cool
description: In 2007, Collinsville was named one of the 10 coolest small towns in America in Arthur Frommers Budget Travel. A share of credit for that distinction belongs to LaSalle Market, which, in its versatility as a cafe, community center, deli and entertainment venue, is very much an old-style general store.

title: A Koran Burning Ignored in the U.S. Was News in Afghanistan and Pakistan
description: As my colleagues Enayat Najafizada and Rod Nordland report, thousands of protesters, enraged by the burning of a Koran at a Florida church, overran a United Nations compound in the Afghan city of Mazar-i-Sharif on Friday, killing at least 12 people.

title: Contemporary French and Consistent Elegance
description: IN 1985, Jean-Louis Gerin took over the Greenwich outpost of his fellow Frenchman Guy Savoy; it has been Restaurant Jean-Louis ever since.

title: Feeling Betrayed, a Furious Tea Party Shakes Its Fist at Both Political Parties
description: Washington

title: Cocktails for Locavores or for Lovers of Honey
description: LOCAL lore suggests the cocktail was invented in Elmsford around the time of the Revolutionary War, when a barmaid would garnish drinks with the tail feathers of roosters from Loyalist chicken coops. And its a fact that Purchase has long been the United States base of the French spirits giant Pernod Ricard (Absolut, Beefeater, Kahla) and that New Rochelle is home to Sidney Frank spirits importer (Jagermeister). But despite Westchester Countys intoxicating background, there had been no alcoholic spirits distilled there since Prohibition. No legal spirits, at least.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 1
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the 100th anniversary of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire, stargazing at the Columbia University Observatory, and a schools fight for space.

title: Vine Ripened
description: Sebastian Errazuriz, the Chilean-born designer and artist, became famous for his Bilbao shelf, in which a real tree branch was attached to a wall to create an organic display unit. In his latest design, the Metamorphosis shelf, Errazuriz really goes out on a limb. The inspiration for the limited-edition Baltic birch plywood shelf (which is hand-carved by the Italian company Horm) came from his grandmothers ivy-covered garden. The dark branches that crawled along the walls were so thick that I would use them as natural shelves for my garden toys, Errazuriz said. Given the $75,000 price tag, however, your spade and trowel had better be by Faberg.

title: The Height of City Manufacturing
description: Im guessing that not even the most hard-bitten or nostalgic New Yorker would want to travel back to the days when the city was choked with waterfront factories and industrial squalor. But The Vertical Urban Factory, a small, intriguing show at the Skyscraper Museum in Battery Park City, makes you wonder what was lost on the way to our greener, more stroller- and bike-friendly city.

title: Odd Textures, Elegant Poses and Maths Golden Mean
description: IN just a few days, Mark Chatterley will drive from his home in Williamston, Mich., to the Clay Art Center in Port Chester, his black Ford extension van filled with larger-than-life ceramic human forms packed, he said, like cordwood. Upon his arrival, Mr. Chatterley, an award-winning sculptor who has exhibited nationally and internationally, will arrange those pieces, along with some smaller wall works, in the centers gallery, where his solo exhibition, Mark Chatterley: Clay Dreams, is set to open on Saturday.

title: At Tulane, No Fireworks Over Airgas Case
description: NEW ORLEANS  If you were expecting fireworks on Friday about the Delaware Supreme Courts decision in the Airgas case at the Tulane Corporate Law Institute, you were sorely disappointed.

title: Clock Ticking on War Powers Resolution
description: President Obamas legal team, having decided he could launch military strikes in Libya last month without congressional authorization, is now weighing a related question: What happens if Congress never votes to approve the operation, but hostilities are still underway in mid-May?

title: As E-Waste Law Kicks In, the Ideal Option Varies
description: As I report in Saturdays Times, a new state law took effect on Friday making electronics manufacturers responsible for offering free recycling programs. Many residents of New York City are likely to continue relying on so-called collection events to get rid of their e-waste, however.

title: Cooking With Mangoes
Chic in Review | Dear Lady Gaga
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: In Unfinished Mozart Opera, Berio Provides the Last Word
description: Luciano Berio, the Italian modernist composer who died in 2003, was exuberantly curious about all kinds of music. Madrigals, symphonies, opera, pop  you never knew what would hook him. He was particularly drawn to unfinished works by masters. Among those was Mozarts incomplete singspiel Zaide. When the European Mozart Foundation asked Berio to compose a reconstruction, he leapt at the chance.

title: Volvo Offers Free Access to Streamed Baseball Games in April
description: No one from Volvo has tossed out the first ball of the 2011 Major League Baseball season, but the car company is making an early pitch.

title: A Farce on the Links, With Hazards in the Clubhouse
description: Golf and sex are the only things you can enjoy without being good at them, observes Pamela, quite a knowing lady, during the opening moments of The Fox on the Fairway.

title: In Candida, Tribute to Womens Strength
description: What kind of Victorian housewife is Candida exactly?

title: The Teachers Who Shaped Our Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Through the Prism of the Human Body
description: The human form is so pervasive in Western art that it is almost impossible to imagine our visual culture without it. The artists who gave us the Parthenon, the Mona Lisa and Guernica lived in vastly different worlds, yet they all channeled the essences of those worlds into their representations of the figure. There are no such epochal examples among the 43 works in Human Connections: Figural Art From the Bruce Museum Collection. But in this small, dense show, the Bruce asks us to think about the figure in art in a novel way. In most museum shows, we look at the subject  a painter or period or motif  through the lens of art history. Here, we are meant to see a range of artworks through the prism of the human body.

title: Denial of Political Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Ballplayers and Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastor Who Burned Koran Demands Retribution
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Before a Koran was burned at his modest church here on March 20, the pastor Terry Jones held a self-styled mock trial of the holy book in which he presided from the pulpit as judge. The prosecutor was a Christian who had converted from Islam. An imam from Dallas defended the Koran.

title: Illegal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mascot Takes Center Stage
description: HOUSTON  On Friday at the Reliant Center, the most popular Butler Bulldog was not Coach Brad Stevens, or forward Matt Howard. The most popular Butler Bulldog was, well, the actual Butler bulldog.

title: Song-and-Dance Man Shows His Two Sides
description: Steven Reker has something of a split personality that has made itself known on the stage. Over the last few years, hes appeared as either a dancer or a musician with a number of artists, including David Byrne, Yoshiko Chuma and Miranda July.

title: Away From His Desk, Up on the Bandstand
description: Wynton Marsalis has been making albums for the last 30 years, since the release of his self-titled Columbia debut. Through all but the first six of those years, he has been not only a celebrated trumpeter and composer but also the public face of Jazz at Lincoln Center, an organization built around his vision, and in many ways still propelled by it.

title: Orchestra and Violin, Matching Wits
description: Too numerous to count are the new works from major composers, involving prominent executants and unfurled with no small fanfare, that subsequently vanish once the final notes of the initial engagement (or engagements) has faded. Not so In Tempus Praesens (In the Present Time), the Russian composer Sofia Gubaidulinas second violin concerto, which has an uncommonly steadfast advocate in Anne-Sophie Mutter, the violinist for whom it was written.

title: Tip of the Week: Using Tech for Your Taxes
description: With just over two weeks left before Tax Day, many people have yet to deal with the annual ritual of preparing tax returns. In an attempt to make it quicker and more efficient, the Internal Revenue Service continues its Free File program for filing federal taxes online. Taxpayers with a gross adjusted income less than $58,000 can use free tax preparation software provided by the agencys partners. People with larger incomes can use the Free File Fillable Forms, which are electronic versions of the traditional paper worksheets. Both options are available here.

title: Reviewing the BMW X3
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich reviews the X3, BMWs compact luxury S.U.V., which in its second generation has become a little less compact. Despite finding the redesigned X3s looks fussy and overconsidered, Mr. Ulrich raves about the cars performance, which he says tops that of every other crossover in its class:

title: Divine Life Force, Please Meet Truth and Existence
description: The lyric soprano Jessica Rivera has become a respected purveyor of contemporary fare, making a splash in (among others) Osvaldo Golijovs Ainadamar and John Adamss Doctor Atomic.

title: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
Erasing the Digital Past
description: THE Internet never forgets.

title: Back to the Futurama and the Ferris Wheel
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.

title: Fox Expands Presence in Hispanic TV
description: Just as Bob Dylan wrote that you dont need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows, you dont need a census taker to know how quickly advertisers, marketers and media companies are responding to the results of the 2010 census.

title: Paperback Business Best Sellers
Why Gerry Ferraro Mattered
description: OH, theyve come to talk to me about my life, she said, laughing. They think Im going to die soon. Im not, you know. Not for a very long time.

title: A Place to Start Again
description: An ex-convict is the superintendent of a West Harlem apartment building that is home to many formerly homeless or incarcerated.

title: Keys to a Castle
description: IN a nod to hue, not heft, Chris Carney christened his 600-pound Treadlok safe the Leprechaun. It is nearly the same color as the tattoo of a four-leaf clover on the knuckle of the middle finger of his right hand  a tattoo his mother threatened to scrub off with steel wool after he got it as a defiant ninth grader.

title: Photo Replay: April 1
description: A look at the day in sports, from dreary Opening Day weather to fun in the sun in Rio de Janeiro.

title: The Workout Begins When Pants Go Missing
description: I HAVE braved wars in the Caucasus, frothing-at-the-mouth nationalists in the Balkans, jihadi radicals and environmental sludge disasters. So I thought I could handle a workout at the Equinox gym near Columbus Circle.

title: In a Broadway Role, Many Returns
description: Lace curtain Irish is an acid-tipped verbal dart when it zips from the mouth of Frances McDormands character, Margie, and hits Tate Donovan, as Mike, in the Broadway play Good People. Margie, bitter and unemployed, is stuck in Southie, a hardscrabble Boston neighborhood. Mike, a doctor, has left both her and the neighborhood behind.

title: A Day to Design Collages
description: The professional portfolio of Richard Meier, 76, the Pritzker Prize-winning architect, includes dozens of geometric designs spanning decades and continents. On Sundays, he contributes to another body of work, using scraps of found paper to create collages, a collection of which will eventually appear in a book. Mr. Meier lives in a duplex on East 72nd Street and owns a house in East Hampton, N.Y. ELISA MALA

title: Talking Work, or Escaping It
description: Since 1994, I Trulli has stood fast on East 27th Street as a destination for the food of Apulia  the heel of the Italian boot  even as the neighborhood has evolved from a nondescript mixed-use area into a hub for creative industries and trendy restaurants. With rustic wood floors, white marble counters, a wood-burning oven, a double-sided fireplace and a backyard patio, the restaurant and attached wine bar draw a mix of local office workers, residents and Italian tourists, said Nicola Marzovilla, the owner. On Wednesday, as Mr. Marzovillas mother, Dora, made fresh orecchiette at the front of the house  a skill that even in Puglia is becoming a lost art, Mr. Marzovilla said  two business partners stopped into their regular haunt for lunch by the fire.

title: For Activists, Tips on Safe Use of Social Media
description: FROM Cairo to Madison, Wis., much has been made about the positive role technology has played in helping galvanize and organize populist movements.

title: The World This Week
description: The art of the defection, a stalemate in Libya and clashes in Syria.

title: Motion and Emotion Discover New Pairings
description: When springtime hits, student showcases are almost as ubiquitous as street fairs. And, yes, they can certainly be as annoying. But the Second Avenue Dance Company crowned its spring concert with a new work by the treasured minimalist choreographer Lucinda Childs that is optimistic, rigorous and, well, just a joy to behold.

title: The Mural Vanishes
description: If you havent seen it yet, take a look at what is the most widely viewed mural in America at the moment.

title: Goldman Gives Blankfein a $5.4 Million Cash Bonus
description: Cash is back.

title: Making Ends Meet
description: Before

title: As UConn Plays On, Once-Prized Recruit Can Only Watch
description: The former University of Connecticut basketball recruit Nate Miles is effectively homeless. He moves from friends couch to friends couch, still recovering from a violent assault that left him with a stab wound and a punctured lung and a monthlong stay in the hospital.

title: Yankees Fans Sound Off About 2011
description: When the Red Sox signed Adrian Gonzalez and Carl Crawford, order in the American League East was jolted. Tremors from the move were felt well outside the Interstate 95 corridor, as nearly every expert (including the Times) is picking the Red Sox to finish atop the Yankees for the first time since 2008.

title: Preparing to Defend Walker
description: HOUSTON  The veteran role players, not the superstar freshmen, have led Kentuckys run to the Final Four. The junior guard DeAndre Liggins, the teams best defender, is a prime example.

title: Cuomo Stands Out Among Peers for Low Profile
description: When President Obama invited the countrys newly elected governors to Washington for lunch and a chance to rub elbows with cabinet secretaries and West Wing officials, Andrew M. Cuomo sent his regrets.

title: Protesters Scold Egypts Military Council
description: CAIRO  Thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square on Friday for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council move faster to dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime.

title: Bringing Skateboarders Doing 60 to a Halt
description: LAGUNA BEACH, Calif.  Chance Gaul cannot drive a car yet. He is only 14. But he is already the fastest thing on wheels around here.

title: Manning Marable, Historian and Social Critic, Dies at 60
description: Manning Marable, a leading scholar of black history and a leftist critic of American social institutions and race relations, whose long-awaited biography of Malcolm X, more than a decade in the writing, is scheduled to be published on Monday, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 60.

title: A High School Poised at a Moment of Pride and Great Anxiety
description: On a cold, sunny Tuesday morning, the entrance to Rice High School in Harlem is bustling. Television reporters are milling about, waiting to talk to the schools current and former basketball coaches about Kemba Walker, the Rice alumnus who will lead the University of Connecticut Huskies in the N.C.A.A.s Final Four this weekend. The students are excited because a busload of girls from a Catholic school in Brooklyn have arrived for a pre-prom get-to-know-you in the gym. And President Obama is visiting the neighborhood later in the day.

title: Job Growth Alters Playbook for Obama and His Critics
description: LANDOVER, Md.

title: Lewis Holds Lead In L.P.G.A. Major; Wie Is in Contention
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Stacy Lewiss first tournament as a professional was the 2008 United States Open. After holding the third-round lead and finishing tied for third, Lewis assumed the L.P.G.A. Tour would be a continuation of her college success.

title: Calipari Acts as If He Has Been There Before
description: HOUSTON  The last question at Fridays news conference for Kentucky Coach John Calipari drew laughter from some and astonishment from others. It seemed to draw a reaction from everyone but Calipari, who basically shrugged.

title: Polite Robber Is Given a 60-Month Sentence in Gas Station Holdup
description: Saying please and thank you is a virtue, but for a robber in Seattle, politeness went only so far.

title: Podcast: Jobs, Wages and Middle-Class Costs
description: A drop in the unemployment rate and a jump in job creation must count as good news, but this is no time for celebration.

title: Lawmaker Calls Bishop Pedophile Pimp
description: A top Republican in New Hampshire on Friday called Bishop John B. McCormack of Manchester a pedophile pimp on his Facebook page.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Rebel Attack on Brega Ends in Stalemate
description: BREGA, Libya  Libyan rebels resumed their offensive on Friday by massing heavier weapons in an attack on this eastern oil town, but were repulsed in the fading light of afternoon and backtracked along a main road under fire.

title: New Yorks High Court Attacks False Confessions
description: A young man of limited education and low I.Q. confesses to murder. His statement is a fine-grained picture of the crime: The victim had been dressed in a red-striped nightshirt, cooking chicken and mashed potatoes, when the attack began. He was stabbed 15 or more times with a 12-inch serrated knife. Later, the killer used a paper towel to clean a cut on his own hand and dabbed his wound with intensive-care lotion.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Lou Gorman, Whose Red Sox Lost to Mets, Dies at 82
description: Lou Gorman, who as general manager of the Boston Red Sox put the finishing touches on the 1986 team that came within one strike of bringing the franchise its first world championship in 68 years, only to have it snatched away by the Mets, a team he had also helped put together, died on Friday in Boston. He was 82 and lived in Weston, Mass.

title: Jurors Side With Toyota in Lawsuit Over Crash
description: A federal jury in New York on Friday cleared the Toyota Motor Corporation in a civil lawsuit of accusations about unintended acceleration.

title: The Census of Doom
description: A little knowledge is a dangerous thing; a lot of it can be deadly. Such was the case on the eve of the Civil War. Among all the events that touched off the great conflict  John Browns raid in 1859, Abraham Lincolns presidential victory in 1860  there is one that has been strangely ignored by most historians. True, it was less dramatic than the others. It occurred when enumerators traveled from door to door throughout America, counting up Easterners and Westerners; Northerners and Southerners; blacks and whites; freemen and slaves. The numbers that they came up with helped to split apart the Union.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: I Am In. I Am Going to College
description: So much has happened over the past few months. My feelings throughout this crazy milestone we call the college admissions process have changed entirely so many times that its difficult to keep track of them all.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Finish by the Phillies Looks Familiar
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Phillies had four hits through eight innings Friday. Then they torched Brandon Lyon, Houstons closer, for six in the ninth. To anyone who has paid any attention at all to the Phillies, neither of those things should come as a huge surprise.

title: Butler Coaches Have a Child Entourage
description: HOUSTON  Tracy Stevens, the wife of Butler Coach Brad Stevens, summed up a second straight Final Four trip this way: Insanity.

title: Youve Passed the Interview. Now Give Us a Presentation.
description: This interview with  Chris Cunningham, co-founder and C.E.O. of Appssavvy, a social media-focused marketing firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. (The New York Times has an ownership stake in Appssavvy of less than 5 percent.)

title: Excuses, Excuses, Excuses
description: Whenever the worlds greatest investor gets in a tight squeeze, he straps on his angel wings, readjusts his halo, and leans on his reputation for avuncular straight talk to make the problem go away.

title: Fall on Subway Platform Severely Injures a Teenager
description: An 18-year-old high school student from the Bronx was seriously injured on Friday when he fell on a platform at the Union Square station and either struck his head on a stopped subway train or was hit in the head by one pulling in, the authorities said.

title: Religious Radicals Turn to Democracy Alarms Egypt
description: NAHIA, Egypt  Abboud al-Zomor  the former intelligence officer who supplied the bullets that killed President Anwar el-Sadat and is Egypts most notorious newly released prisoner  waxes enthusiastic about ending the violent jihad he once led.

title: Malcolm X
description: From Chapter 7, As Sure as God Made Green Apples

title: On Eve of Redefining Malcolm X, Biographer Dies
description: For two decades, the Columbia University professor Manning Marable focused on the task he considered his lifes work: redefining the legacy of Malcolm X. Last fall he completed Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention, a 594-page biography described by the few scholars who have seen it as full of new and startling information and insights.

title: To Improve, Rubio Needs to Come to N.B.A.
description: ATHENS  Outside of the N.B.A., the Euroleague is the best basketball in the world. For Ricky Rubio to lead a team of F.C. Barcelonas caliber, at age 20, is a tremendous accomplishment. But he may have learned all he can by playing professionally in Spain, and if basketball is his first priority, its time to come to the N.B.A.

title: Bonds Trial Damages a Familys Ties
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Until Thursday, Barry Bondss mother, Pat, had shown little emotion during her sons perjury trial in United States District Court.

title: Donald Trump Gets Weirder
description: Donald Trump has run faux campaigns for president before, flirting with the Democrats and independents. This time, hes playing a conservative Republican. By 2016, hell probably be talking about his affinity for the Alaskan Independence Party or the Whigs.

title: Gov. Cuomos Budget
description: New Yorks lawmakers passed a $132.5 billion budget before the April 1 deadline, a rare event. That is, on the whole, a political win for Gov. Andrew Cuomo, who cut $10 billion out of it.

title: A New Tune for Egypt's Radical Muslims
description: Egypt's fundamentalist Muslims are preaching at universities, advertising on streets, and politicizing in five-star hotels. Their goal: to influence the Muslim content in Egypt's new constitution.

title: Disney Said to Have Cleared Hurdle for Shanghai Park
description: It appears that the Walt Disney Company has cleared the final hurdle in its decades-long bid to build a theme park on the Chinese mainland.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 1, 2011

title: Coaches Calhoun and Calipari Share a Genuine Dislike
description: HOUSTON  The contentious relationship between Connecticuts Jim Calhoun and Kentuckys John Calipari is perhaps the longest and most entertaining coaching feud in college basketball. It started so long ago that Calipari has held five jobs since.

title: Girl, 11, Sues the Police, Claiming She Was Handcuffed
description: An 11-year-old Bronx girl has sued New York City, claiming that police officers overreacted last spring, handcuffing her after a fight with a third-grade classmate and denying her mothers request to be present when they interviewed her.

title: Salafi Movement Seeks a New Role in a New Egypt
description: Salafism, a radical Islamic movement in Egypt, attempts to gain a foothold in the burgeoning democracy that has emerged in the wake of former President Hosni Mubaraks abdication.

title: Paterson Teacher Suspended Over a Post on Facebook
description: A first-grade teacher in Paterson, N.J., was suspended on Thursday after she posted on her Facebook page that she felt like a warden overseeing future criminals, district officials said.

title: Decades After Ban, Columbia Opens Door to R.O.T.C. Return
description: More than four decades after Columbia University, the heart of the Vietnam-era student movement, banned R.O.T.C. from campus in a moment of 1960s antimilitary rage, the University Senate voted overwhelmingly on Friday to support efforts to bring the group back.

title: The Long Chill, by the Numbers
description: New Yorkers looked out the window with gritted teeth on Friday and endured another dreary day in a year that has seen plenty of them. The gloom was a sorry excuse for a date as promising as April 1, a flubbed herald for spring weather that seems as if it will never come. April Fools Day, right?

title: Nassau Bus Riders May Get Reprieve on Service Cuts
description: State officials announced an agreement on Friday that could delay cuts to the Long Island Bus service in Nassau County that would have meant the end of trips for 16,000 of 100,000 riders.

title: Air Traffic System Update Encountered Turbulence
description: Imagine an air traffic system where planes would no longer have to wait in long rush-hour lines before taking off, or have to circle the skies before landing. In this world, planes would be able to fly more direct routes and land along smoother glide paths.

title: The Truth About American Muslims
description: At the Justice Department, its called the post-Sept. 11 backlash  the steady stream of more than 800 cases of violence and discrimination suffered by American Muslims at the hands of know-nothing abusers. These continuing hate crimes were laid bare at a valuable but barely noticed Senate hearing last week that provided welcome contrast to Representative Peter Kings airing of his xenophobic allegation that the Muslim-American community has been radicalized.

title: Bloggingheads: Libya Now, Syria Next?
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Matt Welch of Reason debate whether Libya opens the gates for further military interventions.

title: Mission Accomplished, Nonprofits Go Out of Business
description: A few nonprofit groups have recently announced plans to wind down, not over financial problems but because their missions are nearly finished.

title: By His Own Reckoning, One Man Made Libya a French Cause
description: PARIS

title: An Uncertain Future for a Mets Fixture
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  In 2003, Jose Reyes made his major league debut a day before his 20th birthday, playing shortstop in an interleague game in Arlington, Tex., for Art Howe, then the Mets manager. Nearly a decade later, Reyes is entering his eighth full season in New York. He has appeared in 924 games as a Met, is the senior member of the team in terms of service time and will now be playing for his fourth manager and general manager.

title: More Than 50 Years of the Final Four
description: Correction Appended | Rich Clarkson has been a pivotal figure in photojournalism for the last half-century. While he was the director of photography at The Topeka Capital-Journal in Kansas, his staff of photographers  which included Brian Lanker, Jim Richardson and David Alan Harvey  produced groundbreaking news and documentary photography. He was also assistant managing editor for graphics of The Denver Post and director of photography of The National Geographic Society.

title: Saturday: Ways of Charles de Gaulle
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I just dont understand some people. If someone you know happens to be a practicing physician, wouldnt you think that the last  thing theyd encourage you to consume is a crunchy, sticky treat? And yet, thats just what Mark Diehl does today. Shame on you, Dr. Diehl. And you call yourself a dentist.

title: Envoy Decides to Represent Nicaragua, not Libya
description: UNITED NATIONS  A former Nicaraguan foreign minister who had been appointed by Libya to be its envoy to the United Nations has changed his plans and will represent Nicaragua instead at the international body, diplomats said Friday.

title: More Physicians Say No to Endless Workdays
description: HONESDALE, Pa.  Even as a girl, Dr. Kate Dewar seemed destined to inherit the small-town medical practice of her grandfather and father. At 4, she could explain how to insert a pulmonary catheter. At 12, she could suture a gash. And when she entered medical school, she and her father talked eagerly about practicing together.

title: U.S. Starts Inquiry in Miami Police Shootings
description: MIAMI  The Justice Department has opened an inquiry into seven fatal shootings of suspects by Miami police officers since last July, according to a letter sent to a Miami congresswoman.

title: It Only Looks Dangerous
description: MIXED martial arts is one of the fastest-growing sports in America. Yet for years the New York State Legislature has refused to sanction M.M.A.  making New York one of the last states holding out against the sports expansion. (Connecticut is a holdout, too.) After helping to block a clause in last years budget that would have legalized M.M.A., Bob Reilly, a state assemblyman, called it a violent sport not worthy of our society.

title: Georgia: U.N. Court Rejects Claim of Ethnic Cleansing by Russia
description: The International Court of Justice on Friday rejected a claim by the former Soviet republic of Georgia accusing Russia of ethnic cleansing in two rebel enclaves. The court, the judicial arm of the United Nations, ruled that it had no jurisdiction to decide the case, but made no decision on the merits of the accusation. In a statement on its Web site, the court said Georgia violated procedure by failing to hold direct talks with Russia over the dispute before going to court. Georgia filed the complaint in the midst of its war with Russia in August 2008, accusing Moscow of complicity in the forceful expulsion of ethnic Georgians from Abkhazia and South Ossetia. Both sides leveled accusations of ethnic cleansing during the war, though there has been no independent legal confirmation that such crimes occurred.

title: Satellite Subscribers Are Facing Loss of Mets and Yankees Programming
description: The Mets and Yankees networks are in parallel battles with satellite operators.

title: Salvation Army Accuses Bank of Mismanaging Its Assets
description: The southern division of the Salvation Army filed suit against the Bank of New York Mellon on Friday for almost $22 million, contending that the bank had grossly mismanaged assets belonging to the charity by investing them in mortgage-backed securities and other risky investments.

title: Cuts Leave Patients With Medicaid Cards, but No Specialist to See
description: LAFAYETTE, La.  Eight-year-old Draven Smith was expelled from school last year for disruptive behavior, and he is being expelled again this year. But his mother and his pediatrician cannot find a mental health specialist to treat him because he is on Medicaid, and the program, which provides health coverage for the poor, pays doctors so little that many refuse to take its patients.

title: Arizona Asks to Set Fines for Health Risks
description: PHOENIX  Arizonas Medicaid program, criticized last year when it halted some organ transplants to save money, has come up with another cost-saving measure that has people talking.

title: In Egypts Democracy, Room for Islam
description: Cairo

title: 2 More States Turn Over a Drug Used in Executions
description: Kentucky and Tennessee turned over their supplies of a drug used in executions to the federal authorities on Friday, weeks after Georgias supply was seized because of questions about how it had been imported.

title: Vatican: Visitors Must Declare Cash
description: The Vatican put a new rule into effect on Friday requiring that anyone bringing 10,000 euros (about $14,000) or more into Vatican City declare it to Vatican authorities. The rule is part of new anti-money-laundering regulations aimed at bringing the Vatican in line with international standards on financial transparency and helping it shed its image as a tax shelter. Italian authorities are investigating the Vatican Bank for money laundering. The Vatican has denied wrongdoing.

title: In Opener, Remade Mets Are Hardly a Hit
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  After an off-season of turmoil and transition that has provided a backdrop of uncertainty and concern, the Mets opened their 50th campaign against the dim expectations of a skeptical baseball world.

title: Disagreements Persist on Plan to Avert Government Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  Members of Congress remained at loggerheads Friday over a plan to avert a government shutdown, with House Republicans digging in behind a bill that would make it the law of the land to cut $61 billion from current spending, despite the fact that the Senate has already rejected that idea.

title: Don Hill, Nightclub Owner and Fixture of SoHo Scene, Is Dead
description: Don Hill, a music promoter whose club Don Hills, a stalwart of SoHos vibrant music scene, has brought together punks, drag queens and debutantes in the name of rock n roll for almost two decades, died on Thursday in Manhattan.

title: Rangers Among 4 Teams Scrambling for the Playoffs
description: Only days ago the Rangers seemed a sure bet to make the N.H.L. playoffs, but now, in the next to last weekend of the regular season, it is anyones guess where they will end up.

title: What Happened to Zero Tolerance?
description: A meeting of the nations Roman Catholic bishops is scheduled for June. It needs to repair the gaping holes uncovered in their zero tolerance mandate for priests suspected of sexually abusing children.

title: What Does New York Smell Like to You?
description: New York smells like many things, and some of them are good: freshly baked bagels, a beer and a dog at Yankee Stadium, the salt air that blows in on a summer morning.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: TimesCast | Syria Continues Clampdown
description: The Syrian government condemns social media in an effort to quell dissent.

title: TimesCast | Yemen's Dueling Protests
description: Pro- and anti-government factions divide Yemen's capital with competing protests.

title: TimesCast | U.N. Workers Killed
description: April 1, 2011 - At least 12 people were killed after an angry mob demanding retribution for the burning of a Koran in Florida overran a United Nations compound in Mazar-i-Sharif.

title: Red Bulls Acquire Veteran Midfielder
description: The Red Bulls acquired the veteran playmaking midfielder Dwayne De Rosario, 32, from Toronto F.C. for midfielder Tony Tchani, 21, defender Danleigh Borman, 26, and a 2012 draft choice. De Rosario, who is expected to be available or Saturdays game against the Houston Dynamo, scored 15 of Torontos 33 goals last season.

title: Three Games to Watch on Saturday
description: League play returns across Europe and M.L.S. teams return to full strength this weekend after a break for friendlies and Euro 2012 qualifiers. Several of the games have long-range title implications.

title: Japan Struggles to Plug Leak as Radioactive Water Seeps Into the Sea
description: TOKYO  Highly radioactive water is leaking directly into the sea from a damaged pit near a crippled reactor at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, Japanese safety officials said Saturday. The leak was the latest setback in the increasingly difficult bid to regain control of the plant.

title: Protests Over Koran Burning Reach Kandahar
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Violent protests over the burning of a Koran in Florida flared Saturday for a second straight day, with young men rampaging through the streets of this southern capital city, flying Taliban flags and wielding sticks.

title: The Weekend Word: Spending
description: Todays Times

title: After Much Shouting, Apologizing for the Shouting, Then Shouting Again, a Decision
description: About a year ago, there was a girl in my Spanish class who was a foreign exchange student from Santiago, Chile. She gave a brief PowerPoint presentation about her life back home, replete with pictures of mountain ranges and colonial architecture. During the Q. &A. session, one student asked, How much is a year of college tuition there?

title: YES and DirecTV Extend Deadline
description: The YES Network extended the deadline to make a new deal with DirecTV until Thursday, giving Yankee fans who subscribe to the satellite service a reprieve.

title: As Houston Hosts Final Four, New Orleans Gets Ready
description: As the college basketball world descends upon Houston this week for the mens Final Four, preparations are under way for the 2012 edition in New Orleans. Next year will be the citys first time hosting the event since 2003, which also means it will be the first time since Hurricane Katrina struck in 2005. The city has hosted major sporting events since Katrina  including the N.B.A. All-Star game in 2008 and N.C.A.A. mens tournament games in 2007, 2010 and 2011  but is just now getting back into the Final Four (and Super Bowl) rotation.

title: More on 1921
description: In an earlier post, I noted that Warren Harding has become an unlikely hero of the right, with claims that his hands-off response to the 1920-21 recession was the right role model for our times. As I noted, even a quick look at the actual facts shows that 1920-21 bears no resemblance to 2008-?, and instead looks like 1981-82: a recession was brought on by tight monetary policy aimed at limiting inflation, and was followed by a rapid recovery when monetary policy was relaxed.

title: The Pain Caucus of 1937
description: My friend and colleague Irwin Collier, of the Free University of Berlin, sends me a snippet from the Harvard Crimson, in 1937:

title: Lollapalooza in Chile, a Different Chi-Town
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A franchise expands to an unlikely spot this weekend as Lollapalooza, the giant rock festival that has become an annual event in Chicago, opens a new front here in the capital of Chile.

title: Former Steeler Starts Over as a Womens Coach
description: The football players huddled on the sideline in the fading sunlight. Several looked out from under silver helmets at their 6-foot-3, 310-pound coach, Darnell Stapleton, in a gray sweatshirt with Pittsburgh Steelers emblazoned on the front.

title: Keeping Score: The Traits of a Winning Team
description: In our book, Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method, we analyzed the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, to identify championship characteristics. Based on that research, we are again focusing on the factors that might help predict the winner of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament. Last years analysis correctly predicted that Duke would win the championship, and that Butler would be a threat to Michigan State in the semifinals.

title: Keeping Score: Statistic Combines Physics and Luck
description: Perhaps no aspect of baseball has received more statistical scrutiny over the last decade than pitchers control over the outcomes of balls in play. Ever since a paralegal named Voros McCracken posted a theory on the Internet in 1999 that pitchers could exert influence only on their strikeouts, walks and home runs allowed  leaving everything else up to fielders and luck  researchers have pored over a centurys worth of data on batting averages on balls in play.
