It turns out that McCracken and his detractors were partly right: although some pitchers are in fact more hittable than others, figuring out which ones they are while they are active is exceedingly hard.

title: The Bank Run We Knew So Little About
description: IN August 2007, as world financial markets were seizing up, domestic and foreign banks began lining up for cash from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: Gauging the Pain of the Middle Class
description: LIKE everyone else, government officials want to look good. That often leads them to enact policies that promote favorable movements in the indexes by which they are judged. But when those indexes are imperfect, bad choices often result. And thats nowhere more evident than in economic policy.

title: Jeff Banister: A Pirate Once, and a Pirate Still
description: Jeff Banister did not receive much of a signing bonus when the Pittsburgh Pirates drafted him in the 25th round in 1986. But the words of encouragement from the scout who signed him, Buzzy Keller, formed the basis of an unbroken relationship between an organization and a grinder.

title: In Nascar, Paul Menard Is the Surprise of 2011
description: MARTINSVILLE, Va.  Paul Menard may be the only Nascar driver with a Facebook page devoted to his facial hair.

title: On New Path, Leading to Frozen Four
description: GRAND FORKS, N.D.  Important conversations always take place at the kitchen table at the Frattin house in Edmonton, Alberta. The one Matt Frattin had with his parents in August 2009, when he was supposed to be preparing to play hockey at the University of North Dakota, could not have been more difficult.

title: In New York, E-Waste Recycling Law Takes Effect
description: A state law took effect on Friday requiring electronics manufacturers to make it free and convenient for New York residents to recycle their old or broken computers, television sets and gadgets. Although the widespread efforts will begin right away, it may take a while for that convenience to kick in.

title: Long Path to Final Four for UConns Okwandu
description: HOUSTON  As recently as four years ago, Charles Okwandu knew goaltending only as it related to his favorite sport, soccer, and his regular position, goalkeeper. Yet on Saturday, when Connecticut played Kentucky in the Final Four, Okwandu was expected to tend the Huskies goal as a defensive stalwart, a testament to Nigeria and basketball and one improbable outcome.

title: Time Might Be Right for Derby Hopeful To Honor and Serve
description: INDIANTOWN, Fla.  It was a late Sunday morning, and the oval at Payson Park training center was deserted except for a trainer on horseback, a Hall of Fame one by the name of Bill Mott. Two of his horses came out of the far turn, the sound of their hooves drowning out the songs of redwing blackbirds. As they passed, Mott turned his pony and together they sauntered back to the barn.

title: Who Took The Money Away?
description: Yep, my head will be talking tomorrow, on This Week.

title: Madden Puts Concussions in New Light in His Game
description: Ever since the seriousness of concussions became apparent on a national scale, the primary message for young football players  if you get a concussion, get off the field for the rest of the day  has been one of the most difficult for youngsters to accept and execute. That reality will soon be aided by fantasy.

title: A Quick Change in Heart Devices
description: With well-connected sales representatives and relationships with influential doctors, Biotronik, a small company, was able to become the main supplier of heart devices to one of Las Vegass largest hospitals  virtually overnight.

title: Variety: A Cruising Diagramless
description: Administrivial Twitter Announcement: Wordplay now has its very own Twitter feed! Follow @nytimeswordplay for the nightly headlines and for announcements of all manner of things going on in the puzzle world.

title: Spy Chiefs Tenure Is Extended in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani government has given another one-year extension to the chief of its powerful spy organization, the Inter-Services Intelligence Directorate.

title: When David Meets Goliath on the Hardwood
description: Houston

title: NATO Airstrike Reportedly Kills Rebels in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  A NATO airstrike near the battlefront in eastern Libya killed 13 rebel fighters outside the pivotal port city of Brega, a rebel spokesman and wounded fighters said Saturday.

title: Romney Explores a Run Without Saying So or Seeking the Spotlight
description: LAS VEGAS  Mitt Romney sightings have been hard to come by this year. But there he was on Saturday afternoon, riding an escalator at the Venetian hotel on the Las Vegas Strip after delivering his first public speech in a month.

title: UConns Kelly Faris Has Been There Before
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Geno Auriemma loves to tease, to needle. He mocks because he must. He can be piercingly funny, drawing laughs the way nurses draw blood. But he did not bother kidding Connecticut guard Kelly Faris this season about reaching the womens Final Four here in the city where she attended high school.

title: After Scare, Southwest Grounds Planes
description: Southwest Airlines grounded 79 airplanes on Saturday after a piece of the fuselage on one of its Boeing 737s ripped open during a flight the day before, leaving a hole in the cabin ceiling and rapidly depressurizing the aircraft.

title: Tiger Woodss Disappearing Empire
description: A look at Woodss golf course design business and its uncompleted ventures.

title: For Tiger Woods, a Golf Course Design Business Is in the Rough
description: IN late June 2008, a week after he astonished the golf world by winning the United States Open while grimacing in pain on a torn left knee, Tiger Woods traveled to a craggy chunk of land on the Baja Peninsula in Mexico. It was a lunarlike landscape of dirt and rock, with an inactive volcano in the background. For several hours, he hobbled over the terrain, discussing with developers his vision for the golf course he would build there, while waves from the Pacific crashed onto the shoreline below. His knee, said one companion, rattled like tools in a tool box.

title: Hundreds Killed in Ivory Coast Town as Conflict Intensifies
description: DAKAR, Senegal  As rebels swept across Ivory Coast in a rapid advance last week to oust the nations strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, hundreds of people were killed in a single town, the United Nations and aid groups said Saturday, in the worst episode of violence during the four-month political crisis that has plunged the country back into civil war.

title: Celebrities Set the Record Straight
description: Stephen Fry is not an anti-Catholic bigot, the actor will have you know. And, Bianca Jagger insists, Billy Joels song Big Shot is not based on a bad date with her. Those and more celebrity protestations are the stock in trade of iCorrect, a new image-protecting Web site founded by Sir David Tang, a businessman and socialite in London. It charges $1,000 a year to post unlimited corrections, provided the subscriber submits proof of identity. Here are some of the corrections, excerpted. TOM KUNTZ

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: A Lethal Sneeze
description: Humans are used to worrying that other species, like gorillas, might transmit their diseases to us. But should we be worried that we are transmitting our diseases to gorillas?

title: Back Then: 2001
description: In August 2001, The Timess Murray Chass recalled a conversation he had with Barry Bonds during spring training in 2000 about the explosion in home runs. Bonds is now on trial in federal court, accused of lying about using performance-enhancing drugs.

title: V.C.U.s Way to Keep Assistants in the Pipeline
description: With Virginia Commonwealths run to the Final Four, Coach Shaka Smart has been the smiling face of the midmajor program and its improbable journey, a celebrity made over two upset-filled weekends in March.

title: Fighting Words
description: Darren Aronofsky, the director of the ballet movie Black Swan, last week rose to the defense of the films star, Natalie Portman, who stood accused by her body double, the ballerina Sarah Lane, of not having performed anything close to 85 percent of the dance sequences, as claimed by Ms. Portmans fianc, the choreographer Benjamin Millepied.

title: Even More on 1921
description: A new paper by Daniel Kuehn. From the conclusion:

title: Why Red Flags Can Go Unnoticed
description: IN the wake of recent disasters  from nuclear reactor failures to oil spills to the collapse of the subprime mortgage market  we have focused on which people and institutions might be to blame. How, we ask in hindsight, could people and institutions have failed to foresee clear signs of trouble  even in the face of warnings?

title: Microsoft + Nokia = a Challenge for Apple
description: IPHONES and Android phones seem to be everywhere I look in Silicon Valley. The future is obvious, isnt it? IPhone, Android and no one else. They will form an exclusive duo in smartphones, just as Windows and Mac have in personal computers.

title: When the Data Struts Its Stuff
description: IN an uncharted world of boundless data, information designers are our new navigators.

title: Doctors Who Want a Life
description: For years, medicine has been dominated by fiercely independent doctors who owned their practices, worked night and day, had comfortable incomes and rarely saw their families. But today, as Gardiner Harris writes, many new doctors are seeking a better way to balance the demands of work and family:

title: Strike Kills Gaza Fighters, Spurring Hamas Warning
description: GAZA  Thousands of Palestinians attended the funerals on Saturday of three senior Hamas militants killed by Israel in an overnight airstrike in southern Gaza, and Hamas leaders warned that Israel would bear the consequences.

title: A Club for the Women Atop the Ladder
description: ON the site of a 17th-century monastery in Cartagena, Colombia,a sort of Illuminati of the business and political worlds gathered in February for their annual winter rites.

title: Line Dancing With the Markets
description: NO one knows which way the worlds financial markets will move on any given day. No one can know.

title: Dont Let Bureaucracy Ruin Your Day
description: ALMOST every worker has been frustrated by bureaucratic obstacles at one time or another. Even with the best of intentions, organizations sometimes snag their employees in impossible tangles of rules and regulations, slowing innovation and productivity. These filter down to customers and suppliers, who run into dead ends as they try to navigate the maze.

title: At Womens Masters, Plunge in Poppies Pond Is Victory Lap
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  The golfers stood on the 18th green of the Dinah Shore Tournament Course and plotted how to land in the water hazard.

title: Mets Dickey Has Visions of Hurling Knuckleballs From on High
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  During the baseball season, R. A. Dickeys job with the Mets requires ascending a hill only 10  inches high, a modest summit from which he surveys the field and throws his knuckleball to batters.

title: Where Jasmine Means Tea, Not a Revolt
description: BEIJING  Over the nearly four decades since President Richard M. Nixon established diplomatic ties with Red China, American politicians have clung to the idea that the growing ranks of Chinese entrepreneurs and college-educated strivers would one day find electoral democracy irresistible. But a stroll through one of the capitals upscale malls quickly demolishes such idealistic notions  and instead makes you wonder whether Chinas autocrats have struck on a flexible model of long-lasting rule.

title: Woods Is Vulnerable on the Course, Too
description: After each of Tiger Woodss five tedious tournaments leading to this weeks Masters, he sounded like a recording when he spoke about how well he was progressing with his new golf swing. But his scores contradicted him.

title: Colorless Food? We Blanch
description: WASHINGTON  Without the artificial coloring FD&C Yellow No. 6, Cheetos Crunchy Cheese Flavored Snacks would look like the shriveled larvae of a large insect. Not surprisingly, in taste tests, people derived little pleasure from eating them.

title: In Search of the First Jump Shot
description: John Miller Cooper, who died last year at 98, once described his historic basketball innovation this way: My feet left the hardcourt surface, and it felt good. It was free and natural, and I knew I had discovered something.

title: Bill White, Away From the Rat Race, Is Writing Bluntly About It
description: At the sight of Bill White, you are tempted to blurt out Hey White! as Phil Rizzuto, his broadcast partner with the Yankees, might have at seeing his old friend emerge from a thick, self-created cocoon. He is 77, powerful looking and back in the limelight after a long hiatus with an autobiography whose very title calls attention to itself: Uppity.

title: Battling H.I.V. in Lesotho
description: Dr. Paul Young, an American pediatric H.I.V. specialist, is highly prized in a country with the world's third highest rate of H.I.V. infection.

title: Doctors Go Far Afield to Battle Epidemics
description: MASHAI, Lesotho  At a clinic in the mountains, reached only by crossing a churning river in a rowboat, Dr. Paul Young, a pediatrician raised in the housing projects of Savannah, Ga., soothed a fussy baby. She stared at him, fascinated, as he made soft popping sounds with his lips and listened to her heart through a stethoscope.

title: Design Well Within Reach
description: Every economic slump imprints itself on interior design, each in its own way. Seventy years ago, for instance, a generation of Americans responded to the Great Depression by adopting a functional European design style known as modernism. They bought Alvar Aalto chairs and Russel Wright dinnerware, or, more likely, low-cost alternatives that made their way into the mainstream. Either way, modernism expressed the frugal spirit of the day.

title: Japans Nuclear Disaster Severs Towns Economic Lifeline, Setting Evacuees Adrift
description: KAZO, Japan  Along with 1,300 other evacuees from a town two miles from Japans damaged nuclear plants, Kunikazu Takahashi and his elderly mother are crowded into an abandoned high school here, sleeping on donated tatami mats as they ask themselves whether it will ever be safe to return.

title: American Joins Team Lotus Driver Development Program, and Tries F1 Car
description: Alexander Rossi, a 19-year-old from Nevada City, Calif., on Saturday was one of seven drivers appointed as part of the Team Lotus driver development program. This takes Rossi a step closer to a possible Formula One drive, and with the U.S. Grand Prix in Austin scheduled for next year, he may have a better chance than one might think.

title: American Joins Team Lotus Driver Development Program, and Tries F1 Car
description: Alexander Rossi, a 19-year-old from Nevada City, Calif., on Saturday was one of seven drivers appointed as part of the Team Lotus driver development program. This takes Rossi a step closer to a possible Formula One drive, and with the U.S. Grand Prix in Austin scheduled for next year, he may have a better chance than one might think.

title: When a Lawsuit Is Too Big
description: WASHINGTON  Can a class-action lawsuit be too sprawling to deliver old-fashioned justice?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A Wide-Open Chase for the Hart Trophy
description: No N.H.L. award is more prestigious than the Hart Trophy for the player judged most valuable to his team. But for the first time in memory, there are no clear-cut favorites for the honor. That was not the case earlier this season.

title: Assessing the Radiation Danger, Near and Far
description: Assessments of the radiation from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant by the Japanese authorities, the International Atomic Energy Agency and others.

title: The RSA Hack: How They Did It
description: The hack last month at RSA Security has been shrouded in mystery.

title: The Larger Game in the Middle East: Iran
description: WASHINGTON    On a Tuesday afternoon in mid-March in the White House Situation Room, as President Obama heard the arguments of his security advisers about the pros and cons of using military force in Libya, the conversation soon veered into the impact in a far more strategically vital place: Iran.

title: With Bethany Hamilton
description: Bethany Hamilton was 13 when she was attacked by a 14-foot tiger shark while surfing off Kauai in Hawaii, on Oct. 31, 2003. She is the subject of a new movie, Soul Surfer, which opens nationwide on Friday. Hamilton, who has a cameo in the film, lost her left arm in the attack but returned to competitive surfing three months later. In 2005, she won her first national title in the 18-and-under division of the National Scholastic Surfing Association championships. Hamilton, who is now 21, lives in Kauai and surfs professionally. VINCENT M. MALLOZZI

title: Stanley Bogdan, Maker of Much-Coveted Fly Reels, Is Dead at 92
description: Stanley Bogdan, a maker of fly fishing reels so coveted that anglers were willing to spend years on a waiting list to buy them and then to pay far more than they would have for reels of only ordinary excellence, died March 27 in Nashua, N.H. He was 92 and a lifetime Nashua resident.

title: Why Walk When You Can Stroll?
description: THE stroller is up on the shelf. When we moved to New York from Silver Spring, Md., not quite a year ago, I thought it would stay there. New York is a walking city and we had found an apartment four blocks from our sons preschool. He was turning 3. The stroller  infernal, clunky, annoying thing  would go into semi-retirement in the coat closet.

title: From Afar, a Vivid Picture of Japan Crisis
description: For the clearest picture of what is happening at Japans Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, talk to scientists thousands of miles away.

title: Reader Comments on My Libya Column
description: My Sunday column argues that there are indeed lots of uncertainties and legitimate criticisms of President Obamas operation in Libya  but weighed against it are the many lives that it has saved, and the prospect that it will ultimately remove Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. On balance, I think the intervention was not only essential but maybe a step toward the emergence of a bit more of an international conscience, the growth of the doctrine of the responsibility to protect. As for the argument that were inconsistent in our interventions: of course were inconsistent, but would you rather we consistently save no one?

title: No to a New Tar Sands Pipeline
description: Later this year, the State Department will decide whether to approve construction of a 1,700-mile oil pipeline from Canada to the Texas Gulf Coast called Keystone XL. The underground 36-inch pipeline, built by TransCanada, would link the tar sands fields of northern Alberta to Texas refineries and begin operating in 2013. The department should say no.

title: In Israel, Time for Peace Offer May Run Out
description: JERUSALEM  With revolutionary fervor sweeping the Middle East, Israel is under mounting pressure to make a far-reaching offer to the Palestinians or face a United Nations vote welcoming the State of Palestine as a member whose territory includes all of the West Bank, Gaza and East Jerusalem.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Jordan Cameron, Fifth-Ranked Tight End
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his depraved obsession with film analysis of rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end. This is the first entry in a series counting down his top five draft prospects at each position.

title: As Busy an N.F.L. Draft as One Can Possibly Imagine
description: The N.F.L. draft is one of the most exciting events in a young players life. Soon, it may also become the most tiring.

title: Sanitation Worker Is Attacked in Brooklyn
description: A city Sanitation Department worker was attacked and another was threatened after a motorist became angry when he could not pass their truck as they collected trash, the authorities said on Saturday.

title: Cutting Out the Middleman
description: For six years, Doug Stafford was a lobbyist for the National Right to Work Committee, an anti-labor group financed by business and conservative interests. His job changed last year but his duties did not when he became the chief of staff to Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky. Mr. Paul is a chief sponsor of the National Right to Work Act, which he said would end forced unionization and break Big Labors multibillion-dollar political machine forever.

title: Sunday Evening With Monday to Come
description: New York is a place people come to have jobs they can love. And yet a certain wistfulness always steals over Sunday evening. You can almost feel the people out on the streets  walking dogs, strolling home from dinner, running along the river  trying to make twilight last a little longer. Monday is gathering and they can feel it.

title: What Would You Do With an Extra $70 Billion?
description: Defense Secretary Robert Gates has vowed that the days of profligacy are over and that the Pentagon will reform its bloated and often corrupt acquisition process.

title: Is It Better to Save No One?
description: Critics from left and right are jumping all over President Obama for his Libyan intervention, arguing that we dont have an exit plan, that he hasnt articulated a grand strategy, that our objectives are fuzzy, that Islamists could gain strength. And those critics are all right.

title: Mad Men and Mad Women
description: WASHINGTON

title: Standards That Everyone Can See
description: LAST week The Times reached a strategic frontier with the full introduction of paid subscriptions for digital access to its content. Perhaps less visibly, but also importantly, the newsroom has moved toward a remarkable integration of its print and electronic operations. The organization has evolved to a new state, one that lives online and expects to be paid for it.

title: Mother Natures Melting Pot
description: THE anti-immigrant sentiment sweeping the country, from draconian laws in Arizona to armed militias along the Mexican border, has taken many Americans by surprise. It shouldnt  nativism runs deep in the United States. Just ask our non-native animals and plants: they too are commonly labeled as aliens, even though they also provide significant benefits to their new home.

title: Romney to Obama: Why Didnt You Call Me?
description: LAS VEGAS  President Obama frequently showers sardonic praise on Mitt Romney for the health care law he signed in Massachusetts, calling it a model for the national plan. On Saturday, Mr. Romney offered a new retort, saying: If thats the case, why didnt you call me?

title: An Iowa Stop in a Broad Effort to Revitalize the Religious Right
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  Hundreds of conservative pastors in Iowa received the enticing invitation. Signed by Mike Huckabee, a former Arkansas governor and 2008 presidential contender, it invited the pastors and their spouses to an expenses-paid, two-day Pastors Policy Briefing at a Sheraton hotel.

title: Koran-Burning Pastor Unrepentant in Face of Furor
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  His churchs membership is down to just a few of the faithful. He is basically broke. Some of his neighbors wish him ill. And his head, he said, carries a bounty.

title: Unpaid Interns, Complicit Colleges
description: ON college campuses, the annual race for summer internships, many of them unpaid, is well under way. But instead of steering students toward the best opportunities and encouraging them to value their work, many institutions of higher learning are complicit in helping companies skirt a nebulous area of labor law.

title: We Work Hard, but Whos Complaining?
description: Los Angeles

title: Shutdown Watch: Six Days Out
description: With six days left until the federal governments spending authority runs out, President Obama talked with congressional leaders as staff continued to work through the weekend on a compromise that could pass next week.

title: Teenage Sexting: What Can Be Done?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Obama Insider, Running the Race From Afar
description: CHICAGO  For two years, Jim Messina worked 41 steps from the Oval Office, a distance he counted when he first arrived at the White House. His next assignment  in an office 700 miles from President Obama  will test whether proximity is the key to power.

title: Crackdown on Protesters Upsets Lives in Belarus
description: MINSK, Belarus  In more than 16 years in power, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, the authoritarian president of this former Soviet republic, has often deployed the courts to persecute opponents, locking them away after the kind of show trials typical of the Communist era.

title: Want to Increase Voting? Discounts Seem to Work
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Airstrike Reportedly Kills Rebels in Libya
description: A NATO airstrike intended to thwart Moammar Gadhafis forces killed 13 rebel fighters in eastern Libya instead, the opposition said Saturday, but they described it as an unfortunate accident and stressed it did not diminish their support for the international air campaign.

title: Obesity and National Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Finance
description: To the Editor:

title: How State Cuts to Education Affect Rich and Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Regional Plants for Our Urban and Suburban Spaces
description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois Workers Find That a Death Penalty Ban Abolishes Their Jobs, Too
description: The day after the death penalty was abolished in Illinois in early March, Wendi Liss received a call from one of her clients, who was facing trial for murder and the prospect of being executed if found guilty.

title: Ballot Subtext: Budget Crisis and Jobs, Jobs, Jobs
description: Focused on winning the mayors office outright, Rahm Emanuel mostly steered clear of the City Council races in the Feb. 22 election. The day after he was elected mayor, he turned to the 14 wards where no candidate for alderman won a majority, necessitating runoffs on Tuesday to complete the new 50-member Council.

title: The Warehouse Cafe
description: Port Costa is generally a quiet hamlet, found at the end of a winding rural road in northern Contra Costa County. But on weekend nights and Sunday afternoons  especially in the summer  it loudly revives itself. Visitors seek out the Warehouse Cafe, the towns legendary watering hole.

title: Two Emergency System Plans Gone Off Course
description: In the wake of the 9/11 attacks, government officials across the Bay Area scrambled to develop new emergency communications systems that would enable a coordinated response in the event of a major crisis. Federal dollars were available, and it seemed like an opportune moment to upgrade key infrastructure.

title: Sara Ruddick, Gave Due to Motherhood, Philosophically, Dies at 76
description: Sara Ruddick, whose 1989 book, Maternal Thinking: Toward a Politics of Peace, laid the groundwork for a feminist approach to understanding and analyzing the practices and intellectual disciplines involved in rearing children, died on March 20 at her home in Manhattan. She was 76.

title: In a Clubby World of San Francisco Mothers, Men Neednt Apply
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Giving Rural Iowans a Taste of Italy
description: SIOUX CENTER, Iowa  When Giovanni Romano, a native of New York, first arrived in this strongly Christian patch of rural northwest Iowa, there was a battle among the local pastors for his soul. He was a recovering heroin addict and former convict, and everyone, it seemed, wanted to save him.

title: Sunday: Triple Bonds
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  You will need your adding skills for this one. Oliver Hill and Eliza Bagg have crammed some phrases together for our amusement.

title: Trump for President in 2012? Maybe. Trump for Trump? Without Question.
description: Something predictable happens to the ratings of Donald J. Trumps Celebrity Apprentice on NBC when he hints at running for president: They rise.

title: Three French Players Punished for Using Technology to Cheat
description: Cheating has become more common in recent years. But a recent French case is the most sensational, and the most troubling.

title: American Joins Team Lotus Driver Development Program
description: From our colleagues at Formula One:Alexander Rossi, a 19-year-old from Nevada City, Calif., on Saturday was one of seven drivers appointed as part of the Team Lotus driver development program. This takes Rossi a step closer to a possible Formula One drive, and with the U.S. Grand Prix in Austin scheduled for next year, he may have a better chance than one might think.

title: Is De Rosario the Final Piece in the Red Bulls Puzzle?
description: HARRISON, N.J.  If there was ever any doubt that the Red Bulls are a now team, that notion was dispelled Friday afternoon when the club announced the acquisition of the veteran midfielder Dwayne De Rosario from Toronto.

title: Wide Support for Democracy Activist in Vietnam
description: BANGKOK  A prominent Vietnamese legal scholar and human rights campaigner who has called for multiparty democracy was due in court on Monday in Hanoi, facing up to 12 years in prison in a case that has mobilized unusually broad public support.

title: Rangers Profess Confidence in Ability to Score More and Clinch a Playoff Berth
description: For the final 15 minutes of an hourlong practice on Saturday, the Rangers engaged in a 3-on-2 drill. This was not arepetition ofodd-man rushes, but a test of what N.H.L. coaches often refer to as battle level. For 30 to 45 seconds each shift, all within the offensive blue line,three forwards would work the puck deep against two teammates and the goaltender Henrik Lundqvist. The drill would end with a goal, or at least a few quality scoring opportunities.

title: Teacher Accused of Attack Threat
description: A teacher was arrested Friday after she threatened to carry out a mass shooting at the Brooklyn high school where she worked, the police said.

title: Cashman Says Feliciano Was Abused by Mets
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Over the last 25 years, there has been almost nothing that the Mets have done better than the Yankees. Yet one small item cropped up after the Mets decided not to re-sign the left-handed reliever Pedro Feliciano and allowed the Yankees to do so instead.

title: Partners in Iniquity
description: Both professional historians and the general public have long explained Americas descent into civil war as the result of the economic divergence between an industrial North and an agrarian South.

title: Caught Between Sidewalk and Street
description: THREE cyclists from two local racing clubs, defiant and ready to take a stand, rolled into Central Park near 110th Street, and were promptly arrested. It was a summer morning in 1881, and bicycles were not permitted in the citys vast park.

title: Mavericks Always Feel at Home
description: The importance of playoff seeding comes down almost entirely to home-court advantage. In the case of Dirk Nowitzki and the Dallas Mavericks, that may not be a cause for concern.

title: Yankees Explain Why Employee Flashed Signs From Stands
description: The commissioners office called the Yankees on Saturday to ask why an employee was flashing hand signals toward the teams players during Thursdays game, a violation of Major League Baseball rules.

title: Two Young Coaches Are Study in Contrast on Sideline
description: HOUSTON  Butlers Brad Stevens and Virginia Commonwealths Shaka Smart are each up-and-coming coaches. But they could not be more different in how they go about actually coaching their teams.

title: When It Comes to Marijuana, Willies Punishment Seems to Vaporize
description: Joe Nick Patoski wrote this column for The Texas Tribune.

title: Certainties of 1970s Energy Crisis Have Fallen Away
description: Unrest in the Middle East, rising oil prices and frustration with federal energy policy  for Texans of a certain age, todays headlines must seem like dj vu. The current situation is far less severe than the aftermath of the 1973 Arab oil embargo. But the parallels are unmistakable.

title: Texas Clout in Congress Rises Along With G.O.P.
description: Last year, with Democrats controlling the United States House of Representatives, Texas delegation of Republicans was largely shut out of power.

title: In Final Four Spotlight, Shadows Follow Calhoun
description: HOUSTON  As Connecticut meets Kentucky in the second national semifinal Saturday night, perhaps the most interesting character is Jim Calhoun, UConns somewhat polarizing coach.

title: Tipping the Odds for a Maker of Heart Implants
description: Las Vegas is a city of few sure bets. But there are overwhelming odds on one thing  the brand of heart device that patients at a major hospital get.

title: The Texas Shuffle: The Month Ahead in Music
description: The month ahead in music.

title: Head of U.N. Panel Regrets Saying Israel Intentionally Killed Gazans
description: JERUSALEM  The leader of a United Nations panel that investigated Israels invasion of Gaza two years ago has retracted the central and most explosive assertion of its report  that Israel intentionally killed Palestinian civilians there.

title: Carolina Tops Isles to Gain on Rangers
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  By now, Rangers fans must be furious with the Islanders for complicating their playoff hopes.

title: Assault in Greenwich Village
description: A police handout video of an assault in Greenwich Village that is being investigated as a hate crime.

title: Jos Argelles, New Ager Focused on Time, Dies at 72
description: Jos Argelles, the father of the Harmonic Convergence, the mammoth New Age event that in 1987 drew thousands of humming adherents to sites around the globe, died in the Australian bush on March 23, not much more than a year before the world, in his view, might well have ended anyway. He was 72 and lived in Ashland, Ore.

title: Anthony Shoulders a Load Stoudemire Used to Carry
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The constant in the evolving formula that N.B.A. teams hope translates into championships  mix a superstar or two with a superstar or two  is that there remains just one basketball to shoot or share.

title: Burnett and Teixeira Show Their Strengths Early
description: Yankees starter A. J. Burnett left one game last season after injuring his hands by slamming them against the swinging doors of the clubhouse in frustration.

title: A Little Clarity in Europes Biggest Races
description: The European club season runs, well, it seems like forever, so it is still too early for the league leaders to start planning parades and renting those open-top buses.

title: Butler Earns Second Chance
description: HOUSTON  Back in the practice gym at Hinkle Field House, during Butlers sweaty summer pickup games, the seeds for the Bulldogs latest run to the national title game were planted.

title: Atop the Leader Board, Tseng Is Helping to Fill a Void on the L.P.G.A. Tour
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  Friends were coming out of the woods to root for Yani Tseng at the Kraft Nabisco Championship. There was Tsengs mother and her mothers friends who are visiting from Taiwan and busloads of people from nearby Beaumont, where Tseng was briefly based as a teenager.

title: A Pioneer of Music for Children Is Still Inspiring
description: Home of the blues. Laboratory for the skyscraper. Birthplace of atomic energy. And cradle of childrens music?

title: New Lanes in the City Elicit a Split Reaction
description: San Francisco is poised to double the number of a long-neglected entertainment asset: bowling alleys.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 3
description: With the federal governments next brush with shutdown less than a week away, the Sunday talk shows are focused on budget negotiations, featuring interviews with the lawmakers who will play a big role in making or breaking the deal.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Photographs of news and features in business.

title: When the Cupboard Is Bare in Washington
Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Translating Your Skills
description: MY father was in the military when I was growing up. I was just a baby when we lived in Alaska, so I have no memory of the dogsled rides my family took, or of seasons without darkness. We lived in Alabama during the civil rights movement, but I was too young to appreciate the historical significance. After that we moved to Germany.

title: A Prank on the Mets, but SNY Isnt Laughing
description: Through two late-season collapses in 2007 and 2008 and then the last two sub-.500 seasons, the Mets have endured plenty of criticism and no little bit of mockery.

title: Student Who Fell on Subway Platform Dies
description: An 18-year-old high school student who collapsed on a Manhattan subway platform and was struck in the head by a train died on Saturday, the police said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 2, 2011

title: Budget Battle to Be Followed by a Bigger Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Congress has yet to settle its first budget fight of the year but is already about to move on to an even more consequential fiscal clash.

title: Trade Pays Off Immediately for Red Bulls
description: HARRISON, N.J.  It took Dwayne De Rosario less than two minutes to impose his personality on his new team, the Red Bulls, on Saturday night.

title: Its Early, but Mets Show a Flair for Late Dramatics
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Two games into the season, the Mets have already provided some compelling moments, good and bad, suggesting that perhaps the next 160 games just might be worth watching, too.

title: N.C.A.A. Photo Replay: April 2
description: A look at the Final Four matchups between Butler-V.C.U. and Connecticut-Kentucky.

title: For V.C.U., Glow Fades to a Future Uncertain
description: HOUSTON  Shaka Smart and his Virginia Commonwealth players passed a legion of newfound fans as they walked off the court Saturday night and stepped into an uncertain future.

title: Still Running, Still Stunning
description: HOUSTON  As the final seconds ticked away, Coach Jim Calhoun stalked the sideline for Connecticut, arms folded, gum churning in his jaw. His expression never changed, even as the Huskies burst into the championship game, on Monday against Butler, even as he moved closer toward the rarest air in his profession.

title: Efforts to Plug Japanese Reactor Leak Seem to Fail
description: TOKYO  Workers struggle to plug a gush of highly contaminated water from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, using sawdust, shredded newspaper and an absorbent powder, appeared to be failing early Monday as the radiation threat from the crippled plant continued to spread.

title: Chorus of Boos at Sheen Show in Detroit
description: DETROIT  About 30 minutes after Charlie Sheen took the stage at the Fox Theater here  the first stop on his Violent Torpedo of Truth/Defeat Is Not an Option tour  he posted a picture of the audience on Twitter accompanied by a message that read, The most honest city in the world honors the most honest man in the universe.

title: Vows: Yoomi and Ben
description: Yoomi and Ben met at law school and seemed to hit it off, but it wasn't until after their bar exam when they traveled to South America together that they realized they had that special something.

title: Spains Prime Minister Will Not Seek Third Term
description: Spains prime minister, Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, announced Saturday that he would not seek a third term in office, putting an end to months of speculation about his political future amid an economic downturn that had considerably undermined his chances of winning re-election.

title: Lollapalooza Chile: All About the Details
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Twenty years after he started Lollapalooza, and six years after he settled it in Chicago each summer, Perry Farrell is an old hand at overseeing festivals. Lollapalooza Chile started with a professional sheen on Saturday, the latest festival to feature multiple stages, prominent sponsorships, environmental gestures, do-gooder information booths and a big crowd. A hint of the attention to detail: on entering, its hard to avoid being handed a sample cup of a sponsors cola. About 20 steps later, when most people have had their drink, smiling people appear with big plastic bags to collect the little cups for recycling.

title: Teaching Gardeners About Birds (as in Chickens) and Bees (as in Hives)
description: Learning how to grow tomatoes in New York and can them is one thing. Finding out the best way to entertain a coop of chickens or when best to oust a queen bee from an urban hive falls into an entirely different realm of community gardening.

title: At Berlin Festival, Music Hits the Big Screen
description: If you hear the strains of various musical genres at cinemas around Berlin, dont be surprised. The annual In-Edit International Music Documentary Festival will take place from April 5 to 10 at Kreuzbergs Moviemento (Kottbusser Damm 22; 49-30-692-4785; www.moviemento.de) and Mittes .HBC (Karl-Liebknecht-Strasse 9; 49-30-24-34-29-20; www.hbc-berlin.de). From electro to flamenco, an eclectic range of musical genres are represented in the lineup of 33 documentaries that feature artists like the White Stripes, Johnny Cash, Feist and Brian Eno.

title: There Are Pitch Invasions, and Then There Are Pitch Invasions
description: The Egyptian powerhouse Zamalek was leading Club Africain of Tunisia, 2-1, on Saturday in their African Champions League match in Cairo when Zamalek appeared to score the goal it needed to advance three minutes into injury time.

title: 8 Secrets to Perfect Pet Photos
description: Pets have such charmwhy is it so few photos of them show it? In most snapshots, pets look stiff, posed and vaguely uncomfortable. Just  come to think of it  like most people in posed shots.

title: The Asymmetrical Online War
description: In 1975, John Brunner wrote a science fiction novel, The Shockwave Rider, about a lone programmer who creates a computer worm that exposes a repressive regimes secrets and ultimately undermines a tyrannical government.

title: For New Yorks Well-to-Do, What to Do With Tax Windfall?
description: Some of the New Yorkers who stand to benefit most from Albanys decision to kill the temporary income tax surcharge on the states high earners  the so-called millionaires tax  do not feel like millionaires.

title: 2 Qaddafi Sons Are Said to Offer Plan to Push Father Out
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  At least two sons of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi are proposing a resolution to the Libyan conflict that would entail pushing their father aside to make way for a transition to a constitutional democracy under the direction of his son Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a diplomat and a Libyan official briefed on the plan said Sunday.

title: Cricket Victory Brings Relief From Scandal in India
description: MUMBAI, India  India has had plenty of downbeat news in recent months: a litany of tawdry scandals, an unexpected sharp decline in foreign investment, the ineffectiveness of a bickering Parliament. A nation once brimming with confidence and global aspirations has seemed to stumble.

title: William Young, Who Helped U.S. Organize Secret War in Laos, Is Dead at 76
description: CHIANG MAI, Thailand  William Young, a missionarys son who mixed evangelical zeal with covert missions for the C.I.A. in Southeast Asia and who helped organize the secret war  in Laos for the United States during the Vietnam War, died on Friday at his home here in northern Thailand. He was 76.

title: Schott Op-Chart: Pluviocabulary
description: April showers bring forth May flowers  that much is uncontested. But the variety of wet weather with which spring confronts us would test even an Eskimos powers of description. To aid the discussion of precipitation, we present some of pluvial terms to be found in the inestimable Oxford English Dictionary. Click here for the Pluviocabulary.

title: For Qatar, Libyan Intervention May Be a Turning Point
description: DOHA, Qatar  Friendly to Iran even as it serves as a base for the American military, Qatar has long had one of the most creative foreign policies in this unstable region. But now, by sending its tiny air force to fly missions over Libya and granting other critical aid to the Libyan rebels in their fight for freedom and democracy, this very rich Persian Gulf emirate is playing a more ambitious and potentially more risky role.

title: French in Control of Ivory Coast Airport
description: PARIS  French forces in coordination with the United Nations took over the Ivory Coasts primary airport in the main city of Abidjan on Sunday so that planes could land and foreigners could be evacuated as fighting between the forces of rival presidents showed no sign of abating.

title: Dino Anagnost, Who Led Little Orchestra Society, Dies at 67
description: Dino Anagnost, the longtime conductor of the Little Orchestra Society, the highly regarded New York chamber orchestra that presents concerts for children and adults, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: In the Mountains of Patagonia, a Harbinger of a Rising Ocean
description: Land ice is melting virtually everywhere in the world, one of the central pieces of evidence that the earth is warming. Scientists have long known that this synchronized ice melt seemed to be picking up speed in many places, but detailed measurements for individual glaciers and ice fields have been hard to come by.

title: Ask About Alzheimers Disease
description: The two largest studies ever of Alzheimers disease have led to the discovery of five new genes that increase risk of the disease, Gina Kolata reports in todays New York Times. There are now 10 genes that are known to increase the risk of Alzheimers in old age.

title: Vast Gene Study Yields Insights on Alzheimers
description: The two largest studies of Alzheimers disease have led to the discovery of no fewer than five genes that provide intriguing new clues to why the disease strikes and how it progresses.

title: Afghans Protest Koran Burning for Third Day
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Afghan protests over the burning of a Koran in Florida continued Sunday for a third day, with three more people killed here.

title: In Kazakhstan, President Appears to Have Won Easily
description: SEMEY, Kazakhstan  This springs hasty campaign season in Kazakhstan has sometimes felt like a pep rally for Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the steelworker-turned-Communist-Party-boss who has ruled the country since 1989. That impression was heightened on Sunday when one of the presidents three challengers acknowledged that he, too, had voted for Mr. Nazarbayev.

title: Israel Grapples With Retraction on U.N. Report
description: JERUSALEM  Israel grappled on Sunday with whether a retraction by a United Nations investigator regarding its actions in the Gaza war two years ago could be used to rehabilitate its tarnished international image or as pre-emptive defense in future military actions against armed groups.

title: Born of Pirate Radio, Seeking a Spot on British Dial
description: Blair Munyan, a former United States Navy officer who served aboard a submarine off the coast of England in 1965, was reading an article about abandoned sea forts recently when he was flooded with memories of Radio Caroline, the offshore pirate radio movement known for breaking the British governments stranglehold on radio.

title: China Takes Dissident Artist Into Custody
description: BEIJING  The Chinese authorities on Sunday detained Ai Weiwei, a high-profile artist and stubborn government critic, as he tried to board a plane for Hong Kong, his friends and associates said. Mr. Ais wife, his nephew and a number of his employees were also taken into custody during a raid on his studio on the outskirts of the capital.

title: BP Seeks to Resume Drilling in Gulf of Mexico
description: LONDON  BP has asked United States regulators for permission to resume drilling in the Gulf of Mexico, two company officials said on Sunday, creating a delicate situation for the Obama administration as it seeks to balance safety concerns with a desire to increase domestic oil production.

title: Upsets Attest to Vitality in Womens Game
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: N.F.L. Draft: Lance Kendricks, Fourth-Ranked Tight End
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his depraved obsession with film analysis of rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at each position.

title: Diminished Individualism Watch
description: A few weeks back I commented on a George Will column in which he said that

title: Summer Concert Series May Find New Home
description: Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, may move one of his long-running concert series this summer because of opposition over the shows noise and a proposal for a huge new amphitheater there.

title: Belligerent and Boozy, and Thats Just the Audience
description: DETROIT  Charlie Sheen chose Detroit as the starting point for his My Violent Torpedo of Truth/Defeat Is Not an Option live performance tour. Before his show at the Fox Theater here on Saturday night you could speculate on a metaphorical link between the city and the star: phoenix rising from the ashes or shattered wreck of former glory. Either one might have seemed appropriate.

title: Chaos and Confusion
description: March 30  April 5, 1861

title: Proceeding Nacho Duato-Style, Like Fish Darting Through Water
description: The choreographer Nacho Duato ran the Compaa Nacional de Danza in Spain and its associated junior troupe, CND2, for 20 years until  in a storm of recriminations with the Spanish government   he left last year. Unsurprisingly, the companies wont retain the extensive repertory he created for them. At the Skirball Center on Friday night CND2 presented three pieces by Mr. Duato on a program that is part of a final tour of his work.

title: For Healing, Not Words but Bodies in Motion
description: Fall and Recover, a production by the Irish contemporary choreographer John Scott, is named after Doris Humphreys concept of fall and recovery in dance, essentially when the body is caught between two worlds. In this place one can express the tension between lightness and weight.

title: The Night They Called It a Day
description: Tomorrow Morning, a musical by Laurence Mark Wythe, keeps its focus on the big emotional moments of ordinary lives: marriage and divorce, love and commonplace heartache. But that title is not the only thing that feels flat about this show, a York Theater Company production at the Theater at St. Peters.

title: Identities as Elements to Play With and Juggle
description: Who but De Palma would think of using old-movie trash, and even soft-core pornos, to provide heart for a thriller? Pauline Kael asked in her rave review of Brian De Palmas Carrie.

title: Another Outing for This Gambling Tale? What Are the Odds?
description: In this age of short-attention-span audiences, if youre going to perform an old-fashioned play the old-fashioned way  that is, with two intermissions  youd better have a spark to inject into that third act to make audience members glad they stayed around. The Actors Company Theater, in its pleasant production of Three Men on a Horse at the Beckett Theater, has one, and his name is James Murtaugh.

title: Cabrera Tries to Keep Focus on the Field
description: Last season, when Texas won the American League pennant, Josh Hamilton of the Rangers was the leagues most valuable player. Hamilton, a recovering alcoholic and drug addict, traveled most of the time with Johnny Narron, a personal coach assigned to monitor his behavior and be his companion.

title: A Reality Check for Steinbeck and Charley
description: In the fall of 1960 an ailing, out-of-sorts John Steinbeck, pretty much depleted as a novelist, decided that his problem was he had lost touch with America. He outfitted a three-quarter-ton pickup truck as a sort of land yacht and set off from his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y., with his French poodle, Charley, to drive cross-country. The idea was that he would travel alone, stay at campgrounds and reconnect himself with the country by talking to the locals he met along the way.

title: Producer Who Did It All, Not in a Shy Way
description: His Way, an HBO documentary on Monday night about the veteran manager, promoter and producer Jerry Weintraub, is a nose-pressed-to-the-glass experience. Its as if Graydon Carter  one of the films producers  has allowed you into the bar at his Waverly Inn just to gawk at the more privileged people being led into the back room.

title: Fulham Pays Tribute to King of Pop
description: Cue the music. Fire up your favorite Thriller videos. A statue of the pop star Michael Jackson was unveiled outside Fulhams Craven Cottage stadium in London on Sunday.

title: Reflections of Sacred Harmonies From Spain
description: The exquisitely ornate sacred works of the Spanish Renaissance composer Toms Luis de Victoria have long been a staple of church choirs, at least in New York, around Christmas and Easter, but they turn up too rarely in concert performances. Perhaps that will change this year, the 400th anniversary of Victorias death. The Miller Theater helped get the commemoration under way on Saturday evening when it presented the Tallis Scholars in an all-Victoria program as part of its early-music series at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

title: House Republicans Propose $4 Trillion in Cuts Over Decade
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans plan this week to propose more than $4 trillion in federal spending reductions over the next decade by reshaping popular programs like Medicare, the Budget Committee chairman said Sunday in opening a new front in the intensifying budget wars.

title: Operatic Slugger Drives Some Pop
description: Nathan Gunn commands an operatic baritone whose mighty heft and richness confer an outsize authority on everything he touches. When he dips into popular music, he suggests a vocal Babe Ruth aiming for the fences, all the while maintaining a heros confident stance. At the Caf Carlyle, where he opened An Evening With Nathan Gunn on Tuesday evening, he belted it out of the ballpark four times. There were also singles, doubles and a couple of strikeouts.

title: Close Is No Longer Good Enough for Butler
description: HOUSTON  Butler was a halfcourt heave away from beating Duke for last years national championship. That fact has not escaped the current Bulldogs players as they prepare to play Connecticut on Monday in the title game.

title: Vivendi to Buy Vodafones Stake in SFR for $11.3 Billion
description: 9:08 p.m. | Updated

title: At the Jacoby, Some Trickery Helps Out the Winners
description: The winners of the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams at the Spring Nationals in Louisville, Ky., last month were Greg Hinze of San Antonio; David Yang of Darien, Ill.; Jacob Morgan of Madison, Wis.; Michael Polowan of New York; Dan Morse of Houston; and Steve Shirey of Fort Worth.

title: Hop Is Off to a Surprisingly Robust Start
description: The Easter bunny was No. 1 at the North American box office over the weekend as the animated and live-action hybrid Hop sold an estimated $38 million in tickets, performing far above expectations. The release from Universal Pictures cost $63 million to make, and audience-interest surveys indicated it would open to about $25 million in ticket sales. But a strong, whimsical marketing campaign did the trick, aided by the comedian Russell Brand, who gave voice to the main character, the Easter Bunnys teenage son, right. Teenage girls, it turns out, find Mr. Brand as hilarious as many adults find him irritating. Summit Entertainments Source Code, an action thriller starring Jake Gyllenhaal, was second with about $15 million in ticket sales, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. Insidious, an extremely inexpensive horror film from FilmDistrict, was third with about $13.5 million in sales. Insidious cost only $1 million to make, according to Jason Blum, a producer of the film. Diary of a Wimpy Kid: Rodrick Rules (20th Century Fox) was fourth with about $10 million, lifting its two-week total to $38.4 million. Limitless (Relativity Media) was fifth, selling roughly $9.4 million in tickets for a three-week total of $55.6 million.

title: Steinberg Prize Awarded
description: Nine Circles, a play by Bill Cain, is the winner of the 2011 Harold and Mimi Steinberg/American Theater Critics Association New Play Award. This years $25,000 prize, which honors a playwright for work that had its premiere outside New York City in the previous year, was presented to Mr. Cain on Saturday at the Actors Theater of Louisville during the Humana Festival of New American Plays. Nine Circles tells the story of a young American soldier accused of an atrocity in Iraq; it was originally produced at the Marin Theater Company in Mill Valley, Calif. This is the second straight year that Mr. Cain, who is also a producer and director, has won the award. Last year his play Equivocation took the honors following a run at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. It then was staged at the Geffen Playhouse in Los Angeles and the Manhattan Theater Club at City Center. Two other playwrights were honored with citations and prizes of $7,500 each: Kathryn Grant for The Good Counselor and David Bar Katz for The History of Invulnerability.

title: Dueling Snow Whites
description: The actress Lily Collins (The Blind Side), below, looks likely to be the fairest of them all in Relativity Medias 3-D film adaptation of the Brothers Grimm story Snow White, Variety reported. If talks with the producers go well, Ms. Collins, the daughter of Phil Collins, will join a cast that includes Julia Roberts as the evil queen and Armie Hammer (The Social Network) as Prince Andrew. Tarsem Singh (The Fall, Immortals) is set to direct the film. Production begins in May, with a release scheduled for June 29, 2012, six months before the arrival of Snow White and the Huntsman, Universal Studios take on the fairy tale, starring Kristen Stewart and Charlize Theron.

title: UConn Gets Ready to Cheer on UConn
description: HOUSTON  Kemba Walker and the Connecticut Huskies had plans for Sunday night: watch Maya Moore and the Connecticut Huskies.

title: Tina Fey Is Greek and Also Teutonic, but She Isnt a Troll
description: Tina Fey is an ugly, pear-shaped, bitchy, overrated troll. Somebody once wrote that on a mean-spirited Web site, whence it could have vanished into oblivion. But Ms. Fey liked the remark too much to let it go.

title: At the Garden, a Retirement and a Resuscitation
description: Over the weekend at Madison Square Garden they came to bury the first decade of the 2000s. On Friday night it was the Strokes, once the catalysts for multiple revivals: of New York City rock, of the more dissolute strains of late 1960s and 1970s rock, and of the idea of hype band as transgressor. One night later came LCD Soundsystem, which had been central to indie rocks move to the dance floor, and which called to mind the sorts of bands that tried to render irrelevant the sorts of bands called to mind by the Strokes.

title: Pay of State University Presidents Holds Steady Despite Cuts
description: In a year in which state universities often absorbed sharp budget cuts and raised tuition, the salaries of the presidents of those institutions largely held steady, according to a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education released Sunday night.

title: Monday: Charged Particles
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  There is something comforting about Monday puzzles. Its like waking up slowly, to the aroma of a well-brewed cup of coffee. Gimmes galore, and as your brain awakens, the mild challenge of a clever theme that is not too challenging at the same time. A perfect way to prime the mental engine for what comes later in the week.

title: Rebel Leadership in Libya Shows Strain
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  With the rebels battlefield fortunes sagging, the three men in charge of the Libyan opposition forces were summoned late last week by the ad-hoc leadership of their movement to a series of meetings here in the rebel capital.

title: Rangers Find a Way to Avoid Repeating History
description: PHILADELPHIA  Yes, Henrik Lundqvist had a flashback, too. Exactly 51 Sunday afternoons after losing a shootout on the final day of the regular season, ending the Rangers playoff hopes, Lundqvist stood at the same spot on the ice in this big arena, sizing up another moment of high drama.

title: CND2
description: Photos of a performance by the junior company of the Compaa Nacional de Danza from Spain.

title: Minmetals Resources Bids $6.5 Billion for Equinox Minerals
description: 9:04 p.m. | Updated

title: The Rails Derby 10
description: A look at the contenders for the Kentucky Derby, listed in order of preference. You can follow Joe Drape on Twitter.

title: Burying the First Decade of the 2000s
description: Photos from concerts by the Strokes and LCD Soundsystem.

title: Tense Calm Prevails in Syria as Latest Crackdown Victims Are Buried
description: CAIRO  Thousands of Syrians marched through the shuttered streets of Douma, just outside Damascus, on Sunday, chanting antigovernment slogans as they buried at least eight victims of the crackdown on Fridays protests, according to witnesses and human rights activists.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo
description: A smart, savagely funny and visionary new work of American theater, whose presence on Broadway invites fanciful comparison to the titular beast. Thats how Charles Isherwood describes Rajiv Josephs play Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, which opened at the Richard Rodgers Theater on Thursday in a production starring Robin Williams. Readers were a little less generous with the superlatives. Following are excerpts from several readers reviews posted on the theater section of NYTimes.com.

title: Fall and Recover
description: Photos from a production by the Irish contemporary choreographer John Scott.

title: Mets Feel Momentum With Road Series Win
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  Among the many problems that beset the Mets last year, perhaps the most confounding was their inability to win on the road, and particularly here against the Florida Marlins.

title: Blast at Pakistan Shrine Kills Dozens
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Two suicide bombers set off an explosion on Sunday evening at a Sufi shrine compound in Pakistan, killing at least 42 people, police officials said. More than 100 people, including women and children, were wounded.

title: Bring Donors Out of the Shadows
description: THE billionaire industrialist brothers Charles and David Koch have drawn sharp criticism for their extensive giving to libertarian causes. Though some of their organizational ties are public, many are unknown, thanks to a provision in the tax code that allows the Koch brothers and other donors, on both the left and the right, to conceal the recipients of their largess, even as they get to write it off on their taxes.

title: With Stakes High, N.F.L. Relies on a Star Lawyer
description: Last week, during a lecture at the Yeshiva University Cardozo School of Law, David Boies was reviewing the case he helped argue against Californias Proposition 8 in that landmark same-sex marriage trial when he paused for a moment to compose himself. Earlier in the evening, Boies had called the fight for equal rights for gays the next step in moving closer to the ideals of the countrys founding fathers. As he recalled asking the four plaintiffs in the case why they wanted to marry, he was briefly overcome by what he remembered as the pain and despair in their responses.

title: Teenagers Speak Up for Lack of Faith
description: PANAMA CITY, Fla.  Every other Wednesday, right after school at 2:45, the newest club at Rutherford High, the atheist club, meets in Room 13-211.

title: G.O.Ps 2012 Strategy Puts Focus on Timing
description: WASHINGTON  The last time Republicans challenged an incumbent Democratic president, they were simultaneously running a Congressional revolution.

title: An Accompaniment Moves Beyond the Bagel
description: IN the 1980s, when the bagel began its ascent from a specialty item served primarily in delis to a staple in chains like Brueggers, and eventually even in McDonalds, it was an auspicious time to be in the cream cheese business. So in commercials for Philadelphia cream cheese over the last few decades, bagels have played a starring role as a platform for the spread.

title: Microlender Focuses on Hospitality Businesses
description: Four years ago, Riccardo Romero could not find a bank to finance his first restaurant, so he ended up opening the Arepas Cafe in Astoria, Queens, with money from friends and a $10,000 loan from Accin, a nonprofit microlender that has seeded small businesses across the country.

description: To the Editor:

description: Washington

title: U.S. Shifts to Seek Removal of Yemens Leader, an Ally
description: SANA, Yemen  The United States, which long supported Yemens president, even in the face of recent widespread protests, has now quietly shifted positions and has concluded that he is unlikely to bring about the required reforms and must be eased out of office, according to American and Yemeni officials.

title: Senior Centers in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: No Longer Shackled by AOL
description: In 2005, Jim Bankoff was working at AOL as executive vice president in charge of products and programming. He decided that AOL needed to move aggressively into news if the business, then still a portal clinging to dial-up customers, was to survive the shift to broadband and the onslaught of new digital sites.

title: Duke Law Students Give Musical Nod to Nixon
description: DURHAM, N.C.  His name is not on any campus buildings. His only portrait is stored in a locked closet. And after his scandal-driven downfall, Richard M. Nixon was so stigmatized here at Duke University  where he earned a law degree  that the faculty rejected a proposal to house his presidential library.

title: City Pension Proposals
description: To the Editor:

title: The One That Got Away Is Still a Yankees Fan, and a Hot Pitching Prospect
description: LOS ANGELES  The best amateur pitcher in the country stepped off the rubber at cozy Jackie Robinson Stadium on Friday night, a roaring locomotive screeching to a stop. Gerrit Cole had two strikes on the hitter, with two outs in the ninth inning, and the 675 fans beneath the eucalyptus trees had started to stamp and clap and chant for U.C.L.A. to finish off Washington.

title: Fox Chief Seeks to Temper Theater Owners Furor Over On-Demand Films
description: LOS ANGELES  Jim Gianopulos, a chairman of Fox Filmed Entertainment, has a thought for theater owners who rebelled last week against a plan by his studio and others to allow home viewing of some movies just two months after they open:

title: For Illumination Entertainment, Animation Meets Economic Reality
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Hollywoods cartoon kings typically work in splendorous surroundings. Jeffrey Katzenberg runs DreamWorks Animation from a Mediterranean-style campus replete with olive trees and fountains. At Pixars glistening complex, John Lasseter has an Olympic-size swimming pool.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Mining Reality
description: There are two classic American folktales about coal. The first tells of greedy rednecks who blow virgin mountains to smithereens. The second tells of greedy corporations that exploit and endanger stout-hearted workers, making sure their souls are owed to the company store.

description: To the Editor:

title: From an NPR Minnow, Lessons for Whales
description: SHARON, Conn.

title: New Districts Seen as Aiding Democrats in New Jersey
description: New Jersey Democrats won a crucial victory for the next decade on Sunday as the state redistricting commission approved their legislative district map, dealing a blow to Republican hopes of retaking control of the Legislature.

title: The Day the Bear Roared
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The larger-than-life bronze sculpture of Jack Nicklaus that stands in the rotunda of the Augusta Museum of History is frozen in a transcendent moment in golf history, one that will reverberate at Augusta National Golf Club this week as Nicklauss epic Masters victory from 25 years ago is remembered.

title: A Wiki Takes Aim at Obama
description: Steven J. Law, the president of Crossroads GPS, a well-financed conservative political group with ties to Karl Rove, had a revelation a few months ago while watching television news.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Spain, Stepping Down in Bid to Retain Power
description: MADRID  With his Socialist Party facing a double-digit deficit in opinion polls, Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero is gambling that his decision not to seek a third term will bolster his partys chances to retain power.

title: Identifying Citys Worst Landlords via Craigslist, and Trying to Penalize Them
description: It is almost second nature for some New York City tenants to suspect their landlords of cutting corners when it comes to fixing a balky heater or securing dangling light fixtures.

title: As Fighting Continues The Injured Received Medical Treatment
description: The ship, carrying hundreds from Misrata to Turkey for care, made a brief stop in Benghazi, where rebel youth gathered on the dock to welcome them and seek news from an embattled city that has been largely cut off from the world for weeks.

title: Prominent Start-Ups in San Francisco Resist a Payroll Tax
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a start-ups initial public offering, a lot of people can get fabulously rich: the founders, early employees and the venture capitalists who staked the company.

title: An Underdog With a Top-Dog Attitude
description: HOUSTON  Its perfect that Butler guard Shelvin Mack finds the whole notion of the Bulldogs as college basketballs version of the movie Hoosiers cheesy.

title: The Truth, Still Inconvenient
description: So the joke begins like this: An economist, a lawyer and a professor of marketing walk into a room. Whats the punch line? They were three of the five expert witnesses Republicans called for last weeks Congressional hearing on climate science.
