description: HOUSTON

title: Science Fairs as Springboards to Prominence
description: Many accomplished people in science and technology competed in science competitions as teenagers.

title: 9/11 Relatives Oppose Plans to Put Remains in Museum
description: Relatives of some of the people who died in the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center demanded on Sunday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ask the loved ones of the more than 2,700 victims where they wanted remains that have not been identified to be placed.

title: The G.O.P.s Empty Stage
description: A month from now, the contenders for the 2012 Republican nomination were supposed to appear at the Reagan Library in Simi Valley, Calif., for the first of their primary debates. But the list of declared candidates is so pitifully short that last week the debate was postponed until September, to avoid the embarrassment of a stage potentially populated only by Tim Pawlenty and the pizza magnate Herman Cain.

title: Promoting Science, and Google, to Students
description: Google is synonymous with search engine, and now, for students,it wants to be synonymous with science.

title: After Long Absence, Knicks Return to Playoffs
description: One confident and boastful declaration hung over the Knicks season of peaks, valleys, notable introductions and exits: Amare Stoudemires statement when he signed last summer that the Knicks were back.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 3, 2011

title: Springs Awakening?
description: There are encouraging signs in the March jobs report, but for each hopeful development, there is a caveat. The economy added 216,000 jobs last month and marked the 13th straight month of private-sector job gains  but the growth is still weak. At a comparable point in the recoveries from other severe recessions, the economy was adding about 400,000 jobs a month.

title: Hole in Southwest Jet Attributed to Cracks
description: The five-foot hole that ripped open midflight Friday in the roof of a Southwest Airlines jet and terrified passengers on their way to Sacramento from Phoenix was caused by fatigue cracks in the aluminum underskin of the lap joints, the National Transportation Safety Board said Sunday.

title: In a Beachside Tourist Town, a Wrenching Decision to Outsource
description: HALF MOON BAY, Calif.  Main Street in Half Moon Bay has all the trappings of a quaint, tourist-friendly town: a repertory theater, a collection of restaurants and more used books than one could ever read.

title: A Coney Island Rebirth, New Orleans Style
description: Business owners and others gathered to mourn the old Coney Island with a New Orleans funeral.

title: An Epidemic of Rape for Haitis Displaced
description: Life after Haitis earthquake has been especially difficult and dangerous for displaced women and girls. In addition to the ongoing crises of homelessness and cholera, a chronic emergency of sexual violence prevails in the settlements where hundreds of thousands still live, well over a year after the disaster.

title: Fixing the Mistake With Young Offenders
description: There is new evidence that state governments are finally understanding what a tragic mistake they made during the 1990s when they began trying ever larger numbers of children as adults instead of sending them to the juvenile justice system.

title: New State Museum Sanitizes Chinas Past
description: Even with a $380 million overhaul, the reopened National Museum of China exemplifies the Communist Partys determination to suppress alternative points of view and control the narrative of history.

title: Gains and Losses
description: After a long, scentless winter, apart from the tang of woodsmoke in the air, you could suddenly smell the earth again early one morning last week. It seems odd to call the scent fresh  it was darker and mustier than that  but fresh is how it felt, hovering like a ground fog above the last banks of snow. A whole field of clover could grow in that smell alone.

title: Found Art
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: At Chinas New Museum, History Toes Party Line
description: BEIJING  At the elaborately renovated National Museum of China in Tiananmen Square, visitors interested in the recent history of the worlds fastest rising power can gaze at the cowboy hat that Deng Xiaoping once wore when he visited the United States, or admire the bullhorn that President Hu Jintao used to exhort people to overcome hardship after the Sichuan earthquake in 2008.

title: Ruling Spurs Effort to Form Digital Public Library
description: Is the tantalizing dream of a universal library dead?

title: Discount Bus Industry Is Subject of Federal Safety Inquiry
description: The National Transportation Safety Board will conduct a comprehensive review of the discount bus industry and the safety regulations governing it following a crash in the Bronx last month that left 15 passengers dead, Senator Charles E. Schumer said Sunday.

title: 3 Partygoers Injured in Shooting Outside Brooklyn Banquet Hall
description: Three guests at a baby shower in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, were shot after trying to chase down two men who had tried to rob another guest, a witness and the police said Sunday.

title: Dark Past in Balkan War Intrudes on New Life
description: STANTON, Ky.  Nearly two decades after fleeing her native Croatia, the squat, hardworking woman known as Issabell Basic lived a quiet life in this small town, firing up her Jeep Cherokee each day for the 25-minute commute to her job making Hot Pockets.

title: Tug of War Between Cable Companies and Channels Comes to the iPad
description: The iPad, which went on sale a year ago, is becoming the latest battleground in a long-running fight over how TV programs will be delivered in the digital age, and who will deliver them.

title: A Colt Gives Clarity to the Derby Picture
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.  Robert LaPenta was not just being gracious. His colt Dialed In had just powered down the stretch like a locomotive to capture the $1 million Florida Derby, but LaPenta wanted to talk about what was one of the toughest fields assembled for a Triple Crown prep race in recent memory.

title: First L.P.G.A. Title Is a Major for Lewis
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  There is a knack to winning with the lead, to taking a third-round advantage and piloting it safely into the clubhouse. In a major championship, it helps to have the nerves of someone who lands jets on aircraft carriers.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the Institute for Supply Managements service sector index for March (Tuesday); retailers sales data for March, weekly jobless claims and consumer credit data for February (Thursday); and wholesale trade inventories for February (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Learning From His Mistakes, Freshman Grows on Calhoun
description: HOUSTON  The maturation of Connecticut guard Shabazz Napier, from the rough neighborhood he grew up in to his academic difficulties in high school to Mondays national championship game, played out in the final 16 seconds of the Huskies semifinal victory against Kentucky.

title: A Tea Party Star Stirs Iowans, and She Isnt Palin
description: WEST DES MOINES, Iowa  Sarah Palin, the reigning heroine of many social conservatives, has given few signals that she will make a presidential bid. Mike Huckabee, who won the Iowa caucuses in 2008 on the strength of his appeal to evangelicals and other constituencies, has mostly offered reasons for not joining the race.

title: Highest Final Four Rating Since 2005
description: Saturday nights Final Four broadcast on CBS posted an 8.9 rating and a 17 share. That tied for the highest since 2005.

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Lesson in Being a State Company
description: Last weeks ouster of the chief executive of Vale, the mining giant based in Rio de Janeiro, sends a terrible signal to the markets about the Brazilian governments intentions. The executive, Roger Agnelli, resisted the states designs to push the $180 billion company into lower-return, if labor-intensive, activities. With President Dilma Rousseffs government forcing his departure, investors must brace for a strategy that favors jobs over profit  in the fashion of Pemex instead of BHP Billiton.

title: Stanford Has Win in Hand, Until It Doesnt
description: INDIANAPOLIS  On basketball recruiting trips from Texas A&Ms campus, Coach Gary Blair frequently drove past the high school in suburban Houston where the Ogwumike sisters honed bounteous athletic and academic skills that would take them to Stanford.

title: Shutdown Watch: Five Days Out
description: With five days left until the federal governments spending authority runs out, Democrats and Republicans took to the Sunday talk shows. Lawmakers from both sides expressed optimism that a government shutdown was not likely, though they agreed that a deal was not yet done.

title: Edwin Gaustad, Religious Historian, Is Dead at 87
description: Edwin S. Gaustad, who took his place in the front rank of American religious historians with seminal works on the religious ideas of the founding fathers, especially Thomas Jefferson, and the arguments about church versus state that evolved from the dissenting sects in colonial America, died on March 25 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 87. The death was confirmed by his daughter Susan.

title: Center for Public Integrity to Start New Site for Investigative Journalism
description: The Center for Public Integrity will start a new Web site this month dedicated to investigative journalism.

title: Ben Silverman Sells Fashion Star to NBC, Network He Left
description: As always in the entertainment industry, business is business  and so, Ben Silverman is back in business with NBC.

title: After 40 Years, Still at Home in the Trenches
description: There are dead giveaways, some right out there in the open. Like that pistol on his hip, a Smith & Wesson Model 10: four-inch barrel, wood grip, nothing automatic, semi- or otherwise, about it. A more compact five-shot revolver is less visible, strapped to his ankle. It seems borrowed from the New York City Police Museum.

title: Web Shoppers Show a Cautious Trend
description: Online shoppers are taking longer to research their purchases, according to a study of consumer behavior across 32 large online retailers. Rather than buy on impulse, they first use the Web to gather information and compare prices.

title: UConns Youth Serves Notice
description: HOUSTON  Connecticut guard Kemba Walker is surrounded by youth. He has been all season. The Huskies regular rotation features five freshmen and two sophomores. It has for most of the season.

title: Looking Ahead to the Mens Title Game
description: All tournament long, Butler has been counted out and picked against because of its size deficit in the post. Teams like Old Dominion, Pittsburgh, Florida and Wisconsin were supposed to pound Butler into submission on the offensive glass. So against Connecticut in the N.C.A.A. title game, controlling the lane again becomes a key for Butler.

title: Word of the Day | fervid
description: fervid \fr-vd\ adjective

title: Transportation Chief to Unveil Pipeline Safety Effort
description: WASHINGTON  With so many pipeline accidents in the last few months that federal investigators cannot get to them all, the secretary of transportation plans to introduce a safety campaign on Monday aimed at coordinating federal, state and local oversight and making more information available to the public about potential hazards under foot.

title: Notre Dame Keeps Cool and Topples UConn
description: INDIANAPOLIS  This was the ending that Notre Dame had long hoped for and that Connecticut had feared.

title: I Stink! Illustrator Shows Elegant Work
description: Parents of small children probably know James McMullan as the creator (along with his wife, Kate) of the popular picture book I Stink! about the nightly rounds of a profoundly disgusting but hard-working New York City garbage truck. He is also enshrined in disco lore for the paintings he did more than 30 years ago for New York magazine that became the visual inspiration for Saturday Night Fever. But these days Mr. McMullan is much better known for the elegantly expressive show posters he makes for Lincoln Center Theater. Last week a large selection of those posters  for plays and musicals like Ah! Wilderness, Carousel, above, and South Pacific  went on display near the theater they helped promote, at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. The posters and other work will remain on view at the library through June 11. On Monday Mr. McMullan will join a fellow theatrical graphic artist, Frank Verlizzo, known as Fraver, at the library for a discussion about poster making.

title: Photo Replay: April 3
description: A look back at the day in sports, including the toppling of the top two womens seeds.

title: Porto Celebrates in the Dark at the Stadium of Light
description: Porto clinched its 25th Portuguese championship with a 2-1 victory over Benfica on Sunday. The evening was especially delicious for Porto and its fans because they were able to wrap up the title inside Benficas stadium, the Estdio da Luz in Lisbon.

title: Lollapalooza Chile: A World-Class Party Band
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Lollapalooza Chile has introduced me to a world-class party band: Chico Trujillo, a local favorite who had a huge crowd shouting along. Every party band needs a rhythm, and Aldo Asenjo, the bands leader and singer, relies on cumbia, the beat heard in countless variations across Latin America. Cumbia often trots calmly, but Chico Trujillos version gallops, bounding along; now and then, the music switches into rumba, equally upbeat. Mr. Asenjo sings lyrics as chattery and percussive as some hip-hop, taking on the ups and downs of love and life, with his voice answered by chortling horns  did he borrow the arranging idea from ska bands?  and a tootling, circusy organ. Syncopation, momentum and a way of romping through pain  a party band needs them all, and Chico Trujillo has them.

title: Biden to Discuss New Guidelines About Campus Sex Crimes
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is urging the nations schools and colleges to do more to prevent sexual violence, saying campus sex crimes often go unreported because victims fear that universities will not discipline offenders.

title: Yale Hockey Player Mandi Schwartz Dies of Leukemia
description: Mandi Schwartz, the Yale player who confronted her leukemia with support from hockey fans from Connecticut to western Canada, died Sunday in Regina, Saskatchewan. She was 23. Her death was confirmed by the university.

title: News Quiz | April 4, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Monitors Fault Voting in Kazakh Election
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  As President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan reveled in a landslide electoral victory on Monday, Western observers sharply criticized the conduct of the polls, saying they witnessed coercive get-out-the-vote measures, ballot-box stuffing and opposition candidates who openly supported the incumbent.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 4, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Mets Are Said to Be Suffering Sizable Losses.

title: Good News About the U.S. Economy?
description: HOW many jobs did the U.S. economy add in March?HOW many months in a row has there been private sector job growth?

description: Todays word, in association with the inspirational Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: What Ideas Do You Have for a Reality Show?
description: Just how absurd and/or desperate have makers of reality television become? asks a Times article that describes 17 new reality shows, eight of which are real and nine fake. Read all the descriptions and guess which are the real shows (Extreme Couponing? Last Man Mowing? Pregnant in Heels?) then describe for us a reality show that youd like to see on television  and why.

title: Solvay to Buy Rhodia for $4.8 Billion
description: 5:37 p.m. | Updated

title: Bodies From 2009 Air France Crash Are Found
description: PARIS  After three failed searches over nearly two years, more than $28 million spent on scores of specialists and the latest in deep-sea technology, not to mention a number of embarrassing premature sightings, French air accident investigators finally found what they were looking for in a sandy plain nearly two and a half miles below the surface of the southern Atlantic Ocean.

title: Japan Releases Low-Level Radioactive Water Into Ocean
description: TOKYO  The Tokyo Electric Power Company began dumping more than 11,000 tons of radioactive water from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant into the Pacific Ocean on Monday, mostly to make room in storage containers for increasing amounts of far more contaminated runoff.

title: Afghan Officer Turns Against U.S. Soldiers, Killing 2
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two American soldiers were shot to death by an Afghan police officer on Monday in northern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said. It was at least the third time this year that Afghan security personnel had turned on coalition soldiers.

title: Tax Havens and Treasure Hunts
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: The Early Word: A Tea Party Star
description: From Todays Times:

title: In Madrid, Food Workshops for Kids and Adults
description: The Gourmets Senses Workshop (Pavillion 8, Feria de Madrid; www.gourmets.net), running April 11 to 14, should provide even the very choosiest of food lovers with a thorough and tasty education in the new specialty foods from Spain and other parts of the world. The only section of the trade fair Salon de Gourmets open to the public, the Workshop offers an introduction to the best new olive oils, vinegars, smoked meats, foie gras, sauces, cheeses, spices, pastries and almost every other imaginable delicacy.

title: 2010 Saints: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the N.F.C. South:

title: Obama Begins Re-Election Facing New Political Challenges
description: 7:34 a.m. | Updated President Obama confirmed Monday morning that he would seek another four years in the White House, beginning a re-election campaign that would ask Americans to endorse the status quo over the increasingly vocal calls from Republicans for a fresh start in Washington.

title: Who Really Freed the Slaves
description: If you enjoyed the story about Maj. Gen. Benjamin F. Butler and how he came to shelter fugitive slaves within Fort Monroe (an excerpt from Adam Goodhearts book 1861: The Civil War Awakening) in the April 3 issue of the magazine, you may be interested in a column Goodheart wrote a few weeks back for the Opinionator, which reminds us how much Butlers position went against the conventions of the time. In it, Goodheart describes what happened to a young slave, likely a teenager, who paddled a canoe for several hours in the dark, across open water, to seek refuge in Fort Sumter.

title: U.S. Moving to a Support Role in Libya
description: BRUSSELS  The United States began to remove its warplanes from front-line missions in Libya on Monday and instead focus on a support role there, a NATO official said.

title: Libyan Rebels Complain of Deadly Delays Under NATOs Command
description: BREGA, Libya  A senior Libyan rebel leader sharply criticized NATO on Monday for bureaucratic delays that he said were putting civilians lives at risk and complicating rebel efforts to fight the Qaddafi forces on the ground.

title: Q&A: Snapping the Screen on a PC or Mac
description: Q.

title: Breaking Records (of Sorts) With Toyota Prius
description: Large corporations and wacky marketing campaigns can make for some cringe-worthy viewing. But credit Toyota Motor Corporation for at least trying harder than most, thanks to a series of more than 200 record attempts centered on the Japanese automakers Prius hybrid. Held in cooperation with the grandiose-sounding and entirely irreverent Universal Record Database, the goal was to establish at least 200 bizarre Prius-related records over two days.

title: The Growing Business of Online Reputation Management
description: Over the weekend I wrote an article for Sunday Styles about new Web services that deal with a new problem  online reputation management. These businesses have cropped up over the past few years to address one major negative aspect of our online world: As quickly as images, blog posts, commentary, status updates and photos are posted on the Web, they are replicated by algorithms and search engines, and dissipate like an airborne virus. The Internet is a permanent record of our past, and it never forgets anything posted online.

title: This Week in Small Business: Democrats and Republicans Talk
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Hackers Turn a Gmail April Fools Joke Into a Reality
description: If you happened upon the Internet Friday, you would have been faced with what has now become an annual tradition online: Technology companies trying to one-up each otherwith April Fools jokes posted online.

title: Vu1 Light Bulb Delayed (Again)
description: In my recent New York Timesstory about a new light bulb technology that hopes to go head-to-head with compact fluorescent and LED lamps, I mentioned that the lamp, developed by the Vu1 Corporation, was scheduled to ship two weeks ago. The lamp did not ship, but the company issued a press release on Thursday stating that the lamps would begin shipping on April 13. The company also said that it had increased the lamps effective life to 11,000 hours from 10,000.

title: Morning Buzz | Opposition to Plans for 9/11 Victims Remains
description: Its warming up to a high of 67, but expect rain to come with it. Showers are forecast all day, with thunderstorms in the evening.

title: Shakespeare in Left Field
description: Bill James is rattling his sabremetrician-ness again. On Wednesday, he published an essay in Slate, Verlander and Shakespeare. Its pretty great for reasons highlighted by its subtitle, Why are we so good at developing athletes and so lousy at developing writers? Throw a brush-back pitch like that and youre sure to start a conversation. So much to argue with! The premise itself. Two gross assumptions underlying the premise. Then, another level down, the issue of what developing means. And good. And lousy. And we  who does that refer to, exactly? Just wait till you get to the actual arguments.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian: Leek, Potato and Zucchini Pancakes With Baby Lettuces
description: One way James Laird, the executive chef and owner of Restaurant Serenade in Chatham, N.J., makes his leek, potato and zucchini pancakes more flavorful is to cook the leeks thoroughly.

title: Congresss Big Budget Week
description: Budget weeks in Congress dont get any bigger than this one.

title: Pfizer Sells Capsule Unit to K.K.R.
description: Pfizer said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its Capsugel unit, which makes a variety of capsules for drugs, to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company for $2.375 billion in cash.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Childrens Academic Scores Affected by a Parents Deployment
description: A new study by the RAND Corporation offers more evidence that children of deployed troops experience more problems than other military children.

title: MLK Assassination Anniversary
description: On this day in 1968, Martin Luther King, who had gone to Memphis to support striking black sanitation workers, was assassinated. Theres a labor event in Trenton commemorating the event, later this morning; Ill be there.

title: Sbarro Files for Bankruptcy
description: Sbarro, the private-equity-owned pizza chain, filed for bankruptcy on Monday as it looked to cut its debt and restructure its balance sheet.

title: Privatizing Medicare
description: So theyre really going to propose it.

title: Regular Old Twins
description: This Sundays Lives column by the novelist Samantha Hunt is not about twiblings; that was the subject of the cover article by Melanie Thernstrom a few months ago, about having two babies born five days apart to two surrogate mothers. And its not about I.V.F.-produced multiples of any kind. Its about good old-fashioned twins, the idea of which, not to mention the physical space they take up inside their mothers-to-be in the last weeks before birth, apparently creeps some people out. A different sort of creepiness can be found in Hunts short story The Yellow, which was published by The New Yorker in November. Youre advised to check it out.

title: Apax Partners to Buy 2 Software Makers for $2 Billion
description: The private equity firm Apax Partners agreed to buy the business software makers Epicor Software and Activant Solutions for about $2 billion, the firm announced on Monday.

title: Face Time | Priyanka Chopra
description: I have always been drawn to the beauty of Indian women, so when I got the chance to speak to Priyanka Chopra, I was excited. She won both Miss India and Miss World in 2000, at the age of 17. Soon after, in 2002, she began her Bollywood career with the The Hero. She now shoots about four movies a year, among many other projects. Shes not afraid of a 20-hour work day  or junk food. I recently got to share a few beauty moments with her.

title: Hedge Fund Criticizes Iron Managements Rights Plan
description: 1:29 p.m. | Updated The hedge fund Elliott Management on Monday released a letter sent to the board of Iron Mountain questioning the companys recent adoption of a shareholder rights plan, or poison pill.

title: The Transmission Mechanism for Quantitative Easing (Wonkish)
description: Its now widely claimed that QE2 has been a success  and for sure, the US economy, which seemed to be sliding into a deflationary morass last summer, has perked up since then. But why? A few thoughts.

title: Sanofi Wraps Up Its Genzyme Offer
description: Sanofi-Aventis said on Monday that it had wrapped up its exchange offer for all Genzyme shares, an offer that expired just before midnight on Friday.

title: Scientists Link New Genes to Alzheimers
description: The Times reports this morning that two enormous studies have linked five genes to the development of Alzheimers disease. The associations are not strong  each gene confers an increase in risk of just 10 to 15 percent  but they should help point researchers to new mechanisms underlying this dementia.

title: Monday Morning Skate: Playoff Races, Key Injuries and Childbirth via Twitter
description: Plus/Minus

title: Behind the Wizards Wand: Making the Harry Potter Films
description: Many adult Muggles will, no doubt, think as I did before visiting Harry Potter: The Exhibition, which opens at Discovery Times Square on Tuesday. I mistakenly assumed that the real point of this 14,000-square-foot display of movie sets, costumes and props would come at the end, where Potterphiles can line up to purchase $44.99 replicas of Albus Dumbledores magic wand or $49.99 replicas of Gryffindors school tie, as they prepare, perhaps, to go in style to see the sagas final film this summer.

title: Reverse Diving
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously shared their favorite April Fools pranks.

title: Insight Venture Partners Raises $2 Billion
description: The venture capital firm Insight Venture Partners announced on Monday it was closing two new funds, which together represent $2 billion in new commitments.

title: April 4 Updates on Mideast Protests and Libyan War
description: On Monday, The Lede is following protest movements across the Middle East and North Africa and the war in Libya. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Libya, read the frequently updated main news article from our colleagues there.

title: Israel Scours Palestinian Village in Hunt for Killers
description: AWARTA, West Bank  In the rolling hills of the northern West Bank, Palestinian villages and Israeli settlements exist in a geographical intimacy that belies decades of mutual hostility, suspicion and fear.

title: Clashes Escalate in Yemen; at Least 12 Protesters Are Killed
description: SANA, Yemen  Deadly violence broke out Monday across Yemen amid signs that the United States had concluded that President Ali Abdullah Saleh, a longtime ally, must be eased out of office.

title: Detroit Symphony Orchestra Has Tentative Deal
description: Striking musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and their management have reached a tentative contract agreement amid a crippling strike that forced the cancellation of the season, both sides said on Monday.

title: Man Arrested After Threat to Islamic Group in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  A man wearing a fake explosive belt was arrested here on Monday after he entered the offices of an Islamic opposition party and said he would blow himself up if the head of the office did not appear, party officials and police said.

title: Pawlenty Responds to Obama With a Video of His Own
description: How do you respond to a slickly produced video by the president of the United States? If you are Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, you respond with a slickly produced video of your own.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: If Youth Can Post Its Facebook Status, Age Can, Too
description: The students shuffled one by one into the sun-dappled Clasons Point branch of the New York Public Library, on Morrison Avenue in the Bronx, taking their seats at round orange tables laden with computers.

title: In Xinjiang, Exploring a Changing Story
description: Carolyn Drake could probably stop now. Her project on the Uighurs, a group of Turkic-speaking Muslims in western China, started in 2007 on her first trip to Xinjiang Province. Her most recent visit was in February. The images she has captured are vibrant, poetic and incredibly varied in scope.

title: Lollapalooza Chile: Tough Female Rappers, Janes Addiction and Polite Dancers
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Latin America loves smart, tough female rappers: Anita Tijoux on Saturday and, on Sunday afternoon, Mala Rodrguez from Spain. Ms. Rodrguez performed wearing a kind of corset, along with pink knee socks, but in her songs she is no bimbo. Her delivery  mostly rapped, occasionally sung  is rapid-fire enough to leave most rappers breathless; her message is self-realization without apologies, limits or inhibitions. Its bragging, flirting, philosophizing and flinging ultimatums. When she called for the crowd to join in, it was to chant Fuerte!  Strong!

title: Monday Reading: I.R.S. Offers Free Tax Software
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Desserts for the Conscientious
description: What is a healthy dessert? For starters, I think that a dessert can be healthy if it has some nutritive value  if sugar, butter and refined flour arent at its core. Certainly fresh fruit qualifies on this score, and two of the best for desserts, apples and pears, are readily available even now, when spring has barely begun.

title: Expedia Adds App for Hotel Bookings
description: Expedia.com is joining the ranks of Priceline and Hotels.com by offering travelers the ability to book hotel rooms through a free app. The Expedia Hotels app  due on iTunes for iPhone and iPod Touch early this month and for Android devices a few weeks after that  allows travelers to reserve rooms in 130,000 hotels in more than 200 countries.

title: Numberplay: Circular Logic
description: A manhole would never fall on someone. Thats not why theyre round. Youd never put a manhole cover on the hole when someones in there. Not even as a prank. And its not going to just slide over by itself.

title: F.A.A. to Order Airlines to Inspect 737s for Cracks
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced on Monday that it would require extensive inspections of some older-model Boeing 737s for cracks in the planes fragile skin that can be caused by pressurization and depressurization of the cabin over tens of thousands of takeoffs and landings.

title: Disaster Memory and the Flooding of Fukushima
description: 2:50 p.m. | Updated below with astounding video from Kesennuma, Japan |Over the weekend, I mused on a question thats bothered me since I read Roger Bilhams report on the great earthquake and tsunami of March 11: Given the history of devastating tsunamis not far away, how could it have taken until 2006 for the word tsunami to show up in government guidelines related to the Fukushima nuclear complex? (For instance, in 1933 a tsunami more than 90 feet high erased coastal villages along part of the same stretch of Honshu coast devastated on March 11.)

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: More than 1,800 health care company leaders and top government officials are expected at the 8th Annual World Health Care Congress in Washington Monday through Wednesday.

title: Leading Vietnamese Dissident Sentenced to Prison
description: BANGKOK  A prominent Vietnamese legal scholar who sued the prime minister and called for multiparty democracy was convicted of propaganda against the state Monday and sentenced to seven years in prison and another three years under house arrest. The case was one of the most highly charged political trials in Vietnam in years.

title: Google Bidding on Nortel Patents
description: Google said Monday it is bidding $900 million on the patent portfolio of Nortel, the communications technology company that filed for bankruptcy in 2009.

title: Wheelies: The Express Yourself Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Where Are The Shakespeares of Topeka?
description: I was going to write a response to the baseball savant Bill Jamess peculiar Opening Day reflections on why America is (supposedly) better at developing athletic talent than literary talent, but happily Alan Jacobs beat me to it. Jamess piece begins by noting that the population of a city like Topeka, Kan., is roughly similar to the population of London in the age of Shakespeare, and then suggests the absence of a Topekan Shakespeare is evidence that Elizabethan England was better at cultivating men of letters than contemporary America  whereas were better at cultivating professional athletes:

title: Nice House, Quiet Block, Grisly History
description: At first glance, it would seem peculiar that someone has not already snapped up the century-old brick home for sale at 21 Howard Place in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn. It has sun-filled rooms, a stately porch, proximity to Prospect Park and a front yard where a salmon-colored impatiens bush, stacks of flower pots and a statue of St. Francis with a squirrel on his shoulder hint at the urban gardening possibilities.

title: Leading Off: Butler Spreads Underdog Fever
description: The Butler mens basketball team has accomplished something truly amazing and no, were not even talking about the stupendous achievement of making two straight N.C.A.A. championship game appearances. No, Butler has gone and turned an entire sport on its head.

title: The Grapes of Wrath, in Burgundy
description: Its a great and twisted yarn, a little too dark for Peter Mayle, but perhaps just macabre enough for Roald Dahl. Somebody was poisoning the great pinot noir vines of Romane-Conti, the nonpareil grand cru vineyard of the Domaine de la Romane-Conti. Only, this was not a short story, it actually happened.

title: Zambia Drops Case of Shooting by Chinese Mine Bosses
description: JOHANNESBURG  In what could be a politically explosive decision, prosecutors in Zambia have decided not to pursue a case against two Chinese supervisors who shot 13 coal miners last year during a wage protest, the managers lawyer said Monday.

title: Bosie Tea Parlor Is Opening in the Village
description: Nicky Dawda rented a nice storefront in Greenwich Village, planning to do some renovations and open a tearoom with the tea expert Kiley Holliday. Simple enough? That was 18 months ago. Now after dealing with city codes, their tearoom, Bosie Tea Parlor, will open on Thursday with about 100 of Ms. Hollidays hand-selected Lge de Th teas in golden canisters on the shelves.

title: Would You Buy a House Where Someone Was Killed?
description: For decades, Howard Place in Brooklyn was a quiet block in Windsor Terrace where the biggest news took place when Helen Hunt filmed shots there for the 1997 movie As Good as It Gets. That changed on Dec. 13, when Ryan Devaney, a troubled resident, tried to kill his parents in their home at 21 Howard Place, and then tried to kill himself by throwing himself in front of a G train. His mother died. Mr. Devaney awaits trial, and his father, who survived, has moved.

title: Nice Argument, Counselor, but Lets Hear Mine
description: WASHINGTON

title: Its All Him | Jerry Weintraub
description: Monday night at 9, HBO will broadcast His Way, a new documentary about the Hollywood producer Jerry Weintraub. The guy is beyond a legend. His recent film credits include Oceans Eleven, Oceans Twelve, and Oceans Thirteen, and go back to The Karate Kid, and Robert Altmans Nashville. Before devoting himself to making movies, he managed and/or promoted musicians like John Denver, Elvis Presley, Led Zeppelin, the Carpenters, Frank Sinatra and Neil Young.

title: In a Reversal, Military Trials for 9/11 Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, ending more than a year of indecision with a major policy reversal, will prosecute Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other people accused of plotting the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks before a military commission and not a civilian court, as it once planned.

title: Harvard M.B.A. Students Stroll the Catwalk for Charity
description: 2:03 p.m. | Updated

title: Butlers Back-to-Back Championship Appearances a 7,500-to-1 Longshot
description: Last week, we established that Virginia Commonwealth had only about 1-in-820 odds of winning five consecutive games and reaching the Final Four. Although V.C.U.s run ended with a loss to Butler in Houston on Saturday, the feat ranks right among anything else accomplished over the course of a single N.C.A.A. tournament; it was about as unlikely as Villanova winning the national title, as a No. 8 seed, in 1985.

title: Muggles Up Close
description: Images from Harry Potter: The Exhibition at Discovery Times Square.

title: In Last-Minute Action, Texas Inmate Disputes Use of Execution Drug
description: A former Army recruiter convicted of killing a woman he met in a Fort Worth bar nine years ago is scheduled to be executed Tuesday, though his lawyers were seeking a last-minute reprieve on Monday as part of a challenge to one of the drugs that is to be used to kill him.

title: VanDerveers Disappointment Tempered by Selection to Hall
description: Over the past 24 hours, Stanford Coach Tara VanDerveer has been through the gamut from sorrow to happiness.

title: The Claim: You Cannot Get Sunburned Through a Car Window
description: THE FACTS

title: Black-Market Trinkets From Space
description: Ebay and other Web sites pulse with hundreds of sales pitches. The pieces below have an exceptional patina, a site called Star-bits.com said of 10 pictured fragments.

title: Lost Tape Is Found in Trial of Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A courtroom development worthy of Law & Order unfolded at Barry Bondss perjury trial on Monday, the day the government was expected to wrap up its case.

title: Freedom Group Seeks to Pull I.P.O.
description: Freedom Group, the owner of of Remington Arms and Bushmaster Firearms, has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to withdraw its filing for an initial public offering.

title: Widget Effect
description: The detrimental effect of treating teachers as homogeneous and easily interchangeable.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Tony Kaye Film and Kings of Leon Documentary Added to Tribeca Lineup
description: A filmmaker and a rock group who have never been shy about expressing themselves will be represented in new offerings at the Tribeca Film Festival, the festivals organizers announced on Monday.

title: Tunis to Allow Italy to Help Patrol Coast
description: ROME  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy flew to Tunis on Monday to meet with Tunisian officials in an effort to stem the waves of desperate migrants that have landed on the shores of the Italian island of Lampedusa in the past three months. Mr. Berlusconi said that 800 had landed in Lampedusa overnight on Sunday alone.

title: Unions Rally, Linking Their Cause to Dr. King
description: Labor unions and civil rights groups held hundreds of rallies and teach-ins on Monday to defend collective bargaining and to tie it to the cause the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was fighting for in the days before his death exactly 43 years ago.

title: The Dependence Economy
description: Over the weekend I attended a talk by Credit Suisses chief economist, Neal Soss, on the structural and cyclical challenges facing the economy. The cheekily titled chart below  showing how much more dependent Americans have become on government money, including in many cases Tea Partiers  is taken from his presentation:

title: A Brief History of Primary Polling, Part II
description: This is the second part of a three-part series exploring the reliability of early primary polls in forecasting the winner of a presidential nomination.

title: Supreme Court Allows Tax Credit for Religious Tuition
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday let stand an Arizona program that aids religious schools, saying in a 5-to-4 decision that the plaintiffs had no standing to challenge it.

title: New Fanta Commercial
description: One of the Fanta's new commercials for TV, online and YouTube.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: American Cancer Society, Atlanta, selected Hipcricket, Kirkland, Wash., for a new assignment, as its national mobile agency of record. Spending has not been determined.

title: Blagojevich Asks for Notes From F.B.I. Interview With Obama
description: CHICAGO  Lawyers for Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, are asking a judge for access to notes from an interview President Obama had with federal authorities over his former Senate seat.

title: The Unasked Question at Berkshire Hathaway
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Katie Couric Has a Few Regrets
description: When you started hosting the CBS Evening News in 2006, there was a lot of talk about mold-breaking. Now the show looks very much like the other network broadcasts.  In retrospect I would have given people what they were used to, a traditional newscast. And then as they got to know me and got more comfortable, then I wouldve started toying with the format and trying new things. I think we were overly ambitious. We probably would have been better off playing it a little safer.

title: Now, Hit Play if You Want a Fanta
description: In the late 1960s, PepsiCo sold its flagship soft drink with a slogan that proclaimed, Taste that beats the others cold, Pepsi pours it on. These many years later, it is the PepsiCo rival, the Coca-Cola Company, that seems to be letting loose.

title: President Obama's Re-Election Effort
description: John Harwood of CNBC and The New York Times and Jeff Zeleny of The New York Times discussed what to expect in the weeks ahead as President Obama's re-election effort gets underway.

title: Country Music Awards Lift CBS in Ratings
description: The Academy of Country Music Awards led Sunday night in the ratings for CBS, as an average of 13 million viewers tuned in to the award show broadcast from 8 to 11 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. CBS won the night over all, drawing 10.3 million to lead the 7 p.m. time slot as well with 60 Minutes. ABC placed a solid second, as 9.7 million watched Secret Millionaire at 8, followed by Desperate Housewives (8.8 million) and Body of Proof (8.4 million) at 9 and 10. NBC ranked third, with 8.5 million for The Celebrity Apprentice from 9 to 11 but lower ratings for Dateline at 7 (5.2 million) and Americas Next Great Restaurant at 8 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with mostly reruns of its animated comedy lineup.

title: Empire Building | Paige Novick
description: Architecture has always been my inspiration, says Paige Novick, who has been designing her eponymous line of costume jewelry for the past four years. This fall she will unveil Phyne, her first fine jewelry collection, adding precious stones into pieces made from metals like sterling silver alloy, more often found in factories than in your mothers jewelry box. The delicate black rhodium and diamond speckled octagonal rings, geometric earrings spiraling with precious stones and metal and gem-tiered cuffs were created, she says, with the Empire State Building in mind, but there may be another muse who deserves some credit here. My mother is a fine jeweler, Novick explains with a smile. Its in my DNA.

title: Multitude of Species Face Climate Threat
description: Over the past 540 million years, life on Earth has passed through five great mass extinctions. In each of those catastrophes, an estimated 75 percent or more of all species disappeared in a few million years or less.

title: Small Banks and Small Businesses Battle Over Swipe Fees
description: Last week was a busy one for those following the battle over rules limiting the fees banks can charge to process debit card transaction. On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, acknowledged that the board, swamped by public comments on its proposed rules, would miss its deadline for completing those rules. Meanwhile, some senators are trying to legislate a further delay in carrying out the rules with two more years of study on the issue, and grocery and convenience store owners have converged on Washington to try to keep efforts to delay, or repeal, the new rules at bay.

title: Obama Invites Boehner for a Budget Talk
description: President Obama invited the speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, and three other Congressional leaders to the White House on Tuesday in hopes of wrapping up a bipartisan agreement on federal spending for the rest of this fiscal year and avoiding a shutdown of the government.

title: 18-Month-Old Foster Child, Severely Beaten, Dies
description: Updated | 3:55 p.m. Kymell Oram, the 18-month-old foster child who the authorities say was severely beaten by his foster mothers 19-year-old boyfriend last month, died last week at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, officials said.

title: The Disappearing School Nurse
description: This from a troubling article on Parenting.com today:

title: Maine Museum to Get Newly Discovered 1840s Murals
description: Newly discovered 1840s murals of inlets, willows, lighthouses and sailing ships are being extricated this week from a house in East Baldwin, Me., for transfer to the Rufus Porter Museum and Cultural Heritage Center in nearby Bridgton. The owners have donated three roomfuls of the scenery, painted by the muralist Rufus Porters nephew Jonathan Poor, along with underlying layers of plaster and lath, fireplace mantels and an entire staircase. The museum is raising $60,000 for the dismantling work, by the salvager David Ottinger, and is renovating an 1830s house that will accommodate the acquisition. Poor died in his early 40s, soon after completing the work for a local physician, perhaps because mural painting was a hazardous profession. My supposition is that all the materials they worked with were poisonous, Julie Lindberg, the Porter museums curator, said.

title: Prosecutor Says Profit Was Behind Deutsche Fire
description: A prosecutor at the trial of three construction supervisors charged in the deaths of two firefighters at the former Deutsche Bank building told the jury on Monday that the defendants had put profit over people, a decision that led to the deaths and put the lives of hundreds of firefighters, inspectors and workers at risk.

title: Jeffrey Katzenberg, DreamWorks Chief, Joins Zyngas Board
description: Bound by a mutual love for animated animals  and profits  Jeffrey Katzenberg, chief executive of DreamWorks Animation SKG, has joined Zyngas board, the company announced Monday.

title: When Katie Couric Met Andrew Goldman
description: Apparently, its official: Katie Couric will no longer anchor the CBS Evening News. Its hardly a surprise. She has been hinting at a move for ages, and speculation that she wouldnt last has been gurgling pretty much since her first day in the anchors chair five years ago. But rarely was she ever so open with her ambivalence about the job as she was in an interview with Andrew Goldman, which appears in the April 10 issue of the magazine but which were publishing online now. Goldman conducted it on Friday, March 25, the day before Couric took off for a pre-big-news vacation to Turks and Caicos. Although she wouldnt confirm that she was leaving the show  she was more interested in discussing her new book, The Best Advice I Ever Got: Lessons From Extraordinary Lives  she expressed some regrets about trying to push the nightly-news genre too far too fast and she floated a theory (though she wouldnt put her name behind it) that CBSs local news lead-ins might have kept her mired in third place.

title: Police Raid Shanghai Gay Bar and Detain More Than 60
description: BEIJINGMore than 60 patrons and employees at a gay bar in Shanghai were swept up in a police raid early Sunday morning and held for more 12 hours, according to the state media and several of those detained.

title: After Breach, Companies Warn of E-Mail Fraud
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Security experts said Monday that millions of people were at increased risk of e-mail swindles after a giant security breach at an online marketing firm.

title: Sale Sets Record for Living Chinese Artist
description: SHANGHAI  A triptych oil painting by Zhang Xiaogang sold for $10.1 million on Sunday at a Sothebys auction in Hong Kong. The sale broke the record for a piece by a living Chinese artist, and was the latest sign of Chinas phenomenal ascent in the global art market.

title: On Our Radar: Salazar Slams Transocean Over Bonuses
description: Interior Secretary Ken Salazar criticizes Transocean, which operated the Deepwater Horizon rig that exploded in the Gulf of Mexico last year, killing 11, for awarding executives bonuses for the best year in safety performance in our companys history. Mr. Salazar says the company was at least at some fault for causing the catastrophe. In my own view, 2010 was probably the greatest year of pain in terms of oil and gas development in the deep water all across the world, especially in the Gulf of Mexico, he said. [Reuters]

title: Good Eats in Paris
description: Jeremy Zilar, the Times blog guru, put together a map of some of my best Paris restaurant recommendations. The comments in the map are mine. Note that most of these places are small, so book ahead if at all possible; the chances of getting a walk-in table are generally not good. For more details on many of these, see:

title: Taped Calls About Akamai Earnings Guidance Heard at Galleon Trial
description: 8:48 p.m. | Updated

title: Bloomberg Hails Moving of Terror Trial
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Monday applauded the Obama administrations decision to move the trial of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, from a Manhattan courtroom to Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Keep Your Eye on the Ball
description: Q. I often see what look like basketballs on overhead electrical wires. What are they?

title: The Curious Case of the Washington Elms That Are Unlike Any Other
description: If a tree in a forest has fewer chromosomes but there is no one to there conduct a genetic analysis, is it any different from the others?

title: Killer of L.I. Motivational Speaker Is Sentenced
description: Every day in the Manhattan Criminal Courthouse, convicted murderers are sentenced to hard time for taking the lives of people who never asked to die. On Monday in Room 1111, Kenneth Minor got 20 years to life for killing a man who did.

title: A Warning on Overuse Injuries for Youths
description: Just as warming weather brings millions of young athletes back onto sports fields, a major athletics association has renewed this warning: Some school-age competitors who are inadequately prepared, or improperly coached, continue to develop serious overuse injuries.

title: Indictment and Unsealing Order
description: The Justice Department disclosed that a grand jury had indicted Khalid Sheikh Mohammed and four others accused in the Sept. 11 attacks under seal in December 2009. It released the 81-page indictment, along with an order unsealing and dismissing it, on Monday.

title: Collecting Seawater From the Depths
description: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

title: Prominent Israelis Will Propose a Peace Plan
description: JERUSALEM  A group of prominent Israelis, including former heads of Mossad, Shin Bet and the military, are this week putting forth an initiative for peace with the Arab world that they hope will generate popular support and influence their government as it faces international pressure to move peace talks forward.

title: BMW M5: A Glimpse of What Is to Come
description: The eagerly awaited BMW M5 wont make its debut at the Shanghai auto show, which opens to the press on April 19, but it will come within an eyelash of its debut. What will be shown at Shanghai is the BMW Concept M5, which the automaker characterized in a Monday news release as a glimpse at the fifth generation of a legend.

title: Regular Fasting May Boost Heart Health
description: Regular fasting may be good for your heart.

title: Charlie Sheen Turns Things Around in Chicago
description: In a turnaround that seems way out of character for Charlie Sheen, the former Two and a Half Men star revamped his one-man show in time to garner applause from his audience in Chicago, one day after alienating a boisterous, liquored-up capacity crowd in Detroit that greeted Mr. Sheen with cheers that quickly turned to boos, according to The Timess A.O. Scott.

title: Ai Weiweis New York Project to Go Forward, With or Without Him
description: A large-scale public art project by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, to occupy the Pulitzer Fountain outside the Plaza Hotel starting early next month, will go forward even if Mr. Ai, who was detained by the Chinese authorities on Sunday, is unable to be present.

title: N.B.A. Prospects Are Facing Uncertainty Over Declaring
description: HOUSTON  Once the afterglow of the N.C.A.A. tournament fades after Mondays national championship game, the focus of the college basketball world will inevitably shift to the N.B.A. draft.

title: On Eve of Meeting in Washington, Israel Announces More Housing Construction
description: JERUSALEM  On the eve of a White House meeting between President Obama and President Shimon Peres of Israel, officials here took steps on Monday to advance controversial new housing in the West Bank and a disputed area of Jerusalem.

title: David Foster Wallaces Unfinished Novel  and Life
description: Every writer dies, probably, still intending to write something. Its a basic fact of (to put it slightly trivially) scheduling: the time lines of mortality and ambition rarely coincide. Thomas Aquinas finished only the first two sections of his Summa Theologica  a work that would loom over philosophical thought for centuries  before (according to some biographers) he hit his head on a branch while riding a donkey and plunged into his final illness. Walter Benjamin worked for 13 years on his magisterial Arcades Project but left it unfinished when he committed suicide to avoid falling into the hands of the Nazis. The list could go on almost indefinitely, with works snuffed out by illness (Flauberts Bouvard and Pcuchet) and genocide (Nmirovskys Suite Francaise) and alcoholic dissipation (Flann OBriens Slatterys Sago Saga). The loss is particularly hard when an author seems to have been really humming along  when the last big thing was a masterpiece and the next one promised to be another. Dostoyevsky, the novelist Norman Rush has said, died still intending to write another volume of The Brothers Karamazov. Its like a knife in my heart that he didnt.

title: N.F.L. Draft: D.J. Williams, Third-Ranked Tight End
description: 3.D.J. Williams, Arkansas (6-2, 245)

title: Making a Commitment: Memorizing and Reciting
description: Overview | What is the value of memorization and recitation? What are some helpful strategies for committing text to memory? In this lesson, students share some of the things they have already learned by heart and then select meaningful passages to memorize and recite to the class. After everyone has recited their selections, they reflect on the process and experience.

title: On Not Learning From Experience
description: Ill no doubt be writing a lot about the Republican plan to dismantle Medicare in the days ahead. But a quick thought now before I go off to listen to Bob Hall explain the high-unemployment, zero-rate trap (pdf).

title: Video: President Obamas Re-Election Effort
description: Read John Harwoods related story, G.O.Ps 2012 Strategy Puts Focus on Timing, published in Mondays Times.

title: Extending Worms Lives, and Maybe Ours
description: Scientists have found a fountain of youth, at least for the tiny C. elegans worm.

title: With 3-Week Break, Women Pros Scatter
description: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif.  The L.P.G.A. Tour is less like a marathon than a gymnastics tumbling run: stretches of intense action set off by long recovery periods.

title: Diabetes Increases Risk of Cancer Death
description: Diabetes has long been associated with a host of serious health problems, including increased risk of vision loss, kidney problems, heart attack and stroke. Now a growing body of research shows that diabetes also increases risk for deadly cancers.

title: U.S. Government Will Exhaust Ability to Borrow in July
description: The federal government will exhaust its ability to borrow money under current law during the second week of July, the Treasury Department said in a letter sent Monday to members of Congress.

title: Admissions Figures on Elon, Harvey Mudd, Brandeis and Nearly 100 Other Colleges
description: In the few days since my colleague Eric Platt and I began publishing our running tally on how many students applied to  and were accepted by  various colleges and universities this year, the ledger has more than doubled, to 100.

title: Leaving an Impression That Has Lasted Forever
description: About 315 million years ago, an insect landed on a muddy patch, sat for a while and flew off.

title: Perot Family Gave to Tea Party Candidates in 2010
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who received nearly 19 percent of the vote for president as an independent candidate in 1992, did not go out of his way to align himself publicly with the Tea Party movement during the 2010 midterm elections, despite the fact that the movement is organized around the principles of small government and fiscal restraint on which his campaign was based. But during six days leading up to the November elections, members of the Perot family contributed $172,000 to 22 Republicans running for the House, many under the Tea Party banner.

title: Quora Makes Changes Aimed at Doctors and Lawyers
description: Since Quora, a question-and-answer start-up , was first introduced last June, it has become something of a Web darling among tech denizens, engineers and early adopters. But the conversations on Quora have quickly fanned out beyond new media and technology. A spin through the site reveals a wide range of topics currently under discussion, including white chocolate, the rapper Lil Waynes ascent to stardom and ways to alleviate car sickness in babies.

title: Hes In!
description: When President Obama confirmed Monday morning that he would seek re-election, his team immediately geared up for the fundraising, releasing this video.

title: Notes From the Underground | o.F.F.
description: The Berlin-based French musician known as o.F.F. performed his brand of sensitive, semi-ambient electronic R&B for a small crowd in at Faktory in Reykjavik, Iceland, last week. Shrouded in a yin yang patterned scarf tucked into his baseball hat, o.F.F. crooned of lost loves and their workings on his heart, while Kira Brekkan, his special guest for the evening, writhed stage left, contributing soft sound effects. o.F.F. wandered into the crowd, presenting red roses to select beautiful young Icelanders, delicately painting a picture of himself as a lover, not a fighter.

title: Can the iPhone Revive the Home Movie?
description: On Saturday evening, I, along with thousands of other fervent music fans, was jammed into Madison Square Garden in New York, helping bid LCD Soundsystem adieu when I noticed a fellow concertgoer filming part of the show with his smartphone. I stopped bouncing for a few minutes to watch him record when I realized that the application capturing the action on stage was using a filtered lens, much like the ones that help give photos snapped with Instagram and Path their vintage veneer.

title: Winter, a Guru of Offense, Ends Wait to Join the Hall
description: Tex Winter, an innovator of the triangle offense; Chris Mullin, who led St. Johns to the Final Four in 1985; and Dennis Rodman, a colorful player known for his rebounding, were selected for the Basketball Hall of Fame on Monday.

title: Promising Debut for The Killing and The Kennedys
description: 3:50 p.m. | Updated

title: Married Gay Couples Refuse to Lie on Tax Forms
description: Some same-sex married couples are refusing to file their federal tax returns separately this tax season, as part of a movement demonstrating that theyre no longer content to quietly comply with the federal law that does not recognize same-sex marriage. And in some cases, these taxpayers will pay Uncle Sam more when they do so.

title: The Materiality of Merger Negotiations
description: Have you heard this one recently: A senior executive buys shares in a company that he may recommend be the target of a takeover, giving him a significant profit if the deal goes through. When the trading becomes known, questions arise whether the Securities and Exchange Commission views the information as material for possible insider trading charges.

title: Water Barriers Mulled (Belatedly) at Leaking Nuclear Complex
description: As I read reports about the release of more than 11,000 tons of radiation-laced water into the sea from the damaged nuclear plant in Japan, I recalled reporting I did more than a decade ago on the many uses of silt barriers  essentially curtains suspended in water  to hold back everything from oil slicks to the bursts of polluted runoff flowing into coastal waters from city storm drains after heavy storms (the water can be pumped and treated once the system is not overloaded).

title: Photo Replay: April 4
description: A view of the day in sports included a long walk in the desert, practice in the sand in Augusta, Ga., and some much cooler curling gear.

title: Back to Work and Life, With a Fresh Perspective
description: I was in the car with Ruth, headed home from one of her last radiation treatments at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: The Bidding Over Blockbuster
description: Investors like Carl Icahn, Dish Network, Monarch Alternative Capital and SK Telecom are looking at the assets of Blockbuster in bankruptcy. The companys fate may be decided in court late Monday.

title: TimesCast | April 4, 2011
description: April 4, 2011 - At least 10 killed at a protest in Yemen; and the United States backs away from its support of Yemen's president, Ali Abdullah Saleh.

title: Poll: More Democrats than Republicans Favor Compromise on Budget
description: Just days away from a potential government shutdown, a majority of Democrats and independents say lawmakers with whom they share views should be more willing to compromise even if that results in a budget they disagree with. But fewer Republicans, especially those that agree with the Tea Party movement, say the same, according to a new poll by the Pew Research Center.

title: Popular Carnival Singer Is Elected President of Haiti in a Landslide
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  One of Haitis most popular entertainers, a provocative Carnival singer previously best known for disrobing and swearing on stage, was elected president in a landslide, according to results announced Monday, placing him at the helm of a nation still struggling to recover from last years earthquake, a cholera epidemic and chronic poverty.

title: I Think Pawlenty Misunderstands Me
description: Wow. So Tim Pawlenty is using something I said on yesterdays This Week in a new ad.

title: Overcoming a Parenting Sabbatical
description: Barbara Hannah Grufferman was in her late 30s when she married and had children. She was in her mid-40s when she made what she describes as the heart- and stomach-wrenching decision to quit my job as president of a small but growing international conference company to be a full-time mother of two daughters. Seven years later she looks back on the decision and says: The challenge  that many women  including me  didnt think through was this: If I decide to remove myself from the workforce for a period of time, will I be able to get back in?

title: Lean Cuisine | Pariss Tiniest Kitchen
description: The only place I dont cook in is my bathtub, Rachel Khoo marvels. A trained pastry chef, twice-published author and self-christened food creative, Khoo hosts lunches at La Petite Cuisine  Paris, or the Little Paris Kitchen, in her 226-square-foot apartment in Pariss Belleville neighborhood. The little kitchen concept might be a considerable hindrance to most chefs, but Khoo has made the most of it. Its like Im on a constant camping holiday, she says of the two gas rings and toaster oven at her disposal, and the resourcefulness that has sprung from them. She has whipped up Eton mess  la franaise, lemon and lavender roast chicken, tonka bean souffl, and croque madame muffins. Khoos favorite dish so far, pot au feu fajitas (melt-in-your-mouth beef stew and fresh vegetables in a tortilla with sauce from the pot au feu), summarizes the spirit of her book: Its not quite French, but it takes on the initial French flavors.

title: Texas Instruments to Buy National Semiconductor for $6.5 Billion
description: Texas Instruments said on Monday afternoon that it had agreed to acquire National Semiconductor for $6.5 billion in cash.

title: Paths of Discovery, Lighted by a Bug Mans Insights
description: About three months ago, Thomas Eisner of Cornell University, a towering figure in the fields of biology, ecology and evolution, and a promoter of the class Insecta and related arthropod throngs so thermodynamically persuasive you kept expecting a pair of antennae to sprout from his forehead, sent my 14-year-old daughter, Katherine, a wonderful, miserable gift.

title: A Man Who Loved Insects
description: Photographs by Thomas Eisner, a professor of chemical ecology at Cornell University known for his in-depth studies of insects and other arthropods.

title: Lollapalooza Flies South
description: Lollapalooza Chile, which took place in Santiago last weekend, was the first installment of the festival outside the United States.

title: Five-Time World Champion, and Struggling to Fit In
description: IM lucky because I usually fly first class, and have been doing that for the last 16 years.

title: Sixers Face Trouble Without Williams
description: With their win over the Nets Friday, the Philadelphia 76ers clinched a playoff berth. Yet by Sunday, their playoff chances - already slim, given the strength of Philadelphias likely first-round opponent, Miami or Boston - had taken a significant hit with Lou Williamss strained right hamstring. Williams was forced to leave the Sixers game against the Bucks during the third quarter, and an already limited Philadelphia team had one less scoring option. According to Kate Fagan of the Philadelphia Inquirer, Williams has been ruled out for the remainder of the regular season and is left hoping to be healthy enough to suit up for the playoffs.

title: TimesCast | Radioactive Water Released
description: April 4, 2011 - Japan began dumping radioactive water from the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant into the Pacific Ocean to make room for more contaminated water. Ken Belson reports.

title: Follow the Turks
description: If ever there was a man whose character finds opportunity in crisis, that man is Ahmet Davutoglu, Turkeys foreign minister. Like Turkey itself, he finds his natural role sandwiched between powers, managing conflict and building relationships. Where does it hail from, that hospital ship bearing the wounded away from besieged Misrata, Libya? It hails from Turkey, of course, and is named after the capital, Ankara. What country has both urged Qaddafi to go, yet maintained a very active embassy in Tripoli? Turkey again. (It was also a crucial go-between in aiding in the release of our own Times colleagues from Libyan captivity the other week.) Which country (and major NATO member) has performed the trick of strongly opposing NATO involvement in any Libyan action  then embracing exactly that? And so on.

title: Poised for Releases: 2 New Screens at Lincoln Center
description: The construction on the south side of West 65th Street is almost finished, the first movie has been booked and a programming consultant with long experience in independent films has been hired. After nearly four years and an investment of $41 million, the Film Society of Lincoln Centers new theater complex, the groups most significant undertaking in years and one that could prove a boon for lovers and distributors of art house films, now has an opening date.

title: Drugs Cost and Safety Fuel a Fight
description: After weeks of controversy, federal health officials announced last week that they would not stop pharmacies from making a cheaper alternative to a costly drug given to prevent premature birth. And separately, they investigated the deaths of nine Alabama hospital patients who received a nutritional supplement contaminated with bacteria.

title: Neediest | New House, New Beats
description: Jason Celik, a young musician with Duschenne's muscular dystrophy, makes hip-hop beats for his brother Peter's raps. The Neediest Cases Fund helped make his family's home wheelchair-friendly.

title: Neediest | Working Together
description: Assistance from the Neediest Case Fund helped Desiree Whitlow pay bills and gave her time to look for a job.

title: Neediest Cases | A Changed Man
description: William Mobley shares how he has overcome addiction and stays focused on the future.

title: Neediest | An Independent Life
description: After deciding to live independently from the family and religious community that raised her, Diana Rutherford ended up at Covenant House and started a career as a chef.

title: Neediest | A New Beginning
description: After months of unemployment, Khalilah El Amin reached out to Brooklyn Community Services for help getting her sons coats for the winter and a laptop so she could pursue her BA online.

title: Neediest | Creating Artists
description: After years of providing art classes for students at P.S. 142, The Educational Alliance after-school program had to cut enrollment because of lost funding. The Fund supplied an additional teacher.

title: Battle for Libya | April 4, 2011
description: Rebels Fight for Control of Brega.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, Yemen and Ivory Coast.

title: Greek Tablet May Shed Light on Early Bureaucratic Practices
description: An archaeologist digging in the rubble of a distant past counts on the conquerors havoc, natures upheavals and plain human negligence to have left legacies of unintended value  like a fragment of a clay tablet bearing archaic writing from an early period of state formation in Greece, more than 3,400 years ago.

title: Harvick Keeps Earnhardt Out of Victory Lane
description: Kevin Harvick chased down Dale Earnhardt Jr. with four laps left in the Goodys Fast Relief 500 at Martinsville Speedway in Virginia on Sunday, and went on to score a fairly unpopular victory. Earnhardt is often voted Nascars most popular driver; Harvick heard plenty of boos in Victory Lane after the race.

title: From Two Stars, Handels Sober Side
description: Nearly 50 years in, the early-music revolution has been largely won. The music of the 17th and 18th centuries is no longer esoteric; on a random night in New York theres as much Monteverdi as Mahler. Audiences are still eager to learn the great lesson of the Baroque, that emotion is focused rather than blocked by the restraints of form.

title: Patterns: Long Hours May Add to Heart Trouble
description: When assessing a patients risk for heart disease, doctors take into account such factors as age, cholesterol and smoking status. A new study suggests an additional measure: long working hours.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Afghanistan, Yemen and Ivory Coast.

title: Directly Confronting the Appalling
description: Anna Politkovskaya, the fearless Russian journalist who was shot and killed by an unknown assailant in Moscow in 2006, wrote about the dark side of Vladimir V. Putins reign: the brutal war in Chechnya; the top-to-bottom thuggery and corruption; the lack of an independent judiciary; the bureaucratic black magic that could poison, or snuff out, a life at a moments notice.

title: Strikes by U.N. and France Corner Leader of Ivory Coast
description: AXIM, Ghana  The United Nations and France went on the offensive Monday against Ivory Coasts strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, striking targets at his residence, his offices and two of his military bases in a significant escalation of the international intervention into the political crisis engulfing the nation.

title: A Comedic TV Talent Turns the Tables on Oprah
description: Meet Zach Anner, a 26-year-old filmmaker from Austin, Tex., who just won his own television show on Oprah Winfreys new network. Hes handsome, smart and funny  oh, and he gets around in a wheelchair. Mr. Anner has cerebral palsy, the sexiest of the palsies, as he puts it in his audition video.

title: Opposition in Azerbaijan Vows to Step Up Protests
description: MOSCOW  Opposition leaders in Azerbaijan vowed Monday to step up a nascent protest campaign against the authoritarian government of the former Soviet republic, despite a recent police crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.

title: Obscure, and Often Devastating
description: It is classified as a rare disease, but the chronic condition called Charcot-Marie-Tooth is one of the most common inherited nerve-related disorders, with an estimated 150,000 patients in the United States. It can be devastating to patients and their families, with crippling effects on balance and the ability to walk and grasp objects. Nor does it help that few people have heard of it, unless they are directly affected.

title: Measuring Radioactive Elements and Their Effects on Human Cells
description: The damaged nuclear reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant in Japan have been releasing radioactive elements into the air and water around the plant. Those elements are dangerous because they are made up of atoms with unstable centers, or nuclei. Seeking greater stability, they constantly emit energy as radiation, in the form of waves like gamma rays or X-rays, and as particles smaller than atoms.

title: Shutdown Watch: Four Days Out
description: With four days left until the federal governments spending authority runs out, the talk grew somewhat more pessimistic on Monday as Republicans declared themselves not satisfied with what Democrats in the Senate were offering. At the same time, President Obama invited lawmakers from both parties to the White House on Tuesday for a last-ditch effort to reach an agreement.

title: Authors Heirs Uncensor a Classic War Novel
description: When the classic novel From Here to Eternity was published in 1951, a few things were gone that had been in the original manuscript: explicit mentions of gay sex and a number of four-letter words.

title: Radiation Is Everywhere, but How to Rate Harm?
description: Since the first reports last month of damage to nuclear reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant, the lingering question has been whether drifting plumes of radioactive elements from the plant will harm people in Japan or other parts of the world. For many people, the biggest fear is cancer.

title: Wolf Crosses the Lake Superior Ice to Become Leader of the Pack
description: In Ontario, in the winter of 1997, a particularly virile male wolf stepped onto the ice of Lake Superior and headed toward Isle Royale, an island about 15 miles offshore. There he radically changed the genetic makeup of an isolated group of wolves that had lived there since the late 1940s.

title: A Swagger and Some Bluster for the Sake of Telling Stories
description: That the tenor Matthew Polenzani sang Schuberts song cycle Die Schne Mllerin so beautifully on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall was no surprise. This fine American artist, a regular at the Metropolitan Opera, most recently as Ernesto in Donizettis Don Pasquale opposite Anna Netrebko, has long been admired for the refinement and expressivity of his singing.

title: Detained Chinese Artists New York Project Will Go On
description: A large-scale public art project by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, to occupy the Pulitzer Fountain outside the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan starting early next month, will go forward even if Mr. Ai, who was detained by Chinese authorities on Sunday, is unable to be present.

title: 40 Stitches Near His Eye Sideline Bruins Thornton, but He Wont Back Down
description: Boston Bruins forward Shawn Thornton hardly seems fazed by the J-shaped gash over his right eye, or the 40-plus stitches it took to close it.

title: Detroits Orchestra Tentatively Has a Deal
