description: Musicians and management have reached a tentative agreement that could end a bitter six-month strike at the Detroit Symphony Orchestra.

title: Rental Car Industry Urges Two-Tier System for Vehicle Recalls
description: The American Car Rental Association wants the government to adopt a new system that would designate some recalls as so serious that a vehicle should no longer be driven while others would allow cars to be driven and repaired later.

title: Louisville Dreaming: Characters Exploring Boundaries
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The American dream is not just a matter of fancy cars, sweet suburban vistas and, as it is imagined today, the prospect of your own reality television show or legion of Twitter followers. Maybe more bewitching is the simple possibility of escaping into a life other than the one you wake up to in the gray dawn. Surely a country founded on the bright hope of mans infinite potential should allow its citizens the chance to slip into a new identity, a more fulfilling way of being?

title: Fielders Choice (1 Letter)
description: Overstimulated

title: Lollapalooza Debut in Chile, Speaking Many Tongues
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  National pride and brand expansion made a happy alliance at Lollapalooza Chile, this countrys first full-scale international rock festival and the first Lollapalooza festival held outside the United States.

title: Liveblogging Bob Hall (Serious Wonks With Paid Subscriptions Only)
description: Update: Heres the paper (pdf).

title: Nuclear Reactions (3 Letters)
description: Nuclear Reactions

title: Overstimulated (1 Letter)
description: Overstimulated

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: KATY B

title: Claremont Prep Is Sold to For-Profit Firm
description: Claremont Preparatory School, a six-year-old institution in Lower Manhattan that has had difficulty fulfilling its ambitions, is being sold to a private-equity-backed firm, in a sign of growing investor interest in private schools in New York City.

title: Following Eminems Lead, Estate of Rick James Looks for Higher Pay-Out
description: Following a recent court decision that gave Eminem and his producers a higher royalty rate for digital music, the estate of Rick James has filed a class-action suit against the Universal Music Group, saying that the company has failed to properly account for royalties and may owe its artists tens of millions of dollars.

title: N.F.L. Says Second Lawsuit Is Unlikely to Succeed
description: Two days before a hearing on the request for an injunction by players to stop the lockout, the N.F.L. responded Monday to a second antitrust suit filed against it by retired and yet-to-be-drafted players, arguing that it suffers the same legal deficiencies as the original request.

title: Pasta With Fish Sauce
description: Adapted from Essentials of Classic Italian Cooking by Marcella Hazan

title: Cod Optimization, From Head to Tail
description: FROM 2006 to 2009 my family food budget was governed by the convergence of two troubling and important phenomena:

title: The Rush to Boutique
description: Hotel experts have all sorts of definitions for boutique hotels. Not cookie cutter, one said. Chic, said another. 100 rooms or less, said a third.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The French Connection'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at William Friedkin's 1971 drama starring Gene Hackman.

title: Experienced, Homegrown Educator Leaves City Schools
description: One of the last high officials at the City Department of Education to ascend through the ranks the old-fashioned way  from New York City public school student to teacher to principal to superintendent to deputy chancellor  resigned on Monday after 22 years in the school system.

title: Q.& A. With Julius Erving
description: Blake Griffin is the reigning dunk champion of the N.B.A., but Julius Erving was the innovator. With his array of spins, leaps and gravity-defying dunks, he won three championships, one in the N.B.A. with the Philadelphia 76ers and two in the American Basketball Association with the Nets. He also won four Most Valuable Player awards in the two leagues and two A.B.A. scoring titles. Erving, who retired in 1987, was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993. Erving, who was honored recently at the Thurman Munson awards in Manhattan, turned 61 earlier this year.

title: Private Jets Warming Up for Presidential Campaign
description: NOW that President Obama has announced his candidacy for re-election, you can almost hear the jet engines starting to rev up around the country as the most brutal form of business travel  campaigning for president  stirs to life.

title: Years After Last Call, Keeping a Bars History Alive
description: Theyve been shooting at Dermot McEvoys regiment for a while. Their aim is now getting distressingly good.

title: Lacking Big Names, but Not Importance
description: Indianapolis

title: Amid Rumors Shes Leaving CBS, Couric Heads to Iraq
description: As reports continue to swirl about an impending departure from her anchor position at CBS News, Katie Couric is to embark Tuesday morning on a long-planned trip to Iraq, where she will report on the military and political situation eight years after Baghdad fell to invading American forces.

title: Cowardice Blocks the 9/11 Trial
description: Last year, Attorney General Eric Holder Jr. described a federal court trial for the self-professed mastermind of Sept. 11 attacks, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, as the defining event of my time as attorney general. On Monday, Mr. Holders dream for demonstrating the power of the American court system crumbled when he announced that the trial would take place not in New York City or anywhere in the United States but before a military commission at the Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, prison camp.

title: Lesbian Judge Chosen for Top Massachusetts Court
description: BOSTON  Gov. Deval Patrick on Monday nominated a lesbian who is married to her partner to serve on the Supreme Judicial Court of Massachusetts.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,506 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: No Party Rentals in Miami Beach? Really?
description: MIAMI BEACH  In this decadent, hard-partying playground, Kirsty Bertarellis 40th birthday celebration rivaled the best of them. More than 200 guests flew in from Europe. A caravan of limousines ferried them to the site, a flashy waterfront home. The party rocked until 4:30 a.m. It cost $3 million.

title: Speedy Trials Sought in Texas Rape Case
description: LIBERTY, Tex.  A state judge said Monday that he would push to hold trials in late July for 14 men accused of repeatedly raping an 11-year-old girl last fall in Cleveland, Tex.

title: To Cut Smog, Navistar Blazes Risky Path of Its Own
description: MELROSE PARK, Ill.  In a testing cell tucked deep in the bowels of Navistars engine plant and technical center here, a hulking prototype of a truck engine sits behind a large glass window like a patient on an operating table. A snarl of sensors and wires is attached to nearly every part of the humming engine, feeding reams of data to a battery of computers and watchful engineers in the adjacent control room.

title: Google Executive Says Goodbye as Page Says Hello
description: Monday was Larry Pages first day back as Googles chief executive, and the management shake-up at the top has already begun.

title: OMG!!! OED!!! LOL!!!!!
description: Its wonderful to experience the ongoing corruption and evolution of the English language. Last month, OMG and LOL were inducted into the Oxford English Dictionary, along with the heart symbol  the first time a meaning enters our most exalted linguistic inventory via the T-shirt and bumper sticker.

title: Mandi Schwartz, Athlete at Center of Marrow Drive, Dies at 23
description: Mandi Schwartz, the Yale hockey player whose struggle with leukemia inspired thousands of people to volunteer to be bone marrow donors, died Sunday in Regina, Saskatchewan. She was 23.

title: Court Rejects Suit on Net Neutrality Rules
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Monday rejected as premature a lawsuit by Verizon and MetroPCS challenging the Federal Communications Commissions pending rules aimed at keeping Internet service providers from blocking access to certain Web sites or applications.

title: Vice Media Empire Is Near a Big Infusion of Cash
description: Vice was born in 1994 as an underground magazine in Montreal, financed by a government subsidy and run by three friends who started their own company because no one else would hire them.

title: The Mets' New Ace
description: Johan Santana, the premier pitcher in baseball and the new ace of the Mets, dominates the game with a changeup that makes batters bend and buckle.

title: Feliciano Stung by Mets Pitching Coachs Comments
description: Pedro Feliciano, the most used pitcher in baseball over the last three seasons, politely disagreed with the assertion of Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman that the Mets abused him, but he could not hold back his irritation about the rebuttal from his former pitching coach, Dan Warthen.

title: Midmajors Find Common Ground, No Matter the Sport
description: HOUSTON  From Butler in basketball to Boise State in football, the so-called midmajor programs of college sports have experienced recent uprisings, challenging the blue-blood programs that have reigned for years.

title: Knicks Greet the Playoffs With a Sigh of Relief
description: Greenburgh, N.Y.

title: Talking to No Purpose
description: On Saturday, during halftime at the NCAA semi-finals, a reporter asked the Connecticut coach Jim Calhoun how his team had managed to build up a 10-point lead. He replied, more or less, We played good defense, although we didnt get enough rebounds. What will you have to do in the second half?, the reporter queried brightly. Add rebounds to the good defense was the answer.

title: In Race With Groupon, LivingSocial Raises $400 Million
description: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg NewsTim OShaughnessy, chief executive of LivingSocial.

title: 3 Months In, 17% Approval for the Schools Chief
description: Concern about the appointment of Cathleen P. Black as the New York City schools chancellor does not appear to be easing as she approaches her 100th day in office, according to an NY1-Marist poll released on Monday.

title: Faldo Predicts Success for a Daring Group of Europeans
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Time alternates between standing still and whizzing past in this home of the Masters. It seems like yesterday that 11 European wins from 1980 to 1999 set off a great debate about Europes dominance of the tournament.

title: Sanctions Are Dropped Against Libyan Defector
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration dropped financial sanctions on Monday against the top Libyan official who fled to Britain last week, saying it hoped the move would encourage other senior aides to abandon Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the countrys embattled leader.

title: Obama Invites Republicans to Meet on Budget
description: WASHINGTON  Trying to head off a crisis, President Obama invited Congressional leaders to the White House for a meeting Tuesday to try to resolve the impasse that is threatening to shutter a large part of the federal government as of Saturday.

title: U.N. Plane Crashes in Congo, Killing 32
description: LIRA, Uganda  A United Nations plane crashed as it was landing in Kinshasa, Congo, on Monday, killing 32 of the 33 people aboard, United Nations officials said.

title: UConn Beats Butler to Win N.C.A.A. Title
description: Kemba Walker scored 16 points and Alex Oriakhi added a double-double as the University of Connecticut captured the mens N.C.A.A. championship with a 53-41 win over Butler. The victory gave Huskies Coach Jim Calhoun his third N.C.A.A. championship and his first since 2004.

title: Wisconsin Election Is Referendum on Governor
description: MEQUON, Wis.  Until a few weeks ago, this states election on Tuesday for a justice of the Wisconsin Supreme Court was widely expected to be dull and predictable.

title: TV Ratings for Men Are Highest Since 2005
description: More people watched the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament through Saturdays Final Four than in any year since 2005, which makes sense. For the first time, four networks  CBS, TNT, TBS and truTV  have been carrying the tournament, instead of just CBS, as a result of a new CBS-Turner deal that goes through 2024.

title: After Rape Report in Libya, Woman Sees Benefit in Publicity
description: TRIPOLI  Eman al-Obeidy says the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi victimized her twice. First members of his militia kidnapped and repeatedly raped her. Then his state television network attacked her as a thief and a prostitute.

title: Back for More, Just Not More of the Same
description: When Brian Duensing did his running last off-season, at home in Omaha, he thought about the Yankees. Naturally, Duensing ran on a treadmill, which is how it must feel sometimes to play for the Minnesota Twins.

title: To Cut the Deficit, Look to Social Security
description: Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Power Authority Approves Revised Plan for Hudson Cable
description: With a trustee newly appointed by the governor taking the lead, the New York Power Authority on Monday hurriedly approved a revised deal for the construction of an $850 million cable that would carry electricity to Midtown Manhattan from New Jersey.

title: Israel Indicts Gaza Man on Terror-Linked Counts
description: JERUSALEM  Israel on Monday handed down an indictment against Dirar Abu Sisi, the Gaza engineer who vanished from a train in Ukraine in mid-February, then surfaced in an Israeli prison. He stands accused of developing rockets and missiles on behalf of Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, for use against Israeli civilians and soldiers.

title: Discovery of 3 More Sets of Remains Adds to L.I. Mystery
description: Investigators on Long Island discovered the remains of three more people on a barrier beach on Monday, bringing the number of remains found nearby to eight since the police began searching for a missing prostitute late last year.

title: Clemens and Accuser Scolded for Interviews
description: A federal judge scolded Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer Monday for speaking to the news media about Clemenss pending perjury trial and reminded all parties that they were not to comment publicly about the case.

title: Fed Help Kept Banks Afloat, Until It Didnt
description: WASHINGTON  During the frenetic months of the financial crisis, the Federal Reserve stretched the limits of its legal authority by lending money to more than 100 banks that subsequently failed.

title: Unfair to Immigrants, Costly for Taxpayers
description: EVERY year thousands of immigrants being held on Rikers Island are transferred to federal custody and deported. Only about half of them have a criminal record, many of them are here legally, most of them have their due process rights violated and all of them are subjected to substandard conditions before being returned to their countries of origin.

title: Hoosier Family Fills Fieldhouse With Pride
description: INDIANAPOLIS  They came to chant, dance, sing, stamp and stand for as long as they believed. They raised their arms for jump shots and free throws as if they were sitting behind the basket in Houston and sounded louder than the crowd in the antiseptic domed football stadium.

title: Buffetts Ruthlessness Is Oddly Absent on Sokol
Ned McWherter, Former Tennessee Governor, Dies at 80
description: Ned McWherter, a sharecroppers son who as governor of Tennessee cajoled the legislature into passing a sweeping health care overhaul, making it the first state to offer health insurance to every uninsured person who wanted it, died on Monday in Nashville. He was 80.

title: With Its Move to Coney Island, Flea Market Is Sprucing Up
description: Debbie Quintana-Stiefel knows it is time to expand her palette. Beyond the brown and deep-red lipsticks she carries, she must now add fuchsias and oranges and complementary foundations to satisfy her new customers.

title: Google Bids $900 Million for Nortel Patent Assets
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google has bid $900 million for the patent portfolio of Nortel Networks, the Canadian telecom equipment maker, as part of a strategy to defend itself against patent litigation.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 4, 2011

title: G.O.P. Blueprint Would Remake Health Policy
description: WASHINGTON  The proposal to be unveiled by House Republicans on Tuesday to rein in the long-term costs of Medicaid and Medicare represents a fundamental rethinking of how the two programs work, an ambitious effort by conservatives to address the nations fiscal challenges, and a huge political risk.

title: Who Could Blame G.E.?
description: With tax day fast approaching, many Americans are thinking hard, and perhaps a little creatively, about finding deductions to help lower their tax bills. Nobody, after all, likes paying more taxes than they have to. So why in the world should we expect the mighty General Electric to act any differently?

title: Expedia and American in a Fare Agreement
description: Consumers searching for flight information will once again be able to find American Airline fares on the Web sites of Expedia and its affiliate, Hotwire  effective immediately  now that the two companies have ended a standoff over fees and how the travel information should be delivered.

title: At Age 84, a Citys Last Geisha Defies Time and a 4th Tsunami
description: KAMAISHI, Japan  The requests to see her perform had dwindled over the years. But when the earthquake struck at 2:46 p.m. on March 11, this citys last geisha was, fittingly, at home getting ready to sing that night at Kamaishis 117-year-old ryotei, an exclusive restaurant featuring fine food and entertainment where she began working as a 14-year-old seven decades ago.

title: Men at War
description: Most historians now argue  and contemporary documents bear them out  that the leaders of the Confederacy were, above all, motivated by a desire to protect their system of slavery. Leaving the Union, they believed, was the surest way to preserve an institution that was now threatened by the newly-elected, and self-proclaimed anti-slavery, president, Abraham Lincoln.

title: Hard Times for Recess
description: More than 150 years ago, Charles Dickens published Hard Times, a novel centered around the students of an English schoolmaster named Thomas Gradgrind, who had no use for play or any sort of imaginative pursuit. For Gradgrind, if something did not demonstrably add to the productive capacity of the nation and could not be justified with facts and statistics, it had no place in a childs education.

title: Israel and Gaza, 2 Years Ago and Today
description: To the Editor:

title: West Bank: Actor-Activist Killed by Militants
description: An Israeli-Arab actor and political activist who directed a childrens theater in the West Bank city of Jenin was shot dead in his car by Palestinian militants, the police said. The man, Juliano Mer-Khamis, 52, who led the Freedom Theater in Jenin, was born to an Israeli Jewish mother and a Palestinian Christian father. Although he was an Israeli citizen, he had lived in Jenin for the past seven years. Mr. Mer-Khamiss mother, a peace activist, had founded the theater. He produced a film in 2004 on his mothers work called Arnas Children, which was widely praised internationally. The police said they were investigating the attack.

title: Obama Opens 2012 Campaign, With Eye on Money and Independent Voters
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama did not directly ask supporters to send contributions as he formally opened his re-election bid on Monday. But to build the grass-roots network that he believes is essential to winning a second term, he is preparing to undertake the most ambitious fund-raising effort by a sitting president.

title: Bikes and the City: Are Lanes the Answer?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cigarette for 75 Cents, 2 for $1: The Brisk, Shady Sale of Loosies
description: By 8:30 a.m., amid the procession of sleepy-eyed office workers and addicts from the nearby methadone clinic, Lonnie Loosie plants himself in the middle of the sidewalk on Eighth Avenue in Midtown. Addressing no one in particular, he calls out his one-size-fits-all greeting: Newports, Newports, packs and loosies.

title: Tuesday: What Hailstones Do
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  You know that version of Murphys Law that says that if you dont want it to rain, you should carry an umbrella with you at all times?

title: Unrest in Yemen Seen as Opening to Qaeda Branch
description: WASHINGTON  Counterterrorism operations in Yemen have ground to a halt, allowing Al Qaedas deadliest branch outside of Pakistan to operate more freely inside the country and to increase plotting for possible attacks against Europe and the United States, American diplomats, intelligence analysts and counterterrorism officials say.

title: Texas Instruments to Buy National Semiconductor for $6.5 Billion
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Texas Instruments said Monday that it planned to acquire National Semiconductor for $6.5 billion in a deal that places a big bet on the increasing need to translate the physical world of humans into the digital form of computers and then back again.

title: Afghan Violence Over the Koran Burning in Florida
A Changed Landscape for Obama
description: A look at the challenges President Obama faces in many states, including those that he flipped from red to blue in 2008.

title: In Rape Case, Court Is Told Police Officer Didnt Have Sex
description: A police officer accused of raping a woman in her East Village apartment while on duty in December 2008 built a rapport with the woman during a discussion of alcoholism and had physical contact with her, but they did not have sex, his lawyer argued in court on Monday.

title: Yankees Find Quality in a Rookie Starter
description: Six months later, the little things come easier for Ivan Nova. How to get to and from Yankee Stadium no longer vexes him. Figuring out what to pack is not a chore. And as a result, when big moments arrive  the sixth inning of the Yankees 4-3 victory Monday against the Minnesota Twins, for instance  Nova is better equipped to handle them.

title: Prospal and Late Goals Boost Rangers Chances
description: Johnny Boychuk, a defenseman for the Boston Bruins, tried whisking the puck out of the goal before anyone could notice. He fooled no one. Michael Sauers third goal of the season counted, and the Rangers stunning, dramatic and last-ditch comeback was complete.

title: Iraq: 4 U.S. Soldiers Killed in Iraq
description: Four United States soldiers have been killed in Iraq in recent days, two from enemy attack and two from what the American military called a non-hostile incident in the north. Two were killed on Saturday from mortar or rocket fire. According to icasualties.org, 14 Americans have been killed in Iraq this year, eight of them from enemy fire.

title: Russia: Rocket Launch Marks 50 Years of People in Space
description: Final preparations were underway Monday evening at the Baikonur space center to launch a rocket in honor of the 50th anniversary of the flight of the first person in space, Yuri A. Gagarin. Two Russian cosmonauts and an American astronaut are scheduled to ride the Yuri Gagarin rocket into orbit, on their way to the International Space Station; the honorary naming was a departure from the usual Russian practice of numbering rockets. The rocket, scheduled to launch before Tuesday, also has a portrait of Mr. Gagarin painted on the side. He was only 27 years old when he made his first and only journey into space, and he later died in a jet airplane crash. The Soyuz model booster was being fueled Monday evening on the same launch pad where Mr. Gagarin blasted off on his flight on April 12, 1961, which began with his words Lets go.

title: Conflicts of Interest in Medicine
Henry Taub, a Founder of a Payroll Firm That Became a Global Giant, Dies at 83
description: Henry Taub, a founder of the payroll company that grew into the global giant Automatic Data Processing, died on Thursday in Manhattan. He was 83 and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Foreclosure Assistance
A Wonder on Two Wheels
description: When the Mets broke camp in Port St. Lucie, Fla., last week, they took with them the hope for a successful season, a remade bullpen, and a special rolling box replete with items from the vital to the absurd to go in that bullpen. Mr. Met has for decades been the lovable and irreplaceable symbol for the organization, but this year, the bullpen will have a mascot of its own, known affectionately as Stosh.

title: Problems With Radioactive Water at the Plant
description: Radioactive water is leaking from the power company in Japan and theres no place to store it.

title: Moment of Truth
description: It was a season of fiscal perestroika. Last fall, the Simpson-Bowles deficit commission released a bold report on how to avoid an economic catastrophe. For a few weeks, the think tanks and government offices were alive with proposals to reduce debt and reform entitlements, the tax code and just about every other government program.

title: Sokols Ways Questioned in Past Suits
description: Lawsuits involving David L. Sokol after he joined Berkshire Hathaway suggest that management had some warnings about his rules-pushing nature long before his resignation last week for buying stock in a company shortly before Berkshire acquired it.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Union-Bashing, Now in Ohio
description: This is Ohios new concept of how to deal fairly with its public employees: Make them an offer, and if they dont accept it, impose it anyway. There will be no appeal or arbitration. And unions will no longer be able to negotiate their health-care benefits or require the payment of dues from members.

title: The Dollars and Cents of Bats and Farming
description: Putting a dollar value on nature and the services it provides isnt easy. Such numbers can show how much our human economy depends on natures indiscernible economy. Take bats. A study in Science magazine reveals just how important they are to American agriculture.

title: Bloggingheads: The Evil Yankees
description: Noam Scheiber, left, of The New Republic and Rich Lowry of National Review debate hating the New York Yankees.

title: Small Airplane Lands in Waves on Beach in Queens
description: A small airplane made an emergency landing in the Rockaways on Monday night, touching down where the beach meets the water. No one was injured in the landing, and the plane was not damaged.

title: Pressure on China to Release Dissident Artist
description: BEIJING  The United States, France, Britain and Germany on Monday called on China to release Ai Weiwei, an internationally known artist and increasingly vocal government critic. Mr. Ai was led away by police officers as he tried to board a plane at Beijing International Airport on Sunday morning and he has not been heard from since.

title: Word of the Day | calorific
description: calorific \ka-l-ri-fik\ adjective

title: UConn Men Top Butler to Capture Third Title
description: HOUSTON  Coming off a season in which it lost in the second round of the National Invitation Tournament, the Connecticut basketball team was under N.C.A.A. investigation, was picked to finish 10th in the Big East and had a roster filled with inexperienced and unproven players. When the Huskies finished ninth in the Big East, their star guard, Kemba Walker, joked that they had exceeded expectations.

title: A Growing Population, and Target, for Marketers
description: IT has been said that in America, a minority group has not truly arrived until it has been marketed to. That was true for African-Americans, gay men and lesbians and, most recently, consumers who speak Spanish.

title: In Ragged Finale, Walker Proves Good Enough
description: HOUSTON  After this college basketball season ended, Connecticut guard Kemba Walker climbed atop the stage on the court at Reliant Stadium. He danced. He clapped. He did the robot. Out poured all the emotion he had accumulated over the past month, the product of 11 wins in UConns final 11 games, of carrying a young team from a ninth-place Big East finish to the pinnacle of his sport.

title: Antitrust Fears Slow Google Takeovers to a Crawl
Frustrated Bulldogs Go Out With a Clang
description: HOUSTON  Butler arrived at the national championship stage because of its scrappy identity built on rebounding, defense and hard work. The Bulldogs were never that pretty. But they were never uglier than on Monday in the national championship game.

title: Another Plane Mishap Forces Landing
description: A flight attendant was making the usual announcements about snacks and in-flight entertainment as United Airlines flight 497 soared past 4,000 feet flight early Monday morning. Suddenly the public address system went dead. And so did the lights.

title: Mens National Championship Replay
description: A look at Connecticuts 53-41 victory over Butler for the N.C.A.A. Division I basketball championship.

title: Who Should Replace Japan in the Copa Amrica?
description: Japan withdrew from this summers Copa Amrica on Monday, saying the effects of last months earthquake and tsunami made it impossible for the team to participate.

title: News Quiz | April 5, 2011

title: Previewing the Champions League Quarterfinals

Wednesdays games have Shakhtar Donetsk at Barcelona and Manchester United at Stamford Bridge to face Chelsea. All the games start at 2:45 p.m. Eastern, and will be broadcast either on Fox Soccer Channel or Fox Sports Net.

title: Sanctions Are Dropped Against Libyan Defector

description: The $7.9 billion takeover of the Australian stock exchange by the Singapore Exchange teetered on the verge of collapse on Tuesday after Australia said it planned to block the deal, setting an ominous example for the big mergers currently under review in Europe and North America.

title: Would People Join an Atheist Club in Your School?
description: A recent article describes a high school in a Bible Belt Florida town that has an after-school club for atheists. The article also reports that atheist clubs have been springing up at more and more high schools. How do you think such a club would be greeted at your school? Would you attend any of the clubs events, or even become a member? Why or why not?

title: Company Says Radioactive Water Leak at Japan Plant Is Plugged

The news came a day after the company said the levels of radioactive material in the seawater near the plant were measured at several million times the legal limit.

title: Who Made Those Chocolate Wrappers?
description: The story of Mast Brothers Chocolate is one of family and one of craft. Rick and Michael Mast, the young owners and proprietors of the company, make organic, artisanal sweets in their Brooklyn-based confectionery. They take great care with their ingredients (cacao beans imported directly from South America), their manufacturing process (time-honored techniques alongside custom-built machinery by a former aerospace engineer) and even their packaging.

It is just one arm of ShermansTravel Media. Others include a Top 25 deals newsletter (sent to four million subscribers) and Smart Luxury Travel magazine (400,000 circulation).

title: Kaiser Permanente Opens Clinic in Washington
description: Just days after the Obama administration unveiled regulations on how doctors and hospitals can band together to offer coordinated care, Kaiser Permanente will open on Tuesday a demonstration center near the Capitol Building to show what it believes such coordination should look like.

title: More Body Armor for the iPhone
description: There must be an awful lot of klutzes out there, or a large number of fearful people, judging by the number of super-shock resistant iPhone cases now on the market. In addition to the Ballistic HC case reported by my colleague, Roy Furchgott, in March, as well as the rugged iPad, iPhone and iPod Touch Otterbox cases, comes a new entry from Griffin, a well-known maker of accessories for PCs, MP3 players and smartphones.

title: Government Forces Fire On Protesters in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Security forces and armed men in civilian clothes clashed with antigovernment demonstrators in the city of Taiz on Tuesday, opening fire on crowds calling for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to step down, witnesses said. It was the third straight day of violence in Taiz, where more than 10 protesters were killed by gunfire on Monday.

title: Chinas Central Bank Raises Interest Rates

title: Anti-Intellectualism in America, Then and Now
description: As a quasi extension of our occasional What Were Reading posts, I will report that just this morning I started Anti-Intellectualism in American Life, by the historian Richard Hofstadter, a book that won the Pulitzer Prize in 1964 and that seemed as if it might have a thing or two to say about the current moment. (Full disclosure: Lest I be accused of publicly putting on airs, I should also point out that I recently read So Far ,  the midcareer autobiography of Kelsey Grammer, a book that is definitely worth judging by its cover.)

title: For Patients With Dementia, Hands-On Comfort
description: You can see the logic. Old people with dementia can become frightened and restless, angry or agitated. Reiki, a Japanese healing practice that supposedly channels a universal energy, is said to be soothing and deeply relaxing. So why not offer reiki to elderly dementia patients?

title: Groundhog Day on the Budget
description: Like Atrios, I am not looking forward to this. Its going to be just like the Social Security fight, only worse: once again, Very Serious People will pretend not to notice that the Republican plan is a giant game of bait-and-switch, dismantling a key piece of the social safety net in favor of a privatized system, claiming that this is necessary to save money, but never acknowledging that privatization in itself actually costs money. And well have endless obfuscation, both-sides-have-a-point reporting that misses the key point, which is that the putative savings come entirely from benefit cuts somewhere in the distant future that would, in all likelihood, never actually materialize. (What do you think will happen when retirees in 2025 discover that their Medicare vouchers arent enough to buy insurance?)

title: Tuesday Reading: Rental Car Firms Seek Special Recall Rules
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Nobel Laureate Loses Last Legal Battle to Save Job at Bank
description: NEW DELHI  Muhammad Yunus, the Nobel Peace Prize laureate and Bangladeshi microfinance pioneer who popularized the notion of giving tiny loans to the poor, lost his legal battle on Tuesday to hold on to his job as managing director of the bank he created more than 30 years ago.

title: Statues of Limitations
description: Plenty of sports owners tell their fans to go to hell. But they tend to do it in some sort of euphemistic way  unloading a star, raising ticket prices, moving the team to another city under cover of the night. They dont usually just say, Go to hell.

title: Jrgen Mayer H. | Pattern Recognition
description: Jrgen Mayer H. has been on a roll. Ever since winning the prestigious Audi Urban Future Award last fall, the 45-year-old architect  who is based in Berlin and who is known for his sometimes challenging experiments (both visually and technologically) with shape and color  is racking up one plum commission after the other. There is the inauguration of a new airport in Mestia, Georgia (the country, not the state); a special line of asymmetrical eyewear (looks better than it sounds); and last week, after almost seven years of planning and construction and much political wrangling, the opening of his biggest project to date, the Metropol Parasol, a 150,000-square-foot mushroom-shaped, mixed-use public plaza in the heart of Seville, Spain. Made of polyurethane-coated timber, it successfully marries an archaeological site with a farmers market, multiple bars and restaurants, and a terrace with breathtaking views of the Andalusian capital.

title: The Private Equity Parallels With Buffett
description: Since the story broke over questionable stock trades by David L. Sokol, a former top lieutenant to Warren E. Buffett, DealBook has heard from a range of people about the controversy.

title: The Investor Who Missed Out on the Chip Deal
description: Shareholders of National Semiconductor are uncorking the Champagne after hearing the news that Texas Instruments has agreed to pay $6.5 billion for the company, about 78 percent above where its shares closed on Monday.

title: Calling Dr. Fine: Sean Hayes to Play Larry in Three Stooges Movie
description: It was always clear that Larry Fine was pretty good with a Stradivarius, but who knew he was a song and dance man too? Sean Hayes, the Will and Grace star, Tony Awards show host and Tony-nominated performer for last years revival of Promises, Promises, is set to play Larry, the frizzy-haired, fiddle-playing member of the Three Stooges in a new Three Stooges movie to be directed by Bobby and Peter Farrelly (Theres Something About Mary, Hall Pass). The Hollywood Reporter said that Mr. Hayes will join Will Sasso, of Mad TV and $#*! My Dad Says, who is set to play the follicularly deficient Curly Howard. The movie is not a biographical film and will instead feature a slapstick trio in new comedy sketches based on the original Stooges. It has already taken a few eye gouges en route to the big screen: at one time, the planned cast included Sean Penn as Larry, Jim Carrey as Curly and Benicio Del Toro as Moe, but that fell apart like a high-society pie dinner after Mr. Penn withdrew from the project. A new actor to play Moe and a release date for The Three Stooges aint yet soiten (and they havent been determined either).

title: Supreme Court Issues Stay of Execution
description: The United States Supreme Court on Tuesday granted a temporary stay of execution to Cleve Foster, a former Army recruiter who was convicted of killing a woman he met in a Fort Worth bar.

title: Facebook Effect
description: One of the most frequent questions on my book tour has been, Do you think the increasing use of Facebook, texting and tweeting damages genuine social interaction?

title: Critics Picks Video: The French Connection
description: This week A. O. Scott looks back at  The French Connection. The 1971 film follows the New York City police detective Popeye Doyle (Gene Hackman) as he goes after Brooklyn drug dealers and uncovers an international drug ring. The French Connection was based on a real-life case that the director, William Friedkin, stripped down and also opened up, Mr. Scott said. He focuses on the details of police work and puts together car chases that have become the stuff of cinematic legend. Have you seen The French Connection? Please share your thoughts.

title: Highballs and High Art
description: The current fads for artisanal liquor, louche bars and everything Mad Men must have inspired Cocktail Culture: Ritual and Invention in American Fashion, 1920-1980, an exhibition that opens Friday (and continues through July) at the Museum of Art at the Rhode Island School of Design. It features more than 220 artifacts, including a Dansk ice bucket, a Norman Bel Geddes soda siphon, Paco Rabanne purses and lots of little black dresses (as well as the red one shown below, by Norman Norell). The show begins in the 1920s, when American cocktail culture was mostly confined to the home, and the French, with their beaded cocktail dresses and Ren Lalique Art Deco glass, set the standard for a night on the town. But the most durable pieces, the ones that youd still want to break out for guests today, date from the 1950s, when every hour was happy hour and cocktail design was strained through a Modernist sieve. Consider Donald Colfleshs 1959 silver-plated pitcher for Gorham (below), whose sleek form seems to respond only to one request, essential and elegant: martini, straight up.

title: Economic Diversity at Harvard (Cont.)
description: Harvard officials have responded to The Chronicle of Higher Educations recent chart on economic diversity at top colleges  which I wrote about last week  and have made some good points. The brief version: Harvards undergraduate student body is more economically diverse than The Chronicles numbers suggested. Its still not very diverse, but it has become more diverse in the last few years.

title: Budget Stances Harden as Deadline Nears for Shutdown

In fact, we can be sure that whatever happens, it wont be what the plan says will happen.

title: Composers Eiffel Tower Plan Is Approved
description: Dogged efforts by the composer Joseph Bertolozzi to turn the Eiffel Tower into one big musical instrument are paying off. Mr. Bertolozzi, who has created a piece of music by harvesting percussive sounds from the Franklin D. Roosevelt Mid-Hudson Bridge near Poughkeepsie, N.Y., said he recently received approval from the Eiffel Tower Operating Company (the Socit dExploitation de la Tour Eiffel) to record samples from the tower. The samples would then be assembled into a piece of music, with the ultimate goal of performing it live on the tower itself. Mr. Bertolozzi traveled to Paris in the fall to present his project, and he received a letter of approval last month. The tower operating company said it was open to the idea of a live concert but was making no promises. Now, Mr. Bertolozzi said, all he has to do is raise the money. He said his aim was to have performances in 2014, the towers 125th anniversary.

title: Paul Ryan and the Triumph of Policy
description: You do not have to like the long-term budget that Paul Ryan and the House Republicans have released this morning. Theres plenty in the plan for liberals to hate, moderates to doubt, and conservatives to question. But you do have to respect it. As my colleague David Brooks writes today, it is the most comprehensive and most courageous budget reform proposal any of us have seen in our lifetimes. It puts flesh on the bones of the standard-issue conservative pledge to limit governments growth, and it does so not with evasive pledges on process (like the risible idea of a balanced budget amendment) or dishonest suggestions that the deficit can be erased by defunding N.P.R. and slashing foreign aid, but by attacking entitlement spending deeply and directly. George W. Bush touched the third rail of American politics with his Social Security gambit, and lived to regret it. With their proposal to transform Medicare from an open-ended entitlement to a system that provides support for seniors premiums, Ryan and the Republicans are reaching out and grabbing it with both hands. In the process, they are being brutally honest with the American people, in ways that the Obama White House has repeatedly refused to be, about the scale of the deficit challenge and the scope of the reforms needed to address it.

title: Britain Arrests 2 in Phone-Hacking Case
description: LONDON  Scotland Yard said Tuesday that two journalists had been arrested, questioned and released on bail in the renewed inquiry into a five-year-old case involving illegal hacking of celebrity voice mail by The News of the World, the gossip-driven tabloid owned by Rupert Murdoch that is one of Britains most widely circulated newspapers.

title: N.F.L. Players Put Faith in Lawyers Bold Move

Jeffrey Kessler grew up in Brooklyn in the 1960s as an admittedly inadequate two-guard in basketball, his shot only slightly less bad than his ball-handling. He played no football.

Any others, beside BAMCO? And while were on food service: Melanie Warner writes that the USDAs new nutrition standards for school lunches are forcing food companies to work to keep their products in the cafeteria.

title: Remembering Larry Finch, Memphiss Pivotal Figure
description: Larry Finch used to tell stories of growing up in Orange Mound, a tough neighborhood in Memphis: the houses with no indoor bathrooms and the streets patrolled by the police who treated the people with such distrust that Finch remembers them stopping him and rolling a patrol car window closed with his head in it. But when Finch would tell these stories, he was always laughing.

description: Mercedes-Benz is recalling almost 137,000 of its M-Class sport utility vehicles because tapping the brake may not disengage the cruise control.

title: The Problem With Deficit Solutions Like Representative Ryans
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan, Republican from Wisconsin, released a dramatic new deficit-reduction proposal Tuesday, one that would slash $5.8 trillion from spending levels over the next decade. Among the more controversial highlights is a cap on Medicare and Medicaid spending, by giving individual Medicare recipients vouchers of a certain amount, and block grants to states for Medicaid. The pundit consensus seems to be that Mr. Ryans plan will be the framework for thinking about how to resolve budget issues  in David Brookss words, the standard of seriousness for anybody who wants to play in this discussion.

description: Wall Street has plenty to say about the Dodd-Frank Act, and the Treasury Department is listening.

This is not the kind of gender gap that makes headlines in the West  related to jobs, salaries, and the like, but a more profound one. Read a Wall Street Journal blog post by Diksha Sahni for a solid review.

description: Eliminate parent coordinators in schools: $87 million. Replace 500 police officers with civilians: $16.5 million. Encourage teachers to serve jury duty during the summer $2.4 million. Restore the commuter tax: $735 million. Tax plastic grocery bags ($94 million) and cosmetic surgery ($50 million). Tax an obscure type of compensation earned by hedge fund partners the same way other business income is taxed: $200 million.

description: Last year, my wife and I followed The Timess suggestion and went to Morocco for two weeks with my family (we have two daughters, ages 12 and 10). We had the best vacation ever. For our vacation in July, we would really like to replicate our Morocco experience, which was cultural, adventurous and exotic. Any suggestions for us?

description: LARCHMONT, N.Y.  The two oil paintings hung for decades in the basement recreation room of the mans childhood home in Connecticut, over the Ping-Pong table alongside a paint-by-numbers picture by his older sister.
