title: Wisconsin Election Turns Into Referendum on Governor
description: RACINE, Wis. Under sunny skies but chilly temperatures, voters in this state streamed into polling places on Tuesday to cast ballots in a race for the Wisconsin Supreme Court, a contest that until only a few weeks ago had been widely expected to prove dull and predictable.

title: Kate Bush Has Permission to Use Words of James Joyce
description: Molly Blooms wandering soliloquy in James Joyces Ulysses was the inspiration for The Sensual World, the title song from Kate Bushs 1989 album, but at the time the Joyce estate would not give her approval to use the words in her lyrics. Now Ms. Bush has received the long-awaited permission to use the text, and she has rerecorded the song, which she renamed Flower of the Mountain, according to BBC News. Ms. Bush said she was delighted to have the chance to fulfill the original concept. The new track will be released in May on Directors Cut, her first new album in six years.

title: Tim Kaine Announces Senate Run in Virginia
description: 2:31 p.m. | Updated The decision by Tim Kaine to give up his job as chairman of the Democratic National Committee to run for the Senate in Virginia sets up what is likely to be an intense confrontation in 2012 between two former governors in a critically important swing state.

title: A Plan to Dig Up the Bones of a Suspected Mona Lisa Model
description: A former Italian television producer who has achieved notoriety by claiming to dig up the bones of cultural figures like Caravaggio and Dante has set his sights on the woman believed to be the model for the Mona Lisa, The Associated Press reported.

title: Stage Beauty | Tamaryn
description: The shoegazer singer Tamaryn, who started a North American tour with the Raveonettes last week, has learned a thing or two about stage makeup. I dont always use primer on my eyes, and I never wear powder  I like everything to be a little dewy and sexual looking, said the singer during a pretour shopping spree in SoHo. (Stops included M.A.C. and Sephora.) She recently discovered Super, Dr. Nicolas Perricones new collection, at its flagship in Berkeley, Calif.  the band is based in San Francisco  and swears by the First Blush Brightening Serum: Ive been using it over makeup to set it and have a bit of a glow. Other must-haves include Osis Mattifying Powder (I sprinkle it in my hair and it looks teased), Stila Kajal Eye Pencil in black (looks better the next day), Frederic Malle Une Rose (androgynous but romantic  plus the traditional Goth girl scent is rose water) and Tom Ford Bruised Plum Lip Color (its like neu-Goth, because its sheer). But the singer is always looking to evolve with her look: I really want to start wearing brown lipstick. Ive been watching a lot of My So-Called Life lately, and they all have that brown lipstick! I think the 90s are what its all about right now.

title: Teaching Women to Think Like Angels
description: The overwhelmingly male field of angel investing is about to become a bit more diverse. Ten women, including some business owners (TechCrunch has the full list), will soon learn the secrets of angel investing during the Pipeline Fund Fellowships inaugural six-month program for aspiring female angels. Beginning this month, the group, chosen from among 50 applicants, will attend monthly workshops on issues like due diligence and valuation, and will be paired with mentors who are seasoned male and female investors. The program, held in New York, will culminate with an investment by the group in a women-led, profit-making, socially conscious venture.

title: Steps Toward a Smaller Detroit
description: Detroit officials are identifying areas of the city that are most worthy of future investment.

title: Birthday Time
description: Lets say it is your friends birthday. Should you ask her what she wants and simply buy her that present, or should you thoughtfully think of something yourself and surprise her? An article in the Journal of Experimental Social Psychology suggests the first route is best. Francesca Gino and Francis Flynn conducted 5 separate studies and found that people were more pleased by gifts they explicitly requested. They were also quite pleased by gifts of cash. Givers believe that people like surprises but giftees just want what they want.

title: 6 Held in Germany in Rebuilt Euro Fraud
description: FRANKFURT It was not a glamorous Hollywood-style bank heist. No tunnels. No rappelling from helicopters. Not even a single ski mask.

title: Top Chef Masters Downsizes
description: In the restaurant world, change usually means expansion: more dishes, more tables, more dining rooms, more spinoffs. The restaurant-themed contest series Top Chef Masters has gone in the opposite direction, downsizing for its third season, which begins Wednesday night on Bravo.

title: TimesCast | April 5, 2011
description: April 5, 2011 - Jennifer Steinhauer on the looming shutdown, and Sheryl Gay Stolberg on the mechanics of how it would work.

title: Butler Contemplates Meaning of Failed Title Run
description: For every winner of the N.C.A.A. title, there must be a team that suffers the heartbreak of losing.

title: Dancing Carries ABC Again in Ratings
description: A two-hour installment of Dancing With the Stars attracted an average of 21.4 million viewers on Monday, lifting ABC to first place in the nights ratings ahead of CBS and its college basketball coverage, according to Nielsens estimates. Although final audience figures for CBSs live broadcast of the N.C.A.A. mens championship game were not immediately available on Tuesday, preliminary overnight estimates were down slightly compared with last year, when 23.9 million watched the title matchup on CBS. Despite that modest decline, the games ratings were still high enough that CBS might have led the night over all were it not for lower ratings preceding the basketball coverage for sitcom reruns at 8 and 8:30, The Big Bang Theory (9.6 million) and Rules of Engagement (7.4 million). The repeats lagged in comparison with ABCs 10 p.m. audience for Castle (11.7 million) following Dancing With the Stars. NBC ranked third with Harrys Law at 10 (7.4 million) following a rerun of Chuck at 8 (2.5 million) and The Event at 9 (3.9 million). Fox was fourth with repeats of House (4.4 million) and The Chicago Code (3.9 million).

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Japan, Libya and Ivory Coast.

title: Indian Accounting Firm Is Fined $7.5 Million Over Fraud at Satyam
description: The Indian affiliate of PricewaterhouseCoopers routinely failed to follow the most basic audit procedures, the United States Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday as it penalized the firm for its failed audits of Satyam Computer Services, the Indian company that falsely reported more than $1 billion in profits.

title: Nutrition Standards Urged for Meals With Toys
description: Captain Cold and the Littlest Pet Shop toys may have met their match in Leroy G. Comrie Jr.

title: Photo Replay: April 5
description: A view of the day in sports included headers in soccer, the blur of artistic gymnastics and some behind-the-scenes looks at preparation for the Masters golf tournament.

title: A Scene From 'Blank City'
description: In this scene from the documentary "Blank City," about the "No Wave Cinema" movement, James Nares discusses how he sneaked his cast into a vacant apartment to shoot his film "Rome 78."

title: The Course Is the Star of a Celebritys Game
description: As a multiracial American who likes golf, I once revered Tiger Woods from afar. Then, after meeting him and learning that he could talk about video games the way a normal dude does, I thought I actually liked him as a person. So when he humiliated his wife and family (not to mention himself) in front of the entire planet with his spectacular sexual self-immolation, I was as disgusted and disillusioned as any fan could be. Heading into this weeks Masters tournament, I am not rooting against him. But for whatever trouble he is having getting his game and his life back together, I, like millions of others, have zero sympathy.

title: F.B.I. Agent Describes Tips and Galleon Trades
description: 8:43 p.m. | Updated

title: N.F.L. Draft: Kyle Rudolph, Second-Ranked Tight End
description: 2. Kyle Rudolph, Notre Dame (6-6, 259)

title: From Shark Tank Co-Host, a Dose of Reality for Start-Ups
description: An entrepreneurs first pitch meeting with venture capitalists is many things  risky, nerve-wracking, potentially lucrative if the idea sells. But is it good television?

title: A Diner in Name Only
description: THERE was smoke coming out of the ventilation ducts. It was late evening at the M. Wells diner in Long Island City, Queens, and rain was coming down in sheets. A waiter dashed through the narrow dining room and turned off the fan. The smoke retreated, then started up again, thick and brown. Some people started to cough.

title: Reviewing M. Wells
The Legal Side of Bob Dylan
description: With the lights dimmed and the audience sitting rapt, a man with an acoustic guitar took the stage and sounded the opening chords to Bob Dylans Hurricane.

title: Fed Minutes Show No Haste to End Stimulus
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve shows few signs of easing its aggressive efforts to stimulate growth before the middle of the year, according to the minutes of the most recent meeting of the central banks policy-making committee, released on Tuesday.

title: Protecting Your Smartphone
description: A few years ago, my husband left his old-fashioned cellphone in his car overnight and a thief broke in and snatched it. By the time we realized it was gone and notified our cellular carrier, the thief had run up a few hundred dollars of calls  a unwelcome expense, but hardly devastating.

title: Candidates and Campaigns: Analyzing the 2012 Presidential Field
description: Overview | Who will run for president in 2012? What strengths and weaknesses do potential candidates bring? How are the Republican and Democratic Parties likely to approach their presidential campaigns? In this lesson, students consider the field and the political climate and then create a class Wiki profiling the most prominent potential presidential candidates. They then take their analysis further by creating campaign strategies for the political party or specific candidate of their choice.

title: Obama to Hold Facebook Town Hall
description: President Obama will be expanding his town-hall-style sessions to the next frontier, White House officials said on Tuesday: Facebook.

title: Facebook to Host Obama Town Hall Meeting
description: How do you know you are the hottest company in Silicon Valley? When you get a visit from the President of the United States.

title: Eagle-Cam: Cuteness and Danger in Equal Measure
description: As I write this, more than 170,000 people around the world  a larger audience than a lot of television shows are drawing in the middle of a weekday afternoon  are watching a live broadcast of an eagle sitting on its nest.

title: Royal Wedding Receptions, No Gift Required
description: WHO needs Westminster Abbey? If you want to be among the throngs celebrating the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, all you need is a MetroCard and an alarm clock.

title: Ecuador Expels U.S. Ambassador Over WikiLeaks Cable
description: MEDELLN, Colombia  Ecuadors government said Tuesday that it was expelling the United States ambassador, Heather M. Hodges, over comments made public in a diplomatic cable released by WikiLeaks in which Ms. Hodges referred to high-level police corruption in Ecuador and possible knowledge of it by the president.

title: A Corporate Campus Made to Mirror Facebook
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Facebook, which started out in a dormitory at Harvard, transferred to a rented house in Silicon Valley and now occupies a cluster of office buildings in Palo Alto, Calif., is about to make its biggest move yet: to a 57-acre campus in this small city about 30 miles south of San Francisco.

title: For Help, Find the Blue Light and Push the Green Button
description: It resembles a friendly robot, as if the Subway of Tomorrow had beamed back evidence of advanced technology to our primitive subterranean present. Its sleek, oddly humanoid body, stainless steel with a pulsing blue light at the top, looks as indigenous to the New York City subway as a Modernist sculpture.

title: Companies Play for Laughs in Press Releases
description: Press releases about a companys latest big deal or board member were once somber affairs. The dispatches announced the news  and that was pretty much it.

title: Growing Body Count, but Search for a Woman Goes On
description: It began as a simple search for a missing prostitute named Shannan Gilbert, who had disappeared in May, and has evolved into a grisly murder mystery. The remains of eight people have now been discovered on a several-mile stretch of the Long Island shore, and the search will continue on Wednesday  for clues, evidence and, her family fears, perhaps the body of Ms. Gilbert.

title: The Problems With Derivatives Clearing
description: The International Monetary Fund is out with a new paper on derivatives after the storm, and it is a strangely academic exercise for an institution that one would hope would be a bit practical.

title: London, This Time Following in More Mature Footsteps
description: When I went to London in January, my idea had been to build a trip around advice from graduate students living there. After all, who would know more about seeing the city on a pittance than the impoverished intellectual crowd?

title: New York Philharmonic Cancels Cuba Trip
description: The New York Philharmonic has yet again canceled a proposed trip to Cuba, and this time it may be for keeps. The orchestra was tentatively planning to go in June, but no charter planes big enough to take it were available, said the Philharmonic spokesman, Eric Latzky. In addition, the school year will have ended, making it too difficult to gather children for a planned youth concert, he said.

title: Estrogen Lowers Breast Cancer and Heart Attack Risk in Some
description: In a finding that challenges the conventional wisdom about the risks of some hormones used in menopause, a major government study has found that years after using estrogen-only therapy, certain women had a markedly reduced risk of breast cancer and heart attack.

title: Wind is Not For the Birds
description: The American Bird Conservancy has posted video of a vulture being struck and maimed by a wind turbine blade. The move is part of a campaignseeking bird smart design and deployment of this energy option.

title: Twitter Lit
description: Marjorie Garber, a professor of English literature at Harvard, who, in addition to several books on Shakespeare, has given us critical studies on dog love, cross-dressing and sex and real estate, has a new book out about why literature matters. If the study of literature has come under fire of late (not least because of the critical practices of professors like Garber), in her latest, The Use and Abuse of Literature, she sounds much like the humanists of yore.

title: Steinhardt Talks of Buffetts Snow Job
description: Michael H. Steinhardt, chairman of Wisdom Tree Investments, describes Warren E. Buffett as a master of public relations, who has conned much of the public and the media. In an interview with CNBC, Mr. Steinhardt asserted that David L. Sokols resignation amid allegations of insider trading was a common American practice, but that it was rare for Mr. Buffetts organization to be caught up in such an affair.

title: Teamwork Is Great, but Talent Is Essential
description: Houston

title: Shutdown Watch: Three Days Out
description: With three days left until the federal governments spending authority runs out, politicians in Washington sounded increasingly worried on Tuesday about the prospect that the government could shut down in a matter of days.

title: French Panel Debates Secularism and Islam
description: PARIS  Frances governing party pressed ahead on Tuesday with a controversial debate on the nature of secularism and the challenges of Islam, an exercise criticized by some in the government and numerous religious leaders and ridiculed as cynical by both the Socialist opposition and the far-right National Front.

title: NBCUniversal Gears Up for Upfront
description: Night and day, to borrow the words of Cole Porter, the NBCUniversal division of Comcast is wooing marketers and agencies as its broadcast networks, cable channels and online properties get ready for the 2011-12 upfront advertising sales season.

title: Recording Is Excluded in Case Against Bonds
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The judge presiding over Barry Bondss perjury trial on Tuesday excluded a secretly recorded conversation that prosecutors said would bolster the credibility of one of their star witnesses.

title: 1099 Repeal Passes Senate, Heads to White House
description: On Tuesday Senate Democrats conceded defeat in the battle of how to pay for repealing the expanded 1099 reporting provision that passed last year as part of the Affordable Care Act but which many small-business owners consider burdensome. In voting to approve the bill, the Senate agreed to adopt a House Republican measure that Democrats viewed as an effort to undermine their health care law. Nonetheless, the bill passed the Senate by a lopsided 87 to 12  with most Democrats voting in favor. Shortly after the vote, the White House signaled that President Obama would sign the repeal.

title: American Soldier Is Denied Asylum in Germany
description: The German government has denied asylum to an American soldier who deserted in 2007 to avoid a second deployment in Iraq.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Japan, Libya and Ivory Coast.

title: White House Promises Veto of Anti-E.P.A. Bill
description: In case there was any doubt, the White House on Tuesday issued a formal statement opposing a bill now before the House that would bar the Environmental Protection Agency from regulating greenhouse gases for the purpose of combating climate change.

title: Wells Fargo Settles Case Originating At Wachovia
description: WASHINGTON  Even as Wall Street churned out mortgage-backed securities and derivatives in 2006, the sellers of the often-convoluted packages sometimes knew that parts of the deals  namely those that they could not sell  were worth far less than face value.

title: Ryan The Ridiculous
description: OK, lets leave the badness of the Medicare plan aside for now, and look at the economic projection the plan is based on. Heres part of what the people at Heritage are claiming the plan will accomplish:

title: Mickelson Mourns a Storm Casualty on Magnolia Lane
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The entranceway to Augusta National Golf Club, known as Magnolia Lane, dates to the 1850s. And the 61 massive magnolia trees that flank the 330-yard road leading to the clubhouse were grown from seeds planted in the same antebellum period.

title: Now Showing | Pulp Fashion
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#855", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: George Hill and the Green Light
description: Within 15 seconds of entering Sundays game against the Phoenix Suns, George Hill had made his first basket. After 35 seconds more, he had made another. Minutes later, Hill was in the midst of a full-blown explosion, as he dropped a pair of pull-up three-pointers, hit a short jumper, and then successfully executed the patented, controversial rip move to earn three foul shots and pull off an 11-2 run all on his own. Toss in an extra basket and a technical free throw, and Hill concluded his six-minute stint in the first quarter with 16 points and spotless shooting from the field and the free throw line.

title: Recipes for Ribs
description: Different flavors and preparations for ribs.

title: Finding Many Ways to View One Myth
description: Handel liked the myth of Acis and Galatea so much that he set it to music twice, and did plenty of tinkering with both versions. As told in Ovids Metamorphoses, the story is simple and brief: the shepherd Acis and the sea nymph Galatea are happily in love, but the Cyclops Polyphemus loves Galatea too. When Galatea rejects him, Polyphemus squashes Acis with a boulder, whereupon Galatea transforms her lover into a fountain.

title: Merkel's Coalition Partner Chooses a New Leader
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels center-right government received a much-needed boost Tuesday after the Free Democrats, her coalition partners, quickly ended an internal leadership feud and chose a popular young physician to revive the partys standing in time for the next federal elections, in 2013.

title: Discharges, Dropouts and Piles of Paperwork
description: When the state comptroller began an audit of the citys high school dropout rate, there was some expectation that its findings would be explosive. It was started after allegations that the city might be artificially plumping up the graduation rate through a paperwork sleight-of-hand, classifying some students who had dropped out as discharges, meaning they simply left the school for another school. While dropouts are counted against the graduation rate, discharges are not.

title: Old Hand and a New One Crossing Paths in Harmony
description: For those who have followed the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter since her days as a bright young protge of the imposing German conductor Herbert von Karajan, watching her become a mentor and benefactor in her own right has a special resonance. Her own fame secure, Ms. Mutter, 47, is devoting time to fostering a new generation of musicians.

title: Excerpt: 'Breaking in'
description: The new Fox action comedy about a security firm stars Christian Slater and Bret Harrison.

title: Viewership Falls for Mens N.C.A.A. Final
description: Connecticuts 53-41 win over Butler in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball championship game Monday night attracted an average of 20.1 million viewers, down 19 percent from last years 23.9 million when Duke beat Butler by 2 points in a more compelling game.

title: The Battle for Libya | April 5, 2011
description: Forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi battered rebel fighters on the road outside a strategic oil town Tuesday.

title: Devilish Job, for a Slacker or a Schemer
description: You might think that the young actor Bret Harrison, not yet 30, wouldnt have to worry too much about typecasting. But that would just mean that you havent seen his new sitcom, Breaking In.

title: Ban Is Proposed on Including Toys With Unhealthful Meals
description: Inspired by San Franciscos happy meal ban on toys and other items from meals that dont comply with certain nutritional standards, City Room reports, a City Council member from Queens is proposing that New York City restaurants not be allowed to offer such items with meals that have more than 500 calories and more than 600 milligrams of sodium, and that get more than 35 percent of their calories from fat. The meals would also have to include one-half cup of fruit or vegetables, or one serving of whole-grain products.

title: Sandra Lee, Governors Girlfriend, to Sell Home Products Line
description: As her boyfriend, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, is busy preaching austerity and sticking close to home, the domestic goddess Sandra Lee is expanding her empire, which already includes a magazine, two Food Network television shows and 23 cookbooks. Next up: Sandra by Sandra Lee, a collection of home products that will be sold at Sears and Kmart stores next spring.

title: An Academic Hit Man Brings More Bad News
description: This book began its life as a fizzy essay, published in The Atlantic Monthly in 2008, that contained at its core, like a radioactive pellet, a seemingly uncontroversial argument: Not every American kid is cut out for college.

title: Hempstead, in Protest, Is Severing Ties With Chase
description: The village of Hempstead on Long Island is pulling its money from JPMorgan Chase and severing its ties with the bank to protest lending and foreclosure policies, according to local officials there.

title: That 80s Moment When Nothing and (Almost) Everything Mattered
description: Cline Danhiers Blank City uses conventional documentary methods  talking-head reminiscences intercut with clips from the archives  to explore the work of a group of aggressively anticonventional artists. This is not a criticism. The movie is about the iconoclastic filmmakers clustered in the East Village and Lower East Side of Manhattan in the late 1970s and early 80s. The chaotic, fast-moving, hazily remembered scene they created deserves and benefits from the scholarly consideration Ms. Danhier offers. A dogged journalist and a careful, enthusiastic cultural historian, she illuminates a hectic and fascinating place and time, bringing it back to life and tracing its continuing influence.

title: Steven Sebrings Downtown Faces
description: Fine art and fashion make a pretty agreeable cocktail. For the photographer Steven Sebring, each is an ingredient in a body of work that spans several decades and a multitude of photographic techniques. Mr. Sebring takes a painterly approach to portraiture in his current show of monumentally scaled images of American cultural icons  poets as he calls them  who have left indelible mark on the Manhattans downtown culture. Viewed at close range, his subjects radiate light like stained glass  hence the title of the show, Illuminations, at Milk Studios in Chelsea. At a distance, the features of his subjects  writers and musicians including Jim Carroll, Joey Ramone, Richard Hell and Patti Smith  seem almost animated, swimming into focus as the viewer backs away.

title: After Months of Turmoil, Tiny Virginia Quarterly Review Is an Awards Finalist
description: The New Yorker received nine nominations for National Magazine Awards, the most for any publication this year, the American Society of Magazine Editors announced on Tuesday.

title: Wasserman Schultz Picked as D.N.C. Chairwoman
description: 7:05 p.m. | Updated Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida was named Tuesday as the new chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, with President Obama selecting her to lead the partys fund-raising and organizational efforts heading into the 2012 election cycle.

title: Personal Worship
description: Kevin OCallaghan, an instructor at New Yorks School of Visual Arts, not long ago came across an auction on eBay at 3 in the morning for church pews and interior elements from a church in Newark. Any interested party had exactly 24 hours to bid or the items would be destroyed. On a whim, OCallaghan put in a bid for $500 for the entire church interior and, to his surprise, he won. Within 24 hours, with the help of his students, he drove away with 32 pews in a 24-foot truck and brought them to a workshop at the school.

title: Bed Check | Soho House Berlin
description: First timers to East Berlin expecting rough trade and post-communist punk life are in for a shock when they arrive in the gentrified orbit of Mitte. Now the neighborhood is crammed with fashion boutiques, gourmet coffeehouses and, most recently, high-style hotels. Casa Camper opened last January, with 51 brightly colored rooms, an Asian tapas restaurant and a 24-hour rooftop lounge. Then the Weinmeister came along afterward, with oversize beds and a crowd of hard-partying creative types.

title: In Corporate Disclosure, a Murky Definition of Material
description: Harry Campbell

title: Time for an Uprising by Cisco Shareholders
description: Cisco Systems makes a juicy target for an activist assault  and the chief executive, John T. Chambers, seems to know it. True, most presumptuous investors dont have the means to build a significant stake in the $100 billion technology giant. But Ciscos poor performance, valuable assets, cash pile and years of capital misallocation provide the kindling to spark long-suffering shareholders into an uprising.

title: France's Military Lead
description: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen analyzes the possible reasons for President Nicolas Sarkozy's aggressive strategy in Libya and Ivory Coast.

title: Champions League: Can Inter and Tottenham Survive?
description: Schalke and Real Madrid will be hard-pressed to squander their prodigious leads after the first leg of their quarterfinal series in the UEFA Champions League.

title: Put Your Money Where Your Taste Is
description: THE other guy in LimoLand was named Alvaro, I think. Thats what it sounded like from inside the fitting room, where Id heard him come into the store and begin asking about the brand. It was too youthful for him, he thought. Too colorful. By this time Id gotten a glimpse: he was Balazs-like, crisp and certain, but taller. He had some time on his hands. He was curious. The woman behind the register pointed out a photo book that piqued his interest.

title: Miles of Aisles, Endless Opportunities to Save
description: The neighborhood Gristedes, the local Food Emporium: theyre your enemies. The prices are inflated, the selection is limited. And those aisles! Its as if they dont want two perfectly reasonable people to peruse the cookies at the same time. (Um, I mean whole-grain cereals, of course. And fruit.)

title: Signs of Repression in Tripoli on the Faces of Two Women
description: Since she was dragged away from foreign journalists in a Tripoli hotel ten days ago, Eman al-Obeidy, a Libyan lawyer who wanted to tell the world that she had been gang-raped by government security forces, has become an icon of resistance to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis rule.

title: A NASA Ode to a Color-Sensing Satellite
description: NASA has produced a very nice video tribute to the SeaWiFS orbiting sensor, which provided vast amounts of valuable data on Earths waters, plant life and weather from 1997 through 2010. The video is narrated by Gene Feldman, an oceanographer at the Goddard Space Flight Center:

title: A Long Swim Looking for Laughs
description: The Umbrella Plays, as befits its title, is full of waterworks. There are, most arrestingly, the white plastic buckets of water that get dumped over heads and emptied sideways onto characters bodies. And then there are the tears, the oh so many tears: wracking sobs, misty eyes, messy heaves, all trickling and streaming out from one fraught encounter to the next.

title: An Artist Takes Role of Chinas Conscience
description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, who disappeared into police custody in Beijing after he was detained on Sunday while trying to board a flight for Hong Kong, is a fully 21st-century figure, global-minded, media-savvy, widely networked. He is also the embodiment of a cultural type, largely unfamiliar to the West, that dates far back into Chinas ancient past.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Wine Divorced From Food? Lets Be Adults About It
description: WINE and food belong together. Thats always been one of my cardinal beliefs.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Oysters With a Cause

title: La Silhouette
description: 362 West 53rd Street, Midtown, (212) 581-2400, la-silhouettenyc.com

title: Thirstbarvin
description: 629 Classon Avenue at Pacific Street, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 857-9227.

title: A Kosher Chicken From Murrays Coop
description: Murrays chickens have been among the better birds around. Theyre raised locally without antibiotics in certified humane conditions. But until now they havent been kosher. In response to customer demand, Fairway has arranged to have some chickens processed in a glatt kosher plant in Rockland County. Kosher chickens tend to have more flavor because they have to be salted. Simply roasted, with a piece of the fat from the cavity parked on the breast to melt for basting, its a very tasty chicken. I added no seasoning.

title: When Class Meant Brie and Pears
description: SURELY it tells us something about the fickle nature of the American appetite that Harry & David is looking for ways to remind its customers of the existence of trees.

title: At This Farm, Its All Garlic and Eggplant
description: Locavores who criticize monocultural farming obviously do not have Patrick Salvati and Dorothy DeMarco in mind. Their Salento Farm in Shelton, Conn., may not be monocultural, but its close to it. They grow only garlic and eggplant. Their garlic is German hard neck, and they chop it up with garlic scapes, adding olive oil and Parmigiano-Reggiano to make a garlic pesto, so you can banish mint jelly forever for that spring lamb roast. They also dry and pulverize it to make first-rate pungent garlic powder to use in dry rubs, to season your pizza dough, and so forth. Ours is all garlic, nothing else, not like the commercial brands, Mr. Salvati said, as he won over a garlic powder skeptic at his new stand in the Greenmarket. Their tangy pickled eggplant is excellent on a bruschetta. In fall and winter, they sell the garlic heads, too.

title: Ribs Without Smoke
description: CONVENTIONAL wisdom holds that pork ribs taste best when cooked outdoors on a grill or smoker. Conventional wisdom hasnt experienced the sweet-sour balsamic-glazed St. Louis-cut spare ribs at Animal in Los Angeles. The restaurants chefs, Jon Shook and Vinny Dotolo, prepare them in a way that most barbecue purists would never order, much less eat: baked in the oven.

title: Rib Heresies: The Bones That Got Away
description: Ive spent a few weeks researching the fine points of pork ribs braised in the oven. But what about the most commonly braised bones of all, beef short ribs? My final indoor rib satori came from a neighborhood restaurant near where I live in Miami  a not infrequent source of weeknight carryout. Opened by two Mexico City-born restaurateurs, Lalo Durazo and Oscar del Rivero, Talavera in Coral Gables serves the sort of regionally inspired Mexican food rarely found in South Florida.

title: Final Bidders for Blockbuster Include Icahn and Dish
description: Several bidders squared off on Tuesday in Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan in an all-day auction of Blockbuster, the long-struggling video-rental pioneer.

title: Generational Divide Colors Debate Over Medicares Future
description: The Republican budget released on Tuesday is a daring one in many ways. Above all, it would replace the current Medicare with a system of private health insurance plans subsidized by the government. Whether you like or loathe that idea, it would undeniably reduce Medicares long-term funding gap  which is by far the biggest source of looming federal deficits.

title: The Fickle Fashions of Food
description: Whenever Im confronted with news about the latest diet to end all diets, I find my mind drifting back to the 1980s.

title: Cephalon Rejects Valeants $5.7 Billion Takeover Bid
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated

title: The Inner Workings of Midlife Crises
description: It has been 18 years since an adventurous, autobiographical indie comedy called My Lifes in Turnaround  about the making of a movie called My Lifes in Turnaround  charmed critics and began the filmmaking careers of a cabbie named Eric Schaeffer and a bartender named Donal Lardner Ward. Now the two men have written, directed and starred in a sequel, Theyre Out of the Business. Like their first film, its a fictionalized account of its own making, and it demonstrates that you should never underestimate the value of youthful energy.

title: To Sell Cars, Ford Swaps Rides Once Again in Ad
description: The third and latest version of Fords Swap Your Ride advertising campaign premiered Tuesday night on network and cable television. The ads are part of a spring sales promotion.

title: Nissan Wants Someone to Live the Glamorous Life of a Reporter
description: As if the hungry mob of reporters expected to attend press days at this years New York International Auto Show werent huge enough, Nissan wants to invite yet one more.

title: Crisis Saddles Village With Unwanted Notoriety
description: IITATE, Japan  The mayor sprang into action the moment he heard that scientists from the International Atomic Energy Agency were in the village halls parking lot. He rushed outside to confront the group, three Europeans and a Japanese, who wore surgical masks and cloth booties as they waved around a Geiger counter.

title: Vieira Likely to Leave NBCs Today
description: Meredith Vieira, the co-host of NBCs Today show, will probably leave the top-rated morning show this year, two people with knowledge of her deliberations said Tuesday.

title: Bernard Clayton Jr., Cookbook Author, Is Dead at 94
description: Bernard Clayton Jr., a newspaper reporter whose love for fresh bread inspired him to master the art of baking and write several classic cookbooks on bread and pastry, died on March 28 in Bloomington, Ind. He was 94.

title: Taliban Exploit Tensions Seething in Afghan Society
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  If the protesters who pushed this city to the brink last weekend were really worried about Koran burning, wondered Layloma Popal, the headmistress of this citys biggest girls school, then why did they try to burn down my school?

title: A Military Trial for the 9/11 Detainees
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico: Two Americans Shot and Killed in Tijuana
description: Two American men were shot and killed in Tijuana as they waited in line to cross the border into San Diego, the Baja California State authorities said Tuesday. Kevin Romero, 28, and Sergio Salcido, 25, who lived near the beach outside Tijuana and worked at a brewery equipment company in San Diego, were shot before 3 a.m. Monday on their way to work. Matt Pelot, who employed the two men, said that Mr. Romero had told him he was living with a Mexican woman and hoped to adopt her son. Ral Gutirrez, a spokesperson for the state attorney generals office, said the authorities believed that the killings were unlikely to have been tied to drug trafficking.

title: Yankees Power Hides Top of Lineups Struggles
description: Power is a great equalizer. With a flick of the wrist, it can bail out poor pitching, erase deficits or pad leads. In the case of the Yankees, it can also minimize their deficiencies, like the slow starts by Brett Gardner and Derek Jeter atop their batting order.

title: The Way We Eat, and the Colors We Like
Lobbyists on Capitol Hill
Married Gay Immigrants
Frances Role in Three Conflicts Displays a More Muscular Policy
description: PARIS  France on Tuesday found itself engaged in three shooting wars at once for the first time in memory, indicating a new muscularity in using power by the politically embattled French president, Nicolas Sarkozy.

title: A Nuns Book
The Light Bulb Debate
Ai Weiwei, Chinese Dissident Artist
description: Images of the artist, who was taken into Chinese custody on Sunday.

title: The Phillies Four Aces
description: Just in case you missed it, this weekends Sunday Magazine profiled the Philadelphia Phillies talent-packed pitching lineup. And in an accompaniment to the article, Nate ranked the best four-man pitching rotations in Major League Baseball history.

title: Connecticut and Butler Saved Worst for Last
description: It became all the rage at some point Monday night to proclaim Connecticuts eventual 53-41 victory over Butler the worst championship game ever. Twitter, for one, was overrun with the idea. At halftime, CBS analysts took turns trying to top one another in describing how awful it was. Any real measurement of the awfulness involves aesthetics and statistics, and this game had a lot of both going against it.

title: Democrats Get New Leader as Kaine Announces Run
description: Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, announced Tuesday that he would run for the Senate in Virginia, setting up a clash in 2012 between two former governors in an important swing state. George Allen, a Republican, is already running for the seat he held for one term before being ousted in 2006 by Senator Jim Webb. Later Tuesday, Democratic officials said President Obama had selected Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida to take over as committee chairwoman, leading the partys fund-raising and organizational efforts heading into the 2012 election season. She would be the first woman to serve as the permanent head of the committee.

title: Suit Over 109 Square Feet Ends in a $150,000 Settlement
description: A home-buying couple who sued a major Brooklyn developer in a dispute over 109 square feet agreed to settle the case for $150,000, but rejected the developers offer of an additional $20,000 to keep quiet about the agreement.

title: From the Windows of Abidjan
description: Abidjan, Ivory Coast

title: Ford Executive Charged With Drunken Driving
description: Elena Ford, director of global marketing, sales and service operations for the Ford Motor Company and a great-great-granddaughter of Henry Ford, will appear in court later this month on charges of drunken driving and child endangerment. Todd Flood, Ms. Fords lawyer, said she had waived an arraignment that had been scheduled for Tuesday in Ferndale District Court.

title: Syrian Rights Groups Raise Toll From Unrest
description: CAIRO  Human rights groups on Tuesday raised their estimates of the death toll from unrest in Syria, as protest organizers there continued their call for more demonstrations against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Go Philly!
description: Foodwise, among the most progressive cities in the country right now is Philadelphia, where the alliance of a forward-thinking mayor and a 19-year-old non-profit is moving things forward. Within a year or two, Philly might be funding better access to real food for its poorest citizens by taxing soda. And if you accept the notion that childhood obesity and the accompanying Type 2 diabetes are big problems, and youre aware that soda is a major cause, youll agree thats a huge step in the right direction.

title: Intel Unveils Chips for Mission Critical Server Tasks
description: Generating buzz for a new microchip  one that is for servers, no less  is challenging. But Intel gave it a try with its latest line of microprocessors, the Xeon E7, unveiled on Tuesday, by renting a former bank and briefing reporters in the vault.

title: Better Cleanup Planned at Former Chrome Plant
description: JERSEY CITY  Some 25 years ago, Ellen Wright was driving home through her neighborhood of single-family wood-frame houses here when shenoticed that the streets were slick with green water.

title: Across the Great Football Divide
description: INDIANAPOLIS

title: At Particle Lab, a Tantalizing Glimpse Has Physicists Holding Their Breaths
description: Physicists at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory are planning to announce Wednesday that they have found a suspicious bump in their data that could be evidence of a new elementary particle or even, some say, a new force of nature.

title: White House Assails Pakistan Effort on Militants
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday gave Congress a harshly critical assessment of Pakistans efforts to defeat Al Qaeda and other militants, saying that after years of work with the Pakistani military there remains no clear path toward defeating the insurgency that thrives in the country.

title: From Where They Stand, It Looks Easier
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: Times Up, Qaddafi
description: Tripoli, Libya

title: Short Game Gives Mickelson an Edge
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  To know more about why Phil Mickelson has emerged as the favorite to win the Masters for the second straight year, consider one minor incident from his transcendent weekend at the  Houston Open. Hint: it has nothing to do with how far down the fairway he was blasting his drives.

title: As Shutdown Looms, Agencies Brace for Its Impact
description: WASHINGTON  The National Zoo would close, but the lions and tigers would get fed; Yellowstone and other national parks would shut down. The Internal Revenue Service could stop issuing refund checks. Customs and Border Patrol agents training officials in Afghanistan might have to come home. And thousands of government-issued BlackBerrys would go silent.

title: Servicers Said to Agree to Revamped Foreclosures
description: The nations top mortgage servicers are expected to sign legal agreements by the end of this week compelling them to change their foreclosure procedures, regulatory officials said Tuesday.

title: Estimating Medicare Taxes Versus Benefits
description: My column this week describes some work by Stephanie Rennane and Eugene Steuerle examining the total amount of money people pay in Medicare taxes over the course of their lives, as well as the total benefits they receive. For every cohort of workers, going back to the founding of Medicare in the 1960s, the benefits exceed taxes.

title: The Budget Battles: Republicans Maneuver Toward a Shutdown
description: The House Republicans on Tuesday made it clear to anyone who had missed it that they are not interested in a deal on the current federal budget. In a meeting at the White House, they rejected a deal to get through the next six months. President Obama, silent for too long on this fight, emerged from the meeting to say that he would tolerate no more ideological gamesmanship. But the Republicans, if anything, only increased their demands, and a government shutdown seemed likely to begin on Friday.

title: CBS Executive Denies Being F.B.I. Informant
description: A CBS News executive angrily denied reports that he was a government informant during the Oklahoma City bombing investigation, saying Tuesday that reports that he had cooperated with the Federal Bureau of Investigation and named a confidential source were outrageous and untrue.

title: When a Punch Line Is No Longer a Lifeline for Egyptians
description: CAIRO  The jokes have stalled, another sign that Egypts revolution has too.

title: The Budget Battles: The Threat to Medicaid and Medicare
description: Representative Paul Ryans proposals to reform Medicare and Medicaid are mostly an effort to shift the burden to beneficiaries and the states. They have very little reform in them.

title: A Passageway for Prisoners, 40 Feet Below
description: Here is a small strip of Pearl Street in Lower Manhattan, and what lies beneath this ordinary patch of asphalt and concrete is a 40-yard boulevard dedicated to murderers, gangsters, villains, thieves, scoundrels.

title: Virginias Bad Old Man
description: It was two days after the presidential inauguration, and the Virginia secession convention was in an uproar. The pro-secession minority insisted that Abraham Lincolns Inaugural Address was a declaration of war against the South. But the delegate from rural Franklin County, Jubal Early, nicknamed the Bad Old Man for his stubborn attitude and imposing figure, would have none of it.

title: A Noisy Casting Call as Thousands Quack for Aflac
description: IT sounds like the setup for a punch line: A man walks into a room and quacks like a duck, then so does another and another and. ...

title: U.S. Sees Array of New Threats at Japans Nuclear Plant
description: United States government engineers sent to help with the crisis in Japan are warning that the troubled nuclear plant there is facing a wide array of fresh threats that could persist indefinitely, and that in some cases are expected to increase as a result of the very measures being taken to keep the plant stable, according to a confidential assessment prepared by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Hunting Birds of Paradise
description: You know those moments when You Just Want to Die?

title: Through Political Prism, Iraqis Grieve
description: TIKRIT, Iraq  The people in the offices waited to die as the gunmen, wearing police uniforms and suicide vests, went door to door, tossing hand grenades and spraying gunfire. Days later, the provincial council headquarters here was a charnel house of smeared blood and burned flesh.

title: The Budget Battles: Prosperity for Whom?
description: If the House Republican budget blueprint released on Tuesday is the path to prosperity that its title claims, it is hard to imagine what ruin would look like.

title: Twitters Tax Break Clears One Hurdle
description: Twitter is well on its way to getting a tax break in San Francisco after threatening to leave the city for the suburbs.

title: Rebuilding Downtown From the Ground Up
description: QUINCY, Mass.  Barring a catastrophe, few cities get the chance to totally rebuild their downtowns, from the sewer lines deep underground to the sidewalks, buildings, parks and lighting above. But an unusual public-private partnership is allowing this city of 91,000, first settled in the early 17th century and famed as the hometown of the Adams presidents, to try to do just that.

title: 2 School Custodians Accused of Fake-Job Scheme
description: Two school custodians in the Bronx cheated the city out of more than $500,000 by creating no-show jobs and using school money to pay no-show workers to maintain private properties one of them owned in Queens, city investigators charged on Tuesday.

title: Recent U.N. Actions Show Policy Shift, Analysts Say
description: UNITED NATIONS  The unusual military strikes by the United Nations against military bases of the Ivory Coasts strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, represent a seminal moment in which an organization generally disinclined to intervene forcefully in the affairs of member states is showing a new willingness to take bold action to save lives, diplomats and analysts said.

title: A Conservative Vision, With Bipartisan Risks
description: WASHINGTON  The audacious long-term budget path that House Republicans outlined on Tuesday is not going to become law anytime soon, if ever. Senate Democrats and President Obama will see to that.

title: Contrarian Adding Bets in Mideast
description: When it comes to investing in the Middle East, Thomas J. Barrack Jr. takes the long view. Very long.

title: Callahan Is Out With a Broken Ankle
description: Ryan Callahan, a 26-year-old forward who does a little of everything for the Rangers, fractured his right ankle while trying to preserve his teams stirring victory Monday over Boston, the Rangers said. Callahan will be sidelined indefinitely.

title: Brazil Rejects Panels Request to Stop Dam
description: SO PAULO  Brazils government emphatically refused on Tuesday to suspend work on a huge hydroelectric dam in the Amazon, despite pleas that the project could displace tens of thousands of indigenous people and cause environmental harm.

title: Inquiry Into Payments by Device Maker
description: Nevada state officials have begun an investigation to determine if payments to cardiologists there by a little-known heart device company were legitimate consulting fees or inducements to the doctors for using its products.

title: States Fear Local Effects if Shutdown Cuts Off Cash
description: Already straining to make ends meet as the longest downturn since the Great Depression grinds on, state and local governments are now facing a new, unwelcome question: What would a shutdown of the federal government mean for their struggles to balance their budgets?

title: Unable to Swing, Bay Is Unlikely to Return Soon
description: PHILADELPHIA  It just wouldnt be the Mets if there werent some lingering injury problem to frustrate them.

title: Witnesses in Police Rape Trial Outline Evening of Drinking
description: By the time Kofi Owusu pulled his yellow cab up to the front of an East Village apartment building early one December morning in 2008, the passenger in the back seat had already vomited twice  once inside the taxi, he said in court on Tuesday.

title: New Haitian Leader Pledges Reconciliation
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  It was a new stage on Tuesday for Michel Martelly, the former hit-maker who nicknamed himself president in song and is now on the verge of serving as the real thing in this devastated country.

title: A Beach Landing? Well, Hed Seen It on TV
description: These things look so easy in Alaska.

title: More Pupils Are Learning Online, Fueling Debate on Quality
description: MEMPHIS  Jack London was the subject in Daterrius Hamiltons online English 3 course. In a high school classroom packed with computers, he read a brief biography of London with single-paragraph excerpts from the authors works. But the curriculum did not require him, as it had generations of English students, to wade through a tattered copy of Call of the Wild or To Build a Fire.

title: Once a Great Flop, Now Sold for Billions
description: In announcing the sale of Pringles on Tuesday, Procter & Gamble concluded what had been a tumultuous, sometimes zany, 50-year experiment in engineered food.

title: Wednesday: Took by the Hand
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome to Wednesday, where the wordplay ramps up just a bit, and there may or may not be a twist in the theme. I wouldnt call todays debut puzzle by Gareth Bain twisted, but it is a fine theme that works very well. Add to that a bit of misdirection in the cluing, and weve got a very clever puzzle to get us through that midweek slump.

title: In New Jersey, Ex-Prosecutor Pleads Guilty in Bribery Case
description: NEWARK  A fixture in legal and political circles, Clifford J. Minor has been a police officer, judge, prosecutor, defense lawyer and mayoral candidate. On Tuesday, he added an unflattering entry to his rsum: confessed felon.

title: Screening the Days Catch for Radiation
description: Eric Ripert, the chef of Le Bernardin, the high temple of seafood in Manhattan, bought a new kitchen gadget a few days ago: a radiation detector.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 5, 2011

title: Standpipe Irrelevant in 2 Deaths, Lawyer Says
description: Lawyers for three construction supervisors charged in the deaths of two firefighters at the former Deutsche Bank tower challenged on Tuesday one of the central assertions made by prosecutors: that the removal of a section of standpipe in the basement had prevented the firefighters from obtaining water that could have saved their lives.

title: Knicks Enjoy a Rare Laugher
description: Carmelo Anthony was seated comfortably next to Amare Stoudemire, each of them wrapped in big towels and broad smiles. Anthony muttered something, Stoudemire laughed and a few feet away, Anthony Carter hit a running, two-handed layup  all unmistakable signs of a rout.

title: Marie and Bruce
description: Images from the revival of Wallace Shawns 1979 portrait of marital misery at the Acorn Theater.

title: Theres Room for Everyone Aboard a Marital Misery Tour
description: Marie and Bruce, Wallace Shawns 1979 portrait of a festering marriage, is just the show to see when youre in a really, really bad mood. Not that Mr. Shawns play, which has been revived in high style on Theater Row by the New Group, is likely to pull you out of that mood.

title: Young Does It All for Mets in Debut
description: PHILADELPHIA  When the Mets signed Chris Young during the off-season, they projected a pitcher who could excel at Citi Field, the Mets spacious home, where so many long fly balls turn into catchable balls in front of the imposing high walls.

title: Shutting the Government Down
description: Details on the government shutdown.

title: S.E.C. Weighs Trading Limits to Avert Extreme Volatility
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Tuesday that it would consider limits on the amount by which a stocks price can move in any five-minute period, a fixture that would replace the single-stock circuit breakers installed after the so-called flash crash volatility on May 6, 2010.

title: Dr. D.M. French Dies at 86; Treated 60s Marchers
description: Dr. David M. French, who helped found an organization of doctors that provided medical care to marchers during the civil rights era and who later organized health care programs in 20 African nations, died on Thursday in Charlottesville, Va. He was 86 and lived in Barboursville, Va.

title: Sewage Holding Tank Bursts, and Two Men Are Killed
description: Two workers died on Tuesday and millions of gallons of largely untreated sewage spewed into a river when a holding tank wall collapsed at a treatment plant in Gatlinburg, Tenn.

title: Soriano Sets Up Yanks for Disappointment
description: Perhaps it is better this way. Perhaps it is better for the Yankees to discover now, in the fifth game of their season, that their bullpen is not invincible. That not all leads are safe, not even against the team that has tried and tried and failed to topple them.

title: U.S. and Colombia Said to Reach Trade Deal
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration will announce  perhaps as early as Wednesday  that it has reached agreement with Colombia on a free trade pact, a United States official said on Tuesday.

title: Arizona: $10,000 Fine for Petroglyph Graffiti
description: A federal judge fined a North Carolina man $10,000 on Monday and sentenced him to five years probation and 100 hours of community service for scrawling his name into a well-known petroglyph while on a fishing trip on the Colorado River in Arizona last June. Trenton A. Ganey, 29, pleaded guilty to using a rock to scrape his first name into Indian rock art known as the Descending Sheep panel, believed to be more than 1,000 years old, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: FOREIGN

title: Aggies Beat Irish for First N.C.A.A. Title
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The womens N.C.A.A. championship game had just begun Tuesday and it already seemed to be over for Notre Dame, which could barely make a pass, much less a basket, against a ferocious Texas A&M defense.

title: Soldier of Fortune: Collecting Receivables
description: There are many bumps in the road on the way to building a successful business. Many of the challenges are right in front of you  like finding business, delivering the product or service on time, hiring the right people, and financing the whole to-do. One of the most surprising, upsetting, and dangerous challenges is trying to collect money owed (as we discuss in a small-business guide published today). If you own a cash business, this should not be a problem. If you are in a business that has to extend credit, it is a problem that can have disastrous consequences.

title: Big Medical Groups Begin Patient Data-Sharing Project
description: The ideal of computerizing patient records is captured in the words behind the governments aspirational acronym, N.H.I.N., for Nationwide Health Information Network.

title: De Rosario Hastened Exit From Toronto
description: Dwayne De Rosario probably wrote his own ending to a sad hometown saga that saw the Ontario product sour on Toronto F.C. and end up wearing the colors of the Red Bulls.

title: The Truth About Sex and Exercise
description: Lets be clear about this at the start. Vigorous sex will not inevitably cause your heart to stop, and neither will jogging. But you could be excused for believing that both activities are lethal if you relied on some of the coverage of an important new article published last month in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Word of the Day | turbid
description: turbid \tr-bd\ adjective

title: Numbers of Children of Whites Falling Fast
description: WASHINGTON  Americas population of white children, a majority now, will be in the minority during this decade, sooner than previously expected, according to a new report.

description: Texas A&M defeated Notre Dame 76-70, winning its first national basketball title.

title: Bloomberg Is Sued Over Citys Handgun Permit Fee
description: A gun-rights-advocacy group sued Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday, claiming that the city fee for obtaining a home-handgun permit was so excessive that it impinged on the Second Amendment.

title: Belated Realism on Yemen
description: The Obama administration is doing the right thing by trying to ease President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen from office. It should have started weeks ago, after Mr. Salehs supporters opened fire on protesters and more than 50 people were killed, turning most of the country against him. With the civilian death toll mounting and the military too divided and preoccupied to pursue a dangerous Al Qaeda affiliate, Mr. Salehs swift departure is essential.

title: News Quiz | April 6, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Fueled by Protests, Angry Wisconsin Voters Show Up to Fight
description: WAUKESHA, Wis.  Union supporters and Democrats unleashed their fury over Scott Walker, the Republican governor, and his efforts to diminish collective bargaining rights at the ballot box on Tuesday.

title: Mort Sahl, Tammy Wynette and Captain Beefheart Added to National Recording Registry
description: Mort Sahl may not have wanted his comedy album At Sunset to be recorded, but it is now headed for a permanent place in the audio archives of the Library of Congress, along with works by Tammy Wynette, Captain Beefheart, Al Green, Steely Dan and De La Soul, as well as one of the earliest known recordings of Take Me Out to the Ball Game, the library is scheduled to announce on Wednesday.

title: Ivory Coast Opposition Pounds at Strongman
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Opposition forces in Ivory Coast on Wednesday blasted away at the residence of the nations strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, hoping to seize him alive for a possible trial after he refused French and United Nations demands to step down.

title: Wayne Rooney Runs on Rage
description: Six months ago, Wayne Rooney cut a rather despondent figure. The injuries and the media scandals in his private life appeared to have taken their toll on Manchester Uniteds star striker, both mentally and physically. Critics and fans were assured that he would return to his best soon enough, but until the start of 2011, evidence of such a recovery was scant.

title: Palestinian Security Forces Abused Journalists, Report Says
description: JERUSALEM  Palestinian journalists have been subjected to detention and abuse at the hands of Palestinian security agencies, a pattern that has led many to self-censor and produced a chilling effect on the free exchange of information and ideas, a human rights group said in a new report.

title: What Possessions Does Your Family Treasure?
description: The La Vache family of Brooklyn have taken such good care of their 1963 Buick Wildcat coupe that all 75,745 miles it has traveled have been recorded in a diary begun the day they bought the car. What possessions do you or does someone in your extended family have that are treasured this way?

description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  After a rebuff last month from King Abdullah, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates met privately with him for an hour and a half on Wednesday in an attempt to thaw ice-cold relations between Saudi Arabia and the United States.

title: To Tell the Story, Forget Perfection
description: Ty Cacek, 20, is the first of three photographers who will be summer interns in The New York Times photo department to be featured on Turning Point. Mr. Cacek was raised in Columbia, Mo. After high school, he moved to Kampala. He is expected to earn his undergraduate degree from Western Kentucky University in 2013.

title: Core of Stricken Reactor Probably Leaked, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Wednesday that some of the core of a stricken Japanese reactor had probably leaked from its steel pressure vessel into the bottom of the containment structure, implying that the damage was even worse than previously thought.

title: Commerzbank to Repay $20.3 Billion of German Bailout

title: Berlusconi Prostitution Trial Starts but Is Adjourned
description: ROME  A highly anticipated trial in which Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi faces accusations of paying an underage girl for sex and other improprieties opened amid media fanfare in Milan on Wednesday but was immediately adjourned till the end of May.

title: Bonnards Time in Normandy on Show in Giverny
description: The painter Pierre Bonnard lived in the lovely Normandy town of La Roulette from 1911 until 1938, charmed by its rustic beauty and its proximity to the home of his friend Claude Monet in Giverny. Already established as an artist, he would develop there into one of the most popular of the Impressionists.

title: Seeking Your Questions on the Big Decision
description: This is the point in the college admissions season where the responsibilities of applicant and admissions officer flip. Now that the colleges have made their decisions  accept, reject or defer  the choices, for the most part, rest with applicants and their families. A decision, usually in the form of a deposit, is due May 1.

description: Q.

title: A Wedding Planner for All, Including Those in Need
description: Devorah Benjamin zips up her fatigues  a black hooded sweatshirt with The Wedding Planner embroidered in fluorescent pink across the back  and is ready for another days battle. Her army stands at the ready: musicians, photographers, florists, hair and makeup artists, and a team of middle-aged mothers who volunteer their nights to cook and donate food.

title: Romeo and Juliet in the Casa Presidencial
description: I divorced the president to get married to the people. So proclaimed the first lady of Guatemala in March as she announced her candidacy for her countrys presidential election in September.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A top Afghan official confirmed on Wednesday that the countrys government had been in peace talks with the Taliban.

title: Rehearse Me a Little, Wherever You Are
description: Its not so hard to be married, as one wry lyric from Stephen Sondheims Company reminds us. But rehearsing when only half your cast is available is a different story.

title: Introducing Sustainable Profits: Turning Waste Into Profit
description: My company, TerraCycle, has a very unusual business model. We turn the worlds waste into new products. We collect non-recyclable waste, some straight from manufacturers and some from schools, charities and other community groups, and we partner with other manufacturers to recycle or upcycle that material into new products  like plastic lumber from juice pouches and shower curtains from sewn-together granola wrappers. My channel on this blog will be a diary of our experiences and decisions, our lessons learned and opportunities missed.

title: Dish Network Wins Auction for Blockbuster
description: After a bankruptcy auction that extended into the early hours on Wednesday, Dish Network announced that it had emerged as the winner of Blockbusters assets, with a bid valued at $320 million.

title: The Newcomers Guide to Wireless Tethering
description: What it is: Your smartphone has a high-speed, 3G data connection. Your laptop may only have Wi-Fi. Tethering turns your smartphone into a wireless router, sharing the phones 3G connection with other devices over Wi-Fi. No more wireless data cards for laptops, and devices like Wi-Fi-only iPads can get on the Internet via a phone.

title: Wasserman Schultz Brings Fund-Raising Prowess and TV Presence to D.N.C.
description: 11:57 a.m. | Updated In choosing Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida as the next chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, President Obama has turned to a telegenic young woman from a key swing state who will be an aggressive champion for his policies.

description: Is Tom Coughlin a better coach than Rex Ryan?

description: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

description: Daimler and Rolls Royce made their joint offer for the engine maker Tognum official on Wednesday, leaving their bid unchanged from the initial proposal of 24 euros a share.

title: Portugal Asks Europe for Bailout
description: LISBON  Portugals caretaker government gave in to market pressures on Wednesday and joined Greece and Ireland in seeking an emergency bailout. The decision came after the government was forced to pay much higher rates to sell more debt.

title: Advice From General McChrystal: Listen, Learn and Lead
description: In one remarkably tumultuous year, Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal reached career highs and lows that few military men ever achieve or endure. After decades of distinguished service and becoming the primary architect of Americas counterinsurgency strategies in Iraq and Afghanistan, General McChrystal in June 2010 became the first general in nearly 60 years to be relieved of his command by a president in wartime for disrespect toward the White House.

title: Nocturnalist | Uplifting Surprises, but Few Pure Scots
Privatizing Medicare
description: As part of their budget proposal, Republican lawmakers are now talking about replacing the Medicare program with a private system that would rely on commercial insurers to provide coverage to the elderly instead of the federal government.

title: The Fragile Success of School Reform in the Bronx
description: On a recent morning, Ramn Gonzlez, the principal of M.S. 223, a public middle school in the South Bronx, arrived at work as usual at 7:30, stripped off his coat and suit jacket, deposited his tea and toast from a nearby diner on the cluttered conference table in his office and hustled down the hallway to the schools back door to greet arriving students. Gonzlez had a busy agenda for the day. Among other things, he needed to get to work on a proposal for the citys Department of Education to expand 223 into a high school.

Smith will receive lifetime achievement honors at this years Tony Awards, and the playwright Eve Ensler, the animal trainer Bill Berloni, Sharon Jensen and the Alliance for Inclusion in the Arts and the Drama Book Shop will also receive special distinctions this year, Tony organizers said on Wednesday.

title: Out There in the Dark, All Alone
description: LAST month, in response to an aside I made about Americans no longer being the avid moviegoers they once were  comparing the 90 million who went to the movies each week in 1948 with todays audience, which hovers around 23 million  Matthew Sigman, a self-confessed big-screen film fan from New York, wrote in with a quibble. I do beg to differ on the statistical basis of your statement suggesting Americans dont love movies as much as they used to because annual attendance has dropped, Mr. Sigman wrote.

title: Fat Talk
description: Conversations in which women criticise their body shape, despite often not being overweight.

title: Remembering Don Hill
description: When Don Hill, who opened his eponymous downtown club in 1993 (and before that, the Cat Club and Kennys Castaways), died last Thursday, social media were buzzing with words of remembrance. Many people knew him as the man at the end of the bar, drinking tequila and Heineken, occasionally playing video games. We did parties last month for the First Precinct and the Hells Angels, said Paul Sevigny, who, along with Nur Khan, began working with Hill about seven months ago to bring some new blood to the place. Thats how universally loved he was. Loved, yes, but also a mystery even to those who knew him  details about his family and childhood remain fuzzy. Youd go in there with someone whod never been and youd be like, Oh, theres Don! And people would be like, Theres actually a Don Hill? said the makeup artist Mike Potter. People didnt know he was a real person. Like many, Potter, a club regular in the 90s, has Don Hills to thank for his career: After John Cameron Mitchell recognized him from the SqueezeBox party, the two became friendly, which led to Potter doing the makeup for Hedwig and the Angry Inch. Brendan Manning, of the New York City chapter of the Hells Angels, points out that Hill, whose memorial service is tonight at St. Patricks Cathedral in NoLIta, had booked  for $200 a week  a guy named Bruce Springsteen, back in the Kennys Castaways days. The Moment asked a few who knew Hill personally to tell us about him (in more than 140 characters).

title: NCIS, New and Old, Lifts CBS in Ratings
description: A new installment of NCIS topped the ratings on Tuesday night as 18.8 million viewers watched the show on CBS at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen estimates. CBS led the night over all despite broadcasting a rerun of NCIS: Los Angeles (12.6 million) at 9 p.m. opposite ABCs Dancing With the Stars results episode (15.6 million). ABCs new series Body of Proof won at 10 p.m. with 11.1 million viewers, outperforming The Good Wife on CBS (10.6 million) and Parenthood on NBC (4.7 million). ABCs No Ordinary Family (5.7 million) lagged behind the first half of NBCs Biggest Loser, which averaged 7.3 million viewers from 8 to 10. NBC ranked third for the night, behind CBS and ABC but ahead of repeats on Fox.

title: Trailer: 'Macbeth'
description: Scenes from Cheek by Jowl's production of Shakespeare's tragedy, which opened Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. (Video courtesy of BAM)

title: Except for Newsweek, Advertising Growth for Most Newsweekly Magazines
description: Weekly news magazines fared well in the first three months of the year, according to one closely watched industry barometer  except for Newsweek.

title: Dogs Best Friend?
description: Man has very little to do with the well-being of dogs in two new, very funny books about our pets and the company they keep. Say Hello to Zorro!, by Carter Goodrich, observes the relationship between old dog and new, while Scritch-Scratch a Perfect Match, by Kimberly Marcus, considers the relationship between dog and flea. Neither twosome forms a fast or easy friendship.

title: Hawk Cam | Live From the Nest
description: Update, May 11 | A red-tailed hawk hatchling emerged May 6 in the nest of Violet and Bobby, high above Washington Square Park. But Violet has a badly injured leg that is imperiling her life. Rehabilitators will be at N.Y.U. on Thursday to capture her, treat her and, hopefully, return her immediately to the nest. For the latest (along with this video player) go to: Hawk Cam | Updates From the Nest.

title: Hawk Cam | Watching Bobby and Violet

title: Gross? Maybe. But It Got Me on TV, Right?

title: Ovation Cable Channel Is Ready to Dance
description: For years, cable channels have filled their programming schedules with repeats of popular series from broadcast networks, everything from I Love Lucy to The Golden Girls to Law & Order. Now, a new generation of cable channels is picking up some nontraditional network fare.

title: A Homage to a Homage, Destruction at Its Core
description: JEAN TINGUELYS Homage to New York was billed as the ultimate homemade gadget  a towering contraption composed of found junk, dismembered bicycles, dismantled musical instruments, glass bottles, a meteorological balloon and electric motors in questionable condition. It was slated to come to life and spectacularly self-destruct in a one-night-only performance for some 250 patrons and reporters in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden at the Museum of Modern Art on March 17, 1960. And self-destruct it did, but not quite according to plan.
