title: Amateurs Face Unkindest Cut at Augusta
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  An amateur has never won the Masters. An amateur has not threatened to win the Masters since Charles Coe finished tied for second in 1961. In the last 10 years, only 8 of the 48 amateurs in the field have made the cut. Other tournaments might consider changing their policy on amateur exemptions when 84 percent of them miss the cut over a decade.

title: Culture in 3-D
description: The first art-house film in 3-D opens today in Paris and is scheduled for release in the United States later this month. Pina, a collaboration between Pina Bauschs Tanztheater Wuppertal dance troupe and the German director Wim Wenders, is a stunning use of the 3-D medium to convey the emotional impact of Bauschs art to her fans and new audiences alike  and its beating out the Royal Opera Houses Carmen in 3D by a matter of weeks.

title: Will It Happen Again? Examining Mass Extinctions on Earth
description: Overview | What is a mass extinction, and why do some scientists think human beings may be responsible for the next one? What do we know about the past extinctions, including their likely causes? In this lesson, students learn about mass extinctions, map extinction events to a geologic timeline, and explore current ideas about whether human influences may lead to another major extinction event.

title: How Old Is Your Plane?
description: That is the question on some travelers minds following the fuselage rupture on a Southwest flight on Friday that that prompted the carrier to temporarily ground part of its fleet  and led the Federal Aviation Administration to issue a directive calling for inspections of some older-model Boeing 737s for similar cracks.

title: Only One Vegetable Can Be the Official One
description: ALBANY  First came the budget fight. Now it looks as if it will be the food fight.

title: Learn How to Collect From Slow Payers
description: SMALL-BUSINESS owners know it is cash flow or die. While the recession officially ended in June 2009, many companies are still reeling. Credit can be hard to come by, and profits have not completely bounced back. On top of that, many customers are taking longer than ever to pay their bills.

title: As It Wraps Up Galleon Case, Prosecution Revises Its Math
description: The indictment of Raj Rajaratnam charged the hedge fund manager with earning $45 million by trading on inside information.

title: J. J. Abrams Collaborating on Novel for Little, Brown
description: J. J. Abrams is not a big fan of disclosing the plot details of new films hes directing (see Super 8) or producing (Cloverfield) before theyve been released, so dont expect any spoilers  or even a title  for a new novel on which hell be collaborating. The publisher Little, Brown said on Wednesday that it had acquired a book that Mr. Abrams, the director of Star Trek and a creator of the television series Lost, Alias and Felicity, had conceived and will be written by Doug Dorst, the author of the supernatural crime novel Alive in Necropolis. A release from the publisher happily cited Mr. Abramss film and television credits and mentioned that Mr. Dorst is a graduate of the Iowa Writers Workshop and a three-time Jeopardy! champion. And Mr. Abrams said in a statement that Doug is a genius, adding that he could not be more excited to collaborate with him on this completely original project. Just what that project is neither Mr. Abrams nor Little, Brown is indicating, except to say that it is planned for a fall 2012 release on the Mulholland Books imprint. Watch for further clues as soon as we know where to find them.

title: Bugs and Brains
description: Some researchers subscribe to what is known as the parasite stress hypothesis. This holds that over the course of evolution the body faced a trade-off between maximizing intelligence and maximizing the power of the immune system. To test this Christopher Eppig, Corey Fincher and Randy Thornhill compared the IQ levels and disease stress in various American states. Sure enough, states where people have to guard against more infectious diseases (presumably because of climate) had lower average IQs. This is one of those studies where it is important to remember that correlation is not causation. Still, the researchers did find that after controlling for education and wealth, disease stress was the best predictor of state IQ.

title: Grammys Cutting More Than 30 Categories
description: The Grammy Awards have gotten a trim.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Virgil Green, Top-Ranked Tight End
description: 1.Virgil Green, Nevada (6-3, 249)The safest tight end in this draft is Notre Dames Kyle Rudolph. So if youre looking for surer things, he has the combination of blocking skills, receiving and toughness after the catch that should earn him a starting opportunity within the first 12-18 months of his N.F.L. career.

title: The G.O.P.s Dukakis Problem
description: The Republican Partys presidential-nominating process has always been run by elites. Oh, the voters have their brief moments of triumph, hoisting up an unelectable right-winger (i.e., Pat Buchanan) or an uncontrollable moderate (John McCain, the circa-2000 version). But the establishment always wins. Meeting in their K Street offices and communicating through organs like George Wills column and National Review, the main financers and organizers settle upon a useful frontman, a reliable vessel for the partys agenda who  and this is the crucial part  is blessed with the requisite political talent. Democrats have been known to mess that last part up and nominate a dweeb, but Republicans have generally understood that an agenda tilted toward the desires of the powerful requires a skilled frontman who can pitch Middle America. Favorite character types include jocks, movie stars, folksy Texans and war heroes.

title: The Surge in Data Processing
description: Computer users often feel awash in data. It turns out, so does the whole world.

title: Other Carriers Follow Southwest and Inspect 737s

title: Frocks and Downtown Friends
description: I noticed on Deadline Hollywood Tuesday night that R.J. Cutler, the director of The September Issue, has signed to make a feature film of Lee Tullochs Fabulous Nobodies, a satiric novel set in the New York of the late 80s, when fashion and clubbing were the main events. Ms. Tulloch, who has lived between Australia and New York, went on to write other books, but Fabulous Nobodies seemed to strike a chord with people who were in New York (or wanted to be) at that time. More interesting to me is how difficult it has been for a filmmaker to capture the fashion scene. What are the great fashion films? The producers for the Fabulous Nobodies adaptation are Julie Anne Quay, the former executive editor of V magazine; Gail Lyon (Erin Brockovich); and Mr. Cutler.

title: A Little Kick From the Mideast: Folk Spices the Jazz

Hes among the current bumper crop of adaptable transplants from Israel to New York, like the saxophonist Eli Degibri, the multireedist Anat Cohen and her brother Avishai Cohen, a trumpeter. Unlike some of these peers Mr. Klein uses Middle Eastern folk elements as a patently important part of his platform, maybe the most important part.

description: If you want an easy puzzle, solve a Rubiks Cube.

title: Nearing End of Office, Gates Visits Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  On what is likely to be his last visit to Iraq as defense secretary, Robert M. Gates arrived here Wednesday night for talks with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and meetings with American commanders about the withdrawal of all United States troops by the end of the year.

title: Not Disneyfied Enough? Mickey Mouses Cruises Are Coming
description: Visitors who do not believe the Times Square area has been Disneyfied enough will soon be able to put on their mouse ears, head a few blocks west and board a Disney Cruise Line ship to a Disney island.

title: Notes on the Ryan Budget
description: As promised, after yesterdays praise, a few initial criticisms. The basic architecture of the budget, I think, is exactly right: It means-tests Medicare and shifts the program from an open-ended entitlement to a defined benefit; it block-grants Medicaid to the states (something that governors of both parties have wanted for a long time); and it promises to lower tax rates while broadening the tax base, which is the essence of any good tax reform. But inevitably, there are devils in the details. Here are three obvious problems.

title: A Slam Try and a Possible Way to Resist It
description: To begin today, look at only the West hand in the diagramed deal. What would you lead against six hearts?

title: Ambition Doth Curse All Makes of Men
description: That ambition can poison the hearts of small spirits as thoroughly as great ones is the unsettling message of the director Declan Donnellans intimate, streamlined new production of Macbeth at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. As portrayed by the compelling actor Will Keen, Shakespeares Scottish general is less a man of great distinction undone by the pursuit of immoral ends than an average fellow caught in a trap of someone elses making, rattled with nervous laughter at the horror of what he has become.

title: Start-Ups: Founders on Funding
description: In the current boom of social and mobile start-ups, four Silicon Valley entrepreneurs discuss their experiences attracting investments for their companies.

title: Back-to-the-Land Life Recalled in Dark and Light
description: Melissa Coleman was born in 1969 to parents who were hippie pioneers. In 1968 they had moved to Cape Rosier, Me., to start an organic farm and devote every waking hour to its upkeep. They had gone there as protgs of Helen and Scott Nearing, whose books, most notably Living the Good Life, inspired a back-to-the-land movement predicated on hard work and strict discipline. Their goals reflected Thoreaus determination to live so sturdily and Spartan-like as to put to rout all that was not life.

title: The Flora-Bama Interstate Mullet Toss
description: DEADLIEST THROW  Inside the Flora-Bama Insterstate Mullet Toss from UM Media Documentary Projects on Vimeo.

title: Fowndr Offers Private Social Network for Start-Ups
description: Look out people of the Internet, theres another social network on the horizon! But this new network isnt designed to compete with Facebook, Twitter or MySpace; instead, its intended for the people who build these services.

title: To Renovate, and Surpass, Citys Legacy
description: NEW ORLEANS  As Democrats and Republicans continue to feud over the budget, and the federal government prepares to shut down, the effect of the budget war on the fate of a single proposal for the renovation of a dilapidated public housing project in New Orleans may seem inconsequential.

title: In Time for Opening Day, an At Bat 11 With Sweeteners
description: The top-grossing app on iTunes last year wasnt Angry Birds, Cut the Rope or any of the other cheap blockbuster games gobbled up by the masses. Instead, it was a $15 app, MLB.coms At Bat, aimed at big children who would rather watch a game than play one.

title: Texas Tech Redeems Itself With Final Four Chess Victory
description: Texas Tech University is at the top of a new college pecking order.

title: Changing Libyan Tactics Pose Problems for NATO
description: PARIS  Angry charges by Libyan rebels that NATO has failed to come to their aid point up a question that has haunted the Western air campaign from the start: how to avoid a stalemate and defeat the Libyan leader without putting foreign troops on the ground.

title: The Long and Wireless Road to a Home Router
description: Buying a home wireless router is about as chaotic and confusing a shopping experience as you will ever encounter.

title: Its Nick Caves World; They Just Dance in It
description: Theres a visceral thrill to Stephen Petronios choreographythat is unlike anything offered by other contemporary choreographers. Legs whip round bodies with razor-edged ferocity; high, flying jumps erupt into the air; pelvises and torsos ripple through abrupt, unpredictable changes of direction, shifting from vertical to horizontal and back in the blink of an eye. The movement, with its improbable juxtapositions, seems to pour across the stage in an unquenchable flow, and yet its rarely too much for the eye to absorb.

title: Owning George Washington: The Auction
description: Growing up in the tiny town of Ephrata, Wash., Tom Washington and his older brother Nat, blood relatives of George (yes, that George) were surrounded by family lore. There were more tangible connections as well: family papers going back to 1662, tools George Washington used in his early years as a surveyor, even bits of his coffin. Now, after generations of safekeeping, the family is selling its treasures at auction starting Thursday, creating a buzz of excitement among Americana experts.

title: Excerpt: 'Anything Goes'
description: Sutton Foster and Colin Donnell sing the number "You're the Top" from the Roundabout Theater's revival of "Anything Goes." (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Inside Marwencol
description: A look at the photographer Mark Hogancamps home and the tiny universe he has created there.

title: Nu? Is This 2nd Ave.? No, Its Lincoln Center
description: In everything he does, from conducting the San Francisco Symphony to spearheading that orchestras multimedia educational project Keeping Score, Michael Tilson Thomas brings thorough musicianship sparked with theatrical flair. On Tuesday night an audience that packed Avery Fisher Hall learned about the roots of Mr. Thomass theatrical instincts when the New York Philharmonic presented The Thomashefskys: Music and Memories of a Life in the Yiddish Theater, directed by Patricia Birch, in the first of two performances.

title: Baruch Blumberg, Who Discovered and Tackled Hepatitis B, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Baruch S. Blumberg, the Nobel Prize-winning biochemist and medical anthropologist who discovered the hepatitis B virus, showed that it could cause liver cancer and then helped develop a powerful vaccine to fight it, saving millions of lives, died Tuesday in Moffett Field, Calif. He was 85 and lived in Philadelphia.

title: What a Drag: Broadway Revival of La Cage aux Folles Is Closing
description: They built a dress for Harvey Fierstein, but alas, audiences did not come in numbers substantial enough to keep the Broadway revival of La Cage aux Folles running: that musicals producers released a statement on Wednesday evening saying that it would close on May 1: Were sorry to have to announce the final weeks of this exuberant production, which has brought great joy to audiences for the last year, as well as to everyone who has worked on the show, on stage and off.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Robots
description: For situations that are too deadly for humans, robots can come in mighty handy. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, J.D. Biersdorfer speaks with Tim Trainer of iRobot about the four robots the company has sent to Japan to help with relief efforts. Mr. Trainer, vice president for operations in iRobots government and industrial division, said the military and industrial robots would be used to control the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear reactors damaged by earthquake and tsunami. iRobot also makes consumer products like the Roomba vacuum cleaner.

title: Shopping Picks for April 7
description: Burkman Bros for the SoHo sportsman; soft stripes for springtime; animal prints come alive with Burberry Exotics and more.

title: Kevin Spacey, in Role as Lobbyist for the Arts
description: The actor Kevin Spacey visited Capitol Hill on Tuesday  officially Arts Advocacy Day  to bolster support for public arts funding

title: High-Level Departures Continue at City Schools
description: John White, a deputy chancellor of the New York City Department of Education, will resign to oversee struggling schools in Louisiana, the city announced on Wednesday. It was the latest in a series of high-level departures from the department since the appointment of Schools Chancellor Cathleen P. Black late last year.

title: Council Approves Bills to Improve Snow Response
description: Three months after a powerful blizzard revealed startling weaknesses in the citys chain of command, the City Council voted on Wednesday to overhaul the way the city responds to snowstorms.

title: Japanese Citys Cry Resonates Around the World
description: MINAMISOMA, Japan  It was a desperate plea for help, spoken into a small digital camcorder by the mayor of this seemingly forsaken city, and posted on the Internet like a bottle tossed into a digital sea.

title: The 2011 Easter-Egg Audit
description: This is what happens when the taxman and the Easter Bunny meet.

title: Last Tango in Nassau: The Final Our Towns Column
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.

title: Star Designer Leaves Balmain Fashion House
description: Balmain, a 66-year-old French fashion house that recently engineered a comeback with skimpy dresses and spray-on jeans that were shockingly priced, announced on Wednesday that its star designer, Christophe Decarnin, had left the company. His departure is the latest in a string of shake-ups that suggest, after the John Galliano debacle at Dior, that luxury fashion houses are becoming less interested in promoting lively personalities than in protecting their own brands.

title: Up On the Farm
description: Aerials of the remote Monegros region of northeastern Spain.

title: Clean Energy Is a Target of Ryan Budget Plan
description: A long-term Republican budget plan released this week by Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin calls for drastic cuts in federal spending on energy research and development and for the outright elimination of subsidies and tax breaks for wind, solar power and other alternative energy technologies.

title: Transocean Bonuses Reflect a Tin Ear
At Frozen Four, a Little Sibling Rivalry
description: ST. PAUL  Logistically, Betsy and Steve Rust  whose sons, Matt and Bryan, play on different teams in the Frozen Four  are running this down the middle. They booked a room at the same hotel as Michigan, where Matt is a senior center. But for Thursdays national semifinals at the Xcel Energy Center, they will sit with other parents from Notre Dame, where Bryan is a freshman right wing.

title: Skin Deep: Slicked-Back Hair
description: Heres how to achieve a slicked-back look for these minimalist times.

title: A More Grown-Up Look for a Minimalist Time
description: BEDAZZLED hair clips and ponytail elastics suddenly seem childish. Quite a few spring fashion shows, including those of Bill Blass, Erin Fetherston and Dries Van Noten, featured a more sophisticated slicked-back alternative. And no matter what your hair texture or length, you need only a good blow dryer, volumizer and holding spray to pull it off.

title: Shopping for Pet Bowls With the Materious Designers
description: Stephanie and Bruce Tharp, who run the Chicago firm Materious, set out to find the most interesting pet bowls their city has to offer.

title: Kabinett & Kammer Offers a Menagerie in the East Village
description: Cozily ensconced in an East Village storefront that was recently a tattoo parlor, Kabinett & Kammer is the Manhattan outpost of an Andes, N.Y., antiques shop that has captured the attention of celebrities like Amy Sedaris and Anderson Cooper. (Mr. Cooper liked the original store so much, he hired the owner, Sean Scherer, to design his apartment across town.)

title: Mark Hogancamps Photographs
description: The photographers own images of Marwencol, the miniature World War II-era town that he has created at his home.

title: Rewiring an Old Lamp
description: SOMEHOW, everything I fix ends up far uglier than it was when I started. Its my zero-sum approach to handyman projects: what you gain in functionality, you lose in beauty.

title: Sales at Odegard, Desiron and Others
description: During the Odegard warehouse sale, through Sunday, samples, overstocked and discontinued items, and one-of-a-kind rugs, furniture and accessories are marked down as much as 70 percent (6-by-9-foot rugs, regularly $3,024 to $7,182, are $1,058 to $2,532; 9-by-12-foot rugs, regularly $6,048 to $14,364, are $3,024 to $5,065); 30-30 47th Avenue, Long Island City, N.Y., (718) 784-1704 or odegardinc.com/warehouse.

title: A Collection That Reveals William Sofields Softer Side
description: William Sofields new collection from McGuire furniture is a stylistic departure from the sleek contemporary pieces for which he is known. The line, introduced last month, celebrates such seemingly un-Sofield materials as rattan, rawhide, Danish cord and coconut shell.

title: A New Look for the Rolling Pin
description: Tahir Mahmood, a Toronto designer born in Pakistan, made 10 versions of his rolling pin before he found one that was modern enough to suit him.

title: Susan Roy on Cold War Housekeeping
description: Bomboozled: How the U.S. Government Misled Itself and Its People Into Believing They Could Survive a Nuclear Attack, out this month from Pointed Leaf Press, is a mouthful of a title for an enticing visual history of the fallout shelter, which allowed cold war anxiety to be cheerfully reconfigured as a home story and gave the phrase nuclear family new meaning.

title: Greenery, Inside and Out
description: This three-story house in the Panchsheel Park neighborhood of South Delhi has 15,594 square feet of space, enough room for everyone to maintain a degree of privacy.

title: From the Campana Brothers, a Rug Priced Like a Piece of Art
description: When is a rug a work of art? Maybe when its priced at more than $35,000.

title: Pet Bowls
description: CHICAGO

title: Hot on the Trail of Chili Peppers
description: PATAGONIA, Ariz.

title: In a Tiny Universe, Room to Heal
description: MARK HOGANCAMP died 11 years ago tomorrow, when five men kicked his head in outside a Kingston, N.Y., bar in the early morning hours. He was reborn months later, after he awoke from a nine-day coma, his memory wiped nearly clean of the details of his life  his early marriage, girlfriends, family, Navy service, thundering alcoholism, homelessness, jail time  and he had to relearn how to eat, walk and think at age 38. Feeling shunned by the outside world, he created his own world, a tiny society called Marwencol.

title: In New Orleans, a Place for the Imperfect
description: A classic New Orleans cottage furnished with finds from antiques stores and consignment shops.

title: A New Cottage in New Orleans With Katrina Patina
description: NEW ORLEANS

title: Music in Review
description: MIDORI

title: In South Delhi, a Home for Three Generations
description: NEW DELHI  From the moment they decided to build a house on a wide dusty street lined with eucalyptus trees in this teeming city of about 17 million people, Manit and Sonali Rastogi knew it would have to meet the needs of not only six different people, but three different generations.

title: A Collector of People Along With Art
description: LIKE a Zelig of the art world, Sam Green was seemingly always there, filling a space in the social picture that no one quite realized was empty. Over five decades Mr. Green played pivotal roles, first as a curator, then as an art dealer, a municipal adviser and finally as a society gadabout and preservationist whose scope took in the more remote corners of the planet.

title: All-Night Sendoff for a Clubland King
description: THERE were no guest lists, V.I.P. lines or finicky doormen at Don Hills the night of March 31  but such an uncouth departure from the nightlife pecking order was forgivable. Earlier that day, Don Hill himself, a legendary fixture in New Yorks clubland who presided over three decades of underground culture bridging punk, glam-androgyny, indie rock and electronic dance, passed away abruptly in his mid-60s.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,436 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,508 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Haitian Deportations to Resume
description: After a two-month pause, immigration authorities will resume the deportations of Haitians who have been convicted of crimes in the United States. Immigration and Customs Enforcement began deporting Haitians in January, removing 27 that month, but stopped after one deportee died of choleralike symptoms shortly after arriving in Haiti and others fell ill. In new guidelines issued last Friday, the agency said it would limit deportations mainly to Haitians convicted of violent crimes and repeat offenders, who had also been ordered removed by an immigration court. Agency officials said they would not place a priority on deporting Haitian criminals who require medical treatment in this country. Catholic advocates said many of the first deportees had served their sentences and had been living without incident for years. The agency suspended the deportations after a Jan. 12, 2010, earthquake in Haiti.

title: Bid for State of Palestine Gets Support From I.M.F.
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian Authority, which is working toward global recognition of its statehood in September, got an endorsement on Wednesday from the International Monetary Fund, which said that the authority was fully capable of running the economy of an independent state.

title: Scene City: A Laid-Back Party for Keanu Reeves
description: Mr. Reeves plays nice at an indie film party on Monday.

title: The Monolinguist's Crutch
description: Smartphones mean that it's easy to carry around a pocket-sized translator. But translation apps are still a work in progress.

title: A Cozy Premiere for Keanu Reeves
description: KEANU REEVES likes to play the nice guy. Theyre not always easy characters, but theyre a pleasure to play, he said Monday night during a screening for his new movie, Henrys Crime, a comedy about a bank heist in which he plays the title role. Theres a feel-good element to it.

title: Soriano Apologizes for Absence After Loss
description: Not long after Rafael Soriano imploded in the Yankees 5-4 loss to Minnesota on Tuesday night, his cellphone rang. It was his mother calling from the Dominican Republic. He did not answer.

title: A Showdown Over Americas Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fixture of Hollywoods Past, Now Tarnished by Strife
description: LOS ANGELES  This was once a place for the famous, or at least those who wanted to be. There were ballroom dances and Champagne toasts, a welcoming place for the star-struck ladies who lunch.

title: As China Ages, Birthrate Policy May Prove Difficult to Reverse
description: YICHENG, China  Under Chinas family-planning regulations, most couples are barred from having more than one baby. Wang Hong and her husband, Zhang Jingfeng, are among those who were granted a second chance  and decided against it.

title: Dreaming of a Virtual Library: Authors Guild v. Google
description: To the Editor:

title: Building a Stage for Mideast Peace Before the Final Curtain
description: JENIN, West Bank  Juliano Mer Khamis lived a paradox. The internationally renowned actor, director and political activist, who was killed here this week, was both an Israeli and a Palestinian, born to a Jewish mother and an Arab Christian father in the Israeli Arab town of Nazareth.

title: The Long-Term Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: Loose Cigarettes for Sale
description: To the Editor:

title: A Survivalist Sees Profit in Helping Others Prepare
description: MESA, Ariz.  Swimming pools are one way of surviving Arizonas sky-high temperatures, which hit triple digits in a recent uncharacteristically early burst of heat. But Dennis McClungs pool, in the Phoenix suburb of Mesa, has been redesigned into a survivalist refuge of an entirely different sort.

title: As Days Grow Longer, So Do Hems
description: FASHION happens by degrees. No banner headlines announce its arrival. (Make way for the mini! Salute the trapeze!) It appears by stealth, like the wisp of cloud that heralds summer showers.

title: Longer Hemlines Sweep the City Streets
description: A year ago, a movement toward sweeping skirts was just starting. This spring, long skirts and dresses are a full-on trend.

title: Borders Plan for Recovery Is Described as Doubtful
description: Borders presented a restructuring plan to its creditors on Wednesday that promised publishers and landlords a sleeker, more efficient company poised to emerge successfully from bankruptcy through increased online sales and revamped stores.

title: A 45-Year-Old Apprentice, Holding Her Own
description: Monique Faatimah Lee is proof that late bloomers can find career nirvana. Ms. Lee, 45, waited until her 30s to attend college (she graduated from Howard University in 2003 with an anthropology degree), then worked as a personal trainer until she decided to try carpentry. She is in the third year of her union apprenticeship, with one more to go before she is certified as a full-fledged mechanic of her trade. She lives in the West Farms neighborhood of the Bronx.

title: Bahrains Rulers Tighten Their Grip on Battered Opposition
description: SAAR, Bahrain  Thousands of weeping mourners filled the streets of this dusty village on Wednesday, pumping their fists and calling for the death of the royal family.

title: American Citizenship
description: To the Editor:

title: Abuse of the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Courtesys End
description: Charleston Harbor, S.C., April 7, 1861

title: Sudan Says Israel Launched a Missile Strike on a Car, Killing 2
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The government of Sudan accused Israel on Wednesday of carrying out a fatal airstrike on a car traveling from the Red Sea city of Port Sudan.

title: Bloggingheads: President Bachmann?
description: Ben Smith, left, of Politico and Ari Berman of The Nation debate the presidential prospects of Michele Bachmann.

title: Syria Tries to Placate Sunnis and Kurds
description: CAIRO  The government of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria offered several unusual gestures on Wednesday intended to earn it good will among Sunnis and Kurds.

title: Despite the Chatter, a Wide-Open Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Aside from the back nine on Sunday, when results crystallize and the winner emerges, the best part of the Masters is the entire day Thursday, when the tournament finally begins and all the speculative chatter ends.

title: Prosecution Rests Its Case in Galleon Trial
description: Louis Lanzano/Bloomberg NewsRaj Rajaratnam, right, with his lawyer John Dowd, arriving at federal court.

title: Many Hedge Funds Still Smarting From the Financial Crisis
description: Last year, Kenneth C. Griffin, the founder of the hedge fund giant the Citadel Group, celebrated his second year of double-digit gains.

title: Gung-Ho for Big Cuts in Spending, Less Fond of the Ones That Hurt Back Home
description: WASHINGTON  As a candidate, RepresentativeJaime Herrera Beutler denounced stimulus spending and, once elected, voted for a Republican budget bill that would make $61 billion in cuts to a vast array of programs this year.

title: Gitmo Fatigue at the Supreme Court
description: Is the Supreme Court finally finished with Guantnamo?

title: Trading Up: Varsity Jackets
description: For the big man off campus, the varsity jacket.

title: This Championship Season
description: GIVEN the continuing demand for people who can write code in their sleep, its safe to say the gaunt, spectacled look known as geek chic isnt going anywhere soon. But its old rival, the ruddy, broad-shouldered B.M.O.C., is showing at least one sign of life: the varsity jacket, the 1950s favorite that turned up in a slew of fall fashion collections.

title: Critics Call Terrorism Hearing in Manhattan Anti-Muslim
description: A state senator has scheduled a daylong hearing for Friday on terrorism preparedness in New York City, featuring an array of experts in law enforcement, emergency response and counterterrorism.

title: Libyan Rebels Dont Really Add Up to an Army
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Late Monday afternoon, as Libyan rebels prepared another desperate attack on the eastern oil town of Brega, a young rebel raised his rocket-propelled grenade as if to fire. The towns university, shimmering in the distance, was far beyond his weapons maximum range. An older rebel urged him to hold fire, telling him the weapons back-blast could do little more than reveal their position and draw a mortar attack.

title: Mets Get a Look at a Pitcher Theyd Rather Not See
description: PHILADELPHIA  Just three days after his San Diego Padres were eliminated from postseason contention last year, Chris Young was not particularly enthusiastic about settling in to watch games that he had expected to play in himself.

title: At N.F.L. Hearing, Judge Urges, but Doesnt Compel, a Return to Talks
description: ST. PAUL  The N.F.L. will probably remain dormant for at least a while longer, after United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson said Wednesday that she would take a couple of weeks to decide whether to grant the players request for an injunction to lift the lockout.

title: Bloggers Challenge President on Standardized Testing
description: Does President Obama believe standardized testing has gone too far?

title: Obama Takes Aim at Inequality in Education
description: Describing education and education equality as the civil rights issue of our time, President Obama called Wednesday for a renewed effort to eliminate the achievement gap between African-American students and others.

title: Out of Context
description: THE 9/11 memorial in New York, still being planned, is to be dedicated on the 10th anniversary of the attack. Intended as a place for commemoration, reflection, education and solace, the memorial and museum will serve as a repository for the remains of the victims.

title: 0-5 Red Sox Are Looking for Answers
description: CLEVELAND

title: Rush to Use Crops as Fuel Raises Food Prices and Hunger Fears
description: The starchy cassava root has long been an important ingredient in everything from tapioca pudding and ice cream to paper and animal feed.

title: Beck and Fox End Relationship Grown Cold
description: The negotiations that led Glenn Beck to announce his departure from the Fox News Channel on Wednesday ended with an expression of lets part as friends, according to several people with knowledge of the talks. But behind that moment was a torrent of acrimony that underscored just how fractious the relationship between Mr. Beck and the network had become during his three-year run on Fox.

title: Small Carrier Gets Big Tailwind From Social Media
description: THE popularity of Richard Simmons, the fitness guru known for his big personality and tiny shorts, peaked sometime in the 1980s, but on YouTube he is enjoying something of a Justin Bieber moment.

title: Senate Rejects Bills to Limit E.P.A.s Emissions Programs
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Wednesday rejected efforts to block the Environmental Protection Agencys program to regulate greenhouse gases, defeating four bills that would have limited the agencys attempts to address global warming.

title: Medicine on the Move
description: Sometimes you really do want to tell the medical profession to just make up its mind.

title: Disabled, but Looking for Work
description: BATESVILLE, Ark.  Christopher Howard suffers from herniated discs in his back, knee problems and hepatitis C. As a result, Social Security sends him $574 every month and will until he reaches retirement age  unless he can find a job.

title: Why Pay Congress?
description: If we careen over a cliff on Friday and the American government shuts down, hard-working federal workers will stop getting paychecks, but the members of Congress responsible for the shutdown are expected to be paid as usual.

title: Europeans More Open Approach Wins Fans
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.

title: Wal-Mart v. Women
description: The employment discrimination lawsuit against Wal-Mart, which the Supreme Court heard last week, is the largest in American history. If the court rejects this suit, it will send a chilling message that some companies are too big to be held accountable.

title: Dust Is Gone Above the Bar, but a Legend Still Dangles
description: On Sunday morning, before the ancient doors of McSorleys Old Ale House opened once again to spill that beer-and-sawdust aroma upon an East Village sidewalk, the owner took on a sorrowful job that in good conscience he could not leave to any of his employees. Too close to tempting the fates.

title: No Najar? No Big Deal.
description: The kneejerk reaction to Andy Najars decision to play his international soccer with his native Honduras rather than his adopted country, the United States, is that its another humiliating blow for a United States national team that keeps losing its most talented immigrants.

title: Better Protecting Prisoners
description: The Justice Department is finalizing new rape-prevention policies that will become mandatory for federal prisons and state correctional institutions that receive federal money. The rules, based on recommendations from a Congressionally mandated commission, would be a major improvement. But the department needs to remedy several weaknesses before it issues final regulations.

title: A Temporary Reprieve for Nassau Bus Riders
description: A late infusion of cash from Albany has postponed the plan of the Nassau County executive, Edward Mangano, to cripple his countys bus service, but only until the end of the year.

title: George Tooker
description: Government Bureau, a 1956 painting by George Tooker, was inspired by his maddening encounter with the New York City Building Department. Most people who waste hours in line just end up with sore feet and headaches. Mr. Tooker, who died on March 27, emerged with one of the best-known depictions of modern alienation and despair.

title: States Judges Told to Shut Courtrooms Earlier to Cut Costs
description: Judges across New York State were told on Wednesday to shut down their courtrooms a half-hour earlier every day in an effort to cut back on overtime paid to staff members like court clerks and court officers.

title: Rifts Within Both Parties Test Leaders in Budget Fight
description: WASHINGTON  On one level, the budget showdown that continued to play out here on Wednesday is all about the balance of power between the two parties, a question of whether President Obama has regained his footing and can still control the direction of the country or whether Speaker John A. Boehner and the Republicans are now calling the shots.

title: Obama Is Set to Redo Team on War Policy
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama assembled his first national security team, it was quickly dubbed, not always accurately, the Team of Rivals. Now that some of its key members are heading for the exits, the question is whether his next war council could be named the Corps of Consensus.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 6, 2011

title: Labor Panel to Press Reuters Over Reaction to Twitter Post
description: In what would be the first government case against an employer involving Twitter, the National Labor Relations Board told Thomson Reuters on Wednesday that it planned to file a civil complaint accusing the company of illegally reprimanding a reporter over a public Twitter posting she had sent criticizing management.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Haiti Winner Claims Wider Vote Edge Than Reported
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Michel Martelly, the presumed president-elect of Haiti, said Wednesday that his landslide showing in an election runoff was actually stronger than was indicated by results released Monday. He said it pointed to a mandate that a very weak opposition needed to respect as he moved to rebuild the shattered country.

title: Obama Meeting Fails to End Stalemate Over Federal Budget
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama and Congressional leaders said Wednesday that a late-night White House bargaining session produced no budget breakthrough that would avert a government shutdown this weekend but agreed the two sides had narrowed the issues in efforts to strike a deal.

title: Thursday: Source of Venom
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  At first, I thought I had forgotten how to read. Then, I thought I had forgotten how to solve a crossword puzzle. You might catch on faster than I did but hold onto your hats, folks: weve got us a Henry Hook puzzle that blows a longtime crossword cluing convention out of the water. I am a subversive of the first order, and so I loved this puzzle.

title: Audit Finds L.I. School Overbilled the State
description: A state-supported school for disabled students on Long Island overbilled taxpayers by $835,074 over two years, with some of the money going toward an executives salary and the lease on his Lexus, the state comptrollers office said in an audit released on Wednesday.

title: Knicks Move Up a Notch, but Are Bruised in the Process
description: PHILADELPHIA  In another week, the Knicks may learn what they gained or lost in a late-season battle for playoff position with the Philadelphia 76ers. As they departed the Wells Fargo Center late Wednesday, they only could contemplate what they might have lost in the pursuit of one more win.

title: Father Finds Son and Another Man Shot to Death in a Brooklyn Basement
description: Two men were found bound, gagged and shot to death in the basement of a home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn on Wednesday, the police and relatives said.

title: Mourning the Short Life of a Beaten Toddler
description: Three simple sentences offered by a priest on Wednesday came closest to conveying the senselessness of the act that brought strangers together inside a Roman Catholic church in Downtown Brooklyn.

title: Pelfreys Problems Show Mets Are Missing an Ace
description: PHILADELPHIA  When Johan Santana had shoulder surgery last September, the Mets knew he would be unavailable to them until the middle of the 2011 season, at best. So for the first three months of the season, the Mets would need an interim ace.

title: Trial Looks at Conditions Faced by Firefighters in Deutsche Bank Blaze
description: When Firefighter Robert Brown entered the former Deutsche Bank building as it was being consumed in smoke and flames in 2007, he said, he quickly realized it was one of the worst fires he had ever experienced.

title: Federal Departments Lay Out Plans in the Event of a Government Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  With the possibility of a government shutdown looming, Obama administration officials raced Wednesday to identify essential government services that would have to be provided if the government ran out of money.

title: A Freak Accident at the Queensboro Bridge, Until It Happens Again
description: It seemed a grisly freak accident: a small sedan, navigating a curvy Queensboro Bridge off-ramp early one morning last week, careened off the road and smashed into a Long Island City storefront, severing the arm of the driver and injuring his female passenger.

title: Freshman Voices in the Budget Fight
description: The freshman class of the 112th Congress is taking a hard line on government spending.

title: Dot-com Boom, Then And Now
description: As multibillion-dollar valuations for marquee-name social-media companies like Facebook and Groupon become the norm, echoes of the dot-com boom - and subsequent bust - reverberate among investors.

title: Police Lesson: Social Network Tools Have Two Edges
description: Officer Trey Economidy of the Albuquerque police now realizes that he should have thought harder before listing his occupation on his Facebook profile as human waste disposal.

title: Rangers Not Backing Down on Approach to Blocked Shots
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Ryan Callahan, his broken right ankle in a surgical boot, used crutches to get around the Rangers dressing room Wednesday. Callahan is out indefinitely, but he promised that his teammates would be as fearless as he is, as fraught with peril as that can be.

title: Shooting at College in Alabama Kills a Woman and Wounds 3
description: ATLANTA  A woman was killed and three other people, including a woman believed to be in her 90s and a 4-year-old girl, were wounded on Wednesday afternoon when a man with a gun walked onto the campus of a community college in Opelika, Ala., and began firing, the police said.

title: W. H. Prusoff, Who Developed AIDS Drug, Is Dead at 90
description: William H. Prusoff, a pharmacologist at the Yale School of Medicine who, with a colleague, developed an effective component in the first generation of drug cocktails used to treat AIDS, died on Sunday in New Haven. He was 90 and lived in Branford, Conn.

title: Odd Exceptions in the Family Planning Rulebook
description: BEIJING  A corps of 500,000 bureaucrats enforces Chinas family planning regulations, a sometimes-bewildering rulebook that includes more than 20 exceptions to the one-child-per-family guideline.

title: Oil Spills May Leave More Emotional Than Physical Scars, Study Finds
description: NEW ORLEANS  In a review of past oil spills as well as the available data from last years BP spill in the Gulf of Mexico, doctors found that adverse health effects from oil and chemical exposure are less likely than behavioral and mental health issues to pose significant long-term risks for most gulf residents.

title: Photo Replay: April 6
description: A view of the day in sports included a save in soccer, a play at the plate in baseball and marathon competitors working their way through the Sahara.

title: Five for the Money
description: Larry Dorman picks five golfers who have the best chance to wear the green jacket on Sunday at Augusta National.

description: Perhaps the most important graphic for understanding the political implications (as opposed to the policy implications) of the current budget debate is this one:

title: G.E. Plans to Build Largest Solar Panel Plant in U.S.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In a move that could shake up the American solar industry, General Electric plans to announce on Thursday that it will build the nations largest photovoltaic panel factory, with the goal of becoming a major player in the market.

title: Deals Creep Back, Though Not Yet to the Mega Level
description: Bigger deals are back.

title: Battling Headwinds in a Shifting M.&A. Marketplace
description: Harry Campbell

title: A Standard That Raises More Questions Than It Answers
description: We are told that beauty is in the eye of the beholder. That also appears to be the standard for determining whether information was material to establish securities fraud.

description: chide \chid\ verb

title: Virginia Lawmakers Limit Insurers Abortion Coverage
description: RICHMOND, Va.  Lawmakers in Virginia approved an amendment Wednesday that would ban private insurance plans from covering abortions if they participate in a state health care exchange under President Obamas new health care law.

title: At 0-5, the Red Sox Are Scrambling
description: CLEVELAND  Daisuke Matsuzaka had done his usual flirtation with the strike zone (96 pitches, 54 strikes), and it was time for a relief pitcher in the sixth inning at Progressive Field on Wednesday night. Terry Francona, the manager of the Boston Red Sox, looked at the Cleveland Indians lineup and chose Dennys Reyes, figuring Reyes could stay in for a while against a left-leaning order.

title: The Money Network
description: Facebook, Zynga, Groupon, Twitter and LinkedIn have come to define the social Web. Founded within the last five years, the quintet of start-ups is now estimated to be worth more than $71 billion.

title: Deal Mashup
Scarred by the Dot-Com Bust, Reinvented for Social Media
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Thomas Weisel doesnt have much personal experience with social media. He has never opened a Facebook or Twitter account, and he has resisted buying an iPhone.

title: The Valleys Banker Returns to the Top
description: Frank Quattrone never shied away from the spotlight a decade ago. Now, Silicon Valleys star banker tries to stay behind the deal-making scenes.

title: The Dot-Com Boom, Then And Now
description: As multibillion-dollar valuations for marquee-name social media companies like Facebook and Groupon become the norm, echoes of the dot-com boom  and subsequent bust  reverberate among investors. DealBook spoke to Michael Holland, chairman of Holland & Company, and John C. Coffee, a professor at Columbia Law School, about the structural differences that exist between the dot-com boom of the 1990s and the social media boom of today.

title: Founders Now Take the Money and Maintain Control
description: In a small office in San Francisco, electronic music blared as several programmers loomed over two computers. David Morin, the founder of Path, a social network start-up, gave the signal and the companys site and iPhone application went live.

title: Mario Cuomo Still Believes
description: You would think that Mario Cuomo would have been proud to watch his son Andrew sworn in as governor of New York last New Years Eve, ascending to the job his old man held for 12 years. Apparently, you would be wrong.

title: Bank of Japan Pledges Aid for Rebuilding From Quake
description: HONG KONG  The Japanese central bank announced measures Thursday to help reconstruction efforts in areas affected by the devastating earthquake and tsunami last month but held off deploying any more sweeping measures in its economy-stimulating arsenal.

title: News Quiz | April 7, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

description: Test your proofreading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the article Newly Homeless in Japan Re-Establish Order Amid Chaos.

title: French Forces in Ivory Coast Rescue Japanese Diplomat
description: ACCRA, Ghana  Helicopter-borne French special forces staged a dramatic nighttime rescue of a Japanese diplomat caught up in the fighting in Ivory Coast on Thursday, as opposition forces besieged the residence of the nations strongman, Laurent Gbagbo, for a second consecutive day, seeking to end his disputed claim to power.

title: Daily Lexeme: Psychogony
description: Todays word, in association with the stimulating Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Quacking for Aflac
description: WHO tried out to be the new voice of the duck character in advertisements for the insurer Aflac?WHO are judging the auditions?

title: Goldman Moves to Buy All of Australian Venture
description: Goldman Sachs said on Thursday that it had offered to buy all of its joint venture in Australia and New Zealand for an undisclosed sum, driving further into a dynamic regional economy buoyed by commodities prices.

title: Powerful Aftershock Complicates Japans Nuclear Efforts
description: TOKYO  The strongest aftershock to hit since the day of the March 11 earthquake and tsunami in Japan rocked a wide section of the countrys northeast on Thursday night, prompting a tsunami alert, raising fears of new strains on the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant and knocking out external power at three other nuclear facilities.

title: Is Online Learning as Good as Face-to-Face Learning?
description: Some experts estimate that more than a million students in the United States, from kindergarten through 12th grade, are taking courses online. Have you ever taken a class for credit online? What was the experience like? In general, do you think K-12 students can learn as much in an online course as they can in a traditional class? Why or why not? What makes for a good online course, in your opinion?

title: Big Banks Have a Powerful New Opponent
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Without People, the Power of Place
description: When global decision makers discuss whether to enter into war, or where to hold the next World Cup, they are often sitting in beautifully lit, well-designed rooms.

title: Gates, in Iraq, Talks of Effects of Budget Fight
description: BAGHDAD  On what he described as probably his final visit to Iraq, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates on Thursday turned from eight years of war here to the fight raging at home. If the United States government shuts down this weekend and into next week, he told American troops, there would be a delay in their pay.

title: N.Y. Fed Raises $1.3 Billion From First A.I.G. Bond Sale
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold $1.3 billion worth of mortgage-backed securities on Wednesday that it had acquired in the bailout of American International Group, the first of several sales it plans.

title: Training in the Heat of the Race in Malaysia
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  I can see the Petronas Twin Towers from my hotel window in Kuala Lumpur. This morning rather than taking three different public transportation lines  a monorail, a train and a metro  to get to the train that takes me to the airport where the race track is located, I decided I would simply walk towards the Twin Towers, where I knew there would be a direct line to the train to the airport.

title: Training in the Heat of the Race in Malaysia
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  I can see the Petronas Twin Towers from my hotel window in Kuala Lumpur. This morning rather than taking three different public transportation lines  a monorail, a train and a metro  to get to the train that takes me to the airport where the race track is located, I decided I would simply walk towards the Twin Towers, where I knew there would be a direct line to the train to the airport.

title: An Agonizing Wait Prolonged by a Cellphone Internet Hookup
description: It seems that I am always fated to learn about my critical admissions decisions on the slowest possible Internet connection  the one on my cellphone.

title: New Night-Life Spot in Berlin Is About More Than Parties
description: A new club and performance space is flourishing in Kreuzbergs Kottbusser Tor area, a bohemian neighborhood in Berlin. In the shadow of a former housing project, Sdblock (Admiralstrasse 1-2; 49-30-609-418-53; www.suedblock.org) opened in December with a lineup as diverse as its surroundings. On any given night, one might stumble in to find a video installation, a record release concert, or an evening of Israeli pop for gay partygoers.

title: The Early Word: One More Day
description: In Todays Times:The federal government continues to move toward a possible shutdown after a late-night meeting at the White House between President Obama and congressional leaders failed to produce anything more than a pledge to keep negotiating. Carl Hulse and Jackie Calmes report that the House is scheduled to vote today on a stop-gap measure to fund the government for one more week until a budget can be passed, even though Democrats have said the bill would dead-on-arrival in the Senate. If the lawmakers fail to strike a deal, the government will effectively shut down when the clock strikes midnight Saturday.

title: 2010 Falcons: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. Today, we complete our look at the N.F.C. South:

title: Q&A: Supersize Cut-and-Paste in Microsoft Word
description: Q.

title: New Test Appears to Back Range Claim for Battery
description: Makers of batteries for plug-in vehicles are in something of a tight spot. They are under considerable pressure to improve their products so that electric vehicles will be attractive to more drivers. But if they actually manage to come up with a radically improved battery, their breakthrough is likely to be met with skepticism  perhaps dealing a permanent blow to their reputation.

title: Wow, Mom: Its an Ambigram!
description: Wow, mom.

title: A Tough Time to Time the Sale of a Business
description: As with most economic news of late, there are mixed signals right now in the business-for-sale marketplace. Some folks say now is great time to sell  or, at a minimum that the market is better than it has been over the last two years  while others disagree. Where can a business owner turn to get clear direction? Since the dartboard has been used famously for picking publicly traded stocks, lets ask the Magic 8 Ball a few questions about selling a small business.

title: Is a Well-Rested Doctor a Better Doctor?
description: Recently, I saw a young friend who is training to be a surgeon. Extremely bright and the recipient of numerous medical school awards for her work with patients, she had been anxious as a student about the grueling hours she would face once she began working as a junior surgeon on the wards.

title: European Bank Raises Rate for 1st Time Since 2008
description: FRANKFURT  Defying critics and breaking ranks with its counterparts in the United States and Britain, the European Central Bank moved on Thursday to slay what some economists say they believe is an imaginary inflation threat, raising the benchmark interest rate in the euro area for the first time since 2008.

title: The Wizard of Offal
description: At 40, Julien Fouin is working on his fourth, maybe fifth career. He was first known as a journalist and an author, then as the editor of Rgal (Feast), which was unquestionably Frances best culinary magazine. More recently, he opened two restaurants in Paris, and he has also helped write two books that are being published this year, the first of which, Cuisines Paysannes, which roughly means cooking from the farm, has just been released. (The other one comes out this fall.)

title: A Common Infection, Commonly Overtreated
description: As people get more frail and old, physicians tend to do more, when often we should do less.

title: Chelsea Doomed by In-the-Box Thinking
description: London

title: Taliban Attack a Police Training Center in Kandahar
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Taliban insurgents carried out a deadly two-stage attack in this southern capital on Thursday, using an ambulance packed with explosives to bomb a police and military training center that had just been assaulted by heavily armed insurgents wearing suicide vests.

title: Rio Tinto Names Riversdale Directors
description: With its stake in Riversdale Mining now approaching 50 percent, Rio Tinto added three directors to the companys board.

description: April will continue to come in like a lion on this overcast day, with highs reaching the mid-50s and rain a possibility.

title: Cheers for the Hero, Followed by an Opera
description: James Levine has been given countless ovations during 40 years with the Metropolitan Opera. But the enthusiastic round of applause and bravos he received from the audience at the Met on Wednesday night when he appeared in the pit to conduct the seasons first performance of Alban Bergs Wozzeck must have been especially gratifying. He had last performed at the house nearly two months before, conducting Donizettis Don Pasquale, and it was a relief to all, it seemed, to have him back in action.

title: Thursday Reading: The Debate Over Physician Fatigue
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: The Case for Having More Kids
description: Bryan Caplan, an economist at George Mason, is the author of Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids, which will be released this week. Mr. Caplan doesnt believe everyone should have a lot of children. But he does say many parents and future parents should consider having more children than they are currently planning.

title: Ciao, Bella
description: Giulietta, which had its debut in a whitewashed loft during New York Fashion Week, is helmed by Sofia Sizzi (above, center), a Florentine-born Manhattanite who is driven by a love for lavish Italian fabrics. Is that really double-knit? one observer whispered of a black wool suit consisting of skinny flared trousers, a hip-length narrow-lapeled jacket and a long fitted vest that could serve as a minidress to nouveau Twiggys. The 24-look collection includes a black wool sateen dress accented with a Peter Pan collar, a handmade lace widow skirt and a saffron printed pantsuit based on Sizzis sketch of a Baroque cathedral ceiling. The shoes  velvet, satin and felt wedges and heels (all vegan, to match the 33-year-olds lifestyle) in salmon, saffron and cardinal red  attest to what Sizzi learned while working as an accessories designer at Gucci, Calvin Klein and Donna Karan. Clever 60s proportions and mod collaborations with the milliner Patricia Underwood and the jeweler Thomas Bliven add a bit of nonecclesiastical zing. From $435 at Barneys New York.

title: Chinese Defend Detention of Artist on Grounds of Economic Crimes
description: BEIJING  The investigation of the celebrity artist and social critic Ai Weiwei on suspicion of economic crimes is in keeping with the rule of law in China, a Chinese official said Thursday, defending Mr. Ais detention in the face of growing condemnation by foreign nations and liberal Chinese of the detention.

title: Markets Turn Lower, and Oil Prices Rise Again
description: Oil prices rose to their highest level in more than two years on Thursday, while Wall Street erased gains prompted by better-than-expected economic data after reports of another earthquake in Japan.

title: Is Nuclear Power Simply Too Brittle?
description: Despite the public focus on radiation risks, cost has long been the main obstacle to a substantial expansion of nuclear power generation, and will be even more as a result of Japans still-unfolding effort to secure the wave-ravaged Fukushima Daiichi complex.

title: Loosies
description: Cigarettes sold individually.

title: Jefferies to Buy Prudential Bache Commodities Business
description: Jefferies said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Prudential Baches Global Commodities Group from Prudential Financial for $430 million.

title: Will Members of Congress Get Paid in a Shutdown?
description: The new moral high ground in Washington as Congress careens toward a complete budget impasse is not We shouldnt shut the government down. It appears to be: Dont pay us if we do.

title: Peeling Away Multiple Masks
description: He was a master of reinvention who had as many names as he did identities: Malcolm Little, Homeboy, Jack Carlton, Detroit Red, Big Red, Satan, Malachi Shabazz, Malik Shabazz, El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz and, most famously, Malcolm X. A country bumpkin who became a zoot-suited entertainer who became a petty criminal who became a self-taught intellectual who became a white-hating black nationalist who became a follower of orthodox Islam who became an international figure championing life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness for all people.

title: Poetry Pairing | April 7, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: French Strike Gbagbo Defenders During Rescue of Japanese Diplomat in Ivory Coast
description: As my colleagues Adam Nossiter and Alan Cowell report, a French special forces team rescued Japans ambassador to the Ivory Coast before dawn on Thursday after his compound was stormed by members of a militia loyal to the self-appointed president, Laurent Gbagbo.

title: Alec Baldwin Calls for Five More Seasons of 30 Rock
description: After remarks by Alec Baldwin on Monday night suggested that the end of 30 Rock was in sight, causing apoplectic fans to threaten to cancel their subscriptions to Kabletown, he has dialed back his comments, saying that he hopes the NBC comedy series will continue, but implying that his own time on the show was winding down.

title: Davis Polk Names Thomas Reid Managing Partner
description: Davis Polk & Wardwell announced on Thursday that Thomas J. Reid had been elected managing partner, the first non-American-born head of the New York law firm.

title: PNC Increases Dividend 250%
description: The PNC Financial Services Group announced on Thursday that it had raised its quarterly payout to 35 cents a share from 10 cents, a fresh sign that banks are looking to put the financial crisis behind them.

title: American Idol': Top 9 Overshadowed by Weirdness
description: Scotty McCreery > Jacob Lusk > Haley Reinhart > Paul McDonald > Lauren Alaina > Pia Toscano > Stefano Langone > Casey Abrams > James Durbin

description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the dining section.

title: Co-Leaders Short Games Go a Long Way
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Rory McIlroy and Alvaro Quiros advanced golfs youth movement and its global reach in a major way on a sunny Thursday at the Masters. First it was McIlroy, the 21-year-old prodigy from Northern Ireland, who went out early and shot a seven-under-par 65 that gave him almost an entire day as the youngest first-round leader in the 75-year history of the tournament.

title: Reid Says Government Shutdown More Likely
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the top Democrat in the Senate, said Thursday morning that he was not nearly as optimistic about avoiding a shutdown as he was after a Wednesday night Oval Office meeting, saying it looks like its headed in that direction.

description: If you take the euro area as a whole . . .

title: Hey, Mr. Critic: Eat Your Way Down the L Line
description: The electronic postman delivered messages from people who will be staying deep in Brooklyn for a weekend, from a devoted child looking to blow his parents minds, and from an old college friend seeking guidance for a catch-up lunch on the East Side. My responses are below. You can as always ask me your own questions, at dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: Cities, Soda Taxes, Obesity and More
description: Some reflections after my column about Philly:

title: Cathleen Black Is Out as City Schools Chancellor
description: Read the final version of this article that ran in the newspaper, as well as a profile of Dennis M. Walcott and an analysis of the mayors attempt to cut his losses.Updated, 6:02 p.m. | Cathleen P. Black, a magazine executive with no educational experience who was named New York City schools chancellor last fall, stepped down Thursday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced.

title: Chinese Warship May Be Nearly Ready
description: BEIJING  The Chinese state news agency has posted photographs of an aircraft carrier under reconstruction that appears to show the warship near completion. Captions with the photos said that the work would end soon and that the carrier was expected to sail later this year.

title: Will Trump Run? Christie Doubts It
description: Is Donald Trump really running for president? Chris Christie, who calls Mr. Trump a really good friend of mine, doesnt think so.

title: Ballet Theaters Gala Plans Have a Cuban Feel
description: Thanks to the Si Cuba festival, music and dance from the island are everywhere in New York this spring, and though American Ballet Theater isnt on the festival program, it feels as if the company were doing its part to add to the mix. Its annual spring gala, set for May 16, will feature a tribute to Jose Manuel Carreo, the retiring principal dancer who was born in Cuba, and a one-night-only performance of the Cuban choreographer Jorge Garcias Majisimo. Cuban-born dancers will be featured in the work, including Xiomara Reyes of Ballet Theater and the sisters Lorena Feijoo (San Francisco Ballet) and Lorna Feijoo (Boston Ballet). Honorary chairs for the evening, which will also feature highlights from the coming spring season, are Michelle Obama, Carolina Herrera, Caroline Kennedy and Blaine Trump. Tickets (starting at $25) to the performance only are available at metoperafamily.org.

title: Your Rib Questions, Answered
description: Fresh from his investigation into the secrets of oven-baked ribs, Steven Raichlen is answering readers questions. If theres anything that the author of Planet Barbecue and the host of Primal Grill can elucidate for you, leave a question here.

title: How Kind Are We
description: Theres been a shift in how we think about human evolution. Years ago, people tended to see evolution as a competition for survival of the fittest. But now there is more emphasis on the gentler virtues. People survive because they are really good cooperators. Research into hunter-gatherer cultures has contributed to this new understanding. People once believed that early humans lived in small kinship circles and fought to pass along their common genes.

title: Political Divide Poses Risks for Portugal in Bailout Talks
description: LISBON  Portugals request for an international bailout puts European leaders in the difficult position of drafting a package of austerity measures and financial aid that will survive the countrys caretaker government.

title: Even More Ryan Ridiculousness
description: Heres the table from the CBO report you really want to focus on:

title: Moving From Disability Benefits to Jobs
description: In an article today, I explore why Social Security is strained by the number of workers who now collect disability benefits, and why it is so difficult for these beneficiaries to go back to work.

title: Old Village Hall | Whats Old Is New Again
description: Scott Hill couldnt have guessed that the souvenir balsam pillow he purchased on a trip to Maine would be the first step toward opening his shop. But the modest keepsake became a retail catalyst when Hill contacted the manufacturer and custom ordered 50 Greetings from the Catskills pillows, which he arranged to sell in a friends shop near his country home in Andes, N.Y. Encouraged by the demand for memorable gifts, Hill opened two seasonal stores of his own in Andes, before establishing a permanent East Village flagship.

title: Donors Asked to Withhold Aid Over Proposed Law in Cambodia
description: BANGKOK  A proposed law to control nongovernmental groups in Cambodia threatens to silence some of the last independent voices in an increasingly repressed nation, a group of leading international human rights agencies said Thursday.

title: Sharjah Biennial Director Fired Over Artwork Deemed Offensive
description: 6:42 p.m. | Updated The Sharjah Biennial, a sprawling art event in the United Arab Emirates that began in 1993 and is now in the midst of its 10th iteration, has been celebrated as a pioneer in bringing ambitious contemporary art to the Middle East. But its delicate balancing act  allowing artists freedom of expression while respecting a host of cultural and religious sensitivities  seems to be proving harder to maintain.

title: F.B.I. Files Reveal Details of Investigation of the Notorious B.I.G.s Killing
description: The F.B.I. spent nearly two years investigating the 1997 killing of the hip-hop artist the Notorious B.I.G., focusing on a man the bureau suspected may have been the rappers assassin, but ended its inquiry in early 2005 after prosecutors decided there was insufficient evidence to pursue a case, according to recently released F.B.I. records reported on by The Associated Press.

title: Selection Near on Overseer Of the 9/11 Health Fund
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department is nearing the appointment of a special master to administer a multibillion-dollar fund created to provide financial compensation for rescue workers and others who became sick from toxic fumes, dust and smoke from ground zero after the 2001 attack, according to Congressional officials who are monitoring the deliberations.

title: The Perfect Family
description: A boy and a girl. The ideal family, right?

title: Libyan Rebels Say Airstrikes Killed 5
description: ZUEITINA, Libya  The commander of the rebel army said it was likely that NATO warplanes conducted an airstrike against a convoy of rebel tanks early Thursday, killing at least four people in the second case of friendly fire in less than a week.

title: Companies to Offer Plug-In Conversions
description: Electric cars will play a starring role in many automakers lineups for the next few years. But what about the vehicles already out there, burning gasoline and diesel? ALTe Powertrain Technologies, founded by three former Tesla Motors executives, aims to convert those vehicles by the thousands to operate as plug-in hybrids.

title: Cuomo the First
description: My interview with the political legend Mario Cuomo in this Sundays magazine just went live on The Timess Web site. In doing some research for the article (I was trying to compare Marios inaugural address with his son Andrews), I made one of those minor discoveries that leave you feeling so lucky to be living in the Internet age. It turns out that the State of New York recently posted video from the first Governor Cuomos inaugural address in 1983. Its only a few minutes, unfortunately, but its still fun to watch if youre someone who likes political history, if only for the outsize presence of the interpreter for the deaf. (This is before the advent of text crawls.)

title: Zetterberg Injury Throws Scare into Red Wings
description: Theres never a good time to lose a superstar player, but the eve of the N.H.L. playoffs might be the worst time.

title: Leggs Returns to TV Advertising
description: An apparel brand that was once one of the most visible in mainstream media is making a comeback.

title: U.S. Retailers Report a Surprising Rise in March Sales
description: March was expected to be a poor month for retailers, who were hit by the triple whammy of unspringlike weather, a late Easter holiday and rising gas prices.

title: The Farewell Concert as Filibuster
description: Last Sunday, the day after LCD Soundsystems final concert at Madison Square Garden, I ran into a friend who attended the show and asked him for his opinion of it. I had seen some effusive posts on Twitter from people at the show, and I read some positive reviews afterward, from sources I had previously heard of and some I hadnt.

title: With Rule Revision, Golf Gives Back What Cameras Take Away
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  With high-definition television and super-slow-motion replays increasingly playing a role in how golfs rules are implemented, the sports governing bodies took a step back Thursday, revising a rule so that some golfers in unique situations would be only penalized, not disqualified.

title: Missile From Gaza Hits School Bus
description: JERUSALEM  A 16-year-old Israeli boy was critically wounded on Thursday when an antitank missile fired out of Gaza struck a school bus in southern Israel, according to military officials, setting off a new round of hostilities along the Israel-Gaza border.

title: The Gas Age
description: The Energy Information Administration has released World Shale Gas Resources, an important commissioned report providing an assessment of how much natural gas is locked in shale deposits in 14 regions around the world. (Heres its overview of shale gas in the United States.) Heres a map of the surveyed regions:

title: U.S. Fails to Qualify for U-20 World Cup
White House Meeting on Budget Fails to End Impasse
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama's third attempt in 24 hours to end the budget standoff on Thursday night did not produce a deal to fend off a shutdown of the federal government, but negotiators issued a statement saying they had "narrowed" the issues significantly.

title: As China Grows, So Does Its Appetite for American-Made Products
description: SHANGHAI  Americas huge trade deficit with China has raised concerns about American competitiveness and jobs moving overseas. But a new study offers a glimmer of hope to Americans: Last year, American exports to China soared 32 percent to a record $91.9 billion.

title: Are You Smart Enough to Eat Here?
description: A few weeks ago, on Twitter, a friend raved about a wonderful meal he had just finished. Intrigued, I asked what restaurant he had just come out of. In response, I was directed to the Web site of an operation called the No. 68 Project, a cultural dinner series. A button marked Request an Invitation beckoned from the top right corner of the page.

title: Same As He Ever Was
description: A correspondent asks how its possible that Paul Ryan would release such an extreme, unprofessional plan.

title: Citis New Policy May Mean Fewer Bounced Checks
description: Citibank says it will change the way it processes customers checks, a move that could result in fewer fees for bounced checks for account holders.

title: Judge Approves Dishs $320 Million Deal for Blockbuster
description: A federal bankruptcy judge on Thursday approved Dish Networks $320 million purchase of Blockbuster, paving the way for the troubled retailer to exit Chapter 11 protection.

title: Trailer: Midnight in Paris
description: A trailer for "Midnight in Paris," a film by Woody Allen starring Owen Wilson, Marion Cotillard, Rachel McAdams, La Seydoux, Kathy Bates and Carla Bruni.

title: Theater Talkback: The Joys of Feel-Bad Drama
description: An acridness hung in the air during the New Groups revival of Wallace Shawns Marie and Bruce the other night, something I dont often experience at the theater. It was the thick, curdled aura of an audiences collective discomfort.

title: Hughes Is Working on His Velocity Problem
description: Manager Joe Girardi may not like people talking about the right-hander Phil Hughess missing velocity, but Hughes isnt hiding from it. With his second start of the season Friday in Boston, he knows he will need his fastball to pick up the couple of miles per hour it was missing in his 2011 debut.

title: Mexican Authorities, Investigating Hijacking, Find 59 Bodies
description: MEXICO CITY  The discovery of 59 bodies buried in mass graves in northern Mexico led officials on Thursday to acknowledge that criminal gangs had begun to inflict a new form of terror: stopping buses and removing passengers, some never to be seen again.

title: U.S. Seeks HSBC Customers Names as Part of Tax Inquiry
description: Switzerland. The Caribbean. India?

title: Gunman Opens Fire at School in Brazil, Killing 12 Children
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  As family members mourned their loved ones and kept vigil at hospitals for the injured, this city searched for understanding Thursday after a shooting at a public school left 12 students dead and 12 others wounded.

title: Confronting an Enduring Taboo
description: LOS ANGELES  In the past couple of weeks, a Web site called Outsports.comhas written about a gay Brigham Young athlete who abided by the universitys honor code, published an essay from a lesbian basketball player at a Catholic girls school in California, and featured the Miami (Ohio) hockey team a year after the death of the openly gay student manager Brendan Burke, a son of Toronto Maple Leafs General Manager Brian Burke.

title: Undecorate
description: A post-recessionary approach to interior design, where anything goes.

title: Popcast: LCD Soundsystem, the Strokes and Bill Callahan
