description: The trailer for "The Arbor," a documentary about the British playwright Andrea Dunbar.

title: Shutdown Likely to Affect Some, but Not All, Services for Veterans
description: 10:54 a.m. | Updated

title: A New Dance Center for Houston
description: The Houston Ballet will celebrate the grand opening Saturday of its new Center for Dance, a $46 million project with multiple rehearsal studios, administrative offices, a wardrobe workshop and even a special room for shoes. It also includes a dance laboratory with stadium seating for developing and performing new work. The troupe has been busy on other fronts as well. It has won the Rudolf Nureyev Prize for New Dance, a $25,000 grant intended to encourage large companies to make new works. The company is using the money to commission a piece by Jorma Elo that will have its premiere in October at the Joyce Theater in New York. The prize is awarded by the Joyce Theater Foundation from an endowment created in part by the Rudolf Nureyev Foundation.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 8
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Twitter Patter | @noneck
description: Tweeting Since January 2007Followers 3,365Twitter Bio Dir. of tech innovation @ NYSenate.gov; co-founder/partner of @NuAMS; @digidem advisor; member of #BikeNYC, #TN2020 & @RSAorg.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The Brooklyn Beefsteak returns to The Bell House, 149 Seventh Street (Second Avenue), on Sunday with copious amounts of beef and beer. Tickets for the 5 to 8 p.m. seating are still available online at $50 for one ticket or $45 if four or more tickets are bought. Platters of steak and all-you-can-drink McSorleys beer will be served.

title: After Years of Cost Cuts, Texas Tries to Find More
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  It is hard to overstate the budget-cutting furor that has gripped lawmakers in this capital, where the Republicans who control the Legislature and all statewide offices believe voters sent them an ironclad mandate last year to shrink the size of government.

title: McIlroy Leads in Masters Second Round
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  At 21 years old, Rory McIlroy has already had a career that dwarfs men twice his age. He has won two tournaments as a professional, one in Europe and one in the United States. He has won more than $10 million on the course, made many millions off it in endorsements and bonuses, and has traveled the world in private jets.

title: Lil Wayne Cancels European Tour
description: 6:07 p.m. | Updated

title: Blue Bird Recalls 3,900 School Buses for Fire Hazard
description: The Blue Bird Corporation has told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that 3,900 of its school buses have a fire hazard.

title: What a Government Shutdown Means for Wall Street
description: This is not exactly what Wall Street had in mind when it asked the government to stay out of its business.

title: Glass Menagerie
description: When the designer Gregory Parkinson approached the specialty jeweler Ten Thousand Things to create accessories for his spring 2010 collection, his only request was riots of color. The result is a series of coin-size glass enamel talismans, which have since become a permanent fixture at Ten Thousand Things meatpacking district studio/boutique. As you stack them, it becomes like a composition of sorts, says David Rees of Ten Thousand Things. He and his partner, Ron Anderson, create folksy bijoux by fastening the swirling, multicolored pendants onto necklaces. Its like were making stones instead of finding stones, and how fun is that?

title: 9 Palestinians Die as Israel Hits Gaza in Retaliation for Hamas Attack on Bus
description: GAZA  Israeli air forces and artillery struck Gaza repeatedly on Friday, killing four militants and five civilians, according to Palestinian officials. The attacks were in retaliation for a Hamas missile strike on an Israeli school bus on Thursday that critically wounded a 16-year-old boy.

title: Walcott and a Little Pal Go Back to Their School
description: Just in case anyone needed reminding that the schools chancellor-designee, Dennis M. Walcott, is a proud product of the citys public school system, Mr. Walcott returned Friday morning to his elementary alma mater in Queens, this time accompanied by a smiling 7-year-old prop: his grandson Justin, a second grader at the school, Public School 36 in St. Albans.

title: Democratic Committee Uses Budget Stalemate to Raise Money
description: Senate Democrats are using Fridays midnight deadline for funding the government as an opportunity to try to raise some funds for their campaign committee.

title: Vote-Counting Error In Wisconsin Points to Incompetence, Not Conspiracy
description: When Kathy Nickolaus, the county clerk in Waukesha County, Wisconsin, spoke to the press on Thursday after revealing that she had failed to count more than 14,000 ballots in the hotly contested state supreme court election, one might have expected her to offer her resignation.

title: Objects of Artistry at Armory Fair
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#262", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Meanwhile, in Libya
description: I havent written about our Libyan intervention for a week or so, but with the media focused on the budget battles in Washington, it seemed worth rounding up some of the latest news and analysis from the Wests ongoing non-war with Muammar el-Qaddhafis regime. First, from todays Times:

title: TimesCast | April 8, 2011
description: On Thursday night, President Obama announced that while progress had been made, no deal was reached over the budget impasse threatening to shut down the government.

title: Living In | The West 70s
description: In an area flanked by Central and Riverside Parks, theres no neglected avenue, one agent said.

title: Reform, Real and Fake
description: Ezra Klein has a very good post on all the ways in which the Affordable Care Act makes a serious effort to grapple with health costs, while the Ryan plan doesnt:

title: Part 1: Answers to Readers Decision-Time Questions
description: Beginning today, Bruce Poch, a veteran of the admissions world who worked at Wesleyan and Connecticut College before serving, until recently, as dean of admissions at Pomona College in California, is answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice. The responses by Mr. Poch, who is focusing on queries related to the final weeks of this years admissions season, will resume on Monday and continue throughout the week.

title: Your BMW X3: Lets Go to the Videotape
description: When I ordered my new BMW 1 Series coupe last summer from the factory in Munich and shipped it home, I was able to track it online as it departed Bremerhaven (on a ship) and landed in Newark.

title: Museums Press for the Release of Ai Weiwei
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation is leading an international effort to call for the release of Ai Weiwei, the Chinese Conceptual artist who was taken into police custody in Beijing after he was detained on Sunday while trying to board a flight for Hong Kong. It has gathered the support of the museum community, including the Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, the Tate in London along with the American Association of Art Museum Directors.

title: Dining Out for Passover
description: As families scatter and old cooking traditions are lost, more Jews are celebrating Passover in restaurants. Here are some restaurants that will observe the holiday with meals ranging from Passover menus to formal Seders, with the dates and some details about them:

title: The Far North and Wintry Weather
description: Heres a quick swing north. The National Snow and Ice Data Center has inaugurated a useful new Web feature, Icelights, that offers the public a two-way portal for addressing questions about the behavior of sea ice and ice sheets and their relationship to the world far from the poles. The latest feature, What is the connection between Arctic sea ice and U.S. weather?, explores the hypothesis that open Arctic waters in fall or winter could influence storm patterns and snowfall outside of the region.

title: The Royal Wedding
description: The Times's Christine Haughney talks about the coming royal wedding with Shawn Rabideau, a wedding planner in New York who often works with celebrity clients.

title: Parenting in a Prison Colony
description: The conversation became heated here yesterday during the discussion of how far one mother went to put food on the table.

title: Winless Red Sox Make Moves Ahead of Home Opener
description: BOSTON  As hard as this may be to believe, the Red Sox players were not sitting by their lockers holding back tears Friday morning at Fenway Park. Theyre 0-6 as they prepare to face the Yankees in their home opener, but you couldnt really tell. Then again, the fans havent had their say yet.

title: Vintage Trump
description: Not content with dangling the possibility of a presidential run, Donald Trump has now apparently bought a winery, paying $6.2 million at auction on Thursday for the Kluge Estate Winery and Vineyard in Charlottesville, Va. The sale included more than 700 acres, including the winery and vineyards, according to C-Ville Weekly.

title: Weekend Competition: Topical Ice Cream Flavors
description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab is solicitingtopical ice cream flavors.

title: Data Visualized: More on Teaching With Infographics
description: In an uncharted world of boundless data, information designers are our new navigators, begins a recent Times article, When the Data Struts Its Stuff.

title: Pop Shop | Andy Warhol for Incase
description: Andy Warhol was always a tech nerd. He was obsessed with his audio recorder (he called it his wife) and was rarely seen traveling without his headphones on.

title: When Times Were Saucy
description: Prepare to join the newsroom of The Times in a collective gasp.

title: Down to the Wire on Budget Negotiations
description: Paul Volpe and Jeff Zeleny discuss the last-ditch efforts to avoid a government shutdown, which could come at midnight on Friday.

title: Optimism Is Back, Says Top Private Equity Deal-Maker
description: Scott M. Sperling, co-president of Thomas H. Lee Partners, says the threat of a double-dip recession has lessened, and that crucial credit markets are as robust as weve seen since the financial crisis.

title: U.S. Clears Google Acquisition of Travel Software
description: The Justice Department on Friday approved Googles $700 million acquisition of a flight search software maker, but imposed conditions limiting how Google could use the companys technology, potentially opening the door to broader antitrust scrutiny of the search giants activities.

title: France to Help Italy Block Tunisian Migrants
description: ROME  Italy and France agreed on Friday to carry out joint sea and air patrols to prevent Tunisian migrants from arriving in Italy, a move that appeared to ease tensions between them over how to contend with thousands of North African migrants who have landed in Italy since January.

title: Johnson & Johnson Settles Bribery Complaint for $70 Million in Fines
description: WASHINGTON  A wide-ranging government investigation of corrupt overseas marketing practices by drug and device makers scored its first major victory Friday when Johnson & Johnson admitted bribing European doctors and agreed to pay $70 million in civil and criminal fines.

title: Video: Down to the Wire on Budget Negotiations
description: After a series of negotiating sessions at the White House and talks that stretched into the wee hours at the Capitol, President Obama and lawmakers failed to produce a budget deal by Friday morning, just hours from a government shutdown.

title: Technicals Have Orlandos Howard Smelling Conspiracy
description: Its not unusual to hear N.B.A. players semi-jokingly discussing their theories that referees are out to get them. But Orlando center Dwight Howard doesnt sound as if hes joking.

title: The Suburbs of Manhattan
description: WHEN Paul Kahn was growing up on the Upper West Side in the 1980s, he recalled recently, it was pleasant and livable but a neighborhood that might seem surprising in hindsight. There were some blocks his parents didnt let him walk on; many children, himself included, went to private school; and his Little League, which drew from both the Upper West Side and Harlem, still felt uncrowded.

title: Jill Fernald and Geddes Munson
description: IN the third grade, Jill Fernald shocked her family when she arrived home with blisters covering her hands. She had failed a swinging exercise on the monkey bars in gym class, then practiced for hours on the bars after school until she earned the teachers certificate of achievement.

title: Staging a Royal Wedding, This Side of the Pond
description: WHILE it might take all the kings horses to put together the kind of wedding day that Kate Middleton and Prince William are expected to enjoy on April 29, any wedding planner worth his royal oats could put together an, um, equally regal affair right here in New York.

title: Why the Eichmann Trial Really Mattered
description: To write about the trial of Adolf Eichmann is to put its most notorious court reporter, Hannah Arendt, in the dock. In the nearly 50 years since its publication, her account of those proceedings, Eichmann in Jerusalem, has come to overshadow its subject. The book, it is true, commands attention. It is a breathtaking admixture of genres (history, philosophy, journalism) and contains strong, often unconventional, moral judgments (especially her contempt for the Jewish leaders who cooperated with their murderers). It aims to render grand historical conclusions but remains unintentionally and inescapably personal.

title: Message From a Stranger
description: In New York, mementos of previous tenants have a wonderful way of resurfacing. To their finders, they are a kind of house-warming gift.

title: The Man Who Fell in Love With His G.P.S.
description: In his novel The Notebooks of Malte Laurids Brigge, Rilke writes of those who have been thrown away (die Fortgeworfenen), or what Michael Hulse translates as the untouchables: those sad husks of men, spat out by fate, as Rilke describes them, unworthy of being touched by either divine providence or simple human benevolence. Brigge has something of Dostoyevskys Underground Man seething within him, and also recalls the sordid unnamed narrator of Henri Barbusses novel Hell: misfits and spiritual lepers, indeed spat out by fate, these characters are simultaneously too outraged and too sensitive for civilization. They are precursors to perhaps the most notable misfit in 20th-century European fiction, Meursault from Albert Camuss novella The Stranger.

title: Fashion TV, Theme and Variations
description: As gray-haired fashion moguls know, success lies in finding a look and repeating it, with minor variations, for years. Dont frighten the horses! Creators of reality television also favor this formula. At least eight new reality fashion shows and one scripted series are in development, following on the stilettoes of Project Runway and the Hollywood stylist Rachel Zoe.

title: Boehner Declares G.O.P. Is Damn Serious
description: The rhetoric just keeps getting hotter as the prospect of a shutdown nears.

title: Message From a Stranger
description: FOR New Yorkers drawn to old houses and apartments, the reminders that they are hardly the first to inhabit their rooms can be thrilling. If those people had their way, no one would ever empty a cellar or clear out an attic.

title: Listening to Chimps
description: In an article from Sundays magazine that is now online, Rob Walker, a contributing writer and blogger, writes about Radiolab, a public radio show that, he says, expects you to stop checking your inbox, updating your status or playing Angry Birds and spend a solid hour listening. One of my favorite episodes (it demanded, as I recall, a complete cessation of dishwashing to listen with the proper attention) included the story of Lucy, a chimp who was raised by a psychotherapist and a social worker who wanted to find out how human she could become. Here is a Lucy slide show:

title: British Tabloid Accepts Blame in Cell Hacking
description: LONDON  Faced with a cascade of lawsuits and a widening police investigation into illegal hacking of phone messages by the News of the World tabloid, its parent company on Friday publicly admitted wrongdoing, apologized and offered to pay damages to some of the people who are alleged to be victims of the paper.

title: Scrumptious Desserts (Hold the Guilt)
description: What is a healthy dessert? Martha Rose Shulman tackles this question in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: A Sex Strike in New Jersey
description: Imagine that every heterosexual man in a community went on strike, refusing to have sex with women until certain demands were met. Never mind what demands; just picture it. How far you get with this thought experiment depends on the dogged ingenuity of your imagination (assuming you can conjure more than an abandoned picket line strewn with trampled signs). As plots go, its just silly. Reverse it, though, and everything changes.

title: Introducing Joe Louis to a New Generation
description: If the magazine The Ring were to rank oxymorons, childrens boxing book would be No. 1 in the heavyweight division.

title: A Teenagers View of the Gulag
description: They took me in my nightgown. The opening sentence of this superlative first novel by Ruta Sepetys demonstrates the strength of its unembellished language. Thus, 15-year-old Lina Vilkas, along with her mother and younger brother, is deported from her Lithuanian home by the Soviet secret police in 1941, and begins a cattle-car journey through a series of forced-labor camps that will span 12 years and 6,500 miles.

title: A New Narnia for the Tween Set
description: The rest of book publishing may be tottering on the brink, but the market for young adult fantasy seems as difficult to destroy as, well, a vampire. Series about children learning to harness otherworldly powers to vanquish cosmic evil  Stephenie Meyers Twilight, Philip Pullmans His Dark Materials and, of course, J. K. Rowlings Harry Potter  have a powerful archetypal appeal, with each iteration attracting young readers afresh.

title: Up Front: Beverly Cleary
description: In the early 80s, when the childrens book authors Beverly Cleary, profiled on our back page this week to mark her 95th birthday, and Judy Blume, author of books like Deenie and Blubber, were with the same publisher, their boxes of fan mail were accidentally switched.

title: The Ageless Appeal of Beverly Cleary
description: In the opening chapter of Beverly Clearys Ramona the Pest, first published in 1968 and still popular today, Ramona Quimbys teacher reads aloud the Virginia Burton classic Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel to a rapt group of kindergartners. As Ramona listened, Cleary writes, a question came into her mind, a question that had often puzzled her about the books that were read to her.

title: Courtroom Drama
description: With perfect (if shamelessly calculated) timing, THE FIFTH WITNESS (Little, Brown, $27.99), Michael Connellys new legal mystery featuring Mickey Haller  known in certain circles as the Lincoln Lawyer because he does business out of the back seat of his Town Car  arrives in bookstores at the same time the feature film adapted from the first book in this series (also called The Lincoln Lawyer) hits the movie theaters. Despite that confluence of events, Haller hasnt gone Hollywood in this lively caper, although he does sell out to some extent by disengaging himself from his bulletproof car (acquired from a drug dealers widow) and renting a real office, complete with a nap couch.

title: Inside the List
description: WHO MOVED MY LATTE? Starbucks may be struggling to regain its glory days, but the companys chief executive, Howard Schultz, is on top of the hardcover nonfiction list with Onward: How Starbucks Fought for Its Life Without Losing Its Soul.

title: Editors Choice
description: BISMARCK: A Life,  by Jonathan Steinberg (Oxford University, $34.95.) With an incisive psychological approach, Steinberg describes a highly complex man who incarnated the duality that later tempted Germany into efforts beyond its capacity.

title: Paperback Row
description: LORD OF MISRULE,  by Jaimy Gordon (Vintage Contemporaries, $15.) Winner of the 2010 National Book Award for fiction, this novel revolves around four horse races at a second-class racetrack in West Virginia. (Lord of Misrule is a shiny black beetle of a stakes horse.) Gordon ably shifts perspective among several characters, including an old groom, a trainer and his girlfriend, an outsider drawn to the broken-down beauty of the animals.

title: Hero of Egypts Revolution, Military Now Faces Critics
description: CAIRO  A blogger was jailed recently for insulting the military. Human rights advocates say that thousands of people have been arrested and tried before military courts in the last two months. Protesters have been tortured and female activists subjected to so-called virginity tests.

title: TechStars Nurtures Start-Ups With Mentors
description: On Thursday, nearly a dozen technology start-ups present their new or improved company at an event called TechStars Demo Day at Webster Hall in New York. Each start-up gets eight minutes on stage to convince investors sitting in the audience  the sponsors say they are expecting several hundred  to finance the company.

title: Tokyo Street Style
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#630", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Helping Your Teenager Become a Safe Driver
description: IN about six months, Ill be facing another rite of passage: my older son will begin driving lessons.

title: Will Lawmakers Raise Money During a Shutdown?
description: If the government shuts down, will lawmakers continue holding fund-raisers?

title: Reflections on the Relevance of Schools Chancellors
description: Poor Cathleen P. Black. She was so overmatched: 1.1 million children, 75,000 teachers, almost 1,700 schools. Its a lot.

title: Spain From Above
description: In this Sundays magazine, the Look pages feature an abstract image from the photographer Edward Burtynsky. Last year, Burtynsky took to the air to take photographs of various agricultural regions in Spain, including the Monegros, regarded as one of the areas with the greatest biodiversity in Europe. We had room to print only one such image, but you can see additional images online.

title: Bonds Jury Deliberates; Anderson Released
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Just before 8:30 a.m. Friday, jurors in Barry Bondss perjury case walked into a room on the 19th floor of the Phillip Burton Federal Building here to begin deliberating his fate.

title: In Outburst, Putin Says W.T.O. Rules Dont Apply
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia interrupted a speech on the economy by a deputy minister on Friday to sharply rebuke him for suggesting that the government should abide by World Trade Organization rules on import tariffs. Russia is not yet a member of the global trade group but is applying to join.

title: How to Read Poetry Today
description: Some years ago, I wrote a poem called Broken Promises, which was adopted by the Poetry Out Loud project for its annual competition, meaning that high school students can recite it or one of several hundred other poems and maybe advance through regional and state competitions to the nationals, where some serious money is at stake. Broken Promises deals with just that: the promises we break and how they limp around and gaze at us reproachfully while enjoying an immortality denied to the promises weve kept.

title: Citi Field Coming to Life
description: A few players are warming up on the grass in advance of the seasons first game at Citi Field.

title: Big Deal | Paying Extra to Smell the Flowers
description: Saturday, 4:42 p.m. | Updated Supporters of New York Citys parks and gardens have long asked residents of nearby buildings to help pay for the upkeep of these green spaces.

title: Scary Years
description: A look back at the films in the Scream franchise.

title: Rrrring! Hello, Sidney? Its Happening Again!
description: DO you like scary movies?

title: The Walden of the Wildfire
description: Many of us have probably on at least one cubicle-gray afternoon dreamed of lighting out in a rented U-Haul for some territory or other. Few whove acted on the impulse have made as excellent use of a sabbatical as Philip Connors has, and there are few territories left as wild and grand and as richly meaningful, or as spectacularly combustible, as the one Connors found almost a decade ago  New Mexicos Gila Wilderness, the first designated wilderness in the history of the world, which also happens to be, as Connors puts it in his finely, wryly, at times poetically wrought first book, the epicenter of American wildfire.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Return of The Witching Hour
description: Perusing the comic racks, the average reader would be hard-pressed to find a title more oddly foreboding than Disaster in a Jar. Or find a more peculiar story than one about a psychiatrist trapped in a time warp with three cackling witches setting the scene. In the land of the superhero, this type of hair-raising tale  best read under a blanket with a flashlight  is a true rarity.

title: 4 A.M. E-Mail Said Deal Was Off, Reid Says
description: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the majority leader, said he received an e-mail at 4 a.m. Friday indicating that Republicans were backing away from a deal they had reached the night before on how much money to cut from the budget.

title: Of Nose Jobs and Inner Beauty
description: TESTED 2012 Acura TL

title: Sticking by Rosy Predictions for the Stock Market
description: PREDICTING the future is a tough business, particularly when unexpected events make your crystal ball look more like a snow globe. But the group of strategists and advisers polled for this column in January are so far sticking to their forecasts that equities are poised for growth this year.

title: Pace Offers Shakespeare Fans an Alternative
description: There are three very different productions of Macbeth under way in New York this month, but admirers of Shakespeares lighter work have an alternative: The Acting Companys production of The Comedy of Errors, which begins performances at Pace University on Saturday night after a five-month national tour. Directed by Ian Belknap, this Comedy of Errors draws on Charlie Chaplins style of visually spare comedy routines as inspiration for staging the plot of two sets of identical twins accidentally separated at birth. The play, produced in association with the Guthrie Theater, is scheduled to run through April 17. It is part of the inaugural season of Shakespeare at Pace, a new endeavor that most recently included F. Murray Abrahams Shylock in The Merchant of Venice.

title: Piecing Together Wallaces Posthumous Novel
description: In his office at Little Brown, where he is executive vice president and publisher, Michael Pietsch still has the tower of a manuscript and the handwritten journals and notebooks he carried out of David Foster Wallaces studio, in a duffel and two Trader Joes bags, after Wallace killed himself in September 2008.

title: St. Johns Coach Lavin Has Prostate Cancer
description: St. Johns Coach Steve Lavin, who took the Red Storm mens basketball team to its first N.C.A.A. tournament since 2002 in his debut last season, was found to have an early stage of prostate cancer, but he is expected to keep coaching and to make a complete recovery.

title: Everest Without the Crowds
description: PERCHED on a narrow platform 17,500 feet above sea level, we paused to snack on boiled potatoes and the spicy Tibetan dumplings called momos, and to drink in the view.

title: Letters: Rainy Seattle, and Dreamy Paris
description: RAIN, RAIN, GO AWAY

title: Eco-Paris
description: FOR two scorching days in Paris last May, the Champs-lyses was closed to traffic, covered over with grass. Visitors traipsed through a forest of Lebanese cedar trees and snapped photos of goat pens and stacked pyramids of vegetables, with the Arc de Triomphe looming above. It was all part of Nature Capitale, a large-scale installation created by the French street artist Gad Weil, who timed it to coincide with International Biodiversity Day, an annual event sponsored by the United Nations. The spectacle drew two million visitors, among them two surprise guests: the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, and his wife, Carla Bruni, who wore jeans and an untucked oxford shirt with rolled-up sleeves, providing a bit of barnyard chic in the Eighth Arrondissement.

title: In Australia, Driving the Great Ocean Road
description: ALONG the shores of the Indian Ocean, as the coastline east of Adelaide, Australia, wends its rocky way toward Melbourne, lies one of the worlds classic drives: the Great Ocean Road. Here, brutal, slicing surf and weather pound malleable limestone and sandstone, eating away at the Australian continent, and leaving mile after mile of sweeping vistas of sculptured cliffs, towers and arches framed against the roiling turquoise sea.

title: The Poetry of Hangzhou
description: ON a misty afternoon in February, Lingyin Temple, a fourth-century Buddhist site that is one of Chinas most important sanctuaries, felt more like a carnival than a place of worship. In large multigenerational packs, festive families were gathered for the Lunar New Year holiday, tossing fistfuls of ceremonial paper money into huge open fire pits and waving incense sticks as they jostled through crowds on their way to visit the 80-foot-high Buddha that is the buildings centerpiece. All the while they were downing fried tofu on sticks and corn on the cob and taking photos of everything on digital cameras. My family and I, possessing the only Western faces in the crowd, qualified as a photo coup  especially my towheaded toddler. Look over here, foreign baby! a young mother shouted as she held up her baby next to mine. The holiday period may officially last only a week, but the celebratory mood in Hangzhou seems to have permanently taken over this ever more vital city.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Luca in Yountville, Calif.
description: BASICS

title: Renegade San Francisco Underground Market
description: IN the Bay Area, year-round farmers markets and food co-ops are plentiful and well-established. Too well-established, it turns out, for a group of amateur chefs, foragers and home food purveyors in San Francisco. So the disparate crew founded a renegade market for vendors who lack the commercial kitchens and licenses needed to operate elsewhere.

title: Exploring Nepals Everest Region
description: Leaving the main trail behind, and taking the less-traveled Three Passes Loop.

title: In Ljubljana, Bridges Connect Past and Future
description: Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia, may wrap around the foot of its medieval castle, but more contemporary attractions are within walking distance of the citys true heart, the banks of the Ljubljanica River.

title: Australias Great Ocean Road
description: Along one of the worlds classic drives: mile after mile of sweeping vistas of sculptured cliffs, towers and arches framed against the roiling turquoise sea.

title: Small Wonders, Awaiting the Eyes of the Curious
description: Its easy for New Yorkers, in the speed and chaos of city life, to overlook the small wonders that can be unearthed through occasional bouts of curiosity. And sometimes that stuff can be pretty cool, or at the very least feature beer.

title: Detroit Symphony Reaches Deal With Musicians
description: The musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra will take a major pay cut and will be reduced in number but will not have their jobs redefined to require teaching, coaching and other forms of community outreach, according to details of a new contract agreement released by the symphony on Friday.

title: Classics in Wide Open Spaces
description: The Copperstate 1000, a four-day rally in Arizona, gives owners of vintage sports cars room to roam.

title: Old Flames, Eternal City
description: Picture a woman of a certain age, alone in an Italian city, sitting in a cafe, pulling a spare chair against her table and nudging her coffee cup far from her water glass, so onlookers might imagine her to be accompanied. How sad, how brave, how hard to watch! In the film Summertime, Katharine Hepburn played such a woman, on a solo vacation in Venice, winking back tears while maintaining perfect posture and a rigid smile. But what if the lonely tourist werent as lonely as she appeared? What if a man was coming to lay claim to that chair, that coffee, that woman; and what if that woman wished he wouldnt, doesnt at all want a coffee and is aware now that were at an age when we must take care not to be embarrassing. Might the mans presence make the woman lonelier than his absence? In her new novel, The Love of My Youth, so nostalgic in its title, Mary Gordon overturns sentimental assumptions, redirecting the readers sympathies from what could have been to what in fact was  and to what therefore followed. Using the passage of time as a soft pedal, she gentles the impact of a devastating affair, creating the record of a passion more safely reread than relived.

title: From the 12C, Performance Without Pain
description: WOKING, England

title: Seeing Sights of Arizona in Valuable Vintage Cars
description: PHOENIX

title: McLaren Cuts Price of Its Carbon-Fiber Menu
description: WOKING, England

title: Six Keys to Saving by Starting at Community College
description: When Rich Johnston started college in the 1970s, four years at a standard university was out of the question financially. So he worked, knocked off two years of community college credits in 19 months and then worked some more.

title: How Evolution Explains Altruism
description: What do colon cancer, ant colonies, language and global warming have in common? This might sound like the front end of a joke, but in fact its a serious challenge to the standard view of evolution. Martin A. Nowak, the director of the Program for Evolutionary Dynamics at Harvard, has devoted a brilliant career to showing that Darwin, and particularly his followers, batted only two for three. Random mutation and natural selection have indeed been powerful motors for change in the natural world  the struggle for existence pitting the fit against the fitter in a hullabaloo of rivalry. But most of the great innovations of life on earth, Nowak argues, from genes to cells to societies, have been due to a third motor, and master architect, of evolution: cooperation.

title: Tina Fey and Me
description: IN the fall of 2008, when I heard that Oprah Winfrey would be making a guest appearance on Tina Feys NBC sitcom, 30 Rock, I experienced the unique joy that arises when two entities you love equally but dont think of as having much in common unexpectedly intersect  as if your iPhone suddenly started making pizza.

title: Avatar Director Cautions Against Early Video-on-Demand Release
description: LOS ANGELES  James Cameron has seen the future of cinema, and as far as hes concerned, it does not involve accelerated access to movies via video-on-demand.

title: Attending Community College to Save Money
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I offer up advice to students and parents who are using community college as a deliberate, money-saving strategy.

title: Look of the Moment | Eva Green
description: The Look: Pump up the volume  a structured top pairs triumphantlywith fluid trousers.

title: Alfia Sadekova, Oleg Ilitchev
description: Alfia Sadekova and Oleg Ilitchev were married Friday morning at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell of the city clerks office officiated. On Friday evening, Alexander Kalachev, vice consul in New York for the Russian Federation, led a Russian civil ceremony in the offices of the federations Consulate General.

title: Grace Applefeld, William Cleveland IV
description: Grace Lauve Applefeld and William Choice Cleveland IV were married Saturday evening at the Engineering Society of Baltimore. The Rev. Phebe L. McPherson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Thomas Malia, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Sarah Lobel and Dunstan Barnes
description: Sarah Anne Lobel, the daughter of Caryl L. Lobel and Dr. Martin L. Lobel of Milwaukee, was married Saturday evening to Dunstan Henry Barnes, a son of Anne J. Barnes of Abingdon, England, and Timothy D. Barnes of Edinburgh, at the Biltmore Hotel in Coral Gables, Fla. Judge Edward K. Newman of Miami-Dade County Court in Miami officiated.

title: Mrcia Nunes , Diego Mayer-Cantu
description: Mrcia Maria Maiera Nunes and Diego Armand Mayer-Cantu were married Thursday in Rio de Janeiro. Archbishop Orani Joo Tempesta of Rio de Janeiro performed the ceremony at the Church of Nossa Senhora da Glria do Outeiro.

title: Laura Kirschbaum, Paul Adams
description: Laura Michele Kirschbaum and Paul Adams were married Saturday at St. Patricks Old Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Donald Sakano, the cathedrals pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Catherine Pitt and Nigel Young
description: Catherine Krown Pitt and Nigel Godfrey Young were married Friday afternoon in Richmond, England. Wendy Miles, a superintendent registrar of the borough of Richmond Upon Thames, officiated at Cambridge Cottage on the grounds of the Royal Botanic Gardens at Kew.

title: Abigail Lorge, Seth Abbey
description: Abigail Cleveland Lorge and Seth Michael Abbey are to be married Sunday at Highlawn Pavilion, a restaurant in West Orange, N.J. Gerald Fierst, a minister of the Universal Brotherhood Movement, is to officiate.

title: Sonya Mirbagheri, Alexander Cheney
description: Sonya Michelle Mirbagheri and Alexander Leonard Cheney were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Jewelnel Davis, a Baptist minister and the chaplain of Columbia University, led a nondenominational ceremony at the Central Park Boathouse. Dr. Naser Sharifi, the chairman of the Reza Islamic Center of Long Island in Westbury, N.Y., then led a Persian wedding ceremony.

title: Joan Snyder, Alex Kuhl
description: Joan Kathleen Snyder, a daughter of Diane E. Snyder and Douglas E. Snyder of Macungie, Pa., was married Saturday afternoon in New York to Alex Andrew Kuhl, the son of Rena A. Kuhl and William B. Kuhl of Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. Richard D. Baker performed the ceremony at St. Malachysthe Actors ChapelRoman Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

title: Robin Quittell, Aron Ponticelli
description: Robin Meredith Quittell, the daughter of Jeanne LeTourneau Quittell and Dr. Glenn S. Quittell of Harrison, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Aron John Ponticelli, the son of Debra Yelencsics Ponticelli and Jack T. Ponticelli of East Bend, N.C. Jonathan Lippman, the chief judge of New York State, officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Lauren Bogner and Matthew Wallerstein
description: Lauren Alison Bogner, the daughter of Joan Bogner and Stephen Bogner of Cresskill, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Matthew Perlik Wallerstein, the son of Susan Perlik and Mitchel B. Wallerstein{cq} {cq}of New York. Gregory A. Winfield, a friend of the bridegrooms parents who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Tribeca Rooftop in New York.

title: Tessa Deutsch, Paul Klepetko
description: Tessa Barak Deutsch, a daughter of Ellen B. Deutsch and Stanley I. Deutsch of New York, was married Monday to Paul Russell Klepetko, a son of Barbara Jean Klepetko of Sydney, Australia, and the late Vladimir Jiri Klepetko. Justice Alice Schlesinger of the State Supreme Court officiated in her courtroom in New York.

title: Elizabeth Dubin, Alexander Pugatch
description: Elizabeth Joy Dubin and Alexander Scott Pugatch were married Saturday evening at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in New York. Rabbi Alfredo F. Borodowski officiated.

title: Casey Marks and Adam Sills
description: Casey Jill Marks and Adam Lawrence Sills were married Saturday by Rabbi Dr. David M. Posner at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Heather Babby and Eric Rimsky
description: Heather Lynn Babby, the daughter of Ellen R. Babby and Lon S. Babby of Bethesda, Md., was married Saturday evening to Eric Cummins Rimsky, the son of Cathy C. Rimsky and Lee C. Rimsky of Port Washington, N.Y. Rabbi Lewis D. Solomon officiated at the Ritz-Carlton in Washington.

title: Christina Duss, Lincoln Isetta
description: Christina Marie Duss and Lincoln William Raymond Isetta were married Saturday at Our Lady Star of the Sea Catholic Church{cq}in Ponte Vedra Beach,{cq}Fla. The Rev. Tim Lozier{cq}, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Anna Aronova , Michael Berger
description: Dr. Anna Aronova and Michael Brandon Berger were married Saturday evening at the North Ritz Club, a caterer in Syosset, N.Y. Cantor Sergei Schwartz officiated.

title: American Heiresses on the World Stage
description: When I write, it is into another world, 29-year-old Margaret Fuller confessed in 1840 as she was about to take up the editorship of The Dial, a Boston journal that would feature the work of her friends Emerson and Thoreau. Although she had yet to cross the Atlantic, Fullers tastes had been so much formed by the European mind, through her reading of British literature and Latin, French, Italian and German texts, that she feared she might never do something worthily that belonged to the country where I was born.

title: Turning to Spirits for Healing
description: Many Haitians in New York practice voodoo, a healing-based religion long misunderstood and maligned in Western popular culture.

title: Brooklyn Voodoo
description: Haitian-Americans are embracing the centuries-old traditions of voodoo, an often stigmatized religion that is undergoing a renaissance in New York City.

title: Lennons Letters to Be Collected in New Book
description: John Lennon may be better known as a writer of songs like Strawberry Fields Forever, I Am the Walrus and Imagine, but he was also a prolific composer of correspondence that will be compiled for the first time in a book that Little, Brown is preparing for next year.

title: For Those Still Wary of the Stock Market
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, went back to the strategists and advisers he spoke to in January, to see how their predictions have fared this year. Even considering all the turmoil in the Middle East and the Japanese earthquake and nuclear problems, they are all sticking with their forecasts that equities will grow this year.

title: Eisenhower, Patton and Bradley: Team of Rivals
description: Dwight D. Eisenhower, George S. Patton and Omar N. Bradley, the three outstanding American commanders in North Africa and Europe from 1942 to 1945, were, if not exactly brothers in arms, at least friends, even if their friendship was often disrupted by envy, backbiting and disagreements over strategy. Fellow graduates of the United States Military Academy, all three were immensely ambitious.

title: Voodoo, an Anchor, Rises Again
description: IT was past 3 a.m. in a dim basement in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and Jack Laroche, a Haitian-American computer engineer, nervously awaited his bride: a voodoo spirit named Ezili Freda who believers say has the power tolavish loveand wealth andrenderwayward spouses impotent.

title: Book Review Podcast: Francisco Goldman
description: This week: Francisco Goldman discusses his new novel, Say Her Name; the historian Deborah Lipstadt revisits the trial of Adolf Eichmann; and Pamela Paul talks about Beverly Cleary. As always, Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Men, Unemployment and Disability
description: In the worst economic times of the 1950s and 60s, about 9 percent of men in the prime of their working lives (25 to 54 years old) were not working. At the depth of the severe recession in the early 1980s, about 15 percent of prime-age men were not working. Today, more than 18 percent of such men arent working.

title: In Portugal Crisis, Worries on Europes Debt Trap
description: PARIS  For the third time in a year the European Union is going through the same ritual, bailing out another insolvent country. Portugal now follows Greece and Ireland to the European welfare office to ask for new loans on the condition of ever more drastic spending cuts.

title: Hearing on Terror Includes Heated Debate on Islam
description: In a local reprise of a polarizing Congressional hearing last month on the question of Islam and terror, state lawmakers warned in grave terms on Friday of the threats facing the New York area, while other lawmakers and interfaith groups criticized the proceedings as anti-Muslim and incendiary.

title: Rossini Scholar Disagrees With Met
description: The scholar and editor Philip Gossett is an expert on early-19th-century Italian opera, particularly the works of Verdi and Rossini. So naturally, the Metropolitan Opera asked him to write program notes for its premiere production of Rossinis penultimate opera and last comedy, Le Comte Ory, which will be carried live on Saturday in an HD transmission to movie theaters and on the Mets radio network.

title: The Prehistory of Baseball
description: Among the many books that have educated us about the birth and infancy of baseball, John Thorns extraordinarily detailed and well-documented Baseball in the Garden of Eden is the advanced seminar, the one that begins by telling you that everything you thought you knew is wrong. Its premise is that when it comes to baseball, what is generally thought to be history is myth, and the two most prominent myths  the one that Abner Doubleday invented the game in Cooperstown, N.Y., in 1839, and the other that the responsible party was a New Yorker, Alexander Cartwright, who formalized the games rules in 1845  were promulgated by men with ulterior motives.

title: Roses Brilliance Obscures Bulls Other Efforts
description: Derrick Rose spent the better part of his Thursday evening looking like the best basketball player on the planet. The leagues inevitable most valuable player dissected one of the top defenses in the N.B.A. by making all of the simple plays, finishing the far more difficult ones, and generally making the impossible seem routine.

title: Two Rockers, Old Hits And Reasons to Believe
description: The Heart & Soul tour, a pairing of Rod Stewart and Stevie Nicks, is pure nostalgia, a valentine for the middle-aged and what they listened to from 1976 to 1978. Not a judgment, just a fact. But the really outmoded part about the concert is that the link between them is the radio.

title: Texas E.V. Charging Plan Expands to Dallas-Fort Worth
description: The utility NRG Energy is joining with the charging provider AeroVironment to expand its subscription-based electric eVgo car service from Houston to Dallas-Fort Worth. Eventually, the program, which NRG describes as an integrated network of charging products, services and payment plans that helps make E.V.s practical for drivers, will be expanded to include San Antonio and Austin.

title: Childrens Bookshelf: The Environment
description: CLOUDETTE  By Tom Lichtenheld.  40 pp. Christy Ottaviano/Holt. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7)

title: Two Explanations for the Stalemate
description: As a government shutdown looms, Michael D. Shear discusses how the Democrats and Republicans have offered different reasons for the budget stalemate.

title: Meanwhile, Pale Male Is Taking His Cues From Hefner
description: Enough of Violet and Bobby, live from the nest  you know, the red-tailed hawks at New York University with the video feed. Inquiring minds want to know whats with Pale Male and all the girlfriends.

title: An Egg-Bot Prints Easter Egg Designs
description: The April issue of Martha Stewart Living always bums me out. I covet the beautifully ornate decorated eggs featured within the glossy pages of the magazine. But who am I kidding? I cant recreate that at home. Its hard enough getting a single color consistently dyed around my shell, let alone stamp them with a botanical print.

title: Psilakis Returns to His Roots
description: Eight years ago, Michael Psilakis sold his Italian restaurant on Long Island and began to open restaurants in Manhattan that would present Greek food in a new light  more creative than traditional.

title: Wheelies: Texas Road Rules Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Acer Enters the Tablet Market
description: Acer, one of the worlds largest makers of PCs, will begin selling a tablet at Best Buy stores.

title: $3 Trillion Here, $3 Trillion There
description: OK, $2.9 trillion. Anyway, pretty soon youll be talking about real money.

title: McLaren Goes Street Legal
description: McLarens allegiance to uncompromised performance shines through in the MP4-12C.

title: Clip: 'The Eleventh Year'
description: A scene from Dziga Vertov's "Eleventh Year," courtesy of Edition Filmmuseum. Music by Michael Nyman.

title: Machine Age Poet, Born in Revolution, Stifled Under Stalin
description: IN many ways the Soviet filmmaker Dziga Vertov (1896-1954) was an artist of his time. A kindred spirit of the Constructivist artists who thrived in the wake of the 1917 October Revolution only to be stifled by the Stalinist policies of the 1930s, Vertov was a futurist at heart, a poet of the machine age. For a filmmaker in the reborn Russia the thrill of the new was palpable. Vertov, who saw theory and practice as inseparable, sought to uncover what made the young medium of moving images distinct from the other arts. Every film and every manifesto was an opportunity to examine the latent possibilities and harness the untapped power of cinema.

title: New York for Tokyo
description: As Japan recovers from the devastation of last months tsunami and earthquake, New Yorks fashion crowd is uniting to support Japanese relief efforts in its own way. Whether its in the form of spirited soirees, grand auctions or limited-edition merchandise, there are stylish options for everyone to get involved.

title: Mixed Reaction to Blacks Brief Tenure
description: We spoke to parents and educators at public schools in East Harlem and in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on Friday morning about Cathleen P. Blacks ouster as schools chancellor. Some bid her good riddance, but others felt she had been treated unfairly and never given a chance to prove herself and learn her job. Heres a roundup:

title: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ivory Coast, Afghanistan, Japan, and Brazil.

title: The Professor and the Lieutenant
description: The magazine is running a moving Lives column this Sunday by a professor of English literature at West Point. On the very afternoon last summer that she was going to mail a care package to a former student serving in Afghanistan, she found out that he was killed in action.

title: House Votes Against Net Neutrality
description: WASHINGTON  The House of Representatives approved a measure on Friday that would prohibit the Federal Communications Commission from regulating how Internet service providers manage their broadband networks, potentially overturning a central initiative of the F.C.C. chairman, Julius Genachowski.

title: Interesting Concepts and Offhand Remarks From Jeep
description: Chryslers marketing plan for Jeep includes mass events where enthusiasts gather to celebrate the brand while the automaker shows off hardware. On April 16-24, the faithful will gather in Moab, Utah, for the Easter Jeep Safari, and Jeep will display a range of custom vehicles, which are also meant to promote Chryslers Mopar brand, which markets accessories and high-performance parts.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Beyond
description: Photographs from Ivory Coast, Afghanistan, Japan and Brazil.

title: Manny Ramirez Retires After Testing Positive
description: Manny Ramirez retired from baseball Friday instead of facing a 100-game suspension for testing positive for a performance-enhancing drug, according to two people briefed on the matter.

title: No Weekend Getaway for the Obamas
description: The possibility of a government shutdown has forced President Obama to postpone his planned family vacation to Williamsburg, Va., officials at the White House said.

title: Video: Parties Offer Differing Explanations for the Budget Stalemate
Changing Ideas Drive Some Celestial Searches
description: According to the concept statement for I Like This, a collaboration between Antony Hamilton and Byron Perry, objects wait patiently in stasis for a purpose, a beginning.

title: Children Make Older Parents Happy
description: Not EVERY study concludes that parents are miserable.

title: Mayor Awards Prizes in Next Idea Competition
description: Ideas that could help heart doctors monitor their patients and lonely hearts determine if suitors have doctored their pictures were the winners in New York Citys second annual competition for business plans developed by students in other countries.

title: Spoiler Alert: It Hits an Iceberg
description: THERE are two kinds of spoilers at the movies: The kind where someone gives away the plot point upon which the entire moviegoing experience rests, that ruins the movie before its even begun, that makes you say I might as well stay home. And the type where someone tells you the ship sinks in Titanic. One can never be too careful. After all, its been at least a decade since The Sixth Sense (1999), The Crying Game (1992) or The Others (2001) were first released, yet each contains a payoff that friends still wont reveal to friends, lest the experience be ruined. Such indiscretions can have lifelong effects.

title: Sixty Chefs in the Palace, and Still Just Average
Harlem Armory, 10:27 A.M.
description: Danny Ryan, 5, embraced his father, Sgt. John Ryan, as the New York Army National Guards 442nd Military Police Company returned from nine months in Iraq.

title: Mean Streets and Nasty Spies
description: Taxi Driver

title: Federal Judge to Take On New Role
description: For just over four years Raymond J. Dearie has made decisions, issued rulings and handed down sentences as the chief judge for the federal court in the Eastern District of New York, which includes Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island and is one of the busier districts in the country.

title: What a Government Shutdown Means for Travelers
description: As the deadline nears for Congressional leaders to reach an agreement on the federal budget, travelers should prepare themselves for possible closures and cancellations in the event of a government shutdown.

title: Chic in Review | Au Revoir, Christophe Decarnin
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Sentence of the Week: The Pale King Edition
description: This edition of Shamblandersons Sentence of the Week comes front-loaded with a giant chunk of David Foster Wallace. (Not to get into a big publishing-industry back story that nobody cares about, but this is because I was forbidden to tweet sentences from The Pale King, D.F.W.s unfinished novel, as I read them, because of a nondisclosure agreement the publisher forced all reviewers to sign. Which later turned out to be a specious pseudo-embargo that enraged booksellers across America. So I had to wait and tweet them all at once.)

title: Red Sox Rough Up Hughes For First Win
description: BOSTON  To get an idea of what Phil Hughes has felt like in his two starts this season, imagine pointing a gun at a target. Pull the trigger, and then a cartoon flag that says Bang! shoots out. On Friday afternoon at Fenway Park, Hughes essentially came unarmed to a duel. His diminished fastball and erratic control were no match for the Red Sox, who knocked him out after two innings, scoring six runs en route to a 9-6 victory against the Yankees.

title: Matzo Brei Teams Up With Lox and Eggs
description: OF all the recipes in the Passover canon, one of the simplest is matzo brei. Soak matzos in egg and maybe a little milk or water until softened, fry in butter or oil. Top with powdered sugar or maple syrup if you like the sweet side of things, or salt and pepper if you have more savory hankerings.

title: Los Angeles, Perhaps, but Brooklyn Is Forever
description: TV ON THE RADIO has made no secret of its catholic taste. Since 2001 this Brooklyn band  Tunde Adebimpe, Dave Sitek, Kyp Malone, Jaleel Bunton and Gerard Smith  has made ambitious rock with shades of post-punk, electronica and psychedelic jazz, and lyrics about global politics, love and language. The group made its latest album, Nine Types of Light (out Tuesday on Interscope), in Los Angeles, where Mr. Sitek now lives, its first recording outside New York; on Wednesday, the band will make its debut as headliner at Radio City Music Hall. But its members have not given up the indie ethos of the Brooklyn community that nurtured them. The band has already made videos for each song on the album, to be released both individually and edited into a film. We as a band always have so many ideas for things that arent just musical, Mr. Adebimpe said. And for less than the price of a Maroon 5 video you can make a full-length feature.

title: A Heroic Fantasy for Skeptics
description: BEFORE he published A Game of Thrones, the first in his series of best-selling novels set on the mythical continent of Westeros, George R. R. Martin spent about a decade in an all-too-real place called Hollywood. For five years he happily wrote for television series with supernatural themes, like The Twilight Zone and Beauty and the Beast; and for five more he toiled discontentedly on television pilots and movie scripts that never made it, usually because an executive or producer decided they were too ambitious.

title: This Sundays Magazine: A Note from the Editor
description: As a new weekend ritual here on The 6th Floor, Im going to post an editors letter about the issue of the magazine that arrives with your Sunday newspaper. Itll be something like the editors letters that other magazines publish, except less formal and, because of the surprisingly strong views of my staff, with no pictures of me. Im just going to give you a sense of what went into making the magazine and leave it at that. Youll have to imagine how I look in an expensive suit.

title: Norwegian Pianist Takes a Deeper Dip Into Beethoven
description: Most pianists make the Beethoven piano sonatas staples of their repertories. Even pianists of a Romantic bent for whom Beethoven is not a specialty usually play some of these touchstone works.

title: A Little Kick From the Middle East: Folk Spices the Jazz
description: The Israeli pianist Omer Klein works in a modern-jazz mode, brisk and borderless, and yet his music vibrates with cultural specificity, projecting a sense of place. Hes among the current bumper crop of adaptable transplants from Israel to New York, like the saxophonist Eli Degibri, the multireedist Anat Cohen and her brother Avishai Cohen, a trumpeter. Unlike some of these peers Mr. Klein uses Middle Eastern folk elements as a patently important part of his platform, maybe the most important part.

title: Limits to Disaster Memory, Even Etched in Stone
description: I encourage you to read Tsunami-hit towns forgot warnings from ancestors, a haunting and fascinating Associated Press story by Jay Alabaster describing centuries-old stone tablets warning of coastal tsunami risk that dot the Japanese coast ravaged by the great earthquake and resulting waves on March 11th.

title: Childrens Bookshelf: The Environment
description: Reviews of new childrens books with green themes.

title: O! Poetry
description: To the Editor:

title: League and Players Discuss Mediation Options With Judge
description: Lawyers for the N.F.L. and players held a conference call with Judge Susan Richard Nelson on Friday to discuss options for holding mediated negotiations.

description: To the Editor:

title: Great Soul
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Bonds Jury Ends Deliberations for the Day
description: 7:15 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO  After deliberating for about six hours, the jurors in Barry Bondss perjury trial left the courthouse for the day, headed for a weekend off and a tough week ahead.

title: Houston Oil Lobbyists Paid for Former Congressmans Libya Mission
description: A private diplomatic mission to Libya by a former U.S. congressman, who wanted to meet Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and convince him to step aside, was paid for by two Houston businessmen whose firm brokers oil and gas deals in unstable countries.

title: At the World Youth Congress, Lifelong Lessons for Players
description: What should be done to encourage more youngsters to play bridge?

title: 2011 Masters Replay: Round 2
description: A view of the second round of the Masters, where Rory McIlroy ascended to the top of the leader board.

title: A Tax Refund in 28 Days, Not the Feared 145
description: Tim Ryan says hes not sure exactly how it happened, but hes not complaining: When he checked his bank account on Friday, it indicated a deposit of $1,009  from the Internal Revenue Service. His tax refund had arrived, much sooner than he had expected. It must be an Easter miracle, he said in an e-mail.

title: Playlist: TV on the Radio
description: Brooklyn-based band "TV on the Radio" made a music video for each of the ten tracks on its new album, and is stitching them together for release as a feature film.

title: Conservatives Urge Boehner to Cut a Budget Deal and Move On
description: Are Republicans ready to declare victory in the shutdown showdown and move on?

title: Fighting Teenage Pregnancy With MTV Stars as Exhibit A
description: DURING the impatient weeks between episodes of MTVs Teen Mom franchise, fans (nearly three million on Facebook alone) can still stay current with the girls dramas.

title: TV on the Radio Makes a Film
description: D.I.Y. culture is hard to shake, or at least it is for TV on the Radio, the critically-beloved Brooklyn art rock band. As a companion to its fourth studio album, Nine Types of Light (out Tuesday from Interscope), the group created a feature-length movie, built from videos for each of the albums tracks. We as a band always have so many ideas for things that arent just musical, Tunde Adebimpe, one of the bands vocalists, said in an interview. And for less than the price of a Maroon 5 video, you can make a full-length feature.

title: How Does Tina Fey Juggle It All?
description: In her new (and very funny) book Bossypants, Tina Fey declares that the rudest question you can ask a woman is How do you juggle it all? When I first read that (in a pre-publication date excerpt of the book in the New Yorker) I disagreed. I really WANTED to know how Fey does all her juggling.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 8
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Xanadu, the stalled New Jersey Meadowlands mall project; the continuing hunt for the body of Shannan Gilbert; and the the funeral of Louis Dewayne Mosely, 18 months, who the authorities say was beaten to death while in foster care.

title: My Climate-Control Issues
description: Lake Bell, 32, the actress known for roles in How to Make It in America, Boston Legal and Childrens Hospital, is at work directing her first feature film, In a World, which she also wrote. A native Upper East Sider, the actress this month introduces the Lake satchel, a design collaboration with Botkier, proceeds from which will benefit Oxfam.

title: A Libyan Rebel in Need of a Lift
description: If ever there was an indicator of a rebel force in disarray, it was this: a lone Libyan rebel in uniform on the highway leading away from the battlefield, unarmed, almost dazed, separated from his unit, trying to hitch a ride.

title: An Everyman's Golf Pro, at Bronx Course
description: Yes, you can teach a New Yorker something. Paul Sliva, the longtime golf pro at Van Cortlandt Golf Course in the Bronx, has a way of making a complicated game seem simple.

title: Government Shutdowns and Approval Ratings
description: As the odds of a government shutdown increase, its probably worth reflecting quickly on the last time this happened, which was in 1995 and 1996. There were actually two shutdowns that year  a brief one from Nov. 14 through Nov. 19, 1995, and a longer one from from Dec. 16 through Jan. 6, 1996.

title: Automakers Adjust Production to Quake-Related Shortages
description: The global auto industry, hindered by a shortage of parts from key factories in Japan after last months earthquake and tsunami, is still struggling to maintain steady production.

title: Bloggingheads: The End of Medicare?
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate Paul Ryan's plans for Medicare.

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

description: Introduction

description: On his recent return to the United States for a friendly against Argentina, Jozy Altidore was asked how he was doing with a new language, Turkish.

title: Syrian Activists Distribute Video of Protests
description: Updated | 7:46 p.m. As my colleagues Liam Stack and David Goodman report, Gunfire erupted after prayers in the southern city of Daraa on Friday as security forces across Syria moved to counter a third week of protests against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Unspeakable Truth, Unspoken
description: Language is both a source of artillery and the substance of impenetrable defenses in the remarkable play Born Bad by the British writer Debbie Tucker Green at Soho Rep. Running just an hour, this intense, stylized drama about poisonous family secrets hits you like a triple shot of espresso. You leave feeling slightly shaken: excited by the plays formal invention, moved by its coiled emotional power.

title: Energy of Innovation (The TV Show)
description: Its not American Idol, by any means, but I was invited to sit on a panel helping a Washington, D.C., audience weigh the attributes and faults of seven finalists in a nationwide search for talented innovators pursuing energy breakthroughs. The result is Planet Forward: Energy Innovation, a one-hour special being shown on many PBS stations around the country tonight at 9:30. Heres a snippet:

title: A Bachelor, Five Couples and All Their Tuneful Discontents
description: Bobby baby, Bobby baby, Bobby baby: that nagging refrain is the musical default position of the 1970 Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical Company, which had the first of four staged concert performances at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening.

title: A Limited Lens on Ivory Coast
description: Jane Hahn, 32, has been covering the conflict in Ivory Coast since March 31. Ms. Hahn, a freelance photographer, is based in Accra, Ghana. She spoke to Kerri MacDonald late Friday afternoon from Abidjan, where she is staying at a Jordanian United Nations peacekeeping camp.

title: The Countdown Clocks Became Part of the Story
description: How much time did Congress have to avert a government shutdown on Friday? The news media kept track  down to the second.

title: Where Eagles Dare, and Other Workscapes
description: Its time once again for some How the heck did they film that? TV. Only this installment also carries a nagging Why are people still living like that? undercurrent.

description: Todays opera stars are under physical and aesthetic demands that have them clocking more time at the gym  or in a yoga studio, or on a staircase.

description: David Tyree may be an alumnus of Syracuse, but on Saturday afternoon, he will be donning the red and black of Rutgers.

title: Editor Silenced, With the Help of Unreliable Sources
description: MANAMA, Bahrain

title: Peter G. Petersons Last Anti-Debt Crusade
description: A FEW days ago, as beleaguered Democrats, disunited Republicans and noisy Tea Party scolds  which is to say, Official Washington  engaged in a quarrelsome debate over whether to shut down the federal government, Peter G. Peterson, the longtime fiscal hawk, was in his office in New York, polishing a speech for the 268th anniversary of Thomas Jeffersons birth.

title: Unearthing a Celluloid Artifact of the 60s
description: In the 1960s, the Pop artist Wynn Chamberlain often toyed with making a movie and spent time visiting various avant-garde filmmakers on their sets. In 1963 he bought 10 rolls of 16-millimeter film, only to come across Andy Warhol using them, on a visit to Mr. Chamberlains country house, to shoot the poet John Giorno sleeping for the early anti-film Sleep.

title: In a Survey of Bosses, Good News for Job Seekers
description: AMERICAN companies say they plan to hire. If they do as they say, the unemployment picture will brighten considerably.

title: States' Scramble for an Execution Ingredient
description: Internal documents show state officials frenzied efforts to secure sodium thiopental after the sole domestic supplier stopped making it.

title: Three More Kenyan Officials Face International Charges
description: PARIS  Kenyas deputy prime minister, Uhuru Kenyatta, and two others appeared Friday before the International Criminal Court in The Hague on charges of crimes against humanity, including orchestrating murder, persecution and rape, linked to Kenyas disputed election in 2007 and its bloody aftermath.

title: New Hurdles for Women Seeking Abortions
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Major Deegan, the Everyman Golf Pro
description: PAUL SLIVA, the ponytailed pro at Van Cortlandt Golf Course in the Bronx, was leaning against the clubhouse bar last week wearing rumpled rain pants, and wraparound sunglasses perched on his sun visor.

title: No Breakfast, but Bagels for Lunch
description: The founder and chief executive of Teach for America, Wendy Kopp, 43, is also the author, most recently, of A Chance to Make History: What Works and What Doesnt in Providing an Excellent Education for All, written with Steven Farr (PublicAffairs, 2011). She is half of an education power couple: Her husband, Richard Barth, 44, is president and chief executive of the KIPP Foundation. They live on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with their four children: Benjamin, 11; Francis, 9; Haddon, 7; and Georgina, 3. How does she do it all? Heres a clue: Sleeping in means rising at 6. ELISSA GOOTMAN

title: A First Look at the McLaren MP4-12C
description: Maybe you didnt know that one of the wonders of the modern world is situated in England, a 9 train ride from Waterloo Station in London.

title: Tens of Thousands Protest in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  More than 100,000 people converged on Yemens capital for a second Friday of dueling demonstrations over the fate of President Ali Abdullah Saleh, who faces a rising tide of international sentiment in favor of his departure.

title: Real Estate Debacle as Window Into Past
description: WHEN life hands you lemons, the old saw goes, make lemonade. Katharine Greider has gone the saying one better, providing refreshment and nourishment without any sour aftertaste. After she and her family were suddenly forced to abandon their apartment in Alphabet City a decade ago, she transformed her personal real estate debacle into an adventure in urban anthropology. The result:  The Archaeology of Home: An Epic Set on a Thousand Square Feet of the Lower East Side (PublicAffairs, $26.99).

title: Opening With Hope, Ending With a Loss
description: The Mets came home to Citi Field on Friday to play in front of a crowd that bore the hope and optimism that are always permissible at this point of the season, even for skeptical fans who have grown increasingly cynical over the past two years.

title: Music in Review
description: ORCHESTRA OF ST. LUKES

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: NETTIE MAYERSOHN had served in the State Assembly in Albany for 28 years, and for most of it, she sat in the same chair in the Assembly chambers: in the front, to the right of the speaker, in a cluster of Republicans, as it happened, even though she was a Democrat.

title: City May Play Role in Labor Fight Between Crane Workers and Developers
description: The men who operate and maintain cranes and other heavy equipment are the royalty of the construction industry, with some earning well over $200,000 a year in jobs often passed down from fathers to sons.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Whose Light Is It, Anyway?

title: U.S. to Keep 3 Brigades in Europe
description: President Obama has revised a Bush administration plan from 2004 that would have halved the number of Army combat units deployed in Europe, and will instead retain three of the four brigades. Stationing three brigade combat teams in Europe beyond 2015 will allow the American military to maintain a flexible and rapidly deployable ground force in support of NATO, as well as to meet a broad range of 21st century challenges, the Pentagon said Friday in a statement. A brigade traditionally has 3,000 to 5,000 soldiers.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Georgia: Shootout in Abkhazia
description: A Russian border guard and two Georgians were killed in a shootout in Abkhazia, a breakaway Georgian territory, Russias Federal Security Service said Friday. Russian border guards were inspecting an abandoned house when they were attacked, a spokesman told the Interfax news service. The security service said the two Georgians had been identified as officers from the Georgian Interior Ministry. A spokesman for Georgias Interior Ministry denied that, saying one of the Georgians had been wanted by the police and the other was an area resident. Russian guards began patrolling the boundaries of Abkhazia and South Ossetia, a second enclave, after the 2008 war between Georgia and Russia over the territories.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Walk-On Goalie Is on Brink of Title
description: ST. PAUL  The Michigan mens hockey players like to kick a soccer ball around their dressing room, as they did Friday morning after their last practice before Saturdays N.C.A.A. Frozen Four championship game. The ball ricocheted off the legs of reporters who were interviewing the standout goalie Shawn Hunwick at his locker. That was O.K. with him.

title: Why Is This Man Smiling?
description: HENDERSON, Nev.

title: Calculating the Pay Figures
description: To measure the amounts that executives were paid last year, Sunday Business asked Equilar, an executive compensation data company, to compile and analyze pay data from corporate filings.

title: Other Retailers Find Ex-Blockbuster Stores Just Right
description: More than 6,000 Blockbuster locations have closed in the last few years, leaving dark stores at many a shopping center and intersection.

title: S.E.C. to Study Easing Rules on Shares of Private Companies
description: WASHINGTON  The chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered a staff review of the regulations that guide how small companies raise money from investors, as it considers relaxing the rules.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Japan Cargo Is Screened at U.S. Ports
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Radiation detectors originally intended to thwart terrorists smuggling nuclear bombs into the country have been put to another use at this sprawling port across the bay from San Francisco.

title: A Passport to a Parallel Experience
description: FOR Passport, a new theatrical work by Robert Whitman that will be staged April 16 and 17 at Montclair State University and on the banks of the Hudson River in Beacon, N.Y., the artist relied heavily on technical guys, he said.

title: A Pregnant Surrogate, and a Split Decision
description: A lonely soul in her middle 30s, Faith, the central figure of How to Pray, has become pregnant as a surrogate for her brother and his wife.

title: Justice by Day, Folk Songs by Night
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Lack of Data Heightens Japans Nuclear Crisis
description: TOKYO  Nearly one month after Japans devastating nuclear accident, atomic energy experts, regulators and politicians around the world are still puzzling over a basic question: How much danger is still posed by the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant?

title: Allies of Zimbabwes President Push for Quick Vote
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  As Zimbabwe hurtles into another violent political season, President Robert Mugabes party is fiercely pushing for a quick election this year because of fears that the presidents health and vigor are rapidly ebbing, senior party officials said.

title: Snookinomics: Profits From a Tan
description: THIS week, media outlets everywhere mocked Rutgers for paying Nicole (Snooki) Polizzi $32,000 to talk about drinking and tanning on March 31. That was $2,000 more than what the Nobel laureate Toni Morrison will receive for the schools commencement speech next month.

title: Woods Fights Way Onto Leader Board of Next-Generation Names
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  The second round of the Masters on Friday might have begun as another chapter in Rory McIlroys American coming-out party, but it closed with an event more familiar to the Augusta National grounds as Tiger Woods made another sudden and memorable charge up the leader board.

title: Doctors Who Work Long Hours, and Those Who Dont
description: To the Editor:

title: A Mall in New Jersey
description: To the Editor:

title: Shake-Up Could Affect Tone of U.S. Policy on China
description: WASHINGTON  With tensions rising over Chinas crackdown on dissent, the Obama administration is about to lose three of its most prominent players on China policy  a shake-up that could reinforce its efforts to cultivate other Asian countries to counterbalance an increasingly assertive Beijing.

title: Serial Killer in L.I. Case Is Seen as Versed in Police Techniques
