description: Whoever killed four prostitutes, and possibly four other people, and then dumped their bodies in heavy underbrush along a beachfront causeway on Long Island appears to have a sophisticated understanding of police investigative techniques, according to people briefed on the case.

title: Out of Cameras View, Ad-Libs to Augustas Rituals
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Every year in early April, people tune in to the Masters for a dose of familiarity. The golf course is instantly recognizable. The color of the fairways and the flora always seem the same. The greens, and their unique features, are like old friends. From the plantation-style clubhouse to the famed stone bridges, golf fans feel they know Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Russians Riled by Attacks on Blogging Service
description: MOSCOW  For a few hours this week, the cacophonous discourse that typically reverberates through the Russian Internet went silent when cyberattacks crippled the countrys top blogging service, Livejournal.ru.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 8, 2011

title: Mediated Talks Between N.F.L. and Its Players Discussed
description: Lawyers for the N.F.L. and its players held a conference call with Judge Susan Richard Nelson on Friday to discuss options for holding mediated negotiations.

title: Giving a Haggadah a Makeover
description: Why is this Haggadah different this Passover from all other Passovers?

title: Rights Abuses Extend Across Middle East, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Dire abuses of political and social rights that fueled popular uprisings in the Arab world and a war in Libya are continuing and have in some cases worsened in countries important to American security, including Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Yemen and Pakistan, the State Department said on Friday in its annual report on human rights.

title: Abortion Opponents Use Health Law to Put Restrictions in Private Insurance
description: WASHINGTON  As more states begin setting up health care exchanges for individuals to buy insurance under the new health care law, abortion opponents are using the opportunity to try to restrict abortion coverage in private insurance plans.

title: In Helping Others, Finding What Was Never Truly Lost
description: After she had unpacked, and her toothbrush was on the sink, the woman realized something was missing. She turned to John Sullivan, the tall, smiling social worker who had discovered her on a bench in the Broadway median. The woman was a nurse who had lost her grip and had been living in a tent on the Upper West Side, until Mr. Sullivan coaxed her off the street. She was delighted to be in an apartment of her own.

title: On the Street | The Renewal of Fashion
description: The parks glow with cascades of forsythia and fields of daffodils, and fashion is at last stepping out of its winter cocoon.

title: Before Deal, Angst Over Effects of Shutdown
description: PHOENIX  Even in the remote reaches of northern Arizona, where the grandeur of nature can make human beings seem small and insignificant, the fear about a possible shutdown before a budget deal was announced late Friday was wreaking havoc amid the surging water and rustling spruce trees at the Grand Canyon.

title: With Friends Like These
description: Lucretia Mott, the Philadelphia Quaker famous for her work in the abolition and womens rights movements, never met Abraham Lincoln. But Mott and many of her faith thought they knew him well enough to be wary: though the South was up in arms over his antislavery statements, he was nowhere near radical enough for Motts small but influential religious community. Indeed, by March 1861, the views of Mott and other Quakers provide a trustworthy indicator of how Northern radicals saw the possibility of sectional conflict on the eve of the Civil War.

title: In Insider Case, a Long-Cold Trail Got Hot
description: CNBCGarrett Bauer, pictured on CNBC, is charged with insider trading.

title: A Classic Theater Is Renovated and Reimagined
description: SIBBY HARRISON and Joan McCartney are, at age 82, among the older and wiser habitus of the landmark Picture House in Pelham. So it was with a special knowingness that they lamented the state in which they had, on their most recent visits, found the theater: the sticky floors, the shaky seats, the roof worn so thin that a hard rain drowned out on-screen dialogue.

title: A Conference on War, Inspired by a Dance
description: Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Shovel, Strain, Stack No More in High Water
description: The lowly sandbag has improbably  and seemingly eternally  remained the back-breaking brick of choice for anyone in a hurry to erect makeshift barriers during flood season.

title: Catering Halls Plan for a Hotel Upsets the Neighbors
description: Grand Prospect Hall has long held an affectionate spot in Brooklyns heart, starting in the gaslight era of the 1890s when Brooklyn society ventured out of their elegant Park Slope brownstones to attend operas or other entertainment in the halls gilded auditorium.

title: Education Pick Who Sometimes Cuts Flights Short
description: Choir singing, ballroom dancing and ... skydiving?

title: Eastern Subtlety, Western Minimalism
description: What does it mean, in the 21st century, for a Western artist to borrow heavily from aesthetic traditions of the East? Its a question that hovers around the career retrospective Rebecca Salter: Into the Light of Things at the Yale Center for British Art and the pendant show Rebecca Salter and Japan at the Yale University Art Gallery.

title: Late Clash on Abortion Shows Conservatives Sway
description: WASHINGTON  The emergence of abortion as the last and most contentious of the issues that held up the budget deal reached Friday night highlighted the enduring influence of social conservatives within the Republican Party even at a time when the Tea Party movements focus on fiscal austerity is getting most of the attention.

title: Bidding Frenzy for Tickets to Eat at Next in Chicago
description: Taking equal inspiration from Wrigley Field scalpers and the citys grittiest pawn shops, food- and cash-obsessed Chicagoans have started a vibrant trade in tickets to a new restaurant, with bidding in one case hitting $3,000 for a group of seats overlooking the kitchen.

title: N.C.A.A.s Double Standard
description: I dont know about you, but I had a hard time stomaching the sight of Jim Calhoun holding the championship trophy after Mondays final game of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: Report Says Coast Guard Was Unprepared for Spill
description: NEW ORLEANS  An internal review of the Coast Guards performance during the BP oil spill cleanup last year has concluded that the agency was caught badly unprepared and that the response operation was dogged from the beginning by significant planning failures.

title: Manny Ramirez Retires After Testing Positive
description: Manny Ramirez, one of the greatest hitters in baseball history, retreated into retirement Friday, opting not to serve a 100-game suspension after he tested positive for a performance-enhancing drug for the third time in his career.

title: The World This Week
description: This week: colonialism revisited, NATO's Libya problem and continuing violence in Syria.

title: In City School System, Hopes That New Leader Can Steer Right Course
description: At dozens of struggling schools, New York City education officials have yet to apply for federal money that could help turn them around. Some principals are complaining about reorganizations that have left them without sufficient guidance. Charter school leaders are upset about fights sparked by where the city is placing them. A new teacher evaluation system, long discussed, is mired in negotiations with the teachers union, and its point person has just resigned.

title: Saturday: What a Crystal Ball Gazer Sees
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  The nice thing about Saturday puzzles is that, despite their difficulty level, they tend to give us some of the best cluing of the week. Its not always the most clever; its not always the most punny. But it definitely goes off in a much different mental direction than, say a Wednesday puzzle. Thats what we have here.

title: Loopy and Profound, Show Tells the Drama of Missionaries Work
description: Midway through the first act of The Book of Mormon, the acclaimed new Broadway musical, a warlord swaggers into a Ugandan village. Bedecked in ammo belts, brandishing an assault rifle, he demands surrender and announces his intent to sexually mutilate all the local women.

title: On Incoming Chancellors First Day, a Hot Seat Before the City Council
description: Dennis M. Walcott started his first full day as the citys chancellor-appointee walking his grandson into Public School 36 in St. Albans, Queens. Less than two hours later, he was greeted with hugs and congratulations when he appeared at a City Council budget hearing.

title: Donald Trump Strikes Back
description: Donald Trump has written a letter complaining about me.

title: Black Admits Being Ill Prepared
description: A day after her surprise ouster as New York Citys top education official, Cathleen P. Black acknowledged that she was ill-prepared for the demands and visibility of running the nations largest public school system.

title: Rubiks Cube of Re-elections
description: So, The One wants a Round Two.

title: In Yemen, Hardly a Revolution
description: Leipzig, Germany

title: Faithful Congregation Shows Signs of Optimism, if You Can Call It That
description: The Mets have given their fans little cause for optimism in recent years, with two late-season collapses followed by two sub-.500 finishes, and no major additions to the 2011 roster.

title: At State Senate Meeting on Threats to City, a Tense Debate Over Islamic Terror
description: At first glance, a hearing convened in Manhattan by a State Senate committee on Friday seemed as solemn an undertaking as any. As the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks approaches, lawmakers pledged to study how vulnerable the New York City area remained to another act of terror.

title: Three Men in a Room
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo has vowed to push the Legislature to adopt real ethics reform. Albany desperately needs tougher rules to end the pay-to-play culture and deep-rooted corruption. But we would feel a lot better if his negotiations werent going on behind closed doors.

title: Mass Graves Raise Concerns About Brazen Gangs Kidnapping Mexican Migrants
description: MEXICO CITY  They were young men, traveling by bus to work in the fields and factories of northeastern Mexico, or perhaps hoping to get across the border to a job in the United States. Somewhere along the way, they vanished.

title: How Much of a Threat?
description: Thousands of Japanese citizens are dead or missing after last months devastating earthquake and tsunami, hundreds of thousands have lost their homes and Japans government and power company are still struggling to control three badly damaged nuclear power reactors.

title: Cue the Obama Money Bundlers
description: President Obamas campaign machine is telling its chief money raisers to go all out in the big-dollar political art called bundling. The goal is to enlist 400 or more bundlers  specialists in packaging contributions from deep-pocketed supporters  to pledge to raise $700,000 each for the 2012 campaign.

title: The Vocal Stylings of New York City Transit
description: New York City is a very up close and personal sort of place. But weve been struck recently by the number of automated voices we hear. Commuters, in particular, travel to the backdrop of those voices. The accents often sound homegrown. But there is often something just slightly, deliciously off.

title: 7,000 Private School Applicants Got Incorrect Scores, Company Says
description: More than 7,000 students were incorrectly graded on the standardized test required for admission to most New York City private schools, the test company confirmed on Friday.

title: Red Sox Set Bad News Aside at Home
description: BOSTON

title: Rout Helps Heal the Ailing Knicks
description: NEWARK  Amare Stoudemire watched, Carmelo Anthony shot and smiled for a while before joining him, and the Knicks season-ending goals of healing and competing mixed together in a satisfying 116-93 rout of the Nets on Friday.

title: Tweaks Aside, Rangers Can Only Wait and See
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  For the second straight year, it will come down to Game 82 for the Rangers. To make the playoffs, they will almost certainly have to win their season finale against their perennial rivals the Devils on Saturday afternoon at Madison Square Garden.

title: New York Subpoenas 2 Foreclosure-Related Firms
description: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, has issued subpoenas to the states largest foreclosure law firm and a related company, indicating that his office has some doubts about the effort by state attorneys general to resolve questionable foreclosure practices among the nations top banks.

title: Baggage, New and Old, Arrives at Citi Field
description: The Mets first home opener took place on April 13, 1962. It was a Friday, but Mets fans already know that.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In San Francisco, Giants Celebration Is Undimmed by Bondss Trial
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The Phillip Burton Federal Courthouse is an imposing edifice, built in the 1950s of concrete and glass and looking every bit a relic from its era.

title: Bosko Radonjic, Gambino Family Ally, Dies at 67
description: Bosko Radonjic, a Serbian nationalist migr who participated in the bombing of a Yugoslavian diplomats home in suburban Chicago in 1975 and who later became an associate of the Gambino crime family boss John Gotti, died on March 31 in Belgrade, Serbia. He was 67.

title: The Battle for Libya | April 8, 2011
description: Libyan rebels struggled to maintain their presence in Ajdabiya on Friday as Qaddafi government forces launched artillery barrages against the citys western gate.

title: HSBC Told to Disclose Records of Possible Tax Cheats
description: A federal judge has approved a government request for permission to force HSBC, one of the worlds largest banks, to turn over the names of scores of Indian-American clients suspected of tax evasion through the banks operations in India. The approval, by Judge Phyllis J. Hamilton of Federal District Court in Oakland, Calif., became public on Friday and mirrored the speed with which a similar request regarding the Swiss bank giant UBS was approved, by a different judge, in 2008. That request was later dropped when UBS disclosed 4,450 American client names, a watershed in Swiss bank secrecy. Investigators suspect that HSBC, which is based in London solicited Indian-American clients through representatives offices in New York and Fremont, Calif.

title: L. J. Davis, Journalist and Novelist, Is Dead at 70
description: L. J. Davis, a journalist and novelist who wrote about money and business, real estate and home renovation, the Industrial Revolution and his beloved Brooklyn, often with wry or sardonic humor, was found dead in his Brooklyn home on Wednesday. He was 70.

title: The College Decision From The Professors Perspective
description: As the next class of college freshmen weigh their choices, I asked Lynn F. Jacobs and Jeremy S. Hyman, authors of The Secrets of College Success, to compile some tips for readers of The Choice. What follows are excerpts. Jacques Steinberg

title: Serious
description: Im in an airport lounge, for my sins, and theres no avoiding the TV running CNN. And theres David Gergen, telling me that the Ryan plan, whatever its flaws, is serious. So I guess thats the Very Serious People line.

title: Violence Rises as Israel and Hamas Trade Blows
description: GAZA  A surge in fighting between Israel and Hamas continued for a third day on Saturday, with Israeli aircraft and artillery killing three more militants, including a senior commander. At least 18 people have been killed since Thursday, Palestinian officials said.

title: Vettel Finds the Speed When He Needs it, and Scores Pole
description: As Sebastian Vettel said himself, he managed to find the speed he needed at just the right moment: As the last contender across the line in his last lap in qualifying for the Malaysian Grand Prix. Thats when the Red Bull driver snapped the pole position out of the grasp of Lewis Hamilton, of McLaren Mercedes.

title: Vettel Finds the Speed When He Needs it, and Scores Pole
description: As Sebastian Vettel said himself, he managed to find the speed he needed at just the right moment: As the last contender across the line in his last lap in qualifying for the Malaysian Grand Prix. Thats when the Red Bull driver snapped the pole position out of the grasp of Lewis Hamilton, of McLaren Mercedes.

title: Urban Forager | Irish Moss, on Our Shores but Vanishing
description: A friend and I recently took a stroll along the rocky shoreline of Pelham Bay Park, where, among the treasures of low tide, we noted bulging clam beds, oyster shells and an effusive crop of bladderwrack seaweed fronds waving from the shallow depths of the Long Island Sound. Near my boots, next to a partially opened bivalve making bubbles in the water, was a reddish-brown tuft of alga about the size of my palm. Flat, cool and smooth to the touch, the seaweed had a distinctly briny odor.

title: Q. and A.: Taking On Climate Skepticism as a Field of Study
description: Andrew J. Hoffman, the Holcim professor of sustainable enterprise at the University of Michigan, has spent the last year or so applying his tools as a social scientist to researching the cultural and social underpinnings of the backlash against climate change science.

title: Reads & Reactions
description: In this edition of Reads & Reactions: Airfare controversies, 2012 disagreements, how-to-rank-reporting disputes and the comment of the half-month from a FiveThirtyEight reader.

title: Adversity Nothing New as W.P.S. Enters Third Season
description: Womens Professional Soccer is set to begin its third season on Saturday when the Atlanta Beat host the Boston Breakers. The top-flight womens pro league emerges from a turbulent off-season leaner and battle-worn, but ready to play on.

title: Obama, Searching for a Vision
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama emerged from spending talks last Thursday night, he went before cameras to insist that an agreement was needed to avoid a government shutdown that he warned would damage the country. What he did not do was make a public case for what should be in the agreement itself.

title: Some Democrats Complain About Budget Compromise
description: 1:59 p.m. | Updated  President Obama hailed the late-night budget deal that averted a government shutdown on Friday as good news for the American people, but members of his own party seemed less convinced.

title: Enriching a Few at the Expense of Many
description: SOME people say it doesnt really matter how much companies pay their executives, at least as far as the shareholders are concerned. Whether investors prosper depends on the executives management skill, not on penny-ante items like pay, this argument goes.

title: The Shutdown That Wasnt
description: I would like to thank John Boehner, Harry Reid and President Obama for vindicating my decision not to write about the budget negotiations this week, on the assumption that the talk of a shutdown was mostly sound and fury, and then when the deadline hit a deal of some sort would be struck. I based that assumption primarily on my reading of the Speaker of the House, who made it abundantly clear  in word, deed, and especially body language  that he wanted the government shut down about as much as Indiana Jones wants to be locked in a room full of cobras. Given that the two sides werent that far apart in the closing days, in Boehner I trusted, and he didnt let me down.

title: The Last Word: Sidney Lumet
description: Sidney Lumet was one of America's most prolific filmmakers. Here he discusses his career, his gritty New York films and his legacy.

title: A Director of Classics, Focused on Conscience
description: Sidney Lumet, a director who preferred the streets of New York to the back lots of Hollywood and whose stories of conscience  12 Angry Men, Serpico, Dog Day Afternoon, The Verdict, Network  became modern American film classics, died Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Your Thoughts on Director Sidney Lumet
description: Sidney Lumet, a director who preferred the streets of New York to the back lots of Hollywood and whose stories of conscience  12 Angry Men, Serpico, Dog Day Afternoon, The Verdict, Network  became modern American film classics, died Saturday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: McIlroy Continues to Set Pace, and Field Struggles to Keep Up
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland moved one step closer to ushering in a new era in golf on Saturday at the Masters, shrugging off the immense pressure of playing with the tournament lead, distancing himself by four strokes from his closest pursuers and closing in on his first major championship.

title: Video Shows Deadly Raid on Cairos Tahrir Square
description: As Reuters reports, thousands of protesters have returned to Cairos Tahrir Square on Saturday, enraged by a deadly predawn raid on demonstrators there by Egypts military.

title: Can You Afford a College Internship?
description: Can You Afford A College Internship?

title: In Libya, an Odd-Couple Alliance
description: WASHINGTON  At home in France, he has long been called Sarko lAmricain. But it took an American president and the threat of a massacre in Libya to give President Nicolas Sarkozy the chance to channel his inner American. With his call for military action against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, his recognition of the rebels and his readiness to arm them, Mr. Sarkozy has looked every inch the swaggering world leader, less a latter-day Charles de Gaulle than a Gallic Ronald Reagan.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: The Weeks Business News in Pictures

title: Attention, Team: Park Your Egos at the Door
description: This interview with  Chauncey C. Mayfield, president and chief executive of MayfieldGentry Realty Advisors, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Picking Stocks to Keep Ahead of Inflation
description: IF investor behavior foreshadows whats in store for the economy several months down the road, inflation could be a bigger threat than government figures now suggest.

title: Its Not Mount Everest. Its My Workload.
description: Q. Over the last couple of years your company has eliminated jobs, and you now have more work than you can handle. How do you ask for help in a way that doesnt make you look inadequate or incompetent?

title: As Qaddafis Troops Move In, a Seesaw Battle for Rebel City
description: AJDABIYA, Libya  Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi pressed a coordinated ground attack on Ajdabiya on Saturday, bringing the front lines of the battle with the Libyan opposition forces back to the doorstep of this strategically vital rebel city.

title: Hard Knocks and High Hopes
description: THE first quarter of 2011 was a tempestuous time for the world and for the financial markets. But for the markets, at least, there has seemed to be relatively little lingering damage.

title: Beaten-Down Munis May Offer Some Bargains
description: BARGAIN hunters have swooped in to strengthen the municipal bond market after a major skid between mid-November and mid-January. But specialists say they think the prospects are still bright for income-seeking investors.

title: Get Rich Quick, but Make Sure Its Legal
description: AS our nations economic blues wear on, many of us are looking for unconventional avenues to achieve the riches so tantalizingly out of reach. Weve read the investment guides and watched the fast-money yammerers on television. But the big score still seems no closer than the prospect of winning the lottery.

title: Demystifying the Fund Universe
description: IT is amazing how little many of us really know about our mutual funds.

title: Tax Savvy: Strategies to Lower Your Bill
description: FEW paper chases can match the marathon that Americans must complete every tax season. Even so, the most financially savvy do not equate filing their returns with crossing a finish line.

title: Real Estate Funds Defy Housings Gravity
description: THE housing market may be facing a prolonged dip in prices, but for real estate mutual funds the problem is very different: prices that have climbed so much that they may not be sustainable.

title: Commodities Success Brings Calls for Caution
description: A PERFECTLY unfortunate combination of circumstances has been underpinning the global commodity markets. High fiscal deficits in the West and accelerating demand in emerging economies have created the sort of inflationary backdrop in which commodities thrive, as have out-of-the-blue events like political instability in the Middle East and in North Africa, snow in the American Plains and a cyclone in Australia.

title: Variety: A Squeamish Acrostic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  If youre like me, you might want to make sure youre securely seated before you do this acrostic. Its not for the faint of heart. And its not because it was difficult. Its the subject matter.

title: College Enrollment Fell Slightly in 2010
description: The share of recent high school graduates enrolled in college by the October after their graduation fell slightly in 2010, according to a new report from the Labor Department.

title: Upon the Points of Our Swords
description: Charleston Harbor, S.C., April 9, 1861

title: Flexing After an Energy Boost
description: OIL and gas stocks helped propel the returns of three of the top-performing mutual funds in the first quarter. Only one of the three  the Fidelity Select Energy Portfolio is, by charter, a dedicated energy investor. The others  the FPA Capital fund and the Metzler/Payden European Emerging Markets fund  have more freedom to roam, but their managers unearthed values in the sector and seized them.

title: At Opposite Ends of Africa, Fear and Confidence in Markets
description: PROTESTERS thronged the streets in capital after capital in the Arab world in the first quarter of 2011. Governments toppled, and NATO planes thundered in the skies above Libya. The upheaval rattled stock markets throughout North Africa and the Middle East and led to a nearly two-month suspension of trading on the Egyptian stock exchange.

title: Stock Pickers Are No Longer the Stars
description: ITS an old Wall Street pitch: Trust us, were experts.

title: Whats in a Lethal Injection Cocktail?
description: THE latest controversy over the always controversial subject of capital punishment: the drugs used to execute people on death row.

title: Some Mets Fans Are Optimistic for 2011
description: The Mets did not give their fans much reason to feel optimistic on Friday after losing their home opener, 6-2, to the Washington Nationals. But fans still expressed some hope that all is not lost for their team in this early 2011 season.As Richard Sandomir wrote:

title: Why So Many Serial Killers on Long Island?
description: Some towns and counties have cancer clusters. Others have high rates of traffic fatalities or foreclosures. In New York, Long Island has been grappling with its own disturbing demographic: Three serial killers who targeted the same type of victims have operated in the same tidy suburbs in the span of 22 years.

title: Dodger Stadium Beating Highlights Fans Unease
description: LOS ANGELES  When fans around the country think of Dodger Stadium, many still picture a gracefully aging park with an easy atmosphere, where fans are known for arriving late and leaving early in hopes of beating the traffic, and where the soundtrack is still provided after all these years by the broadcaster Vin Scully.

title: One Spooky Dude
description: Glenn Beck last week announced his departure from the Fox News Channel  meaning, among other things: goodbye, Spooky Dude. Thats Mr. Becks colorful moniker for his bte noire George Soros, the liberal financier whom the contentious host sees as puppet master of much of the worlds trouble. Here are excerpts from the dozens of times Mr. Beck has so characterized Mr. Soros on Fox.  TOM KUNTZ

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Fighting Words
description: Ai Weiwei, one of Chinas most prominent artists, a co-designer of the Birds Nest Olympic stadium and an outspoken critic of the government, was detained by authorities Sunday as he tried to board a plane for Hong Kong.

title: 2 Protesters Killed in Egypts Tahrir Square
description: CAIRO  Egypts security forces shot and killed at least two protesters and wounded dozens before dawn Saturday in an attempt to disperse peaceful demonstrators spending the night in the capitals iconic Tahrir Square, officials and witnesses said.

title: Again, a Star Is Prosecuted for His Unlikability
description: The trial of Barry Bonds has always been more than a simple case of pursuing a bad guy and proving that he lied. The chase and the subsequent trial have been as much about a baseball era driven by vanity and greed, and fueled by performance-enhancing drugs.

title: To Honor and Serve Is Hurt, and Off the Derby Trail
description: The Kentucky Derby continues to vex the Hall of Fame trainer Bill Mott, whose To Honor and Serve has a strained a suspensory ligament in his left foreleg and is off the Derby trail.

title: Gbagbo Loyalists Regain Ground in Ivory Coast
description: PARIS  As the wily Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbo remained cornered in the basement of the presidential residence in Abidjan on Saturday, his forces retook the offensive in a series of military actions, belying recent predictions of his imminent downfall.

title: Trying to Conquer a Course That Many Greats Could Not
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  It has long been unspoken but axiomatic among those who live in the stratospheric world of the membership rolls of Augusta National Golf Club: people desperate to join never will, regardless of how hard they may try.

title: Republicans and Democrats Alike Claim Successes in Averting a Federal Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  The hard-fought budget compromise late Friday that narrowly averted a government shutdown calls for increasing Pentagon spending while imposing significant cuts on a wide range of domestic federal programs, including some items that are part of the new health care law.

title: Feel Like a Wallflower? Maybe Its Your Facebook Wall
description: ONE recent rainy night, I curled up on my couch with popcorn and Netflix Instant, ready to spend a quiet night at home. The peace was sweet  while it lasted. Soon, my iPhone began flashing with notifications from a handful of social networking sites, each a beacon of information about what my friends were doing.

title: Jobless Rate Is Not the New Normal
description: IT takes a while to match people with jobs, so even in normal times the unemployment rate is never zero. Before the recent recession, in the view of many economists, the lowest sustainable rate of unemployment in the United States  a level known as the normal or natural rate of unemployment  was around 5 percent.

title: Should Catchers Moonlight?
description: A catcher with exceptional offensive talent is a rarity in baseball, and a luxury. But what happens when the luxury becomes a necessity? If a catcher is too productive, a team feels his absence on the days he needs to rest.

title: In Kazakhstan, a Good Old-Fashioned Sham Election
description: ASTANA, Kazakhstan  Even by the standards of the post-Soviet republics, Nursultan A. Nazarbayevs re-election victory was superfabulous.

title: Foreboding in Sacramento as the Kings Wither Away
description: SACRAMENTO  From the moment it took root in the fertile fields north of downtown, the building known as Arco Arena kindled the basketball passions of this sleepy capital city, tantalizing and tormenting its famously rabid N.B.A. fans.

title: President Adopts a Measured Course to Recapture the Middle
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama opened the week by calling on Democrats to embrace his re-election campaign. He closed it by praising Republicans for forging a compromise to cut spending this year and avert a government shutdown.

title: Its Time for Your Face-Lift, Miss Piggy
description: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.

title: The Drought Is Over (at Least for C.E.O.s)
description: HAPPY days are back  in the corner office, at least.

title: If You Cant Name That Star, Try Asking Your Telescope
description: LONGTIME stargazers learned the basics of the night sky the hard way  with pencils, star charts and lots of patience with their telescopes.

title: Better Business Bureau Makes Its Case
description: AS regulars know, the Haggler has written three consecutive columns about the Better Business Bureau. The moral of these unhappy tales is that the organization appears to have drifted from its original mission  policing bad behavior in corporate America  to something decidedly less consumer- friendly.

title: With Logan Struggling, Felicianos Importance Is Highlighted
description: BOSTON  Want to know how much the Yankees could use Pedro Feliciano? Behold the results for Boone Logan, the only left-hander in their bullpen, when he has faced left-handed hitters:

title: Stockroom to Boardroom
description: MY entrepreneurial side comes from my father, Stanley Rawn, who was born in Brooklyn and moved to Atlanta to attend Georgia Tech. After arriving, he met a girl named Esther Kuniansky, and they married five years later.

title: The Deadlocked Debate Over Education Reform
description: Few would argue that she was a good choice. But as you watched the almost giddy reception that greeted the departure of the New York City schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, last week  She wasnt in the class for the full semester so it wouldnt be appropriate for me to give her a grade, said Michael Mulgrew, president of the United Federation of Teachers  it was hard not to wonder whether the debate over school reform has reached a point where debate is no longer possible.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Gasps From the Grandstand After the Invoice Arrives
description: Sticker shock keeps getting worse for some sports fans.

title: Japan Orders Nuclear Plant Operators to Obtain More Emergency Generators
description: TOKYO  Radiation readings spiked sharply in one reactor at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant after a powerful aftershock late Thursday, according to data released by the government, a development that might indicate new damage to the already compromised reactor.

title: The Films of Sidney Lumet
description: Sidney Lumet, Director of American Film Classics, Dies at 86

title: In Japan, Pro Soccer Grinds to a Halt
description: SUWON, South Korea  The relationship between the city of Kashima on Japans eastern coast and its J-League soccer team is a close one. The Antlers are the most successful squad in the leagues 18-year history, with seven championships. And Kashimas residents have had plenty of chances to see their team win, with a stadium that can hold 40,000 of the citys 66,000 residents.

title: Celebrating Defeat
description: Ezra Klein gets this right, I think: its one thing for Obama to decide that it was better to give in to Republican hostage-taking than draw a line in the sand; its another for him to celebrate the result. Yet thats just what he did. More than that, he has now completely accepted the Republican frame that spending cuts right now are what America needs.

title: The Womens Health Initiative and the Body Politic
description: In 1898, German doctors fed fresh cow ovaries to a young woman suffering from severe hot flashes after having her ovaries removed. It was a milestone of sorts in womens medicine, leading to crude hormone treatments and eventually commercially prepared drugs to relieve the symptoms of menopause.

title: Landmarks From Two Decades of Study
description: 1991 National Institutes of Health embarks on a study of menopause hormones after observational data suggest that women who use hormones have lower rates of heart disease.

title: All of a Wars Trappings, With Accuracy at Stake
description: FORT SUMTER NATIONAL MONUMENT, S.C.  If the period leading to the outbreak of the Civil War was a confusing patch in American history, the threat of a government shutdown threw the spirited preparations for a commemoration of the Confederate attack on Fort Sumter 150 years later into almost as much chaos.

title: N.H.L. Math Often Equals Points for All
description: Last year the N.H.L. general managers acknowledged that something was wrong about the shootout, the postgame penalty-shot contest it installed in 2005, when it abolished tie results.

title: Seven Are Killed in Shooting t Stores Near Amsterdam
description: PARIS  A gunman went on a deadly rampage among weekend shoppers in a small town in the Netherlands on Saturday, weaving in and out of shops, shooting and killing until he finally turned his automatic weapon on himself, Dutch officials and witnesses said.

title: FreeDarko Goes Dark
description: Started by a group of friends from a fantasy league to write about basketball for fun, FreeDarko ended up becoming the first of what became a long line of irreverent basketball blogs.

title: Pedro Martinez Waiting for That One Last Call for Help
description: If there were a classified section published for athletes, you might see a listing like this:Free-agent pitcher looking for work. Eight-time All-Star, three-time Cy Young Award winner and 2004 World Series champion. Contact Pedro Jaime Martinez at a fishing pier in the Dominican Republic or Miami.

title: Farrakhan Using Libyan Crisis to Bolster His Nation of Islam
description: When Louis Farrakhan, leader of the Chicago-based Nation of Islam, staunchly defended Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi recently, he seized headlines for an organization that has made little news in recent years.

title: Once, It Was Spring, and the Knicks Won a Playoff Game
description: The last time the Knicks made a meaningful playoff appearance, the circus intervened. Not the figurative circus  the Isiah Thomas-Stephon Marbury kind  but an actual circus. Or at least, people practicing for a circus.

title: Taliban Seen Stirring Mob to Violence in Afghanistan
description: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan  While it is still too early to say who were the killers of the seven United Nations employees here last week, senior police officials say they suspect current or former Taliban members or other insurgents of leading the violence, aided by sympathizers and hard-line mullahs who whipped up a crowd of thousands angered by a Koran burning in the United States.

title: Battle for Ajdabiya
description: Government soldiers and rebel gunmen battled in the streets of a strategic city on Saturday after the Libyan military used shelling and guerrilla-style tactics to open its most serious push into opposition territory since international airstrikes began.

title: Forcing the F.A.A. to Fly Blind
description: PASSENGERS fainted when a 5-foot hole opened in the roof of a Southwest Airlines Boeing 737 flying from Phoenix to Sacramento last week. The most frightening moment may have been when, as one passenger said, You could look out and see blue sky.

title: Iraqis Protest U.S. After Comments From Gates
description: BAGHDAD  A day after Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates suggested that American troops could remain here for years, tens of thousands of protesters allied with Moktada al-Sadr, the radical anti-American Shiite cleric, flooded the streets demanding an end to the American military presence.

title: Win, Wait, Then Off to Playoffs for Rangers
description: Chris Drury, Henrik Lundqvist and several other Rangers gathered Saturday night to watch the game between Carolina and Tampa Bay, the Rangers playoff fate hinging on the outcome. If the Hurricanes won, the Rangers would not make the postseason; if the Hurricanes lost, the Rangers would be in.

title: Japanese Workers Braved Radiation for a Temp Job
description: KAZO, Japan  The ground started to buck at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, and Masayuki Ishizawa could scarcely stay on his feet. Helmet in hand, he ran from a workers standby room outside the plants No. 3 reactor, near where he and a group of workers had been doing repair work. He saw a chimney and crane swaying like weeds. Everybody was shouting in a panic, he recalled.

title: A Quick Hello From the Tourist in Chief
description: Just hours after reaching a deal to avert a government shutdown, President Obama paid a brief visit to the Lincoln Memorial on Saturday  presumably to highlight that it, and other national monuments, were open for business.

title: Next on the Agenda for Washington: Fight Over Debt
description: WASHINGTON  The down-to-the-wire partisan struggle over cuts to this years federal budget has intensified concern in Washington, on Wall Street and among economists about the more consequential clash coming over increasing the governments borrowing limit.

title: Ex-Military Officer Jolts Peru Presidential Race
description: BOGOT, Colombia  In a Peruvian presidential campaign field full of wild cards, Ollanta Humala, a nationalist former military officer who led a thwarted army revolt in 2000, has emerged as a strong front-runner and injected fresh uncertainty into the Andean nations political system.

title: Crew Member Kills Officer During Tour f British Sub
description: LONDON  One of Britains mass-circulation tabloid newspapers, The Mirror, had already dubbed the countrys newest nuclear submarine the S.S. Calamity over a series of mishaps since the $2 billion missile-carrying vessel began sea trials early last year.

title: Concessions and Tension, Then a Deal
description: WASHINGTON  At one crucial moment in the game of chicken over a looming shutdown of the United States government, President Obama and the House speaker, John A. Boehner, faced off in the Oval Office. Mr. Boehner, a Republican heavily outnumbered in the room by Democrats, was demanding a provision to restrict financing to Planned Parenthood and other groups that provide abortions. Mr. Obama would not budge.

title: Iraq Blocks U.S. Aid to Camp of Iranian Exiles After Clash
description: The government of Iraq continued on Saturday to block the delivery of American humanitarian aid to Iranian exiles who were wounded in clashes with the Iraqi Army at a camp north of Baghdad, an American military spokesman said.

title: Blowin in the Idiot Wind
description: Bob Dylan may have done the impossible: broken creative new ground in selling out.

title: On Quake History and Climate Warnings
description: After reading about Japans aging, and largely forgotten, stone tablets warning of tsunami risk, a Dot Earth reader, Mesa from Telluride, Colo., posed an important question about the human capacity to act sensibly when facing future risks (some abbreviation expanded):

title: Transient Is Sought in Blast at California Synagogue
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Local and federal law enforcement officers were searching on Saturday for a man thought to be responsible for an explosion outside a synagogue here.

title: A Divided Portugal Is Unwilling to Commit to Bailout Terms
description: LISBON  Portugals political feuding continued to play a role in the nations efforts to seek relief from mounting debt. The caretaker Socialist government dismissed a European Union request that all of the countrys main political parties take part in negotiating the terms of a bailout package.

title: Our Cowardly Congress
description: This isnt government were watching; this is junior high.

title: Our Lovable Government
description: And, yes, thats meant ironically. My Sunday column argues that the latest budget battles have been a supreme example of dysfunction. At the last minute Friday night, the two sides agreed to a budget deal and averted a government shut-down, but this is still a wretched way to run a superpower. And while I particularly blame the Republicans for threatening to shut down the government (a threat that Democrats did not make during the Bush years), its also true that the Democrats are at fault for not passing a budget and spending bills when they should have last year before the fiscal year began, when they controlled both houses in Congress.

title: Seattle Ponders (Some More) the Wisdom of Replacing a Roadway
description: SEATTLE  Here in the capital of the Pacific Northwest, where commercial jets were born but now the mayor brags about biking to work, questions over commerce, climate change and community are converging on a couple of fateful miles of asphalt.

title: For Sheep, a Long Way From Farm to Table
description: FOR many Connecticut families, spring lamb is as much a part of Easter and Passover traditions as matzos and multicolored eggs. And since most varieties of sheep bear lambs in mid- to late winter, there is just enough time to fatten them up for the holiday table.

title: Miss G.: A Case of Internet Addiction
description: There are certain popular diversions  television, video games, the Internet  that we pursue so deliriously we end up hating ourselves for loving them. Others we brightly recast as the duties of citizenship: newspapers, public radio, sports.

title: Banks Are Off the Hook Again
description: Americans know that banks have mistreated borrowers in many ways in foreclosure cases. Among other things, they habitually filed false court documents. There were investigations. Weve been waiting for federal and state regulators to crack down.

title: With Power and Bullpen, Yanks Survive Shaky Start
description: BOSTON  It took two hours to play the first four innings at Fenway Park on Saturday, and in the Yankees bullpen, Dave Robertson could feel the game dragging. He sensed an opportunity.

title: Tax Indictment for Tax Activist
description: DENVER  Taxpayers have rights. It says so in the Colorado Constitution in an amendment known as Tabor, which passed in a voter referendum drive in the early 1990s that was led by a man named Douglas E. Bruce.

title: What to Do About Invasive Species
description: To the Editor:

title: How General Electric Dealt With the Tax Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors and Device Makers
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 Aldermen to Initiate Newcomers
description: Before Mayor-elect Rahm Emanuel and City Council members are sworn in next month, some incumbent aldermen will offer a crash orientation course for the bumper crop of new members.

title: For Kosher Stores, a Holiday Makeover
description: CEDARHURST, N.Y.

title: Women and Unions
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern and Caribbean, Focused on the Seasonal
description: YOU may not enter Alvin & Friends as one of the pals of the owner, Alvin Clayton, but by the time you leave, youre likely to feel that youve become one.

title: Pies for All Seasons
description: Orchards are not just for apple-picking season. Salingers Orchard, Farm Market and Bakery in Brewster is open throughout the year, and the apples there are kept in just-picked condition. Last week Fuji, Golden Delicious, Empire and Mutsu apples were available, each for $22 a half-bushel.

title: Juggling the World, Wearily
description: A DAY in the life of the New York Times foreign desk begins with Laurent Gbagbo holed up in the basement of his fortified residence in the Ivory Coasts main coastal city of Abidjan.

title: One Restaurant; Two Distinct Cuisines
description: DESPITE the rich influence of Italian immigrants on Argentine culture, the two cuisines barely meet up, much less tango, at Valdebenitos Bistro, a 110-seat storefront Argentine-Italian restaurant that opened early last year in Somerville. This is not to say that you cant get a tender and flavorful churrasco with vinegary chimichurri sauce  you can, and we did.

title: Not Just Cheddar
description: Specialty food shops are often the realized visions of entrepreneurial enthusiasts who want to appeal to customers with equally sophisticated palates. Affinage, a cheese store in Fairfield named for the art of aging cheese, is something different.

title: The Coach Is Upbeat, Winning and Fired
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Lessons From Nuremberg
description: London

title: Sometimes a Big-Time Communications Guy Will Actually Communicate
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Sunday: Kin of Fairies
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  What do you stand FOR? More importantly, what do you stand against? And is it stable, because you have to be careful with that sort of thing. Someone could get hurt.

title: Justice Kagan Dissents
description: In the Supreme Courts 5-to-4 ruling about a school-choice program in Arizona, Justice Anthony Kennedys opinion leaves intact a program that has disbursed almost $350 million of state funds, most of it to schools choosing students on the basis of religion.

title: A Four-Way Tie for First, and a Controversial Finish
description: The European Individual Chess Championship has become a magnet for top players, with more than 160 grandmasters participating in this years competition.

title: What Happened to the Investigation?
description: Last summer the House Ethics Committee accused Representative Maxine Waters of bringing discredit on Congress by helping to secure a government bailout for a troubled bank where her husband held stock and had been a director. Ms. Waters, a California Democrat, angrily denied the charge and demanded a public hearing.

title: Billiard Palacade
description: Like to call your own shots? Many Bay Area pool players enjoy games at Billiards Palacade, an Outer Mission hangout and tournament center in the former Rialto movie theater. HANK PELLISSIER

title: The Truth About Charley
description: Bill Steigerwald has made an intriguing, if disheartening, discovery that seems to have eluded admirers and scholars of John Steinbeck for decades. Steinbecks Travels With Charley in Search of America is shot through with dubious anecdotes and impossible encounters.

title: Gaining White Residents, Brentwood Earns a Niche
description: Nine years ago, Barbara Israel sold her home in Union City and moved to Brentwood, on the eastern edge of Contra Costa County.

title: In Space, Nice Guys Finish First
description: Oakland, Calif.

title: Reconfigured Can Maker Invigorates Dogpatch
description: In the Dogpatch neighborhood, along a once-desolate stretch of San Franciscos Third Street, lies what some call a skyscraper on its side. It is the former home of the American Can Company, a manufacturer that once employed thousands in its four-block-long plant overlooking the bay.

title: States of Conflict: An Update
description: LEAVING aside all the new conflicts in the Middle East, how are our nations longstanding struggles in Iraq, Afghanistan and Pakistan going?

title: Chronicle and Building Are Reflection of Economy
description: In December 2009, 10 employees from the technology company Square moved into an empty corner of the San Francisco Chronicle building at Fifth and Mission. The space had been stripped bare, but Square gave it touches of startup chic: rows of Apple computers, a sparkling-water dispenser, chandeliers designed by Jonathan Adler.

title: One Protester Killed as Security Forces Open Fire in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Clashes broke out late Saturday evening between security forces and demonstrators here, killing one protester and wounding 15, doctors said at a field hospital at the site.

title: Replacing a Museum Director Who Was a Rare Find
description: Finding the right new director for the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, will be as big a challenge for the museums board as it will be for the successor of Peter C. Marzio to live up to his outsize legacy.

title: The Prosecution Rests, but I Cant
description: New Orleans

title: Gil Robbins, Folk Singer With the Highwaymen, Dies at 80
description: Gil Robbins, a singer, guitarist and songwriter with the folk group the Highwaymen and a fixture on the folk-music scene, died on Tuesday at his home in Esteban Cant, Mexico. He was 80.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Greg Little, Fourth-Ranked Receiver
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his depraved obsession with film analysis of rookie prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at each position.

title: Ousted From Austin, but Seeking New Role in Houston
description: When Ellen Cohen decided to run for Houston City Council, two months after losing a re-election bid for her State House seat, a friend worried, Isnt that a step down? Ms. Cohens answer? No, its a step closer.

title: Spraying to Make Yards Green ... but With Paint, Not Water
description: PHOENIX  There used to be two kinds of homeowners in this scorching city, those with dazzling green lawns irrigated by sprinklers and those with more natural backyard expanses of rocks, cactuses and desert flora, which required no watering at all.

title: An 18-Month Budget Offers a Way Out
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Community Pushes for University of Houston-Victoria to Join A&M System
description: In January, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching elevated the University of Houston to its top tier of research universities. But, in the ensuing celebration for this hard-to-achieve accolade, some are feeling left out.

title: Brazil Mourns Children Gunned Down at School
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Children cried uncontrollably at funerals here on Friday. A police helicopter dropped rose petals onto the cemetery. Even police officers and journalists were moved to tears as they watched families say goodbye to 12 children shot dead on Thursday morning in a rampage of a kind this country had never experienced.

title: Relief in Boston Proves Fleeting as Worries About Pitching Staff Rise With Its E.R.A.
description: BOSTON  A brief respite from panic and doom expired quickly here. Less than 24 hours after the Boston Red Sox earned their first victory of the season, it was back to losing on Saturday, back to more frustration and confusion in a city thats becoming edgy about its beloved baseball team.

title: Country Could Have 2 Reasons to Brag
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Should Rory McIlroy prevail Sunday and win the Masters, it will not only give players from the PGA European Tour simultaneous possession of all four major championships  a sort of collective version of the Tiger Slam from 2001 to 2002  it will mean the United States Open champion and the Masters champion will both be from Northern Ireland.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Woods Is Steady, but Not the Way He Used to Be
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  With each new hole Saturday, Tiger Woods would walk onto the tee, and the galleries would greet him with an imploring, beseeching roar. They wanted magic. They wanted something special. They wanted an archetypal Tiger Woods moving day charge.

title: Surprise Contender for Kentucky Derby Bursts Out of Pack to Win Wood Memorial
description: Graham Motion is a cautious horse trainer and, like many of them, a superstitious one as well. Not once had he mentioned the Kentucky Derby to the owners of Tobys Corner, Dianne and Julian Cotter. It looked like a wise decision a month ago when the colt finished a well-beaten third in the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: Vows: Joan & Alex
description: Three years of "Sunday Funday" led Joan Snyder and Alex Kuhl to marriage.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 10
description: Having narrowly averted a federal government shutdown on Friday, lawmakers will take to the Sunday talk shows to rehash the compromise that kept Washington in business.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 9, 2011

title: Cloning Redwoods
description: A group of tree enthusiasts are seeking to preserve redwood trees on the West Coast by cloning them.

title: Minnesota-Duluth Overcomes Michigan for Its First N.C.A.A. Title
description: ST. PAUL  To give the Xcel Energy Center, an N.H.L. arena, more of a collegiate feel for the Frozen Four, the N.C.A.A. hung 17 blue, black and white banners from the rafters, representing every program that had won an N.C.A.A. mens hockey championship.

title: Beltrans Homers Lift Mets at Home
description: For the second game in a row, Mets fans clogged the aisles and filed out of Citi Field en masse before the final out.

title: From Ancient Giants, Finding New Life to Help the Planet
description: FORT DICK, Calif.  Shooting skyward like a jagged knife, the giant stump in a cul-de-sac in this Northern California town is by all appearances dead and gone: ashen gray, hollowed by fire and sheared at about 40 feet by coastal winds or lightning.

title: A Countrys Eyes Could Be Smiling
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Should Rory McIlroy prevail Sunday and win the Masters, it will not only give players from the PGA European Tour simultaneous possession of all four major championships  a sort of collective version of the Tiger Slam from 2001-2  it will mean the United States Open Champion and the Masters champion will both be from Northern Ireland.

title: Masters 2011, Round 3: McIlroy Is the One to Beat
description: Rory McIlroy will take a four-stroke lead to the final round of the Masters after shooting a two-under 70 on a sweltering Saturday at Augusta National.

title: Scott Gives Australia Hope at Augusta
description: With a five-under-par 67, the Australian Adam Scott will head into Sundays final round tied for sixth place, the highest he has been on the 54-hole leader board since he first qualified for the Masters in 2002. In that Masters, Scott was 13th after three rounds and finished tied for ninth.

title: Newly Born, and Withdrawing From Painkillers
description: BANGOR, Me.  The mother got the call in the middle of the night: her 3-day-old baby was going through opiate withdrawal in a hospital here and had to start taking methadone, a drug best known for treating heroin addiction, to ease his suffering.

title: Garcia Done In on Back Nine
description: Since 2004, when he tied for fourth, Sergio Garcia has missed three cuts at the Masters and finished no higher than a tie for 38th. With a three-under-par 33 on the first nine holes Saturday, Garcia moved to seven under for the tournament and was threatening to join the final groupings in Sundays fourth round.

title: China Detains Church Members Over Public Praying
description: BEIJING  The police detained dozens of members of an underground Protestant church on Sunday morning, after the congregation tried to pray in a public plaza in the north of the capital.

title: Rebels and NATO Strikes Repel Assault on Key Libyan Town
description: AJDABIYA, Libya  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis military forces appeared to falter in eastern Libya on Sunday on the second day of an assault against the strategic rebel city of Ajdabiya, as opposition fighters aided by NATO airstrikes retook their positions and claimed the checkpoints at the citys approaches.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Randall Cobb, Third-Ranked Receiver
description: Matt Waldman is the author of  The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: London Museum Revisits Lost Collections
description: Since at least the 17th century, London has been a home to a wide range of museums and private collections of medical and natural history artifacts, most of which no longer exist. Through July 2, the Hunterian Museum (35-43 Lincolns Inn Fields; 44-20-7869-6560; www.rcseng.ac.uk/museums) will display remnants of a handful of these lost, forgotten and, in some cases, partially destroyed collections in Londons Lost Museums: Nature and Medicine on Show.

title: Official Defends Japans Response to Disasters, Calling Them Unprecedented
description: TOKYO  A top government official on Sunday defended Japans response to the humanitarian and nuclear crises set off by last months natural disasters, saying the scale of the earthquake and tsunami that killed thousands and damaged a nuclear power station far surpassed what experts had planned for.

title: How to Clean a Lens the Right Way
description: When I solicited photographers for their top tips, I was reminded of how important the fundamentals are to strong shots and how often they go overlooked.

title: Malaysian Grand Prix Entertains as Vettel Wins Again
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  The new Formula One is a like a Rubiks Cube: We know how it should look at the end of the process, but all the fun is in figuring out the multitude of combinations needed to get there.

title: Malaysian Grand Prix Entertains as Vettel Wins Again
description: SEPANG, Malaysia  The new Formula One is a like a Rubiks Cube: We know how it should look at the end of the process, but all the fun is in figuring out the multitude of combinations needed to get there.

title: Gulf Nations Repeat Offer to Mediate Crisis in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  A regional bloc of Persian Gulf countries on Sunday renewed its offer to help mediate the political crisis in Yemen and to ease the transition of power from the embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh.

title: China Detains Worshipers Over Praying in Public
description: BEIJING  The police detained more than 100 members of an underground Protestant church on Sunday after the congregation tried to pray in a public plaza in the north of the capital.

title: A Closed Book
description: Charleston Harbor, S.C., April 10, 1861

title: Obama to Call for Broad Plan to Reduce Debt
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will call this week for Republicans to join him in writing a broad plan to raise revenues and reduce the growth of popular entitlement programs, as the battle over the nations financial troubles moves past Fridays short-term budget deal and into a wider and more consequential debate over the nations long-term fiscal health.

title: Excerpt: 'The Loose Nut'
description: A clip from the Woody Woodpecker animated film, followed by the same clip slowed down to show in greater detail the abstract artwork within. (Courtesy of Universal Studios Licensing)

title: Mubarak Denies Corruption and Defends His Legacy
description: CAIRO  Hosni Mubarak, the Egyptian autocrat forced from power by the throngs in Tahrir Square two months ago, spoke for the first time since then in an audiotape broadcast on Sunday, denying that he and his family had amassed wealth overseas and defending his honor and legacy.

title: NYSE Euronext Rejects Bid by Nasdaq and ICE
description: 8:49 p.m. | Updated

title: A Farm Grows in the Battery
description: This could give the phrase down on the farm new meaning.

title: Two Decades of Comedy Central
description: In the 20 years since Comedy Central began broadcasting, the network has helped launch the careers of a number of comedic talents.

title: Text and Audio of Mubaraks Self-Defense
description: As my colleague Ethan Bronner reports, Hosni Mubarak, Egypts former president, made his first public remarks since being deposed in February, in a recorded address to the Egyptian people broadcast by Al Arabiya, a Saudi-owned satellite network, on Sunday.

title: True to Mission, Comedy Central Still Strong at 20
description: On television, the laughter is coming from every direction.

title: Moving Between Two Worlds, Outsiders in Both
description: When encountering a first novel as self-assured, elegant, and perceptive as The Free World, David Bezmozgiss intimate portrait of the Krasnanskys, a Jewish family from Latvia immigrating to the West in 1978, theres a temptation to say that the author displays a maturity far beyond his years. But Mr. Bezmozgis, who is yet another vaunted member of The New Yorkers 20 Under 40 group, was born in Riga, Latvia, in 1973, which makes him nearly the same age that Philip Roth and Leonard Michaels were when they respectively published Portnoys Complaint and Going Places in 1969. So it might be more accurate to say that Mr. Bezmozgis writes like someone exactly his age but from a previous generation.

title: Schwartzel Charges to Victory at Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Fifty years to the day after Gary Player, the godfather of South African golf, became the first international player to win the Masters, his countryman Charl Schwartzel won the 75th Masters on Sunday, breaking though a chaotic afternoon shootout by birdieing the final four holes at Augusta National Golf Club.

title: Poland and Russia Spar Over Wording of Memorial
description: MOSCOW  Ceremonies on Sunday and Monday in memory of the president of Poland and dozens of the countrys top political and military leaders who died in an airplane crash a year ago are being overshadowed by a dispute between Russia and Poland over the wording of a memorial plaque.

title: A Word From Those Who
description: Ive been reading various news analyses of the Ryan plan, and Im feeling depressed. In the past, Ive complained about false equivalence  of views differ on shape of the planet type reporting. But what Im seeing here is worse: supposedly objective, even-handed reporting that actually prejudges the issue according to current conventional wisdom.

title: Age of Diminished Expectations
description: Im sorry to say it, but I expect the worst from the upcoming presidential speech on deficit reduction. OK, maybe not the worst; I dont think hell call for privatizing Medicare, but who knows? But I do expect a lot of preemptive concessions to the Republicans, which will, as usual, be the starting point for further concessions.

title: Lessons From the Hormone Studies
description: For more than 100 years, women and doctors have been debating the safety and necessity of hormone treatments for women at the end of their reproductive years, as I report in the Week in Review section of Sundays New York Times.

title: An Imbalanced Budget Deal?
description: Theres a pretty broad consensus that Republicans got the better of the budget negotiations that concluded late Friday. Heres David Weigel of Slate making the point. Heres Andrew Stiles of the National Review. And Richard Eskow of the Huffington Post. And Carl Cameron of Fox News. And Ezra Klein of the Washington Post.

title: Grab Your Wolf Suits and Open Your Ears
description: The New York City Opera, struggling to close a $5 million deficit, has postponed its announcement of its next season, which is troubling news for opera buffs and supporters of this essential company.

title: The Bollywood Treatment, for Husbands
description: You cant step into the same river twice, but you can, it seems, watch the same Bollywood movie twice (or three or four times). Thank You, an Anees Bazmee comedy dedicated to the proposition that all men are dogs, hews so closely to tried-and-true formula that it could serve as a kind of template.

title: British and Dutch to Sue Over an Icelandic Debt
description: LONDON  The British and Dutch governments are taking steps to sue Iceland to claw back the billions of euros they paid to depositors in their countries after Icelandic banks collapsed in 2008.

title: Amid Catchy Choruses, Personal Tales of Lifes Brutal Verities
description: The perky refrains in the freaky existential cabaret written and performed by the playwright Young Jean Lee are probably not going to be squeaked out by Britney Spears, wailed by Mariah Carey or even bellowed by the freak-flag-waving Lady Gaga anytime soon.

title: A Few Big Boards Decide a Junior Teams Title
description: The sixth White House Junior Teams tournament took place in the Netherlands late last month. Twenty-four teams from 20 countries (the Dutch had three teams competing and the Israelis two) played a 10-board round robin to qualify four teams for 24-board semifinals.

title: Russell Brand Is Up and Down at Movie Theaters
description: Hop was No. 1 at North American theaters for a second weekend in a row, selling an estimated $21.7 million in tickets for Universal Pictures (for a total of $68.2 million). But it was one of those weekends when a flop was the news: Arthur, a $40 million Warner Brothers remake starring Russell Brand, right, was a distant second with about $12.6 million  a terrible result considering the studios considerable marketing campaign. Brand burnout may have played a role. Mr. Brand, the comedian, known for his fingernails-on-a-chalkboard voice, has made recent appearances to promote his films  he is also a prominent member of the Hop cast (as the voice of E. B., left)  on outlets as varied as American Idol and the Kids Choice Awards. Hanna, a Focus Features release about a 16-year-old assassin, was a stronger-than-expected third with $12.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticket statistics. Soul Surfer (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth with about $11 million; this drama, based on the true story of a girl who returns to surfing after losing her arm in a shark attack, received positive scores in exit polls. Insidious (FilmDistrict) was fifth with about $9.7 million for a two-week total of about $27 million. Also notable: Your Highness, a stoner comedy starring Natalie Portman and James Franco that cost Universal about $50 million, was a bomb, opening in sixth place with $9.5 million.

title: No Major Relics Stolen in Egypt
description: Of the roughly 1,000 relics stolen from museums and archeological sites in Egypt since the sweeping protests began there in January, none were items of major importance, said Zahi Hawass, Egypts minister for antiquities, Agence France-Presse reported. There is an inventory of everything, and it will be difficult for the items to leave the country, Mr. Hawass told the Spanish newspaper El Mundo on Sunday, adding that the thieves were probably looters who lived near the sites, as opposed to organized criminals, and that they probably had little knowledge of the value of the goods they had pilfered. Many of the relics were taken from the Egyptian Museum in Cairo, which houses much of the King Tutankhamen collection, as well as the tombs of Hetep-ka at Saqqara and Em-pi at Giza.

title: Jackson Poetry Prize
description: James Richardson has received this years Jackson Poetry Prize, a $50,000 award presented to an American poet by Poets & Writers, a nonprofit organization for creative writers. Mr. Richardsons latest collection, By the Numbers: Poems and Aphorisms, was released by Copper Canyon Press in November and was a finalist for the 2010 National Book Award. His previous collections include Interglacial: New and Selected Poems and Aphorisms (Ausable, 2004), a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, andVectors: Aphorisms and Ten-Second Essays (Ausable, 2001). The prize has been awarded since 2007 by a panel of three distinguished poets. This years panelists were Mark Doty, Rita Dove and Gerald Stern. Previous winners were Elizabeth Alexander, Tony Hoagland, Linda Gregg and Harryette Mullen.

title: Some Fringe Encores
description: Urinetown, Williamsburg: The Musical and Dog Sees God, among several other shows, will return to the New York International Fringe Festival this spring and summer as part of a concert series to benefit the festivals 15th anniversary season. Every Thursday for 15 weeks (May 5 through Aug. 11) at the Laurie Beechman Theater at the West Bank Cafe, the Alumni Association of the New York International Fringe Festival will present a performance, concert or reading of a show from the last 15 years of festivals. It is the first benefit for the organization. A schedule and casting details are at fringenyc.org.

title: New Job, but Still Chasing Bad Guys
description: NBC is reintroducing Law & Order: Los Angeles on Monday with a premiere-worthy two-hour special, which is a bit like having a fancy formal wedding on the grounds that the first marriage was annulled so it doesnt count. And as in the case with many a second marriage, the new version isnt really different  its just a slight change in casting.

title: Bids for Warner Suggest Faith in Industrys Future
description: Could a record company still be a good investment? The bids for the Warner Music Group, one of the four major record companies, suggest that some people think so.

title: Pairing Their Sounds and Sharing the Blues
description: Eric Clapton chose the songs and Wynton Marsalis laid out the musical territory for Wynton Marsalis and Eric Clapton Play the Blues, the Jazz at Lincoln Center concert at Rose Theater on Friday night, the first of two shows. It was a concert so fixated on elegant details that its blues were bloodless.

title: New Yorks Pioneering World Music Impresario Announces His Retirement
description: Since 1985 there have always been two things you could count on at a World Music Institute concert: stirring traditional sounds (and dance) from a faraway corner of the planet, and a dry yet thoughtful introduction by Robert Browning, the institutes founder and executive director.

title: Glancing Backward, Then Facing Forward
description: While museums engage in high-profile performance initiatives and debates, the dance world continues its method of preservation in the same quiet, humble way it has for decades, through a more mobile sort of archive: the body.

title: Euro Divergence (Slightly Wonkish)
description: Just as a reminder that others have problems: Cezmi Dispinar points me to a post with an excellent chart about the problem of adjustment:

title: Watching the Trees and Portraits Go By, on Wings of Violins
description: The Unsound Festival, a celebration of contemporary music with an emphasis on the avant-garde, has flourished in Krakow, Poland, since 2003, when it was started by Mat Schulz, an Australian writer who settled there in 1995. Last year Mr. Schulz brought an edition of the festival to New York, and it proved a lively addition to the citys thriving new-music world, not least because of its focus on European electronica composers who are scarcely known here.

title: Monday: Well, Whaddaya Know!
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Welcome, my friends. Mr. Ian Livengood and I are so glad you could join us in his lair, I mean, puzzle. Dont bother trying to escape; a good number of the villains of your cinematic and televised nightmares surround you.

title: At Gannett, Furloughs but Nice Paydays for Brass
description: Just in case Gannett employees thought 2011 might bring better news after years of layoffs and furloughs, the year was just four days old when a note landed in the in-box of people who work for the community news division saying, once again, they were required to take an unpaid week off.

title: Kneel Before Zod: Michael Shannon to Play Superman Villain
description: Known for the unearthly menace he brings to the characters he portrays on televisions Boardwalk Empire and off Broadways Mistakes Were Made, its only natural that Michael Shannon would end up as an alien villain in Zack Snyders new Superman movie. Warner Brothers Pictures said on Sunday that Mr. Shannon, an Academy Award nominee for Revolutionary Road, will play General Zod, an evildoer who comes from Supermans home planet of Krypton. The studio said the film, whose previously announced cast includes Henry Cavill (The Tudors) as Superman and Amy Adams (The Fighter) as Lois Lane, will be titled Man of Steel.

title: That Noisy Woodpecker Had an Animated Secret
description: LOS ANGELES  Sixteen years ago Tom Klein was staring at a Woody Woodpecker cartoon, The Loose Nut, when he started seeing things.

title: Detroit Symphony Returns to a Giddy Reception
description: DETROIT  As the musicians took the stage, applause and cheering erupted. We love you guys! a concertgoer yelled. A violinist mouthed, Wow, another tapped her music stand with her bow in appreciation, and the awe-struck players stood facing a packed-to-the rafters audience for five minutes while the love flowed over them.

title: Helping Fans Dress Like a Video Game Hero
description: PRODUCT placement within video games is common enough these days that gamers barely notice it, but when Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker was introduced last year, some players snickered when they saw its protagonist, Naked Snake, occasionally wearing a T-shirt with the a logo for Axe, the mens grooming brand. The game, after all, is set in 1974  nine years before Axe was introduced, in France, and 28 years before it gained prominence with its introduction in the United States.

title: The Battle for Libya | April 10, 2011
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis military forces appeared to falter in a second day of assault against Ajdabiya.

title: Research In Motion Eyes a Rebound
description: WATERLOO, Ontario  In a rare interview last week, Mike Lazaridis, one of Research In Motions two chief executives, was the one asking questions:

title: In Egypt and Tunisia, the Games Must Go On
description: The descent into chaos of last weeks African Champions League match in Cairo between Zamalek of Egypt of Tunisias Club Africain apparently will not delay the decisions by soccer authorities in both north African countries to resume league play on Wednesday.

title: BP Fast Becoming a Takeover Target
description: BP, the British oil giant, should be on bid alert. It has many hallmarks of a target: a discounted share price, a strategic setback and a weakened management team.

title: The Rails Derby 10
description: A look at the contenders for the Kentucky Derby, listed in order of preference. You can follow Joe Drape on Twitter.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the trade deficit for February and import prices for March (Tuesday); retail sales for March, business inventories for February, and the Federal Reserve beige book (Wednesday); the Producer Price Index for March and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for March, industrial production and capacity utilization for March, and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

title: Qaddafis Handling of Media Shows Regimes Flaws
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Even the Qaddafi government escort could not contain his disbelief at the sloppiness of the fraud: bloodstains his colleagues had left on bedsheets in a damaged hospital room for more than a week as evidence of civilian casualties from Western airstrikes.

title: Libyan Rebels Take Risks With Makeshift  Arms
description: In cheerful and crisp English, Adel Sanfad presented his new weapon, which was mounted on a welded frame to the back of his jeep near the front lines in eastern Libya. These used to be for airplanes, he said. Then he added, in a flash of pride that was undercut slightly with a wince: But we modified them.

title: New Doubts About Turning Plutonium Into a Fuel
