description: On a tract of government land along the Savannah River in South Carolina, an army of workers is building one of the nations most ambitious nuclear enterprises in decades: a plant that aims to safeguard at least 43 tons of weapons-grade plutonium by mixing it into fuel for commercial power reactors.

title: A Symphony Returns
description: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra played its first concert of the season after a bitter months-long strike.

title: Catch Me if You Can
description: Photos of the new Broadway musical.

title: Holocaust Memories, via Cable
description: Comcast, the nations top cable company, is distributing 10 films about the Holocaust in a public service project it is calling Days of Remembrance. And it started with an unrelated telephone call to the directorSteven Spielberg.

title: NYSE Euronext Chief Calls Nasdaqs Bid Inconsistent With Long-Term Strategy
description: In rejecting an $11.3 billion takeover bid by the Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange, NYSE Euronext made a forceful case that a merger with Deutsche Brse was the real way to generate long-term value.

title: Mike Campbell, Zimbabwean Farmer Who Fought Land Seizure, Dies at 78
description: JOHANNESBURG  Mike Campbell, a ferociously independent white Zimbabwean farmer who sued his countrys autocratic ruler, Robert Mugabe, to stop the seizure of his land and improbably won, only to lose the farm when the government defied the court ruling, died on Wednesday. He was 78.

title: The Crisis Next Time
description: The federal government survived the hostage crisis created by House Republicans, but emerged staggering from the deal struck Friday night. The compromises were damaging, the amount of money cut from a sickly economy was severe, and the image of Washington as a back-alley dogfighting garage will not soon fade.

title: John McCracken, Sculptor of Geometric Forms, Dies at 76
description: John McCracken, a West Coast artist who brought a New Age openness to Minimalist sculpture, along with a vocabulary of bright, sleek slabs, blocks and columns that balanced teasingly between painting and sculpture, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: The Clarion Notes of Defiance
Bay Areas Little Leagues Overflow With Would-Be Giants
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The good vibrations from the San Francisco Giants World Series victory last fall continue to reverberate in the Bay Area, where children inspired by the improbable success of the Giants assemblage of castoffs have overwhelmed local Little Leagues.

title: New Rules for Mortgage Servicers Face Early Criticism
description: Federal banking regulators have not officially imposed their new rules for the top mortgage servicers, but criticism is already being heard. A wide coalition of consumer and housing groups is denouncing the legal agreements, which are likely to be published within a few days.

title: City, Destroyed and Yet Hopeful, Begins to Move On
description: MINAMISOMA, Japan  After nearly four weeks of living in distant refugee shelters, or huddling indoors at home for fear of nuclear fallout, Toshie Nagasawa finally came here to say goodbye.

title: Intel, on the Outside, Takes Aim at Smartphones
description: With an Intel Inside sticker affixed to their PCs, computer buyers in the 1990s could hardly avoid knowing whose microchip was making their machines work. The campaign made Intel one of the most recognizable brands and cemented its position in the PC industry.

title: With Aid and Migrants, China Expands Its Presence in a South American Nation
description: PARAMARIBO, Suriname  The Foreign Ministrys elegant new headquarters here is a gift from the Chinese government. Chinese signs on hundreds of businesses, from casinos to grocery shops and furniture stores, beckon the residents of this capital. Chinese work crews are paving roads cutting through the jungle.

title: From Uncle Mo Show to Wide-Open Kentucky Derby
description: So much for the talk about Uncle Mo being the next Seattle Slew or the suspicion (or hope?) that he belonged in a different stratosphere from his fellow 3-year-olds. When Uncle Mo turned for home Saturday in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, Tom Durkin, the voice of New York racing, said what many were thinking: It is the moment of truth for Uncle Mo.

title: France and U.N. Hit Ivory Coast Strongmans Home and Palace
description: BOUAK, Ivory Coast  French and United Nations helicopters fired missiles on Sunday at key positions held by forces loyal to the entrenched strongman Laurent Gbagbo in Abidjan, the countrys economic capital, partly destroying Mr. Gbagbos residence, according to one of his top aides.

title: Israel and Hamas Consider Cease-Fire
description: JERUSALEM  Israel and Hamas signaled on Sunday that they were willing to restore calm after days of intense fighting, and while militants in Gaza fired about 10 rockets and mortar shells into southern Israel, most fell in open areas close to the border and Israel did not immediately respond.

title: Celtics Creak Toward Postseason, Hoping They Have Legs for a Run
description: BOSTON  Only two games remain in what has been an extraordinarily trying season for the Boston Celtics. Then the playoffs arrive, and it remains to be seen which Celtics team will show up: the current unpredictable group that the former Celtic Kevin McHale called Sybil because of its multiple personalities, or the savvy, been-there, done-that group that can play at a high level any time it chooses.

title: It Came Out of the Viral Media Swamp
description: LOS ANGELES  It seems fair to ask why Sidney J. Sheinberg, 76 years old and long retired as president of MCA Inc., the erstwhile parent of Universal Pictures, spent much of last May tromping through the swamps of Louisiana with the crew of a little monster movie called Creature.

title: In Federal Court, a Docket Number for Global Terror
description: The indictments are all filed under the same basic docket number, 93 Cr. 180, an indistinct series of numerals and letters that reveals more with each new installment.

title: A Sore Subject
description: The day after Derek Jeter told a few reporters that he aint talking about his retooled hitting mechanics anymore, Joe Girardi sounded as if he, too, had been growing tired of what has become a daily topic of discussion in his sessions with the news media.

title: For Cowboy Poets, Unwelcome Spotlight in Battle Over Spending
description: ELKO, Nev.  This isolated town in the northeast Nevada mountains is known for gold mines, ranches, casinos, bordellos and J. M. Capriola, a destination store with two floors of saddles, boots, spurs and chaps. It is also the birthplace of the annual Cowboy Poetry Gathering, a celebration of range song and poetry that draws thousands of cowboys and their fans every January and receives some money from the federal government.

title: Searching for Answers, Yankees Hughes Tinkers With His Motion
description: BOSTON  Phil Hughes has maintained that his struggles derive from a lack of arm strength, not flawed mechanics. But just in case, he tinkered with his motion during his bullpen session Sunday evening with the Yankees pitching coach, Larry Rothschild.

title: Nationalist Candidate Appears to Be Leading in Perus Presidential Vote
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Peruvian voters cast ballots on Sunday in a presidential election notable for the surging candidacy of Ollanta Humala, a nationalist who is critical of the expanding influence of foreign companies in Perus booming economy.

title: For Mets, Relievers Struggles Trump a Starters Strong Effort
description: Chris Youngs 108th and final pitch on an overcast Sunday afternoon was a deft split-finger fastball that dipped past Washington Nationals second baseman Danny Espinosa for a called third strike. Young, the towering new Met, was cheered as he strolled back to the dugout.

title: McChrystal to Lead Program for Military Families
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, who was relieved of command in Afghanistan after a magazine profile quoted his subordinates as disparaging senior civilian leaders, has been invited back to public service by the Obama administration to help oversee a high-profile initiative in support of military families, White House officials said Sunday.

title: Actors in Smaller Studios, Making Pictures for the Smaller Screen
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  The film set was professional, even if the actors kept messing up the scene by laughing at the star, who was flailing in front of a green screen, pretending to be eaten alive.

title: Eighth-Seeded Rangers Have Reasons to Like Their Chances Against Capitals
description: John Tortorella was defiant Saturday afternoon as he waited to learn the Rangers playoff fate.

title: With a Spending Deal in Hand, Lawmakers Now Turn to the Details
description: WASHINGTON  As more details of the budget deal between President Obama and Congressional leaders trickled out on Sunday, lobbyists and lawmakers stepped up their efforts to secure or kill specific provisions benefiting wolf hunters in Montana, profit-making colleges and various public works projects.

title: For McIlroy, a Collapse He Never Saw Coming
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Charl Schwartzel, the new Masters champion, had already been enveloped in applause and then whisked away for the traditional posttournament television interview in nearby Butler Cabin. Workers were beginning to line up five rows of chairs for the awards ceremony. Most of the crowd was walking to the exits.

title: New York Terrorism Indictments
description: Five of 14 indictments that chart a history of terrorism conspiracies in New York City and elsewhere.

title: JPMorgan Accused of Breaking Its Duty to Clients
description: In the summer of 2007, as the first tremors of the coming financial crisis were being felt on Wall Street, top executives of JPMorgan Chase were raising red flags about a troubled investment vehicle called Sigma, which was based in London. But the bank chose not to move out $500 million in client assets that it had put into Sigma two months earlier.

title: Woodss Tantalizing Surge Comes Up Short on the Back Nine
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Tiger Woodss second shot to the par-5 15th green landed soft and rolled 4 feet past the hole. It was not long after the third-round leader Rory McIlroys implosion at the 10th hole, a triple-bogey that altered the course of the 2011 Masters. Passing a massive scoreboard that overlooks the 15th green, Woods peeked at the upheaval taking place on the leader board.

title: With Shovels and Shears, Police Plod Through a Hiding Place for Bodies
description: JONES BEACH ISLAND, N.Y.  Thickets of bayberries, reeds and a type of vine called sea tomatoes crisscross the dunes off the northern edge of Ocean Parkway. Sowed early in the last century to accompany the Robert Moses-inspired roadway, the plants have grown into a greenish wall to shroud this barrier island and its mysteries.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 10, 2011

title: Sensible Rules to Make Bus Travel Safer
description: Three major bus accidents in the Northeast, including the horrific crash on Interstate 95 in the Bronx that killed 15 passengers and critically injured several others, may finally spur Congress to mandate bus safety improvements.

title: A Lawsuits Unusual Question: Who Is a Man?
description: What is a man? For ElJai Devoureau, this is not a rhetorical question.

title: Who Really Sent That E-Mail?
description: Americans are right to be concerned about a huge data breach at an online marketing company, Epsilon, which resulted in the theft of names and e-mail addresses for customers and employees of some of the nations largest businesses, including Citibank, Disney and Verizon.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Courics Rocky Five-Year Path to a Likely Parting With CBS
description: For Katie Couric, the offer in 2006 to become the anchor of CBS Evening News came with another incentive, one she prized almost as highly, according to two of her friends: the chance to report for 60 Minutes, the newsmagazine that for Ms. Couric stood for the kind of serious journalism she had always aspired to.

title: Bluefin Tuna Catch a (Small) Break
description: The numbers of endangered bluefin tuna are rapidly dwindling, due to vast overfishing fueled by Japans insatiable sushi appetite. The international body set up to conserve these fish has utterly failed to do its job. But a small and clever innovation may slow their decline: special hooks designed to help commercial fishing boats in the Gulf of Mexico avoid catching bluefin accidentally.

title: Close-Knit, New to the House, and Resistant to Blending In
description: WASHINGTON  Even by the standards of Capitol Hill, where the bonds of friendship form quickly and endure, the four Republican freshmen from South Carolina stand out.

title: A City Schools Uphill Fight Over Sharing Space With a Charter
description: In a city where so many public schools are segregated by race and wealth, Public School 9 in Brooklyn is an exception.

title: Marketer Puts Its Chips on Times Square
description: The flavor of New York City would be different without Times Square. The Frito-Lay division of PepsiCo seems to agree.

title: Scamming as Fast as He Can
description: As befits a lad of the 1960s with a talent for smooth come-ons, Frank Abagnale Jr. prefaces the story of his life with the promise that it will have more curves than a Playboy bunny. title: By Silencing Yankees, Beckett Provides Hope for Red Sox
description: BOSTON  Josh Beckett marked his territory early against the Yankees on Sunday night, firing four 94-mile-per-hour fastballs to Brett Gardner before fooling him with a curve. Derek Jeter tapped out to shortstop. Mark Teixeira stared at an unhittable pitch, a two-seamer that curled across the inside corner for strike three. So went the first inning for the Yankees, and the next eight were more of the same. A lineup that blistered Red Sox starters the first two games at Fenway Park looked modest and middling against Beckett, who silenced the Yankees in a 4-0 victory.

title: Two Shows Share Diversity Award

Amy Poehler and Rashida Jones of NBCs Parks and Recreation were to host the second installment of this three-part ceremony sponsored by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation. Among the other honorees were Kristin Chenoweth, the actress and singer; Robert Greenblatt, the chairman of NBC Entertainment; and Bianca Peet, a 17-year-old from Corpus Christi, Tex., who rallied to start a Gay Straight Alliance at her high school after the groups application was denied by the school district. More awards will be presented on May 14 in San Francisco; a third ceremony was held last month in New York.

title: Virtual Gold, Real Money
description: In June 2007, Julian Dibbell published an article in the Sunday Magazine about the shadow economy in virtual goods, focusing on gold farmers in China  workers hired by Chinese companies to play huge, multiplayer online games for the sole purpose of acquiring loot that could then be sold at a profit to regular players who didnt have the time or the inclination to do it themselves and who use this purchased loot to increase their chances and status in these games. For years now, the vast majority of virtual goods has been brought to retail not by players selling the product of their own gaming but by high-volume online specialty sites like the virtual-money superstores IGE, BroGame and Massive Online Gaming Sales  multimillion-dollar businesses offering one-stop, one-click shopping and instant delivery of in-game cash, Dibbell wrote. These are the Wal-Marts and Targets of this decidedly gray market, and the same economic logic that leads conventional megaretailers to China in search of cheap toys and textiles takes their virtual counterparts to Chinas gold farms.

title: A Hard Rain: Modest Turnout for Bob Dylan in Vietnam
description: Days after his historic and headline-generating concert debut in mainland China, Bob Dylan played his first performance in Vietnam on Sunday night, eliciting criticism but drawing only moderate crowds. BBC News reported that Mr. Dylan, whose Sunday show at RMIT University in Ho Chi Minh City was his first ever in that Communist country, once again played a set list that had to be approved by the government there, a stipulation he had agreed to with the Chinese government for his concerts in Beijing and Shanghai last week. (Sundays show included spirited tunes like A Hard Rains a-Gonna Fall and Highway 61 Revisited, but no obvious protest songs like Blowin in the Wind.)

title: Be the Armchair Ethicist
description: April 11 update: Thanks to everyone who participated in Armchair Ethicist. This was our first live Web chat about a letter, and I think the results were tremendous  so many replies, and so much careful thought. (And so little screaming and name-calling  thank you for that!) Overall the deleters were in the majority, but the answers reflected a wide range of ideas and many subtle gradations of ethical thinking. I learned a lot, mostly about how seriously you all take these issues. What a great lesson! Lets do this again soon. (And as for me, well, Ill be publishing my thoughts in the magazine soon.)

description: I am practically giddy as I write this. I am seated at my regular coffee shop, the one where I came nearly every morning to work until about five weeks ago, when a bad fall more or less confined me to the couch. But broken bones heal, and while I am still on crutches, and not yet allowed to put weight on my left foot, I am now wearing jeans (rather than the yoga pants I wore for five weeks), with a shoe on my right foot (rather than a sneaker). Most exhilarating of all, I drove here on my own. For the first time in more than a month, I feel like ME.

title: Bertolucci to Receive Honorary Palme dor at Cannes
description: As a filmmaker, Bernardo Bertolucci has had a lasting impact on how audiences think of Asia and Africa, Buddhism and butter, but he has never won a Palme dor  the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival. It is a gap on his trophy shelf that the organizers of the festival said they intended to correct at this years celebration. Mr. Bertolucci, whose films include The Last Emperor, The Sheltering Sky, Little Buddha and Last Tango in Paris, will be given an honorary Palme dor at the opening ceremony of this years festival, it was announced on Monday. The festival has previously presented honorary awards to filmmakers including Woody Allen (in 2002) and Clint Eastwood (in 2009), and starting this year plans to make the distinction an annual tradition.

(Ms. Daly is reprising the role she played last spring at the Kennedy Center.)

title: What to Expect From Hat on Broadway?
description: Tuesday, April 12 | Updated Stephen Adly Guirgiss new comedy will openopened on Monday night at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, starring Chris Rock, in his Broadway debut, Bobby Cannavale and Annabella Sciorra.

title: Fast Food | A Restaurant With a Shelf Life
description: JBF LTD, the James Beard Foundations temporary restaurant, which opens in the Chelsea Market on Tuesday, April 12, will be around for only 27 days. But its short life span is also its theme  a pop-up thats a countdown.

title: Water Bills Likely to Rise, but by Less Than Projected
description: Homeowners can expect a 7.5 percent increase in their water bills this summer, although the rise is lower than expected, in part because the city used so much water during last summers scorching heat.

title: German Exchange Doesnt Plan to Sweeten NYSE Offer
description: Deutsche Brse does not plan to sweeten the terms of its merger with NYSE Euronext, because top managers of the German exchange operator are convinced that a rival bid has little chance of success, people with knowledge of the transaction said Monday.

title: Egypt Sentences Blogger to 3 Years
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian blogger was sentenced Monday to three years in prison for criticizing the military in what human rights advocates called one of the more alarming violations of freedom of expression since a popular uprising led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak two months ago.

title: Video: More Budget Debates on the Hill
description: Read John Harwoods column, Now, the Hard Part for Nervous Republicans published in Mondays Times.

title: A Generous Opening to the Lucerne Easter Festival
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  By now many music lovers, having heard critics grouse for years about the glut of Handel Messiah performances at Christmas, know that the work was written for Lent. But those listeners, critics included, may be hard pressed to name another Handel oratorio written for the Easter season.

title: An Extended Farewell for Steve Carell at The Office
description: A quick departure for Michael Scott probably would be better for productivity at Dunder Mifflin, but NBC isnt letting go of Steve Carell, who has played that beloved if inept character on The Office for seven seasons, that easily. On Monday the network said it would extend the running time of the April 28 episode of The Office, on which Mr. Carell bids farewell to the series, to run about 50 minutes total, including commercials; it will be followed by an extended 40-minute episode of Parks and Recreation, a regular 30-minute episode of 30 Rock and zero minutes of Outsourced.

title: Virtual Conferencing
description: New technology allows meeting participants to see and talk to one another in a virtual environment. (UCSB Research Center for Virtual Environments and Behavior)

title: Middleman in Insider Trading Triangle Says There Was Once a Fourth
description: Craig Ruttle/Bloomberg NewsKenneth T. Robinson leaving federal court in Newark on Monday.

title: Wheelies: The Mustang Edition
description: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:

title: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ivory Coast, France, Libya and Yemen.

title: A Tonsil Remedy Is Fitted for a New Century
description: The Tonsil Hospital is no more.

title: Keeping Eyes on Distracted Drivings Toll
description: While driving a car, have you ever:

title: Italy Lashes Out at European Union Over Immigrants
description: ROME  Tensions rose between Italy and its European Union partners on Monday over how to handle an influx of immigrants from North Africa, prompting the Italian interior minister to question the utility of the European Union.

title: Court Upholds Facebook Settlement With Twins
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, the Olympic rowers and identical twins who claimed that they, not Mark Zuckerberg, had the original idea for Facebook, have lost the latest chapter in their six-year legal feud. But its a loss that comes with a pretty nice consolation prize. And it may not be the end of the case.

title: Stresscalation
description: The contagiousness of stress. (Originally, the ways in which people increase their own levels of stress.)

title: Pakistan Tells U.S. It Must Sharply Cut C.I.A. Activities
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistan has demanded that the United States steeply reduce the number of Central Intelligence Agency operatives and Special Operations forces working in Pakistan, and that it halt C.I.A. drone strikes aimed at militants in northwest Pakistan. The request was a sign of the near collapse of cooperation between the two testy allies.

title: Gee, How Did That Towel End Up in My Suitcase?
description: Hotel guests may want to think twice now before walking off with that bathrobe. Linen Technology Tracking, a company in Miami, has patented a washable RFID chip that can be sewn into towels, robes and bed sheets, allowing hotels to keep track of their linens.

title: Orszag Rebuts Criticism in New York Magazine Profile
description: Peter Orszag, the former White House budget director, describes himself in a New York magazine article as relieved to be out of the West Wing  a place he didnt want to be in the first place.

title: Commemorating the Civil Wars 150th Anniversary
description: Facebook Event | Adam Goodheart, Disunion writer and author of the book, 1861, invites you participate in a lively chat on April 12 at 12 p.m., Eastern Standard Time, on the Disunion Facebook page to commemorate the start of the Civil War on April 12, 1861. So come one, come all! And bring your questions about Fort Sumter and the coming of the Civil War. Or just anything else you think needs saying. Adam Goodheart will be answering questions until 1 p.m, E.S.T.

title: Defense in Insider Trial Seeks to Present Galleon as Disciplined
description: 9:15 p.m. | Updated

title: More Speculation About Kate Middletons Dress
description: The May issue of British Vogue is all bridal in honor of the bride Kate  er, sorry, Catherine  Middleton, whose wedding to Prince William on April 29 has everyone playing a daily guessing game about her dress and tiara. The magazine features three separate covers: Freja Beha Erichsen in a silk faille Oscar de la Renta gown; Lara Stone in a delicate Bruce Oldfield; and Natalia Vodianova in a draped Vivienne Westwood dress with a tulle bolero. Mario Testino photographed the piece, called Wedding Belles.

title: Depressed About Allergies?
description: In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores the link between allergies and depression.

title: Video Captures Ordeal of Subway Riders Trapped in Elevator
description: Another day, another harrowing and viral YouTube video of a New York City mass transit nightmare.

title: 3-D Avatars Could Put You in Two Places at Once
description: If Jim Blascovich and Jeremy Bailenson are right, here is whats in store for you and your avatar very soon, probably within the next five years:

title: Shake-Up at Renault Over Chain of Failures
description: PARIS  The French automaker Renault dismissed its chief operating officer and six others after internal and external audits showed a chain of failures in the events that led to the unjust accusations of spying against three of its employees.

title: Studies Say Natural Gas Has Its Own Environmental Problems
description: Natural gas, with its reputation as a linchpin in the effort to wean the nation off dirtier fossil fuels and reduce global warming, may not be as clean over all as its proponents say.

title: Numberplay: Tracking the Ball
description: Imagine that you and your best buddy are missile tracking engineers working for the Pentagon (nice steady job in these times!). The two of you played hoops for rival schools in your youth, and each of you believes he is better than the other. You challenge each other to a one-on-one grudge match in your backyard, the winner entitled to bragging rights forever. All your colleagues show up, some with video cameras to film the historic showdown. Its an intense match, and both of you are giving it all youve got. The game goes right down to the wire. You are one point behind, and with just a few seconds to go, you uncork a buzzer beater. The ball travels in a graceful arc towards the basket. To your eyes, it seems certain to go in. At that very moment, a hefty twig descends from the tree above, strikes the ball and deflects it away. The buzzer sounds.

title: Taking Out Tonsils Less Often
description: In todays 18 and Under column, Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, writes about the declining popularity of tonsillectomies, which were once almost routine in pediatrics.

title: No Taxation Without Calculation: Filling Out Tax Returns
description: Overview | How much of workers income goes to taxes? Why? In this lesson, students estimate how much various people would need to earn to cover their expenses, and then take into account their tax burden. After exploring the 1040 form, they work in groups to use mocked-up financial forms to fill out tax returns for taxpayers, then swap with another group to conduct an audit.

title: What Were Reading: China Finally Runs a Trade Deficit
A Vaccine for the Very Young Takes Aim at Bacterial Diseases
description: With help from international donors, Congo introduced a new vaccine this month in an effort to save more of its babies from pneumococcal disease.

title: Renovation of a Terminal, Keyed to San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO  If the prospect of flying holds all the appeal of a cross-country bus trip, the $6,500, lipstick-red leather Egg chairs at San Francisco International Airports Terminal 2 are intended to return some long-lost glamour to air travel.

title: David Foster Wallace, Self-Help Reader
description: The Pale King, David Foster Wallaces posthumous novel about I.R.S. agents struggling against boredom, may be unfinished, but it is still 548 pages long. Fortunately for those Wallace fans who are too busy finishing their own taxes to start reading the book, some shorter bits of Wallaceana have been popping up.

title: Coda Automotive Raising Money to Finish Electric Car
description: Coda Automotive, an electric vehicle developer in Santa Monica, Calif., with a battery joint venture in Tianjin, China, is seeking fresh capital to complete work on its first model, the electric Coda Sedan. Christopher Rose, the companys senior vice president for corporate development, said on the sidelines of the Berkeley-Stanford Cleantech Conference in San Francisco last weekend that the $50 million investment the company was seeking would be used to finish the car.

title: The Big Boards Big Rejection
description: On Sunday, NYSE Euronext rebuffed an $11.3 billion bid from the Nasdaq OMX Group and IntercontinentalExchange, reaffirming a proposed merger with Deutsche Brse. Duncan L. Niederauer, chief executive of NYSE Euronext, talks about why the Big Board turned down the Nasdaq deal in a video interview with CNBC.

title: Blogger Jailed for Insulting Egypts Military
description: As my colleagues Liam Stack and Ethan Bronner report, an Egyptian activist who criticized Egypts army on his blog was sentenced to three years in jail on Monday by a military court.

title: Giants Who Scarfed Down Fast-Food Feasts
description: Nothing in the dinosaur world was quite like the sauropods. They were huge, some unbelievably gigantic, the biggest animals ever to lumber across the land, consuming everything in sight. Their necks were much longer than a giraffes, their tails just about as long and their bodies like an elephants, only much more so.

title: Consolidation of Trade Publications Nears
description: The long-planned consolidation of three familiar trade publications into one is beginning at Prometheus Global Media.

title: Screening Prostates at Any Age
description: When, if ever, are people just too old to benefit from cancer screening?

title: When Should Men Stop P.S.A. Testing?
description: Older men who often have the least to gain from prostate cancer testing are being screened at twice the rate of men in their 50s, Gina Kolata reports in todays Science Times.

title: Why Insider Trading Is Wrong
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the head of the Galleon Group, is defending himself against charges of insider trading by arguing that his trades were based on the so-called mosaic theory, which means his firm gathered information from every nook and cranny of the market to put together a picture of a company.

title: Held at the Gate, in the Service of Tequila
description: IM a bit of a nomad. I was born in New York, went to college in Ohio, worked in the Midwest and then moved to San Francisco during the first dot-com boom.

title: A Condo, High-Profile Residents and a $40,000 Bill
description: Ken Nahoum has been known in downtown social circles for his celebrity photography and music videos; his companion, a Victorias Secret model; his great season seats at Knicks games; and his collection of penthouses at 95 Greene Street in SoHo.

title: Level 3s Bid for Global Crossing Could Lead to More Deals
description: 7:36 p.m. | Updated

title: Jura Has Its Day in New York
description: Its kind of a crazy Jura  day in New York today, what with all sorts of dinners and tastings going on and Jura producers here offering their wares. The level of interest in the wines of the Jura has grown outlandishly in the last few years. Its still minute in the great scheme of things, but Jura producers traveling to New York for tastings? Unheard of until recently.

title: Face Time | Mary Louise Parker and Charlie Mars
description: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist who is known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

title: Embedistan: Unembedded vs. Embedded
description: PAKTIA, Afghanistan  I have spent six months in Afghanistan, 85 percent of it unembedded.

title: TimesCast | April 11, 2011
description: Ivory Coast's former leader is captured by his political rival; and a French law banning the full-face veil leads to arrests and protests.

title: Romney Makes It Official, Quietly
description: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, quietly made his presidential ambitions official Monday by forming an exploratory committee to run for president in 2012 and declaring in a video that it is time that we put America back on a course of greatness.

title: New Orleans Horns, Raw and Funky
description: The Rebirth Brass Band ended its full-throttle show at Brooklyn Bowl on Thursday night more or less swarmed, yielding the stage to an eager throng. This of course was a handy bit of showmanship, timed to coincide with several of the bands best-loved New Orleans anthems (Feel Like Funkin It Up, Cassanova, Do Whatcha Wanna) and with the climax of accumulated energies in the room. But it was also an affirmation of core principles. A stage is little more than a platform for the Rebirth Brass Band, and the distance it imposes on an audience is a passing inconvenience, even on the road.

title: Ancien-Rgime Change
description: Until very recently, when people gathered to do the math on United Nations Security Council reform, it was always a given that France had the weakest claim to permanent membership on the council.The others on the so-called P5  the United States, Russia, China and Britain  all made more sense. Frances membership as a victor of World War II was always questionable.

title: The Many Paths of Japans Avant-Garde
description: One conclusion to be drawn from the New Juilliard Ensembles concert at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening is that there are few generalizations to be made about Japanese avant-garde classical music around the turn of the 21st century. The concert, among the last offerings of Carnegie Halls JapanNYC festival, featured six works by as many composers, all born after World War II and not very much alike.

title: Mini Countryman Geared Up for Rally Racing
description: The Mini Countryman is grown up, gussied up and now ready to race.

title: Is This the Poster Food for a Radiation Menace?
description: One of the many endearing things about my husband is that he has five Geiger counters.

title: Now Reading | American Fashion Travel
description: American Fashion Travel (Assouline, $45) collects detailed questionnaires, personal photos and amusing anecdotes from both established and up-and-coming designers, who may live and work in America but whose wanderlust is in no way confined to the United States. We discover, among other things, that Alexander Wang prefers the George V in Paris. Francisco Costa considers Havaianas sandals to be the perfect souvenir  not entirely unexpected from a bona fide Brazilian. Tommy Hilfiger loves to dine at Bukhara in New Delhi. Cynthia Rowleys favorite travel book is Local Color, by Truman Capote. Lisa Mayock of Vena Cava shares her carry-on essentials: gum, a notebook and trashy magazines. And Phillip Lim swears by Shiseido eye patches to cure jet lag.

title: The Brahms Behind the Schoenberg
description: Whatever toll James Levines health problems have taken on his conducting schedule, and his career more generally, when he does mount the podium  as he did last week to conduct Wozzeck at the Metropolitan Opera, and again on Sunday afternoon, when he led the Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall  his performances are invariably so finely polished and intensely communicative that you cannot doubt that he is at the top of his game.

title: Still Tapping Into the Teenage Soul
description: Although the history of vocal groups from the golden age of doo-wop is strewn with one-hit wonders, Little Anthony and the Imperials are not among them. And at Feinsteins at Loews Regency last week, where the group is playing its first New York nightclub engagement in more than three decades, the reasons for its staying power were evident.

title: Rabbis Sound an Alarm Over Eating Disorders
description: In the large and growing Orthodox Jewish communities around New York and elsewhere, rabbinic leaders are sounding an alarm about an unexpected problem: a wave of anorexia and other eating disorders among teenage girls.

title: Photo Replay: April 11
description: A look at the day in sports, including the view from a tennis tournament in Monte Carlo and an Olympic track star entering a much different race.

title: OpenTable and Its Snail-Mail Rewards Checks
description: OpenTable certainly makes it painless to find a good restaurant and make a reservation. So why the heck cant the company make it more convenient to redeem the rewards points you earn by using its service?

title: A Bunker of History Begins to Open
description: The New-York Historical Society has long seemed like a remote fortress on Central Park West because of the stately but insular architecture of its stone building and a certain bumpiness in its public relations.

title: Diving in Search of the Great Vampire Squid
description: In his 2009 Rolling Stone article about Goldman Sachs, Matt Taibbi called the firm a great vampire squid wrapped around the face of humanity, relentlessly jamming its blood funnel into anything that smells like money. Say what you will about that description, but it does express a clear point of view. The same cannot be said for William D. Cohans Money and Power, which invokes the vampire squid line twice but has no comparably bold attitude of its own.

title: House Republicans Seek to Remove Federal Funding for Planned Parenthood
description: There has been a change of plans among Republicans in Congress concerning a measure that would seek to end funding for Planned Parenthood, the subject of a fierce battle between Republicans and Democrats that threatened to upend a plan last week to keep the government open.

title: Seeking Bliss Among the Honks and Hisses
description: Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, 54, the Indian spiritual guru, said it was his first time in Times Square, as he walked up Broadway on Monday morning.

title: Gullibility
description: It has been quite a spectacle watching most of the punditocracy go into a swoon over Paul Ryan and his plan, then  once a few of us pointed out what was actually in the plan (and equally important, what wasnt)  watch some of them try to climb down without quite admitting that they had been taken for a ride. And my sense is that a fair number of people still cant believe that such a thing is possible  that there must have been some substance there, that the whole cadre of Very Serious People couldnt have been taken in by an obvious fraud. But I remember when:

title: Appeals Court Rules Against Arizona Law
description: PHOENIX  The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled against the State of Arizona on Monday and let stand a lower court decision blocking the most contentious parts of the states immigration law from going into effect.

title: Their Bright Teenager Is a Cannibal
description: Goodness knows Manhattan moms have ample reasons for anxiety about disappointing children. Why couldnt little Justin rise to the occasion of his kindergarten interview? How is it possible for a 12-year-old to lose three cellphones in as many months? Was it really necessary for Pearl to cause such havoc at her play date?

title: Judge Returns Players and N.F.L. to Mediation
description: The N.F.L. and its players, now a month into the lockout, on Monday were ordered back to the negotiating table with a mediator.

title: Playoff Experience Is Not Rangers Defensemens Strong Point
description: Ryan McDonagh, the Rangers rookie defenseman, will enter his teams best-of-seven first-round series against Alexander Ovechkin and the Capitals without any previous playoff series experience. This does not just mean professional hockey.

title: Wrapping Up Life and Death in One Album
description: PAUL SIMON

title: Taking a Second Look at Penguins Decline
description: The population of Adlie penguins in Antarctica has declined by 50 percent in recent years, and everyone who has watched a nature movie or television show knows that the reason is the rapidly melting sea ice that has limited the size of their winter habitat. But what everyone knows may be wrong.

title: Masters Helps CBS Master Prime Time
description: CBSs Sunday-afternoon coverage of the Masters golf tournament helped lift the networks prime-time ratings as well, as CBS topped the night for the fifth consecutive Sunday. Although final audience figures for the Masters were not available on Monday, preliminary overnight estimates were the second highest in 10 years, behind last years broadcast. Following the final round of that tournament, CBSs 60 Minutes delivered the largest audience in prime time, garnering 13.1 million viewers in the 7 p.m. hour. CBSs reality shows The Amazing Race and Undercover Boss each drew 10.7 million viewers, at 8 and 9, while CBSs CSI: Miami won the 10 p.m. hour with 10.2 million. ABC finished second, earning its best ratings at 8 for Secret Millionaire (9.1 million), while two hours of Brothers & Sisters averaged 6.5 million from 9 to 11 and lagged behind The Celebrity Apprentice on NBC (8.1 million). NBC was third with 4.3 million for Dateline at 7 and only 3.5 million for Americas Next Great Restaurant at 8. Fox was fourth with its animated comedies.

title: Prune and Almond Braised Short Ribs
description: Adapted from Tony Maws, Craigie on Main, Cambridge, Mass.

title: Seder for Two, Please: Restaurants Court Tradition
description: WHEN Victoria Herrmanns grandparents died in 2005, her familys Passover Seder tradition passed away with them. Her parents never had a Seder. (And her siblings had converted to Christianity.)

title: A Couples Knot, Tied Tighter by Dual Diagnoses
description: Until February, Nathan and Elisa Bond were about as ordinary a 30-something couple as you could find in Brooklyn. Mr. Bond, 38, was a teacher and an artist; Ms. Bond, 36, worked for a real estate broker; their daughter, Sadie, had turned 1 in the fall. The last thing on their minds was cancer.

title: Stupak Signs On as a Lobbyist
description: Bart Stupak has become the latest lawmaker  and one of the biggest names  among those who left Congress last year to move to a lobbying job. Venable LLP, a Washington law firm and lobbying shop, announced that it had signed him to work on legislative and government affairs.

title: For a Mans Tie, a Womans Touch
description: Chiffon, organza and tulle  fabrics traditionally used in womens fashion  can now be found in mens neckties, thanks to the nascent brand C.Chauchat. We are going to put tutu fabric on men  and they dont even know it, boasts Curie Choi, one half of the female design duo thats giving the classic mens accessory a new feel. Madame Chauchat is a lady who puts frenzy in the men around her, Choi says about her brands namesake, a character from Thomas Manns Magic Mountain.

title: Obama Favors University Setting to Deliver Policy Lectures
description: When President Obama decides that he wants to give a somber policy lecture about a big, tough-to-understand subject, he heads back to school  literally.

title: Concert for Japan
description: A marathon benefit concert took place at the Japan Society.

title: Obama Speech a Curveball, Chambliss Says
description: ATLANTA  A Republican leader in a bipartisan Senate group negotiating a debt-reduction package said on Monday that President Obama threw us a little bit of a curveball with the weekend announcement that he plans to deliver a speech on the subject later this week.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ivory Coast, France, Libya and Yemen.

title: Adobe Goes After Tablets in Software Update
description: To many, tablet computers have one major weakness: It is hard to create original content on them. But on Monday, Adobe announced a series of updates to its software that might help address that.

title: Hudson River Park, 4:47 P.M.
Strum, Pluck, Rescue, Rebuild
description: The hair was a little grayer, and the chins were a little weaker, but early Saturday afternoon at Japan Society it was like the 1980s again. The performers  Philip Glass, Hal Willner, John Zorn, Laurie Anderson, Lou Reed  were the same ones you might have found together back then, joined now for the first part of a 13-hour Concert for Japan, one of several earthquake relief benefits organized by the tireless Mr. Zorn.

title: Music With Texture, Shaking the Auditorium
description: Rumbles, thunderclaps and a baleful reading from the Old Testament prophet Amos  I will slay the last of them with my sword  opened the set by Lustmord on Sunday night at the Abrons Arts Center, the finale of the Unsound Festival of electronic and contemporary music and video. It was an extraordinarily rare live performance by the British musician Brian Williams, who has been recording as Lustmord since 1980 but has given only a handful of public concerts during his career, emerging for the Unsound Festival in Krakow, Poland, last year.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Passion of Joan of Arc'
description: A .O. Scott examines the currents of emotion in Carl Theodor Dreyer's 1928 film.

title: Tough Call on Goldstone Retraction
description: In my column on Sunday April 10, I described the complex, fast-moving environment in which The Timess foreign desk reports developments online and in print. A further challenge to journalists on the desk is deciding how to prioritize the news, especially given the volume and urgency of news in the current climate. While one might argue that in the digital medium there is unlimited space for news, in print the situation is different. The recent case of the retraction of a key assertion by Richard Goldstone, the South African jurist who led a panel investigating Israels invasion of Gaza two years ago, is a case in point.

title: Arthur Sells Fewer Tickets Than Predicted
description: LOS ANGELES The weekend was even worse for Russell Brand than initially thought.

title: The Science of the Spill
description: One year after the largest oil spill in the history of the Gulf of Mexico, scientists are trying to determine the long-term ecological effects.

title: Court of Extinction (1 Letter)
description: Court of Extinction

title: Burden of College Loans on Graduates Grows
description: Student loan debt outpaced credit card debt for the first time last year and is likely to top a trillion dollars this year as more students go to college and a growing share borrow money to do so.

title: Threats Big and Small (2 Letters)
description: Threats Big and Small

title: Black Journalists Group Leaves Minority Coalition
description: The National Association of Black Journalists has pulled out of an alliance intended to improve minority representation in the media, saying the groups conference no longer provided enough revenue to meet its goals.

title: Amazon to Sell the Kindle Reader at a Lower Price, but With Advertising Added
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazon is shaving another $25 off the price of its Kindle e-reader, this time with the help of advertisers.

title: Prescription for Parity (1 Letter)
description: Prescription for Parity

title: More Remains Are Found on Long Island, This Time in Nassau
description: Hours after expanding the search to Nassau County on Monday, the police on Long Island discovered human remains in two more places along Ocean Parkway, only miles from where investigators in Suffolk County have found eight bodies and said they are on the trail of a serial killer.

title: A Stingy Traveler Stung by Hotel Fees
description: I AM not so big on luxury travel. Im simply too cheap, even when Im traveling on the company dime.

title: Eating Disorders Among Orthodox Jews
description: In the large and growing Orthodox Jewish communities around New York and elsewhere, rabbinic leaders are sounding an alarm about an unexpected problem: a wave of anorexia and other eating disorders among teenage girls, reports Roni Caryn Rabin in this weeks Science Times.

title: Pairings: Saltimbocca of Shad and Shad Roe
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Looking for Renewed Magic in Beaujolais
description: YOU dont have to scratch too far under the surface of most wine lovers to find fond, possibly romanticized memories of a special bottle that changed everything for them.

title: Meteorite Hunters (1 Letter)
description: Meteorite Hunters

title: Jonathan Alter Leaves Newsweek
description: Jonathan Alter, a long-time columnist for Newsweek, has left the publication after 28 years there. Though his last day on the Newsweek payroll was over a week ago, Mr. Alter said he had not yet completed my deal with my new employer.

title: Yakov Kreizberg, Orchestral Conductor, Dies at 51
description: Yakov Kreizberg, an internationally known conductor praised for the depth and intensity of his interpretations, died on March 15 at his home in Monte Carlo. He was 51.

title: Previewing Brushstroke, David Bouleys Latest
description: Inside the chefs new Japanese restaurant in TriBeCa.

title: Marvell Co-Founders Sue Goldman Sachs
description: At the height of the financial crisis, two co-founders of Marvell Technology had to sell a big portion of stock in the semiconductor company after a margin call from Goldman Sachs.

title: Giant Toys for Attracting Much Older Boys
description: AN unusual promotion planned for the Indianapolis 500 is based on the saying that the only difference between men and boys is the size of their toys.

title: For Mourners of Knut, a Stuffed Bear Just Wont Do
description: BERLIN  A polar bear died and the zoos director decided to stuff its body and put it on display in a museum. (The director prefers the technical term, dermoplastik, though to most people its stuffed.)

title: Medtronic Bone-Growth Product Scrutinized
description: One of Medtronics most profitable divisions  selling bone growth products used in spinal fusion procedures  faces growing pressure amid a widening criminal investigation into the companys marketing of one product and a rejection by federal regulators of another one.

title: 10 Indicted in Conspiracy to Fix Games at San Diego
description: Two former University of San Diego basketball players and a former assistant were among 10 people indicted as part of a conspiracy to commit sports bribery, federal authorities said Monday. The conspiracy included the operation of an illegal sports bookmaking service and the distribution of marijuana.

title: An Appalachian Radio Voice Threatened From Afar
description: WHITESBURG, Ky.  Rich Kirby, a part-time producer for WMMT3, the community radio station here, was interviewing two local aid officials the other day about the effect of Washingtons proposed budget cuts on this region, in the heart of Appalachia.

title: Masters Ratings Slip
description: Charl Schwartzels stunning victory in the Masters generated a 10.4 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating Sunday on CBS  down from 12.0 last year when Phil Mickelson won and Tiger Woods returned to competitive golf. It was still the second-highest-rated final round in 10 years.

title: Obama, the G.O.P. and the Budget Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: After a Long Wait, Brushstroke Is Poised to Open
description: Unlike an actual brushstroke, there is nothing spontaneous about David Bouleys new Japanese restaurant of the same name. Brushstroke, which has been serving tryout dinners to invited guests in TriBeCa and will open to the public on April 20, took nearly a decade to develop. Even the name has been waiting in the wings since 2007.

title: Mexico: More Bodies Found Near U.S.
description: Mexican authorities said Sunday that they had found 16 more bodies buried in mass graves in the northeastern state of Tamaulipas, raising the total to 88. The victims are believed to have been kidnapped from intercity buses traveling to the United States border. The United States Consulate in the border city of Matamoros said that an American citizen was among those who were reported kidnapped from a bus and was still missing.

title: 88.7 on Appalachias Dial
description: WHITESBURG, Ky.  WMMT, at 88.7 on your FM dial or www.wmmt.org on the Internet, is a rural station that dishes up almost all original programming. Apart from all manner of music, the shows include Holler to the Hood, which plays hip-hop aimed at the growing prison population in the region. The show tapes and broadcasts messages from inmates far-away friends and families.

title: Bob Dylan Revisited
description: To the Editor:

title: Karzai Blames Western Firms for Kabul Banks Troubles
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As a delegation of Afghan officials traveled to Washington to present their plan to international financial authorities to dismantle Afghanistans largest private bank, President Hamid Karzai on Monday denounced Western accounting firms and advisers for corruption and failing to detect the banks troubles.

title: Hedda Sterne, an Artist of Many Styles, Dies at 100
description: Hedda Sterne, an artist whose association with the Abstract Expressionists became fixed forever when she appeared prominently in a now-famous 1951 Life magazine photograph of the movements leading lights, died on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 100.

title: Donald Trumps Letter: An Insight Into the Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq Steps Back Onto the Regional Stage
description: BAGHDAD  On Monday morning, the Iraqi foreign minister stood in a marble rotunda of Saddam Husseins old Republican Palace, once the heart of the American occupation, and noted that this was where the United States held sway when it was trying to help us run our country.

title: Rematch That Has a Lot to Live Up To
description: One coach doused a heckling fan with water. The other became famous for inserting the same profanity in each clause of a long, supposed-to-be-inspirational dressing-room speech.

title: For Mets Manager, Adjustments Are Part of the Job
description: For Mets Manager Terry Collins, lineup tinkering is a way of life. He said Monday that he was not a big believer in the idea of leaving the previous game at the ballpark. Collins said he was still thinking about the next days lineup on his drive home, as his head hits the pillow and over his morning coffee the next day. If that sounds like a lot of work, there is a reason.

title: After Bishops Attack Book, Gauging Bounds of Debate
description: Is God male? The Old Testament uses the masculine pronoun to describe him. Jesus refers to the divinity as Father. So does that make the creator a masculine force  and mean that men are more godlike than women?

title: EQT Nurtures Companies It Buys, Defying Vulture Label
description: Liselotte Sabroe/Scanpix, via ReutersJeff Gravenhorst, the chief executive of ISS, an EQT company.

title: Britain: Sub Crewman Arraigned
description: A 22-year-old navy submarine crewman appeared in magistrates court in Southampton on Monday, charged with killing one of the vessels senior officers and wounding three crewmen in a burst of automatic rifle fire while the submarine was berthed in the citys harbor last week. The suspect, Able Seaman Ryan Donovan, was not asked to enter a plea and will return to court on Wednesday. A police investigation has focused on the gunmans motives, which British newspapers have reported as related to his having been denied use of a crew toilet and a request for shore leave. A navy inquiry is centering on how the seaman was cleared for high-security duty on the missile-carrying submarine despite postings on the Internet that revealed that he had legally changed his name to Reggie Moondogg before joining the navy and had written aggressive rap songs.

title: A Dollar Is a Dollar: Elena Kagans Style
description: When Elena Kagan was nominated by President Obama to be an associate justice of the Supreme Court, some observers speculated that she might be the long-sought liberal counterweight to Antonin Scalia, noted for his intelligence, his wit and his prose style. Of course its too early to tell, but Kagans dissent (her first) in Arizona Christian School Tuition Organization v. Winn would seem to give those distressed by the Courts current direction some hope. (Scalia honed his rhetorical skills as a dissenter earlier in his career.)

title: A Scorecard for Companies With a Conscience
description: Eleven years ago, the Vermont-based ice cream-maker Ben and Jerrys found itself in a position other companies might have found enviable. Several firms were bidding to buy it. The top bid was from the Dutch conglomerate Unilever.

title: Report by Catholic Church Sees Gains on Sexual Abuse
description: An annual report issued by the Roman Catholic Church in the United States found that almost all of its 195 dioceses and archdioceses were in compliance with the abuse prevention plan that American bishops put in place in 2002 in response to the national scandal over clergy sexual abuse.

title: Dance, Laugh, Drink. Save the Date: Its a Ghanaian Funeral.
description: At 2 a.m. on a Saturday in the Bronx, the dance floor was packed, the drinks were flowing and a knot of young women with stylish haircuts and towering heels had just arrived at the door, ready to plunge into the fray.

title: Festive, Fund-Raising Funerals
description: Ghanaian funerals, all-night affairs with open bars and window-rattling music, are festive fund-raisers for bereaved families as well as midnight reunions for immigrants looking to dance off the grind of life in New York.

title: Excerpt: 'War Horse'
description: A clip from the show at Lincoln Center Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Sixty Wins, a Top Seeding, and an Underdog Story
description: The unforeseen, unmitigated feel-good underdog story of the N.B.A. season fits none of the standard profiles.

title: Gas Prices Rise, and Economists Seek Tipping Point
description: Gas prices are approaching record highs, but so far most Americans do not appear to be drastically cutting back their driving or even their spending as they did in 2008.

title: Possible Libya Stalemate Puts Stress on U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Three weeks ago, President Obama ordered American troops into the first humanitarian war on his watch, vowing to stop the forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from massacring their own people. Mr. Obamas hope was that a quick application of power from the air would tip the balance, and the Libyan rebels would do the rest.

title: Budget Cuts Raise Doubt on Course of Recovery
description: WASHINGTON  The budget deal struck last week amounts to a bet by the Obama administration that the loss of $38 billion in federal spending will not be the straw that breaks the back of a fragile economic recovery.

title: Indians Join Fight for an Oklahoma Lakes Flow
description: TUSKAHOMA, Okla.  Sardis Lake, a reservoir in southeastern Oklahoma young enough to have drowned saplings still poking through its surface and old enough to have become a renowned bass fishery, is not wanting for suitors.

title: Angst Over Jeters Hitting Is Off to a Robust Start
description: BOSTON  Derek Jeters problem back then was strikeouts, not groundouts. Inside fastballs gave him the most trouble, and pitchers could sense it. Jeter saw a lot of them early in the 1998 season, when he slumped to a .200 average through the Yankees first nine games.

title: Syrian University Protests Violently Suppressed
description: Pro-democracy protests in Syria spread for the first time to a university campus and were violently suppressed on Monday, a day after the government of President Bashar al-Assad acknowledged that it was using force against protesters.

title: Olympic Medalist Seeking Seat in New Jersey Senate
description: As candidates made their final dashes to enter New Jerseys legislative races, Democrats came up with a little surprise star power on Monday, as Carl Lewis, the former track-and-field champion, entered the race for a seat in the State Senate.

title: The Defenders

title: Stockholders of Big Board Are Lobbied for 2 Deals
description: Richard Drew/Associated PressNYSE Euronext investors must weigh two competing offers.

title: New York Mob Boss to Testify for the Government
description: When he appeared in a Brooklyn courtroom in 2003, Joseph C. Massino claimed to be a restaurateur and the owner of a catering company. This time, he will offer no such pretense; when he takes the witness stand on Tuesday, he will make history as the first official boss of one of New Yorks five mob families to break ranks and testify for the government.

title: Lt. Harleston Brings On the Brick Dust
description: Beneath leaden clouds that streaked across the sky over Charleston Harbor on the morning of April 12, 1861, white smoke curled from the fiery mouths of booming Southern artillery. The acrid smell of saltpeter permeated the air as cannon pounded Fort Sumter with what one newspaper described as an iron vengeance.

title: African Union Attempts to Broker Libyan Cease-Fire
description: As African leaders met with rebel representatives in Benghazi, the fighting between loyalist and rebel forces continued outside Ajdabiya.

title: Physicist Reviews Nuclear Meltdowns
description: WASHINGTON  The three partial Japanese nuclear meltdowns bring the worldwide total to a dozen accidents with reactor core damage since the first one in 1957, and nuclear reactors worldwide are suffering such accidents about eight times more frequently than the United States safety goal, an American physicist said.

title: In Iowa, a Swath of Destruction
description: Fred Standa, the mayor of Mapleton, Iowa, was sitting on his porch Saturday watching the black cloud boiling up from the horizon when storm sirens blared a warning through town. Suddenly the cloud spit out a tornado funnel into the empty farmland.

title: Never Been This Bad, North Dakotan Says
description: Along the Red River Valley, severe flooding has become a rite of spring in recent years.

title: Winds and Dry Land Leave Texas Ablaze
description: HOUSTON  Firefighters struggled on Monday to contain wildfires that consumed more than 480 square miles in West Texas over the weekend, as high winds fanned flames through bone-dry grasslands and scrub and hampered aircraft from dropping water.

title: Vexing Rise in Oblique Injuries, and Little Explanation
description: Nearly everyone has four of them  broad flat muscles, known as obliques, that attach the rib cage and the pelvis on each side of the body and, until recently, have not really been part of the sports lexicon.

title: Republican Medicare Plan Could Shape 2012 Races
description: WASHINGTON  Just four months into their new majority, House Republicans face a potentially defining Medicare vote this week that is sure to become a centerpiece of Democratic efforts to recapture the House in 2012 and spill into the presidential and Senate campaigns as well.

description: WASHINGTON  Mayor Vincent C. Gray was arrested for disorderly conduct on Monday while protesting provisions of Friday nights budget deal in Congress, his spokeswoman said.

description: Some pitchers remember specifics of long-ago confrontations, a fastball that hummed or a slider that hung. Jason Isringhausen is not one of those pitchers. He said he recalled only one detail from his first game in the majors, with the Mets in 1995.

title: Bonds Jury Hears About Injection Again but Reaches No Verdict
description: SAN FRANCISCO  After two full days of deliberations  more than 10 hours of debate  the jurors assigned to determine Barry Bondss fate came up empty again Monday and failed to render a verdict.

title: Poetry for Everyday Life
description: Heres a clunky but unremarkable sentence that appeared in the British press before the last national election: Britains recovery from the worst recession in decades is gaining traction, but confused economic data and the high risk of hung Parliament could yet snuff out its momentum.

title: Pass the Boone Pickens Bill
description: On Wednesday, amid all the hullabaloo over the budget battles, a simple, discrete and largely overlooked bill was dropped into the Congressional hopper. Sponsored by two Democrats and two Republicans  thats right: an actual bipartisan piece of legislation  its official title is the New Alternative Transportation to Give Americans Solutions Act, or the Nat Gas Act, for short. People in the know, however, call it the Boone Pickens bill.

description: NATIONAL

title: Masters Ratings Slip
description: Charl Schwartzels stunning victory in the Masters generated a 10.4 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating Sunday on CBS  down from a 12.0 last year, when Phil Mickelson won and Tiger Woods returned to competitive golf. It was still thesecond-highest-rated final round in 10 years.

Within minutes of calls from a furious skateboarder who had been struck by a vehicle and from people reporting a large, unruly crowd, a three-car crash and a woman screaming on a corner, a man called about a homeless person in his hallway, asleep.

While ruling that public financing and limits on contributions are valid ways to limit donors undue influence, it struck down candidate, campaign and independent spending limits.

description: Famed for his brilliantly colored abstractions full of fanciful imagery, Joan Mir (18931983) ranks with Picasso, Matisse and Van Gogh as a preeminent artist of the 20th century. His work, considered a precursor to Abstract Expressionism, combined Surrealist symbolism with fervent political views; the result is both playful and socially conscious. Though strongly identifying with his Catalan heritage, Mir will soon be making a prominent appearance in London.

title: Digital Diary: Do Social Networks Make You Feel Left Out?
description: On Sunday, I wrote a column outlining my difficulties dealing with FOMO, or the fear of missing out: an unexpected side effect of using social media sites. While tuning into Facebook, Twitter, Foursquare and Instagram can provide a thrilling peephole of the daily lives of our social circle, there can sometimes be a darker side  an odd blend of anxiety, envy, inadequacy and, eventually, irritation that arises by seeing all the cool and interesting activities that everyone you know is up to.

Cooperman, chairman and chief executive of Omega Advisors. The prominent hedge fund player sought to defend the industry, saying it took no money from TARP and outperformed the markets overall. In an interview with CNBC, Mr. Cooperman also speaks in defense of Warren E. Buffett, but adds that David L. Sokol should have sold his shares in Lubrizol as soon as he spoke to Mr. Buffett.
