title: Start the Presses
description: From handmade hair accessories to artisanal pickles, theres a metaphorical back-to-the-land movement for every profession. For graphic design, its letterpress, a labor-intensive printing process that creative types are taking up as an antidote to days spent staring at their iMacs. Produced on antique presses and characterized by heavily impressed lettering on thick paper, letterpress cards and stationery  if youve received a wedding invitation from an even vaguely arty couple in the past few years, chances are it was letterpress printed  are the graphic design equivalent of slow food. For designers who want to unplug, literally, letterpress is a chance to spend time refining their craft using a method that was considered old-fashioned long before the days of Photoshop. People miss the hands-on experience of printing, says Daniel Gardiner Morris, a fourth-generation letterpress printer and the founder of the Arm, the Williamsburg studio where many local printers have learned the basics of handling Industrial Revolution-era machinery. Even if you dont know anything about the process, when you pick up something that was printed on a letterpress, you know theres something different about it. It was touched by human hands. Here, the lowdown on five printers who are getting their fingers inky.

title: New Details Emerge on Sokol and Lubrizol Deal
description: 9:18 p.m. | Updated

title: Crist Apologizes for Misuse of Talking Heads Song
description: Some days Charlie Crist is an ally of rock stars, and some days he is their adversary. On Monday, Mr. Crist, the former governor of Florida who, before he left office, helped champion a posthumous pardon for Jim Morrison, confirmed that he had settled a lawsuit with David Byrne after using a Talking Heads song in a campaign ad without permission, The Associated Press reported.

title: Legislative Leaders Praise Cuomo, Tactically
description: ALBANY  The State Senate majority leader, Dean G. Skelos, patted Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on the shoulder and then turned to a nearby lectern. Governor, I congratulate you, Senator Skelos said.

title: Space Shuttle to Land in Manhattan
description: A space shuttle is coming to Manhattan, but not one of the three that have carried astronauts into orbit.

title: Battle of the Baristas
description: On Sunday, Philip Search, an espresso and coffee consultant for Dallis Brothers Coffee, won the Northeast Regional Barista Competition, three days of competitive coffee held this year at Milk Studios in Manhattan. With the victory, Mr. Search earned a berth in the semifinals of the United States Barista Championship, to be held in Houston later this month.

title: Activist Starts Hunger Strike in Bahrain
description: Updated | 2:21 p.m. After Bahrains interior ministry acknowledged that two political prisoners had died in custody last week, the daughter of a detained human rights activist began a hunger strike on Monday, calling on the authorities to release her father and other members of her family who have been arrested.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: A New Obstacle to College Appears
description: Before my extensive college marathon began, I thought there was only one barrier  an academic one, consisting of standardized tests and rigorous coursework  standing as an obstacle between me and going to college.

title: Going to War: Part 2
description: HELMAND, Afghanistan  Where does a logistics unit like ours fit into a counterinsurgency fight? I put the question to my Marines and didnt get much back, so my fellow platoon commanders and I dived into the topic more completely.

title: Tracing Nitrogens Path Through the Ocean
description: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

title: Westoxification & Modern Toxicity
description: Terms used in India to characterise the adoption of the material trappings of Western life without also embracing Western values of equality.

title: In Rape Trial, Police Vernacular Slips Into 911 Call
description: Anyone can look at a homeless man sleeping in the hallway of an apartment building and describe him as a homeless man, but there is a certain subset of New Yorkers who see the same man and say, male white.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Passion of Joan of Arc
description: This week A. O. Scott looks back at the trial and execution of St. Joan as recounted in the silent classic by the Danish filmmaker Carl Theodor Dreyer in The Passion of Joan of Arc (1928). The film is based on the transcripts from the trial and explores it from a political and religious perspective. Theres something powerful and mysterious about beholding the image of a human face, Mr. Scott says about the films use of close-ups to build a kind of spiritual intensity. The entire first half is a succession of close-ups, which, Mr. Scott says, create a feeling of intimacy and confinement. And the drama, even the narrative itself, are contained within these faces. The film is ultimately more concerned with emotion than politics, making it that much more of a human story. The Passion of Joan of Arc creates an uncanny, unforgettable, almost unique sense of connection to its main character, Mr. Scott says. We may not ultimately understand Joan, but we know her. Have you seen the film? Please share your thoughts.

title: Saudis Adjust Oil Production as World Demand Fluctuates
description: PARIS  Saudi Arabia has maintained its role this year as the worlds oil producer of last resort, the International Energy Agency said Tuesday.

title: Annals of Well, Duh (Commodity Prices)
description: The Chicago Fed has a new paper (pdf) showing that shocks to commodity prices do not, in fact, presage higher core inflation. Actually, its quite a good little piece  and kudos to Charles Evans, the Chicago Feds president, for putting his name on it in these days of fanatical inflation hawks.

title: Selling Your Car? Try Making a Video
description: Thinking about selling your car yourself, instead of trading it in for credit toward a new one? Some amateurvideo recording and smart use of the Web may bring you more offers and a better price, advises the automobile site Edmunds.com.

title: One, But Not Done: Perry Jones Stays in the Game
description: Perry Jones, the Baylor basketball player and subject of my March 13 cover article, is not by nature a contrary person. He likes to do whats expected of him. Its his strength  hes coachable  but also a weakness. Hes compliant, sometimes passive.

title: Solace in the Stadium as Baseball Resumes in Japan
description: CHIBA, Japan  The parking lots around QVC Marine Field were closed because the land underneath them liquefied in the March 11 earthquake. Some scoreboards were turned off to save electricity, and a new inning could no longer begin after a game was three and a half hours old for the same reason. Flags at the stadium were flown at half-staff, and players on one of the teams, the Tohoku Rakuten Golden Eagles, wore patches on their uniforms that in effect urged their fans to stick with it.

title: Texas Governor to View Wildfire Damage
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is scheduled on Tuesday to take an aerial tour of areas damaged by wildfires that continue to burn hundreds of thousands of acres across the state, while rivers in North Dakota and Minnesota are generally receding, officials said, though the risk of flooding is expected to increase again by the end of the week.

title: For Flip Video Camera, Four Years From Hot Start-Up to Obsolete
description: It was one of the great tech start-up success stories of the last decade.

title: Notes From the Underground | Oh Land
description: The Danish recording artist Oh Land performed an hour or so worth of songs at a small gallery space on the Bowery. Hosted by VS magazine, the event was packed elbow to elbow with fans curious to hear the new artists work, including her hit single Sun of a Gun. Oh Land, a stunning blonde, led a minimal band  synth player, a percussionist and three classical musicians; she herself hit notes alternately on a xylophone, a drum machine and what looked like a vintage miniature finger organ. A cloud of white balloons behind her on the stage sometimes carried projections of her face. As sweet as she looks (she was dressed in a shirt adorned with plush toucans), she asked the crowd, earnestly, to keep it down during the quieter songs.

title: Cisco Shutters Flip, Two Years After Acquisition
description: Cisco Systems  which heralded the $590 million purchase of Pure Digital Technologies two years ago  is closing the company, which makes Flip video cameras, as part of a broader effort to restructure its consumer business.

title: A Display of Sportsmanship
description: As we wait for a jury in San Francisco to end the Barry Bonds trial, perhaps tolling the final bell on what we think of as the steroids era, it would be rather heartwarming if the city were the stage for the dawn of another era. How nice if we could use Mondays events to begin an era of civility  although wed settle for the Era in Which Fans Stopped Beating One Another Up  with the Giants dedicating the game against the Dodgers at AT&T Park to the recovery of Bryan Stow.

title: Hope Sprouting Amid Italian Film Studios Decay
description: ROME  It was a sun-kissed spring day here, warm, with swarms of camera-toting tourists congregating in the Piazza del Popolo, fruit and vegetable vendors selling puntarelle at the market stalls in the Campo de Fiori, and Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi poised to go on trial for abuse of power and paying an underage girl for sex.

title: No to Female Golfers, Maybe to Female Reporters
description: Within 30 minutes of the Masters Golf Tournaments stirring conclusion on Sunday, eyewitness accounts rocketed around Twitter that Tara Sullivan, a columnist for The Bergen Record, had been denied access to the locker room at Augusta National Golf Club, where she was to interview Rory McIlroy, who had just posted the greatest last-day collapse in the tournaments history.

title: Energy Options and Polarized Politics
description: The Bipartisan Policy Center, as its name implies, tries to define a path on issues like energy that can work in a period of polarized politics and shrinking budgets. Its a tough challenge. Thats why the new centers latest effort, An Open Letter to the American People and Americas Leaders: A New Era for U.S. Energy Security, focuses arguments for action on oil mainly on the basis of economic and geopolitical conflict, with the environment and climate in the background.

title: Fte Accompli | T Design in Milan
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#671", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Frankly, My Dear, the Windies Do Live for This
description: MARIETTA, Ga.  It doesnt take much to talk Selina Faye Sorrow into slipping on her replica of the dress Vivien Leigh wore in the barbecue scene from the film Gone With the Wind.

title: Making TV Safer: Chinese Censors Crack Down on Time Travel
description: BEIJING  In a bizarre move, Chinas television censors have issued new guidelines that all but ban TV dramas featuring time travel.

title: Coppola Buys His Winerys Old Name Back
description: Its almost enough to make you dizzy: Francis Ford Coppola announced yesterday that his Rubicon Estate, formerly known as the Niebaum-Coppola Estate, will heretofore be known as Inglenook. Say what?

title: A Far Different Albany Debut for This Schools Chief
description: ALBANY  Dennis M. Walcott came to the Capitol two months ago to shepherd around New York Citys new schools chancellor, Cathleen P. Black, and to sit by her side as she testified before lawmakers. On occasion, when lawmakers posed particularly technical questions, Mr. Walcott stepped in to answer.

title: An Economists Argument for More Children
description: The title alone would make you buy this book, no? Called Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids: Why Being a Great Parent Is Less Work and More Fun Than You Think, it is written by Bryan Caplan, an economics professor at George Mason University. His goal is to persuade you that you are trying too hard to make your children turn out good.

title: Political Disputes Cloud Portuguese Bailout Talk
description: LISBON  International creditors started discussing the terms of a bailout for Portugal on Tuesday amid concerns that their initial challenge would be to sort out the countrys political disputes rather than its financial situation.

title: Huffington Post Is Target of Suit on Behalf of Bloggers
description: The Huffington Post is the target of a multimillion dollar lawsuit filed in United States District Court inNew Yorkon Tuesday on behalf of thousands of uncompensated bloggers.

title: Pistons Closing With More Fireworks
description: A season of buffoonery is one step closer to a merciful end for the Detroit Pistons.

title: School Janitor Charged in Rape of Student
description: Updated, 3:35 p.m. | A janitor at a middle school in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, was arrested Monday night on charges of raping a 13-year-old student, the police and an education official said.

title: Kennedy Mania
description: If it seems to you that every time you pick up a copy of Vanity Fair, theres an article about the Kennedys, youre not far wrong. It turns out, according to Eliza Gray at The New Republic, that roughly one thirdof the issues ofVanity Fair since 2003 have contained at least one article about a Kennedy, written by a Kennedy, or mentioning a Kennedy at least seven times.

title: Racing Around the World, Once Again
description: On Thursday morning the green flag will drop on the World Race 2011 as an eclectic group of cars and trucks leaves Times Square, bound for Paris. The event is meant to replicate a 1908 around-the-world race that was sponsored by The New York Times. That first event was won  six months later - by George Schuster, a mechanic from Buffalo, in a machine called the Thomas Flyer.

title: G.D.P. Estimate for First Quarter Slides
description: 2:06 p.m. | Updated  And the year started out so very hopeful.

title: Stolen King Tut Statue Returned to Cairo Museum
description: A gilded statue of Tutankhamun that was stolen from the Egyptian Museum in January has been returned, along with three other objects, Egypts minister of antiquities, Zahi Hawass, announced on Tuesday in a news release on his Web site. The figure is from a statue of the king standing in a boat throwing a harpoon. The looters had broken the figure of the king off the boat, which they left in the museum.

title: Indulging in Gone With the Wind
description: Ardent fans of Gone With the Wind  called windies  are gearing up for the 75th anniversary of the book in Atlanta.

title: A Mafia Boss Breaks a Code in Telling All
description: It was a straightforward question, but not one usually answered by the likes of Joseph C. Massino. At least not with such candor.

title: Vain Glorious | Dude No. 1 Beard Oil
description: Who: Anne McClain, creator of MCMC Fragrances.

title: Hospital Is Drawn Into Bahrain Strife
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  A handful of soldiers, their faces covered by black masks to hide their identities, guard the front gate of Salmaniya Medical Complex. Inside, clinics are virtually empty of patients, many of whom, doctors say, have been hauled away for detention after participating in protests.

title: Part 3: Answers to Readers Decision-Time Questions
description: All this week, Bruce Poch, a veteran of the admissions world who worked at Wesleyan and Connecticut College before serving, until recently, as dean of admissions at Pomona College in California, is answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice.

title: Memories From Big Pink: Robbie Robertson to Write His Life Story
description: In his lyrics and music Robbie Robertson,  the Band guitarist turned solo singer-songwriter, has told the tales of the Confederate soldier Virgil Cane and a mysterious new arrival to a town called Nazareth, but he has never fully unpacked his own life story until now. On Tuesday the Crown Publishers imprint of Random House said that it had acquired a memoir from Mr. Robertson,  one that he plans to write himself after a few curtailed efforts at collaborating on a biography with other writers and journalists.

title: NASA Chooses Space Shuttles Retirement Homes
description: NASAs space shuttles, which have been carrying astronauts aloft for 30 years, were assigned to their final destinations on Tuesday: one will head to the nations capital, another to Los Angeles, and the third from its current home at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida to the centers visitor complex next door.

title: Play Along With Coltrane
description: Dan Cohen (dont know him) posted a transcription of John Coltranes Giant Steps on YouTube that has the notes of the tenor solo pop up on the sheet music as they are played. As a semiretired sax player, I felt a wave of panic set in as the chord changes go flying past. (Thanks to Craig Pittman, author of Manatee Insanity, for posting this on his Facebook page, where I first saw it.)

title: Fill-In | Long-Necked Sauropods
Don Browne to Retire From Telemundo
description: Don Browne, the president of the Spanish language network Telemundo, is retiring, giving the new owner of the network, Comcast, an opportunity to install a new chief.

title: Is Alfa Romeo Still Coming to America in 2012?
description: Fiat Group is denying published reports of new delays in plans to re-establish its Alfa Romeo brand in the United States.

title: Obama to Meet Congressional Leaders Tomorrow
description: 2:43 p.m. | Updated Congressional leaders will visit with President Obama at the White House on Wednesday morning just hours before Mr. Obama gives a speech on his approach to deficit reduction, Congressional sources said.

title: Snapshot of a Fateful Conversation
description: It was 7 p.m. last Wednesday at the Pierre Hotel on the Upper East Side. As far as Cathleen P. Black knew, her future as the chancellor of New York Citys public schools was still secure.

title: Ready or Not, Playoffs Await
description: Over the course of a few hours Monday evening, the Knicks learned their playoff position (sixth), their opponent (the Celtics) and their first-round disposition (likely testy).

title: Capitals, in Familiar Spot, Look for Different Result
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Nobody has to tell the Washington Capitals that the Rangers mean trouble. New York won three of the four regular-season games against the Capitals. Two of those were Washingtons worst defeats of the year, including a 7-0 shutout on Dec. 12. When clubs last met on Feb. 25 the Rangers outscored the Caps, 6-0.

title: The Problem With Multiple Chapter 11 Plans
description: Until October 2005, dueling Chapter 11 plans were a theoretical possibility, but a rare occurrence in reality. The Federal Bankruptcy Code contemplated that a debtor might lose its exclusive right to propose a plan, but bankruptcy courts routinely extended exclusivity and the debtor typically proposed the only plan in the case. The plan was often the result of negotiation and might look very different from the first plan proposed by the debtor, but there was only one plan.

title: Police Officers in Swaziland Squash Rally for Democracy
description: JOHANNESBURG  The police in Swaziland, the last absolute monarchy in Africa, squelched a long-planned pro-democracy rally on Tuesday, firing water cannons and tear gas into crowds in Manzini, the nations largest city.

title: Baryshnikov Strikes Gold With Art Sale
description: Mikhail Baryshnikovs magic extended beyond the stage on Tuesday morning when a panoramic cityscape of St. Petersburg, Russia, by the 19th-century painter Petr Petrovich Vereshchagin sold at Sothebys for $746,500. The dancer bought the painting in 1978 and recently donated it to the Baryshnikov Arts Center in Manhattan, which he established in 2005. The buyer was an unidentified German collector bidding by telephone who paid well above the $500,000 high estimate.

title: At JoeDoe, Its Not Passover Without a Playlist
description: Jill Schulster, who owns JoeDoe in the East Village with her husband, the chef Joe Dobias, has shared the Passover playlist she put together for the restaurants seders. The list is on iTunes, where you can preview and download almost all of the tracks. Here, Ms. Schulster describes how the list was born.

title: Whats With the Fish?
description: This photograph was taken at 9:20 a.m. Tuesday in New York City. Can you write a caption that explains what it depicts?

title: We Shop in Public
description: When it goes live this month, Motilo.com will use features like videoconferencing to allow users to shop with friends and create complete outfits, even if the items are from different online stores. And thanks to social networking components, users shopping predilections will be broadcast to the world, allowing anyone to become a trendsetter. To kick-start the process, Motilos chief executive, Sofia Barattieri di San Pietro, commissioned a bevy of pretty young It girls and stylists, including Valentine Fillol-Cordier, Anna Dello Russo and the D.J. Bip Ling, to share their picks with Motilos users. Soon we want to involve different women, with different backgrounds, ages and charisma, Barattieri says. It is only the beginning. Above, Fillol-Cordier wears a Carven silk-bourette pantsuit and a Lanvin brushed-satin floral brooch, all available at Motilo.com.

title: Barbour Decision on 2012 Presidential Race by End of April
description: There are a lot of people taking aim at Mitt Romney and his health care record these days. Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi is not among them.

title: LPSV
description: Initialism for the mother ships used by Somali pirates: Large Pirate Support Vessels.

title: Mubarak Hospitalized in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Hosni Mubarak, the former autocratic president of Egypt forced out by the revolution two months ago, was abruptly hospitalized on Tuesday in the beach resort of Sharm el Sheik. The state-run daily newspaper Al Ahram said it happened after prosecutors had begun questioning him about charges of possible corruption and other crimes.

title: At Galleon Trial, Flashes of Anger From the Defense
description: Even before the insider-trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam started for the day, members in the courtroom gallery witnessed a clash between the prosecution and defense on Tuesday.

title: Ryans Five-Point Plan
description: I just did a taping for All Things Considered with Douglas Holtz-Eakin, and more or less on the spur of the moment came up with a simple description of the Ryan budget plan. Basically, the plan has five points  except that only two of those points are real, while the other three are fake.

title: Brooklyn Bike Lane Is Scuttled (No, Not That One)
description: Updated, 4:24 p.m. | Cross one bicycle lane off the list.

title: Call for Low Rates Is Lost on Euro Zone
description: The International Monetary Fund appeared to warn the European Central Bank on Monday against further interest rate increases, saying that the euro area is still in a fragile state. The warning may not have much effect, though. The European banks president, Jean-Claude Trichet, emphasized last week that the central bank will not be swayed by outside pressure.

title: Excerpt: 'Happy Endings'
description: The ABC sitcom follows a jilted man, played by Zachary Knighton, and his friends.

title: Gagarin Revisited
description: Tuesday is the 50th anniversary of Yuri Gagarins historic space flight. To mark the occasion, a groundbreaking biography of the space pioneer,published for the first time in the United States this month by Walker & Company, was recently excerpted in our mens issue. Here, one of the books authors, Jamie Doran, revisits Gagarins legacy.

title: Keeping Score on Nuclear Accidents
description: Now that Japan has raised its assessment of the Fukushima accident to a 7 on the International Atomic Energy Agencys scale, equal to the 1986 accident at Chernobyl, it may be time to review past accidents. Thomas B. Cochran, a physicist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, just did that in preparing to testify on Tuesday afternoon before the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee.

title: U.N. Praises Palestinians Progress Toward a State
description: JERUSALEM  The United Nations praised Palestinian Authority efforts at strengthening its institutions in a report on Tuesday, describing aspects of its administration as sufficient for an independent state.

title: Countering the Siege
description: WASHINGTON  Perhaps more than any other American, Gerald W. McEntee has surfed the rising tide of public sector unions to success and power. As leader of the largest union of state and local government workers for three decades, he has amassed enormous political influence and a huge campaign war chest that he has not hesitated to use to advance his unions interests.

title: G.M. Will Accelerate Malibu Production Schedule
description: The next generation of Chevrolets Malibu will apparently be in dealer showrooms sooner than expected. According to a story in Tuesdays Detroit Free Press, production of the 2013 Malibu will begin in January, rather than in May 2012. In confirming the report, a Chevrolet spokesman, Dave Darovitz, said the accelerated program had been requested by Dan Akerson, chairman and chief executive of General Motors.

title: Get With the Programs: Exploring the Implications of Federal Budget Cuts
description: Overview | What do federal budget cuts mean for your state and community? How should Congress decide which programs and services to cut and which to keep? In this lesson, students investigate and make presentations on programs whose financing may be cut in the federal budget. They then discuss and vote on whether these programs should be cut or maintained. Finally, they write letters to their United States representatives and senators.

title: Swimming With the Beautiful People
description: COBI LEVY was greeting guests at the top of the stairs at Niko, his new restaurant in the second-floor space on Mercer Street that used to be Honmura An. He did so with cool professionalism, apparent disdain or bro-hugging intensity, as the situation demanded. His eyes scanned the room constantly, a driver watching his mirrors, keeping an eye on his gauges, going fast at night, destination certain.

title: Reviewing Niko
A New Public-Private Partnership for Patients
description: Federal officials announced a new public-private effort called the Partnership for Patients: Better Care, Lower Costs on Tuesday in which hospitals, doctors, nurses, patient advocates, health plans and employers will work together to try to improve the quality of the nations medical care. The idea is to work together to save lives and money by reducing hospital errors, injuries and complications that could be prevented.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ivory Coast, Libya, Italy and Japan.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ivory Coast and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ivory Coast, Libya, Italy and Japan.

title: Islanders Erase Interim From Capuanos Job Title
description: Jack Capuano was coaching a minor league team in Bridgeport, Conn., in November when the Islanders called and asked him to stabilize their team, which had lost its confidence, several players to injury and 10 games in a row. He did so well as their interim coach that Tuesday, the Islanders gave him the job for keeps.

title: Texas Governor a Winner on School Funds
description: 4:33 p.m. | Updated Among the winners in Friday nights federal spending agreement, count Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

title: Boehner Warns Obama on Tax Increase
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner will issue a warning Tuesday to President Obama a day before the president is set to deliver a major speech on the nations deficit: Raising taxes is unacceptable and a nonstarter.

title: TimesCast | April 12, 2011
description: Japanese officials rate the Fukushima nuclear crisis at the same level as Chernobyl; Japan's baseball seasons opens; and Britain and France urge NATO to intensify airstrikes on Libya.

title: Core Valuables
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#577", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: A Look at the Nuclear Accident Scale
description: As my colleagues Hiroko Tabuchi, Keith Bradsher and Andrew Pollack report, Japan has raised its assessment of the accident at the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant to the worst rating on an international scale, putting the disaster on par with the 1986 Chernobyl explosion.

title: Disclosure Sheds New Light on Sokol Timeline
description: Warren E. Buffett said he held back nothing in a letter announcing the resignation of David L. Sokol, a top Berkshire Hathaway manager.

title: Securities America Said to Reach $180 Million Settlement
description: 7:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Marijuana Growing Gobbles Electricity, Study Finds
description: Dont bogart that megawatt, my friend.

title: The Secret History of Ads in Books
description: Amazons announcement that it will start selling an advertising-supported Kindle at a discounted price has provoked some grumbling about the commercialization of the reading experience.

title: Creators of Smash TV Pilot Are Waiting for the Show to Go On
description: The New York-based creators of Smash  an NBC fall season prospect about the making of a Broadway musical  have concluded filming and editing the one-hour pilot episode and expect to meet soon with their executive producer, Steven Spielberg, to finish a final cut to deliver to NBC, according to Smash head writer Theresa Rebeck.

title: How to Take Home a Piece of Daniel Radcliffe (and Other Tales from Broadway Auction Season)
description: Anyone can buy a T-shirt from the Broadway revival of the musical How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying emblazoned with the face of its star, Daniel Radcliffe. But it takes a truly determined and deep-pocketed theatergoer to go home with a piece of clothing soaked with Mr. Radcliffes sweat.

title: Mexicans Work the Longest Hours
description: According to a new report from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, people in Mexico spend more hours of their day working than the people of any other country.

title: Opening Day in Japan
description: The return of baseball has been infused with meaning this year as Japan struggles to right itself after the earthquake and tsunami on March 11.

title: Tourondel to Open a Midtown Brasserie This Summer
description: Laurent Tourondel is planning to open an American-style brasserie this summer in the new Cassa Hotel and Residences, 70 West 45th Street. Details of the restaurant, including its name, have not been decided, but there will be about 150 seats and it will be open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Mr. Tourondel was once a partner in the BLT restaurants but now remains involved only with BLT Market in the Ritz-Carlton Central Park. He also owns a burger place, LT Burger, in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

title: Are Your Miles a Mess? Heres How to Put Them to Use
description: I used to be a frequent-flier miles skeptic. The rewards system world seemed so overwhelming. Was it worth it to book a more expensive flight to gain miles? And where do I keep my membership number anyway? Do I use a credit card that promises a mile for each dollar spent or the one that gives me 1 percent pure cash back? How about dining in certain restaurants or sending packages by Federal Express just to gain miles?

title: Political Conflicts, Family-Style
description: A cacophony of arguments adds up to chaotic noise. Its the sound of no one being heard, until one voice cleanly breaks through to articulate a point about the Arab-Israeli conflict in 1948. Then that premise is quickly rejected, leading to another theory and counterattack.

title: Before School Ends, Time to Make the Matzo
description: The children filed out of yellow school buses and descended the stairs to the basement of a Jewish community center in Queens, where they put on plastic aprons and paper chef hats in preparation for a lesson on how to make matzo.

title: Eurofile | Bobo Heaven in Paris
description: Peruse the Paris papers these days and youll notice an obsession with bobos: no, theyre not a team of cheerleaders or a troupe of clowns, but rich, artsy types known as bourgeois bohemians, who are now pretty much the tip of Parisian tastemakers. So when friends who were recently staying in Saint Germain des Pres asked me where to go to people watch, I told them to head for the Ninth Arrondissement  citadel of bobo cool.

title: The Battle for Libya | April 12, 2011
description: France and Britain urged NATO on Tuesday to intensify airstrikes against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces.

title: A Farce With Two of a Kind
description: If youre not having fun at The Comedy of Errors, just wait. After a muddled start, this production, by the Acting Company, catches fire, delivering more than enough laughs to make up for its early lapses.

title: Dark Lessons in the Classroom
description: Just when you thought Broadway and especially Off Broadway was suffering from a surfeit of solo shows, along comes The Promise, by Douglas Maxwell, to redeem the format. Thank the stage veteran Joanna Tope; her performance in this production  brought to the 59E59 Theaters by the Random Accomplice company from Glasgow  infinitely enriches a 90-minute parable already loaded with dramatic heft.

title: Why Is This Trial Happening?
description: The insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam has confused me in the same way that it has confused my colleague Andrew Ross Sorkin, who writes in his column today that he would not want to be Mr. Rajaratnams lawyer.

title: The Worlds 50 Best Restaurants? Says Who?
description: IF you had called for a reservation at the restaurant Noma in Copenhagen on Saturday, April 24, 2010, you could have dined there that night. By the time it next opened, the following Monday, you would have faced competition from 100,000 people to get a table. In the intervening 48 hours, Noma had won the top spot on the San Pellegrino Worlds 50 Best Restaurants list.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Nom Wah Tea Parlor
description: BACK in the day, when Chinatown was just three mean streets, Doyers was the kink in it, a dogleg alley barely 200 yards long, its tenements riddled with fan-tan houses and opium dens, its cobbles sweating whiskey and camphor. The tongs went at it down there with hatchets and snickersnees, rival gangs of fallen men with names like Mock Duck and Girl Face.

title: Gin and Passover: No Longer Contradictory
description: Except for matzo, anything thats made with grain is prohibited during Passover. That means the usual spirits distilled from rye, corn or wheat are off limits.

title: Wine Prices Slashed; This Offer Wont Last
description: WHAT do you consider a bargain in wine? Ten percent off? Twenty? How about 40? That was the discount that Wines Til Sold Out offered recently on 2006 Chateau Angelus, a top Bordeaux that was being sold for nearly $100 off its original price of about $250.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Baskets for a Cause

title: Wise for Some Restaurants, Coupons Are a Drain at Others
description: MARC MURPHY, who owns four restaurants in New York, gets pitched by salespeople all the time. But these days most of them seem to be selling the same thing: online deal ploys.

title: Mark Kurlansky Imagines a World Without Fish
description: In his histories of cod and oysters, Mark Kurlansky described how those species once thrived in the wild, and how they were depleted. His latest book casts an even wider net and, with the help of superb illustrations and an interwoven graphic novel by Frank Stockton, creates a compelling narrative for young people and adults. World Without Fish details how humans are destroying ocean life and how that destruction will affect the entire planet. It urges readers to be responsible consumers of fish and avoid threatened species. Beware of fish that is very inexpensive, he adds. Cheap fish has usually been caught in careless ways. The book includes the Monterey Bay Aquariums Seafood Watch chart on seafood to eat or avoid.

title: Coffee Cakes With Mothers Touch
description: In New York, a coffee cake is synonymous with babka, but in the Midwest, it is defined by streusel. A good example is the moist, square cinnamon cake (at left) strewn with streusel and raisins that Dave Evans, a native of Indianapolis, is baking according to the recipe of his mother, Connie Evans. The streusel is on the top and the bottom of the cake. If you serve the cake upside-down and warmed, the topping becomes nicely caramelized. Mr. Evans is also baking and selling his mothers mellow carrot cake, studded with chocolate chips and drizzled with chocolate.

title: For Walcott, a Fast Track to Certification
description: It is full steam ahead for the certification of Dennis M. Walcott to be the next schools chancellor of New York City.

title: In F.D.I.C.s Proposal, Incentive for Excessive Risk Remains
description: Harry Campbell

title: Light Practice Puts Serena Williams on the Road Back
description: It is still a long way back to Wimbledon and the circuit she once ruled, but Serena Williams announced her return to the practice court Tuesday by posting a photograph on Twitter of herself serving in a pink body suit.

title: No Halt to Planned Parenthood Fight
description: House Republicans may have lost their battle against Planned Parenthood in the compromise with Democrats on a spending bill agreed to last Friday, but they will continue to fight the war.

title: Family of Slain Giffords Aide Pushing Restrictions on Ammunition
description: TUCSON  Kelly OBrien lost her fianc, Gabe Zimmerman, on Jan. 8 when a gunman opened fire at a constituent event held by Representative Gabrielle Giffords. Ross Zimmerman lost his son. The two appeared at a news conference in Washington on Tuesday to support legislation banning large-capacity ammunition magazines like the one used in the killing of six people that day.

title: Take Friends to Chicago, Then Hit Fast-Forward
description: In the pre-Facebook era of Friends, the American television audience more or less rolled with the idea that a group of six men and women in their 20s would spend all of their time in one anothers company, confined to a single living room and a cloyingly named coffee bar. By the time we were well into the new millennium, we knew better. Or rather we understood that the only condition in which we might be having dinner with the same people all of the time was if we were sequestered with them on a bizarre island after a suspicious plane crash. And so we watched Lost, with its CliffsNotes philosophies and an implicitly grim view of structured socializing that seemed perfectly suited to the virtual age.

title: Looking Down the Barrel of a Debate
description: Barbara Kopples engrossing, frustrating documentary Gun Fight  its not liable to inspire happy thoughts in people on either side of the gun-control debate  begins with eerie cellphone video footage taken during the Virginia Tech shootings in April 2007, and the aftermath of that rampage provides the films emotional ballast.

title: Small Players Offer Smart Cards, but Not Big Banks
description: You may have read in this newspaper about some Americans having problems  using their credit or debit cards overseas because the cards rely on older magnetic stripe technology. Many countries are switching to more fraud-resistant cards that use tiny chips to conduct transactions.

title: Age Before Beauty? Giggs Gives Manchester United Both
description: Ryan Giggs once again proved that there is often no match for the guile of age  even on a soccer field populated by expensive, mostly young talent.

title: With Season Still Uncertain, N.F.L. Schedules Preseason
description: The N.F.L. announced its preseason schedule Tuesday  for games that might never be played.

title: S.B.A. Spared in 2011 Spending Deal
description: While many federal agencies will take a haircut in the spending bill negotiated last weekend between Senate Democrats and House Republicans  total nonmilitary discretionary spending will be cut by 7 to 8 percent from 2010 levels  the Small Business Administration has emerged from the negotiations largely intact.

title: 5-Year Deadline Sought for Ridding Schools of PCBs
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency and the New York City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, are both calling for replacing school light fixtures that are leaking PCBs in five years or less, putting more pressure on the Bloomberg administration to speed up its planned time line of 10 years.

title: Why Is This Trial Happening?
description: Floyd Norris of The New York Times examines some big questions about the Galleon case: Why is Raj Rajaratnam fighting against what seem to be high odds in his insider trading trial? And what does he have to lose? Read more

title: Video Shows Syria Clash From Two Angles
description: As unrest reportedly continued in Syria on Tuesday, dramatic video posted on YouTube appeared to show an attack on protesters in the southern city of Daraa on Friday, during clashes that left at least 21 people dead.

title: Q. and A. With Mark Kurlansky
description: Mark Kurlansky has described the pleasures and problems of seafood in his books Cod and The Big Oyster.

title: Taking Off the Pounds to Chase a Sun-Powered Victory
description: Just a few days ago, the newest and best hope in American solar car racing improbably rested atop four laundry baskets.

title: U.S. Lagging in Using Technology, Study Shows
description: The United States continues to lag other nations in its use of computing and communications technology, according to an annual study issued Tuesday by the World Economic Forum.

title: Redirecting Cisco by Cutting Sprawl
description: Ciscos chief executive, John Chambers, acknowledged last week that the company he has run for 16 years had lost its way. Now hes putting some money where his mouth is and shutting parts of the overextended networking companys shrinking consumer business. Thats sensible as far it goes. More will be needed to simplify Ciscos sprawl and improve shareholder returns.

title: Abernathy Takes Lead in P.R. League Tables
description: While league table talk tends to revolve around the banks and law firms that put together deals, theres another important class of advisers: the public relations firms who promote the selling of those mergers and acquisitions.

title: Senators Propose New Online Privacy Law
description: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts and Senator John McCain of Arizona on Tuesday made a bipartisan call for new legislation to protect consumer privacy on the Internet.

title: A Pool Man in Chad, at the Intersection of the Personal and the Political
description: The title figure in A Screaming Man never screams or shouts. He rarely raises his voice above the pleasantly conversational and sometimes hardly speaks at all, though his silences can be telling. He works as a pool man in a modest hotel in Chad, where, during the day, he watches over splashing children and lazily sunbathing adults and not much else. Come dusk, he gathers together the wet towels that have been discarded on the chaises and cordons off the pool. His employer calls him by his given name, Adam (played by Youssouf Djaoro, a tall and cool drink of water), but everyone else calls him Champ, a title reflecting a past glory that he wears as proudly as his dazzlingly white uniform.

title: Recipes for the Passover Table
description: Matzo ball soup, short ribs, macaroons and more holiday recipes from The Times.

title: First Family of Writers Grows by One
description: WASHINGTON  In the fall of 2007, while helping her ambitious older half-brother, Barack Obama, campaign for president, Maya Soetoro-Ng holed up in the basement of the Obamas Chicago home to pursue a long-held ambition of her own: writing a childrens book.

title: TimesCast | Season Opener in Japan
description: Ken Belson reports on Japan's baseball season opening after a three-week delay.

title: What to Do With Your Flip Now
description: Ciscos announcement on Tuesday that it would stop making its easy-to-use Flip video cameras leaves something like two and a half million buyers wondering, What now?

title: Republicans Scramble for Votes to Pass Budget Bill
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans scurried on Tuesday to secure the votes needed for a bill that would keep the government financed for the rest of the fiscal year, delaying action by one day to abide by their self-imposed rule to air all legislation publicly for three days before a vote.

title: At What Price Beauty? Check Todays Deal
description: JASMINE CHESS had long wanted to try eyelash extensions, but the high cost had kept them off her beauty shopping list. Then Ms. Chess, 25, saw an offer to buy the service at a reduced rate ($225 instead of the usual $450) on Gilt City, an online portal that sells vouchers to fitness boutiques and spas (along with restaurants and other attractions).

title: Grammy Chief Defends Award Cuts
description: The decision by the group that organizes the Grammy Awards to eliminate nearly one-third of the award categories, announced last week, is meeting resistance from musicians and record producers. They complain that the changes were done behind their backs, are meant to cater to the interests of television and major record labels and that they discriminate against ethnic minorities and performers of genres outside the mainstream.

title: Mixed Martial Arts Makes Inroads in Baseball Training
description: Mixed martial arts may be illegal as a competitive sport in some states, but several baseball players are incorporating its fighting methods into their training routines.

title: Fears About Immigrants Deepen Divisions in Europe
description: ROME  Since the global financial crisis, the European Union has been deeply divided over economic policy. With the Libya intervention, it has split over foreign policy. But today few issues are proving more divisive within the bloc than immigration.

title: Too Much of a Sweeping View Nudges Barcelona to Shed a Law
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Each year since 2004, Jacint Ribas has taken out his bicycle in March, and wearing nothing more than his salt-and-pepper hair, has pedaled it through the streets of this port city. By now he reckons he has covered about 4,800 miles, opening the season for going undressed in public.

title: Budget Deal Deeply Cuts High-Speed Rail Program
description: President Obamas fledgling high-speed rail program was dealt a serious setback by the budget deal that he struck with Republicans last week: new details released Tuesday showed that the agreement will not only eliminate financing for high-speed rail this year, but will also take back some of the money that Congress approved for it last year.

title: Tales of Lives Extinguished All Too Soon
description: What can you say, Erich Segal asked in the first sentence of Love Story, his cathartic heave of a novel, about a 25-year-old girl who died?

title: Yesterdays Shocks, Sounding Lyrical Today
description: When we go to a performance of a once-controversial work, we naturally want to hear what all the fuss was about. A Rite of Spring, say, is good if it conveys some sense of why that ballet incited a riot back in 1913 in Paris.

title: TimesCast | Demanding More From NATO
description: April 12, 2011  John F. Burns and Eric Schmitt report on pressure from Britain and France for NATO to intensify attacks.

title: Ovechkin Scores Less, but Capitals Aspire to More
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  It seems an odd thing to ask whether Alex Ovechkin is mentally ready for the playoffs, but that question was put to Washington Coach Bruce Boudreau on Tuesday on the eve of the Capitals-Rangers first-round series.

title: Ex-Governor Apologizes for Using Song in Ad
description: Some days Charlie Crist is an ally of rock stars, and some days he is their adversary.

title: Piece of the Empire State Building Could Be Yours
description: People who have always wondered what it might be like to dabble in a little New York real estate may soon be able to dabble in a lot of it  by buying a piece of its most famous skyscraper, the Empire State Building.

title: Sampling New Work One Step at a Time
description: The subway ride from Bed-Stuy to Harlem is a long one, giving a dance critic ample time to anticipate nervously the emerging choreographer (that ridiculous term) sampler waiting at the other end. Showcases are not for the faint of heart.

title: Turning 150, but Youthful as Ever
description: Since its founding in 1861, the Yale Glee Club has become one of the best collegiate singing ensembles, and one of the most adventurous. This is the kind of glee club that has been conducted by Krzysztof Penderecki; it is to the television show Glee approximately what the Metropolitan Operas National Council Auditions are to American Idol.

title: Hedge Fund Manager Is Prominent in Mets Picture
description: For weeks, Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire hedge fund manager, has been a mysterious figure in the drama of the Mets, and their financially and legally beleaguered owners.

title: Banks Gaining a Foothold in the Still-Fragile Economy
description: Just two years after the financial panic reached its nadir, the nations biggest banks have regained their footing.

title: Take My Alewife, Please
description: Thank you all for your many dozens of entries on our Whats With the Fish? photo-captioning contest.

title: Impatience Over Recovery at Morgan Stanley
description: A year and a half into a campaign to rebuild Morgan Stanley, some shareholders are losing patience with James P. Gorman, the firms chief executive.

title: Overseas Banks Could Face Novel Penalty From U.S.
description: Amid their widening investigation into banks suspected of facilitating offshore tax evasion by wealthy Americans, the federal authorities are contemplating a novel punishment: a severe monetary penalty normally reserved for individual Americans.

title: Rescuing Ghost Brands From Grocery Limbo
description: What does Kraft Foods have in common with Dan Aykroyd, Ernie Hudson, Bill Murray and Harold Ramis? They are all ghostbusters.

title: Rules for Mortgage Servicers Are Criticized as Ineffective
description: Hopes back in January that the troubled foreclosure process could be fixed with decisive and simple actions have disappeared with the ice and slush.

title: Cinecitt: Romes Fabled Film Studio
description: Photographs of the Italian film studio where for generations some of the most memorable scenes in motion picture history were shot.

title: Maryland: Bill Giving Tuition Breaks to Immigrants Is Sent to Governor
description: The General Assembly has approved legislation to grant in-state tuition to students who are illegal immigrants, opening new possibilities to them as other states consider legislation to restrict the rights of illegal immigrants. The bill would grant in-state tuition to students in four-year universities who had first graduated from high school in Maryland and then attended a community college for two years. They must also show that they or their parents have filed Maryland tax returns for all of those years. Gov. Martin OMalley, a Democrat, is expected to sign the bill into law this month, making Maryland the 12th state to have such a provision, according to Casa de Maryland, an advocacy group for Hispanics.

title: Murphy Returns to the Lineup, but the Mets Are Rained Out
description: Two starts in a row do not a regular job make, but Daniel Murphy was sure pleased to see his name on the Mets lineup card Tuesday for the second straight day. After delivering a few good at-bats and a couple of defensive gems in Monday nights loss to the Rockies, Murphy was scheduled to play second base and bat No. 2 before Tuesdays game at Citi Field was postponed because of rain.

title: A New South City Looks to a Future Not Built on Banking
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Just a few years ago, this city had placed all its eggs in the banking basket, becoming a regional powerhouse and a symbol of the New South after a series of mergers and acquisitions that resulted in the financial titans Bank of America and Wachovia.

title: Salvador Assael, 88, Dies; Coaxed Riches From Pearls
description: Salvador Assael, a titan of the cultured pearl business whose wares were prized for their size, hue and luminosity, died on April 1 in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Group Faults the F.D.A. on Oversight of Devices
description: The Food and Drug Administration is allowing some high-risk devices like artificial hips to be sold without strenuous testing, despite promises that it would address regulatory issues affecting them, a federal watchdog group plans to testify on Wednesday.

title: Diplomatic Breakdown Amid Bieber Fever in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  The teenage pop idol Justin Bieber became embroiled in a diplomatic imbroglio on Tuesday when it emerged that plans for a meeting between the singer and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel had been called off, with the sides differing over why.

title: How to Save a Trillion Dollars
description: In the scheme of things, saving the 38 billion bucks that Congress seems poised to agree upon is not a big deal. A big deal is saving a trillion bucks. And we could do that by preventing disease instead of treating it.

title: High Prices Sow Seeds of Erosion
description: When prices for corn and soybeans surged last fall, Bill Hammitt, a farmer in the fertile hill country of western Iowa, began to see the bulldozers come out, clearing steep hillsides of trees and pastureland to make way for more acres of the states staple crops. Now, as spring planting begins, with the chance of drenching rains, Mr. Hammitt worries that such steep ground is at high risk for soil erosion  a farmland scourge that feels as distant to most Americans as tales of the Dust Bowl and Woody Guthrie ballads.

title: Syria Presses Crackdown in Two Cities on Coast
description: CAIRO  The security crackdown on Syrias coastal region tightened on Tuesday, with checkpoints blocking off access to the city of Baniyas and its outlying areas and a violent raid by government security forces on the nearby village of Bayda, local human rights advocates said.

title: Schneider Electric of France Begins Talks With Tyco
description: 9:32 p.m. | Updated  A French conglomerate, Schneider Electric, has begun takeover talks with Tyco International about a potential deal, according to people briefed on the matter, in what could be one of the biggest deals this year.

title: Stravinsky Invades Mozarts Turf
description: Mostly Mozart this summer will present a mini-series devoted to Stravinsky, as well as Mozarts Don Giovanni with Ivan Fischer conducting the Budapest Festival Orchestra and Handels Orlando performed by the Philharmonic Baroque Orchestra under Nicholas McGegan, Lincoln Center said on Tuesday. The festival, which over the course of its 45 years has often featured composers not named Mozart, is planning nine events that somehow involve Stravinsky  a film program, concerts of his music, performances of works he inspired and a rendition of his Renard by the Mark Morris Dance Group. The International Contemporary Ensemble, a group of about 30 musicians based in Brooklyn and a rising presence on the new music scene, will have a prominent role in the festival, which will run from Aug. 2 to 27.

title: 13 Former Campers Echo Senator Scott Browns Claim of Abuse
description: BOSTON  Thirteen alumni of a Cape Cod summer camp have reported being sexually abused there decades ago since Senator Scott P. Brown revealed that he was groped by a counselor there as a child, a lawyer said Tuesday.

title: Reshaping Medicare Brings Hard Choices
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has deep disagreements with House Republicans about how to address Medicares long-term problems. But in deciding to wade into the fight over entitlements, which he may address in a speech Wednesday afternoon, the president is signaling that he too believes Medicare must change to avert a potentially crippling fiscal crunch.

title: For Flushing and Its Waterfront, Time to Think Big
description: Flushing, Queens, home to one of the largest Asian populations in the United States, is one of the most crowded downtown areas in New York City. The Flushing Main Street stop on the No. 7 subway line was the busiest station outside of Manhattan in 2009, and 19 city bus lines stop downtown, where more than 40,000 people reside.

title: Charles Laufer, Founder of Tiger Beat, Dies at 87
description: Charles Laufer, who as a high school teacher in 1955 despaired that his students had nothing entertaining to read and responded with magazines aimed at teenage girls desperate to know much, much more about the lives of their favorite cute stars, died April 5 in Northridge, Calif. He was 87.

title: Bad X-Rays Found Again at a Brooklyn Hospital
description: Long after a major Brooklyn hospital said it had stopped over-radiating premature babies, state inspectors have found that some inappropriate X-rays were still being administered as recently as January, state records show.

title: Suspected Point-Shaving Scheme Shows Gambling Remains Persistent Issue
description: For all of the suspensions, fines and N.C.A.A. investigations in the past year in college sports, few have posed a threat to the integrity of the games themselves like Mondays announcement that two former University of San Diego basketball players and a former assistant  were among 10 people indicted in a point-shaving scheme.

title: Social Security and Those Who Need It
Jury to Continue Deliberating in Bonds Perjury Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The jury in Barry Bondss perjury trial finished its third day of deliberations Tuesday, leaving the courthouse without giving any hints to which way it was leaning.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,437 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: The Long Goodbye
description: Chapter One: Love

title: The Erratic Knicks Take the Playoff Stage
description: No matter how promising or miserable the Knicks have looked, the ultimate expectation has been that they would make the playoffs and probably lose in the first round. The Knicks have indeed made the playoffs, and they will be a heavy underdog when they play the defending Eastern Conference champion Boston Celtics in the first round.

title: In Role as Teacher, Showalter Remains Student of Game
description: Buck Showalter was excited to be playing his first professional game in June 1977. He kept taking in all the sights at Bobby Maduro Stadium in Miami  including the strange half-field tucked alongside left field, the position he was patrolling.

title: Suit Alleges Bias in Disability Denials by Queens Judges
description: The Queens office that hears appeals of Social Security disability cases is well known to lawyers, judges and many other New Yorkers as an inhospitable place to seek benefits.

title: Imagining the End of the Bush Tax Cuts
description: My column this week examines the political challenge at the center of the deficit debate: the mismatch between the government services that voters want and the taxes that they are willing to pay. I suggest that a deadlock over the Bush tax cuts  expiring on Dec. 31, 2012, as prescribed by current law  may be one of the most plausible medium-term solutions.

title: A New Catholic Mass: More Than Language at Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: A High Cost, to Little Effect, for a Window Into the Mob
description: One day, after a bad couple of hours in court, the mob boss Joseph C. Massino turned to the marshals escorting him to a cell.

title: The Sex Discrimination Lawsuit Against Wal-Mart
description: To the Editor:

title: City Postpones Hiring 540 Police Recruits
description: The Bloomberg administration, laboring under continued budget troubles, said Tuesday that it was shelving plans to hire a 540-candidate Police Academy class that was to be sworn in this month, city officials said.

title: Defense Keeps Its Focus on Galleons Research
description: Louis Lanzano/Bloomberg NewsRichard Schutte, former Galleon president, arriving at court on Tuesday.

title: Lobbyists Won Key Concessions in Budget Deal
description: WASHINGTON  At a quarter till midnight last Friday, with a deal to avert a government shutdown barely an hour old, Senator Harry Reid phoned a fellow Democratic senator, Ron Wyden, at home and startled him with some bad news. You lost free-choice vouchers, Mr. Wyden recalls Mr. Reid telling him.

title: Pace of Attacks in Libya Conflict Is Dividing NATO
description: WASHINGTON  With the United States limiting itself to a supporting role in the conflict in Libya, fissures opened among NATO allies on Tuesday over the scope and intensity of attacks against the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, officials here and in Europe said.

title: Libyan Rebels Set to Talk, but Maybe Not With Qaddafis Ex-Ally
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Rebel leaders here said Tuesday that they were not ready to commit to talks with Moussa Koussa, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis former confidant who defected to Britain but left there for Qatar.

title: Knicks and Celtics Renew Playoff Rivalry
description: Earlier this season, Bostons Paul Pierce quickly and confidently dismissed any notion of a rivalry between his team and the Knicks. Pierce has been a Celtic his whole career, since 1998, and not once during that period had the two teams met in the postseason, when the stakes are higher and rivalries are born.

title: Mixed Martial Arts: A Relatively Benign Sport?
State Liquor Laws: An Industry Response
How Manhattan Drum-Taps Led
description: On the evening of April 12, 1861, Walt Whitman attended a performance of Gaetano Donizettis opera Linda di Chamounix at the Academy of Music, on 14th Street and Irving Place in Manhattan. Just before midnight he was walking down the west side of Broadway, toward the Fulton Ferry to return to his home, in Brooklyn. Suddenly, he later recalled, he heard in the distance the loud cries of the newsboys, who came presently tearing and yelling up the street, rushing from side to side more furiously than usual.

title: Do-Nothing Congress as a Cure
description: WASHINGTON

title: Art and Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Preseason Scheduled Despite Lockout
description: The N.F.L. announced its preseason schedule  for games that may never be played. With court proceedings and labor negotiations expected to last into the summer, training camp and the preseason could be wiped out unless the courts rule that the N.F.L. has to lift the lockout and begin the league year.

title: Japans Reactors Still Not Stable, U.S. Regulator Says
description: WASHINGTON  The condition of the damaged Fukushima Daiichi reactors in Japan is static, but with improvised cooling efforts they are not stable, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a Senate committee on Tuesday.

title: Pray. Hope. Prepare.
description: When I was in Cairo during the Egyptian uprising, I wanted to change hotels one day to be closer to the action and called the Marriott to see if it had any openings. The young-sounding Egyptian woman who spoke with me from the reservations department offered me a room and then asked: Do you have a corporate rate? I said, I dont know. I work for The New York Times. There was a silence on the phone for a few moments, and then she said:  Can I ask you something? Sure. Are we going to be O.K.? Im worried.

title: Despite Poor Race, Uncle Mo Seems Fine
description: Uncle Mo is healthy despite his lackluster third-place finish in the Wood Memorial on Saturday. The colts owner and trainer are still mystified about why he suffered his first defeat in his final prep race before the Kentucky Derby.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 12, 2011

title: Giving Doctors Orders
description: WASHINGTON

title: Spending Fallout Weakens Canadas Prime Minister
description: OTTAWA  The two summit meetings of world leaders hosted by Canada last June might have enhanced Prime Minister Stephen Harpers image as a world leader and bolstered his re-election prospects this year. Instead, the political fallout over the billion-dollar cost and how some of the spending benefited one of his allies threatens to undermine his campaign.

title: Wednesday: Something to Reflect On
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This couldnt have been an easy theme to polish up for publication, and leave it to Liz Gorski to succeed with it. Im going to explain it here, so please avert your eyes if you do not want the theme spoiled for you.

title: From Amphitheater Bit Player to Gods Errand Boy
description: David Greenspan plays a demon sent spinning through time on a mission of salvation in Go Back to Where You Are, his endearingly daffy new play at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Playwrights Horizons. This particular demon was originally a failed actor from ancient Greece named Passalus, and on his sojourn in the 21st century he finds it useful to transform himself into a genteel British matron and former actress named Constance Simmons. All of this whimsy means that Mr. Greenspan the playwright has concocted a honey of a part for Mr. Greenspan the actor, one that allows him to deploy multiple voices and display multiple facets of his baroque, androgynous stage persona.

title: As the Mountaintops Fall, a Coal Town Vanishes
description: LINDYTOWN, W.Va.

title: China: Monastery Sealed Off After Suicide Protest
description: Security officers have placed an important Tibetan monastery in Sichuan Province under lockdown after a young monk committed suicide by setting himself on fire on March 16 to protest Chinese policies in Tibetan areas, according to a report released late Monday by a Tibet advocacy group based outside China. The monastery, Kirti, is one of the most important centers of learning in the region. The report by the group, the International Campaign for Tibet, which has a network of contacts inside Tibetan areas, said that a barbed wire fence was being built behind the monastery, and that armed security officers inside the compound were preventing monks from leaving and food from being delivered.

title: State Senator and 7 Others Plead Not Guilty to Corruption
description: State Senator Carl Kruger and seven other defendants pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to corruption charges in what federal prosecutors described as a broad-based bribery racket.

title: $6.5 Million Settlement in Wrongful Conviction
description: Jeffrey Deskovic spent half of his life in prison for a rape and murder he did not commit, but it was only this week, four and a half years after his release, that he received some measure of justice: a $6.5 million settlement with Westchester County on a federal civil-rights lawsuit stemming from his wrongful conviction.

title: Afghanistan: Envoy in Building as Bullet Hits Window
description: A bullet struck a window of the building in Kabul where the European Unions ambassador to Afghanistan, Vygaudas Usackas, was working Tuesday. No one was injured, and although the bullet left a mark, it did not penetrate the window. European Union officials said they were not sure if the shot was intentional. An investigation is under way, according to a statement from a spokeswoman for the European Union that said the window was bulletproof.

title: Portugals Unnecessary Bailout
description: South Bend, Ind.

title: 4 Die in Smuggling Tunnel Under Gaza-Egypt Border
description: Four Palestiniansdied Tuesday in a smuggling tunnel beneath the Gaza-Egypt border, according to medics in Gaza. Authorities with Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip, said the mensuffocated whilerepairing the tunnel, which they said had been hit by an Israeli missile several days ago during a recent wave of violence. Some people have died in the tunnels in the past after being overcome by fumes while smuggling fuel to Gaza.

title: One Step Forward, 20 More to Go
description: Gail Collins: David, now President Obamas going to make a budget-balancing speech. I guess it could be worse. Its better than having him announce another war. But Ill bet youre more eager to hear what he has to say than I am.

title: A Coal Town Vanishes
description: A small town in West Virginia has essentially disappeared in the wake of the states largest surface-mining operation.

title: Congress, in a First, Removes an Animal From the Endangered Species List
description: Congress for the first time is directly intervening in the Endangered Species List and removing an animal from it, establishing a precedent for political influence over the list that has outraged environmental groups.

title: In Arizona, Taxes Help Hold Down Costs
description: TUCSON  Arnold Mendezs gas station, which was selling regular unleaded for $3.63 a gallon on Tuesday, does not have the cheapest prices in a city with some of the lowest gas prices in the nation. For a better price, Mr. Mendez motioned a few blocks down East Speedway Boulevard to a competitor that beat his prices handily.

title: In California, Strategy as Tough as Traffic
description: WEST COVINA, Calif.  The number 7 had fallen off the sign at the Mobil station just off the San Bernardino Freeway, so it almost looked as if a gallon of gas was just $4.05, a bargain here these days. But sure enough, the correct price was on the pump a few feet away: $4.75.

title: Senators Question Safety of Water Used in Gas Drilling
description: Several Democratic senators said Tuesday that the Environmental Protection Agency should step up regulation of the natural gas industry because they are concerned that toxic chemicals used in drilling could enter the public water supply.

title: Budget Battles: Tax and Spending Myths and Realities
description: Here are two numbers to keep in mind when thinking about the House Republicans budget plan: They want to cut spending on government programs over the next decade by $4.3 trillion. And they want to cut tax revenues over the same period by $4.2 trillion.

title: Ivory Coast Gets a New Chance
description: In his bid to cling to power, former President Laurent Gbagbo unleashed unconscionable violence on his people and brought Ivory Coast to the brink of civil war. When he was finally captured on Monday, photographs showed him as a pathetic, depleted figure. He should now be tried for his crimes. Mr. Gbagbo brought this on himself, and other strongmen and thugs should take heed.

description: CHICAGO  A full week after voters in Wisconsin cast ballots for the State Supreme Court in a volatile, topsy-turvy contest that had become a referendum on the states new Republican leadership, the state was still waiting for the final outcome.

title: Calling Card

title: U.S. Airmen Quietly Reopen Wrecked Airport in Japan
description: NATORI, Japan  Last month, when a team of United States Air Force Special Operations forces reached the damaged Sendai Airport, just a mile from the coast, it found a devastated landscape of uprooted buildings, smashed vehicles and the bodies of the dead.

title: Russia: Moscow Man Sought in Judges Killing
description: State investigators on Tuesday said the police were seeking to detain a 28-year-old Moscow man in the killing of Eduard Chuvashov, a judge who was despised by skinhead groups for his tough sentences in ethnic killings. Mr. Chuvashov was shot in the stairwell outside his apartment one year ago, after extremist Web sites called for his death. The suspect, Aleksei Korshunov, is in hiding, the Investigative Committee said Tuesday. Mr. Korshunov is believed to be a member of a neo-Nazi group called United Brigade-88, and may also be linked to the killing of a young reporter and a human rights lawyer who were shot as they left a news conference in January 2009, according to the Sova Center, a research group that tracks hate crimes.

description: When thinking about the candidates for the 2012 Republican nomination, we can divide them into basically three groups.

title: A Distinctive American Voice, Ever Yearning for Home Sweet Home

Carolina in My Mind, Sweet Baby James, Shower the People, My Traveling Star and You Can Close Your Eyes, all of which he performed at a Carnegie Hall gala concert on Tuesday evening celebrating the halls 120th year, share the same elusive magic. Along with Home on the Range, Red River Valley and Stephen Foster ballads, they seem somehow to have always existed.

description: Silgan Holding, a packager based in Stamford, Conn., said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire Graham Packaging, a producer of plastic containers, for about $1.3 billion in cash and stock as its seeks growth abroad.

title: How to Mend Medicare
description: Changes to Medicare may seem ever more likely, with President Obama expected on Wednesday to talk about ways to lower the deficit and eke savings out from entitlement programs. He is speaking just a week after Republicans laid out a proposal that would privatize Medicare, the insurance program for people over 65.

title: Urban Realist With a Humanist Streak
description: THE half-dozen great or almost-great New York movies Sidney Lumet directed from the late 1950s to the early 80s  for the sake of argument, lets specify 12 Angry Men (1957), The Pawnbroker (1964), Serpico (1973), Dog Day Afternoon (1975), Network (1976) and Prince of the City (1981)  are hardly period pieces. But nowadays it is almost impossible not to look at them that way. These movies are such vivid time capsules of urban life and cinematic style that it can seem as if they must have been intended as such.

title: Sidney Harman, Newsweek Chairman and Audio Pioneer
description: Sidney Harman, the prominent entrepreneur, former government official and owner of Newsweek magazine, died on Tuesday night in Washington, according to a statement by his family. He was 92.

title: Wednesday Reading: How to Really Use Frequent-Flier Miles
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the new that could hit your wallet.

title: Is Paul Ryans Budget Brave?
description: In the week since Paul Ryans budget proposal hit Washington, theres been significant liberal pushback against the idea that Ryan and the rest of the House Republican leadership deserve to be called serious or brave. If Ryan and Co. were actually courageous, the liberal argument goes, they would have proposed raising taxes, or demanded Medicare cuts for current seniors, or otherwise taken on more conservative shibboleths and right-leaning interest groups. Political bravery, in this view, requires more than just proposing a more rigorous version of your own factions usual proposals. It requires breaking out of the partisan box completely, and risking the ire of your own sides ideologues as well as the wrath of your political opponents.

title: Asked and Answered | Ginevra Elkann
description: Ginevra Elkann is a filmmaker who is also the vice president of the Pinacoteca Giovanni e Marella Agnelli, an art gallery in Turin, Italy. (The Agnellis were Elkanns maternal grandparents.) And, as if she didnt have enough on her plate, Elkann has edited a book called May I Introduce You?: A Guide to Creative Talents, which includes interviews with 25 innovators in fields including design (the architect Bjarke Ingels), fashion (Christian Louboutin; Carol Lim and Humberto Leon of Opening Ceremony), business (Henri Seydoux of the wireless device maker Parrot; Yooxs Federico Marchetti), art (Pablo Bronstein) and journalism (Aatish Taseer). Sponsored by Stefanel and published by Electa, the book makes its debut Wednesday in Milan. Last week, Elkann took a few minutes to talk with T.

description: As part of its giant data release on Tuesday, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has put together numbers on the old-age support ratio. That refers to the number of people who are of working age (20 to 64 years old) relative to the number of people over retirement age (older than 65).

title: Sidney Harman, Newsweek Chairman, Is Dead at 92
description: Sidney Harman, an audio pioneer who built the first high-fidelity stereo receiver, dabbled in education and government, and made a late-in-life splash by acquiring an antiquated Newsweek magazine and wedding it with a sassy young Web site, The Daily Beast, died Tuesday night in Washington. He was 92.

Find it at the Economix blog.

title: Bloomberg and Clinton to Merge Climate Groups
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and former President Bill Clinton, two of the most influential spokesmen for environmental sustainability, will merge their global climate groups under a plan announced on Wednesday.

title: Lucerne, a Wagner City, Engages in Yearlong Affair With Brahms
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  Lucerne is having a yearlong affair with Brahms. Through the various parts of the Lucerne Festival, Bernard Haitink has been conducting the Chamber Orchestra of Europe in a comprehensive Brahms cycle. During the piano festival in November, they presented the two piano concertos (with Emanuel Ax as soloist) and the two serenades. In the current Easter festival, they performed the second of three programs on Monday evening, and they offer the third on Wednesday. In the summer festival, in August, they will add two final concerts amid a smattering of Brahms performed by others (Claudio Abbado and the Lucerne Festival Orchestra, Christian Thielemann and the Dresden Staatskapelle).

title: Samurai Shopper | Oil Gusher
description: A number of conventional beliefs simply dont fly, like: political elections equal democracy, or you cant time the stock market. Superstitions involving black cats are easily discredited, but still die hard. (If you step on a crack, you probably wont break your mothers back.) Then theres fortune cookie-esque wisdom: a stitch in time saves nine, I guarantee it. But slow and steady doesnt necessarily win the race, especially if steroids are involved.

title: Rangers Prepare for Life Without Hamilton
