description: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders sought on Wednesday to contain growing conservative opposition to the new 2011 spending deal as the House prepared for contentious back-to-back votes on budget measures.

title: Harman Family to Keep Its Stake in Newsweek
description: In the weeks before his death, Sidney Harman acted every bit the proud new business owner he was. He took part in meetings. When he could not be there in person, he dialed in by video conference. He answered his own phone when colleagues called. And until last Friday he was still discussing the business affairs of Newsweek and The Daily Beast.

title: Courting Disaster the E.T.F. Way
description: It didnt take long for financial engineers to find a new playground. Fresh from dreaming up collateralized debt obligations (C.D.O.s), structured finance specialists are applying similar techniques to exchange-traded funds. E.T.F.s are wildly popular with big and small investors who love the liquidity and diversification such investments promise. But derivatives, special purpose vehicles and skewed incentives, hallmarks of the last boom and subsequent bust, have found their way into E.T.F.s as well.

title: How to Carve a Leg of Lamb in Three Cuts
description: Mark Bittman presents a technique for carving lamb shank in three easy cuts.

title: Yale Student Killed as Hair Gets Caught in Lathe
description: As a Yale undergraduate majoring in astronomy and physics, Michele Dufault was used to extreme physical environments. She worked on underwater robotic vehicles last summer as a fellow at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts. She also traveled to Houston as part of a team of undergraduates chosen by NASA to perform a plasma physics experiment in reduced gravity.

title: Taiwanese Technology Company Is Discussing a Deal With Brazil
description: Foxconn, a Taiwanese technology company, is discussing a $12 billion deal to manufacture displays for computers and tablets in Brazil, Brazilian officials said Tuesday. The technology giant would build a plant in Brazil that would employ about 100,000 workers, including 20,000 engineers, Aloizio Mercadante, Brazils minister of science and technology, told reporters in Beijing on Tuesday. Foxconn could encounter labor issues in Brazil: the country is facing a shortage of technology professionals estimated at 92,000 this year, according to the Brazilian Association of Information Technology and Communication Companies, or Brasscom.

title: Thursday: Get Unhitched
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Is it humid in here or is it me?

title: Particle Hunt Nets Almost Nothing; the Hunters Are Almost Thrilled
description: This could have been the day they discovered dark matter.

title: Raise Americas Taxes
description: President Obama in his speech on Wednesday confronted a topic that is harder to address seriously in public than sex or flatulence: America needs higher taxes.

title: High Costs Linked to Gaps Around Air-Conditioners
description: After embracing environmentally friendly construction, Martin Dunn, a developer of affordable housing in the city, made a frustrating discovery: the energy that he hoped to save with improved insulation and efficient boilers was being siphoned off through gaps around the air-conditioners in apartment windows.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,517 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: A Tragedy in Newburgh
description: Lashanda Armstrongs van rolled off a boat ramp into the Hudson River, killing her and three of her children. Her 10-year-old son survived.

title: Yanks Offense Returns to Support Burnett
description: When mentioned in a baseball context, the phrase its early usually has a negative connotation. It speaks to a teams shaky start, a hitters slump, a pitchers struggles, with the belief  and expectation  that progress is being made. With A. J. Burnett, it seems it is always early  until it becomes too late. There is genuine enthusiasm now surrounding Burnett, whose mediocre personal statistics obscure a more valuable significance.

title: Frustration Finds Its Way Into the Mets Clubhouse
description: Terry Collins came to the Mets last November with a reputation for being passionate and direct, and those characteristics were on display late Wednesday night. Just 11 games into the season, a frustrated Collins addressed his players after their 5-4 loss to the Colorado Rockies, their sixth defeat in seven games, then made his displeasure public.

title: Michael C. Latham, Expert on Nutrition in Developing World, Dies at 82
description: Michael C. Latham, an expert on international nutrition and tropical health who waged a long campaign against the use of infant formula and for the practice of breastfeeding in developing countries, died on April 1 in Boston. He was 82 and lived in Newfield, N.Y.

title: States Look to Ban Efforts to Reveal Farm Abuse
description: Undercover videos showing grainy, sometimes shocking images of sick or injured livestock have become a favorite tool of animal rights organizations to expose what they consider illegal or inhumane treatment of animals.

title: Billy Bang, Jazz Violinist Inspired by Vietnam Experience, Dies at 63
description: Billy Bang, a violinist whose gritty, expressive and spirited playing earned admiration in contemporary jazz circles, died on Monday at his home in Harlem. He was 63.

title: Abraham Rothberg, Who Wrote of Golem and Stalin, Dies at 89
description: Abraham Rothberg, an author whose works, most of them fiction, roamed from the ghettos of medieval Prague through the counterculture upheavals of America in the 1960s to the machinations of Soviet Communism, died on March 28 at his home in Rochester. He was 89.

title: An Exhibition in April Goes to the Celtics
description: BOSTON  In a few days, the venom will fly, vocal cords will fray and a half-dozen All-Stars will tangle and tussle under the TD Garden lights, a rivalry renewed. Until then, all are conserving their fervor.

title: Shakespeare Slept Here, Albeit Fitfully
description: Those pushy Macbeths may be backstabbing social climbers, but you must admit that their new digs are to die for. The Thane of Cawdor and his wife have moved into a deserted hotel in the hinterlands of the West 20s, and my dear, what theyve done with the place. Dont be surprised if it shows up soon on the cover of Architectural Digest, bloodstains and all.

title: Do Cellphones Cause Brain Cancer?
description: On Jan. 21, 1993, the television talk-show host Larry King featured an unexpected guest on his program. It was the evening after Inauguration Day in Washington, and the television audience tuned in expecting political commentary. But King turned, instead, to a young man from Florida, David Reynard, who had filed a tort claim against the cellphone manufacturer NEC and the carrier GTE Mobilnet, claiming that radiation from their phones caused or accelerated the growth of a brain tumor in his wife.

title: Santorum Forms Presidential Fund-Raising Committee
description: Former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania announced on Wednesday that he had opened a presidential fund-raising committee, a step that allows him to explore a bid for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Rangers Fall in a Tightly Played Opener
description: WASHINGTON  If Game 1 was any indication, the opening-round series between the Rangers and Capitals will be short on goals, long on grit and very evenly matched.

title: Resistance to Jaitapur Nuclear Plant Grows in India
description: MADBAN, India  When a farmer named Praveen Gawankar and two neighbors began a protest four years ago against a proposed nuclear power plant here in this coastal town, they were against it mainly for not-in-my-backyard reasons.

title: Word of the Day | chaotic
description: chaotic \ka--tik\ adjective

title: Details of the Deal
description: The 459-page legislation of the budget plan the Democrats and Republicans agreed to in order to avert a government shutdown shows hundreds of reductions to federal agencies and groups.

description: In response to inquiries from The New York Times about how federal investigators and prosecutors had responded to the financial crisis, the Justice Department, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Bureau of Investigation provided the following statements.

title: Who Needs a Beach When Lifes a Goof?
description: Kesha began her show at Roseland Ballroom on Wednesday night within a diamond shape of lights, wearing light-emitting sunglasses, singing and playing two synthesizers on a high platform. She didnt move much, in her torn fishnets and army boots; she was cold, imperious, robotic.

title: What Song/Artist Pairings Would You Like to Hear?
description: A review describes a recent Carnegie Hall concert in which James Taylor and guests like Sting and Bette Midler sang their versions of classic songs including Home on the Range and Penny Lane. Is there a song that you love, whether old or new, that you would like to hear a different artist perform? What song would that be, and whom would you like to hear sing it? Why?

title: NATO Showing Strain Over Approach to Libya
description: BERLIN  NATOs foreign ministers, showing the strains of fighting two wars at once, tried to play down divisions over the intensity of the air campaign against Libya on Thursday, urging patience and resolve as the alliance carried out what one official called a significant level of attacks on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces.

title: The Default Major: Skating Through B-School
description: This article is a collaboration between The New York Times and The Chronicle of Higher Education, a daily source of news, opinion and commentary for professors, administrators and others interested in academe. David Glenn is a senior writer at The Chronicle covering teaching and curriculum.

title: Is Goldman Sachs Too Big to Fail?
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Conveying the Sadness in Japans Stoicism
description: The Associated Press photographer David Guttenfelder, who lives with his wife and two young daughters in Japan, was on assignment in North Korea when amagnitude 9.0 earthquake struck northern Japan on March 11.

title: Colleagues Rebuke Gaza Reports Author
description: JERUSALEM  Three members of the United Nations panel that investigated Israels Gaza war two years ago rejected on Thursday an essay written by the fourth, the former chairman Richard Goldstone, in which he retracted the panels key conclusions, especially that Israel had deliberately made civilians targets.

title: German Firms Move Toward Postnuclear Economy
description: HANOVER, Germany  Josef Mehrer, a family-owned German company established more than 120 years ago, has survived by adapting with the times. Early on, it made sewing machines, then machines for cleaning beer vats, then it switched to compressors in the 1950s.

title: N.F.L. Draft: DeMarco Murray, Fourth-Ranked Rusher
description: Matt Waldman is the author of  The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: The Early Word: Money, Money, Money
description: In Todays Times: President Obama on Wednesday laid out a plan for cutting $4 trillion from the federal budget over 12 years, staking his opening position in a debate that will consume Washington in the coming weeks, as the administration faces off with Congress over raising the national debt ceiling, and into next year, as the president runs for re-election. Mark Landler and Michael D. Shear examine the politics and substance of Mr. Obamas proposal, a mix of long-term spending cuts, tax increases and changes to social welfare programs. Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to lead bipartisan negotiations aimed at reaching a budget deal by the end of June.

title: What Big Medicine Means for Doctors and Patients
description: A colleague described a recent meeting at his hospital by saying that five years ago, most of the physicians in the room had been like him, independent owners of small group practices. Now a majority were employees of the hospital.

title: Gothic Mansion in London Reopens
description: England certainly has its share of castles, but very few are close to the center of London and even fewer are the inspiration behind an 18th-century novel. Strawberry Hills Gothic Mansion is both. Originally built in the late 1700s by Horace Walpole, the politician, historian and novelist, this ornately decorated mansion has recently reopened to the public after an extensive two-year renovation.

title: A Look Ahead to Reveals in Shanghai
description: The Shanghai motor show was strictly a second-rate affair until a few years ago, when China emerged from the dusty backwater of industrialism into one of worlds premier automobile markets.

title: Q&A: Taking the Windows 7 Taskbar to Task
description: Q.

title: In Class of Colorful Freshmen, Meet the Most Contrarian
description: WASHINGTON Representative Justin Amash does not believe the government should subsidize public broadcasting, vehemently opposes abortion rights and thinks Democrats are wrong about spending. Yet he has voted against every Republican measure that conforms to those views.

title: How We Decided to Go Global
description: When I first suggested taking TerraCycles operations global, there was nearly a mutiny among my board members and executive team. No exaggeration, they thought Id lost my mind. As quickly as Id brought up the idea, it was tabled  that is, until I got a phone call in 2008 that set everything in motion.

title: Obama Speech Defends Liberal Principles
description: In the hours before President Obamas 44-minute speech on the nations mounting debt, liberal groups were whipped into a frenzy, warning that Mr. Obama was poised to capitulate  once again, in their view  to Republican philosophy on taxes, the deficit and spending cuts.

title: Vitaly Petrov Describes Crash in Malaysia
description: SHANGHAI  Vitaly Petrov of the Renault team described on Thursday some of the frightening powers that can be unleashed while driving at speed in Formula One  especially during a crash.

description: SHANGHAI  Vitaly Petrov of the Renault team described on Thursday some of the frightening powers that can be unleashed while driving at speed in Formula One  especially during a crash.

title: North Korea Prepares to Indict American
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The North Korean government is preparing to indict an American man it has detained on unspecified charges, saying the man has already admitted his crime, the state news agency reported on Thursday.

title: BP Gets an Extension From Rosneft to Salvage Their Oil Exploration Deal
description: LONDON  The British oil giant BP won a last-minute respite Thursday in its efforts to salvage a share exchange and Arctic exploration agreement with Rosneft, the state-controlled Russian oil company.

title: Ask the Experts About Autism
description: Half a million children with autism will become adults in the next decade, writes Amy Lennard Goehner in todays Times Health Guide, and options to care for them are limited. The good news is that many states are providing more support for people with autism who live with their families and giving families greater flexibility and control over budgets.

title: The Modern Family Musical Is Not a Commentary on Anything
description: This is a purely theoretical sitcom subplot, from Wednesdays episode of Modern Family, about a musical challenged by an incomprehensible second act, a supporting cast hobbled by injuries and a leading man left stranded in midair, and a single-minded director who is all but threatened with mutiny. That could only ever happen on television, not in real life.

title: BP and Rosneft Extend Deal Deadline
description: With the deal looking tenuous, BP and Rosneft agreed to extend the deadline for their share swap agreement  pushing back the date to May 16 from April 14.

title: Visiting the Festival From Home
description: Along with Sundance, the Tribeca Film Festival is leading the way with online and video-on-demand offerings.

title: As Tribeca Festival Turns 10, Grumbling Subsides
description: Yikes! Is the Tribeca Film Festivals 10th year already upon us? It was just the other day, it seems, that the festival barged into the neighborhood and, despite its good will, was greeted with a raised eyebrow by snooty cinephiles for its free-for-all mixture of art, entertainment and community development.

title: Third British Journalist Is Arrested in Phone-Hacking Case
description: LONDON  Police officials said Thursday that they had arrested a third journalist in connection with an expanding case of phone-hacking by reporters at The News of the World, a British tabloid.

title: A Reprieve for Western Water Users
description: Not quite five months ago, on Nov. 27, the level of Lake Mead, the massive federal reservoir that serves faucets and fields in Nevada, Arizona and California, hit an all-time low level of 1,081.85 feet above sea level. Seven feet lower, and the first water shortage ever would have been declared in the rivers lower basin.

title: Mark Kurlansky on Sustainable Seafood
description: Mark Kurlansky replies to readers questions about fishing and the state of the oceans.

title: Morning Buzz | Mommy Just Drove the Car in the Water
description: Thursday will be refreshingly sunny and warm, with highs in the upper 60s.

title: Search for Bodies Edges Closer to Crippled Nuclear Plant
description: The Japanese police moved their search for bodies closer to the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant on Thursday as workers continued to remove radioactive water from the facility.

title: Critical Reports on Banks Weigh on Financial Shares
description: Financial shares tumbled on Thursday after government reports criticized banks involved in the mortgage crisis, but stocks in the broader market were little changed.

title: Part 5: Answers to Readers Decision-Time Questions
description: All this week, Bruce Poch, a veteran of the admissions world who worked at Wesleyan and Connecticut College before serving, until recently, as dean of admissions at Pomona College in California, is answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice.

title: Profile in Style | Ikram Goldman
description: For the Chicago-based retailer, whose eponymous store stocks the likes of Azzedine Alaa (a close friend), Comme des Garons and Nina Ricci, fashion is a family affair. Next month, the shop moves to a sprawling, multilevel space in the citys Gold Coast area. The first floor will feel like your moms supergiant closet, Goldman says, while the second floor will contain a cafe and a gallery curated by Goldman and her husband, Josh. The third will house a playroom for their sons. Like the new store, the familys River North home is filled with vintage and modern pieces, and is as inviting to designer-clad adults as it is to the high-chair set. Go to interactive >>

title: Higher Energy Costs Push Up Producer Prices
description: Producer prices rose 0.7 percent in March, propelled by higher energy costs, in the third consecutive monthly increase of prices before they reach the consumer.

title: Medicare on the Table
description: Probably no other federal program aside from Social Security has as much impact on older Americans and their families as Medicare, now front and center in the intensifying argument over the federal budget and deficit reduction.

title: Almodvar, Von Trier and Malick in Cannes Competition Lineup
description: Were still not entirely sure what Terrence Malicks generational drama The Tree of Life will be, but we can safely say that it will be one of 19 new films contending for the Palme dor at the Cannes Film Festival that were announced by the festivals organizers on Thursday. Also on the feature competition slate for this years festival, which runs from May 11 to 22, are Pedro Almodvars La Piel Que Habito (The Skin I Live In), starring Antonio Banderas as a plastic surgeon seeking his daughters rapists; We Need to Talk About Kevin, a drama directed by Lynne Ramsay (Morvern Callar) and starring Tilda Swinton and John C. Reilly; Melancholia, from the Danish filmmaker Lars Von Trier (Antichrist); Sleeping Beauty, from the novelist turned first-time filmmaker Julia Leigh; and Ichimei (Hara-Kiri: Death of a Samurai) from the Japanese director Takashi Miike. The festivals opening night film, which is not shown in competition, is Woody Allens Midnight in Paris. Other features that will be shown out of competition this year include Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides, directed by Rob Marshall, and, just to make things interesting, Jodie Fosters latest film, The Beaver, starring Mel Gibson.

title: Climate, Communication and the Nerd Loop
description: 4:15 p.m. | Updated |Randy Olson, the marine biologist turned filmmaker and author whos about as far from the label nerd as can be, had his Howard Beale mad as hell moment over climate miscommunication last week on his blog, The Benshi.

description: Iron Mountain, facing a proxy fight led by the hedge fund Elliott Management, said on Thursday that its chairman, Richard Reese, would become chief executive, effective immediately.

title: Up for Parole? Better Hope Youre First on the Docket
description: A new paper finds that experienced parole judges in Israel granted freedom about 65 percent of the time to the first prisoner who appeared before them on a given day. By the end of a morning session, the chance of release had dropped almost to zero.

title: Thtre du Chtelet Aims to Bring Broadway to Paris
description: PARIS  Since his first season as director of the venerable Thtre du Chtelet in 2006, Jean-Luc Choplin has been seeking to marry the sophisticated with the popular, the daring with the safe.

title: Economism and Economites
description: The theory that peoples lives are principally focused on production, exchange, and consumption.

title: Poetry Pairing | April 14, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Judging of Bonds Has Just Begun
description: Barry Bondss statistics cannot be erased. Bonds did not get away with his actions in federal court, where he was convicted of a count of obstruction of justice Wednesday. But in his era Bonds was allowed to stay on the field and hit 762 home runs and win seven Most Valuable Player awards.

title: Questions Remain about Normal Heart Staging
description: The producers of the coming Broadway premiere of The Normal Heart are referring to the show as a presentation, which has prompted more than a few potential audience members to ask whether it will be a staged reading  similar to the one-night-only Normal Heart benefit on Broadway last October  or a standard production where the actors will have memorized their lines.

title: Playoff Preview: Eastern Conference
description: No. 1 Chicago Bulls (62-20) vs. No. 8 Indiana Pacers (37-45)The Bulls finished with 62 wins, the most since Michael Jordan left the organization. The Bulls captured championships in the five other seasons they captured at least 60 wins. Those teams were all led by Jordan. Derrick Rose, who will probably become the leagues youngest M.V.P. winner and would be a college senior at Memphis had he stayed, leads one of the N.B.A.s most balanced rosters, anchored by the solid defenders Joakim Noah and Luol Deng under the first-year coach Tom Thibodeau. Indiana faces long odds in trying to become the fourth team to beat a top seeded team. The Pacers are in the playoffs for the first time in five years and are the only qualifiers with a losing record, but can still be considered a mild threat. They rallied after firing Jim OBrien and attaching Frank Vogel as interim coach. Danny Granger is one of the leagues quality wing players, Darren Collison is one of the leagues quickest point guards and the center Roy Hibbert provides scoring and length.

title: Playoff Preview: Western Conference
description: No. 1 San Antonio Spurs (61-21) vs. Memphis Grizzlies (46-36)

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.Dow Jones: Wall Street wont love the numbers, but there is some good news in this report on restaurant dining: analysts say tap water was the fastest-growing beverage at casual dining chains in 2010.  Sam Sifton

title: Fantasia in D
description: Nowhere was the contrast in views over health care stronger than on drugs. Obama called for using Medicares purchasing power to reduce drug costs; Paul Ryan, in his hissy fit response, held Medicare Part D  which specifically denies Medicare the ability to bargain  as an example of the cost savings that can be achieved through privatization (although he didnt call it that.)

title: Ugandan Opposition Leader Wounded During Protest
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  A former presidential candidate and leading opposition figure was shot Thursday by the military police during a modest street demonstration over rising commodity prices here in the Ugandan capital.

title: Barbour Supports Budget Deal
description: As some conservatives in Congress and Tea Party activists across the country voice their opposition to the budget deal reached last week, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi is defending the agreement as a good first step and urging Republicans to look at the bigger picture.

title: Ready or Not
description: FOR those parents and school administrators who believe it is never too early for students to begin preparing for the PSAT and SAT, the College Board has begun offering a junior version of its marquee college-entrance exams  this one specifically for eighth graders.

title: Arts Group Calls for Worldwide Sit-In for Ai Weiwei
description: Artists and curators will hold a sit-in outside Chinese embassies and consulates on Sunday to protest the detention of the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei. Mr. Ai was detained on April 3; on April 7, a Chinese official told The Times that he was being held on suspicion of economic crimes.

title: A French Vote for More Bikes in the City
description: If you are cranky about all those bicycle paths popping up around the city, you might as well blame it on the French. City Hall legend has it that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg took a liking to the green-tinted lanes after seeing a successful bike network in action on a trip to Paris, which has embraced the two-wheeled lifestyle.

description: Most village residents are opposed to the Jaitapur plant project, arguing that it will kill off their livelihoods and local economy.

title: Mitt Romney and the Nurdles
description: No sooner had Mitt Romney officially announced his intention to run for president then several commentators noted that the R in his newly introduced logo looks quite a bit like the AquaFresh logo.

title: What Code-Breaking Scoop?
description: In his column Secrecy in Shreds, Bill Keller writes that The Chicago Tribune published the fact that the United States had broken the Japanese code and that The Tribune could be successfully prosecuted for such publication. I beg to differ. The Tribune never mentioned that its story was based on broken codes. In order for a successful prosecution, the government would have had to prove that the story was published with guilty knowledge. I do not believe The Tribune had such knowledge.

title: Uncharitable Advice
description: The Ethicist says that taking donations that other people made and passing them off as your own would show an uncharitable spirit. In North Carolina, we call it fraud. There is no difference between defrauding your employer for a charitable reason or for a selfish one. While Ariel Kaminers analysis of how world tragedies can eclipse other genuine charitable efforts was enlightening, the real issue your correspondent raised was whether the noble purpose of enhancing contributions sanctions defrauding an employer. It does not.

title: Bill to Speed Offshore Drilling Clears House Panel
description: Just a week before the one-year anniversary of the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, legislation that would greatly speed the pace of offshore drilling permitting has been approved by the Republican-led House Natural Resources Committee.

title: Ford Widens F-150 Recall by 1.2 Million Trucks
description: Under pressure from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Ford has agreed to recall an additional 1.2 million pickup trucks because the drivers air bag may inadvertently deploy.

title: Walcott Receives Waiver to Be Schools Chancellor
description: Deputy Mayor Dennis M. Walcott was cleared Thursday by the state to become the next New York City schools chancellor.

title: What Deals Could Glencore Make?
description: Glencores long-awaited filing for its initial public offering has ended one topic of speculation, only to stoke another: What deals will the commodities trader make?

description: The official in charge of air traffic controllers for the Federal Aviation Administration resigned Thursday after a series of episodes in which controllers across the country slept as airplanes landed.

title: Shortages of A.D.H.D. Medications?
description: Is your child taking Adderall or Ritalin? Have you had trouble filling their prescription in recent weeks?

title: After Game 1, Capitals Semin Has a Lot to Talk About
description: WASHINGTON  Alexander Semin is something of an enigma. Semin, 27, a Siberian wing, appears to score at will on some nights while taking unnecessary penalties and being otherwise invisible on others. But if the Capitals are to defeat the Rangers in the first round of the 2011 Stanley Cup playoffs, Semin will almost certainly have to play a pivotal role.

title: Media Executive to Run New Jersey Performing Arts Center
description: John Schreiber, a media executive, has been selected as the new president and chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in downtown Newark, the centers board announced on Thursday.

title: Now Dazzling | Museo Soumaya in Mexico City
description: When the pop star Shakira toured Mexico Citys new Museo Soumaya, her guide was none other than the museums founder, Carlos Slim Hel. A labor of love from Slim, the worlds richest man (who is also a creditor and minority shareholder of The New York Times Company), the museum, named after Slims late wife, has certainly got the city  and the art world  talking. Since it opened a couple of weeks ago with a gala attended by President Caldern and Gabriel Garca Mrquez, more than 30,000 curious locals and tourists per day have streamed through its doors. (The museum is free to the public.)

title: Excerpt: 'Wonderland'
description: Janet Dacal and E. Clayton Cornelious in the number "Advice From a Caterpillar," from the new Broadway musical "Wonderland." (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: At Trial, Accuser Recalls, in Pieces, Night of Rape

title: J. & J. Unit Recalls Epilepsy Drug
description: For consumers who have been losing trust and patience with Johnson & Johnson over its manufacturing and quality control issues, the announcement of a recall on Thursday from a company unit that makes neurology drugs may seem all too familiar.

title: Put a Poem in the Pocket of a Poobah
description: This is national Poem in Your Pocket Day. As always, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pulled a poem from his virtual pocket (his iPad) this morning and read it.

title: Sony Pictures Classics to Distribute Polanskis Carnage
description: If you cant easily locate a pair of squabbling, overeducated married couples to eavesdrop on, and dont want to move to New York to do it, you can head to your local movie theater in a few months. Carnage, Roman Polanskis film adaptation of Yasmina Rezas play God of Carnage, has been acquired for distribution by Sony Pictures Classics, which said on Thursday that it plans to release the film at the end of the year. The stage version of God of Carnage, which in 2009 won the Tony Award for best play, chronicles two Brooklyn couples who are brought together by a playground fight between their children, leading to a night of arguing, drinking and vomiting. Its original Broadway cast featured Marcia Gay Harden (a Tony winner), James Gandolfini, Hope Davis and Jeff Daniels (all Tony nominees). The film features a script written by Mr. Polanski and Ms. Reza, and will star Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly.

title: For Many Chinese Men, No Deed Means No Dates
description: BEIJING  In the realm of eligible bachelors, Wang Lin has a lot to recommend him. A 28-year-old college-educated insurance salesman, Mr. Wang has a flawless set of white teeth, a tolerable karaoke voice and a three-year-old Nissan with furry blue seat covers.

title: And Now for Our Special Tonight: The Bartender
description: As an owner and principal manager of Mayahuel, an East Village bar and restaurant specializing in tequila and mescal, Philip Ward has his hands full. Hes there all the time, doing everything from staff scheduling to emergency plumbing.

title: Eighth Graders: Sharpen Your No. 2 Pencils for a PSAT and SAT Scrimmage
description: In a column for this weekends Education Life supplement, I write about ReadiStep, a new standardized test from the College Board that is intended, at least in part, to familiarize eighth graders with the style of questions theyll eventually find on the PSAT and SAT.

title: Altoona Becomes Pom Wonderful  For a Price
description: The documentary filmmaker Morgan Spurlock has found another catchy way to promote his next release, The Greatest Movie Ever Sold, which takes a wry look at product placement and the integration of brands in the plots of movies and TV shows.

title: Infection Could Force Uncle Mo to Miss Derby
description: Uncle Mo has a gastrointestinal infection and may not run in the Kentucky Derby on May 7. The colt was the undefeated 2-year-old champion and the prohibitive 1-to-10 favorite in Saturdays Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, but he ran poorly and finished third behind Tobys Corner and Arthurs Tale.

title: Maya Collapse and Modern Society
description: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes about an expedition to Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan excavated the Maya site of Ceibal.

title: An Outcome With No Winners
description: No matter what you think of Barry Bonds  and an understanding nod to whose who have been trying hard not to think of him at all  it was vaguely possible during his perjury trial to manage a smidgen of admiration for the complete stubbornness with which he approached his unmasking. Could anyone really sit through the revelation of the slimiest side of the steroid scene  his steroid scene  and remain the brick wall that Bonds did? But most likely, he lost even that by flashing a victory sign after it was over. Victory? Really?

title: David Foster Wallace and the Literary Tax Accountant
description: Edmund Wilson was the leading literary critic of his generation. He was also an accomplished tax delinquent. From 1946 to 1955, Wilson did not file any income tax returns. Taxes were withheld from his salary at The New Yorker, but the proceeds from his best-selling novel Memoirs of Hecate County and other freelance work went to pay for his two divorces, three children and various houses. The Internal Revenue Service eventually caught up with him, hitting him with some $68,000 in back taxes and penalties. Even after his death in 1972, his wife was still dealing with the paperwork.

title: Up Front: Tom McCarthy
description: Tom McCarthy, whose brainy, high-concept novels include Remainder and C, was among the corps of early readers who seized on Infinite Jest, David Foster Wallaces postmodern masterpiece.

title: David Foster Wallace: The Last Audit
description: It seems to me there are two ways of understanding the document assembled from a jumble of boxes, disks and printed or handwritten papers that, at the time of David Foster Wallaces suicide in 2008, ran into the high hundreds of pages  a document that, conscientiously and intelligently whittled down by Wallaces editor Michael Pietsch to 500-odd pages, is now being published under the title The Pale King, and, just as significantly, the subtitle An Unfinished Novel.

title: Popcast: Paul Simon, Pruning the Grammys and More
description: In this weeks Popcast, Larry Rohter unravels the controversy over the decision by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences to narrow its Grammy Awards categories; Ben Sisario delivers a progress report on the celestial jukebox; and Jon Pareles explains Paul Simons best record in two decades. Ben Ratliff is the host.

title: Whats in Your Belly Button?
description: Scientists at North Carolina State University have launched the Belly Button Biodiversity project, tracking a variety of microorganisms lurking in human navels, reports MSNBC.

title: Breast Device Recall Made Most Severe
description: The recall of a medical device that left particles of tungsten in womens breasts has been classified as the most serious type of recall, one involving situations in which there is a reasonable probability that use of these products will cause serious adverse health consequences or death, the Food and Drug Administration said on Wednesday.

title: New York School Districts Challenge State Mandates
description: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y.  A roomy yellow bus waited outside the high school in this affluent Long Island suburb, its door open to students headed home at the end of classes. Ten minutes later, it rolled away with 12 riders scattered among the 66 seats.

title: Spotify Puts New Limits on Free Streaming
description: Spotify, the popular European streaming music service, is reducing the amount of music its users will be able to listen to for free, a move that may signal a compromise with record companies as Spotify tries to enter the American market.

title: In Praise of Pink Polish
description: My inbox makes it clear that you want a chance to discuss boys and pink nail polish, aka How a Photo of a Mom Spending Time with Her Son Fed the Culture Wars.

title: Seeing Things | Adam Silvermans Reverse Archaeology
description: The Los Angeles potter Adam Silverman always dreams big, far beyond the scale of the distinctive pieces he makes for Heath Ceramics (where he is studio director of Heath Los Angeles) and for his own Atwater Pottery label. For most of the last year his latest dream has taken him to Fort Worth, where construction is underway on Renzo Pianos addition to Louis Kahns iconic Kimbell Art Museum. Silverman, who studied architecture at the Rhode Island School of Design, was intrigued by the convergence of Piano and Kahn, two of his favorite architects. Add to the mix Tadao Andos new Fort Worth Modern museum next door to the Kimbell, and you have a triumvirate of design giants.

title: Get Bad Loan Terms? Now Youll Get Some Clues Why
description: Did you apply for a loan but receive a higher interest rate than you think you deserve? Youre now entitled to receive a few clues about how the lender arrived at its decision.

title: Budget Deal Cuts Reverse Mortgage Counseling
description: One casualty of the latest federal budget deal: Funds for counseling older Americans seeking reverse mortgages, or loans that let those 62 and over tap their home equity.

title: The Detroit Pistons New Private Equity Driver
description: Chris SchwartzTom Gores coaching a youth soccer team.

title: Theater Talkback: Are Musicals Losing Their Voices?
description: We didnt need dialogue! We had faces! The famous lines spoken by Gloria Swansons decrepit silent-movie goddess Norma Desmond sprang to mind the other night at Avery Fisher Hall during the New York Philharmonics concert version of Company. I imagined there might be a few old-time Broadway performers in the audience muttering similar sentiments to themselves as they watched Lonny Prices vocally vacuous presentation of the Stephen Sondheim-George Furth musical. Back in my day, we had voices! I could picture one seething through his or her teeth to a colleague at intermission.

title: Mayor Shows His Testy Side in Deposition for a Lawsuit
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was patronizing, telling a lawyer who quoted from his memoir that your reading is good. He was unsympathetic, saying that as a hard-driving and ultracompetitive boss, he considered those who left his company disloyal and bad people.

title: N.F.L. and the Players Union See the Same Forest, but Different Trees
description: When they left mediation a month ago, the results of two weeks of conversation provided a convenient Rorschach test for the N.F.L. and the players union.

title: What Were Reading: Takes on the New Budget Proposals
Guess Where This Is
description: Its time to guess the location. This weeks hint: Visitors to this pier, at a seaside town in Europe, have been enjoying warm weather over the past week. Guess the name of the town in comments below.

title: Cocoanista
description: A confectioner who produces limited-edition chocolate collections. (Cocoa + fashionista)Asserting that if chocolatier Jacqueline Jaceks confections had legs, they could walk a fashion runway, The Edmonton Journals Chris Zdeb observed:

title: A Good Samaritan Is Accused of a Bad Deed
description: Updated, 4:14 p.m. | Appearances sure can be deceptive. This video appears to show a heroic chain of events: a tractor-trailer overturns, terrifyingly, speeding around a curve on the Bronx approach to the Robert F. Kennedy Bridge, crushing a van against the guardrail.

title: 2010 Jets: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the A.F.C. East:

title: On Our Radar: Rand Paul Attacks Appliance Efficiency Rules
description: A report by Yang Chuanmin of the Southern Metropolitan Daily on the effects of a toxic spill by Chinas largest gold mining company wins top honors in the second annual China environmental press awards. Even on the hottest summer days, few women wear skirts in Bitian village. They do not want to expose their feet, which are covered with festering blisters from the water of the Ting River, the article began. [The Guardian]

title: House Democrats Win First-Quarter Money Battle
description: The Congressional campaign committees for both parties have been racing to shore up their financial positions ahead of next years election  and so far, the Democrats seem to be off to a faster start.

title: U.S. Says It Shut Down Password Theft Network
description: The Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said on Wednesday that they had dismantled a giant international network of computers infected by malicious software, one that was used in an eight-year financial crime spree.

title: How Parenting Matters
description: Jane Waldfogel, a Columbia University professor who specializes in research on children, is the author of Britains War on Poverty, which was published last year. She previously wrote, What Children Need, an overview of research on child development. Several of Ms. Waldfogels research papers are available from the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: Why Is So Much Marketing the Same?
description: Last week, we presented a positioning deck to a new client, a semiconductor manufacturer. To arrive at a unique positioning statement that differentiates our clients, we generally conduct research and look at many factors, including what the competition is doing and saying in the marketplace.

title: The New School
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#865", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Congress Passes Budget Bill, but Some in G.O.P. Balk
description: WASHINGTON  Congress voted Thursday to keep the government financed through September, putting an end to a raucous first skirmish in this years showdown between Democrats and Republicans over federal spending while presaging bigger ones to come.

title: Chinas Case Against Artist Cites Taxes, Paper Says
description: SHANGHAI  Ai Weiwei, the prominent Chinese artist and social critic who was detained by the police this month, is being investigated for tax evasion, destroying evidence and distributing pornography, according to a Hong Kong-based newspaper with close ties to Beijing.

title: More About the Budget and Health
description: Heres the article by David Ludwig about the relationship between technology and diet that started me down this path in the first place. Really good reading, and not at all technical. (The clinic that Ludwig runs at Childrens Hospital in Boston is dedicated to the evaluation and treatment of children who are overweight/obese and/or those with type 2 diabetes.)

title: Phonetic Clues Hint Language Is Africa-Born
description: A researcher analyzing the sounds in languages spoken around the world has detected an ancient signal that points to southern Africa as the place where modern human language originated.

title: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Uganda, Nepal and North Korea.

title: Knicks Get an Unlikely Proponent: Reggie Miller
description: Reggie Miller, the former sharpshooting guard for the Indiana Pacers, holds no allegiance to either the Knicks or Boston Celtics. Miller, though, caused his share of heartbreak for both franchises, which makes him more than an interested bystander to the approaching first-round series between them.

title: Libyan Port City Is Filled With Migrants Desperate to Exit
description: MISURATA, Libya  The man pressed close, patting the pockets of a foreigner, repeating a single word: Food. Food. Food.

title: Now Serving | Tinys and the Bar Upstairs
description: Three years ago, Matt Abramcyk, 34, was standing around the bar of his now shuttered West Village spot, the Beatrice Inn, with siblings, Jack, 26, and Ana, 29. That night, the fiercely close clan decided to collaborate: Matt had the restaurant experience; Jack was Beatrices head bartender; Ana was chief Champagne drinker, and their father, Israel Abramcyk, who is known as Ray, held the real estate, a landmark TriBeCa townhouse he had owned for more than 20 years. Thus, Tinys and the Bar Upstairs were born.

title: When the Devil Is in the Installation Details
description: In a story in Thursdays Times, I write about the energy wasted when air-conditioners do not fit snugly through windows and walls. The dimensions of the problem are described in a report from the Urban Green Council titled There Are Holes in Our Citys Walls.

title: Medication-Related Injuries on the Rise
description: The number of people treated in hospitals in the United States for problems related to medication errors has surged more than 50 percent in recent years.

title: Berkley to Run for Ensigns Senate Seat
description: Representative Shelley Berkley, Democrat of Nevada, announced Thursday that she would seek the Senate seat held by John Ensign, a Republican who announced last month that he would not seek a third term to avoid what he predicted would be an exceptionally ugly campaign.

title: Iraqi Youths Long for Their Own Moment in the Arab Spring
description: In Iraq, the youth-led uprisings across the Middle East have conjured a range of emotions. Resentment, for the fact that in Egypt and Tunisia and elsewhere the people are seemingly taking control of their future and with their own hands and voices are demanding and achieving change. Iraq, of course, required Americas guns and soldiers to topple an autocratic government. Empowerment, for the events have allowed officials here the confidence to tout their own democracys progress, however violent and fragile it still is. And finally, for the youths of Iraq, the inspiration to demand a more perfect country, despite facing an entrenched political elite that has stood in their way.

title: The Tragic Death of the Flip
description: Day before yesterday, my jaw hit the floor, and I still havent managed to get it back up again.

title: A Good Samaritan Is Accused of a Bad Deed
description: From our colleagues at City Room:

title: Weather Satellites on the Chopping Block
description: As my colleagues Eric Lichtblau, Ron Nixon and I report in summary form in Thursday mornings paper, the budget deal moving through Capitol Hill slashes funds that the Obama administration requested for a satellite program considered vital for the nations weather forecasting. That raises the prospect of less accurate forecasts and other problems, some of them potentially life-threatening, starting in 2016.

title: An Animated City
description: The director Carlos Saldanha discusses setting the animated film "Rio" in his hometown.

title: Pogues Posts: The Tragic Death of the Flip
description: David Pogue mourns the end of the Flip camcorder in a post on his blog.

title: Pain of British Fiscal Cuts Could Inform U.S. Debate
description: LONDON  In the United States, the debate over how to cut the long-term budget deficit is just getting under way.

title: YouTube Sentences Copyright Offenders to School
description: In many countries around the world, if you break the law by stealing copyrighted content you can be sentenced to prison and heavily fined. But if Google catches you breaking copyright laws, the punishment is more akin to being caught smoking in the boys room in high school: Youre forced to take an online class atYouTubes Copyright School.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Quantum of Solace'
description: Marc Forster, the director of Quantum of Solace, discusses a scene from the film.

title: Speed on the Sea
description: Powerboat racing, a sport refashioned in the 1990s to draw spectators and advertisers, was recently showcased in Key West, Fla.

title: Casting Complete for Porgy and Bess, as Henry, Lewis and Grier Join McDonald
description: The American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., has completed the casting for Porgy and Bess, which it is presenting in a new adaptation by Suzan-Lori Parks and Diedre Murray. Joshua Henry, who starred in The Scottsboro Boys on Broadway will play Jake. Philip Boykin is Crown and Trista Dollison is Clara, who sings the signature song Summertime.

title: Hearts, and Lives, Out of Step
description: LAST May I was like a balloon without a string, in desperate need of some tie to the earth. Set to graduate from college a semester early, I had no job lined up and no prospects. And I was suffering from the kind of acute loneliness that comes from dating college guys for whom the word girlfriend does not exist and whose idea of a proposal is sending a graphic, indecent late-night text message.

title: Figuratively Speaking: Exploring How Metaphors Make Meaning
description: Overview | How are metaphors used in both writing and everyday life? What is the role of metaphors in shaping our reality? In this lesson, students raise their awareness of the prevalence and function of metaphors in our everyday language by investigating common metaphors in poetry and song, analyzing the use of metaphors in a variety of short texts and exploring the metaphors in use throughout their daily life.

title: Video Shows Defense of Besieged Misurata
description: My colleague C.J. Chivers reports on Thursday from the besieged Libyan city of Misurata, which he reached on an aid ship chartered by the International Organization for Migration. .bbpBox{background:url(http://a1.twimg.com/profile_background_images/184718761/twitterBgroundImage.JPG) #395c3d;padding:20px;}

title: Wrong Mail
description: I was going through my mail at work when I opened a card that began: Dear Pooky Bear. Horrified, I checked the envelope and saw that it was addressed to a co-worker and delivered to me by mistake. It was an affectionate note, probably from his girlfriend (a k a Princess), and while hardly pornographic, it was personal enough that hed be mortified to know I read it. Should I deliver the note, or save us all the embarrassment and toss it?

title: ARPA-E Is Poised to Put Products on the Grid
description: ARPA-E, the governments incubator for high-risk energy inventions, has its first graduate in the electricity area  a new energy storage technology  and on Thursday it announced a preliminary agreement to get it tested.

title: Mitch Daniels Opposes Arizona-Style Immigration Law
description: Is Mitch Daniels, the governor of Indiana, going to run for president in 2012?

title: City Unemployment Rate Ticks Down to 8.7 Percent
description: New York Citys unemployment rate dropped to 8.7 percent in March, its lowest level in two years, as hiring continued at a steady pace, the states Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: Idol Rules Wednesday Night Ratings, Again
description: The eight remaining American Idol contenders performed music from movies on Wednesday as the reality competition lifted Fox to another easy victory in the prime time ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, 22.4 million viewers tuned in to the 90-minute episode of Idol from 8 to 9:30 p.m.  nearly one full week after the show surprised many faithful watchers with the news that one of this seasons perceived front-runners, Pia Toscano, had been voted off.

title: Get in the Swim
description: Sure, right at this moment you are probably still wearing a coat. And a scarf. And boots. But if you wait until its 70 degrees outside to start shopping for a bikini, chances are what you will find in the stores are next falls coats and scarves and boots. To get you started, here is a guide to the seasons splashiest swimwear trends. From Bottega Venetas technicolor suits to nautical stripes to retro boy-short styles from SUNO, unleash your inner Gidget  or CZ Guest or Kate Bosworth.

title: Beating Tumor, Then Live at the Apollo
description: Danion Jones, 6, who used music to get through a 3-year battle with a brain tumor, sang Wednesday night at Amateur Night at The Apollo.

title: An iPhone Case for Gordon Gekko
description: Upholding the belief that bigger is better, Thumbs Up, a British gadget and novelty company, is offering an iPhone case that resembles the brick, the infamous chunky cellphone that became a status symbol in the 80s.

description: The demise of one of broadcastings oldest institutions, the daytime soap opera, crept closer Thursday as ABC announced it would end two of its long-running daily serial dramas, All My Children and One Life to Live.

title: My Week With Woody Allen
description: Woody Allens new film, Midnight in Paris, will be the opening film at the Cannes Film Festival on May 11; looking even further into the future, Alec Baldwin, Penelope Cruz, Ellen Page and Jesse Eisenberg appear to be part of the ensemble for Allens next film, which will be shot in Rome to continue his European themes of recent years.

title: Judge Says Blagojevich Cannot See Notes From Obama Interview
description: CHICAGO  A judge ruled on Thursday that lawyers for Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, cannot view notes from an interview President Obama had with federal authorities over his former Senate seat.

description: An 11-acre property in Mahopac, N.Y., includes an 1865 farmhouse, a more modern guesthouse, a barn and a pond.

description: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

description: The Business Roundtable, a group comprising 200 of the largest companies in the United States, is out with a study that claims to show that the United States levies excessively high tax rates on companies. It actually shows nothing of the kind.

title: A Weekend in Amsterdam
description: Exploring the citys recent pockets of innovation are worth the detour.

title: 36 Hours in Amsterdam
description: MOST visitors to Amsterdam rarely wander beyond the arched bridges, watery passageways and crooked canal houses of the enchanting city center. But equally fascinating is the development boom around the harbor and in the once gritty areas that lie between the historic center and the surrounding ring road (A10). These pockets of innovation  pioneered Brooklyn-style by young designers and entrepreneurs who cannot afford the rents on the Keizersgracht  are worth a detour. To explore them, just act like a local: hop on a bike and go.

title: Egyptian Military to Review Cases of Jailed Protesters
description: CAIRO  Egypts ruling military council said Thursday it would review court verdicts handed down to hundreds of civilians detained since it took power after President Hosni Mubarak stepped down on Feb. 11.

title: Sloppy Mets Make a Mess of Their First Homestand
description: On the eve of the 2011 season, Terry Collins, the Mets energetic and passionate new manager, said it was vital for the team to get off to a good start in order to instill confidence in the players, and also to demonstrate to the fans that things had changed for the better.

title: Belarus Officials Details on Bombing Raise Questions, Too
description: MINSK, Belarus  The authorities here on Thursday released a few more details about this weeks deadly subway blast, including what they said were freeze frames from surveillance video of the attacker carrying the bomb that killed 12 people and wounded nearly 200.

title: Luongo Looks to Change his Playoff History
description: You cant blame Vancouver Canucks fans for being happy, but still skeptical, about goalie Roberto Luongo.

title: Knockouts
description: The brutal beauty of the boxer has long been captured by photographers and filmmakers, most memorably in Bruce Webers 1987 cult favorite, Broken Noses.Following in this romanticized style comes Repton Boxing Club, a short documentary by Alasdair McLellan, the Britain-based fashion photographer. MeLellans film  sponsored by Sunspel, a historic English underwear manufacturer  centers on a storied boxing club in Londons East London and in particular on Ryan Pickard, the young, squinty-eyed knockout of a narrator. Pickard and his brother spar and sweat like sprinklers in the sun-drenched ring, wearing singlets, tees and fine cotton boxer shorts from the classic Sunspel line. With training time done, Ryan and his mates head to the local cafe to get away from the missus, show off their tattoos and debate whos the greatest fighter of all time. A day in the life of a fighting lad.

title: ABC Cancels All My Children and One Life to Live
description: The demise of one of broadcastings oldest institutions, the daytime soap opera, crept closer on Thursday as ABC announced it would end two of its long-running daily serial dramas, All My Children and One Life to Live. The cancellations will leave General Hospital as the only soap on ABC, and CBS as the only network with more than one soap on its schedule. ABC said it would replace All My Children and One Life to Live with less expensive, unscripted programs. Read more on Media Decoder

This slick new tablet, which is officially called the PlayBook, sports a seven-inch touch-screen, weighs 0.9 pounds and costs between $500 and $700, depending on memory capacity.

title: Car Sharing Start-Ups Bask in Zipcars I.P.O. Glow
description: Zipcar, the car-sharing provider, raised $174.3 million in an initial public offering Thursday morning, marking a first for a segment once dominated by nonprofits and local community organizations. The strong showing could be a boon for new companies aiming to make money through alternatives to vehicle ownership.

description: The New York painter Josh Smith calls Peter Brant the guy with the eye. Its an apt phrase for a well-known talent spotter and dealmaker who was in his 20s when he met Warhol and has since amassed one of the largest holdings of work by that Pop Art master. (Mr. Brant also owns Interview Magazine, which Warhol founded in 1969.)

title: Budget Compromise Slashes Funding for Weather Satellites
description: The budget deal moving through Capitol Hill slashes funds that the Obama administration requested for a satellite program considered vital for the nations weather forecasting. That raises the prospect of less accurate forecasts and other problems, some of them potentially life-threatening, starting in 2016. Jane Lubchenco, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, warned at a Senate hearing on Wednesday that the cutbacks would probably lead to a serious gap in satellite data, undermining National Weather Service forecasts. Read more on Green.

title: Going Public, Zipcar Revs Its Engine
description: With an initial public offering on the Nasdaq, Zipcar, Inc. raised more than $174 million. The company has yet to make a profit, but investors are betting its lead over competitors will pay off.

title: The Mountaintop Will Come to Broadway
description: The Mountaintop, Katori Halls play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will make it to Broadway this fall, but with only one of the two high-profile actors who were expected to appear in it. Producers for the play said on Thursday that Samuel L. Jackson, the Academy Award-nominated star of Pulp Fiction, would portray Dr. King in the production, to be presented at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, with previews beginning Sept. 22 and an opening on Oct. 13; Kenny Leon, a Tony Award nominee for last years revival of Fences, will direct. Halle Berry, who was supposed to play Camae, a hotel maid at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis in Ms. Halls imagined account of the night before Dr. Kings assassination, will not be participating in the production as had been anticipated. In a statement, producers said, Ms. Berry would not be appearing in the role due to child-custody issues. The Mountaintop, which made its debut in London in 2009, won Ms. Hall the Olivier Award for best new play last year.

title: A Country Searching for Engineers to Serve Its Nuclear Needs
description: NEW DELHI  Besides political protests, Indias nuclear energy ambitions face another big roadblock, critics say: a shortfall of trained people to run, repair and regulate power plants.

title: A Fantasy World of Strange Feuding Kingdoms
description: With the amount of money apparently spent on Game of Thrones, the fantasy epic set in a quasi-medieval somewhereland beginning Sunday on HBO, a show like Mad Men might have the financing to continue into the second term of a Malia Obama presidency. Game of Thrones is a cast-of-at-least-many-hundreds production, with sweeping Braveheart shots of warrior hordes. Keeping track of the principals alone feels as though it requires the focused memory of someone who can play bridge at a Warren Buffett level of adeptness. In a sense the series, which will span 10 episodes, ought to come with a warning like, If you cant count cards, please return to reruns of Sex and the City.

title: Dance Listings for April 15-21
description: Dance

title: An Intimate Setting For a Range of Intensity
description: There is a very particular relationship between dancer and audience in a small space: emotions and expressions are palpable, effort and intensity clear. Thats the advantage of the tiny theater in the basement of the Museum of Arts and Design, where the monthly series Dance Under the Influence began in February. The disadvantage is that the stage is just eight feet deep. As Ronald K. Brown, one of the performers on the program Wednesday night, put it after the show, You cant really do a diagonal.

title: The Language, and Footwork, of Farewell
description: Dance Theater Workshops final season is drawing to a close. Who knows what the future holds for New York Live Arts, as the institution will be called upon merging with the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company? But it is a pleasure to report that with The Making of Americans, the last workshop commission to have its premiere on the main stage, a very special theater is going out on a very high note.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: Art

title: Frenetic Intimations of, Yes, Positivity
description: TV on the Radios frontman, Tunde Adebimpe, liked the view from the stage at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night. Many tiers, many levels, he said. Speaking of many, many levels ... , he said, trailing off as the band started the hurtling beat and buzzing synthesizer bass line of the next song, Dancing Choose. TV on the Radios longtime mission has been to pack its songs with as many levels and layers of sound and sense as they can hold. It crams together funk and rock, soul and punk, anthem and noise, insight and rant, apocalypse and dance frenzy, brains and muscle.

title: Forward-Looking Sculptures by a Man Straddling Two Worlds
description: In the decades before World War II, many artists were thrilled by the steel- and fossil-fuel-based technology embodied in trains, planes and automobiles, and edifices like the Eiffel Tower and the Chrysler Building. Few were more inspired by the promises of industrial modernity than the sculptor John Storrs.

title: Easter: Raising Voices
description: A sampling of choral works for the Easter season in New York. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: Easter: From Pipes to Poetry
description: A sampling of seasonal celebrations in New York, including dance, drama, readings and processions. Admission is free unless noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: Paradise Is Only Half the Story in a Complex Caribbean Nation
description: Ian Thomsons book The Dead Yard, a bleak and prickly survey of Jamaicas past and present, takes its title from one of that countrys funeral practices. When someone dies, those who loved him or her gather around the dead persons house for a wake that can last as long as nine days. These events are often ecstatic; theyre akin to reggae versions of a New Orleans jazz funeral. People dance, the author writes, as if possessed by ghosts.

title: Spare Times for April 15-21
description: Around Town

title: Italian Activist Kidnapped in Gaza
description: Update | 8:57 p.m. After this post was originally published, a Hamas security official told Reuters and The Associated Press that an Italian peace activist kidnapped in Gaza has been killed. The official said that the Italian activists body was found in an abandoned house after midnight local time and two men were arrested. My colleague Fares Akram in Gaza is working to confirm these reports and will have more information soon in his new article.

title: Two Points of View, Miles Apart
description: IT might be simplistic or a little silly to say that Robert Whitman  the performance pioneer who is probably the least known member of the vanguard that gave birth to the American experimental theater scene in the 1960s  basically foretold the creation of the Internet in his work. But when you consider the evidence, its hard not to believe he created it himself. Decades before YouTube and years before the video camera became a common artists tool, Mr. Whitman, a kind of junkman of fleeting imagery, extolled the virtues of television as a great way to collect stuff; besides whats on the air, a camera on anything brings it in live. In 1972, in News, the first of his telephone pieces, he enlisted people around the city to use pay phones to call in descriptions of what they were doing or seeing at that moment, which the radio station WBAI broadcast live, a kind of aural Twitter stream. In one of his earliest theater pieces, American Moon, in 1960, he split the audience apart in separate tunnels to give each person a slightly different sense of the action. In doing so, he fulfilled what the curator Lynne Cook once described as his distinctive desire to work collectively to construct an experience intended for the solitary individual, a phrase that could just as well describe a lot of the social and cultural architecture of the Web.

title: The Worlds Largest Dinosaurs
description: Images from the show at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: In Dinosaur Science, Size Is Just the Beginning
description: Before entering the fascinating new exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History, The Worlds Largest Dinosaurs, which opens on Saturday, walk through the Hall of Saurischian Dinosaurs where the composite skeleton of the Apatosaurus reigns, the core of its 140-million-year-old frame seeming almost incidental to its stupendously sweeping neck and tail. The weighty immensity of these fossilized bones once earned this creature  one of the largest to have plodded the planet  the name of thunder lizard (Brontosaurus).

title: The Mountaintop Will Come to Broadway, With Jackson but Without Berry
description: The Mountaintop, Katori Halls play about the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will make it to Broadway this fall, but with only one of the two high-profile actors who were expected to appear in it. Producers for the play said on Thursday that Samuel L. Jackson, the Academy Award-nominated star of Pulp Fiction, will portray Dr. King in the production, which will be presented at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, with previews beginning Sept. 22 and opening Oct. 13; Kenny Leon, a Tony Award nominee for last years revival of Fences, will direct. Halle Berry, who was supposed to play Camae, a hotel maid at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis in Ms. Halls imagined account of the night before Dr. Kings assassination, will not be participating in the production as had been anticipated. In a statement, producers said Ms. Berry would not be appearing in the role due to child custody issues, and that an actor for the role will be announced shortly. The Mountaintop, which made its debut in London in 2009, won Ms. Hall the Olivier Award for best new play last year. The play is produced by Jean Doumanian Productions, Sonia Friedman Productions, Ambassador Theater Group, Jerry Frankel, Ted Snowdon, Bob Bartner and Tom Wirtshafter.

title: Meat Discovered in Meatless Magazine
description: Vegans and vegetarians are known to be clever about food substitutions: baking with applesauce in place of eggs, turning tempeh into sausages. But it seems that VegNews, a San Francisco-based vegetarian lifestyle magazine, has been doing things the other way around: using photographs of meat and dairy to stand in for the stand-ins.

title: Ville Platte Highs Last Game
description: The Ville Platte High Bulldogs may have played their last football game as their Louisiana school faces an uncertain future.

title: Starving Food Banks
description: Increasing numbers of people seek help from the nations struggling food banks.

title: For Sale: A Home for Artists
description: The home of Pen and Brush, a century-old former club in Greenwich Village devoted to female artists and writers, is for sale.

title: Sketches From the Man Of Steel
description: Few artists have pushed drawing to such sculptural and even architectural extremes as Richard Serra. He has magnified the medium with immense black shapes that sit directly on the wall, their absorptive darkness forcing the space around them to expand or contract. Using black oil paintstick, he has exaggerated drawings physical surface, creating expanses of texture that have the rough tactility of bark, or massing dark, roiled spheres as thick as mud pies.

title: Theater Listings: April 15  21
description: Theater

title: Spare Times: For Children for April 15-21
description: BOOM TOWN

title: More Drama for an Opera, Not All of It From the Singers
description: CHICAGO  When Georg Solti conducted the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and Chorus in two concert performances of Verdis opera Otello at Carnegie Hall in 1991, the drama centered mainly on the Otello, Luciano Pavarotti. No, make that melodrama, bordering on circus.

title: Orchestral Recitations Of 2 Symphonic Poems
description: We accept without much question today that orchestral music can tell a story or evoke a particular scene. Like many things we take for granted, though, this idea needed to be invented, which Liszt did with a series of 13 symphonic poems based on sources as disparate as a contemporary painting and Hamlet.

title: The Battle for Libya | April 14, 2011
description: There was fresh discord within NATO on Thursday over arming the rebels and the bombing campaign.

title: Science and Secrets in New York City Playgrounds
description: A BRONZE dragon. Squares that chime underfoot. A gargantuan seesaw that allows a few children to lift many. And water, water everywhere.

title: Extraordinary Play
description: A look at five of the most unusual playgrounds in New York City.

title: Morgan Stanley Chief Gets a Pay Cut of $1 Million
description: Even though James P. Gorman was promoted to chief executive of Morgan Stanley last year, he received a $1 million pay cut, as his total compensation fell to $14 million, the firm disclosed Thursday in a regulatory filing.

title: U.S. Groups Helped Nurture Arab Uprisings
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the United States poured billions of dollars into foreign military programs and anti-terrorism campaigns, a small core of American government-financed organizations were promoting democracy in authoritarian Arab states.

title: Jazz Listings for April 15-21
description: Jazz

title: Tennessee Williams: Life Is All Memory
Tribeca Returns
description: Stephen Holden narrates a look at some of the selections in the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Dunkin Brands Hires JPMorgan and Barclays to Lead I.P.O.
description: JPMorgan Chase and Barclays Capital have won an underwriters bake-off that was a little sweeter than usual.

title: For One Last Weekend, a Chance to See Spider-Man 1.0
description: The Green Goblin will live  into Act II.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: Classical

title: Hey, Short- Timer, Park It Here
description: FOUR adults, 3-year-old twins and a new baby in a two-bedroom Manhattan apartment?

title: License Plate Reading Cameras Gain Legal Backing
description: Last year, as the police in New York were ramping up their reliance on license plate reading cameras as a new crime-fighting tool, a Manhattan judge affirmed their use as lawful and valuable in taking guns off the streets of the Bronx.

title: Sanctuaries of Sound to Observe the Easter Holiday
description: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and other sites in New York, from Friday through Easter Sunday, compiled by Anne Mancuso. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

title: Whos the Mayor of City Hall?
description: Whos the mayor of City Hall?Thats a question Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will face on Saturday, New Yorks first official Foursquare Day.

title: Living In | Prospect Heights, Brooklyn
description: Prospect Heights is an evolving neighborhood that is also a blend of the old and the young, the established and the newcomers.

title: Historys Loose Ends, and a Tightening Noose
description: I happened to see The Conspirator, a new historical drama directed by Robert Redford, on the day that the Obama administration, reversing its earlier position, announced that Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four others would be tried by a military tribunal for their suspected roles in the Sept. 11 attacks. This coincidence underscored the films topical relevance, which was hardly obscure to begin with. Its theme is the rule of law in the aftermath of a national tragedy, the assassination of Abraham Lincoln, who died on this date  April 15  in 1865. What might have been an antiquarian courtroom drama or a belated eruption of Bush-era civil libertarian outrage has been given potent and painful currency by recent events.

title: Tucked Between Past and Future in Brooklyn
description: ON the north side of Prospect Heights in northwestern Brooklyn, construction workers are busy building the Barclays Center, the future home of the New Jersey Nets.

title: Europa Cup Semifinals an All-Iberian Affair
description: The word for Europe in Portuguese is Europa, which seemed appropriate Thursday after three Portuguese clubs  Porto, Benfica and Braga  advanced to the semifinals of the Europa League.

title: Risky Short-Term Debt Is Creeping Back
Pawn, Prize and Beauty, So Submit She Must
description: There are times when the lights are low and the bodices have been gently loosened that The Princess of Montpensier, a rousing amalgam of ambition, moods and genre conceits, looks like one of those old-fashioned diversions in which swords clang as bosoms heave with sweet passion. The pretty bosom of the title character played by Mlanie Thierry tends to swell rather gently, but it also rides so high in her dresses that it evokes the temptations displayed in the windows of Parisian patisseries. The French director Bertrand Tavernier deploys some smart ideas in this film, a period story about wars on the battlefield and those closer to home, but theres something a bit goatish in his attention to some female charms.

title: Ford Lists 25 E.V.-Ready Cities
description: Ford has just released a list of the 25 most electric vehicle-ready cities in the United States, and, no great surprise, it looks very much like the initial list of urban areas slated to get the new Focus Electric when it rolls out late this year. Only a few of the cities are additions, including Baltimore, Dallas, Hartford, Honolulu and Charlotte, N.C.

title: Broker Fee Rules Take Effect
description: THERE have been changes in federal rules covering how mortgage brokers are paid, and while legal challenges to them persist, the question now is how the new system will work in practice.

title: Q & A
description: Shareholders Avoiding Conflict of Interest

title: Michael E. Shields
description: Mr. Shields, 43, is the managing director of ING Real Estate Finance (U.S.A.), which has a $6.7 billion portfolio of term loans, construction loans and subordinate debt.

title: A Hint From Scion: It May Be the FT-86 Sports Coupe
description: The slinky video teaser from Toyotas Scion brand is all shadows and highlights, and speculation is that the concept car set for unveiling at next weeks New York International Auto Show will be a version of the long-anticipated FT-86 sports coupe.

title: Weekend Miser
description: As Jim Morrison sang, People are strange. And no one knows that better than the Coney Island Museum. Its Congress of Curious Peoples, also sponsored by the Morbid Anatomy Library, wraps up on Saturday and Sunday with a symposium featuring experts on the art of curiosities and a visit to Sideshows by the Seashore. The Fairground and the Museum: Human Anatomy on Display, The 19th Century Dime Museum in the Contemporary Imagination and Science and Technology for Public Amusement are a few of the themes that will be discussed by scholars like Norman M.
