Klein, author of The Vatican to Vegas: A History of Special Effects, and Alison Griffiths, author of Shivers Down Your Spine: Cinema, Museums & the Immersive View. ($25; sideshow visit, $10; Coney Island Museum, 1208 Surf Avenue, near West 12th Street, Brooklyn; (718) 372-5159, spectacularium.org/congress-of-curious-peoples.)

title: Electoral Shifts
description: The wide array of demographic groups that shifted toward the Democrats in the presidential election.

title: House Tour: Mahopac, N.Y.
Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 12:15 P.M.
Something New and Sparkly
description: HAVING lived primarily in postwar high-rises, Jordan Kingston envisioned a charming brownstone as her next home. An entire ground floor would be best, with a garden out back and a welcoming door that I could put a wreath on for the holidays, she said.

title: Fortunes and Misfortunes of War, From a Danish Perspective
description: The history of modern war is also, in part, the history of the means by which war has been brought home to noncombatants. Certain conflicts became known through  and are now remembered by  specific image-making technologies. The Civil War is identified with the battlefield photographs of Mathew Brady and others; World War II coincided with the maturation of motion pictures; Vietnam came into American living rooms via television. In each case the specific properties of a given medium helped to shape public perception of the war and its effects.

title: Principal Cleared of Charges in Confrontation With Teacher
description: A Brooklyn public school principal who had been charged with assaulting a teachers union representative in a 2009 confrontation in his office has been cleared of all charges, the Brooklyn district attorneys office said.

title: Hamas Says It Found Body of Italian Activist
description: GAZA  A radical, Al Qaeda-inspired Islamic group in Gaza said Thursday that it had kidnapped an Italian citizen in the Palestinian territory and threatened to execute him unless Hamas, which rules Gaza, released the groups imprisoned leader by 5 p.m. on Friday.

title: Nuclear Cleanup Plans Hinge on Unknowns
description: TOKYO  Even before the troubled Fukushima nuclear plant has been brought under control, two conglomerates vying for contracts in an eventual cleanup are estimating that the effort could take 10 years  or 30.

title: Obamas Debt-Reduction Panel Idea Gets Little Traction
description: The bipartisan Congressional team that President Obama proposed this week to negotiate a long-term debt-reduction plan with the White House is shaping up to be smaller and less ambitious than he spelled out  that is, if it gets off the ground at all.

title: T.V.A. Considers Improvements for 6 U.S. Nuclear Reactors
description: WASHINGTON  The Tennessee Valley Authority said Thursday it was considering millions of dollars of improvements to protect its six nuclear reactors from earthquakes and floods.

title: Romance or Film Noir? Both, and a Thriller
description: Attention armchair sleuths: After viewing the Italian psychological thriller The Double Hour, you may want to see it a second or even a third time to decipher its secrets. The movie, which won its stars, Ksenia Rappoport and Filippo Timi, awards at the 2009 Venice Film Festival, will put mystery bloodhounds on a scent that after about the 20-minute mark is suddenly lost.

title: The Game Is American, but the View, Alpine
description: LANDQUART, Switzerland  This town, cradled by snow-capped Alpine peaks, is not Green Bay. Not that it isnt trying: it has plenty of cheese, this being Switzerland, and it has football  the American kind.

title: When Female Artists Were Storming the Gates
description: In !Women Art Revolution, Lynn Hershman Leesons new documentary about the female artists of the 1970s and 80s who fought to break through into the male-dominated American art world, a film crew asks people outside the Whitney Museum in New York in 2008 and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 2009 if they can name three female artists.

title: Hard-Pressed Homeowners Facing Another Financial Threat
description: Estrella Bryant was at risk of losing her San Francisco town house last year.

title: Bands Promote Awareness, and Giggles, but Arent Lewd
description: Baby-pink ribbons they are not. But a federal judge in Pennsylvania has ruled that I  Boobies bracelets  worn as breast cancer awareness accessories  are not lewd, either, and overturned a ban on them at a public middle school there.

title: Obamas Budget Plan: A Scorecard
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Natural Gas the Solution to Our Energy Problem?
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Repair, as an Art and a Science
description: If Mitchell Zelmans customers are sorry to see him, hes not offended.

title: Burden of Student Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: No Football? No Problem for Oakland
description: As the National Football League lockout enters its second month, cities across the country are scrambling to make contingency plans to deal with lost revenues if the season is canceled. But not Oakland, home of the leagues most enigmatic franchise, the Raiders, where an exceptionally one-sided stadium deal means that the beleaguered city may actually save money if the team doesnt play.

title: Trepidations Aside, On the Road Becomes a Movie at Last
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: My Good Internet Habit
description: To the Editor:

title: Kid Gloves and Bowie Knives
description: New York, April 15, 1861

title: migrs in New York Who Arent Outsiders
description: The Manhattan subculture of upscale bohemian migrs examined in The Imperialists Are Still Alive! is a world that, so far as I know, hasnt been explored from the inside with any depth. As you observe its central character, Asya (lodie Bouchez), an ambitious conceptual artist, zip around New York in cabs and limousines, visiting art galleries and popping into parties, a multicultural vision of urbanity coalesces that is very different from that of a typical movie of impoverished immigrants trying to assimilate in an outer borough.

title: The Importance of the Family in a Childs Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Somalia, Wobbly on Ground, Seeks Control of Its Airspace
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  With pirates running rampant offshore and Islamist militants boxing lawmakers into a corner of this bullet-ridden capital, the beleaguered Somali government does not control its land or its seas.

title: Admitting Clients Are Drug Traffickers, but Denying Guilt
description: As the trial began last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan, the lawyers for three West African defendants made a series of highly unusual admissions: One after another, they told the jury that their clients were involved in the global drug trade.

title: Inaugural Spenders Will Pay Rahms Party Tab
description: Big-money donors will pay up to $50,000 for exclusive access to premium events celebrating Rahm Emanuels inauguration next month, but the public will benefit, too, because those large contributions will also finance free events open to all.

title: A Tea Party Congressman Cultivates His Base
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Psychologist Who Cleared Death Row Inmates Is Reprimanded
description: A psychologist who examined 14 inmates who are now on Texas Death Row  and two others who were subsequently executed  and found them intellectually competent enough to face the death penalty, agreed on Thursday never to perform such evaluations again. Lawyers for the 14 inmates hope the agreement will help their clients, who they argue are mentally handicapped, to escape lethal injection.

title: Red State Home Companion
description: POCATELLO, Idaho  It gets pretty lonely out here on the lava beds of the Snake River Plain if youre looking for something other than a right-wing rant for company on the car radio. From Twin Falls to Idaho Falls, Rush Limbaugh, Sean Hannity, Laura Ingraham and Glenn Beck rule the airwaves. Beck is on two stations in Pocatello, case you missed one of his conspiracy theories.

title: Trump Mulls Announcement on Apprentice
description: Donald Trump acknowledges that he has a very tough decision to make regarding his potential run for president as a Republican candidate, but he has a plan for how and when he may make it.

title: School District Considers Property Tax Increase, and Layoffs if It Is Rejected
description: The Chicago Public Schools are considering an $80 million property-tax increase as they try to close a budget deficit now estimated at $820 million, and they may have to lay off more than 2,000 teachers and increase class sizes without it, according to internal documents obtained by the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Let Us Eat Fish
description: Seattle

title: The Shrieks Continue
description: Like its predecessors, Scream 4 replaces the values of storytelling and suspense with the value of being in on the joke. Unfortunately, in the 11 years since Scream 3, the joke has gotten pretty old.

title: The Guns of Academe
description: Los Angeles

title: A CD-Only Music Store That Plays to Its Own Beat
description: One of these days, Chris Miller is going to run out of space for compact discs at his CD-only music shop, Chicago Digital, in Oak Park. Last week he had to put a second shelf in the restroom. It extends from the top of the toilets water tank to the ceiling and accommodates classical composers from Liszt, Franz, through Mozart, W. A.

title: A Motley Consensus on the Afghanistan Line Item
description: It isnt every day that liberals like Representative Jim McGovern, a Democrat from Massachusetts, appear at Capitol Hill news conferences with conservative stalwarts like Representative Walter B. Jones, a Republican from North Carolina.

title: Despite Setbacks, Arizona Sheriff Wont Yield the Spotlight
description: MESA, Ariz.  It is not uncommon for law enforcement agencies to have helicopters and planes to patrol from above, but Joe Arpaio, the sheriff of Maricopa County, has created what he calls his own air force: a collection of 30 private planes that his air posse uses to track illegal immigrants and drug smugglers.

title: 16 Officers Arrested in Mexico Deaths
description: MEXICO CITY  The authorities have arrested 16 police officers and charged them with protecting a criminal gang suspected of murdering dozens of people and dumping their bodies in farmland about 90 miles south of the Texas border.

title: In Miami, There is Smoke, but No Fire for the Heat
description: MIAMI  With a roster headlined by LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Chris Bosh, the Miami Heat, at least in theory, has enough star power to effortlessly rally a city and pump up a crowd.

title: Macaw Finds His Wings, and Much More, in Brazil
description: Maybe it was just a longing for warmer climes and springs arrival, but Foxs Rio had a killer opening overseas. Maybe it was because this animated feature effort is a significant step forward from the studios Ice Age films, in the richness of its cast, the exuberance of its music and the vibrance of its palette. Or maybe it was because the director, Carlos Saldanha, is from Rio de Janeiro, the principal setting, bringing a wealth of affection to it. Whichever. It works.

title: Unruly G.O.P. Puts Boehner to a Test in Budget Vote
description: WASHINGTON  It should have been a moment of victory for Speaker John A. Boehner and fellow members of a House Republican leadership team still learning on the job as they forced through a record level of spending cuts. Instead, it felt a little like defeat.

title: Spending Agreement Hurts Police and Fire Agencies
description: It may have kept the federal government from shutting down, but the budget agreement that President Obama struck with Congress will make it harder for some struggling cities to keep their police stations and firehouses staffed.

title: Lincoln Declares War
description: Lincolns Proclamation of April 15 is not a literary masterpiece. Nor was it trying to be. There was more urgent business to attend to  namely, the raising of 75,000 volunteers to defend Washington from attack. And yet, like every public document that issued from his pen, it is suffused with the particular phrasings of his mind. When seen in its handwritten version, below, courtesy of the Library of Congress, it is more clearly something that came from him, and not simply the great bureaucracy he personified as president. There are deletions, and inserts, and all the signs of a writer struggling to get it just right.

title: Ethical Businesses With a Better Bottom Line
description: On Tuesday, I wrote about B Corps, or benefit corporations. These are companies that have changed their bylaws to take into account the impact of their decisions on the environment, community and employees, as well as profits. To become a B Corp, a company must also get a passing score on an assessment of its business practices administered by a nonprofit group called B Lab. About 400 companies have become B Corps, and the idea is spreading fast.

title: Japan Opposition Leader Urges Premier to Resign
description: TOKYO  The leader of Japans largest opposition party called Thursday for Prime Minister Naoto Kan to resign, abruptly ending an uneasy political truce forged after the devastating earthquake and tsunami.

title: Budget Deal Fuels Revival of School Vouchers
description: In the 11th-hour compromise to avoid a government shutdown last week, one concession that President Obama made to Republicans drew scant attention: he agreed to finance vouchers for Washington students to attend private schools.

title: Family Portrait
description: The flashback gets so much use in filmmaking that sometimes it just feels like a lazy way to spring a surprise or give a thinly drawn character an excuse for his actions. But in The First Beautiful Thing, the Italian director Paolo Virz gambles his whole film on the well-worn technique and comes out a winner.

title: This Lady Liberty Is a Las Vegas Teenager
description: As if further proof were needed that New York is not the center of the universe.

title: Syrian Government Offers Mixed Message to Protesters
description: CAIRO  Ahead of another day of planned antigovernment protests on Friday, President Bashar al-Assads government in Syria took several steps  including announcing an amnesty for some prisoners  to try to satisfy the growing numbers of demonstrators who have taken to the streets in recent weeks.

title: Cellphone Calls May Offer Insight Into Serial Killer
description: Shortly after a 24-year-old prostitute went missing in July 2009, a mysterious male caller used her cellphone to repeatedly taunt her teenage sister, and, in one harrowing conversation, confess to her murder, several people with knowledge of the phone calls said.

title: Galleon Chief Put Millions Into Fund of Ex-Employee
description: 9:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Arthur Marx, Who Wrote About Groucho, Dies at 89
description: Arthur Marx, who wrote screenplays for film and television and a best-selling book about his father, Life With Groucho, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: Tangled Verdict Gives Bonds Defense Hope
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The lawyers for Barry Bonds did not consider it a failure that he was convicted Wednesday of obstructing justice for giving evasive answers to a grand jury more than seven years ago.

title: Randy Wood, Founder of Dot Records, Dies at 94
description: Randy Wood, who started out stocking records in a nook of his electrical appliance store before going on to found Dot Records, a label that found success in the 1950s recording white artists like Pat Boone singing black artists rhythm-and-blues songs, died on Saturday at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 94.

title: Stop the Blame Game
description: After more than two weeks under attack by NATO forces, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is still slaughtering his people and showing no sign that he plans to give up. NATO and coalition partners are pointing fingers of blame at each other for this frustrating state of affairs, but what they should be doing is creating a renewed sense of common purpose and direction.

title: Colorful Lives and Tragic Deaths
description: Yet another love letter to a Hollywood long gone, Footprints swoons over its familiar locations so exorbitantly that only those who live close by (like the films writer and director, Steven Peros) are likely to share its rapt gaze.

title: They Gather Secretly at Night, and Then They (Shhh!) Eat
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Along with big-wave surfing and high-altitude ultramarathons, eating is an extreme sport here. Which explains why, on a recent Saturday night, Tipay Corpuz, 21, a technology specialist for Apple, took a break from blogging about her obsession with fried chicken and waffles to join 2,500 fellow food geeks at the Underground Night Market.

title: An Undemocratic Bailout
description: Portugal needs international help to meet its debt obligations. But the insistence by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund that the caretaker Portuguese government commit to a long-term plan of fiscal austerity and economic reform in exchange for a rescue package is misguided.

title: The Republican Medicare Reshuffle
description: Representative Paul Ryan and the House Republicans are portraying their budget proposal for the next fiscal year as a courageous effort to finally bring federal spending on Medicare under control. An analysis issued last week by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office finds that the Ryan proposal would sharply reduce federal spending  but at the price of shifting more of Medicares costs onto beneficiaries and their families.

title: At Nursing Homes, Fears of a Budget Armageddon
description: The Texas Legislature is faced with a budget challenge that has pitted the Republican majoritys desire to cut government spending against a vulnerable target: nursing homes.

title: Memo to Arizona Republicans: Papers, Please
description: The Republicans who control the Arizona Legislature are back at it. The Senate just passed a bill that would bar presidential candidates from the ballot in Arizona unless they submitted extensive paperwork proving they were natural-born Americans.

title: A Younger Group for Feminine Products
description: Some girls get their period as young as 8, begins a section for mothers on a Web site by Kotex, the feminine products brand. Have you had the talk?

title: Bryant Should Have Been Forced to Sit
description: If the N.B.A. really did care, as its slogan suggests, Kobe Bryant would be sitting out Game 1 of the Los Angeles Lakers playoff series Sunday against the New Orleans Hornets.

title: Arrested Development and Second Chances
description: The title character of Garth Donovans Phillip the Fossil walks a meandering line between antihero and hero. A superannuated New England townie  at 29 (or so), he might as well be 50 to the teenagers he hangs out with  Phillip sells steroids to the local jocks and has sex with high school girls while also trying to turn his life around by taking over a landscaping business.

title: Pressure Grows to Unwind CVS Merger
description: CVS Caremark is coming under increasing pressure from consumer groups and shareholders to split up, at the same time that federal and state regulators are looking into accusations of anticompetitive behavior by the merged company.

title: Equality in Numbers, but Not in Political Clout
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Ex-Mob Boss Tells Jury, Calmly, About Murders
description: The cross-examination of a Mafia turncoat started quietly and predictably enough on Thursday. Joseph C. Massino, the former boss of the Bonanno crime family, spoke matter-of-factly about having to kill one of his closest associates, simply because he had disobeyed protocol.

title: Price of Tomatoes Has a Lot to Do With These Thefts
description: The high price of produce, especially for tomatoes after the deep winter freezes, has attracted more than heightened attention from consumers. A ring of sophisticated vegetable bandits was watching, too.

title: The Business Market Plays Cloud Computing Catch-Up
description: The big spenders on technology are businesses and government agencies. They buy about 75 percent of the computing goods and services sold worldwide. Yet it is increasingly evident they are not driving the new ideas, excitement and powerhouse technology companies in ascent these days.

title: A Boon for Nannies, if Only They Knew
description: Patricia Francois prowled the American Museum of Natural History on a recent afternoon, looking for nannies. She spotted two, with their charges, sitting in the inky gloaming beneath the famous blue whale, and zeroed in.

title: Rumors of the Democrats Demise in the Senate are Slightly Exaggerated
description: Are Republicans favorites to take back the Senate next year?

title: Obama Goes to Chicago to Talk Money, and Raise It
description: CHICAGO  President Obama, having drawn battle lines with Republicans over how to cut the deficit, returned to his political home here Thursday for a fund-raising visit, bringing the message of fiscal responsibility and core Democratic values he laid out in a speech a day earlier.

title: World Bank and I.M.F. Discuss Inequality in Middle East
description: WASHINGTON  The World Bank once hailed Tunisias economic reforms, noting the countrys increasing prosperity over the last decade.

title: Bankers Named Who Doubted Madoff
description: A new federal bankruptcy court filing on Thursday showed that three current members of JPMorgan Chases executive committee had discussed, as early as June 2007, the possibility that Bernard L. Madoff was running a Ponzi scheme  as, indeed, he was  but took no action to protect investors or alert regulators.

title: Jacksons Farewell Tour Could End Where It Began
description: When Phil Jackson visited Chicagos United Center in December for the Los Angeles Lakers lone regular-season appearance, he stayed away from the farewells and the reminiscing that the occasion otherwise demanded. Six of his 11 championship banners as a coach hang from the rafters there, but Jackson was not in the mood to go on and on about Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen as he moves toward the conclusion of his coaching career.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 14, 2011

title: Adventures in the Drug Trades
description: Billy Corben, the director of Cocaine Cowboys, continues his adventures in the drug trades with Square Grouper, a curiously inert documentary about pot smuggling in South Florida in the 1970s and 80s. (A square grouper is a bale of marijuana.)

title: C.I.A. Sued for Failure to Release Bay of Pigs History
description: A group in Washington sued the C.I.A. on Thursday over its failure to release its history of the Bay of Pigs invasion, the United States-sponsored effort to topple Fidel Castro in 1961. The group, the National Security Archive, filed a Freedom of Information Act request for the five-volume history in 2005, but says it never received the required response. Only one volume has been released.

title: Study Ties Suicide Rate in Work Force to Economy
description: The suicide rate increased 3 percent in the 2001 recession and has generally ridden the tide of the economy since the Great Depression, rising in bad times and falling in good ones, according to a comprehensive government analysis released Thursday.

title: Iraq: U.N. Says 34 Iranians Killed at Exile Camp
description: The United Nations confirmed the claims of an Iranian dissident group on Thursday that dozens of Iranian exiles were killed by Iraqi security forces last week at a camp north of Baghdad. A spokesman for the United Nations said that 34 members of the group, the Peoples Mujahedeen, had been killed near Camp Ashraf, in Diyala Province. The statement contradicted the claims of Iraqi officials, who denied that Iraqi security forces fired on the group.

title: Russia: Jehovahs Witness Acquitted of Incitement
description: A Jehovahs Witness charged in connection with distributing religious literature was found not guilty of inciting religious hatred and enmity on Thursday after a six-month trial in the Siberian city of Gorno-Altaisk. The defendant, Aleksandr Kalistratov, said he hoped the verdict will be useful for my fellow believers, who continue to be persecuted in Russia. Nearly a dozen other cases are being pursued against Jehovahs Witnesses in Russia.

title: Friday: Celebrity Guest Blogger Dana Delany
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  If you do the New York Times crossword puzzle every day, you know that some of them are light repasts and some of them are multicourse feasts. Now that its Friday, we have survived another week of puzzle challenges, and I consider this one by Patrick Berry a sweet finish to the weekday hustle. An AFTER-DINNER MINT, if you will.

title: A Boy and His Steed, Far From Humane Society
description: Its swoon time, ladies and gentlemen. Joey, the current marquee topper at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center, is the kind of matinee idol New York hasnt seen in ages. Tall, high-strung and handsome, with chestnut hair and eyes that catch the light, this strapping leading man is so charismatic you can imagine fans of both sexes lining up at the stage door with bouquets. Or maybe lumps of sugar and handfuls of hay.

title: Hard Times in Philadelphia
description: Five young job seekers in Philadelphia describe how the current financial meltdown has hurt their prospects.

title: A Life Rescued
description: Injured in a car accident and near death, a legal immigrant without insurance experienced a medical deportation.

title: T.V.A. Agrees to Shutter 18 Generators That Use Coal
description: In a sweeping legal settlement, the Tennessee Valley Authority has agreed for the first time to reduce its overall capacity to generate coal-fired electricity, promising to close 18 of its coal-burning generators over the next six years while spending $3 billion to $5 billion on pollution controls on any remaining units that use coal.

title: Obama Puts Deficit Ball Back in Pentagons Court
description: WASHINGTON  When Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates disclosed his new military budget plan in January, he ordered $78 billion in cuts over five years, on top of several hundred billion dollars in savings already found by canceling weapons programs and identifying business efficiencies.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Whos Serious Now?
description: Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, sounds upset. And you can see why: President Obama, to the great relief of progressives, has called his bluff.

title: In Her Childhood Dream, a Funeral Home Was the Destination
description: Lisa S. Dozier was 7 when she saw her first dead body.

title: Subpar 4: Tour Pro Needs 16 Strokes to Finish Hole
description: Kevin Na scored a 16 at the ninth hole of the Texas Open in San Antonio on Thursday, the worst score on a par-4 hole in PGA Tour history. But it could have been worse.

title: Former Tunisian Leader Faces Legal Charges
description: Former President Zine El-Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia, who fled the country after a popular uprising forced him out in January, is now facing 18 legal cases, Tunisias official news agency said Thursday.

title: Ultimate Spoiler Alert
description: President Obama and Paul Ryan are two of the smartest, most admirable and most genial men in Washington. It is sad, although not strange, that in todays Washington they have never had a serious private conversation. The president has never invited Ryan over even for lunch.

title: War Horse
description: Photos from the production at Lincoln Center Theater.

title: Senator Took Remedial Flying Instruction After Landing on Closed Runway
description: A United States senator who landed his twin-engine Cessna on a runway that was closed for construction last October actually touched down, became airborne again and hopped over a group of construction workers and their equipment, and then touched down again, according to information released Wednesday by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Under Threat: The Shock of the Old
description: WHAT happened to Africa? an art-world friend asked. It disappeared.

title: Underground Market and Pop-ups in San Francisco Draw Foodies
description: An underground market and pop-up restaurants are gaining a following of food enthusiasts in San Francisco.

title: American Ballet Theater at City Center
description: Over the last few days marvels have unfolded at American Ballet Theater.

title: Rally Cant Calm Unease Over Hughes
description: Evidence of Phil Hughess pitching aptitude can be found in highlight videos from the 2009 championship season and the All-Star Game garb he received last summer, when he was selected for the first time, at age 24. So, it does exist. He has seen it.

title: Ex-Chairman of New York Stock Exchange May Run for Mayor
description: Richard A. Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, suggested on Thursday night that he would run for mayor of New York City in 2013 if his longtime nemesis, former Gov. Eliot L. Spitzer, entered the race and the citys police commissioner sat it out.

title: Is Sitting a Lethal Activity?
description: DR. LEVINES MAGIC UNDERWEAR resembled bicycle shorts, black and skintight, but with sensors mounted on the thighs and wires running to a fanny pack. The look was part Euro tourist, part cyborg. Twice a second, 24 hours a day, the magic underwears accelerometers and inclinometers would assess every movement I made, however small, and whether I was lying, walking, standing or sitting.

title: Red Bull Arena Hosts U.S. Team
description: The United States womens national team will play its final match before departing for Europe and the World Cup against Mexico at Red Bulls Arena in Harrison, N.J., on June 5. The match will be televised by ESPN2 and Univision.

title: Sports Replay: April 14
description: The day in sports, from major league baseball to Europa League action.

title: Word of the Day | obfuscate
description: obfuscate \b-f-skat; b-fs-kat, b-\ verb

title: Terry Collins Says Mets Need More Practice, and They Do
description: On a day when a ball boy makes the best defensive play of the game, its time for some extra defensive work. Late in the second game the ball boy down the right-field line made a great catch of Daniel Murphys line drive foul ball, but that was the exception.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Doubling Fun at the Garden
description: Tickets for the Knicks first two home playoff games will go on sale Friday at 10 a.m. A few hours later, the Knicks and the Rangers will stage a joint rally in Greeley Square to celebrate their simultaneous playoff appearances, the first time that has happened since 1997.

title: Homer Smith, Innovative College Football Coach, Dies at 79
description: Homer Smith, a football coach whose strategizing enlivened the offenses at U.C.L.A., Alabama and Arizona, and who was the coach at Army in the difficult years at the end of the Vietnam War, died Sunday at his home in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 79.

title: Lebanons Mahdi Scouts
description: The Mahdi Scouts have a reputation of being a feeder for Hezbollahs armed wing.

title: News Quiz | April 15, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Nuclear Company to Compensate Evacuees in Japan
description: TOKYO  The Tokyo Electric Power Company announced plans on Friday to distribute $600 million in initial payments to 50,000 people evacuated because of the accident at its Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, as technicians continued to struggle to repair cooling and electrical systems at the damaged reactors.

title: Tim Ream: Chapter 1, New Hope
description: Welcome to the my first effort for the Goal blog. I will be writing once a week throughout the M.L.S. season so be sure to check back. For those of you who dont know, Im Tim Ream and I am a central defender for the New York Red Bulls. I am currently in my second year with the team and my second year as a professional. But enough with the background and intro, lets get started.

title: A Difficult Family Relationship
description: Treading warily into territory that few dramas dare to explore, Fly Away is a defiantly unsentimental look at the complex codependency between a harried single mother and her severely autistic daughter.

title: Daily Lexeme: Gracioso
description: Todays word, in association with the legendary Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Thanksgiving Recipes
description: A collection of holiday recipes from the Dining section.

title: Test Yourself | History, April 15, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about a famous shipwreck.

title: One Needle, One Count, One Reputation
description: WHO is Barry Bonds?WHO are the other prominent people in sports who break rules listed in this article?

title: Mapping the World's Fastest Supercomputers
description: While the U.S. has the world's fastest supercomputers, it faces increased pressure from countries like India and China.

title: A Civil Rights Headquarters
description: In a small chamber behind the old weight room of a central Harlem gym, the Rev. Al Sharpton runs the National Action Network.

title: Nature or Nurture?
description: Scientists, psychologists, anthropologists and others have long debated which is more influential in making us who we are: nature (that is, the genetic qualities we inherit and are born with) or nurture (the environment in which we are raised). Which do you think has the greater role in shaping us? Why?

title: A Light on the People of Western Sahara
description: When the Irish-born photographer Andrew McConnell saw some images from his project The Last Colony displayed side by side for the first time earlier this week, even he was surprised by the strength in numbers.

title: Homes Lost to Fire in California
description: Most of the 600 trailer homes at Oakridge Mobile Home Park in Los Angeles went up in flames, leaving residents to mourn the loss of their homes and of their community.

title: Gaza Killing of Italian Activist Deals a Blow to Hamas
description: GAZA  For Vittorio Arrigoni, an Italian pro-Palestinian activist who friends said fought peacefully for justice, the end was as violent as it was incongruous.

title: A Holiday in North Korea Amid Cross-Border Tensions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea celebrated its biggest annual holiday on Friday  the 99th birthday of the late dictator Kim Il-sung  and despite a few recent signs of an easing of tensions between the Koreas, hopes for rapprochement remained dim.

title: Outrage in Belgium Over Interview of Ex-Bishop
description: LONDON  A year after his resignation plunged Belgiums Roman Catholic Church into a crisis, the former bishop of Bruges provoked almost universal condemnation on Friday, this time by admitting that he had abused a second nephew and insisting that he was not a pedophile.

title: How Worrisome Is Student Debt?
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: In Berlin, a Long Night of Culture
description: Ever seen an opera performed underwater? Or perhaps you prefer puppet theater. Whatever your predilections, the third annual Long Night of Opera and Theater, being held tomorrow, from 7 p.m. to 1 a.m., offers a unique cultural cross-section of what Berlin has to offer.

title: 1963 Porsche Runs With the Classics, Dude
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.  People talk about cars as rolling sculpture, as art on wheels. But few vehicles have merged the worlds of art and automobile quite like David Duthus 1963 Porsche 356 Reutter Sun Roof Coupe, a k a the Psychedelic Surfer Dude. The cars bodywork is an escapist tribute to a bygone era of peace and love.

title: The Early Word: Looking Ahead
description: From Todays Times:

title: Indonesian Suicide Bomber Attacks Mosque
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  A suicide bomber blew himself up during prayers in a mosque in a police station on Friday, wounding dozens and killing himself, antiterrorism officials said.

title: Tip of the Week: Enhanced PC Search Features
description: Need to search more thoroughly? Windows 7 and Mac OS X 10.6 include search filters that help you find what youre looking for if you cannot easily locate specific files with the Windows Start-menu search box or the Macs on-screen Spotlight search tool.

title: One Show Spins Its Last, As Another Takes Shape
description: History is being made on Broadway this weekend: The $70 million museum piece that is Julie Taymors Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, the most expensive musical of all time, is on display in its final performances through Sunday afternoon, then disassembled out of existence.

title: A More Efficient Approach to Hiring
description: To most small-business owners, the terms video clip and impact are more likely to suggest the latest Jackass-style stunt immortalized on YouTube than something important to their bottom lines. But a few new online services are trying to get companies to embrace video in ways that could have a big payoff for very little effort.

title: New Groups Form to Raise Millions for Democrats
description: 11:30 a.m. | Updated In a city where almost everything seems up for debate these days, Republicans and Democrats in Washington agree on one thing: conservative groups, working outside the normal party structure, outperformed, outhustled and  most of all  outraised Democrats in 2010.

title: Bank of America Profit Drops 37%
description: Bank of America reported a 37 percent drop in first-quarter earnings on Friday, as the nations biggest bank continued to battle the legacy of the mortgage crisis and legal problems linked to the ill-fated acquisition of Countrywide Financial.

title: Complaint Box | Dog Urine
description: As the new gardener for the recently renovated Washington Square Park, I never suspected that I would be spending such a large part of my day chasing people with dogs away from plant beds. As a dog owner myself, I find it almost impossible to tell something as cute as a French bulldog puppy what to do. But it is absolutely necessary if we want our greenery to thrive.

title: Rave New World
description: The off-again-on-again Manhattan club night Ghe20 Goth1k is a creative oasis within New Yorks flagging night-life scene. Organized by Venus X Iceberg (ne Jazmin Venus Soto), it serves as home base to many recently emerged hybrid rave/hip-hop genres. Soto is also producing a documentary called Shakedown. Reminiscent of the 90s cult film Paris Is Burning, it traces the intricacies of black lesbian subculture in Los Angeles. Notably, Soto keeps her love of underground and subculture balanced. As a D.J., she has gained notoriety by mixing news clips from Al Jazeera in with her beats  during a New York Fashion Week gig, she interspersed coverage from the Egyptian revolution. As she puts it, Even club kids should know whats going on.

title: The Horror of Being Wes Craven
description: Since youre so strongly associated with fear and this is our health issue, could you tell me about your own health concerns? My brother and I both used to worry about dying at 40, because our father died at 40. That probably wasnt terribly rational since my father led a rather unhealthy lifestyle shall we say.

title: Riding Along With the Cops in Murdertown, U.S.A.
description: A sign taped to the entrance of police headquarters says it all: Closed weekends and holidays. Every weekday, the doors are locked at dusk.

title: Whats the Single Best Exercise?
description: Lets consider the butterfly. One of the most taxing movements in sports, the butterfly requires greater energy than bicycling at 14 miles per hour, running a 10-minute mile, playing competitive basketball or carrying furniture upstairs. It burns more calories, demands larger doses of oxygen and elicits more fatigue than those other activities, meaning that over time it should increase a swimmers endurance and contribute to weight control.

title: Block Quote: The Case for Comic Books
description: Every would-be writer needs comic books. I certainly did. I can still vividly recall my discovery of comic books, followed closely by the revelation that this reading stuff was actually good for something. Because comic books had it all over Readers. Comic books had pictures, and so did Readers, but in comic-book pictures somebody was flying or punching somebody, while in my Reader little Sally was crying about her little red boat. Even in my prepubescent days I had this vague feeling that Wonder Woman had it all over Jane, although I couldnt put my finger on the reason. I did know that watching Spot run was a real drag when I could watch Krypto the Superdog fly instead. And I knew that if they ever met, Krypto would bite Spots head off.

title: The Waiting
description: I am nothing if not compliant. I held still as I was shuttled back and forth through the wondrous high-tech doughnut, inhaling and holding my breath when instructed. Less than three minutes later, I hopped off the narrow table and put my sweater back on.

title: The New York Cosmos Want to Take the Field Again
description: As a theme for a downtown party, a salute to late-70s American professional soccer sounds a little on the youve-got-to-be-kidding side. But anyone who walked into Openhouse Gallery in NoLIta one rainy night in mid-February would have seen a young crowd in a huge room celebrating the New York Cosmos, the long-defunct team that briefly turned the worlds most popular sport into a glamorous New York fad.

title: The Return of Americas Missionary Impulse
description: NEW DELHI  Bill Gates, Sarah Palin and Warren Buffett (now theres an opening in search of a punch line) each passed through here recently, instructing the Indians on how to be better Indians.

title: The Bleak Game of Thrones Needs More Light
description: As it turns out, adapting George R. R. Martins epic Song of Ice and Fire fiction series for premium cable amounts to such good, simple sense that its stunning that there arent more fantasy series on TV. Considering the falling cost of C.G.I. effects and the rising popularity of the (loosely defined) fantasy genre  like Heroes on NBC, Lost on ABC and the hit Battlestar Galactica on Syfy  its remarkable that networks still seem content to mostly loop the same Mobius strip of programming: detectives puzzling, lawyers pacing, sitcom dads making sitcom children roll their eyes.

title: Driving the Price Up
description: Recently a car backed into my parked car and drove off, leaving my bumper damaged. I was able to track down the culprit thanks to a surveillance camera, and he agreed to compensate me for the cost of the bumper at the lowest estimate I got, which was $576. He provided me with a check for that amount. The mechanic later said that he could probably bang the dent out and repaint it, making it look almost new, for just $100. My wife says that I have an obligation to return the balance of $476 to the offending driver. Im not sure. What says the Ethicist? ARI WALISEVER, WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.

title: How Little Sleep Can You Get Away With?
description: Editors note: Were resurfacing this 2011 magazine article on the science of sleep for Smarter Living.

title: Vettel is Fastest in Shanghai Practice Sessions
description: There may have been a little bit of damage limitation in the second practice session in Shanghai on Friday as the Formula One teams prepared for the Chinese Grand Prix  but I am beginning to be skeptical about it. Im referring to how in the first session this morning Sebastian Vettel, the winner in his Red Bull of the last four races  the first to this year and the last two last year  set the fastest time, more than two seconds ahead of the next best car and driver, Lewis Hamilton at McLaren Mercedes.

title: Vettel is Fastest in Shanghai Practice Sessions
description: There may have been a little bit of damage limitation in the second practice session in Shanghai on Friday as the Formula One teams prepared for the Chinese Grand Prix  but I am beginning to be skeptical about it. Im referring to how in the first session this morning Sebastian Vettel, the winner in his Red Bull of the last four races  the first to this year and the last two last year  set the fastest time, more than two seconds ahead of the next best car and driver, Lewis Hamilton at McLaren Mercedes.

title: U.N. Court Convicts Two Croatian Generals of War Crimes and Frees a Third
description: PARIS  In a shock to Croatia over its conduct of Balkan warfare in the 1990s, a United Nations court on Friday found a Croatian general, Ante Gotovina, guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity in a campaign he led to regain Croatian land and drive Serbs out of the Krajina region in 1995.

title: The Key to Marital Harmony: One Vote Per Couple?
description: In the Hasidic enclave of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, there are many things that women cant or just dont do: Be counted as one of the 10 people needed to make up a minyan, or prayer quorum. Walk around in pants. But vote?

title: Insincerely Yours
description: Republicans are deeply, sincerely concerned about the budget deficit. Thats why, in unveiling their plan last week, they declared themselves willing to give ground on their traditional priorities, signaling a willingness to accept higher taxes on the wealthy and reduced defense spending as part of a deficit-reduction deal.

title: Tax Facts
description: Via Mark Thoma, CBPP has a great set of charts on taxes. Heres one:

title: Indian Doctor Granted Bail in Sedition Appeal
description: NEW DELHI  Indias Supreme Court granted bail on Friday to a prominent doctor who is appealing a sentence of life imprisonment after being convicted of sedition for helping Maoist rebels in the central tribal areas of the country.

title: Barcelona-Real Madrid: Rating the Coming Clasicos
description: Saturday brings the start of three weeks of El Clsico overload, a series of four matchups between the bitter Spanish rivals Barcelona and Real Madrid that will help decide a seasons worth of competitions: the Spanish league, the Copa del Rey and the UEFA Champions League.

title: Madrid vs. Barcelona: Four Times a Soccer Classic
description: MADRID  A clsico encounter between Real Madrid and  Barcelona, the two most successful teams in Spanish soccer, inevitably generates high expectations.

title: The Heritage Heritage
description: A blast from the past: the first time I spent a lot of time dredging through Heritage Foundation analyses was when I was writing this 2002 piece on inequality. And I was particularly struck by the Heritage work on the estate tax (pdf), which contained passages like this:

title: Evercore Co-Founder to Run for Los Angeles Mayor
description: The worlds of finance and politics continue to converge.

title: Lost in the E.R.: Her Dignity
description: My mother fell in the bathroom and cut her head. The overnight receptionist at the assisted living facility, a dim bulb, phoned me to say an ambulance was on the way. I knew exactly how awful the next however-many hours would be: enduring my mothers crankiness, masking my own with brittle good cheer, struggling with the medical people. The emergency room ordeal would leave my mother, and to a lesser extent me, limp for days.

title: A Kingmaker in the Realm of Cheapie Horror
description: LARRY FESSENDEN knew something was wrong with Stake Land, a bleak horror movie about the survivors of a vampire outbreak, before the filming even began. Mr. Fessenden, a producer of Stake Land through his Glass Eye Pix company, worried that an early outline for the movie lacked emotion and resembled a cold, action-driven blockbuster, the kind with a histrionic soundtrack. So he invited the movies young director, Jim Mickle, out for a drink.

title: Waste Watchers
description: Courses like Pattern Making 101, History of Design and Fashion Illustration may be standard fashion school fare, but students in Parsons B.F.A. fashion design program have a new requirement in the curriculum: sustainable design.

title: On the Run in New York
description: Two runners shared their experiences running the New York City Marathon. Listen to their stories and explore the race route.

title: Where the Vote Begins
description: A 360-degree tour of New York Citys Voting Machine Facility, a warehouse near the Hudson River on 33rd Street.

title: Pressure Grows to Unwind CVS Merger
description: Consumer groups contend that behavior at CVS Caremark, the merged drugstore chain and pharmacy benefit manager, is anticompetitive, The New York Times reports.

title: ReTweet | Galliano Out, at Galliano
description: Like we couldnt see this one juggernauting down the highway at a million miles per hour. WWD.com reports this morning that the bte noir of fashion has been given his marching orders in the wake of his recent anti-Semitic outbursts. No word yet on who the new head designer of John Galliano will be, or on whether Christian Dior SA, which owns a majority stake of the label, has plans to sell it.

title: U.S. Consumer Prices Up 0.5%, Pushed Mainly by Food and Gas
description: The cost of living for Americans rose in March, but the inflationary pressures were mostly limited to food and energy costs, a government report said Friday.

title: Friday Reading: When Homeowners Associations Foreclose
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the new that could hit your wallet.

title: Syrians Renew Protests Despite Concessions
description: CAIRO  The largest group of protesters yet thronged the Syrian capital, Damascus, in a widening challenge to the government, defying a nationwide crackdown in which hundreds of demonstrators have been killed by security forces. Marches across the country were met with tear gas, beatings and reports of gunfire.

title: Peace Dividend
description: The proposed benefit to shareholders of Bank of Americas decision to halt expansion activity.Reporting in The Wall Street Journal on Bank of Americas drive to reduce costs and improve efficiency, Dan Fitzpatrick and Shira Ovide spotlighted the term peace dividend:

title: Online Records of an Italian Activists Life in Gaza
description: As my colleague Fares Akram reports, Vittorio Arrigoni, an Italian activist who was kidnapped by Islamist militants in Gaza on Thursday, and found dead early on Friday, arrived in the Palestinian territory on a ship that broke through the Israeli naval blockade more than two years ago.

title: After a Brain Tumor, a Boy, 6, Sings at the Apollo
Blast Kills Afghan Police Chief and 2 Officers in Kandahar
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a sophisticated attack, at least one suicide bomber entered the tightly secured police headquarters in Kandahar City on Friday afternoon and detonated his explosives, killing a police chief and two police officers, according to local government officials.

title: Shares Rise on Optimistic Outlook
description: Stocks rose on Friday as higher-than-estimated data on consumer confidence and manufacturing bolstered optimism about the economy.

title: Musicians Pass Out Leaflets as Bankruptcy Looms for Philadelphia Orchestra
description: The troubled Philadelphia Orchestra is moving closer to seeking bankruptcy protection.

title: Financing the Hand That Slaps (or Nibbles) You
description: HOW ubiquitous is Morgan Spurlock about to be? Well, in addition to the usual marketing and media rollout for a major documentary, his new film, The Greatest Movie Ever Sold, is being promoted by 23 sponsors whose wares are shamelessly plugged in the movie, including Mini Cooper, Pom Wonderful and Amys Kitchen. His mug is on collectors cups at almost 400 Sheetz convenience stores and he is part of a Movietickets.com trailer in theaters. Mr. Spurlock, who came to prominence and the edge of major illness by gorging on McDonalds in Super Size Me, is crisscrossing the country, hawking his movie and his sponsors. He shows up for interviews with a coat  created by Ted Baker  that is festooned with all manner of logos.

title: Taxes Have Always Been Too Complicated
description: President Obama, like many Americans, has called for Congress to simplify the tax code.

title: What to Watch for on Election Night
description: An hour-by-hour guide of what to watch for in key states as polls close across the country tonight.

title: At Mexico Morgue, Families of Missing Seek Clues
description: MATAMOROS, Mexico  The last time anybody heard from Josu Romn Garca was last August, after he and his older brother stopped for dinner in an isolated town about 90 miles south of the Texas border. His final known words went out via text message, from inside the trunk of a car.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dning section.

title: Like Busby Berkeley, With Funk
description: DURING a recent week, the choreographer Laurieann Gibson helped direct the video for her client Lady Gagas new single, Judas, in Los Angeles; taped an interview for The MoNique Show on BET; flew to Atlanta to film a hush-hush project; flew back to Los Angeles to meet with Ryan Seacrest of American Idol, where many of her artists appear; checked in with two other clients, the rappers Nicki Minaj and Sean Combs (a k a P. Diddy), who are both on tour; and shot a vacuum cleaner commercial. And lest you think that last job required any less effort: Im giving you Busby Berkeley mixed with my own sense of funk and soul, she said by phone, heaving a sigh before quickly regaining focus.

title: A Hungry Singer, Consuming His Roles
description: SOME great singing actors vanish into their characters. At the peak of his powers, the Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel more typically swallows his alive. It happened in spades at the Metropolitan Opera a year ago when he joined the cast of Puccinis Tosca, late in the run of the new, much-vilified production by Luc Bondy. As Baron Scarpia, the sadistic chief of the Roman police, Mr. Terfel captured the monsters every facet, now in gallantries of silken delicacy, now in the savage bloodlust of a tiger on the attack. Here was a creation worthy of Dickens, Balzac or Dostoevsky.

title: April 17  23
description: Theater

title: Veteran Loses Battle With Depression After Helping Others With Their Own
description: It was mid-January, 2010, just days after a powerful earthquake had reduced much of Haiti to rubble. Jake Wood, a former Marine and now the head of an international aid organization called Team Rubicon, arrived in Port-au-Prince with a group of volunteers to provide emergency medical care.

title: Sexism Charges Divide Surgeons Group
description: A Valentines Day editorial in the official newspaper of the American College of Surgeons has set off a firestorm of controversy that has divided the largest professional organization of surgeons in the country and raised questions about the current leadership and its attitudes toward women and gay and lesbian members.

title: Russia Warns NATO Over the Size of Libya Attacks
description: BERLIN  As NATO leaders sought additional aircraft Friday to oppose the forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Libya, Russia warned the alliance not to use too much military force there.

title: Hevesi Sentenced to One to Four Years
description: 8:55 PM | Updated Alan G. Hevesi, a former state comptroller, was sentenced on Friday to one to four years in prison for his role in a corruption scheme involving New York States nearly $141 billion pension fund.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: War Horse to Gallop On Indefinitely at Lincoln Center
description: What had been scheduled as a limited engagement of War Horse has been extended indefinitely at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, Lincoln Center Theater announced on Thursday.

title: Audio: At Fund-Raiser, Obama Lets Loose Over Open Microphone
description: 12:07 p.m. | Updated Oops.

title: License Plate Reading Cameras Gain Legal Backing
description: From our colleagues at City Room:

title: Writing About Cancer
description: Siddhartha Mukherjee has a terrific article in this Sundays magazine about whether cellphones cause cancer. When hes not writing, Mukherjee does research and teaches medicine at Columbia University. That makes sense because reading his cellphone story feels a lot like sitting in a riveting college class, where the professor is leading you step by step through the history of what makes for excellent  as well as flawed  scientific research, all the while explaining how to assess the research on brain cancer and cellphones. Mukherjees writing is precise and vivid and you feel like youre in the hands of a very thoughtful, exacting authority. Last fall the magazine published an excerpt from his recent book, Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer, which was a finalist last year for the National Book Critics Circle Award and was named one of the 10-best books in 2010 by our Book Review.

title: The Truth About Sharon Stone and Wes Craven
description: At the tail end of my interview with Wes Craven, I asked the director about a tawdry little story involving Sharon Stone and his ex-wife that had made its way into his biography on various Internet sources, including Wikipedia. If we believe Cravens explanation of the incident, the yarn is like so many things one encounters when doing research on the Internet  almost, but not entirely, true.

title: Bank of Americas Legal Woes
description: Bank of Americas quarterly earnings release barely mentioned the financial firms legal woes. But that doesnt mean theyre not still a drag on profits.

title: A Warning, and 68 Minutes Later a Killer Touches Down
description: TUSHKA, Okla.  The sound of chain saws filled the air in this rural town on Friday as Jessica Eldridge sifted through a pile of rubble that until last night had been her house, looking for clothing, family photos, pots and pans, any belongings she could salvage.

title: A Russian Raymond Proves Hard to Love
description: LAUGH, they say, and the world laughs with you. Phil Rosenthal isnt entirely convinced.

title: Vanishing Act
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#570", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Havens  Ashfield, Mass.
description: Settled in 1745 in the Berkshires eastern foothills, the town is rural and wooded, with farmland, gentle hills and winding roads.

title: Dueling Protests in Yemen Remain Peaceful
description: SANA, Yemen  More than 100,000 demonstrators returned to the streets of the Yemeni capital, Sana, on Friday, some chanting for President Ali Abdullah Saleh and, about two miles away, many against.

title: The Albert Hotel Addresses Its Myths
description: IN the last decade, apartment buildings have been putting together increasingly ambitious histories, some extensively researched and hard-bound with photographs.

title: Where Have All the Bank C.F.O.s Gone?
description: At some of the biggest banks, there has been a revolving door to the office of chief financial officer.

title: Core Inflation Rises, but Is Still Low
description: Fridays inflation report was mostly as economists expected it to be. Core inflation  which excludes food and energy prices and is a better guide to future inflation  rose slightly less than expected, but only slightly.

title: Village Voice Remixes Its Music Festival
description: The Village Voice announced that it would present a new annual music festival after 10 years of producing the Siren Music Festival at Coney Island. Now The Voice is to produce the 4Knots Music Festival, on July 16 at the South Street Seaport. The festival will be free, open to all ages, and held rain or shine. (Its name comes from the speed at which the East River flows, The Voice said.)

title: A Makeover in Mott Haven
description: FOR decades Bruckner Boulevard in Mott Haven, the Bronx, was known more as a place to pass through than visit, especially by drivers trying to beat the toll for the Triborough Bridge. By taking the Willis or Third Avenue Bridge, which feed into the boulevard, travelers can enter and exit Manhattan without paying.

title: Hard Work of Comedy and Straight-Shooting
description: Rope of Sand

title: Lower-Priced Homes Lagging
description: A YEAR after the April 30, 2010, expiration of the federal tax-credit program to stimulate buying, the market in New Jersey is showing widespread weakness in even the most affordable price ranges. In fact, weakness is most discernible in the lower price ranges these days, according to new data on sales.

title: When Adults Call Children Names
description: One of the most viewed video links on ABCNews.com right now is the story of 7-year-old Samantha Shaw, who had plastic surgery to pin back her ears to keep them from sticking out. Her mother, Cammie Shaw, sought the surgery because Samantha is already being teased, and Cammie worries that the bullying will get worse as she gets older.

title: Growing Demand for Group Homes
description: Westbury

title: In Darien, a Case of Down in Front!
description: DARIEN

title: Agency Intensifies Investigation of 150,000 Honda CR-Vs for Fire Hazard
description: Following isolated reports of fires, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has broadened its investigation to an estimated 150,000 Honda CR-Vs from the 2006 model year.

title: Take Me to the Future, and Step on It
description: FUTURE cab? the taxi driver, Arif, asked with a smile. He had pulled his battered Ford Crown Victoria alongside the gleaming new vehicle I was driving around Columbus Circle and took pictures with his cellphone camera as if he had spotted a celebrity on the street.

title: Using Hypnosis to Gain More Control Over Your Illness
description: KIRSTEN RITCHIE, 44, is no stranger to surgery  nearly 20 years ago, doctors removed four tumors from her brain. She remembers the operation and its aftermath as horrific.

title: Habitats | Tompkinsville, Staten Island
description: Anthony and Susannah Abbate, and their son, Tony Jr., 2, live in a decommissioned firehouse on Staten Island.

title: The Puns Story
description: It was with great trepidation that I o-punned this book.

title: Falai Goes Retail; Swedish Fish Spawn
description: Iacopo Falai is on the move again, ready to open Bottega Falai Thursday morning next to his Caffe Falai. Done in his trademark shiny white mosaic tile, and glittering chandeliers, the shop is stocked with mostly Italian products, like dried porcini, sea salts, some herbs and spices, excellent Mancini pasta, olive oils, a selection of Italian cheeses and cured meats, breads, some produce, prepared foods like sandwiches, and the pastries for which Mr. Falai is known. A few tables are available for a snack on the spot but most of the food is to take away. A couple of weeks ago, he also doubled the size of the cafe by taking over an adjacent storefront, adding more seats and a full bar, also done in white tile and sparkle. And for his new Italian cocktail menu, you can watch his bartenders weigh the ingredients for your drink on little scales for better accuracy.

title: Accentuating the Positive Amid Sports Angst
description: In the wake of what felt like an ice bucket full of news this week, with the sobering Barry Bonds verdict, endless squabbling from the characters responsible for the N.F.L. lockout and a cringe-inducing outburst from Kobe Bryant, it seems therapeutic to end the week with a few stories from sports warmer, inspiring side. Fortunately, they are always there, sometimes hidden in odd places, and feel particularly welcome this week.

title: The Siren Song of a Fire Station
description: ANTHONY ABBATE, a native Staten Islander who designs cabinets for high-end audio equipment, sometimes thinks about the ones that got away.

title: On the Street | Spring Trench Coats
description: April showers bring out the trench coats and umbrellas in New York.

title: A Sold-Out Coachella Begins Today
description: Two ways to look at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, in Indio, Calif., which begins its 12th edition on Friday:

title: April 15 Updates on Mideast Protests and Libyan War
description: On Friday, The Lede is following the war in Libya and protest movements across the Middle East and North Africa. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports and observations from journalists and bloggers in the region. For a summary of the latest developments in Syria, read the frequently updated main news article from my colleagues Liam Stack and Katherine Zoepf.

title: On His Sleeve
description: THE Andy Warhol monument  an 11-foot silvery statue of the pope of pop by Rob Pruitt for the Public Art Fund, recently installed on the northwest corner of Union Square  appears to be a success. So far the biggest complaint is that people wish it werent temporary.

title: Galleys of All Kinds Found Here
description: Norman Mailers apartment is located in a 25-foot-wide townhouse at 134 Columbia Heights; the asking price is $2.5 million, and furniture and furnishings are negotiable.

title: What Makes Literature Literature?
description: Near the end of his life, when hed mostly given up lobbing oddball provocations at feminists and masturbators, Norman Mailer anointed The Sopranos as a cultural successor to the great American novel. It was a genuine compliment, though a strange one. Just as Mailer and Truman Capote once advertised the literary intentions of their journalism with the term nonfiction novel, Mailer now honored a television show by suggesting that it wasnt a television show at all, but something else, something literary. The irony was that Mailer had it backward. The Sopranos represented the end of whatever remained of televisions status anxiety; it didnt need to be anything but itself to be taken seriously.

title: All the Presidents Sanctimony
description: Here is how President Obama introduced his plan for deficit reduction in Wednesdays speech:

title: This Weekends Top European Matchups
description: The outstanding matchups in European soccer this weekend:

title: Last of 6 Parts: Answers to Readers Decision-Time Questions
description: This week, Bruce Poch, a veteran of the admissions world who worked at Wesleyan and Connecticut College before serving, until recently, as dean of admissions at Pomona College in California, has been answering questions submitted by readers of The Choice. The series concludes today.

title: Big Deal | Norman Mailer Apartment for Sale
More Thoughts About Spring Lamb
description: It was deep winter when I began planning this weeks column about holiday lamb, but I didnt know how exactly I wanted to approach the animal. Tough luck: I got to spend late winter and early spring playing around with the countrys most underappreciated meat. I love roasting shoulder, and I love braising shanks (and neck, which, if you can get it, is one of the best braising meats there is), but as you can see I eventually settled on the leg  roasted leg, to be exact  because after all it seems most appropriate for the holiday table.

title: Asked & Answered | Philippe Starck
description: Stand C9-D18, Pavilion 13, Euroluce, Fiera-Rho Milan, Italy. Journalists line up in front of a private interview room to meet the perennial French design superstar Philippe Starck. Known for juggling a considerable number of clients (or editors, as his team calls them) at once, Starck was in New York just last week to unveil a novelty toilet seat for Duravit, and this week in Milan, hes presenting a variety of new products with a number of different companies, including Kartell, Dedon, Driade, Baccarat, Magis and Alias. But today its all about ultramodern LED-powered lamps he designed for Flos, the high-end Italian lighting manufacturer.

title: A Gay Former N.B.A. Player Responds to Kobe Bryant
description: After Los Angeles Lakers guard Kobe Bryant directed an antigay slur at a referee Tuesday night from the bench in a game against the Phoenix Suns, the N.B.A. fined him $100,000. Bryant has apologized, saying his words should not have been taken literally. He said he would appeal the fine.

title: Shakespeare Subpoenaed
description: Kenji Yoshino is a respected legal scholar (the Chief Justice Earl Warren professor of constitutional law at New York University) who regularly teaches a course on literature and the law. The device he has come up with in A Thousand Times More Fair is to match a play of Shakespeare with some modern event or issue. One can see how this might stimulate class discussion, and it seems to succeed, since he tells us that his course on constitutional law is oversubscribed by two to one, but the class on literature and law has more applicants by six to one. The process apparently works. But what of the product? Considered apart from the give-and-take of the classroom, one of three things can be the result. First, the stereoscopic approach can deepen ones understanding of both a play and the event matched with it. Second, at least one of the pair can be given new understanding. Third, meaning can be drained, not deepened, on both sides of the matchup.

title: Geoff Dyers Wide-Ranging Curiosity
description: Assembling a collection of reviews and essays is a test of the richness of a critics inner life, an echo-sounding exercise that measures the depth of available talent. While a single piece may be impressive in isolation  rehearsed in a glossy magazine or nestled in the review pages  the book-length selection takes us out of the safety of those shallows and asks whether a writers reflections still rise beyond the threshold of banality when repeated over several hundred pages. If a critics sense of artistic achievement is sclerotically narrow, or based on a single approach applied to every work under consideration, the collection will coolly sketch a relief map of those failings.

title: What Grief Is Really Like
description: The Christmas that Meghan ORourke was 5, her mother gave her a journal  a whole world of blank pages, puzzling to the child but not to the mother. Barbara ORourke explained to her daughter that the book was a place for her to put her thoughts: Youd write something like Today I saw a woman with purple hair crossing Montague Street.

title: New York Paternity Fight May Have Millions of Ripples
description: IT is a small case, really, easily lost among the thousands in New York Citys courts.

title: Francis Fukuyamas Theory of the State
description: This book has two origins, Francis Fukuyama writes in the preface to The Origins of Political Order. The first arose when my mentor, Samuel Huntington of Harvard University, asked me to write a foreword to a reprint edition of his 1968 classic, Political Order in Changing Societies.  Its second inspiration was the decade that Fukuyama spent studying the real-world problems of weak and failed states and that inspired his 2004 book State-Building: Governance and World Order in the 21st Century.

title: At Home With Susan Sontag
description: Its not easy to pick the most unforgettable image from the many that flutter through this memoir like snippets from an overturned wastebasket. Susan Sontag eating a whole package of bacon and calling it dinner? Susan Sontag, passionate friend of the revolution, berating any clerk or waiter who didnt treat her with proper deference? Susan Sontag perched on a sofa in her sons room late at night, smoking and soliloquizing about her evening out, while he and his girlfriend lie silently in bed? Truly an embarrassment of riches, emphasis on the embarrassment, but heres a personal favorite: Susan Sontag choosing to entertain guests in the kitchen.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Beer and bivalves are the theme of Bierkrafts new backyard and garden space, 191 Fifth Avenue (between Berkeley Place and Union Street), in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Starting at noon on Saturday there will be an oyster shuck fest with 15 special cask beers.

title: Kate Atkinsons Unorthodox Mystery Series
description: Its West Yorkshire not long before the Yorkshire Ripper starts his killing spree, and two police officers make a grisly discovery. Behind a locked door in a block of flats lies the decomposing body of a woman. But thats not the worst of it. The worst of it is theres a child locked in with her, filthy, nothing but skin and bone, looking like a famine victim.

title: How Language Heals
description: Diane Ackerman and Paul West have combined brilliant literary careers with the most enviable of marriages, a decades-long duet. Speculating on their longevity as a couple in One Hundred Names for Love, Ackerman writes: We stayed together for the children  each was the others child. And we were both wordsmiths, cuddle-mad, and extremely playful. . . . All couples play kissy games they dont want other people to know about, and all regress to infants from time to time, since, though we marry as adults, we dont marry adults. We marry children who have grown up and still rejoice in being children, especially if were creative. Imaginative people fidget with ideas, including the idea of a relationship. If theyre wordsmiths like us, they fidget a lot in words.

title: The Royal Wedding
description: The Times' Christine Haughney talks with Prince Dimitri of Yugoslavia, who comes from a long line of royalty.

title: Tempest in a Compost Heap: Controversial Comedy Sign Gets a Funny New Home
description: The strange saga of a silly sign  or is that the silly saga of a strange sign?  apparently came to an end on Friday with some help from a television comedy star and a New York environmental group.

title: GroVont Redux
description: Lydia Elkrunner (ne Callahan) is not a very nice person. She insults on a whim and delights in temper tantrums. She refuses to repair the brake lights on her decaying BMW because that would be giving other drivers too much information. At 58, she acts as if shes 20 and, of a benign nonagenarian, gleefully quips, Dont you admire the Eskimo ritual of leaving their elderly behind on an ice flow. Really, shes everything self: self-absorbed, self-important, self-indulgent. You know why living with you would be so healthy, Grandma? her down-and-out 28-year-old granddaughter remarks. Because you are so incredibly wrong that you clarify what is right.

title: Editors Choice
description: SAY HER NAME,  by Francisco Goldman (Grove, $24.) Goldmans passionate, moving novel takes as its subject his tragically short marriage to the fiction writer Aura Estrada, who died in a bodysurfing accident in 2007, when she was 30.

title: Paperback Row
description: HELLHOUND ON HIS TRAIL: The Electrifying Account of the Largest Manhunt in American History,  by Hampton Sides (Anchor, $15.95.) Sides pieces together a viscerally dramatic account of the last days of Martin Luther King Jr.  including a moment-by-moment retelling of his assassination on April 4, 1968, in Memphis  and intercuts Kings story with the maneuverings of James Earl Ray, the man tried and convicted as his killer.

title: Weekend Competition: Whats the Onomatopoeia?
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to dance across their keyboards to provide the spelling of the sounds that surround us.

title: The Week in Pictures, April 8
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: T. Rowe Price Discloses $190 Million Stake in Facebook
description: T. Rowe Price has made several recent investments in social media companies, including Facebook and Zynga, according to recent filings.

title: Talking Money With Elmo
description: In the wake of the financial crisis, "Sesame Street" is teaching children financial literacy. Ron Lieber talks to Elmo about saving and sharing.

title: Too Young for Finance? Think Again
description: One of the best things about being around preschool-age children is that they are a blank slate awaiting your imprint. All of the big questions come up before first grade  God and death, jail and fairies  and most 4-year-olds will believe pretty much any answer you give them.

title: Inside the List
description: X FACTOR: Manning Marables long-awaited Malcolm X: A Life of Reinvention hits No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list this week, trailing admiring reviews and eulogies for Marable, who died a few days before the books publication. Marable has done as thorough and exhaustive a job as has ever been done in piecing together the life and evolution of Malcolm X, rescuing him from both the hagiography of uncritical advocates and the demonization of undeterred critics, the sociologist Michael Eric Dyson told The New York Times.

title: Qaddafi Troops Fire Cluster Bombs Into Civilian Areas
description: MISURATA, Libya  Military forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi have been firing into residential neighborhoods in this embattled city with heavy weapons, including cluster bombs that have been banned by much of the world and ground-to-ground rockets, according to witnesses and survivors, as well as physical evidence.

title: Hypnosis as a Health Option
description: Todays Patient Money column looks into the costs and potential benefits of hypnosis for dealing with anxiety, pain management and other health issues.

title: Long Putter: an Affront to Purity or a Welcome Tool?
description: As Adam Scott made his charge up the leader board in the final round of this years Masters, golf seemed closer than ever to having its first winner of a Grand Slam event who wielded a long putter. There have been other close calls and the 2009 Masters champion, Angel Cabrera, used a belly length putter, though he did not push it into his belly.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Bilal Powell, Third-Ranked Rusher
description: Matt Waldman is the author of  The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: Gogobot, New Travel Site, Gets Personal
description: Travel planning sites like TripAdvisor.com are standard fare, but Gogobot.com, which debuted in November, offers something a bit different: personalized recommendations for its members based on suggestions from their friends.

title: Wheelies: The Not-So-Golden State Edition
description: In which we bring you automotive news from around the Web:
