description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#325", 592, 340, true, chameleonData);

title: Street Art Show in Los Angeles Attracts Graffiti Nearby
description: You might be able to take the art out of the streets, but its tough to take the street out of the art.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Super-Hero Central
description: There is a lot of turnover on the Manga list this week, and all of the new titles are from VIZ Media. Theres Season 2, Volume 4 of Rosario+ Vampire about life in high school (with werewolves and vampires as classmates) at No. 1; Volume 23 of Skip Beat!, about fame and heartbreak is at No. 2; Blue Exorcist, Volume 1, by Kazue Kato, is third; and Volume 4 of Dengeki Daisy, about strange calls that Daisy gets on the cellphone of her deceased brother, is next.

title: To Catch a Frigate Bird
description: Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and a fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, writes from Panama, where he is studying sleep in wild frigate birds.

title: For Buffett, No More Trips to Pine Valley
description: The decision by ABC to cancel two of its stalwart soap operas, All My Children and One Life to Live, will put about 60 full-time actors out of work, not to mention the scores of part-time actors, producers, directors, writers and crew members employed by each show.

title: Post Your Childrens Reaction to Elmos Money Videos
description: So heres a little homework assignment, jumping off this weekends Your Money column, which reviews the first big efforts by Sesame Street to bring money lessons to the preschool set.

title: Say Hello to 929
description: Saturday is a big day for New York City: It is getting a new area code [pdf], a catchy little number called 929.

title: Comedys Bossypants
description: Tina Fey has written a bestselling memoir chronicling a career that has taken her from improv at Second City to Saturday Night Live, movies and 30 Rock.

title: House Freshmen Post Fund-Raising Numbers
description: 9:11 p.m. | Updated

title: After the Disasters in Japan, a Stoic Response From Aflac
description: CHOFU, Japan  Although Aflac is an American insurance company, the bulk of its revenue comes from Japan. That may be why the company has tried to take a characteristically Japanese approach to responding to this countrys devastating natural disaster.

title: Charting Burials Street Halo
description: Burial is a mysterious British producer who is part of the electronic microgenre called dubstep. His ghostly self-titled debut album, from 2006, and the follow-up Untrue (2007) were widely hailed in both dance and indie circles. Here is a chart of his latest single, Street Halo:

title: Video: The Importance of Wisconsin
description: Read Monica Daveys related story, Wisconsin Awaits Outcome of Supreme Court Vote, published in Wednesdays Times.

title: Why Goldman Is Not a Simple Culprit in the Financial Crisis Report
description: The Senate Permanent Investigation Subcommittees report on the financial crisis is an important document. It is an exhaustive look at certain main aspects of the financial crisis, a report which heavily criticizes Washington Mutual, the now-defunct Office of Thrift Supervision, the credit ratings agencies, Goldman Sachs and Deutsche Bank.

title: Whats the Best Exercise?
description: Looking for the best exercise for your body? Maybe its walking, running, squats or even the butterfly stroke.

title: A 30-Year Run for Jean M. Auel
description: The Land of Painted Caves, the sixth book in Jean M. Auels ice age Earths Children series, debuts at No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list this week.

title: A Second Debut for The Help
description: Kathryn Stocketts The Help, a tale of a young white woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi, tops todays trade paperback list in its first week of release in that format.

title: In the House, Liberal and Conservative Budget Plans Come to the Floor
description: Once in a while, the most meaningless votes in Congress are the most interesting ones.

title: ComicCon for Aspiring Snookis
description: The Reality Rocks Expo, held in Los Angeles last weekend, was the first major fan convention for reality television fans.

title: Big Ant and Vyxsin and, Maybe, You
description: Los Angeles

title: Mortal Kombat Is Back In a Fight for the Future
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia

title: A Good Book, Absent God
description: It is hard to imagine lying down with The Good Book and not inviting Google into bed, too.

title: In Euro Zone, Effects of Trade Collapse Linger
description: AMERICAN exports have fully recovered from the world trade collapse, but those of most other major industrial countries are still well below the levels they reached before the recession.

title: The Cloud Threat to the Software Business
description: In an article published Friday I wrote about cloud computing in the corporate world  its slow embrace so far, despite all the marketing hype, and signs that the pace may be picking up.

title: Five Cities Aspire to Be First to Twin Titles
description: In the 60 years that the N.B.A. and the N.H.L. have both crowned champions, city officials have never been forced to endure the civic headache of celebrating both leagues titles at once.

title: Look of the Moment | Alexis Bledel
description: The Look: Bolt from the blue  sapphire blue crystals and gold paillettes give this prim tea-length dress a carnal allure.

title: One Actress, Many Sides
description: A look at the varying film roles of Angelina Jolie. Her film Wanted is now on DVD.

title: Reality-TV Originals, in Dramas Lens
description: WHEN the documentary series An American Family was broadcast on PBS in 1973, critical and popular reaction varied, but many viewers, including prominent ones, agreed that it was a watershed of some kind. The anthropologist Margaret Mead proclaimed the show as new and significant as the invention of drama or the novel. For a host of commentators, conservatives and liberals alike, the series heralded nothing less than the demise of the nuclear family. Looking back on it in the 1980s, the philosopher Jean Baudrillard described An American Family as a symptom of our altered relationship with reality, characterized by dissolution of TV in life, dissolution of life in TV.

title: The Feel-Bad Hit Of the Season
description: AN acridness hung in the air during the New Groups revival of Wallace Shawns Marie and Bruce on a recent night, something I dont often experience at the theater. It was the thick, curdled aura of an audiences collective discomfort.

title: Ukulele Crazy
description: LIKE everybody else, Eddie Vedder was shocked by what the ukulele could do.

title: From Soft, Feathery Vocals to Locomotive Sax
description: Alison Krauss & Union Station

title: Book Review Podcast: Death and Taxes
description: This week: the poet and essayist Meghan ORourke on her memoir of her mothers death, The Long Goodbye; Jennifer Schuessler discusses her back-page essay on David Foster Wallace and the I.R.S.; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler returns with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: ESPN and MasterCard Put Focus on Futbol
description: ESPN and MasterCard Worldwide are joining forces for an extensive branded-entertainment project that is centered on soccer.

title: Protesters Disrupt House Budget Debate
description: 7:25 p.m. | Updated Protesters disrupted debate on the floor of theHouse of Representatives on Friday, and nine people were removed from the House gallery, arrested and charged with unlawful conduct and disruption of Congress. As RepresentativeChris Van Hollen of Maryland, the ranking member of the budget committee, made his final case for a Democratic alternative to the House Republicans budget plan, protesters began to chant and sing their version ofThe Star Spangled Banner about eight times, and were removed by the police from the gallery.

title: Four Phone-Hacking Cases to Be Tests for Further Claims, Judge Says
description: LONDON  Confronted with the prospect that dozens more potential phone-hacking victims might emerge and sue the tabloid News of the World, a High Court judge said on Friday that he would proceed with four of the current cases, using them as tests to assess damages for further claims.

title: The Pale King': Battling Tax Boredom in Peoria
description: President Ronald Reagan began a radio speech 25 years ago by reading from a very famous U.S. government document. It wasnt the Declaration of Independence or Lincolns Second Inaugural, but a notoriously tangled sentence from Section 509(a) of the Internal Revenue Code:

title: U.S. Expands Seeding of Biomass
description: A few months ago we wrote about Kristianstad, Sweden, an area that now uses biomass to generate all of its heat and some of its electricity. That city pioneered use of this renewable technology, and gradually biomass evolved from a niche component of its fuel mix to the backbone of its fuel supply.

title: 2 Korean Search Engines File a Complaint Against Google
description: SEOUL  The two biggest Internet search engines in South Korea filed a complaint on Friday with the Fair Trade Commission, charging that Google was blocking the installation of their services on smartphones preloaded with Googles Android operating system.

title: Lauren Widel and Henry Rohlich
description: THAT a young man from a small town in rural Delaware could be swept away by an effervescent, cosmopolitan woman to her Southeast Asian island home seems a fantasy. And yet, Henry Rohlich was presented with just this proposal for lifelong romantic adventure.

title: Jonathan Levin Awarded Clark Medal
description: Jonathan Levin, 38, has been awarded the 2011 John Bates Clark Medal, an annual prize given to the most promising economist under 40.

title: Bus Was Going 78 M.P.H. Just Before Fatal Crash on I-95, Investigators Say
description: The bus that crashed in the Bronx last month, killing 15 passengers, was traveling as fast as it could go  78 miles an hour  less than a minute before it flipped onto its right side and slammed into a signpost, federal investigators said Friday.

title: Spring Theater of the Absurd
description: Fashion is many things: beautiful, frivolous, devout, serious  sometimes all at once. It is performance and craft, in whatever style. In photographs and videos, it supplies us with visual intelligence. On May 2, when Daphne Guinness climbs into a window at Barneys New York to prepare for the Costume Institute gala that evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, I hope I have my own frock ready so I can go and watch. Do I think my friend is nutty? Yes, a little. Brave, definitely. And I am far from confident at this stage that anyone can create a performance-art piece with fashion that will mean anything, least of all in a luxury store window on Madison Avenue, and a time when apparel isnt selling so well. But Ill go anyway, just to see.

title: The Use and Abuse of Literature
description: Introduction

title: Bosses Pressed Russian Judge, Official Says
description: MOSCOW  The judge in last years politically charged trial of the former oil tycoon Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky openly admitted that the verdict would be dictated to him by his superiors, a former court official charged in an interview published on Friday.

title: How I Fell for Milan
description: FOR the first 10 years of our relationship, Milan and I were constantly at odds with each other. For my part, the list of gripes included the citys notorious weather  alternately simmering hot or cold as a dungeon and, since much of the city is constructed over filled-in canals, perennially humid; the dearth of contemporary cultural attractions; the fact that the place becomes a ghost town most Fridays, when any self-respecting (there are no other kinds, really) Milanese of means abandons the city for a weekend retreat in the mountains or by the sea.

title: A Fashion-Forward Guide to Antwerp
description: THERE is something strikingly eccentric about Europes historic harbor cities. Perhaps its the centuries of trade and exposure to objects and people from afar; maybe theres something in the water. But whatever it is, Antwerp, a small Belgian city about 40 miles southeast of the North Sea, with expansive docklands along the wide Schelde River, is a place where  amid the postcard-ready quaintness of old Europe  one finds corners of unusual idiosyncrasy and surprise.

title: Destination Dining in Department Stores
description: ITS an age-old truth  albeit one scientifically untested  that shopping builds hunger. Here are four restaurants in department stores (and one shopping complex) around Europe that are worth a visit for those with an appetite.

title: How to Shop in Paris
description: THERE may be no city that takes shopping more seriously than Paris, the birthplace of haute couture and a place where mere browsers, while welcome, can still be made to feel snubbed in subtle ways. In fact, the French term for window shopping, faire du lche-vitrine, translates directly as to go window licking. To shop more like a local, it helps to know the score at the coolest stores in town. Here are four of them.

title: Europe in 15 Perfect Gifts, All Under $100
description: Amsterdam to Athens, 15 stores to explore, and  for those in a buying mood  to find a gift to bring back home.

title: Shopping in Antwerp
description: Amid the cobbled streets and historic facades, energy and talent are bursting from this small Belgium city.

title: Milans Best-Kept Secrets
description: The Milanese love beautiful things, luxurious things, and it is for that reason perhaps that Italian fashion maintains its global position.

title: Waffles Made, and a Promise Kept, at P.S. 10
description: Dennis M. Walcott, the incoming city schools chancellor, was so excited on Thursday night that he had trouble sleeping. He woke up at 3:30 a.m., then again at 5:20, and went out for a two-mile run. By 7:30, he was at Public School 10 in Park Slope, Brooklyn, waffle batter and electric waffle press in hand.

title: A Beautiful Mine
description: The only thing clear about diamonds may be the translucent stones themselves. Everything else is murky and vaguely sinister: where they come from, who dug them up and under what conditions, and, more particularly, if they reek of evil. A diamond isnt like fur, which cant do much to hide its origins. But there is a lurking suspicion that, like the gold of the Nibelungs, no good can come from this bright rock. It doesnt help that the one word that rushes unbidden to stand next to diamond is blood. Diamonds are guilty until proven innocent.

title: The Vote on Term Limits
description: An overview of where New York City Council members stand on the issue of extending term limits.

title: City Council Revises Term Limits
description: The New York City Council voted to revise a term limits law, allowing Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to seek re-election next year.

title: Rays Come Back in Game 2
description: Tampa Bays James Shields dodged danger for five and two-thirds shutout innings Thursday, and the rookie David Price got the final seven outs.

title: William N. Lipscomb Jr., Nobel Prize-Winning Chemist, Dies at 91
description: William N. Lipscomb Jr., a Harvard chemistry professor who won a Nobel Prize in 1976 for his research on the structure of molecules and on chemical bonding, died on Thursday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91.

title: House Approves Republican Budget Plan to Cut Trillions
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Friday muscled through a budget plan that pares federal spending by an estimated $5.8 trillion over the next decade while reshaping Medicare in a proposal that immediately touched off a fierce clash with Democrats.

title: Business Professor Defends Galleon Chiefs Trades
description: 8:19 p.m. | Updated

title: Sabres Miller Shows Playoff Moxie
description: Buffalo Sabres goalie Ryan Miller maybe has been playing it clever this season. Fans wondered if there was something wrong with him, as he didnt look as consistently strong as the goalie who won the Vezina Trophy and the most valuable player award at the Vancouver Olympics last year.

title: Agency Seeks Again to Delist Great Lakes Wolves
description: The population of gray wolves in the western Great Lakes region is healthy enough that it no longer merits protection under the Endangered Species Act, the federal Fish and Wildlife said Friday.

title: After Recession and Scandals, Private Residence Clubs Start to Resurface
description: FRACTIONAL and private residence clubs for the wealthy have been on a roller coaster for much of the last decade. They were all the rage at one point but written off during the recession. Now, two groups are betting that the market may have hit bottom and is ready for a comeback.

title: U.S. Cracks Down on Online Gambling
description: In an aggressive attack on Internet gambling, federal prosecutors on Friday unsealed fraud and money laundering charges against operators of three of the most popular online poker sites. The government also seized the Internet addresses of the sites, a new enforcement tactic that effectively shuttered their doors.

title: Big Deal | Buy One, Get One (Sort Of)
description: It is highly unusual in the West Village, even more so on a street only one block long, to see two neighboring town houses go on the market at the same time.

title: Cooking With Sprouted Brown Rice
description: If youve never heard of sprouted brown rice, youre not alone, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Tea Party Groups Celebrate Tax Day with Big Name Republicans
description: Most Americans dread Tax Day. But Republican presidential candidates? They wouldnt miss it for the world.

title: Chrysler Plans $7 Billion Debt Offering
description: The Chrysler Group plans to sell about $7 billion worth of new debt to repay loans it received from the American and Canadian governments as part of its reorganization, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Friday.

title: Thats Funny: Comedy Across the Curriculum
description: Comedy is news this month, with the 20th anniversary of Comedy Central, the publication of Tina Feys Bossypants, Will Ferrells new role on The Office, Trey Parker and Matt Stones The Book of Mormon on Broadway, and at least one legless reptile on Twitter.

title: Without This Ring, I Thee Wed
description: OF the many issues facing Prince William and Kate Middleton as they approach their April 29 union, controversy has not been among them.

title: For Hopefuls, Part of Battle Is Just Getting to the Derby
description: Todd Pletchers mood was as gloomy as the fog and mist that shrouded his barn at Belmont Park. His big horse, Uncle Mo, had returned to the racetrack for the first time since his only defeat, in the Wood Memorial last Saturday. The colt was bright-eyed, his stride was fluid, and he looked comfortable for a mile jog on the training track.

title: The Secret World of Swiss Banks
description: With the tax deadline looming, CNBC looks at the games that wealthy Americans play to avoid paying Uncle Sam.

title: On Pinwheels, Networks and Resilience
description: I had an utterly minor experience today that helped reinforce my personal sense of where to focus if the goal is fostering a relatively smooth ride as human populations and appetites crest in coming decades.

title: Now Online | T Summer Fashion and Beauty
description: Ts Summer Fashion and Beauty issue is loaded with gems. In a A Diamond in the Roughage, the photographer Richard Burbridge and the set designer Gary Card transform the model Tati into a floral fantasy worthy of Arcimboldo. (Extra points if you can spot the carats.) For A Beautiful Mine, the writer Joshua Levine travels to South Africa with the jewelers behind the Los Angeles line Hoorsenbuhs to look for ethically mined diamonds. But not to be overlooked is our cover star, Cate Blanchett. She is well known, of course, for her portrayals of everyone from Queen Elizabeth I to Katharine Hepburn. In her new film, Hanna, she tries the role of ruthless C.I.A. agent on for size. But lesser known perhaps are the slew of roles she plays off-screen, including the co-artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company, an eco-activist who works with the Australian Conservation Foundation and the mother of three young boys. That is what we call multifaceted. See more from the issue >>

title: Viewers Not So Mad About Paul Reisers Return
description: Twelve years after Mad About You, Paul Reiser made a low-rated return to NBCs comedy line-up on Thursday. Just 3.3 million viewers tuned in to the premiere of The Paul Reiser Show at 8:30 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The new series faces considerable odds, coming after NBCs similarly ratings-starved sitcom Community (3.5 million), at 8 p.m., and occupying a time slot otherwise dominated by American Idol on Fox. For the night, NBC ranked a distant third, garnering its best ratings at 9 p.m. for The Office (7.7 million), which featured a guest appearance from Will Ferrell. Fox led the night with 21 million viewers tuning for an elimination episode of Idol and 11.9 million at 9 p.m. for Bones. CBS placed second, despite broadcasting a line-up of all repeats. ABC was fourth, finishing close behind NBC with reruns from 9 to 11 p.m. following a new episode of Wipeout at 8 (6.2 million).

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: Status Update as Wedding Invitation: Oops!

title: Patterns: Treating Other Conditions May Stave Off Alzheimers, Study Finds
description: Older people suffering from mild memory and cognition problems may be less likely to progress to full-blown Alzheimers disease if they receive treatment for medical conditions like diabetes, high blood pressure and cholesterol, a new study has found.

title: Hazards: More Culprits in Hair Loss Than Just the Salon
description: Many black women suffer from severe permanent hair loss, but little research has been done on the causes of the problem, often dismissed as a cosmetic worry. Still, chemicals used to straighten hair have long been suspected of playing a role.

title: Always a Purple State?
description: Monica Davey reports on the importance of Wisconsin. A State Supreme Court race there, which had become a referendum on the state's new Republican leadership, is still awaiting a final outcome.

title: Hailing a Taxi of Tomorrow
description: A test drive in a yellow-and-black Ford Transit Connect turns heads in Manhattan.

title: The Selby | Hugue Dufour of M. Wells
description: We arent trying to be anything other than a diner, says Sarah Obraitis, who runs the restaurant M. Wells on an industrial stretch in Queens with her husband, Hugue Dufour. But despite the dining cars site, just steps from the Midtown Tunnel, this is no truck-stop operation. Dufour, a French-trained chef and former co-owner of Montreals Au Pied de Cochon, churns out ambitious dishes like foie gras tamales, lamb and beef burgers and bone marrow topped with escargot. You cant deny the richness of our food, Obraitis admits. But we do have doughnuts. Theyre straight up with just cinnamon and sugar. Go to interactive >> | Sam Siftons Review

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

description: At the N.B.A. owners meeting, Mayor Kevin Johnson of Sacramento made a strong enough impression with his pitch to keep the Kings that the leagues relocation committee put off until May 2 the deadline for the teams owners to formally apply to relocate the franchise to Anaheim.

title: To Sleep, Perchance Not to Crash a Plane
description: Reading yesterday about yet another air-traffic controller who fell asleep, I immediately thought about the story How Little Sleep Can You Get Away With?  in this Sundays health-and-wellness special issue of the magazine. I asked Maggie Jones, who wrote the story, what she thought about the air-traffic-controller situation. She said:

description: Attention, Lincoln Tunnel motorists: There is nothing wrong with your radio set; do not attempt to adjust the signal. The Tunnel is controlling transmission.

description: Angela Tillman Sperandio and Samir Bouabana, the graphic designers from the Netherlands behind the design studio Hjrta Smrta, are publishing a wonderful series of books about female graphic designers and art directors who have served as their role models.

title: Taxi, the Remake: A Casting Call
description: THE shape of the New York City taxicab will soon start to change. As the current hodgepodge of sedans, minivans and crossovers is phased out, a single tall, upright van design will be phased in, until eventually almost all yellow cabs will look the same.

title: Go Down, Moussa
description: Moussa Koussa was once Muammar Qaddafis much-feared henchman. Not perhaps henchman in chief, but right up there in the hench. (Alas, that doesnt quite work. The O.E.D. tells me hench is derived from a word for horse.) More recently he was Qaddafis foreign minister and, toward the end, fear almost shaded into pity as an increasingly desperate looking Koussa tried to convey Libyan policy  that is, to explain the unexplainable.

title: Do Issues Matter For Elections? A Test
description: Now that Republicans have voted for the Ryan plan, big tax cuts for the rich, ending Medicare as we know it, and all, we may have a chance to test a major proposition in political science.

description: Over on the Your Money column this weekend, Ron Lieber lands an interview of which I am more than a little envious. He interviews Elmo.

description: Kate Rose Itzkowitz and Andrew Michael Pagano were married Saturday evening at the Metropolitan Building, an event space in Long Island City, Queens. Samantha L. Pinches, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Live Church minister for the occasion, officiated.

Gerlach and Judge Gary A. Gerlach of Milwaukee. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the New Haven Lawn Club, with the assistance of the bridegrooms father, who retired from the Milwaukee County Circuit Court.

McGuirl, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with the assistance of Rabbi Jeffrey Gale at Terrace on the Park in Corona, Queens.

Acoutin, a Universal Life minister, officiated aboard the Ambassador, a charter yacht, of which he is also the captain. Richard Zuniga, a lay pastor of the Chinese Evangelical Free Church in Monterey Park, Calif., also took part.

Lee, was married Saturday to Michael Eliot Lee, a son of Diana Lee and Chester Lee of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Paul Smith, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at One Atlantic, a party space in Atlantic City.

description: Zoe Elizabeth Kiefer and Zeke Mikhail Phillips were married Saturday evening at Round Hill House in Washingtonville, N.Y. Sandra B. Wells, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: TimesCast | April 15, 2011
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's forces fire cluster bombs into civilian areas; and an Italian activist is captured and killed in Gaza.

title: Sentence of the Week, Insomnia Edition
description: This was one of those magical weeks of bedtime reading, when the house got perfectly quiet and my books got very loud and I ended up staying up until 2 in the morning just about every night. I was reading: a big, heavy, three-volume hardcover edition of Samuel Johnsons Lives of the Poets; a newfangled iPhone essay (with pictures, audio, etc.) about ants called Before the Swarm; Father and Son, Edmund Gosses 1907 memoir about growing up with evangelical Christian parents (this was also on my iPhone, via the less high-tech Project Gutenberg); and an advance copy of Nicholson Bakers erotic fantasy novel House of Holes: A Book of Raunch. (This wont be published until August, but  hoo-boy, people, get ready for this book. It is going to be Talked About. There will be fistfights in the hallways of your local public library. I keep describing it to people as porny Alice in Wonderland  an impossible combination of crazy, cheerful imagination and industrial-grade filth. It made me hoot out loud every other page or so, and on a few occasions my mouth actually, literally dropped open. Just get ready.)

title: iPad Resellers Now Camp Overnight at Apple Stores
description: On Wednesday morning I stopped by the SoHo Apple store in New York City to purchase an iPad for a family member. As I had anticipated, a store clerk said they were out of stock and recommended that I check back the following morning. When I asked what time I should arrive, the clerk hesitated, looked around as if about to tell me a secret and said: Well, do you see that group of people outside? Theyre already here waiting for tomorrows shipment of iPads.

title: Clouds Part for U.S. Solar Industry
description: A potentially dim week for the American solar power industry ended on a bright note instead.

title: Ephemeral Paradise, in Medium Format
description: It was a simple stroll on the outskirts of town that inspired the London-based photographer Hin Chua to pursue After the Fall, a project that ultimately took him to more than 40 cities and 15 countries.

title: A Mezzo Keeps It Simple, and Makes It Profound
description: The mezzo-soprano Sarah Connolly was singing By a Bierside, a stark reflection on death written in the World War I trenches by Ivor Gurney, when a tendril of hair fell into her face. It happens.

title: Chicks With Something to Peep About
description: AT Easter time, when the shops erupt in a pastel frenzy of chocolate bunnies, candy eggs and marshmallow chicks, I try hard to resist. Unless Im buying an artisanal rabbit made from single-origin chocolate, most of the confections look a lot better than they taste.

title: Christine Baranski: I Was Never Beautiful
description: CHRISTINE BARANSKI arrived at Michaels, the media hangout on West 55th Street, at 12:30 p.m. on the dot. A somewhat later arrival would have guaranteed an entrance, a gust of warm curiosity, but as she passed the empty tables at the front, the few patrons nosing their menus, I realized, or perhaps remembered, that such impromptu moments were best not left to chance. I should have reserved for 1 p.m.

title: Stage Presence Aplenty, the Better to Have Fun
description: There is something slightly (and deliciously) overwhelming about confronting a lineup studded with the likes of Carmen deLavallade, Robert La Fosse, Valda Setterfield and Gus Solomons Jr. The sheer history and stage presence that any one of these dancers represents alone, never mind cumulatively as members and guest artists of Paradigm, take a moment for an audience member to digest.

title: Mental Redistribution
description: Its well known from the work of Arthur Brooks and others that conservatives give much more to charity than liberals, especially charities meant to alleviate poverty. That makes sense. Liberals believe in government provisions more and conservatives believe in private provisions more. James Lindgren of Northwestern University recently published a Northwestern Law and Economics Research Paper in which he compared attitudes about income redistribution and other beliefs.

title: At the Junior Teams, the U.S. Benefits From a Lethal Lead
description: At the White House Junior Teams in the Netherlands last month, the winner, Israel, met the United States in Round 21 of the 23-round qualifying stage.
