description: A Modest Proposal for a Digital Dtente: 10 Rules to Make Sure Smartphones Dont Make Us Stupid

title: Keep Your Thumbs Still When Im Talking to You
description: YOU are at a party and the person in front of you is not really listening to you. Yes, she is murmuring occasional assent to your remarks, or nodding at appropriate junctures, but for the most part she is looking beyond you, scanning in search of something or someone more compelling.

title: G.D.P. Estimates Slide Further
description: Earlier this week we wrote that several prominent economic forecasters had lowered their estimates of gross domestic product growth in the first quarter of this year. Today saw even further declines.

title: Trendspotting | The Interview
description: Student photographers rove their campuses for The Times. This issue: dressing by degrees. Text by Brian Nichols

title: Lucalis Owner Stabbed and Is in Critical Condition
description: The Daily News reports that Mark Iacono, owner of the Brooklyn pizzeria Lucali is in critical condition after being stabbed by a man with whom he had been arguing on a street in Carrol Gardens.

title: Tuition in the News
description: Admissions stories are a staple of the news business, of course. They have been since the first baby boomer editor realized he couldnt afford the tuition of the school his kid desperately wanted to go to, and he dispatched his reporters to find out why the hell not.

title: Pop Quiz Answers
description: The following are answers to sample questions from the revised Graduate Record Examination, to be offered in August.

title: Big Blog on Campus
description: COLLEGE campuses have always had their boldface names: professors whove logged time in a White House cabinet, opined on PBS NewsHour or written Pulitzer Prize-winning best sellers. To this venerated lot we can add the academic blogger. A remarkable variety of scholars have achieved blogosphere fame, particularly those devoted to subjects related to the public sphere  politics, economics, legal affairs. Law school bloggers are practically their own category.

title: Admissions Tally 2011
description: A few weeks ago, colleges and universities notified millions of restless high school seniors of their admissions decisions for fall 2011. In an environment that becomes more competitive year after year, we asked a sampling of colleges and universities for a sense of how things were stacking up. Over all, admittance rates continued to decline. For example, the Ivy League on average admitted 10 percent of applicants, down from the 11 percent recorded last year. The results shouldnt surprise. Some 2.2 million online applications have been filed for the fall using the Common Application alone, up almost 22 percent from 2010. The glut of applications means admissions offices must deny an increasing proportion of students. But take heart: when the dust settled on last falls freshmen class, the average acceptance rate was 67 percent.

title: Transferring? Get Schooled
description: ABOUT a third of students change campuses on their way to a degree, but its often a bumpier ride than they expect.

title: A Guide to Branch Campuses
description: STUDY abroad is one thing, a degree abroad another. The movement is nascent, but it is possible to earn a degree from an American university without setting foot in the United States, or by flitting among campuses. American colleges and universities operate about 80 branches that offer full degrees, in English, according to the Observatory on Borderless Higher Education, a British research institute. Nearly 80 percent of them have opened since 1999.

title: N.Y.U. in the U.A.E.
description: IN a small classroom at New York University Abu Dhabi, Paulo Lemos Horta was pushing his students to explore the difficulties of translation. In some ways, it might have been a class on any American campus  except that virtually everyone was fluent in a second language.

title: The New G.R.E.
description: EIGHT years in the making, the revised Graduate Record Examination will be introduced on Aug. 1  really. (The debut was pushed back twice as technicalities overwhelmed.)

title: Rx: Read to Your Baby
description: IT was another hectic morning in the pediatric clinic of Bellevue Hospital Center, where the clamorous waiting room had been transformed into a reading room. Toddlers sat crowded onto blue mats as volunteers read loudly from childrens books. Dr. Perri Klass weaved in and out of the steady traffic of strollers. She hovered over one mat, where a 1-year-old named Bella used a pincer grip to lift a board book titled Lets Go to the Park, pointed at pictures and then looked at her mother.

title: Study Abroad in Hot Spots
description: THE world is a perilous place. Just look at Northeastern Universitys study-abroad record this past year: starting last April, the university was forced to suspend programs and evacuate students after State Department travel advisories in Thailand (anti-government violence); New Zealand (twice, for earthquakes in Christchurch in September and February); Egypt (revolution); and Japan (earthquake, tsunami, nuclear crisis). The university had planned to team up with an institution in Tunisia but put that on hold after unrest there.

title: Fragrance Spritzers Hold Their Fire
description: PAMELA VAILE is no fan of the swarm of spray-happy salesclerks who lie in wait at many department stores, all of them eager to douse passers-by with a sample of a fragrance that they are sure the shoppers will totally, absolutely love once they get a whiff. I myself will not walk through that main aisle where all the spritzers are, she said. I cant stand that.

title: Cuba: A Door Ajar
description: THOUSANDS of American college students have been effectively locked out of Cuba since 2004, when the Bush administration tightened restrictions on travel for academic, cultural and religious purposes. Cuba was then the third most popular study-abroad destination in Latin America (after Mexico and Costa Rica); 2,148 United States residents studied there in 2003-4. The number plunged 92 percent in just a year.

title: Teach, Pray, Live
description: WHEN 10 Jesuit priests moved into their new home at Fairfield University about a year ago, some of them couldnt fit their old desks into their new bedrooms. And we live out of our desks, says the Rev. Mark P. Scalese, who teaches at the university. He was referring to the Jesuits penchant for learning, as reflected in a 10-year training period known as formation that includes extensive graduate education. Many end up with three or four advanced degrees.

title: Learning to Listen to Distressed Classmates
description: DAN SULLIVAN, a junior at Worcester Polytechnic Institute, notices the warning signs now, even during finals when most everyone seems stressed.

title: Sharing the Pain, Online
description: IMalive.org, a new crisis intervention help line, hopes to reach troubled young people where they feel most comfortable  in virtual chats.

title: Pointers for Professors
description: Last year, a professor at Bryn Mawr College told a story to his class about how, in explaining a concept, he had confused an international student by referring to a candy bar common to Americans.

title: Test Prep by Text
description: A CONVINCING argument to Mom and Dad for why you need more texting minutes: test prep. The latest entry in the mobile prep industry, SAT Remix, will text one of 300 formidable SAT words precisely at 7 oclock every night, Sunday to Thursday (teenagers are apparently too tired on Friday). The words, accompanied by breakbeat or house, can be played as an audio file and saved as a ringtone.

title: Bingo! Not for Seniors Only
description: BRYANT University in Rhode Island recently unveiled its latest acquisition  a $1,500 Gemstone bingo console, with black light  christened by its president, with some 400 students in attendance. This may be a church-lady game, but its big at Bryant. And this is bingo for the XBox generation: to break a tie, players bust moves in a dance-off.

title: Dont Even Think About Smoking Here
description: THERES a new accreditation on the block. Campuses eager to flaunt their smoke-free status can apply for certification by the health-education organization Bacchus Network. The nonprofit offers three levels of certification  silver, gold or diamond.

title: Yankees Place Hughes on Disabled List
description: Phil Hughes, whose 2011 season has consisted of three disastrous starts and a rub-your-eyes-in-disbelief 13.94 earned run average, was put on the 15-day disabled list Friday. Yankees Manager Joe Girardi declared that Hughes, a 25-year-old right-hander, was going through a dead-arm period.

title: Editors Note
description: Back in early 2002, when Gary Taubes was writing a cover story called What If Its All Been a Big Fat Lie? for this magazine, he and I had lunch every couple of months at Les Deux Gamins, a cafe in the West Village. At the time, I was one of those normal people who ate Cheerios for breakfast, but all that changed as I got to know Gary better. My lunches with him were like meetings with a parole officer, only it wasnt a life of crime that Gary was steering me away from  it was a life of carbohydrates. The first time we went to Les Deux Gamins, the waitress offered us a bread basket. She never did again.

title: Secret Tape of Officer and Accuser Is Crucial to Rape Case
description: On the tape played in court, a few moments after Police Officer Kenneth Moreno says Yes, I did, when a woman presses him on whether he used a condom when he had sex with her, he asks what she remembers from that evening.

title: Seaport Museum Seeks Berths for Vessels
description: The Seaport Museum New York is in talks with various maritime centers about taking its working vessels on a temporary or permanent basis to help defer costs. The museum  at 12 Fulton Street and formerly named the South Street Seaport Museum  is struggling financially, and in February it furloughed 32 employees, half of the staff. It has held conversations with the Hudson River Maritime Museum in Kingston, N.Y.; with Schooner Inc., a nonprofit maritime center in New Haven; and the Gloucester Maritime Heritage Center in Massachusetts.  Mary Pelzer, the Seaport Museums executive director, did not respond to messages seeking comment. The museum has said that it plans to sell Peking, the museums flagship merchant ship.

title: J.&J. in Deal Talks With Synthes
description: Christian Hartmann/ReutersSurgical power tools made by Synthes, a Swiss-American company.

title: Chic in Review | Kate Middletons Down-Do
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Sex Drive, Idling in Neutral
description: THIS is the story a friend told me: One night at a gathering at an apartment in New York City, a woman blithely announced, I would pay someone to have sex with my husband. There were snorts and yips of laughter. I believe one woman even clapped. What did they mean? I asked my friend. Heres to no sex with our husbands ever again? Heres to the end of sex?

title: The Week in Pictures for April 15
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include an urban garden in Battery Park in Manhattan, a voodoo ceremony in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, and a military homecoming at the Harlem Armory.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra May Seek Bankruptcy Protection
description: Painting a dire financial picture, leaders of the troubled Philadelphia Orchestra said on Friday that bankruptcy protection was vital to its survival.

title: A Bachs Lost Passion, From Kiev to New York
description: When a long-lost manuscript by a major composer turns up, expectations can be blown out of proportion. Any scramble to realize a freshly found sliver from Mozarts quill  which is to say, to bring it to exploitable condition  will almost certainly exceed what is ultimately heard.

title: Finding the Soul of Russia Everywhere
description: Did you know that the sighing first theme of Brahmss Fourth Symphony is actually a Russian folk song? Or that the mellow chorale played by the woodwinds at the beginning of the slow second movement is obviously inspired by a Russian Orthodox male choir?

title: Heaven, Love and Water, but No Dreaming
description: This is an anthem for the individual, K. D. Lang said on Thursday night at Le Poisson Rouge, by way of introducing Sing It Loud, the title track of her new album. Theres probably a few people who feel that they dont fit in here tonight. The crowd approved with murmurs and whoops. Even if they didnt fit in elsewhere, they were home here.

title: David Ferry Wins the Ruth Lilly Poetry Award for Lifetime Achievement
description: Who says poetry doesnt pay? The Poetry Foundation has awarded the translator and poet David Ferry the $100,000 Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize for lifetime achievement.

title: The Darker Colors of Patriotism
description: To judge solely by one work, Ledoh, the Burmese-born choreographer who heads Salt Farm, is enthralled by tension. In ColorMeAmerica , which opened at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night, he explores the disintegration of freedom in the name of patriotism. Just as the words in the title bleed together purposefully, this look at America isnt always beautiful; rather, its all very fraught.

title: Seaport Museum Seeks Berths for Vessels
description: The Seaport Museum New York is in talks with various maritime centers about taking its working vessels on a temporary or permanent basis to help defer costs. The museum  at 12 Fulton Street and formerly named the South Street Seaport Museum  is struggling financially, and in February it furloughed 32 employees, half of the staff. It has held conversations with the Hudson River Maritime Museum in Kingston, N.Y.; with Schooner Inc., a nonprofit maritime center in New Haven; and the Gloucester Maritime Heritage Center in Massachusetts. Frank J. Sciame, the Seaport Museums chairman, said through a spokesman that the museum is exploring various options regarding the maintenance of its historic vessels. The museum has said that it plans to sell Peking, the museums flagship merchant ship.

title: Podcast: Good Euros, Bad Euros and Market Worries
description: Greshams Law is a centuries-old economic principle that is often defined quite simply as bad money drives out good money.

title: Young, Restless and Glued to Soaps
description: My first, most vivid television memory is of watching the Watergate hearings in 1973 at my rapt mothers side. My second involves exposure to villainy of another kind  that of Billy Clyde Tuggle, the sort of pimp who drugged his employee base on All My Children. For these encounters with Tuggle, my mother was absent. She was then, and remains now, in her late 80s, a largely news only, no sap, thank you participant in the experience of American television. She reserved (and reserves) her greatest disdain for soap opera drivel and, inevitably perhaps, my addiction to daytime television became my most impassioned act of adolescent subversion.

title: Capturing a Self-Image
description: KIM KARDASHIAN has cellulite!

title: When Publicists Say Shh!
description: CELEBRITY publicists these days should demand hazard pay.

title: Wine With Character
description: The manga series The Drops of the Gods follows Shizuku Kanzaki as he learns about wine, allowing the reader to do the same.

title: When Soloists Dont Necessarily Star
description: The composer Petr Kotik is also an adventurous conductor who founded and directs both the S.E.M. Ensemble, based in New York, and the Ostravska Banda, based in Ostrava, in the Czech Republic. Every now and then Mr. Kotik brings his groups together, as he did on Wednesday evening at Zankel Hall. As in previous collaborations, their chemistry was just about perfect.

title: An Uphill Battle, All in the Name of Art
description: Simone Fortis Slant Board was first performed in 1961 in Yoko Onos loft on Chambers Street in Lower Manhattan. Ms. Ono was not at the Fitzroy Gallery in SoHo on Thursday night, where this 10-minute piece was presented a single time as part of the exhibition Shelf Ramp Wedge Bridge/1. But a host of art world and performance art figures, including Carolee Schneemann, Charlemagne Palestine, Joan Jonas and Dan Graham, were part of a packed crowd on hand for Ms. Forti, a choreographer often associated with the Judson Dance Theater although never formally a part of it.

title: Sauvignon Blanc Season
description: In spring, ones thoughts turn naturally to sauvignon blanc, a dry white wine with aromas and flavors that are generally described as grassy, green, herbaceous and vegetal. Their zesty acidity yields long finishes.

title: One Man, Three Hats: A Turkish Experience
description: MIKE SARAC is practically a one-man band at Caf Taka in Bay Shore. He is co-owner of the three-month-old Turkish spot with his wife, who does not work there; he is the chef and often the waiter as well. (He has a helper in the kitchen and a part-time waiter on weekends.)

title: A Fest for the Eyes
description: Kicking off this weekend at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, the Fashion in Film Festival will be showing its third series of quality films, Birds of Paradise. Focusing primarily on the role of the costume, the festival aims to serve as a visual history lesson for fashion and film buffs with a timeline of European and American cinematic gems. Films scheduled to screen include the rare (Nino Oxilias Rapsodia Satanica, Jack Smiths Normal Love) and the already loved (Cecil B. DeMilles Male and Female).

title: Sweet Luxury
description: The display in the oriel window at Belgique Chocolatier in New Canaan features an arrangement of rabbits, flowers and eggs  a not-too-subtle reminder that Easter is just as much an occasion for chocolates as Valentines Day is. But these are not sweets to be scattered around the yard for your children to collect. Belgiques chocolates are made for more sophisticated palates, and priced that way, too.

title: Pizza Mecca Gets New Dcor and Menu
description: ALFORNO TRATTORIA, marking its 20th year in Old Saybrook this summer, has become something of a shoreline institution, known for its New Haven-style brick-oven pizza.

title: Above All Else, Monkey Bread
description: At Loaf, a new bakery and cafe, an assortment of breads  ciabatta, dill, whole wheat, raisin, foccacia and rye  line a high wooden shelf, their crusty good looks set off by a vibrant backdrop of buttercup-yellow paint. But the golden-brown monkey bread ($7), a pull-apart bread baked in a cake pan, and still warm from the oven, handily upstaged the others.

title: Reclaimed Classics, With Flavor Out Front
description: SOME diners may see the intentionally distressed renovation at Harpers, with its flea market portraitures and minimal illumination, as oddly artsy; others may find it appealingly urban. Whichever. Theres no denying that Chris Vergara, the executive chef of this casual Dobbs Ferry bar and restaurant (he also co-owns Meritage in Scarsdale), has done an admirable job of repurposing scrapped wood into useful table tops, wainscoting and handsome wall paneling.

title: From Four Wheels to Four Walls
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Community Health Faces Inquiry on Medicare Claims
description: Community Health Systems disclosed on Friday that it had received a subpoena by the federal government over possible improper billing of Medicare and Medicaid.

title: 2 Men With Badges and a Story to Tell
description: A Steady Rain is about two regular-guy big-city police officers from the American Midwest, so naturally when the play hit Broadway in the fall of 2009, the producers cast Daniel Craig and Hugh Jackman. The worldly, sexy, British-born James Bond. And the worldly, sexy, Australian-born Wolverine. The limited run of A Steady Rain made big money in New York, but no one seriously thought that audiences went to see the fine plotting or insightful character development by Keith Huff, the playwright. In fact, some critics declared the play itself weak. The Broadway run was all about the movie stars.

title: A Spy Comedy, Complete With an Airplane Chase
description: Alfred Hitchcock was famous for turning up onscreen in the movies he directed. His walk-on was a silent little joke, flying right over the heads of the oblivious characters in the film to land smartly in the audiences lap, a fleeting reminder that what they were watching was a fictional world concocted by the portly fellow who had just stepped out from behind the camera.

title: On School Buses, Ad Space for Rent
description: Cash-hungry states and municipalities, in pursuit of even the smallest amounts of revenue, have begun to exploit one market that they have exclusive control over: their own property.

title: Seeger and Friends, Newly Inspired, Will Meet for Benefit
description: WHEN the remaining giants of American folk music and their graying audience gather, the weight of history hangs heavy in the room. Memories of shared civil rights marches and antiwar rallies come flooding back, as do the inevitable questions about how the language of dissent they forged together can remain relevant.

title: Japanese Carmakers Struggles Could Put Customers in Rivals Showrooms
description: DETROIT  Facing shortages of some auto parts and dwindling supplies of popular cars later this spring and summer, Japanese automakers hope shoppers looking for a new car will compromise on color or extra features.

title: Bloggingheads: Fearing Islam
description: Imam Abdullah Antepli, left, of Duke University and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of GetReligion.org debate Americans' views of Islam.

title: At a Jazz Series, a Piano Also Stars
description: RAHWAY, N.J.

title: Examining the Doctor-Patient Handshake
description: To the Editor:

title: How a False Conviction Put a Man on Death Row
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Strings Are Paired With Poetry
description: Huntington, N.Y.

title: It Depends on What the Meaning of Metaphor Is
description: To the Editor:

title: In This Cinderella Story, the Princes Ball Was a Robbery in Queens
description: Cinderella: a fairy tale, a plucky young lady, a label for rags-to-riches success. And now, in Queens, the word is also a shorthand reference to criminal case No. Q11610636, and as such, an unfortunate nickname for an inmate in a Rikers Island jail dorm for men.

title: The High Stakes of Republicans Budget Vote
description: In Manhattan today, federal prosecutors released an indictment against the founders of the two largest companies to offer online poker to Americans, Full Tilt Poker and PokerStars, charging them with fraud and seeking more than $3 billion in penalties.

title: Civic Engagement by Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Unions Woo Airport Security Screeners
description: Public employee unions may be taking a shellacking in Wisconsin and Ohio, but that has not discouraged the unions representing federal employees from vying to recruit 44,000 airport screeners. It is the largest unionization effort of federal workers in the nations history.

title: A New Jersey Native Returns, Anything but Silent
description: KEVIN SMITH, the Red Bank native and director of New Jersey-based films like Clerks (1994) and Jersey Girl (2004), is under no illusions about his celebrity status in his home state.

title: Comfort Food, All Day and All Night Long
description: The downtown institutions of late night like Florent and the Empire Diner are gone, but their spirit lives on at Cafeteria, a 24-hour modern diner that opened in 1998 on Seventh Avenue at 17th Street. The sleek, minimalist decor and the menu of updated American comfort food still attract crowds of young partiers, celebrities and neighborhood residents. It is a place where those ending their evenings cross paths with those starting their days, where one table might ask for milk in a sippy cup while another asks for more beer. At 2:30 Sunday morning, the crowd included a table of friends from high school in Port Washington, N.Y., out for a bite after bar-hopping in Midtown.

title: California May Require Teaching of Gay History
description: LOS ANGELES  In California public schools, students are required to learn about black history and womens history. And if a bill approved by the State Senate this week becomes law, the state will become the first in the country to mandate that schools also teach gay history.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Young and Younger

title: Paul Violi, a Poet Both Wry and Sly, Dies at 66
description: Paul Violi, a poet with an easy, conversational style and satiric bent who reworked arcane historical verse forms and invented his own in poems that mimicked glossaries, errata slips, travel brochures and cover letters, died on April 2 in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y. He was 66 and lived in Putnam Valley.

title: Can Teetering Toddlers Find Balance in Yoga?
description: SOMETIMES getting a child into a childs pose is harder than it sounds.

title: Four-Wheeled Perk Is Felled by Budget Ax
description: LOS ANGELES  With Gov. Jerry Brown still unable to get agreement on cuts to the state budget, California legislators now have to endure a cut of their own: their vehicles.

title: In the Beefsteak Revival, Gluttony Is Good
description: EVERY now and then, it seems, some wistful city dreamer gets it into his head to resuscitate an old New York tradition and, before you know it, a newfangled speakeasy or a resurrected stickball league or an up-to-the-minute version of burlesque appears. At present, this seeming need for history has brought about a small rebirth of the classic New York beefsteak: the time-honored, Tammany-era smorgasbord where scores of hungry carnivores would gorge themselves on endless trays of sirloin and bottomless pints of beer.

title: Sprint C.E.O. Continues Battle Against Wireless Merger
description: AT&Ts proposed $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile USA threatens competition and innovation in the wireless industry, Dan Hesse, Sprint Nextels chief executive, said on Friday.

title: In Defense of Offense
description: Brief dialogue:

title: Builders Group and Executives Admit to Taking Kickbacks
description: A construction-management company and three of its officers pleaded guilty on Friday to a scheme in which its executives stole millions of dollars from clients at condominium and office projects in the New York area by submitting fake invoices and taking kickbacks from its subcontractors.

title: Immigrants Are Subject of Tough Bill in Georgia
description: ATLANTA  With Gov. Nathan Deals acknowledgment that he would sign a tough immigration law, Georgia was thrust on Friday into the center of the national fight over how much control states have in curbing illegal immigration.

title: Busy, Busy, Busy (Toting Pinky)
description: A former prosecutor and talk show host and an estranged alumna of The View, Star Jones, 49, last month published her third book, Satans Sisters, a roman  clef about a fictitious TV talk show featuring five women of clashing temperaments. Currently a contestant on Celebrity Apprentice 2011, Ms. Jones, who underwent open-heart surgery a year ago, has assumed the role of national volunteer for the American Heart Association. She lives on the Upper East Side with her dog, Pinky, a Maltese, and has a house in Wainscott, on Long Island. ROBIN FINN

title: Zoos 4-D Theater Tickles, While Tackling Wallets
description: Youre sitting in a seat that is vibrating ominously, though its not one of those coin-operated massage chairs. Someone is spitting on you. Something that might be a rat or a roach or a foot fetishist is flicking or possibly licking your ankles. Where are you?

title: An Uncivil War
description: With spring holidays upon us, it is perhaps appropriate to recall that there are times at which we must, if we are to be fully human, loose ourselves from the rationalist-materialist bonds of our daily existence and remember that life is about more than money.

title: Mr. Blackwell, Hollywoods Acerbic Fashion Critic
Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: Events on Longs Island
description: Comedy

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: The World This Week
description: The fall of Laurent Gbagbo; NATO shows signs of strain in its Libyan campaign; Qatar and the Arab Spring.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: Comedy

title: About My Support for Natural Gas
description: Oh, puh-leeze!

title: Patently Obvious
description: Los Angeles

title: From Pay-to-Play to Jail
description: New Yorkers, unfortunately, are all too accustomed to seeing state legislators sent off to jail for their misdeeds. When a court officer slipped handcuffs on Alan Hevesi, the former state comptroller, on Friday morning, however, Mr. Hevesi became the highest-ranking elected official in New Yorks modern history to go to prison for corruption.

title: One Year Later
description: Next week marks the first anniversary of an environmental disaster  the explosion at BPs Macondo oil well that killed 11 workers, sank the drilling rig, sent 4.9 million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico and threw thousands of people out of work. Yet Congress is behaving as if nothing at all happened, as if there were no lessons to draw from the richly documented chain of errors and regulatory shortcomings that contributed to the blowout.

title: Mortgage Woes Stall Bank of America Revival
description: As big banks slowly shake off losses from the financial crisis, Bank of America provided another reminder on Friday of how hard it is to shed the legacy of the past.

title: Critic of War Effort Does His Homework, Up Close
description: NEWPORT, R.I.

title: Breaking Through on Trade
description: After two years of dithering, it is good to see the Obama administration championing freer trade. Last week, the United States and Colombia announced a deal that will improve, and we hope finally win passage of, a 2006 trade agreement signed during the Bush administration. The amended version will strengthen worker protections in Colombia while boosting American exports.

title: An American Romantic Goes to War
description: Just two days after the surrender of Fort Sumter, a crowd gathered at City Hill in Worcester, Mass., to rally for war. Lincoln had called for troops to put down the insurrection the day before, and few responded as passionately as Worcesters citizens  chief among them abolitionist Thomas Wentworth Higginson. Tonight we have more than enthusiasm, announced Higginson. We have unanimity!

title: Mitt! Mitt! Mitt!
description: This was the week weve been waiting for! Decades into the future, you will be able to tell your grandchildren where you were when Mitt Romney announced that he had formed a presidential exploratory committee.

title: The Statue of Liberty Holds Its Own Against Las Vegas Facsimiles
description: LAS VEGAS  For the record, as if that mattered, Frdric Auguste Bartholdi was never a tourist here, having died in 1904, a year before the citys founding as a whistle stop. But the man and the city are now linked in a way that Bartholdi, a Frenchman, would surely never have imagined  the United States Postal Service, for a new stamp featuring Lady Liberty, chose an image not of the original statue in New York Harbor but of a replica at the traffic-choked corner of Tropicana Avenue and Las Vegas Boulevard.

title: Somali Pirates Release Some Prisoners
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  After receiving more than $3 million in ransom, Somali pirates released a hijacked ship and some of its crew, but kept the Indian crew members to try to win the release of pirates held by India, pirates and residents said.

title: The Pirates of Capitol Hill
description: Corporations are roaring. Wall Street is rolling in cash. C.E.O. bonuses are going gangbusters. Its a really good time to be rich!

title: At Titanic Gala, and Thankful for the Nosebleed Seats
description: The guests had just eaten a sumptuous dinner at the Guggenheim Museum on Thursday night, and an orchestra began playing an eerie dirge. Midway through, the partygoers were marched to their deaths.

title: U.S. Has Plans to Improve Online Business Security
description: The federal government plans to spend $56.3 million on technology intended to safeguard the online marketplace and those who operate in it, including consumers, businesses and government agencies. The fact is that the old password and username combination we often use to verify people is no longer good enough, and leaves Internet users vulnerable to ID and data theft, Gary Locke, the commerce secretary, said Friday at a conference in Washington. The network would let consumers use devices like software on a smartphone, a smart card, or a token that generates a one-time digital password, according to a White House statement.

title: Defense, Treading Carefully, Questions Accuser in Trial of 2 Officers
description: She had been on the witness stand for some eight hours spanning two days, recounting gruesome, emotional details of an evening in which she said a police officer raped her, when a moment of levity interrupted.

title: U.S. and China Agree to a Process to Analyze Risks in Economies Worldwide
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and China agreed on Friday to participate in a new international process that will review the risks that major economic powers pose to each other and to global growth and development.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 15, 2011

title: Fans Laugh and Cry for Humbled Pros 16 on Par 4
description: Kevin Na, a little-known professional golfer, chased his ball into some woods and brambles Thursday during a PGA Tour event in Texas. About five minutes and 16 frenzied, desperate and comical strokes later, he emerged a folk hero.

title: A Bunker Sets the Scene for Veterans to Exhibit Art
description: On a tranquil side street in brownstone Brooklyn, where the biggest battles are over takeout menus and strollers, looms a jarringly martial sight: dozens of olive-drab sandbags piled high under a saw-toothed zinc roof.

title: Man Stabs Restaurateur in Brooklyn, Police Say
description: The owner of Lucali, a famed pizzeria in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn, was brutally attacked and stabbed in broad daylight by an acquaintance on Friday afternoon, the police said.

title: Saturday: Is This Thing On?
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Some people will do anything for attention.

title: Ford Transit Connect: New Yorks Taxi of Tomorrow?
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Schwartz writes about his time behind the wheel of the Ford Transit Connect, one of three boxy high-top vans competing to become New Yorks next official taxi. A decision is expected from the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission within a month.

title: Uganda: Antigovernment Protest Set Off by Tuition-Increase Report
description: Anti-riot police officers clashed with student protesters at Ugandas most prestigious university Friday as students demonstrated against tuition increases and widespread government corruption. Students at Makerere University threw stones at the police and burned kiosks as officers shot rubber bullets and threw tear-gas canisters, above, into dormitories and fleeing crowds. The protest began over a report that university administrators planned to double the tuition, which the administration denied, but turned into a protest against President Yoweri Museveni. There have been several small protests over the last week against rising prices and corruption. Protests were also reported in the west on Friday. On Thursday, a former presidential candidate and leading opposition figure, Kizza Besigye, was shot during street demonstrations in Kampala, the capital.

title: China: 54 Detained in Crackdown
description: At least 54 people have been detained in the current crackdown on progressive thought and speech in China, according to a statement released Thursday by China Human Rights Defenders, an advocacy group. The latest person to be detained is Ni Yulan, a housing activist and former lawyer, after previously being tortured by security officers. Ms. Ni and her husband, Dong Jiqin, were taken on April 7 from a Beijing hotel where they had been living. Ms. Ni has not been charged with a crime. So far, four people have been criminally charged during the crackdown. Ms. Ni is likely to have come under increased scrutiny after Jon Huntsman Jr., the American ambassador, visited her in February. Mr. Huntsman and the United States government are suspected by some Chinese officials of promoting the calls for a so-called Jasmine Revolution to challenge Communist Party rule. The most famous of the 54 detainees is Ai Weiwei, an artist and democracy activist.

title: Indonesia: Police Station Bombed
description: A suicide bomber blew himself up during prayers in a mosque in a police station on Friday, wounding dozens of people and killing himself, antiterrorism officials said. The bomber attacked the police station in the West Java city of Cirebon while officers and members of the public crowded into the mosque, wounding at least 28 people, including the police chief, said Air Marshal Chairul Akbar, the general secretary of Indonesias National Antiterrorism Agency.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,518 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: NYC's Next Taxi Cab?
description: The Times' John Schwartz test drives Ford's Transit Connect, one of the three finalists in the competition for New York City's new taxi fleet.

title: Democrats Pounce on Chris Christies Blunt Words
description: Using harsh terms to attack his critics has been a regular feature of Gov. Chris Christies 15 months in office, and Democratic officials, wary of his and the voters wrath, have usually offered only a muted response.

title: At Mob Murder Trial, Judge Criticizes Defense Lawyers Actions
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn chided defense lawyers on Friday for their actions during the trial of a Mafia boss accused of murder.

title: Washington Mayors Missteps Cast Harsh Light
description: WASHINGTON  When Vincent C. Gray campaigned for mayor last fall, he promised to bring character, integrity and leadership back to the District of Columbia.

title: Rangers Fall Flat as Capitals Cruise to Victory
description: WASHINGTON  The Rangers tried to sound positive, but their situation looks grim.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Yankees Lose to Rangers as Hughes Goes on Disabled List
description: Hours after placing Phil Hughes, their struggling No. 3 starter, on the 15-day disabled list, the Yankees needed something, anything, to add a sense of solidity to a pitching staff that has stubbornly refused to coalesce in the early days of the season.

title: County Results Find Incumbent the Victor in Wisconsin
description: CHICAGO  David T. Prosser Jr., a Wisconsin Supreme Court justice whose re-election became intertwined with the states battle over cuts to collective bargaining rights, won the race by 7,316 votes, results from the states counties showed on Friday.

title: Celtics Depth Could Make All the Difference
description: Four summers ago, the Boston Celtics poached Ray Allen and Kevin Garnett, attached them to Paul Pierce and hatched a myth: that championships are built solely on three pillars.

title: Sports Replay: April 15
description: A look at the day in sports, including the Grand Prix in Shanghai, cycling and championship boxing.

title: Counting on a Player Named James, but This One Comes Off the Bench
description: MIAMI  At some point in the N.B.A. playoffs, which open this weekend, a Heat player named James will be asked to make a game-winning or series-changing shot.

title: Knicks Anthony Insists Its a Series, Not a Duel
description: There is nothing restrained or subtle about Carmelo Anthonys offense. He will shoot from anywhere on the court, at virtually any time, with just about anyone in front of him.

title: G.O.P. Push in States to Deregulate Environment
description: Weeks after he was sworn in as governor of Maine, Paul LePage, a Tea Party favorite, announced a 63-point plan to cut environmental regulations, including opening three million acres of the North Woods for development and suspending a law meant to monitor toxic chemicals that could be found in childrens products.

title: TimesCast | Cluster Bombs in Misurata
description: C.J. Chivers reports on the use of cluster bombs in civilian neighborhoods in Misurata.

title: Second Doubleheader in Two Days Doesnt Play Well With Mets
description: ATLANTA  After a double debacle on Thursday, the last thing the Mets needed or wanted was another doubleheader to compound their early-season difficulties. But a rainout at Turner Field on Friday left the Mets scrambling to line up pitchers for the rest of the weekend, and angry at the Braves for foisting a doubleheader on them on Saturday.

title: TimesCast | Italian Activist Killed
description: The Lede's Rob Mackey looks at the digital legacy of a slain pro-Palestinian activist.

title: Back in Style
description: As the Knicks return to the playoffs, so do the suits of Walt Frazier, who devotes hours to his broadcast attire.

title: Walt Frazier  Always in Style
description: In Walt Fraziers closet hangs a polyester cow-print suit with brown-and-black splotches. However absurd, it fits in a menagerie of 100 or so suits that hang on five racks and with patterns of tiger stripes and leopard spots; designs of bold plaids and checks; and colors of yellow, red, salmon and orange.

title: Civilian Casualties in Misurata
description: When cluster bombs like those used by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi are fired into populated areas, they place civilians at grave risk.

title: Garry Reigenborn, a Dancer and Influential Choreographer, Dies at 58
description: Garry Reigenborn, a dancer and choreographer who played an influential role in American experimental dance as a leading member of the Lucinda Childs Dance Company and as a teacher of Merce Cunninghams technique, died on March 10 in Canon City, Colo. He was 58.

title: The Myth of Playoff-Style Basketball
description: The system of playoff expectation in the N.B.A. has long been backward: rather than assuming regular season success translates seamlessly into postseason splendor, playoff teams are treated with skepticism unless theyve been there before. 82 games apparently arent enough to create a representative sample of a teams performance, and those who havent made extended postseason runs in the past are required to prove themselves once again before earning the respect of media pundits and basketball fans alike.

title: A House of Glass
description: The cascading public staircase that covers the new TKTS discount booth in Duffy Square is made almost entirely of structural-strength glass: walls, beams, treads and risers.

title: Come and Meet Those Stepping Feet
description: The newest lights on Broadway are at the new TKTS booth at 47th Street, which offers a kinetic panorama of Times Square.

title: Beats and Hot Buttons
description: Photos of Madonnas first American stop on her Sticky and Sweet Tour.

title: Architectural Monuments in a Reshaped Beijing
description: Explore five notable new projects in Chinas capital city, with audio commentary by Nicolai Ouroussoff.

title: Fighting Alcohol Bootleggers in Alaska
description: In Bethel, Alaska, state troopers have been given the mission of curbing the illegal trade of alcohol, banned or restricted in many rural Alaskan communities.

title: Life at Star City
description: For U.S. astronauts, Star City, Russia, the launching point for Soyuz rockets, can serve as a second home.

title: Space Souvenirs
description: A sampling of space collectibles from the first 50 years of NASA, and beyond.

title: Blast Kills 9 at Afghan Base, Including 5 From NATO
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For the second time in two days, a suicide bomber used an Afghan uniform to elude early detection and approach his target, killing five NATO service members attending an early Saturday meeting at the headquarters of the Afghan 201 Corps in the countrys east. The bombing was one of the worst attacks of its kind, NATO and Afghan military officials said.

title: Lively, Freaky Qualifying Session in China Despite Vettel Domination
description: We are only three races into the season but we are growing used to seeing the same man dominate everything, and todays qualifying session for the Chinese Grand Prix was no different. Sebastian Vettel scored the pole position and his Red Bull dominated the session from the beginning  no contest. Jenson Button and Lewis Hamilton were second and third fastest, for McLaren Mercedes, and Nico Rosberg was fourth fastest in the Mercedes.

title: Lively, Freaky Qualifying Session in China Despite Vettel Domination
description: We are only three races into the season but we are growing used to seeing the same man dominate everything, and todays qualifying session for the Chinese Grand Prix was no different. Sebastian Vettel scored the pole position and his Red Bull dominated the session from the beginning  no contest. Jenson Button and Lewis Hamilton were second and third fastest, for McLaren Mercedes, and Nico Rosberg was fourth fastest in the Mercedes.

title: Climbing Through Pennsylvanias Canopies
description: A canopy tour that proves leaf peeping is not for the faint of heart.

title: The Weekend Word: Recess!
description: Todays Times

title: Runway Wrap-Up: Spring 2009 Collections
description: A selection of looks that emblemize the spring 2009 ready-to-wear collections.

title: City Council Holds Hearings on Term Limits
description: The City Council heard testimony on a change to the term limits law that, if passed, would allow Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to run for a third term.

title: Previewing the New York Auto Show
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich looks ahead to the New York auto show, which opens to the media on April 20. The event opens to the public on April 22.

title: Rising Sectarian Violence in Tripoli
description: In northern Lebanon, sectarian violence has scarred the city of Tripoli and its economy.

title: One Last Time Together
description: Senators Barack Obama and John McCain met at Hofstra University on Wednesday night for the final presidential debate before the Nov. 4 election.

title: App Smart Extra: Help for Singers
description: You can record adequate-sounding audio on an iPhone or iPad, but if youre a more serious vocalist, radio journalist or podcaster, the devices audio features get pretty restricting, pretty quickly.

title: Lucerne Easter Festival: A Mix of the Expectations and Reality
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  The remarkable lineup of musical events and performers at the Lucerne Easter Festival this week has lived up to every realistic expectation. The trick is, in the face of such rich potential, to remain realistic.

title: Why So Many Applications for So Few Elite Spots? Continuing the Discussion
description: Earlier this week, NPRs To the Point asked Whos Applying to Harvard and Whos Getting In, with the program focusing on the surge of applications to the two or three dozen elite colleges and universities.

title: Inflation, Here and There (Wonkish)
description: A few notes about recent inflation developments.

title: A Second Chance
description: Drug courts give arrested addicts a chance to avoid jail by agreeing to a strict program of drug tests, counseling and addiction treatment.

title: Civility is the Last Refuge of Scoundrels
description: At the beginning of last week, the commentariat was in raptures over the Serious, Courageous, Game-Changing Ryan plan. But now that the plan has been exposed as the cruel nonsense it is, what were hearing a lot about is the need for more civility in the discourse. President Obama did a bad thing by calling cruel nonsense cruel nonsense; he hurt Republican feelings, and how can we have a deal when the GOP is feeling insulted? What we need is personal outreach; lets do lunch!

title: Bookshelf
description: Bharati Mukherjees novel Miss New India (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $25) presents the countrys seismic shifts from the perspective of Anjali, a provincial young woman climbing the class ladder. She falls in with a gay expat English teacher and, later, urban arrivistes who watch Seinfeld and tell her that Bangalore is just like Los Angeles, you know, the poor mans Bombay. Fire and Rain (Da Capo Press, $25), David Brownes cultural history of 1970, begins with three Beatles finishing Let It Be while John Lennon lams it in Denmark. (Paul Simon, meanwhile, amazes N.Y.U. students when he decides to teach a songwriting class.)

title: Private Residence Clubs: Anyone Still Buying In?
description: In this weeks Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan takes a look at the world of private residence clubs and fractional ownership real estate. The most well-known example is Exclusive Resorts, where a hefty sign-up fee plus other levies earn you the right to bed down in fancy vacation homes in exotic locales for several weeks each year.

title: A Look Back at the Week in Business
description: Photographs of news and features in business.

title: Say Yes to the Dress
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#568", 592, 723, true, chameleonData);

title: Libyan Rebels Say Theyre Being Sent Weapons
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Libyan rebels in their eastern capital of Benghazi said they had begun receiving arms from abroad, at the same time as forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi escalated their attacks on the besieged western city of Misurata.

title: Letters to the Editor: Questions for Baseball
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Finally Ready to Confront Everest After Fatal Climb of 96
description: ASPEN, Colo.  Neal Beidleman has tried to outrun his association with Everest. But the mountain, he said, was stapled and tattooed on my forehead. It was perhaps inevitable, then, that one day he would return.

title: A Summer With Uncle Casey in the Town He Owned
description: Uncle Casey?

title: A Tour of Laurent Gbagbos Palace
description: After opposition forces unseated Ivory Coasts strongman, soldiers and ministers in President Alassane Ouattaras government toured the abandoned palace.

title: Hammer and Tickle
description: Alina Simone is a folk-pop singer who lives in Brooklyn. Alina Bronsky is a fast-rising European novelist who lives near Frankfurt, Germany. Both are young, both are of Soviet extraction, and both have books coming out this spring. As far as coincidences go, thats not a stunning one, but it further underscores recent artistic contributions from Soviet diaspora children, a whip-smart group now in their 20s and 30s that includes Regina Spektor, Mila Kunis, Anton Yelchin, the comedian Eugene Mirman (a childhood friend of Simones), and the writers Gary Shteyngart, Keith Gessen and Sana Krasikov.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Fighting Words
description: The Roman Catholic Church is preparing to introduce the most significant changes in the Mass in the more than 40 years since the church permitted English in place of Latin. But thousands of priests complain that the new English-language translation of the Roman Missal, the book of texts and prayers used in the Mass, is awkward, archaic and inaccessible.

title: Fantastic Fountains
description: WET Designs is the originator of some of the world's most famous fountains. Owner Mark Fuller explains his business vision and gives a tour of the meticulously designed WET Campus.

title: Prime Number
description: 24: The average debt, in thousands of dollars, of college students who took out loans and graduated last year, according to Mark Kantrowitz, publisher of FinAid and Fastweb, who has compiled the estimates of student debt. Two-thirds of bachelors degree recipients graduated with debt in 2008, compared with less than half in 1993. Overall, student loan debt outpaced credit card debt for the first time last year and is likely to top a trillion dollars this year as more students go to college and more borrow money to do so. In the coming years, a lot of people will still be paying off their student loans when its time for their kids to go to college, Mr. Kantrowitz said.

title: WET Design and the Improv Approach to Listening
description: This interview with  Mark Fuller, C.E.O. (which stands for chief excellence officer) of WET Design, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Homework Regulators Arent Doing
description: ONE too many times, this court has been witness to the shoddy practices and sloppy accountings of the mortgage service industry. With each revelation, one hopes that the bottom of the barrel has been reached and that the industry will self correct. Sadly, this does not appear to be reality.

title: The Budget Debate, Revealed
description: WASHINGTON    The air in the capital these days is thick with references to trillion-dollar deficits, debt-to-G.D.P. ratios and mandatory spending. But the budget debate that became fully engaged last week is about far more than accounting and arcane policy disputes. What is under way now is the most fundamental reassessment of the size and role of government  of the balance between personal responsibility and private markets on the one hand and public responsibility and social welfare on the other  at least since Ronald Reagan and perhaps since F.D.R.

title: Nigerians Vote in Presidential Election
description: A watershed presidential election in one of Americas top oil suppliers, Nigeria, unfolded peacefully on Saturday, a first for a country with a history of rigged and violent votes in the 12 years since the end of military rule.

title: Cyrus Harvey, an Extravagant Entrepreneur, Dies at 85
description: Cyrus I. Harvey, a quirky entrepreneur who created two significant brands in disparate fields  Janus Films, a distributor of movies by international directors like Bergman, Fellini and Kurosawa, and Crabtree & Evelyn, the purveyor of aromatic soaps and botanicals  died Thursday in Dayville, Conn. He was 85 and lived in Woodstock, Conn.

title: Nuclear Cleanup Plans Hinge on Unknowns
description: TOKYO  Even before the troubled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant has been brought under control, two conglomerates vying for contracts in an eventual cleanup are estimating that the effort could take 10 years  or 30.

title: When Unemployment and Profits Are High
description: To the Editor:

title: One Small Protest
description: To the Editor:

title: Germany Turns a Death Strip Into a Sanctuary
description: In the days when Germany was divided, East Germany built a barrier of fences, watch towers and minefields to keep its people from crossing over to the west. Stretching 870 miles from the Baltic to Bavaria, the border was patrolled by soldiers and guard dogs  a no-mans land 100 feet to a few hundred feet wide that few dared to cross.

title: Euro vs. Invasion of the Zombie Banks
description: IS a euro held in an Irish bank in Dublin, or in a Portuguese bank in Lisbon, as sound and secure as a euro in a German bank in Berlin? That apparently simple question holds the key to understanding why the euro zone may splinter and bring a new financial crisis.

title: The Wall of Worry Has Never Looked So High
description: THE stock market has been climbing a wall of worry  thats an old Wall Street adage, and it has certainly rung true lately. Calamities abound and there have been setbacks, but the market has been climbing anyway.

title: Entrepreneurs on the Fringes of Yankees Inc.
description: The stores, stands and bars around the new Yankee Stadium, now in its third season, can still rely on plenty of household names to lure fans.

title: Cuban Leader Proposes Term Limits in Sign of New Era
description: HAVANA  For 52 years the Castro brothers have ruled Cuba. But if President Ral Castro has his way, he may be out of the job as soon as 2013 and definitely by 2018, when he is 86.

title: Workplace Fiction Thats True to Life
description: IVE often wondered why there arent more strong works of fiction dealing with the business world. Offhand, with the possible exception of Tom Wolfes The Bonfire of the Vanities, Richard Fords real estate dramas, or Michael Crichtons forgettable Disclosure, I cant think of many novels of recent years that grapple with the kinds of issues most business people encounter.

title: Serving a Cause, 25 Cents at a Time
description: IN February, Noah Fradin turned 18  finally. Its a relief, he says, that he no longer needs his mom to co-sign the nondisclosure agreements and other documents related to his plan to change the world.

title: Helping Drunken Drivers Avoid Tickets, but Not Wrecks
description: FRIENDS dont let friends drive drunk. If they cant take their friends keys away, they take their smartphone. Why? The phone may have an app that can help them avoid sobriety checkpoints.

title: Variety: Ditsy Puns and Anagrams
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Mel Taubs Puns and Anagrams come out only once every few months, so the key here, as they say, is to just relax and enjoy the ride. They also tend to be much easier than cryptics, so they are a good place to start if you find yourself stymied by cryptic cluing.

title: After Jail, Repairing a Career and a Life
description: EVERYONE makes mistakes, both in their personal life and at work. I committed a felony against a company I worked for, and Im not proud of it. I served time and Ill be making restitution for a long time. However, Im one of the lucky ones; I found another job afterward.

title: More Than a Famous Name
description: I WAS born when my father, the civil rights leader Andrew Young, was a congressman. Im always asked what its like to be his son. Im fortunate to have a dad whos a role model for me and a close friend. His name opened doors for me, but once I got in, I knew that I had to create value.

title: Who Really Cares How Yuppies Raise Their Kids?
description: First there was Amy Chua, the Yale law professor and author of Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, who sent legions of parents into a tizzy with her exacting standards for piano practice and prohibitions against sleepovers.

title: Storm Kills 7 Overnight in Alabama
description: A punishing storm system that began Thursday evening continued to pummel parts of the Deep South into the early hours of Saturday morning. Tornadoes and vicious winds left 17 people dead across four states, officials said.

title: Sweet Valley Twins Are Back, and, Like Readers, Fully Adult
description: In the annals of 1980s young-adult fiction, there were no teenage heroines more loyal, more youthfully wholesome, more impossibly flawless than Elizabeth and Jessica Wakefield of the Sweet Valley High series, with their cascading blond hair, aqua eyes, rosy lips and perfect (in the 80s, anyway) Size 6 figures.

title: As Inmates 23 and 24, Stunned Mubaraks Adjust
description: CAIRO  The prison is called Tora Farm, but there is nothing agricultural about it. It is a two-story block of poured concrete, and for years its massive gray walls have held those deemed enemies of the powerful.

title: The Raider in Winter: Carl Icahn at 75
description: CARL C. ICAHN chases deals the way a dog chases cars. The guy just wont quit. Talk to him for three minutes, and you get the feeling he couldnt quit if he wanted to.

title: Distilling the Wisdom of C.E.O.s
description: This article was adapted from The Corner Office: Indispensable and Unexpected Lessons From CEOs on How to Lead and Succeed, by Adam Bryant, author of the weekly Corner Office column in The New York Times. The book, published Tuesday by Times Books, analyzes the broader lessons that emerge from his interviews with more than 70 leaders.

title: Video of Funnel Clouds in Mississippi
description: A vicious storm system that began in Oklahoma on Thursday has been moving across the southeastern United States, leaving 17 people dead in four states.

title: In the N.H.L., Short and Fast Sizes Up Well
description: Buffalos Nathan Gerbe skates into the Philadelphia zone, spinning 270 degrees, stopping on a dime, then backhands home the goal that clinches a playoff berth for the Sabres.

title: At the Point for the Knicks With Time Running Out
description: The last time a rising Knicks team played an aging championship Boston squad in the first round of the N.B.A. playoffs, mortality visited the favored Celtics at a most inopportune moment.

title: Ups and Downs of Two Top Picks
description: On Thursday, the Mets faced Greg Reynolds, a Colorado Rockies right-hander holding a spot in the rotation for the teams injured ace, Ubaldo Jimenez. The next night, the Chicago White Sox started another right-hander, Philip Humber, in place of their injured ace, Jake Peavy.

title: The Mets Do Not Have to Look Far to Find Bidders
description: He is a man in his 40s or 50s and is probably from Long Island.

title: Freedivers Are Testing the Bounds of Human Endurance
description: LONG ISLAND, Bahamas  Shouts of Breathe! Breathe! Breathe! pierced the tropical air and echoed off the limestone precipice around Deans Blue Hole, a vertical cavern plunging 660 feet, a cobalt blue pool of seawater surrounded by crystal-clear shallows and white sand.

title: U.S. and Allies Seek a Refuge for Qaddafi
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has begun seeking a country, most likely in Africa, that might be willing to provide shelter to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi if he were forced out of Libya, even as a new wave of intelligence reports suggest that no rebel leader has emerged as a credible successor to the Libyan dictator.

title: The Price of Printing Bad Stamps
description: The United States Postal Service admitted this week that its Lady Liberty stamp actually doesnt show the famous statue in New York Harbor, but a half-size copy standing in front of a Las Vegas casino. But the post offices assurances that it loves the design anyway may have less to do with aesthetics and more to do with the potential cost of replacing the billions of stamps already printed  to say nothing of making instant collectors items out of the uncounted number already used on mail.

title: Mets Young Goes on the Disabled List
description: ATLANTA  The Mets placed the right-handed pitcher Chris Young on the 15-day disabled list Saturday with biceps tendinitis and called up Pat Misch to cover them in the bullpen for their doubleheader with the Braves.

title: Weathering a Midlife Crisis In the Haunts of Table Tennis
description: I played table tennis for the first time in a South Bronx cellar in February 1971, when the sport was called Ping-Pong and my opponent was a gangly adolescent wearing a perm and bell-bottoms. Two months later, a United States Ping-Pong team was invited for a weeklong visit to China, which helped restore relations between the countries and elevated the games status.

title: Women Irate at Remarks by President of Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Salehs suggestion that antigovernment protesters in the capital were in violation of Islamic law because women were allowed to mix with men stirred a womens rights march in the capital on Saturday, as thousands of women in this staunchly conservative country made Mr. Saleh an object of public derision.

title: Three Veterans Having Impact in Postseason
description: Among the early surprises in the first days of the Stanley Cup playoffs was the play of three veterans whose best days were supposedly behind them: Montreals Scott Gomez, Nashvilles Steve Sullivan and Detroits Todd Bertuzzi.

title: Egyptian Court Formally Breaks Up Mubaraks Party
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court on Saturday continued the process of dismantling Hosni Mubaraks institutions of power when it formally dissolved the political organization that ruled the nation for decades, the National Democratic Party.

title: Sympathy for DiMaggio?
description: In 1941, Joe DiMaggio of the Yankees put together a 56-game hitting streak that was the talk of baseball. For all the attention he received, DiMaggios .357 batting average at the end of the season fell well short of the American League lead, as Ted Williams of the Boston Red Sox famously batted .406.

title: The Psychology of Cheating
description: To some it was a fitting end to a pointless witch hunt. On Wednesday, after weeks of graphic testimony about steroid use, a jury in San Francisco could not reach a verdict on charges that Bonds had lied about using performance-enhancing drugs, and the judge declared a mistrial.

title: In Iraq, Bottoms Up for Democracy
description: BAGHDAD    Tariq Harb, who was a military attorney under Saddam Hussein and is now a constitutional lawyer and television talking head, was happy to see the liquor flowing again at the Iraqi Writers Unions outdoor cafe. But many other Iraqis arent. There are people who want to kill me because I drink, he said, shuffling prayer beads at the cafe. We are fighting the religious educators, the imams, the preachers, who are extremists.

title: Syrian Leader Says He Will Lift Emergency Law
description: CAIRO  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria addressed his nation on Saturday in a televised speech aimed at appeasing a two-month-old protest movement that has posed an unprecedented challenge to his familys four decades of rule, according to human rights groups.

title: The French, the Veil and the Look
description: PARIS    Many scholars of Islam will tell you that nothing in the Koran requires a Muslim woman to cover her face  that its rules for proper Islamic dress are ambiguous and limited. Say to the believing women that they should lower their gaze and guard their modesty, it says. It adds, They should draw their veils over their bosoms and not display their ornaments.

title: A Shot at a Sane Budget
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Incoming Schools Chancellor Seeks Calmer Debate
description: Dennis M. Walcott said Saturday that he planned to use a softer touch as New York Citys new schools chancellor to ease the bitter rhetorical battles that have caused wide divisions among teachers, parents and bureaucrats. But Mr. Walcott also made it clear that he did not plan any major shifts in Education Department policy.

title: Afghan and Pakistani Leaders Meet in Peace Bid
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Much of Pakistans civilian and military leadership flew here Saturday for a meeting with Afghanistans president to discuss efforts to forge peace with the Taliban. Although leaders from the two countries have met before to discuss a peace deal, the gathering Saturday was unprecedented because of the number of high-level Pakistani officials in attendance.

title: You Say Bay of Pigs, I Say ...
description: Havana

title: Pinned Down in Battered City, Libyan Rebels Endure With Grit and Dirt
description: MISURATA, Libya  Muftah Militan, a rebel with his wounded right arm in a sling and a two-way radio in his left hand, peered from a rooftop at a low-slung skyline. Occasional gunfire chattered below.

title: Amazon Dolphins in Danger
description: The pink river dolphin is a storied symbol of the Amazon, but local fishermen are slaughtering the animal for catfish bait.

title: Nature vs. Nurture, as Seen by Economists
description: In a piece for the Week in Review, I take a look at the most recent yin and yang of the parenting world: Amy Chua, author of Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, vs. Bryan Caplan, an economist at George Mason University who argues in Selfish Reasons to Have More Kids that parents should relax, because nature matters much more than nurture.

title: Fishermen in Amazon See a Rival in Dolphins
description: IGARAP DO COSTA, Brazil  Along the rivers of the Amazon rain forest, people still recount legends in which pink dolphins are magical creatures that can turn into men and impregnate women. Brazilian musicians write songs about them, singing lovingly about the eye of the river dolphin.

title: New Yorks Green Grid
description: MANHATTANS street grid, which turned 200 years old last month, has long been an easy target for urban romantics. They love to point out how its relentless logic  most blocks are a precise 200 feet by 600 feet  imposed a soulless Cartesian order on a once-lush coastal island, trampling nature and leading to two centuries of real-estate mania.

title: 30 Seconds With Bill Walton
description: Bill Walton, who won two championships at U.C.L.A. under Coach John Wooden, also won two N.B.A. championships, with Portland in 1977 and with Boston in 1986. He was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame in 1993.

title: How the Credit Crisis Unfolded
description: The extent of the credit crisis that unfolded from the morning of Sept. 17 to the afternoon of Sept. 18. was unseen to the public but spooked policy makers into action.

title: Testing Heat Distribution
description: An experiment to see how pans of different materials perform.

title: Scenes From a Ball
description: Photos of Tarell Alvin McCraneys play Wig Out!

title: Moscows Drinking Problem
description: VILLANOVA, Pa.  IN an effort to reduce both its sky-high alcoholism rate and its budget gap, Russia recently announced plans to quadruple the tax on the countrys eternal vice, vodka, over the next three years.

title: Tiger Beat: Still Squeaky Clean After All These Years
description: Hair floating, skin dewy, eyes free of guile: the boys of Tiger Beat will never hurt you. In crisp photos and squeaky-clean quotes about love, theyve been practically interchangeable for more than four decades. Its an archetype thats survived any number of invasions: the Brits, disco, boy bands, the Brat Pack, more boy bands, the Disney Channel, TMZ and more.

title: Savvy Start by Garcia Helps Yanks Fill a Void
description: A pitching clinic was offered at Yankee Stadium on Saturday. It had not been advertised, but perhaps it should have been. The price of admission varied, though fans got their moneys worth regardless, rain and chill aside. The lesson lasted a little less than two hours, or as long as it took for the instructor, Freddy Garcia, to work six scoreless innings in his first start for the Yankees, a 5-2 victory against the Texas Rangers.

title: Chemicals Were Injected Into Wells, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  Oil and gas companies injected hundreds of millions of gallons of hazardous or carcinogenic chemicals into wells in more than 13 states from 2005 to 2009, according to an investigation by Congressional Democrats.

title: Board of Philadelphia Orchestra Votes to File for Bankruptcy
description: 5:22 p.m. | Updated  The Philadelphia Orchestras program Saturday night was to include music from the Berg opera Lulu, and the ensemble hopes to avoid the protagonists tawdry end. The board of the Philadelphia Orchestras program voted Saturday to file for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11. Unlike Lulu, who died at the hands of Jack the Ripper, the orchestra will live on, rehearsing and continuing to give concerts while a bankruptcy court judges considers the case.

title: The Power of Mockery
description: The juiciest story behind the Middle East uprisings doesnt concern Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis voluptuous Ukrainian nurse or C.I.A. bags of cash. Rather, its the tale of how a nonviolent revolutionary strategy crafted by Serbian students and an octogenarian American scholar came to challenge dictators in Egypt, Tunisia, Bahrain and many other countries.

title: Justice, Too Much and Too Expensive
description: HABEAS corpus: it is, as Alexander Hamilton suggested, the bulwark of a Constitution. A habeas petition gives a single federal judge the authority to decide if a prisoner is being held unlawfully and order his release. At Guantnamo, habeas plays a crucial role: it provides the essential means by which the federal judiciary can ensure that innocent people are not mistakenly held, indefinitely, as enemy combatants. This is an example of habeas at its best.

title: Wyomings Boom Poses Challenges For Obama
description: GILLETTE, Wyo.  Many economic signs are looking bright for Wyoming right now, and this red-knuckled city of coal miners and oil field mechanics is leading the charge.

title: Atlas Without Angelina
description: WASHINGTON

title: Westminsters Wedding March
description: In choosing Westminster Abbey as the site for their wedding, Prince William and Kate Middleton are joining a select group.

title: For World Champion, Two Uncommon Losses
description: Except for the worlds top players, few people ever have the chance to play a world champion. The exceptions are simultaneous exhibitions, where the champion will play 20 or 30 people at a time. Even then, though the champion has a bit of a handicap, it is a potentially intimidating experience.

title: Tornado Damages Oklahoma School, but Shelter Beneath Stands Strong
description: TUSHKA, Okla.  For 90 years, people in this small rural community have used an underground shelter next to the public school to escape the tornadoes that frequently wreak havoc in the green and rolling countryside here. So when a major twister hit the town at 7:35 p.m. Thursday, people instinctively rushed toward the Tushka Public School to seek haven.

title: France Flies, Germany Flops
description: Berlin

title: Henry Wises Pistol
description: By mid-April 1861 Virginias secession convention had spent two months deadlocked over the question of whether to leave the Union. The disunionists, including Thomas Jeffersons grandson, George Wythe Randolph, were outnumbered  but they also knew that events could easily tilt the balance in their favor, especially if the federal government took up arms against Virginias slave-holding former neighbors. On April 15, their moment finally arrived: in response to the shelling of Fort Sumter, Abraham Lincoln called up 75,000 troops, including 2,340 Virginians, to subdue the rebellion.

title: Guantnamo, on Trial
description: In bringing justice to those accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks, it will never be possible to have military trials at Guantnamo that Americans can be fully proud of, or that the world will see as credible.

title: The Power of Punkd
description: My Sunday column is about the ways bottom-up grassroots youth movements can bring about social change, from toppling Hosni Mubarak to curbing teen smoking. I was drawn into the subject out of fascination with the way the Serbian youth movement had developed strategies that spread to the Georgian revolution, the Ukrainian revolution, and the Egyptian revolution. But an equally important application of this approach is in fighting poverty at home and around the world.

title: Wrongful Foreclosures
description: We were worried recently when we saw an advance draft of legal agreements between federal regulators and the nations big banks to address and correct foreclosure abuses. The actual deals were as bad as we feared.

title: Whitman the Scrivener
description: Kenneth Price is one of many Walt Whitman scholars dedicated to tracking every jot and tittle left by the definitive poet of America. Three years ago, Mr. Price came upon a startling discovery, buried in the National Archives: Whitmans handwriting and his signature initials on documents he copied during his Washington day job as a government clerk.

title: Westminsters Wedding March
description: WHEN Prince William and Kate Middleton marry on April 29, they will join a select group, even among royals. While the site of their wedding, Westminster Abbey, has been the place of every coronation since the Norman conquest, only 15 royal couples have been married there since it was founded in 960.

title: Womens Health: What to Believe?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tiger Beat Sampler
description: Selected covers of the teen-girl tabloid across the decades.

title: Preserving Cowboy Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday: Whence Venus?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  This one seemed tougher than past Sundays, but for me it was worth it. Whats better than a bunch of punchlines from stand-up comedians, humorists and one iconic horror writer? I am a fan of all of the people who contributed theme entries to Matt Ginsbergs puzzle (even Anonymous), so I really enjoyed todays puzzle.

title: Secretive Ethics Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Qualities in an Astronaut: Who Has the Right Stuff?
description: To the Editor:
