description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. to Change Air Traffic Controllers Schedules
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Saturday that it would change scheduling practices for air traffic controllers in an effort to combat excessive fatigue. The decision was announced after a controller was discovered napping while on duty early Saturday  at least the sixth controller to be caught doing so in recent months.

title: To Get Back in Series, Rangers Need More From Dubinsky
description: Brandon Dubinsky is getting the playing time and responsibility a teams leading scorer deserves. But as the Rangers enter Game 3 of their first-round playoff series against Washington on Sunday, Dubinsky will need to put the first two games in his rear-view mirror.

title: With or Without Stars, the Bulls May Go Far
description: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Preservationists Fight to Save Prentice Womens Hospital
description: In a last-ditch effort to block Northwestern Universitys demolition of the old Prentice Womens Hospital, historical preservationists have enlisted a team of architects to imagine three possible futures for the striking cloverleaf-shaped tower: research laboratory, medical office and student housing.

title: 2010 Bills: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the A.F.C. East:

title: In Springfield, a Week of Change in Education
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Emanuel Gets Boost, and Challenges, in Schools Bill
description: A sweeping public school reform bill unanimously approved late Thursday by the State Senate gives Mayor-elect Rahm Emanuel a chance to fulfill a campaign promise and lengthen Chicagos school day, currently one of the shortest in the nation. But first he will have to overcome daunting budget, educational and labor obstacles.

title: Niles Canyon Railway
description: Steam-powered locomotives still chug passengers on Sundays up a former Southern Pacific railway line from the old town of Niles, now part of Fremont, to Sunol, and back. The track winds through Niles Canyon, which is the site of Alameda Creek, numerous Charlie Chaplin films and the legend of a beautiful ghost.

title: Willie Brown Academy, Born in 1992 With High Hopes, Will Close in May, a Failure
description: When the school now known as the Willie L. Brown Jr. College Preparatory Academy opened in San Franciscos predominantly black Bayview neighborhood some 18 years ago, it was at the forefront of an ambitious effort to address school performance and segregation without busing children out of the neighborhood. It was once even part of a Dream Schools program that brought millions of dollars in special aid, along with school uniforms, longer school days and Saturday classes.

title: A Rocky Day for the Dow
description: The Dow Jones industrial average evolved throughout the day, tracking the news from the House where voting on the $700 billion rescue package was taking place.

title: After Dow Drops, Tension in Washington
description: The Dow closed down 777 points after the House rejected a $700 bailout package to rescue the financial industry.

title: Gang of Six in the Senate Seeking a Plan on Debt
description: WASHINGTON  Days after President Obama called for forming a bipartisan group in Congress to begin negotiating a $4 trillion debt-reduction package, the parties have not even agreed to its membership. Yet six senators  three Democrats, three Republicans  say they are nearing consensus on just such a plan.

title: The Idle Rich Should Give Something Back: Taxes
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Citys Art Is a Victim of Neglect, Damage and Loss
description: San Francisco has a trove of public art that should be the toast of the town. Valued at around $90 million and including more than 4,000 items, including statues, paintings and Edvard Munch lithographs, the Civic Art Collection is one of the richest repositories of city-owned art in the country.

title: Humanity as Assailant, Earth as Avenger?
description: .TomDispatch, Grist and many other blogs are carrying an essay by Michael T. Klare, a professor of peace and world security studies at Hampshire College, that offers a counterpoint to Bill McKibbens account of a planet so marred by human affairs that it requires a distorted name, Eaarth. (The video above reflects this notion because it is less natural than it appears.)

title: Stay in Atlanta Costs Mets Two Games and a Pitcher
description: ATLANTA  In the early afternoon Saturday, before the Mets would endure their second doubleheader sweep in less than 72 hours, Manager Terry Collins was discussing the various injuries and roster moves the Mets were facing heading into the day, including the possibility of left fielder Jason Bay being activated by Tuesday. That depended on things falling into place for the Mets, which has not happened very often this season, if at all.

title: At Coachella, Many Takes on the 80s
description: INDIO, Calif.  The artist can render any subject in infinite ways. One has to remember this sometimes at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, where bands are revising 80s pop up, down, and backwards.

title: Rangers Move On And Fire Away Without Lee
description: Cliff Lee pitched a shutout with 12 strikeouts for the Philadelphia Phillies on Thursday. The two other teams that tried to sign him, the Yankees and the Texas Rangers, met in the Bronx the next night, offering a snapshot of how they have dealt with rejection.

title: Pastor Who Burned Koran Says He Was Duped Into Holding Back
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  The pastor who stoked violence in Afghanistan earlier this month by burning a Koran in March produced a recording on Saturday that he said proved he was deceived last September when he agreed to cancel plans to burn 200 copies of the Koran.

title: Rivers Keeps Conversation on Knicks, Not Future
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  There are no lack of story lines for the Boston Celtics heading into the 2011 playoffs. Will Shaquille ONeal ever play? Which team will show up, the one that started the season 23-4 or the one that finished 10-11?

title: Mob Link Is Pursued in Fight Involving Owner of Pizzeria
description: The police have revised the account of a Friday fight between the owner of a popular Brooklyn pizzeria and a man whom a senior law enforcement official described as a Genovese mob associate, after finding witnesses who said that both men had wielded knives. The police were investigating whether the encounter had arisen out of a mob attempt to make the pizzeria owner share his profits.

title: Obama Takes On Congress Over Policy Czar Positions
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama issued a signing statement on Friday night saying that he could bypass a provision in the new budget that would prevent him from appointing White House czars to oversee major policy initiatives.

title: Brazilian Criticizes Wealthy Nations Policies
description: WASHINGTON  Brazils finance minister said Saturday that developed nations like the United States were seeking to solve their own economic problems at the expense of the developing world.

title: Palin Speaks at Tea Party Rally in Madison
description: MADISON, Wis.  At first, the prospect drew mildly worried looks from people on both sides of this states giant political divide: Sarah Palin, the former Republican vice-presidential candidate, was to appear on the steps of this states Capitol, the very place that has become a stage for demonstration after demonstration against Wisconsins Republican-led efforts to cut collective bargaining rights.

title: Qi Bangkok Eatery Opens, With Pichet Ong Joining Later
description: Pichet Ongs debut as a Thai chef at the new Qi Bangkok Eatery, just west of Times Square, will be delayed a little bit so the restaurant can get a propitious head start.

title: Cartel Violence Complicates Tick Eradication Plan
description: An unexpected casualty of the drug-cartel-fueled lawlessness in Mexico: the cattle industry.

title: Pats Pick
description: The best new restaurant

title: Seeds of 2011s Budget Troubles Were Planted, by the Legislature, in 2006
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: Heats Opening Win Over 76ers Isnt Without Complaints
description: MIAMI  The N.B.A. playoffs may be a battle of attrition, a test of endurance akin to the Daytona 500, but the Heats Eastern Conference quarterfinal opener Saturday against Philadelphia felt more like a drag race.

title: House Bill on Student Testing Reopens a Familiar Debate
description: When Representative Rob Eissler, Republican of The Woodlands, brought House Bill 500 to the Texas House floor on April 6, he emphasized what it did not do.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Vows: Susan and Michael
description: Within eight months of meeting online, Susan and Michael knew they were meant to be together. Susan made space in her closet, and Michael found a temporary solution for an engagement ring.

title: The Tea Party Rings In Tax Day
description: Possible Republican candidates for president in 2012 spoke around the country at rallies sponsored by the Tea Party on Saturday.

title: To Capitals, a 2-0 Playoff Lead Is Rarely a Lock
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  Things look desperate for the Rangers, but there is at least one encouraging fact: the Washington Capitals have held a two-games-to-none lead in a best-of-seven series five times  and four times they have lost the series.

title: "Cinema Verite" Clip
description: HBO turns a PBS 1973 documentary into a new series, "Cinema Verite."

title: Stoudemire Stands Out and Buys In to Lift Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It was 7:45 Friday morning, and the only sound in the Knicks suburban training center was the hum of a hard drive playing game film for the coaching staff. The relative quiet was interrupted by the sound of leather pinging against the hardwood outside the office window.

title: For the Red Bulls, a Refreshing Burst of Goals
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Red Bulls served up a heaping portion of revenge in a cold rain Saturday night, five months after the San Jose Earthquakes came to town and ended the Red Bulls promising 2010 season in the first round of the Major League Soccer playoffs.

description: A look at the day in sports, from the N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs to the Bol dOr motorcycle endurance race.

description: HBO turns a PBS 1973 documentary into a new series, "Cinema Verite."

title: Off-Duty Officer Injured in Brooklyn Shooting
description: An off-duty Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority officer was shot and injured as he tried to break up an armed robbery at an auto body shop in Brooklyn on Saturday night, the police said.

title: Regulation of Offshore Rigs Is a Work in Progress
description: WASHINGTON  A year after BPs Macondo well blew out, killing 11 men and spewing millions of barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, the much-maligned federal agency responsible for policing offshore drilling has been remade, with a tough new director, an awkward new name and a sheaf of stricter safety rules. It is also trying to put some distance between itself and the industry it regulates.

title: The Anti-Immigration Crusader
description: WASHINGTON  Three decades ago, a middle-aged doctor sat outside his northern Michigan home and saw a patch of endangered paradise.

description: April 16, 2011

title: Rebels of Misurata
description: Libyans in Misurata have managed for almost two months to prevent their city from being overrun, and some of the reasons are visible on the street.

title: Intiman Theater Cancels Season
description: The board of the financially embattled Intiman Theater in Seattle voted on Saturday to cancel the rest of the 2011 season and lay off the theaters staff, said Susan Trapnell, a consultant that the board hired late last month to lead a financial turnaround.

title: Memorable Shea Moments
description: A look back at some of the classic moments at Shea Stadium.

title: Paul Newman in Pictures
description: A look at the life and career of Paul Newman.

title: The Rivals Meet, Finally
description: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama began the day in Washington and ended it on a debate stage in Oxford, Miss.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, April 17
description: O.K., so Congress passed a budget for the rest of the fiscal year and gets to enjoy a two-week recess. Then what? This week, the Sunday talk shows feature conversations with key lawmakers and administration officials about another pressing economic issue: the national debt.

title: The Red Bulls Find Their Scoring Touch
description: The Red Bulls scored as many goals in the first 15 minutes Saturday night as they had in their first four games, then added another long-awaited one from Thierry Henry in the final minutes to beat the San Jose Earthquakes, 3-0. Read the full article here, and then come back to comment.

title: Tokyo Utility Lays Out Plan for Its Reactors
description: TOKYO  The Tokyo Electric Power Company laid out an ambitious plan on Sunday for bringing the reactors at its hobbled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant into a stable state known as cold shutdown within the next nine months and for trying to reduce the levels of radioactive materials being released in the meantime.

title: Counting Starts in Nigeria After Vote
description: Results from a watershed presidential election in Nigeria began to trickle in Sunday after the voting unfolded peacefully the day before  a first for a country with a history of rigged and violent votes in the 12 years since the end of military rule.

title: Kubricks Oeuvre Celebrated in Paris Show
description: If it can be written, or thought, it can be filmed, the director Stanley Kubrick famously said. His 13 movies  each one, arguably, a milestone of 20th-century American cinema  are celebrated in a retrospective at the Cinmathque Franaise (51 rue de Bercy; 33-1-71-19-33-33; www.cinematheque.fr), showing through July 31.

description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the A.F.C. East:

description: Senator John McCain accepted the Republican presidential nomination in his speech on the final night of the partys convention.

title: Yemeni Opposition Sets Meeting With Gulf Bloc
description: SANA, Yemen  Opposition leaders from Yemen said on Sunday that they planned to travel to Saudi Arabia later in the day to discuss an agreement with the Gulf Cooperation Council on a timetable for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to leave office.

title: One Word: Plastics
Renovations at Gettysburg
description: Images of the new visitor center and restored cyclorama in Pennsylvania.

title: Cleaning for Passover, Crumb by Tiny Crumb
description: First, Joey and Dana Small cordon off their apartment, room by room. Then they begin their search. Every cupboard, closet, doorknob, coat pocket, remote control, couch cushion and crevice is thoroughly inspected.

title: Rebels Flee Key Libyan Town
description: AJDABIYA, Libya  Large numbers of rebel fighters fled this city on Sunday after a rocket and artillery attack by government forces who were reportedly on the western outskirts.

title: For Energy-Starved India, Japans Crisis Raises Hard Questions
description: As I noted in an article in Fridays Times, India faced a big energy challenge even before the earthquake and tsunami in Japan called the future of nuclear power into question.

title: Glencore Versus Goldman
description: 4:01 a.m. | Updated Glencore Internationals initial public offering next month has drawn comparison with the debut of Goldman Sachs more than a decade ago. But how similar are Glencore, the global commodities trader, and Goldman Sachs, the global investment bank?

title: Inflation in China Poses Big Threat to Global Trade
description: SHANGHAI  As the United States and Europe struggle to get their economies rolling again, China is having the opposite problem: figuring out how to keep its revved-up growth engine from generating runaway inflation.

title: Giants Kick Off Season
description: The Giants opened with a 16-7 victory over the Washington Redskins to usher in the N.F.L. season.

title: Gulf Oil Industry in Recovery
description: Workers in the Gulf of Mexico feared that the moratorium on deep-water drilling would destroy their livelihoods, but work is returning.

title: Tornadoes Kill at Least 43 in North Carolina and Elsewhere
description: At least 22 people were killed after violent tornadoes roared through the city of Raleigh and across the heart of North Carolina Saturday afternoon and evening, state officials said Sunday. The storms also severely injured 130 other people and leveled or damaged hundreds of homes, demolished a big-box store and a trailer park, plucked trees out of the earth, and left more than 84,000 people without power.

title: Thoreau Hiked Here
description: The Thoreau-Wabanaki Trail makes it easier to follow the authors footsteps through the Maine Woods.

title: The Finance Crisis
description: Credit markets have suffered as investors moved their money into the safest investments.

title: Van Gogh at the Modern
description: The Museum of Modern Arts exhibit, Van Gogh and the Colors of the Night, includes Starry Night and The Potato Eaters.

title: Travel Day
description: Actually, yesterday was supposed to be travel day. But after Robin and I spent 4 wonderful hours at the airport, they canceled the flight. So, on the road again today. Of course, theyve just postponed this flight

title: You Like Me, You Really Like Me
description: Except for those of you who hate me.

title: From Wall-E to Fukushima, Robots Roam
description: Theres a profoundly odd feeling that arises while examining the latest video and images released by the Tokyo Electric Power Company, showing robots making their way into the shattered and contaminated wreckage of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex. (Heres more on these robots and others on the scene.)

title: Shades of Danny Cepero
description: Better late then never  Quinonez Wilson, the goalkeeper for Sport Colombia, a second division club in Paraguay, last week took a page from the Red Bulls goalkeeper Danny Cepero and scored on a long free kick. One difference  Wilson was shown a yellow card for removing his shirt in celebration!

title: Goodbye Yankee Stadium
description: A panoramic view of Yankee Stadium on the night of the last game.

title: The Field of Dreams
description: Fans were able to enjoy Yankee Stadium for one last time on Sunday.

title: Spectacle Day at Coachella
description: INDIO, Calif.  Saturday at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival: spectacle day.

title: Dig Downtown Unearths an Early Mayors Farm
Virginias Moment
Mirrors, Clowns and Other Visions
description: Alwin Nikolais, a pioneer of multimedia dance, didnt stop at movement. He was a stagecraft wizard whose love for abstraction  along with lights, projections and electronic music  was strangely life affirming. He drew on a dancers musculature, not a dancers emotions. He doesnt even have to be a person  he can be a thing, a place or a time, he once said.

title: Jewish Melodies, Traditional and Not
description: When asked by the violinist Gil Shaham and his sister, the pianist Orli Shaham, to write a work for their concert of Jewish music at the 92nd Street Y, the composer Avner Dorman decided not to create a piece with traditional Jewish melodies.

title: The Kings Screenwriter, Giving Back
description: The screenwriter David Seidler may have reached a career high point in February when he won an Academy Award for The Kings Speech, but the professional  and personal  returns on his long fascination with King George VI have not ended.

title: Some Stuff She Knows About Hawaii
description: Sarah Vowell starts her willfully cutesy-pie book Unfamiliar Fishes, about the Americanization of Hawaii and Americas imperial ambitions, by asking this question about the takeout meal she has bought as a tourist in Waikiki: Why is there a glop of macaroni salad next to the Japanese chicken in my plate lunch?

title: Unconventional Relievers Help Mets End Skid
description: ATLANTA  After watching his team play almost two weeks of hapless baseball, and with the prospect of returning home to Citi Field riding an eight-game losing streak, Mets Manager Terry Collins was not inclined to sit back and hope for a win on Sunday.

title: A Tale of Two Eight-Card Fits, One Found, One Bypassed
description: If you and your partner, with game values, find an eight-card fit in a major and one of you has a singleton or void, four of your major will normally be the best contract. Three no-trump will be preferable usually only if the short suit is opposite a strong holding. (If you find a nine-card major-suit fit, stop worrying about the right strain; just decide how high to go in that suit. The deals in which that will be wrong are so few and far between that you should leave top experts to try to unravel them.)

title: Tracking TV Habits by Ethnic Groups
description: Last November, African-Americans watched two hours more television per day, on average, than the national average of 5 hours and 11 minutes, according to a report recently released by Nielsen, the TV ratings agency, which surveyed TV viewing habits by ethnicity. Asian-Americans watched about two hours less than the national average.

title: Monday: Conqueror of Valencia in 1094
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  I say, anyone for tennis?

title: A Magnates Postscript
description: When Sidney Harman was found to have an aggressive form of leukemia several weeks ago, he sat down to write a short essay for Newsweek about his determination to beat the disease.

title: Philadelphia Orchestra Makes Bankruptcy Move
description: PHILADELPHIA  A humbled Philadelphia Orchestra drew a prolonged ovation on Saturday evening after the final strains of Mahlers Symphony No. 4, one of his sunniest works. Just hours earlier, its board of directors had voted to send the orchestra to bankruptcy court, declaring the move the only way to survive financial disaster.

title: Two Passions, With Two Very Different Effects
description: During Lincoln Centers White Light Festival last year, critics at The New York Times debated the concept of spiritual music. I wrote that even a masterpiece needed a majestic interpretation to offer a more spiritual experience than a lesser work. Location would seem a more prosaic concern, but without favorable conditions even the greatest music can flounder.

title: Avoiding Moderato Becomes a Style
description: The composer Christopher Rouse, in an onstage conversation during a concert of his works presented at Zankel Hall on Friday evening, described one of the primary urges in his music with a striking line: Anything worth doing is worth doing to excess. He credited the saying to Mark Twain, though evidence points to Edwin H. Land, the inventor of Polaroid instant photography. (Famous quotations, like small children, are irresistible to bring up in conversation and nearly impossible to pin down.)

title: A Chastised Museum Returns to Life
description: Just three years ago it looked as if the National Academy Museum and School, founded in 1825, might not make it.

title: Wreckage at the Intersection of Corporate and Consumer Markets
description: IF Apple can do it, why cant we?

title: Verdi, Nuanced and Empowered
description: The conductor Riccardo Muti has always had a big following in New York. So it was no surprise that Carnegie Hall was sold out for Friday nights concert performance of Verdis Otello, the first of Mr. Mutis three programs with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. His hugely anticipated first season as this historic orchestras music director has been twice interrupted for extended periods in recent months by serious health crises. But worries about his health vanished on Friday as Mr. Muti, looking calm, fit and rather self-satisfied, conducted an emphatic and insightful account of this challenging Verdi opera, drawing incisive and beautiful playing from the orchestra.

title: Not Much to Steal but a Heart
description: Beane, the hero of John Kolvenbachs too-quirky comedy, Love Song, has a reality problem: He doesnt know how to live in it. He sees things from a strange perspective and then is defeated by them. Taking a multiple-choice personality test he cant get his head around the questions, much less give acceptable answers.

title: Rio Takes Top Spot at Weekend Box Office
description: Hollywoods parade of cartoon hits continues: Rio, above, was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with an estimated $40 million in ticket sales. The tale of a Minnesota macaw on the hunt for love in South America, Rio cost 20th Century Fox about $90 million to make  cheaper than many animated films  and has already caught on overseas, where ticket sales total about $128 million. Scream 4, which cost the Weinstein Company about $40 million to make, was second with $19.3 million. That result was 57 percent less than the opening weekend in 2000 for the last installment of the Scream franchise, after adjusting for inflation. (But Weinstein does not have to split any profits with Disney, as it did on the previous Scream films.) Hop, from Universal Pictures, was third with about $11.2 million for a three-week total of $82.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. Soul Surfer (Sony) was fourth with $7.4 million for a two-week total of about $20 million. Hanna (Focus Features) was fifth with about $7.3 million for a two-week total of $23.3 million. Also notable: Robert Redfords Conspirator (Roadside Attractions) sold $3.9 million in tickets in limited release.

title: United Nations to Host Cooper-Hewitt Show
description: Remodeling can be inconvenient, particularly for museums. But the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, faced with the coming renovation of its historic mansion at Fifth Avenue and 91st Street, below, has found a not-inappropriate spot for its fall exhibition, which is focused on design solutions to the problems of global slums. The museum is to announce on Monday that the exhibition, titled Design With the Other 90%: Cities, will be at the United Nations. The second of two similarly themed exhibitions, the show will feature roughly 60 projects from 20 countries, aimed at solving problems related to housing, access to clean water, education, waste management and transportation. It will run from Oct. 15 to Jan. 9, and admission will be free. The mansion renovation is part of a $54 million overhaul that will create 6,000 square feet of new gallery space, a new library and additional classrooms for the museums masters program. The museum will reopen in 2013.

title: Rangers Strike on Late Error by Capitals
description: Four-on-four hockey would seem to favor the Washington Capitals and their superstar, Alex Ovechkin, in their first-round playoff series against the Rangers.

title: The Rails Derby 10
description: A look at the contenders, listed in order of preference, for what is now a wide-open Kentucky Derby. You can follow Joe Drape on Twitter.

title: Antiquities Official Sentenced in Egypt
description: An Egyptian criminal court on Sunday sentenced Egypts antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, to a year in jail and ordered him removed from his job, Ahram Online, the English language Web site of the Egyptian state newspaper, reported. The sentence arose out of a dispute over the assigning of a contract to run a bookstore at the Egyptian museum, said Farid Atiya, who sued Mr. Hawass in that dispute. By e-mail, Mr. Hawass denied that he was going to jail and said that the antiquities ministry would file an appeal in the case on Monday. Mr. Atiya, who ran a bookstore next to the museum from 2004 to 2010, said that the verdict would be set aside if Mr. Hawass, within 10 days, closed a new bookstore and gift shop, affiliated with the American University in Cairo Press, that Mr. Atiya said had been opened in violation of a court order. Mr. Hawass, who had long been Egypts top antiquities official, resigned in March and was reinstated two weeks ago.

title: Footnote
description: Joely Richardson (The Tudors, Nip/Tuck) and Cotter Smith (Kin, Next Fall) have been cast in Side Effects, the final play of MCC Theaters 25th anniversary season. David Auburn (Proof) will direct this two-person play by Michael Weller, about a Midwestern couple whose relationship and political aspirations are beginning to crumble; it is a companion piece to Mr. Wellers Fifty Words. Preview performances will begin June 2 at the Lucille Lortel Theater, with an opening on June 19.

title: The Battle Over Education Reform

title: Decision Looms for Laos Dam, but Impact Is Unclear
description: HOUAY SOUY, Laos  The Mekong River is so brown with silt as it passes this impoverished village, it could be called liquid dirt. For millions of people downstream this is the color of life: the Mekong, teeming with hundreds of species of fish and rich in minerals, has for centuries been the lifeline of villages and towns stretching from the rocky rapids of Tibet to the lazy meanderings of the river in the Vietnam delta.

title: Put Yourself in the Story of Passover
description: Though only read once or twice a year, it has probably had more wine spilled on it than any other book ever published. Over the centuries, it has been paraphrased, abridged, translated, transliterated and transformed. It has been sung, chanted, illustrated and supplanted. And in 5,000 or so editions since the invention of the printing press, it has invoked ancient Egypt, Eldridge Cleaver, third-century rabbis, the invention of the sandwich, sixth-century Palestinian poetry, the Holocaust, the ancient Greek symposium, unleavened bread, homosexuality, temple sacrifices, bitter herbs, the civil rights movement and childrens counting songs.

title: A Faltering Ruble, Long Lines and a Bomb Attack Rattle Belarus
description: MINSK, Belarus  The waiting list outside a currency exchange office at the Korona supermarket here had swelled to 52 people and many were getting desperate. Some had been waiting for three days, sleeping in cars, in an increasingly frantic effort to get dollars and euros.

title: Sexual Abuse in Prison

title: The Washington Haggadah
description: A closer look at a Haggadah manuscript from 1478 on display at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Geoff Miller, Co-Founder of Los Angeles Magazine, Dies at 74
description: Geoff Miller, a founder of  Los Angeles magazine, known for its Hollywood star-studded covers and as a guide to the good life in the city, died on Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 74.

title: Drops in the Dollar and the Dow
description: The stock market fell amid further investor concerns, while commodities and precious metals rose as investors sought to hedge against the falling dollar.

title: Once Endangered, Now Recovering
description: Conservation biologists have resuscitated populations of the white-headed langur in China, by taking into account the needs of the people who live around them.

title: Debt Ceiling Increase Is Expected, Geithner Says
description: WASHINGTON  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner said Sunday that Congressional Republican leaders had signaled strongly to the White House that they would vote in favor of raising the national debt ceiling, despite pressure from some lawmakers in the party to use the coming vote as leverage to seek deep spending cuts.

title: A Year After the Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill, a Perfect Day for a Redfish
description: NEW ORLEANS  Near a marina in St. Bernard Parish, slightly south and east of New Orleans, a sign read, Caution Boaters: Do Not Disturb Booms in Water. Yet as Gregg Arnold, a fly-fishing guide, navigated his skiff through the labyrinthine channels that slice through this portion of the Biloxi Marsh, there were no signs of booms, or the oil unleashed by the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon rig last April 20.

title: Learning the Hard Way That Bumps and Elbows Dominate in the East
description: Boston

title: A Warner Merger With Potential
description: A sale of Warner Music would be only an opening act. The company, whose artists include Bruno Mars and Metallica, has attracted a surprising number of suitors. But that is primarily because the show that investors really want to see is a Warner combination with EMI Group.

title: Too Much Relationship Vrit
description: If only it were 1973, Id have the days best celebrity gossip: Pat and Bill Loud are back together.

title: In Sometimes Deadly Clashes, Defiant Syrians Protest
description: CAIRO  Rejecting the Syrian presidents latest effort to mollify them, thousands of protesters took to the streets in cities and towns across Syria on Sunday, using a national holiday commemorating the end of French colonialism to widen their challenge to his familys iron-fisted autocracy. Security officers responded with deadly force, witnesses reported, including live ammunition fired at a funeral and the seizure of critically wounded demonstrators from a hospital.

title: Tornadoes: 3 Days, 14 States
description: More than 240 tornadoes have been reported since Thursday, including a family of 92 tornadoes that killed at least 22 people and left 84,000 without power in North Carolina on Saturday. Tornado activity has been heavier this year than last, according to the National Weather Service.

title: A Line of Brews Draws a Star Endorser, and Critics
description: SINCE the 1980s, the actor Billy Dee Williams has appeared intermittently in advertising for Colt 45 malt liquor, often with a beautiful woman on his arm and accompanied by the slogan, Works every time. Now, to celebrate the introduction of a new product, Blast by Colt 45, a potent fruit-flavored beverage, the brand has a new pitchman, the rapper Snoop Dogg.

title: Christies Conservatism Is Not Just Economic
description: In the throes of New Jerseys financial crisis, Gov. Chris Christie vaulted into office as a strict fiscal conservative. In his first year in the job, he won national attention as a tough-talking manager whose budget-slashing, union-bashing ways seemed to be all about the money.

title: U.S. Rift With Pakistan Grows Over Drone Strikes
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The differences between the United States and Pakistan that broke into the open last week over the scale of C.I.A. operations here signaled a fundamental rift, plunging the relationship, sometimes strained, sometimes warm, to its lowest point in memory.

title: At Least Walking Wont Set Fire To the Fairway
description: Its pretty well established that walking does more for your golf game than riding in a cart. And obviously, it offers more exercise. There is the rare case, however, in which riding in a cart might give you the chance to run for your life.

title: Abrupt Turn as Facebook Battles Suit
description: Aaron Sorkin may want to take notice. The script for a prequel to his hit movie The Social Network almost writes itself.

title: Al Qaeda Stirs Again
description: Washington

title: Arthur Lessac, Holistic Vocal Coach, Dies at 101
description: The human voice is a symphony, Arthur Lessac said, if only one knows what to listen for. With their sustained, purring timbre, the consonants m and n are stringed instruments. Luxuriant w and zh are woodwinds, raucous r a trombone. L is a mellow saxophone; ch a clash of cymbals; and the small explosions p, b and t are percussion.

title: 2 Palestinian Teens Held in Killing of Israeli Family
description: AWARTA, West Bank  Israeli officials announced on Sunday the arrest of two Palestinian teenagers from this village in the northern West Bank who they said were responsible for the killing of five members of the Fogel family in the neighboring Jewish settlement of Itamar last month.

title: You Get the Judges You Pay For
description: LEGAL elites must come to terms with a reality driven by the grass-roots electorate: judicial elections are here to stay. Given this reality, we should focus on balancing important First Amendment rights to financially support campaigns with due process concerns about fair trials.

title: Roger Nichols, Artist Among Sound Engineers, Dies at 66
description: Roger Nichols, a recording engineer whose meticulous studio work with Steely Dan and others earned him seven Grammy Awards, died on April 9 at his home in Burbank, Calif. He was 66.

title: Yanks Rodriguez Sits as Precaution
description: A rib-cage injury kept Yankees third baseman Alex Rodriguez out of the starting lineup Sunday night against the Texas Rangers. And while Rodriguez and the team put a brave face on the injury, no one could say for certain when Rodriguez would play again.

title: Officer and His Dog Play Key Role in Hunt for Remains
description: Ten sets of human remains have turned up in the thick brush off Ocean Parkway on the South Shore of Long Island since December. All of them have been discovered by the police. Five of them were found by the same officer and his partner.

title: Global Markets React to Bank Woes
description: Mondays sell-off came despite moves by central banks around the world to restore investor confidence by injecting enormous amounts of capital into the financial system.

title: Tornadoes Roar Through North Carolina
description: At least 23 people were killed after violent tornadoes roared through Raleigh and across the heart of North Carolina.

title: Pearol Fans Unfurl Flag Few Will Forget
Monks Adjust Recruitment for the Digital Age
description: The Benedictine monks at Portsmouth Abbey in Rhode Island have begun an online advertising campaign to help recruit new monks.

title: Monks Embrace Web to Reach Recruits
description: The Benedictine monks at the Portsmouth Abbey in Portsmouth, R.I., have a problem. They are aging  five are octogenarians and the youngest will be 50 on his next birthday  and their numbers have fallen to 12, from a peak of about 24 in 1969.

title: A Native Son Revitalizes His Paper
description: In 2008, when I last saw Michael Klingensmith, he was sitting in a corner office on the 34th floor of the Time Warner building, one of three powerful executives who controlled Time Inc., the biggest magazine publisher in the world.

title: Salvadoran in Florida Faces Deportation for Torture
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  During the civil war in El Salvador three decades ago, Gen. Eugenio Vides Casanova was that nations top military officer, a close ally valued by the United States for his implacable battle against Marxist guerrillas, in spite of notorious human rights violations by his forces.

title: The Middle-Class Tax Trap
description: Lets tell the truth, Walter Mondale said, accepting the Democratic nomination in 1984. Mr. Reagan will raise taxes, and so will I. He wont tell you. I just did.

title: A Recruits Friend, a Teams Fan and a Headache for Colleges
description: Chris Grace, an ironworker from suburban Chicago, is a Duke fan. A mural in his basement bears the likenesses of the former stars Christian Laettner, Bobby Hurley and Grant Hill, and he regularly checks Web sites to learn which high school basketball players the Blue Devils are recruiting. Then Grace goes a step further: he sends recruits a friend request on Facebook.

title: Retailers Retool Sites to Ease Mobile Shopping
description: Retailers who once envisioned a vast new market of mobile shoppers eagerly hitting buy on their cellphones have run headlong into a harsh reality: their customers are all thumbs.

title: As Favorites Fall, Others Are Waiting to Fill Their Shoes
description: The only thing certain about the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby is that 20 horses are going to show up at Churchill Downs on the first Saturday in May. Whos going to win? That is hard to predict after another highly regarded colt turned in an awful performance in his last major prep race.

title: Lets Not Be Civil
description: Last week, President Obama offered a spirited defense of his partys values  in effect, of the legacy of the New Deal and the Great Society. Immediately thereafter, as always happens when Democrats take a stand, the civility police came out in force. The president, we were told, was being too partisan; he needs to treat his opponents with respect; he should have lunch with them, and work out a consensus.

title: So Much for the Referees
description: Campaigns are delighted at the prospect of a record binge in political spending for next years elections. But their lawyers are scratching their heads in wonderment  and potential delight  that the Federal Election Commission has failed to rewrite regulations after the Supreme Court enabled unlimited corporate campaign spending.

title: For Clemens and Bonds, a Difference in Audience
description: The criminal cases against Barry Bonds and Roger Clemens would appear to have a lot in common  both men are baseball superstars who once seemed destined for the Hall of Fame, and both were accused of lying about whether they had used performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Hospitals Shouldnt Make You Sicker
description: A vigorous quality-improvement program at more than 150 Veterans Affairs hospitals has achieved remarkable results controlling infections over the past several years. It reduced the spread of one of the most deadly bacterial infections, known as MRSA, by 62 percent in intensive care units and 45 percent in other hospital units. If other hospitals could replicate the effort, thousands of patients might be saved from needless infections acquired after they entered the hospital.

title: A Victory for Cleaner Air, and the Law
description: The new settlement between the Environmental Protection Agency, other plaintiffs and the Tennessee Valley Authority resolving clean air violations at 11 T.V.A. coal-fired power plants is long overdue.

title: Time to Reconnect With Joys Missed and Tee Shots Lost
description: There is no documented truth to the theory that months of pitiless snowstorms, weeks of subzero wind chills and an early April dose of sleet that froze the dogs feet to the sidewalk now guarantee that the 2011 golf season will be the best and most satisfying ever.

title: New Yorks Bridges
description: Six lesser-known spans will receive big birthday bashes in the coming years.

title: President Heads West to Sell His Deficit Plan
description: WASHINGTON  After weeks of tussling and political gamesmanship in Congress over federal spending, President Obama will take his message on the road this week, traveling to the West Coast to promote his deficit-cutting plan.

title: The New Republican Landscape
description: Six months after voters sent Republicans in large numbers to Congress and many statehouses, it is possible to see the full landscape of destruction that their policies would cause  much of which has already begun. If it was not clear before, it is obvious now that the party is fully engaged in a project to dismantle the foundations of the New Deal and the Great Society, and to liberate business and the rich from the inconveniences of oversight and taxes.

title: Seeking Clues in Goldmans Succession Plan
description: From the canyons of Wall Street to the City of London and beyond to Hong Kong, an intense guessing-game has begun: who will succeed Lloyd C. Blankfein when he eventually steps aside as chief executive of Goldman Sachs?

title: Three Cups of Tea Author Defends Book
description: While the publishing industry waited to see whether it faced the embarrassment of yet another partly fabricated memoir, Greg Mortenson, the co-author of the best-selling Three Cups of Tea, a book popular with the Pentagon for its inspirational lessons on Afghanistan and Pakistan, forcefully countered a CBS News report on Sunday that questioned the facts of his book and the management of his charitable organization.

title: After Regular Spring Vacations, DAntoni Is Where He Likes to Be
description: BOSTON  In his four full seasons on the Phoenix Suns bench, Mike DAntoni presided over 51 playoff games, each spring bringing a new thrill. In New York, the calendar in late April has been depressingly empty.

description: The big Passover questions are the same every year, and easy enough to answer, starting with Why is this night different from all others?

title: After Storms, a Widespread Path of Death and Damage
description: The terrified look in one of her employees eyes was the first clue Terri Rodriguez had that something was terribly wrong Saturday afternoon.

title: Scrutiny Lags as Jetliners Show the Effects of Age
description: In April 1988, when the cabin roof ripped off an Aloha Airlines 737 and swept a flight attendant to her death, it sent a startling signal to the airline industry about the dangers of metal fatigue. Airlines immediately stepped up inspections of aging jets. Federal regulators cut up old planes to look for the spots under the most stress. And Boeing redesigned the joints that hold its 737s together.

title: A Battle Over Preservation in a Strip Once Worthy of Admirals
description: Once they were the shipshape town houses of the Brooklyn Navy Yards senior officers, but now the gray buildings sit like ruins encountered in a jungle, their facades, roofs and interiors overgrown with ivy, weeds, even saplings.

Last year, the church, called Shouwang, or Lighthouse, collected $4 million from its 1,000 members to buy its own house of worship.

title: Filling in at Third Base, Chavez Fuels Win and Lets Rodriguez Rest Easy
description: For most 33-year-old veterans, backing up Alex Rodriguez would not be an appealing assignment. Rodriguez is a vital player for the Yankees  a cleanup hitter who used to routinely play more than 150 games a year and who still does not come out of the lineup except when injured. But when the Yankees called Eric Chavez last winter and offered him the job as Rodriguezs backup, Chavez thought it sounded great. Three weeks into this season, he has not changed his mind.

How often do you get that much?

title: Love and War Examined at Amsterdam Exhibition
description: Nazi soldiers marched through the streets, fearful citizens were forced into hiding, and targeted groups were shipped to distant camps. Yet in spite of overwhelming conflict, a generation continued to love. Through May 22, the Dutch Resistance Museum in Amsterdam explores the different forms of love to spring from the trenches, shelters and concentration camps of World War II, in the exhibition Love in Wartime.
