title: Off the Charts
description: Billboard produces more than 60 distinct music charts. And while a certain kind of person lives or dies by the fluctuations of the Next Big Sound 25 or the Canadian Hot 100, pop-music charts, like the dreams of youth, are ephemeral. (Sure, Corazon Sin Cara, by Prince Royce, is the No. 1 Tropical single for the week of April 23, 2011. But with Tito El Bambino right behind, for how long?)

title: Nigerias President Wins Election
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Amid violent protests from his main opponents supporters, President Goodluck Jonathan of Nigeria was returned to office after a weekend election judged by analysts to be perhaps the countrys fairest ever.

title: Tax Day Special: David Foster Wallace and the Terrors of the Tingle Table
description: Tax experts have yet to file their reviews of The Pale King, David Foster Wallaces posthumous novel about I.R.S. agents at a regional examination center in Peoria, Ill., in the mid-1980s. But in yesterdays Book Review, I looked at Wallaces correspondence with tax accountants for clues to where the real I.R.S. ends and Wallaces imaginary uber-bureaucracy begins.

title: This Week in Small Business: Tax Day Today, Deficits Tomorrow
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: S.&P. Lowers Outlook for U.S., Sending Stocks Down
description: The United States has long had a sterling credit report from ratings agencies because of the global preference for the dollar. But the latest deficit gridlock in Washington may have taken some of the luster off the reputation of the worlds largest economy and its currency.

title: Report Finds Sri Lanka Attacked Civilians
description: NEW DELHI  A United Nations panel investigating allegations of war crimes by Sri Lankan troops at the end of the bloody battle against Tamil rebels in May 2009 found credible evidence that government soldiers made civilians a target, shelled hospitals and attacked aid workers, according to an unauthorized copy of the panels report.

title: Who Made Googles Map Pin?
description: Googles maps have revolutionized how we interact with the world, how we perceive space and even how we navigate through it. Type in a location, and down drops a red marker, or map pin, that answers any question of place. Outfitted with its own drop shadow, the small, red bubble with a pointed end not only tells us where we want to be, but what exists in the world around us.

title: Ask About Red-Tailed Hawks in New York
description: This week, Marie Winn, the author of Red-Tails in Love: Pale Males Story  A True Wildlife Drama in Central Park, will be responding to readers questions about red-tailed hawks in the city as we anticipate the arrival of the chicks of Violet and Bobby, who are perched above the N.Y.U campus.

title: Something More Familiar Will Replace Il Matto
description: Matteo Boglione said he and his partner, Gian Perugini, will replace their TriBeCa restaurant Il Matto with something less scary and more American.

title: The Temporary Vegetarian:  Leek Tart With Oil-Cured Olives
description: When Katy Sparks, a restaurant consultant and the former executive chef of Quiltys in Manhattan, was developing a menu for Radish, a takeout place in the Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, she created a leek tart with oil-cured olives. For the tart shell, she uses store-bought frozen puff pastry. I love puff pastry, but because Ive never been a great baker, I like help, she said. We buy the Dufour puff pastry.

title: VW Beetle Is Back  Again  Again
description: For those car-mad consumers who have been waiting since the Super Bowl to see the 2012 version of the Volkswagen New Beetle, which was featured in a popular commercial that appeared during the game, the wait is finally over.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Where Are the Voices?
description: Charles Isherwoods Theater Talkback post last week, about the dearth of good musical theater voices, was prompted by what he called the vocally vacuous concert version of Company staged by the New York Philharmonic. Mr. Isherwood wrote that for most of the evening, accomplished singing was all but absent.

title: Cornell Gas Study Stirs Heated Debate
description: Post updated 11:30 a.m.   More researchers and policy analysts have had a chance to digest a new study analyzing the climate impacts of unconventional natural gas development, published this week in the journal Climatic Change Letters. Many of the reactions echo earlier complaints that some of the methane leak data on which the studys conclusions were based are thin (a fact that the authors, including the lead author, Robert Howarth of Cornell University, conceded).

title: Morning Buzz | Questions About Quinoa
description: A high of about 60 degrees with mostly cloudy skies. This evening, theres a possibility of showers.

title: Remembering and Forgetting Milan Kundera
description: When I was a junior in high school, I became obsessed with the Czech novelist Milan Kundera. I would apologize for my pretentiousness, except that it is still an essential part of who I am. I copied a passage from The Book of Laughter and Forgetting onto the first divider in my loose-leaf notebook and tried to get as many of my classmates as I could to check it out. This was not no one, but it wasnt a tremendous number of people either. Repeated reading dug the passage into my mind, and the other day when I was thinking about how hard it is to keep up with the violent pace at which so-called current events are overturning each other worldwide, it popped up unasked for:

title: Once More, With Feeling: Joss Whedon Revisits Dr. Horribles Sing-Along Blog
description: In the pantheon of fantasy and science-fiction projects that Joss Whedon helped create, the Internet musical Dr. Horribles Sing-Along Blog can be easy to overlook: its not his beloved television series that ran a healthy seven seasons (Buffy the Vampire Slayer), or its beloved spinoff (Angel), or his misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time (Dollhouse) or his other misunderstood television show that was canceled before its time and spawned a misunderstood movie (Firefly and Serenity). Dr. Horrible is simply a three-act musical about an aspiring super-villain (played by Neil Patrick Harris), his smug do-gooding nemesis (Nathan Fillion) and the woman who comes between them (Felicia Day). Dreamed up by Mr. Whedon, his brothers Zack and Jed, and Maurissa Tancharoen during the 2007-8 writers strike and produced on his own dime, it is the pure expression of what they wanted to make at the time, without any outside interference.

title: Citigroups Earnings Fall 32%
description: 7:45 p.m. | Updated

title: Where the Next Buyouts Will Come
description: The leveraged buyout has been on the rise, helped by cheap debt and by the huge amounts of cash at the disposal of private equity firms. There were $51.4 billion worth of buyouts in the first quarter, according to Thomson Reuters data, and billions more have been announced in recent weeks.

title: Shareholder Backs Actelion Against Elliott Advisors
description: BB Biotech, a Swiss investment fund, said on Monday that it would stand behind the management of Actelion, Europes largest biotechnology company, in its months-long struggle against the activist hedge fund Elliott Advisors.

title: Deutsche Bank Plan to Sell BHF Unit Collapses
description: In a surprising reversal, Deutsche Bank said on Monday that advanced talks to sell its BHF-Bank division to LGT Bank of Lichtenstein had collapsed.

title: Judge Clears Banks in Parmalat Case
description: 5:39 p.m. | Updated

title: Monday Reading: Travel Advice From Online Friends
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: No Guns, Just Tamales
description: What is more elusive than the fabled dodo? Good news out of Mexico. So I was surprised to see a few recent stories of that type.

title: After Storms, a Path of Death and Damage
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  The reality of the devastation of a storm that sent more than 200 tornadoes ripping across the South, killing at least 45 people and causing millions of dollars in damage, began to sink in Monday morning.

title: Restoring the Beacon
description: A West Side theater has survived through decades of neglect.

title: Mysterious Trades in a Big Block of Tokyo Electric Shares Draw Regulators Interest
description: TOKYO  Japanese regulators and executives of the Tokyo Electric Power Company are asking questions about a seemingly coordinated series of stock purchases two weeks ago that led to an undisclosed buyer or buyers acquiring a large block of the utility, which owns Japans dangerously damaged nuclear power plant.

title: IPhone 4 Becoming Most Popular Camera on Flickr
description: It looks like the point-and-shoot camera is quickly heading to the gadget graveyard. May it rest in peace next to your old VCR, Sony Walkman and Atari game console.

title: Asked and Answered | Deborah Ann Woll
description: The young actress Deborah Ann Woll cut her teeth  err, fangs  as the innocent Christian turned insidious vampire Jessica Hamby on HBOs True Blood (Season 4 starts in June). Woll, 26, hails from Brooklyn but currently lives in Los Angeles, where she recently completed filming on Someday This Pain Will Be Useful To You, a coming-of-age story based on a teenage novel of the same name by Peter Cameron. The Moment recently e-mailed Woll to talk work (vampires, snakes) and play (home improvement and carpentry).

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: The Final Season on NBC
description: So the final season of Friday Night Lights is upon us, and those of us without DirecTV (where the episodes appeared earlier) have waited a long time. Fridays fifth-season premiere on NBC had a distinctly elegiac feel. Landry and Julie were each leaving for college  the goodbyes are in motion. Landry is off to Rice in Houston, and Julie is headed somewhere within driving distance, which means that plans have clearly changed since that Northeastern college tour of last season.

title: Good Tweets Are Nice, but Group Sales Fill Seats
description: More than 55,000 Facebook users like the new Broadway musical Sister Act, which, like most major theatrical productions today, has its own page, as well a Twitter account (1,300 followers), YouTube channel (30,000 uploaded views) and set of apps. (Photoshop your face into a nuns wimple and win free tickets!)

title: Wockah Wockah Bwow-Chcka-Bwow
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed spellings for the sounds that surround us.

title: S&P
description: OK, so Standard and Poors has warned that it might downgrade the US one of these days. At first read, what it says doesnt seem too silly: it lays stress, rightly, on political gridlock. The point should be that the US is perfectly capable both of running large deficits now and getting its fiscal house in order over time; but not if the parties cannot agree on any kind of solution. What we do to spending this year or next is irrelevant.

title: At the Lucerne Easter Festival, Haitink Holds Up a Mirror for Promising Maestros
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  Bernard Haitink and Brahms are big at the Lucerne Festival this year. Mr. Haitink conducted his third and last Brahms program of the Easter Festival with the Chamber Orchestra of Europe at the concert hall of the KKL (Kultur- und Kongresszentrum) on Wednesday evening, and the Brahms cycle concludes in August with two concerts in the summer festival.

title: The Sounds of Drummers, Handled Gingerly
description: New Yorkers make every effort to block out the sounds made by neighbors: their wails that they dont want to go to preschool, their contractors ear-splitting hammer drills, and their heavy-footed gaits, which to those living below can sound as graceful as an elephant breaking in new pairs of stilettos. Even the most patient New Yorker can break down and plead with neighbors to stop that racket.

title: Pentagon Inquiry Into Article Clears McChrystal and Aides
description: WASHINGTON  An inquiry by the Defense Department inspector general into a magazine profile that resulted in the abrupt, forced retirement of Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal has found no proof of wrongdoing by the general, his military aides and his civilian advisers.

title: In Lower Manhattan, the Nations First Official Monument Is Being Restored
description: Even then, 235 years ago, Congress worried about spending. All right, officially it was still the Continental Congress when it approved the new nations first official monument, a monument that ended up in Lower Manhattan. But right there, in its instructions to Benjamin Franklin, it said to watch the cost.

title: The Claim: To Reduce Snoring, Try Sleeping on Your Side
description: THE FACTS

title: Numberplay: Car Talk Pet Store Puzzler
description: Tom and Ray Magliozzi, hosts of the wacky and ingenious NPR radio show Car Talk, discuss cars, car repair and logic puzzlers. The puzzlers are terrific  often classics at heart with a Car Talk twist. I thought it might be fun to try one on Numberplay.

title: Haiti Struggles After Being Hit by Storms
description: Four tropical storms in less than a month have caused floods throughout Haiti, killing at least 300 people.

title: Nuclear Monument
description: The source of plutonium for the bomb that was dropped on Nagasaki was designated a landmark.

title: Facebook and Prineville, Ore., Become Friends
description: PRINEVILLE, Ore.  This small town in the high desert of central Oregon has seen better days. The community of about 9,000 once had five saw mills employing some 1,200 people. Today all the saw mills are gone, and so are their jobs. Three years ago, Les Schwab, the towns best-known business, moved its headquarters to nearby Bend, taking with it about 100 well-paying jobs. In the last 18 months, more than 1,000 residents left the town and the county, which has the highest rate of unemployment in Oregon at roughly 20 percent.

title: Mazda CX-5 to Be Based on Minagi Concept
description: If only in name, Mazda is reining its Minagi concept into the familial fold. The Japanese automaker announced Monday that the compact S.U.V., which was first shown at the Geneva auto show in March, will be named the CX-5 when it enters production in 2012, slotting below the CX-7 and CX-9 crossover vehicles.

title: One Soldiers Experience With One Nation Under Contract
description: We go to war because of the men on our left and right. Since 9/11, we should probably add to that the contractors in the rear providing us food, drinks and organizing basketball tournaments. Maybe we dont fight for them, but we certainly couldnt fight without them. This situation isnt good or bad, it just is.

title: After Funerals for Protesters, Syrian Mourners Call for Revolution
description: On Monday, The Lede is following street protests in Syria, which have intensified throughout the day in the central city of Homs, following funeral for at least 14 people who were killed there on Sunday night.

title: Exercise: Fewer Healthy Habits for Young Mothers
description: Many women adopt healthier lifestyles when they become pregnant, but a new study suggests that young mothers of small children exercise less than other women their age and dont eat as well.

title: Revenge of the Global Savings Glut (Wonkish)
description: Chinese inflation is getting headlines, as it should. But its worth bearing in mind that this is essentially a real problem, not a monetary problem.

title: Ask Medicare 2.0
description: Medicare.gov gets up to 2.8 million visitors a month who use the Web site to do everything from ordering new cards to learning how many problems inspectors found at local nursing homes.

title: A Rare Vote by Speaker Boehner
description: When Speaker John A. Boehner voted on April 14 for a legislative compromise to keep the government financed through September, it was a rare event: he had not voted on the House floor since Jan. 19, when he joined the Republican majority in voting to repeal President Obamas health care law.

title: So Far, Our New Pricing Strategy Is Working
description: When Colicchio & Sons switched to a prix fixe only one month after opening in January, I had to smile. Excellent timing. For me, if not them. We were entertaining the same change during our hiatus at Southfork Kitchen. (Restaurant definition of hiatus: stop serving, start debating.)

title: Datsyuk Dominating Coyotes
description: Detroit Red Wings center Pavel Datsyuk shyly shrugged when asked why hes been able to carve through the Phoenix Coyotes defense with such ease so far in their first-round playoff series. Hes not analyzing his success, just going with the flow.

title: Happy Tax Day
description: Some links in honor of Tax Day:

title: Judges See Sentencing Injustice, but the Calendar Disagrees
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Untrained Eye
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#186", 592, 440, false, chameleonData);

title: Monday Morning Skate: Ryans Stomp, Plus/Minus and Plays of the Weekend
description: Ryans Costly Stomp

title: For the N.B.A. Playoffs, Go West Young Fan
description: We interrupt the East Coast hyperventilation over the Knicks-Celtics playoff series (Two iconic teams! Star players! New York-Boston animosity! Really high concession stand prices!) to direct your attention out west. Because if the Game 1s were any indication, way wilder stuff is happening out there.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: While it is relatively quiet in Washington, with Congress away and no advisory committee meetings scheduled by the Food & Drug Administration, Monday morning still brings some health care news.

title: (Nature vs. Nurture) x Money
description: To the debate over nature vs. nurture (or, as it has shaken out recently, Amy Chua vs. Bryan Caplan), my colleague Motoko Rich reminds us of a most important factor  money. In the Week in Review yesterday, she wrote, paradoxically, the kind of parents who follow debates about parenting  typically more affluent and educated  are those who may have the least to worry about.

title: Publisher of Three Cups of Tea to Conduct Review
description: Viking, the publisher of Three Cups of Tea, said in a statement on Monday that it would review the book and its contents with the author, Greg Mortenson, after a CBS News report that called into question the accuracy of part of the book.

title: How Do You Deal With Neighbor Noise?
description: The sounds of New Yorkers clunking across floors, the peals of construction that stretch from dawn until dusk, the neighbor who takes pleasure singing Fergie songs off key: these are all sounds that New Yorkers tolerate each day from their neighbors. Most New Yorkers dont want to complain because they dont want to make enemies of people they have to see at the annual building barbecue. But plenty of New Yorkers have been known to reach the breaking point and speak up.

title: The 23 Percent Solution
description: As Jonathan Cohn says, American conservatives have a very parochial view of what would constitute crippling levels of taxes. My colleague Ross Douthat cites the possibility of federal taxes rising to 23 percent of GDP (compared with the 19 percent assumed  unrealistically  in the Ryan plan) as something to be deeply worried about. But America is a low-tax country by international standards:

title: A Note on Median Income
description: My column today includes an estimate, taken from this Congressional Budget Office report, of what a median-income family would pay in taxes over the next few decades under the current law baseline  a scenario in which tax rates rise fast enough to cover the budget deficit without any kind of entitlement reform. The median income figure the C.B.O. used (see Table 4-4 on p. 65 of the report) is $94,900 for a family of four, which (as a number of readers have noted) seems much higher than the usual estimates for median income in a four-person household. It turns out that I didnt catch a crucial footnote in the C.B.O. document: All income is assumed to be from compensation, which includes employment-based health insurance and the employers share of payroll taxes. That is to say, the $94,900 in income includes the estimated value of the median familys health care plan as well as their salary, which is not what most people think of when they hear the term median income. I apologize for the confusion.

title: Confronting Your Personal Debt Ceiling
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Frustration and Hope as Oil Drilling Regulator Remakes Itself
description: In Sundays Times, we assessed the Interior Departments progress in revamping the Minerals Management Service, the scandal-ridden agency responsible for regulating offshore oil and gas drilling and collecting royalties from oil development on public lands.

title: Gannett Earnings Fall
description: Earnings at Gannett, publisher of USA Today and dozens of local newspapers across the country, fell in the first quarter as the print advertising market remained stubbornly soft.

title: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Finally Stumbles, and Hamilton Pounces
description: If Formula One drivers hope to beat Sebastian Vettel, the 2010 overall series champion and winner of four consecutive races before this last Sunday, they might have to wait for the German to somehow sabotage himself, as he did on Sunday at the Chinese Grand Prix.

title: Volkswagen Beetle: Squeezing a Classic Shape for New Lines
description: After a tightly controlled introductory campaign, in which not even Oprah Winfrey could reveal more than its silhouette for a giveaway on her daytime TV show, the new Volkswagen Beetle was unveiled in lower Manhattan on Monday morning.

title: Finding Goldman at Fault in the Crisis
description: The exhaustive report on the financial crisis by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations blames various parties, including banks for their risky transactions and federal regulators for their lax oversight. But the subcommittee saved some of its most scathing remarks for Goldman Sachs and its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein.

title: Everyone Whos Anyone (and Then Some) on Tribeca Film Juries
description: What do Nora Ephron and the Wikipedia co-founder Jimmy Wales (both at left) talk about when they get together? Maybe they reminisce about their appearances on The Colbert Report, he says he loved Sleepless in Seattle, she complains about the accuracy of her Wikipedia entry, and then they get around to judging independent films. Thats what the Tribeca Film Festival would have us believe.

title: Mother and Daughter Stabbed to Death in Brooklyn
description: A 56-year-old woman and her 28-year-old daughter were found stabbed to death in a Brooklyn apartment late Sunday night, the police said.

title: Another Palin Book on the Way
description: Another book in the Sarah Palin canon is weeks away from publication. Howard Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, announced on Monday that on May 24 it would publish Blind Allegiance to Sarah Palin, an account of Ms. Palins time as governor and as a vice-presidential candidate, written by Frank Bailey, one of her former aides. In a statement, Howard Books called it a chilling expos of Palin and the story of one mans slow drift from his most cherished beliefs to his ultimate redemption. Mr. Baileys book will come before a widely anticipated book about Ms. Palin, The Rogue, by the author and the journalist Joe McGinniss, which is expected to be released by Crown in September.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q. & A. With Stuart Elliott

title: Thais Are Shocked, Shocked by Topless Dancers
description: BANGKOK  To millions of tourists, this is a city famous for its tolerance and notoriously wild nightlife.

title: How Musicians Communicate Emotion
description: A video from Daniel J. Levitin's lab at McGill University explaining a study on music perception, cognition and expertise.

title: A Brain on Chopin
description: An animation showing changes in brain activity while study subjects listened to a performance of a Chopin etude in E major.

title: Bouillabaisse of Fresh Peas With Poached Eggs
description: In the Provence region of France, it is a peasant tradition to make poor mans bouillabaisse with vegetables. For this soup, only fresh peas will work  dont try it with frozen.

title: A Bowlful of Our Daily Bread
description: Soups thickened with fresh or stale bread are ubiquitous throughout the Mediterranean  indeed, wherever bread is a staple. The simplest are made with thick, toasted slices of bread, sometimes rubbed with garlic, arranged in wide bowls and covered with soup. They can be topped with poached eggs for a satisfying meal.

title: Trust Me, Were Rich
description: Within the developed world, Danes are the most trusting people and Chileans the least, according to new data from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Art Center College of Design, Pasadena, Calif., is honoring a faculty member, Doyald Young, a typeface designer, with the Doyald Young Memorial Scholarship. Mr. Young died on Feb. 28 at age 84. The scholarship will be available to current and incoming students.

title: Notre Dame Report Spreads Responsibility in Student Death
description: High wind, a lack of current weather information and a hydraulic lift susceptible to tipping each contributed to the death of a student video trainer at Notre Dame in October, the university said Monday after a six-month internal investigation into the accident.

title: Actually, Jamie Dimon Now Likes New Consumer Bureau
description: Jamie Dimon, it turns out, has a soft spot for the governments new consumer financial bureau.

title: For Evian, Its Baby One More Time
description: Evian is introducing a second sequel to its hugely popular 2009 campaign that featured babies who, thanks to the magic of CGI, appeared as if they were roller-skating.

title: Same Old Garbage, but a Crisp New Slogan
description: Say hello to the latest salvo in the subways long-running War on Trash.

title: Maternal Baggage
description: They say behind every successful man stands a woman. In the case of Michael Kors, its his mother, Joan, a former model and Korss perennial muse. Now he has designed a bag worthy of carrying not just her wallet and sunglasses but also her name. The Joan, which comes in a variety of colors (including the mocha embossed leather version seen here) and is modestly priced at $398, meets Joans strict standards: I always look for an outside pocket for my phone and keys, she says, and I love a zip closure. But she adds, I certainly wouldnt mind being surprised with a crocodile version! Joan says she plans to celebrate Mothers Day on the West Coast with a fabulous arrangement of peonies and dinner with Michael. The greatest gift hes ever given her? Not having to go shopping for the past 30 years.

title: What Makes Music Expressive?
description: What makes music expressive? Quiz yourself based on new research.

title: "Imagine No Malaria" Ad
description: United Methodist Church's new ad campaign for anti-malaria project.

title: Populist Advance in Finland Could Endanger Bailouts
description: BRUSSELS  Since the euro zone crisis got under way in earnest a year ago, various Cassandras have warned that the day would come when voters would rise up in revolt against paying for the mistakes of others with costly bailouts.

title: To Tug Hearts, Music First Must Tickle the Neurons
description: The other day, Paul Simon was rehearsing a favorite song: his own Darling Lorraine, about a love that starts hot but turns very cold. He found himself thinking about a three-note rhythmic pattern near the end, where Lorraine (spoiler alert) gets sick and dies.

title: Janitors and Corporate Executives Have the Same Pay Plan
description: I mean it: both receive a weekly paycheck. So theres no difference in what theyre offered!

title: Billups Injury Weighs Heavily on Knicks
description: BOSTON  On the morning after their first playoff game in seven years, the Knicks were still limping, rationalizing and grumbling, and still wondering how to unlock the mystery of the mighty Boston Celtics.

title: Campaign Seeks to Take a Bite Out of Disease
description: Advertising is often meant to stimulate the imagination: Picture yourself behind the wheel of a new car, in a new outfit, reaching out to your friends on the coolest new smartphone. An ambitious campaign is now trying to encourage much more altruistic imaginings.

title: Peoplescapes
description: Massimo Vitalis photographs are transporting. When I see one of his pictures, I want to be in it. Partly this is because the settings are so often happy gathering spots: beaches, lakes, pools and other watering holes, ski slopes, gardens and assorted sightseeing sites. Usually theres sunlight; always theres color. Above all, theres clarity  Im convinced that if I look hard enough, I can see everything and forever.

title: In Reversal, Poppy Production Expanding in Afghanistan, U.N. Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Driven by soaring opium prices, farmers are expected to plant poppies at a sharply higher rate in parts of Afghanistan that were previously poppy free, the United Nations said Monday in its annual winter survey of poppy cultivation patterns in this country, the worlds leading opium purveyor.

title: Robot Cousins of Roomba Are Deployed in Japan
description: As The Associated Press explains, the PackBot robots sent in to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant to measure radiation levels there were made by an American company, iRobot, which also makes the Roomba, a robot vacuum cleaner.

title: On Ship of Evacuees From Libya, Harrowing Tales
description: ABOARD THE IONIAN SPIRIT, off Libya  More than 900 migrant workers were evacuated by sea overnight Sunday from the besieged Libyan port city of Misurata, one further step in the international effort to rescue thousands of foreigners stranded within Libya after the rebellion began.

title: The Anti-Dowry
description: The burden of student debt which delays graduates from buying property, founding businesses, or starting families.

title: S&P Can Call Bond Vigilantes From The Vasty Deep
description: Why, so can I, and so can any man. But will they come when S&P does call for them?

title: Kenyan Runs Fastest Marathon in Boston
description: BOSTON  With a brisk wind at his back and a determined countryman on his shoulder to push him down the stretch, Geoffrey Mutai of Kenya pulled away from Moses Mosop in the final quarter-mile Monday to win the 115th Boston Marathon. His time, 2 hours 3 minutes 2 seconds, was the fastest marathon run by nearly a minute, and it smashed the course record, set last year, by nearly three minutes.

title: Video: Working Towards a Budget Deal
description: Read John Harwoods column, Amid Din, Serious Talk on Debt, published in Mondays Times.

title: The Prospects for a Budget Deal
description: John Harwood and Jackie Calmes discussed lawmakers' recent attempts to search for common ground on issues of the debt ceiling and the 2012 federal budget.

title: Winklevoss Twins Ask for New Hearing in Facebook Case
description: Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss are not giving up. The brothers, who claim that they, not Mark Zuckerberg, came up with the idea for Facebook, are asking a federal appeals court in San Francisco to rehear their request that a 2008 settlement between them and Facebook be nullified so that they can pursue their original case against the company.

title: J.&J.-Synthes Talks Spur Hopes for Deals
description: Synthes, the Swiss-American medical tools maker, confirmed on Monday that it was in talks with Johnson & Johnson, spurring hopes of a deal and of possibly others to follow.

title: Between the Lines, Where Musics Soul Resides
description: On Timing

title: Russian Officials Said to Reap Wealth in Tax Case
description: MOSCOW  After accusing government officials here of involvement in large-scale tax fraud three years ago, Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer for a major international investment fund, was arrested and jailed for nearly a year until he died mysteriously in detention.

title: The Nose May Not Know What Its Missing
description: Dr. Ronald DeVere, a neurologist in Austin, Tex., was baffled. In 1995, after recovering from a viral infection, something happened to his sense of smell. Fresh milk smelled sour, the dirty dog pen smelled good, and other odors couldnt be detected at all.

title: Slow Payers Hinder Trade in Europe
description: ZARAGOZA, SPAIN  In 2001, an agricultural co-op here was supplying truckloads of wheat to an Italian pasta maker. At first, no one at the Spanish co-op, Arento, was much alarmed when the pasta factory in Milan fell behind in its payments.

title: How Banks Spin Their Earnings
description: Not surprisingly, banks, in their earnings reports, are quick to highlight the areas of strength and downplay the weak points.

title: The Beatification of David Foster Wallace
description: However much you admire David Foster Wallace or the people who write so well about him (like our own Sam Anderson,Tom McCarthy in the Book Review orJ. J. Sullivanat GQ), there is so much ink being spilled in favor of D.F.W. and his posthumous Great Novel, The Pale King, that its worth considering the dissenters.At Bookslut, http://www.bookslut.com/blog/archives/2011_04.php#017542 Jessica Crispin counts herself among the less-than-convinced (she prefers Henry James) and links to Geoff Dyers allergy to Wallaciana at Prospect. Dyer writes:

title: Cowell Trades One X Factor for Another
description: As he turns his attention to his American adaptation of The X Factor, Simon Cowell is bowing out, at least partly, from the British version of the show he created.

title: No More Messing With J.R.: Citi and Actor Reach Accord
description: Christian Alminana/Agence France-Presse  Getty ImagesLarry Hagman reprising his best-known character, J.R. Ewing in Dallas.

title: 2012 Volkswagen Beetle: A Bug With a Rampaging Y Chromosome
description: Masculine, masculine, masculine. Klaus Bischoff, head of design for the Volkswagen brand, kept returning to the word to describe the design of the successor to the New Beetle, the car Volkswagen calls simply the 21st century Beetle.

title: Our Lessons Are on Spring Break
description: but theres plenty to do in the meantime. This week we acknowledge tax day, Passover, Holy Week and Earth Day. Weve got resources for all of them and more  much more!  below.

title: 2011 Pulitzer Prize Winners Announced
description: The New York Times won Pulitzer Prizes on Monday for its economics commentary and its reporting on Russia, while The Los Angeles Times received the coveted public service Pulitzer and the award for feature photography.

title: 2011 Pulitzer Prizes for Letters, Drama and Music
description: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. The complete list of winners in Letters, Drama and Music is below.

title: Ally Bank Offers Remote Deposit, but Not From Your Phone
Allusions
description: 1. I dont have an original source for Williamson on immaculate transfer  I heard it from him verballyorally at a conference at IIE many years ago, and its hard to find a reference that doesnt trace back to me.

title: Name Your Poison
description: Q. Is it possible to make yourself invulnerable to arsenic poisoning by taking small doses, as sometimes happens in mystery novels?

title: Eye Candy
description: Even among the Warhol Superstars, Candy Darling was a standout. Her spot-on embodiment of a 40s-era Hollywood starlet  demure, mysterious, quiet  stood in contrast to the pretty-little-rich-girl routine of Edie Sedgwick, the drug-fueled silver-tongued cheek of Brigid Berlin and the Teutonic otherness of Nico. And the fact that she was a transgendered woman from Long Island only added to her mystique. Her fame spread via the Paul Morrissey films Flesh and Women in Revolt, and she was immortalized by Lou Reed in the songs Candy Says and Walk on the Wild Side. She died in 1974, from leukemia connected to unsafe hormone treatments, at the age of 29.

title: 60 Minutes Leads CBS to Sunday Night Ratings Win
description: The newsmagazine 60 Minutes delivered the largest audience in prime time on Sunday as CBS won the nights ratings over its network competitors. According to Nielsens estimates, 10.6 million viewers tuned in at 7 p.m. for an edition that featured an investigation into the accuracy of Greg Mortensons book Three Cups of Tea. CBS then also won the 8 p.m. hour with its reality show The Amazing Race (8.7 million). ABC ranked close behind CBS in second place for the night, leading during the 9 p.m. hour with Desperate Housewives (8.8 million). NBC placed third over all, garnering an average of 7.4 million viewers for The Celebrity Apprentice from 9 to 11. Fox was fourth with its animated comedy lineup, although Family Guy (6 million) earned the nights highest ratings in the demographic of adults 18 to 49.

title: Expectations Grow for Greek Debt Restructuring
description: The Greeks reject a debt restructuring out of hand. The European Central Bank fears that such a move will spread financial panic. And, meanwhile, the European Union and the International Monetary Fund insist that their recipe of bailouts combined with sharp spending cuts makes restructurings unnecessary.

title: Julia Louis-Dreyfus Is Elected for Veep
description: Shes not Sarah Palin. Shes not Hillary Rodham Clinton or Michele Bachmann, and needless to say, shes not Joe Biden or Dick Cheney, either. But Julia Louis-Dreyfus will play a female vice president of the United States in Veep, a new HBO comedy series that the network announced on Monday it had picked up.

title: Syria: Fighting the Fungi That Threaten Wheat
description: Fungi that attack wheat are growing as a threat to the hungry inhabitants of poor countries. At a conference this week in Aleppo, Syria, scientists will be planning a counteroffensive.

title: For an Exercise Afterburn, Intensity May Be the Key
description: Depending on whom you ask, the answer to this question is either one of the great myths of exercise or one of the great unappreciated truths: Is there an afterburn effect from a workout?

title: Bobby McFerrin Takes Ice Water Test
description: The singer Bobby McFerrin visited Daniel J. Levitins lab and walked through several experiments, including one that tested how music affected one's threshold for pain.

title: Thank You for Serving Without Pay. You Owe Taxes Anyway.
description: And now, another example that no good deed goes unpunished.

title: Afghan Group Distances Itself From One Under Cloud
description: The ripples created by an explosive television report challenging the veracity of Three Cups of Tea, a bestselling memoir dealing with Afghanistan and Pakistan, have reached Queens.

title: Court Hears Microsoft Patent Case
description: WASHINGTON  Microsofts challenge to a $290 million award against it in a patent infringement suit faced significant headwinds on Monday during arguments at the Supreme Court.

title: 2011 Pulitzer Prizes for Journalism
description: The Pulitzer Prizes were announced on Monday. Following are the winners in Journalism.

title: Hotels Turn to Social Media to Connect With Travelers
description: Hotels have begun offering direct bookings through Facebook and smartphone apps, and they hope that the convenience and direct contact will lure back travelers who have been turning to online travel agencies.

title: Radiation Poses Barrier to Repair Work at Plant
description: TOKYO  Robots deployed inside two reactors at the Japanese nuclear plant overrun by last months devastating tsunami have detected radiation levels too high for workers to enter, posing immediate challenges for a new plan to bring the ravaged complex under control by years end.

title: New Mothers Have Worse Health Habits
description: New motherhood apparently takes a toll on a womans health. Young mothers of small children exercise less than other women their age and dont eat as well, according to a new report.

title: Met Opera Announces Park Series
description: For the third season in a row, the Metropolitan Opera is offering recitals instead of full-scale operas for its free summer parks series. The Met announced in a statement on Monday that the soprano Angela Meade, the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Johnson Cano and the tenor Dimitri Pittas would perform on July 11 in Central Park and on July 13 in Brooklyn Bridge Park. Three other singers would present programs in Crotona Park in the Bronx (July 19); Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island (July 21); Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens (July 26); and Jackie Robinson Park in Harlem (July 28). Those performers will be Layla Claire, a soprano; Rene Tatum, a mezzo-soprano; and Ryan Speedo Green, a bass-baritone. The pianist Bradley Moore will be the accompanist for all of the concerts. The statement said the Met would also present free outdoor screenings of its high-definition broadcasts from Lincoln Center from Aug. 27 to Sept. 5. The last full Met opera in the park was in the summer of 2007. In 2008, the Met presented a lone recital by the soprano Angela Gheorghiu and the tenor Roberto Alagna.

title: Side Sleeping to Reduce Snoring
description: Todays Really? column explores the claim that sleeping on your side can reduce snoring.

title: Drug That Stops Bleeding Shows Off-Label Dangers
description: A powerful, costly drug approved in 1999 for a small group of patients who may bleed uncontrollably during surgery is now used in a host of other surgical situations, sometimes with serious negative effects, two new studies report.

title: Eighty Years Along, a Longevity Study Still Has Ground to Cover
description: After reading The Longevity Project, I took an unscientific survey of friends and relatives asking them what personality characteristic they thought was most associated with long life. Several said optimism, followed by equanimity, happiness, a good marriage, the ability to handle stress. One offered, jokingly, good table manners.

title: Traveling to Jewel Destinations, and the Airplane Antics in Between
description: IT seems as if I built my business around my travel desires. Being in the jewelry business means I get to go to Antwerp, Venice, Istanbul, Hong Kong and a lot of other wonderful places. Theres no downside to this because I get to see such amazing things.

title: Appreciation Trumps Comparisons Between Stars
description: As Chris Paul jumped in the air, collected a pass, and rocketed a perfectly placed pass into the hands of Aaron Gray for an easy scoring opportunity, you could already hear the whispers.

title: Nestl Takes Aim at China
description: Nestl, the worlds biggest food company, has taken a step toward strengthening its position in China by agreeing to acquire 60 percent of the Yinlu Food Group. The family-owned Yinlu had sales of $829 million last year, and its acquisition gives Nestl broader access to a fast-growing segment of the Chinese market, Reuters reports.

title: The Longevity Project
description: Introduction: The Breakthrough Studies of a Lifetime

title: TimesCast | April 18, 2011
description: Kim Severson reports from Askewville, N.C., where at least 11 residents were killed by tornadoes over the weekend.

title: William Rusher, Champion of Conservatism, Dies at 87
description: William A. Rusher, who advanced a rising conservative tide in America for more than 50 years as a political strategist, author, syndicated columnist and publisher of William F. Buckley Jr.s bible of the right, National Review, died on Saturday in San Francisco. He was 87.

title: Is the iPad 2 a Lot Better Than the Original?
description: Over the weekend,Chris Dixon, anentrepreneurand co-founder of the social siteHunch, lamented on Twitterthat he still had not purchased a new iPad 2. Although Mr. Dixon hopes to buy the highly coveted device soon, he questioned whether it was a must have upgrade from the first generation iPad.

title: The Benefits of Sleep, Follow-Up
description: No doubt having read Maggie Joness sleep article in our special health and wellness issue this past weekend and her thoughts on this blog on Friday, the F.A.A. announced Saturday that it was going to change the way it schedules air-traffic controllers.

title: A Fifth Avenue Co-op Says No: Did It Take Subterfuge?
description: To a certain slice of New Yorkers, its the kind of gossip that is whispered over lunches at Bergdorfs and mentioned during air kisses at fund-raisers: being rejected by a Fifth Avenue co-op board. But a Turkish businesswomans story is a bit different. After being rejected by the board at 812 Fifth Avenue, she has spent nearly two years fighting to get back her deposit on the $3 million apartment.

title: Come On, I Thought I Knew That!
description: Trick question: Is it easier to remember a new fact if it appears in normal type, like this, or in big, bold letters, like this?

title: Obama Tax Return Shows Income Down
description: Income for the Obama household continued to slip in 2010, tax returns show, as proceeds from President Obamas best-selling books tapered off. But just as he has said, his income is easily high enough to make the family eligible for a tax increase under his own deficit-reduction proposals.

title: Three Pulitzers for Magazine Contributors
description: The winners of three Pulitzer Prizes that were announced today have written recently for our magazine, and we would like to offer them special congratulations.

title: Obamas Report $1.7 Million in Income for 2010
description: The adjusted gross income reported for 2010 is a considerable drop from the $5.5 million reported by Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle, in 2009.

title: A.I.G. to Sell Rail Services Unit to Perella Weinberg
description: The American International Group said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its rail services to an investment arm of Perella Weinberg Partners for $600 million, as part of the insurers plan to sell off assets to repay its government bailout.

title: The Koch Brothers and Climate Science, Redux
description: Last year, Greenpeace, the environmental group, accused the brothers Charles and David Koch of a stealth campaign to attack climate science, setting off extensive media scrutiny of the Kochs and their company, Koch Industries. (A Koch subsidiary is a major oil refiner.) Now Greenpeace is out with an update.

title: Horseplay in the Water
description: SHORTLY before 8 on Sunday evenings, swimmers doing laps at the Chinatown Y.M.C.A call it a night, and three staff members from the NYC Social Sports Club take over the space, placing 20 yellow and blue inner tubes in the water and putting up goals at each end of the pool.

title: Rocking the New York Auto Show
description: Playing an auto-show media event cant be the best gig in the world.

title: Mothers on the Night Shift
description: Sleep while the baby sleeps is the unattainable goal of most new parents.

title: Opposition Leader Besigye Arrested in Uganda Protest
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The leading opposition figure here was arrested on Monday and charged with inciting violence, as a third day of street demonstrations in the Ugandan capital ended in shrouds of tear gas and rubber bullets.

title: Dance, Dance, Dance | Cate Lets Loose
description: The typically placid Cate Blanchett bounces about in this 80s-inspired clip from Cass Birds cover shoot for Ts summer womens issue.

title: S.&P. States the Obvious
description: Standard & Poors has taken its fair share of criticism in recent years. But at least it isnt too shy to state the much-needed obvious situation on Americas debt.

title: A Star Brings Singers and Composers Together
description: For the soprano Dawn Upshaw, mixing styles and interacting with composers have been signature elements since the start of her illustrious career. Since 2004 Ms. Upshaw has shared her insights, training young singers and composers to collaborate during workshops presented under the auspices of Carnegie Halls Weill Music Institute. That year she worked alongside the composer John Harbison; in 2007 and 2009 she teamed up with Osvaldo Golijov.

title: Berlioz, Shostakovich and Grard Depardieu
description: The main thing a listener wanted from the Chicago Symphony Orchestras visit to Carnegie Hall this weekend was a sense of how this great ensemble was faring under the baton of Riccardo Muti, whose tenure as its music director began in September. You had to have a strong set of mental blinders not to think, in the moments before Mr. Muti walked onstage, about the alarming illnesses that have kept him off the podium much of the season, and that naturally brought to mind the health problems that led James Levine to give up his directorship of the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Those concerns were amplified by the news, announced just hours before the Saturday evening concert, that the Philadelphia Orchestra  Mr. Mutis previous American podium  had declared bankruptcy.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Nigeria, Iraq, Libya and Gaza City.

title: For Montreal Symphony, Shoebox Is a Grand Home
description: MONTREAL  The Montreal Symphony Orchestra, once a storied ensemble that gave blazing performances with the international maestro Charles Dutoit, lost some luster when he left amid acrimony with the players. A bitter five-month strike several years later, in 2005, took a further toll.

title: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Nigeria, Iraq, Libya and Gaza City.

title: From Belarus, Dynamic Drama With Limited Means
description: The firecracker that is set off in the first seconds of the Belarus Free Theaters astounding Zone of Silence, at La MaMa in the East Village, doesnt make much noise, at least not as measured in decibels. But theres a lot of power in the short, sharp pop of this homemade explosive.

title: Willow Garage Introduces TurtleBot Robot
description: It looks as if I can finally stop trying to train my dog to fetch a bagel and coffee from the kitchen each morning. Instead, Ill be able to use a new robot, the TurtleBot, which is made by the robotics company Willow Garage.

title: Noma Again Tops the San Pellegrino List of Best Restaurants
description: The San Pellegrino Worlds 50 Best  Restaurants were announced in London today. For the second year in a row Noma, in Copenhagen, was the top-rated restaurant.

title: Whales Grandeur and Grace, Up Close
description: On a warm summer afternoon in 2005, Bryant Austin was snorkeling in the blue waters of the South Pacific by the islands of Tonga, looking through his camera at a humpback whale and her calf swimming less than 50 yards away. As he waited for the right moment, the playful calf swam right up to him, so close that he had to lower his camera. Thats when he felt a gentle tap on his shoulder.

title: A Cozy Chamber Concert Buoyed by Lapping Water
description: Anyone who has never attended a Bargemusic concert may find it hard to believe that a converted old barge docked at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn is an ideally intimate place to hear chamber music. It is.

title: At Coachella, Every Note Is Writ Large
description: INDIO, Calif.  The Coachella Valley Music & Arts Festival started 12 years ago, a few generations by pop measurements. Its enough time for more than one broad set of tastes to harden and be pushed aside.

title: Turkey Disqualifies 12 Pro-Kurdish Politicians From Parliamentary Election
description: ISTANBUL  Turkeys senior election board on Monday disqualified 12 pro-Kurdish politicians from running for Parliament in the coming election on the grounds that they are legally unfit to be candidates. The unexpected move is likely to anger Kurds in the countrys restive southeast who have been seeking further representation.

title: Treading Very Carefully on the Road to Nostalgia
description: Seen from a certain angle, everything was as it should have been at the Orchestre National de Frances concert, conducted by Daniele Gatti, on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Congrats to David Leonhardt
description: Pulitzer!

title: New Palin Web Site Has Pundits Buzzing
description: Just when political conventional wisdom was starting to turn against the likelihood of a Sarah Palin presidential run, the former governor of Alaska has left new clues on the Internet that she is still very much playing with the idea.

title: Cuomo Releases 2010 Tax Filings
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo earned about $200,000 last year from his salary as state attorney general and income from investments, according to tax filings his office made available on Monday.

title: Mortenson Concedes He Conflated Parts of Memoir
description: Greg Mortenson fled a book signing in Atlanta last week to avoid speaking to 60 Minutes and has so far declined to speak with any reporter from the mainstream media about that shows contention that he inaccurately described pivotal events in his best-selling book, Three Cups of Tea.

title: St. Nicholas Park, 10:11 A.M.
A Recording Studio Found Under the Pacific
description: Humpback whales not only sing, they imitate the singing of other whales. And some of their tunes turn into worldwide hits, with whales all over the Pacific Ocean picking them up.

title: Foreign Money Fuels Faltering Bid to Push Online Poker
description: WASHINGTON  For the past four years, the foreign companies that control the global Internet poker industry have helped bankroll an elaborate lobbying campaign here, seeking to keep the United States from shutting their American operations down.

title: Bwahahaha!
description: Jonathan Chait, sending us to Gawker on the very strange Roger Ailes:

title: Coachella Valley Music Festival
description: This years Coachella festival in California had Kanye West, Arcade Fire and up to 75,000 fans.

title: Using History to Sell Clothes? Dont Try It With the Pharaohs
description: Zahi Hawass, Egypts longtime chief antiquities official, has been criticized in recent months for many things: his closeness to former President Hosni Mubarak, some inconsistent reports on the safety of archaeological sites during the uprising and for his role in a dispute over an Egyptian museum bookstore, for which he now possibly faces jail time.

title: Readers Feel the Pinch of Paying Hotel Extras
description: DONT get Jesse White started about those fees and surcharges that high-end hotels slap onto your bill. He was more than happy to discuss his annoyance with that kind of treatment.

title: Some Dinosaurs Liked the Night Life, Eye Bones Show
description: Paleontologists have generally believed that dinosaurs were active only during the day, preserving their energy at night, when mammals hunted and ate. But an analysis of dinosaur eye structure shows that at least some dinosaurs functioned quite capably in the dark.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,519 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the death of the following American:

title: Reptiles Eat With the Bones Humans Hear With, Fossil Proves
description: One of the knowns in the evolutionary biology of mammals, including humans, is that the three little bones in their middle ear originated in the lower jaw of their reptilian predecessors. The link has been demonstrated in studies of developing mammalian embryos, and two of the three bones are found in the jaw of living reptiles. So reptiles eat with the bones we hear with.

title: For Elite Teams, Questions of Depth
description: There are a lot of things one expects to hear at Staples Center when a Laker player is shooting free throws. Who are you? is not one of them. But when the Lakers Trey Johnson was at the free-throw line during Sundays game against the New Orleans Hornets, he found himself being asked that question by one very loud fan, and it was hard to blame the fan for asking.

title: The Reclusive Other Half of Microsofts Odd Couple Breaks His Silence
description: Here is an example of billionaire humor, as recounted by Paul Allen in his carefully legacy-minded new memoir, Idea Man: Mr. Allen commissioned Octopus, which was to be the largest of his yachts. It would be seven stories high and one-third longer than a football field. Amenities would include a concert stage and recording studio, because Mr. Allen plays the guitar himself and really likes inviting rock stars aboard. Another special feature, because  well, why not?  would be a submarine.

title: New Lessons to Pave a Road to Safety
description: Teenagers are notoriously bad drivers, accounting for 10 times as many crashes as middle-aged ones. But short of keeping them off the road entirely, is there a way to make their driving safer  for them and for the rest of us?

title: Infectious Enthusiasm (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Yahoo Will Keep Search Queries for 18 Months
description: Three years ago, Yahoo cast itself as a defender of privacy by saying it would keep detailed records of its users search queries for just 90 days. The company said it would then purge that information in an effort to strengthen Yahoos relationship of trust with its users.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sick, but Not Alone (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

description: Amanda Marcotte, left, of Pandagon and Daniel Foster of National Review debate the ethics of being a "pick-up artist."

description: To the Editor:

title: Winners of Lukas Prizes For Nonfiction
description: A book about the conflict between Muslims and Christians and one about the migration of black Americans from south to north won the 2011 J. Anthony Lukas Prize Project Awards for exceptional nonfiction.

description: To the Editor:

title: Portugals Economy
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Tax Return Shows Lower Household Income Than in 2009
description: Income for the Obama household continued to slip in 2010, tax returns show, as proceeds from President Obamas best-selling books tapered off. But just as he has said, his income is easily high enough to make the family eligible for a tax increase under his own deficit-reduction proposals.

title: Critics Choice
description: CAMRON & VADO

title: Galea Could Be Discussing Plea Deal in Doping Case
description: Anthony Galea, the Canadian doctor who was indicted last October on charges that he distributed performance-enhancing drugs to professional athletes in the United States, is in discussions with federal prosecutors, his lawyer said Monday.

title: Citys Super Bowl Chooses Lead Host
description: Alfred F. Kelly Jr. grew up in New York a Green Bay Packers fan, the legacy of his father and grandfathers attending Fordham, Vince Lombardis alma mater. Now, after a business career that included being the president of American Express, he will run the host committee for the 2014 Super Bowl at New Meadowlands Stadium.

title: The Assembly Line Is Rolling Again, Tenuously, at Honda in Japan
description: SAYAMA, Japan  As an electric sign tallied the vehicles rolling off the Honda assembly line here, a scrolling message exhorted employees: Lets pool our strength to overcome this crisis.

title: Destruction on Campus Brings End to Semester
description: Instead of cramming for finals, students at the Souths oldest historically black college were cramming their belongings into hastily bought tubs from Wal-Mart after a tornado forced an abrupt departure from their dormitories and, in some cases, an early end to their college years.

title: Lockout Could Jeopardize Game Set for London
description: The N.F.L. will announce its regular-season schedule Tuesday, but it acknowledged for the first time a deadline by which a resolution to the labor stalemate is necessary to avoid disrupting the season.

title: Pulitzers Reward Tenacious Photographers
description: Carol Guzy, Nikki Kahn and Ricky Carioti of The Washington Post have won the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in breaking news photography for their coverage of the catastrophic Haitian earthquake. And Barbara Davidson of The Los Angeles Times has won the Pulitzer in feature photography for chronicling the victims of gang violence.

title: Letting the Banks Off the Hook
description: Judging by last weeks performance, it sure looks as though the countrys top bank regulator is back to its old tricks.

title: Robert Mugabe Hounds Rivals in Zimbabwe, Parties Say
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  More than a quarter of President Robert Mugabes opponents in Parliament have been arrested since agreeing to join the government in a shaky power-sharing arrangement, part of an intensifying campaign of harassment intended to drive them out of office, officials from both sides say.

title: 5 Tips for Photographing Tennis Matches
description: With tennis season approaching, parents will be hovering at courtside, cameras raised, hoping to get the photo that reveals their little slugger as a budding Serena Williams or Rafael Nadal.

title: Deficit Panel to Meet, but Who Will Attend?
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on May 5 will host the first meeting on deficit reduction with members of Congress since President Obama last week called for a bipartisan group to start negotiating an austerity plan, the White House announced late on Monday.

title: Why Trump Soars
description: Very few people have the luxury of being freely obnoxious. Most people have to watch what they say for fear of offending their bosses and colleagues. Others resist saying anything that might make them unpopular.

title: Rangers Follow the Mustachioed in the Playoffs
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Rangers center Brian Boyle is 6 feet 7 inches and weighs 244 pounds, but he has learned that he cannot yet, or maybe ever, cultivate a full Stanley Cup playoff beard, like some of his teammates. So Boyle has grown a thick, black mustache instead.

title: Still an Ideological Oddity in New Jersey, but a Rising Force in His Party
description: WASHINGTON  Long before there was a Tea Party, there was Representative Scott Garrett, a Republican from the forested regions of northern New Jersey who had long stood out among the moderates and liberals of both parties in the states Congressional delegation.

title: Sports Replay: April 18
description: A look at the day in sports, including an eventful Patriots Day in Boston.

title: Obama Hosts Passover Seder at White House
description: When then-Senator Barack Obama and some tired campaign aides held an impromptu Passover Seder in Pennsylvania in 2008, concluding with the prayer Next year in Jerusalem, they could hardly have confidently thought, Next year in the White House!

title: Lack of Success Terminates Study in Africa of AIDS Prevention in Women
description: In an unexpected setback for a new form of AIDS prevention, scientists on Monday halted a study in Africa intended to find out whether a daily antiretroviral pill can prevent women from becoming infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Madison Avenue Turns Toward the Entrepreneurial
description: MADISON AVENUE will never be confused with Silicon Alley, much less Silicon Valley. But increasingly, agencies are trying to channel their inner entrepreneurs by pursuing ventures outside the realm of traditional advertising tasks.

title: Man With $20 Billion to Disburse Finds No Shortage of Claims or Critics
description: From the numbers alone, you might think Kenneth R. Feinberg would be a popular guy.

title: Deutsche Banks $4 Billion Las Vegas Bet
A Better Way to Teach Math
description: Is it possible to eliminate the bell curve in math class?

title: In a Changing Cuba, Many Remain Skeptical
description: HAVANA  For months, Cubans have been treated to an uncharacteristically blunt assessment of their future by none other than their president, Ral Castro.

title: NASA Awards $269 Million for Private Projects
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced Monday that it was distributing $269 million to four companies to develop spacecraft to take its astronauts to orbit in the future.

title: Lawyers for Officers in Rape Trial Try to Stir Doubt Over Details
description: What is the difference between a shaved head and a bald head? Is a social smoker a smoker? What did two police officers say to each other at the foot of the bed?

title: Making Mugabe Laugh
description: BARELY was Laurent Gbagbo, wearing a sweat-damp white tank top and a startled expression, prodded at rebel gunpoint from the bombed ruins of his presidential bunker in Ivory Coast, than Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton announced this conclusion: His ejection, more than four months after he refused to accept electoral defeat, sent a strong signal to dictators and tyrants throughout the region and around the world. They may not disregard the voice of their own people in free and fair elections, and there will be consequences for those who cling to power.

title: Arsenals Agony: 11 Extra Minutes, but Not Much Time Left
description: The climax of Arsenals game against Liverpool Sunday at the Emirates Stadium was anything but boring.

title: Talks on U.S. Presence in Afghanistan After Pullout Unnerve Region
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  First, American officials were talking about July 2011 as the date to begin the withdrawal from Afghanistan. Then, the Americans and their NATO allies began to talk about transition, gradually handing over control of the war to the Afghans until finally pulling out in 2014. Now, however, the talk is all about what happens after 2014.

title: The Court and Global Warming
description: The case about global warming scheduled to be argued on Tuesday before the Supreme Court is a blockbuster. Eight states  from California to New York, plus New York City  sued six corporations responsible for one-fourth of the American electric power industrys emissions of carbon dioxide.

title: Interview With Space Station Astronauts
description: Kenneth Chang of The New York Times interviewed the astronauts aboard the International Space Station on April 12, 2011.

title: William Schaefer, Baltimore Mayor, Dies at 89
description: William Donald Schaefer, a political showman who captivated voters and infuriated critics for more than three decades as the mayor who rejuvenated decaying Baltimore and then as Marylands governor and comptroller, died on Monday at a retirement home in Catonsville, Md. He was 89.

title: Celtics Jermaine ONeal Perseveres Through Injuries
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  Jermaine ONeal and Donnie Walsh noticed each other, but did not speak before Game 1 of the Knicks-Celtics playoff series. The pair share a mutual respect and an unfulfilled past.

title: Ticketmaster Plans to Use a Variable Pricing Policy
description: Buying concert tickets may soon be more like booking an airline flight: what you pay could be determined by when you order.

title: A Myspace Founder Builds Again, Buying Game Companies
description: Monica Almeida/The New York TimesChristopher T. DeWolfe, a co-founder of Myspace, has a new company, MindJolt.

title: Vegan Promoter Uses Photos of Meat and Dairy Items, and Fury Follows
description: VegNews, a vegetarian lifestyle magazine and Web site based in San Francisco, is eating a little crow.

title: If N.B.A. Is Wise, Thrills Will Stay Nonstop
description: Boston

title: Icelands Way
description: In the go-go years leading up to the financial crisis, Icelands banks were hugely irresponsible, luring foreign depositors with high interest rates and putting the money into risky loans. When Icelands big banks went under in 2008, they were 10 times as big as the countrys economy.

title: Playoffs Bright Lights Vexing for Heat Star Prone to Migraines
description: MIAMI  American Airlines Arena is dressed for spring, with each seatback draped in white and each fan attending a Heat home playoff game encouraged to wear a white T-shirt. The effect on Monday was stepping out of 80-degree heat and, visually speaking, into an igloo.

title: Real Prisoners, Phantom Residents
description: The New York State Legislature took a stand for electoral fairness last year when it banned prison-based gerrymandering, the cynical practice of counting prison inmates as residents to pad the population of legislative districts. The new law required that inmates be counted as residents of their home districts.

title: What Stories These Lice Can Tell
description: Were there many bird and mammal species while dinosaurs still lived? Or did they diversify only after dinosaurs were wiped out some 65 million years ago? The fossil record hasnt been much help answering this fundamental question. But a study published recently in the Royal Societys Biology Letters may have found an answer based on a different kind of fossil: fossilized lice.

title: Goldman Spins Away From Success
description: We didnt have a massive short against the housing market, Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, insisted at a Congressional hearing last year.

title: The Heartbreak of Technicalities
description: It should have been one of road racings finest hours  the fastest marathon ever run. In Boston, no less, the cradle of 26.2-mile glory.

title: Many Hit by Spill Now Feel Caught in Claim Process
description: BAYOU LA BATRE, Ala.  By October, Tim Nguyen found that his work in a Mississippi shipyard was no longer paying the bills. His hours had been cut back, part of the general ebb of work along the Gulf Coast after the terrible summer of BP.

title: An Oyster on the Seder Plate?
description: LAST night I put an oyster on my Seder plate.

title: The Battle of Baltimore
description: Baltimore had vexed Abraham Lincoln for months. The city was the secessionist heart of slaveholding, nativist Maryland, a state in which the new president had run fourth in the 1860 election, garnering fewer than 3,000 votes. Marylands population was one-quarter African-American, evenly divided between slaves and free blacks. And yet Lincoln desperately needed the state: without it in the Union, Washington would be completely within foreign  and, after April 12, enemy  territory.

title: Galleon Chief Is Silent as Defense Rests Its Case
description: Louis Lanzano/Bloomberg NewsRaj Rajaratnam and his lawyer, Terence Lynam, leaving court on Monday.

title: Pietro Ferrero, Food Company Scion, Dies at 47
description: MILAN  Pietro Ferrero, who with his brother ran Ferrero, the family-owned producer of Nutella, Tic Tacs, Ferrero Rocher and other sweets sold worldwide, died on Monday while riding a bicycle in South Africa. He was 47.

title: Bijan Pakzad, Designer of High Fashion, Dies at 71
description: Bijan Pakzad, the ritzy fashion designer whose by-appointment-only Rodeo Drive boutique is billed as the most expensive store in the world, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 71.

title: Unity in the Aftermath of Destruction
description: Residents in several southern U.S. states began the process of cleaning up the wreckage after a storm system cut a wide swath of destruction through the area over the weekend.

title: Luck Spares Some From Deadly Tornado Swarm
description: ASKEWVILLE, N.C.  For all the deaths and broken bones and flattened houses, there were still some miracles packed into the 10 minutes it took for the last of a great roar of tornadoes to chew through this rural corner of the state.

title: Nick Biddle and the First Defenders
description: On the afternoon of April 19, 1861, Nick Biddle was quietly helping his unit, the Washington Artillery from Pottsville, Pa., set up camp inside the north wing of the Capitol building. The day before, he was almost killed.

title: Tuesday: Twiddle Ones Thumbs
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Boy howdy, there are a bunch of Bs in this grid. Bs in the theme entries, Bs in most of the non-theme entries. Thirty-five of them, to be precise.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Private School Admissions, a Firm Creates Fans and Skeptics
description: For one Manhattan mother, finding the right private kindergarten for her daughter was a breeze. Getting in, she believed, would be a different story.

title: At a Mob Trial, Testimony Focuses on the Knife and Fork
description: It is no surprise that prodigious helpings of murder, betrayal and honor  or, some might say, the lack thereof  have been on the menu, figuratively speaking, at a mob trial in federal court in Brooklyn. The trial, after all, marks the witness-stand debut of the first official boss of one of New Yorks five Mafia families to testify for the government.

title: In This Fairy Tale, Not One, but Two Queens in Waiting
description: LONDON  When 1,900 invited guests take their coveted places in Westminster Abbey next week for the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, one of the most uneasy seats in the 13th-century Gothic church may be the one occupied by Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, the longtime lover of Prince Charles, and since her marriage to the heir to the throne in 2005, the stepmother to William, Charless older son.

title: Lottery Numbers
Ticket-Fixing Inquiry Puts a Light on Union Delegates
description: When a police officer has a complaint or a question, the first person to hear about it is often a police union delegate. Part fixer and part representative, the delegate is always on call to take complaints about a commander not paying overtime, or from an officer unhappy about a transfer to a midnight tour.

title: As Mets Falter, Everyone Can Sit in the Cheap Seats
description: For the third season in a row, the Mets are not looking like a good team. A miserable 2010 was followed by a winter of frugality that has not inspired a lot of ticket purchasers, which is bad for the embattled owners of the team.

title: Plant Owner Sues Vermont Over License for Reactor
description: The owners of the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant filed a federal lawsuit against state officials on Monday challenging the constitutionality of a state law giving the Vermont legislature veto power over operation of the reactor when its current license expires next March.

title: At 41, Star Closer Hasnt Lost His Edge
description: Eric Chavezs eighth-inning, run-scoring single Sunday night did not end the Yankees victory over the Texas Rangers, but it might as well have. Once the Yankees had the lead and the inning was over, the next step for Manager Joe Girardi was to summon from the bullpen the most foregone conclusion in baseball.

title: Even on Religious Campuses, Students Fight for Gay Identity
description: WACO, Tex.  Battles for acceptance by gay and lesbian students have erupted in the places that expect it the least: the scores of Bible colleges and evangelical Christian universities that, in their founding beliefs, see homosexuality as a sin.

title: ESPN Posts Announcers Deals Online
description: Five days after announcing new endorsement guidelines for its on-air announcers, ESPN posted all of its announcers deals online Monday.

title: Mob Boss Testifies Gotti Plotted to Kill Him
description: John J. Gotti plotted with the No. 2 figure in the Bonanno crime family to assassinate Joseph C. Massino, the former Bonanno boss, Mr. Massino testified on Monday.

title: Justices Decline to Hear Appeal From Chinese Detainees
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court said Monday that it would not hear an appeal from five Chinese Muslims detained at Guantnamo Bay who seek to be released into the United States. There were no noted dissents, but Justice Stephen G. Breyer, joined by three other justices, issued a statement explaining their reasoning.

title: Deadly Twisters Renew Questions About Pressure on Emergency Budgets
description: ATLANTA  Emergency management officials in Southern states said recent budget cutting did not limit their ability to respond to the scores of tornadoes that touched down in six states on Friday and Saturday, leaving at least 44 people dead, injuring hundreds and causing devastating damage to houses, businesses and farmland.

title: At One Post Office, Tax Day Is a Reason to Dance and Sing
description: LAWRENCE, Kan.  As celebrations go, it is a peculiar one.

title: Migrant Workers Evacuated From Libya
description: More than 900 foreigners were evacuated by sea on Sunday from the besieged city of Misurata.

title: Experts Busy Assessing Ferocity of Storms
description: Amid the stunned residents, bleary-eyed insurance adjusters and solicitous relief officials who traipsed through storm-damaged homes and businesses Monday was a small cadre of meteorologists tasked with figuring out just how many tornadoes touched down and how powerful they were.

title: Mets Push Back Bays Return to Thursday
description: After consulting with Jason Bay at Citi Field on Monday, the Mets decided to give the injured outfielder a couple of more days to recuperate from his strained ribcage muscle in Florida, but they expect him in the lineup on Thursday for the first time since July 25.

title: Evelyn Einstein Dies at 70; Shaped by a Link to Fame
description: Evelyn Einstein, whose tumultuous life as the granddaughter of Albert Einstein was both defined and limited by her distinguished lineage, died on Wednesday at her home in Albany, Calif. She was 70.

title: Migrant Workers Evacuated From Libya
description: More than 900 foreigners were evacuated by sea on Sunday from the besieged city of Misurata.

title: Arizona Governor Rejects Bid to Loosen Gun Rules
description: PHOENIX  Gov. Jan Brewer vetoed two controversial bills on Monday that would have allowed guns on university campuses and required presidential candidates to provide additional proof about their citizenship status.

title: Administration Defends Effort on Debt After Credit Warning
description: Stocks on Wall Street rose on Tuesday as investors focused on corporate earnings and the economy, moving on from the negative credit rating outlook given to the United States the previous day.

title: Guidelines Allow Earlier Definition of Alzheimers
description: For the first time in 27 years, the definition of Alzheimers disease is being recast in new medical guidelines that reflect fast-mounting evidence that it begins ravaging the brain years before the symptoms of dementia.
