description: 11:31 a.m. | Updated

title: Nissan Executive Delivers Keynote at New York Auto Show
description: Nissan, the automaker hit hardest by last months massive earthquake and tsunami in Japan, is rapidly recovering from damage to its plants, said Carlos Tavares, the automakers executive vice president, on Wednesday in a keynote address opening the New York auto show. But changes are coming in how, where and when Nissan produces its cars.

title: Coming to Your Kindle: Library Books
description: Reading e-books from the library is easy  unless you own a Kindle.

title: Closing the Galleon Case
description: The trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire co-founder of hedge fund Galleon Group, enters its final phase. The jury will soon begin deliberating, in one of the largest insider trading cases ever.

title: Gay Marriage Opponents Now in Minority
description: A poll from CNN this week is the latest to show a majority of Americans in favor of same-sex marriage, with 51 percent saying that marriages between gay and lesbian couples should be recognized by the law as valid and 47 percent opposed.

title: Arab League Again Delays Baghdad Summit Meeting
description: BAGHDAD  The Arab League delayed its annual summit meeting yet again on Wednesday, a decision that was not unexpected given the turmoil sweeping the region but was nonetheless certain to disappoint the Iraqi government.

title: The 2012 Honda Civic lineup
description: The 2012 Honda Civic lineup

title: The Right Angles
description: Rafael de Crdenas might be the hippest thing going in interior design, and theres certainly nothing square about his first collection of furniture, on display starting May 13 at Johnson Trading Gallery in New York. His angular benches, cabinets and tables (above) were inspired by the architects Frank Lloyd Wright and Bruce Goff. De Crdenas says the cabinets in particular turn the concept of creature comfort on its ear: I see them as anthropomorphic features  friendly beasts.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Choices Must Be Made
description: Arguably the most important thing we can do to limit the growth in health care costs is learning to say no; we cannot afford a system in which Medicare in particular will pay for anything, especially when thats combined with an industry structure that gives providers a strong financial incentive to engage in excessive care.

title: Transcripts of Raj Rajaratnams Wiretapped Calls
description: The secretly recorded phone calls between Raj Rajaratnam and his friends and co-workers form the heart of the governments insider trading case against the head of the Galleon Group. In closing arguments, Reed Brodsky, a prosecutor, highlighted what he called the most powerful evidence of defendants guilt  his own voice.

title: Making Screen-Free Week Permanent?
description: Last months National Day of Unplugging did not, as you might recall, go all that well for me. (Small update: I got the go ahead to bear some weight on the left ankle earlier this week, and yesterday I started what should be six weeks of physical therapy)

title: News.Me, Social News Service, Debuts for iPad
description: News.me, the long-awaited social news service developed in collaboration with Betaworks, a technology incubator, and The New York Times Company, is ready for its debut.

title: Covering (and Working for) Bloomberg
description: Henry Goldman writes his articles on a Bloomberg terminal. His paychecks are stamped Bloomberg L.P. His company ID badge: Bloomberg. And the subject of his stories? Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Tsunami Warnings, Written in Stone
description: ANEYOSHI, Japan  The stone tablet has stood on this forested hillside since before they were born, but the villagers have faithfully obeyed the stark warning carved on its weathered face: Do not build your homes below this point!

title: 2012 Nissan Versa
description: 2012 Nissan Versa

title: An N.F.L. Schedule With a Catch
description: The N.F.L. would like to welcome you to the parallel bizarre universe in which it locks out its players and endangers a season in its mad scramble to milk more money out of the sport for its overspending billionaires and yet announces the season schedule Tuesday with the fanfare of the Academy Award nominations.

title: Closing the Galleon Case
description: Closing arguments have begun in the insider trading case against Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire co-founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund. DealBook spoke to some former prosecutors who have been watching the case, and their consensus is that the weight of evidence does not bode well for the defendant.

title: Post Office
description: WHISKEY bars in Brooklyn tend to try too hard. See the stripper pole at Brooklyn Whiskey, the flower shop at Sycamore and Char No. 4s list of 250 whiskies. In this light, Post Office in South Williamsburg is relatively pretension free. Opened in February, the bar lacks embellishments, evoking the calm, reflective environment of a neighborhood wine bar (even if its name is from a Charles Bukowski novel).

title: A Crime Lurks on the Dark Side of a Clairvoyant Realm
description: Stephen Schwartz, the musical-theater composer and lyricist, could hardly be more successful. His credits include Godspell, Pippin and the long-running Wicked, which has been playing on Broadway since 2003. There was no reason for him to write an opera. He had nothing to prove. So Sance on a Wet Afternoon, his first work in the genre, which had its premiere in 2009 at Opera Santa Barbara, was a labor of love.

title: Back in Black, and Brown and Blue
description: The Coach Duffle bag, which was designed in the 1970s by Bonnie Cashin, is just the sort of no-logo, no-hardware, no-nonsense bag that no one is making anymore. Not even Coach, which saw fit to put this workhorse out to pasture in 1997. But starting June 15, Net-a-Porter is bringing back the Duffle, as well as four other seminal styles from that era, as the Coach Classics collection. Fans of the original will notice only one minor adjustment: an ad for Neiman Marcus in The Dallas Morning News from the 70s listed the Duffle for $36. This summer it will set you back $398.

title: Everything Returns to Carbon
description: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

title: A Passion Play Endures as a Seasonal Miracle
description: WAUCHULA, Fla.  With less than two hours until showtime, a man sits amid the backstage chaos and studies his image in a propped-up mirror. The eyes are grayish blue, the goatee trim, the long dark hair flecked with gray. Not there yet. He scoops another dab of makeup to continue the annual transformation of Mike Graham, now 58, into Jesus Christ, forever 33.

title: A Passion for Playing Jesus
description: Pastor Mike Graham of Florida has been performing the role of Jesus for more than two decades. His passion play involves more than two hundred participants and one hundred animals.

title: St. Patricks Cathedral, 9:19 A.M.
Homes for $170,000
description: A Craftsman-style house in Birmingham, Ala.; a silo-like house in the Catskills; and a loft in Minneapolis.

title: What You Get for ... $170,000
description: BIRMINGHAM, ALA.

title: Media Decoder: Library Books on the Kindle
description: On Media Decoder, Julie Bosman reports that Amazon is changing its policy on library books and the Kindle, creating a new feature that would allow Kindle customers to borrow e-books from more than 11,000 libraries across the country.

title: A New Incentive to Travel Solo
description: Solo travelers going on expeditions often must pay additional fees that can significantly increase the cost of a trip. But the luxury travel company Abercrombie & Kent has a new solo-savings initiative that reduces, and in some cases waives, extra expenses for those hitting the road on their own.

title: Are You Ready for the Presidential Primaries?
description: David Brooks: Gail, every few years around this time I get Iowa fever. I get excited at the prospect of going out to Davenport or Pocahontas and riding in the backseat of a van with some second- or third-tier politicians as they shuttle between coffee shops, doughnut shops and community centers trying to get elected president.

description: The most striking thing about the work of Madame Grs is how early her philosophy was set in stone.

title: Golds Price Surge May Mean Your Jewelry Is Under-Insured
description: Gold prices have skyrocketed over the last decade, which means your jewelry may be under-insured if you havent had it appraised recently.

title: Danish Dynamite | Henrik Vibskov
description: What are some of Henrik Vibskovs favorite pieces in his new store? I love the socks and hats  thats at least my personal style, he says. I always wear a hat, and every guy should have a nice pair of socks. The 38-year-old designer, who referred to himself in an interview as Danish dynamite, just opened an eponymous boutique last Friday on Broome Street in New York, and its filled with plenty of eccentric-looking socks and hats from his line and other indie-Euro imports (Cosmic Wonder, Stine Goya, Ally Capellino and Peter Jensen, to name a few).

title: Concerns Over iPhone Tracking Data
description: British newspaper The Guardian reported today that Apples iPhone stores user-location information and then syncs that data to a file on your PC. Weve requested a comment from Apple and will update accordingly.

title: Bacterial Ecosystems Divide People Into 3 Groups, Scientists Say
description: In the early 1900s, scientists discovered that each person belonged to one of four blood types. Now they have discovered a new way to classify humanity: by bacteria. Each human being is host to thousands of different species of microbes. Yet a group of scientists now report just three distinct ecosystems in the guts of people they have studied.

title: A Treat for Promptness, and Produce at City Hall
description: On account of their good behavior, members of the State Legislature are about to receive a treat: a longer spring break.

title: Wetlands? What Wetlands?
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has become, for some of libertarian or Tea Party convictions, something of an embodiment of government run amok. Environmentalists see the agency, at its best, as the defender of peoples health and the environments welfare.

title: Obama Marks Anniversary of BP Disaster
description: One year ago today, the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig exploded in the Gulf of Mexico because of a runaway oil well. The accident killed 11 rig workers and spilled nearly five million barrels of oil into the gulf, the biggest maritime oil spill in United States history.

description: Jeep Grand Cherokee SRT-8

title: A History of Poor Standards
description: Dean Baker is, rightly, annoyed at the WaPo for engaging in a practice Ive decried often: taking any uptick in interest rates, often one that is probably the result of economic optimism, and reporting as a settled fact that it reflects debt fears.

description: Megan Liberman and Jennifer Preston discuss the role of Facebook and other social media in the early stages of the 2012 Presidential election.

title: Hes Handsome  You Noticed?  but Not Just
description: Any discerning reader who gets as far in Rob Lowes memoir as the photo on the front cover will notice that Mr. Lowe is good looking. Very good looking. So good looking that its almost a liability, and that his memoir, Stories I Only Tell My Friends, has to take his appearance into account. He had to decide how to handle this, his boo-hoo problem, in a book.

title: High, With Kathleen Turner, Will Close on Sunday
description: The crowded latter half of the Broadway season has its first high-profile closure: Matthew Lombardos play High, starring Kathleen Turner as a nun whose faith is tested while working with a young drug addict, will close on Sunday, press representatives for the show said on Wednesday.

title: Restrepo Director and a Photographer Are Killed in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Tim Hetherington, a conflict photographer who was a director and producer of the Afghan war documentary Restrepo, was killed in the besieged city of Misurata, Libya, on Wednesday, and three photographers working beside him were wounded, one fatally, when they came under fire at the citys front lines.

title: Scenes From a Sance
description: The composer Stephen Schwartz narrates a look at his opera "Sance on a Wet Afternoon," at New York City Opera.

description: THE day after returning from the Paris shows last month, Jade Lai had some pressing business. Her spacious new boutique in NoLIta, Creatures of Comfort, was having its first storewide sale. And she was working the register.

title: Lighter Winds Help in Battle Against Texas Wildfires
description: Firefighters from 34 states received some help from the weather on Wednesday as lighter winds helped slow the spread of the wildfires burning across Texas, but the respite was not expected to last.

title: Restrepo Director Is Killed in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Tim Hetherington, the Oscar-nominated film director and conflict photographer who, along with with Sebastian Junger, produced the film Restrepo, was killed in the besieged city of Misurata on Wednesday. Three photographers working beside him were wounded, one fatally. Read more from The Timess correspondent in Libya, C.J. Chivers.

title: Those Elusive Bond Vigilantes
description: For some reason, I have been thinking that the WSJ first warned about the return of the bond vigilantes in May 2009. But noooo [/end Belushi]: it was May 2008. A year later, the WSJ repeated the claim. And a year after that, it repeated it again.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic: In Search of Fine Dining and Harbor Views
description: The digital carrier pigeon brought questions from married people this week, and from dutiful children and copy editors in search of a reunion meal. I did my best to answer them. You may of course send along your own questions about dining out in and around New York City to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: A Bid to Recapture the Sleight of Hand
description: IN the end, it was the T-shirt that undid Agns B., probably. You know the one. Basic white, with the companys cursive logo in the middle  simple enough to become a visual clich, a faux-sophisticate brand reduced to a cheap graphic. It was the type of shirt you might see worn by the anonymous floor sweepers at any high-end salon, hoping to one day get a crack at the balayage brush.

title: Elsewhere: Frightseeing, Palidays and Set-Jetting
description: A recent article for The Independent Online detailed a number of travel-related buzzwords, including:

title: Old-School Interactive Books
description: Once upon a pre-e time, the term interactive book had an entirely different, unplugged meaning. Dating back at least to the publication of Pat the Bunny in 1940, interactive books were ones that encouraged children to open flaps and feel their pages. Read aloud, they elicited call-and-response shouts and audience elaboration. They demanded to be something more than just read.

title: Finding a Lifes Story in Objects
description: LAMOUR Fou, a new documentary about the venerated (and already well-documented) fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent, opens with a scene at a press conference in 2002 when he announced his retirement, which is followed by a scene of his funeral in 2008. Then the camera moves to Saint Laurents fabulous apartment on the Rue de Babylone, where all of his possessions are being packed up and prepared for auction.

title: A Do-It-Yourself Rental in Hollywood
description: THE lead paint from the beams on her apartments ceiling sheds gently and constantly, which is why Cynthia Loebe likes to say that when she sleeps with her mouth open, shes always tasting history.

title: Remaking a Studio Apartment at the Villa Carlotta
description: A renter with a talent for D.I.Y. projects aggressively redecorated her studio in an old Hollywood building.

title: Matter Over Mind
description: Over the next few weeks, this blog may have a distinct Harvard bias. This is not only because I am kissing up to the alpha school, but recently I had a fantastic visit to the Harvard Decision Science Lab, run by Jennifer Lerner, and I got to meet several of the researchers there.

title: Real-Life Lessons in the Delicate Art of Setting Prices
description: Setting prices can be tricky for a small business. If prices are too high, it is usually obvious, and there is an easy solution. But if they are too low, things can get complicated. That is because many business owners find it difficult to raise prices  even if they know they are losing money on every sale.

title: Shopping Snapshots for April 21
description: A look for those unafraid to wear fluorescent green or acid yellow; a company that makes bondage accessories goes mainstream; and other items.

title: Why Is It So Hard to Raise Prices?
description: As todays small-business guide to pricing makes clear, a lot of small-business owners are reluctant to raise prices  sometimes even when they are losing money on every sale. Naomi Poe, who founded Better Batter Gluten Free Flour, initially priced her product to compete with nongluten-free competitors even though her costs were higher than theirs. Eventually, she decided to increase her prices and found her customers were encouraging.

title: Despite Lower Sales, Musicians Earn New Highs
description: For the most part declining album sales are bad news for the music industry. But theres one way in which they can benefit musicians: with everybody selling fewer records, it can be easier for an artist to climb higher than ever on the charts.

title: Airport Screeners Need Runoff to Pick a Union
description: In the largest unionization vote involving federal employees, the nations airport screeners voted in favor of unionizing, but federal officials said on Wednesday that there would be a runoff because neither union on the ballot received a majority of the votes cast.

title: Move Over, State Fish, to Make Room for a State Dog
description: New York State has an official animal (the beaver), an insect (the ladybug), a fish (the brook trout) and even a shell (the bay scallop). Why not a dog?

title: 3G Apple iOS Devices Are Storing Users Location Data
description: A hidden file on the Apple iPhone 4 and iPad 3G has been found to store location information.

title: Chris Hondros, at Work in Libya
description: Chris Hondros of Getty Images died in Misurata, Libya, on Wednesday after an attack that killed Tim Hetherington and injured Guy Martin and Michael Christopher Brown. These pictures, taken earlier in the day, show why Mr. Hondros earned the respect of his colleagues for combat images that were gripping and intimate, but not at all melodramatic or forced. Mr. Hondros spoke with Lens in February about the dangers of conflict photography, after he was assaulted while covering the uprising in Egypt.

title: A Bright Spring Trend Puts Tails Amid the Tresses
description: THE first time Stacey Gersten had feathers put in her hair  while vacationing in Austin, Tex., at the same kind of street-side stand from which you might buy homemade brownies  she panicked. I thought they were so beautiful, said Ms. Gersten, 27, a casting director who lives in New York. Then I thought, What am I going to do when they fall out?

title: Dr. Dre Wins Chronic Lawsuit
description: Dr. Dre has won a lawsuit against the owners of his former record label, Death Row, over the digital rights and royalties for his hit 1992 album The Chronic.

title: Could the California Aqueduct Turn Into a Solar Farm?
description: In Wednesdays Times, I wrote about start-up companies developing solar panel arrays that float on water. The companies see a potentially large market to generate electricity from building floating arrays for irrigation and mining ponds, hydroelectric reservoirs and canals.

title: Obamas to Attend Shuttle Launch
description: 3:22 p.m. | Updated  President Obama and his family will attend the final launch on April 29 of the space shuttle Endeavour, and perhaps join Representative Gabrielle Giffords if she is able to watch as her astronaut-husband, Mark E. Kelly, leads the mission into space, administration officials confirmed on Wednesday.

title: Ford Designer J Mays Shares First Impressions of Beetle
description: J Mays, Fords vice president of global design, chatted with the Wheels contributor Phil Patton on Monday night about the redesigned Volkswagen Beetle. Mr. Mays opinion is particularly notable, as the Oklahoma native designed (along with fellow Ford designer Freeman Thomas) the Volkswagen Concept One  that car that became the New Beetle  in the early 90s while working at VWs advanced design studios in Southern California.

title: New Swiss Tax Rules Signal Big Changes for Private Banks
description: The Swiss have proposed new banking rules in an attempt to improve relations with their neighbors by making it harder for other Europeans to hide money from the tax collector back home.

title: Transparent Photovoltaic Cells Turn Windows Into Solar Panels
description: A new class of transparent photovoltaic cells has been developed that can turn an ordinary windowpane into a solar panel without impeding the passage of visible light, scientists said Tuesday.

title: Documentary Celebrates Olmsted, a Creator of Central Park
description: Olmsted and Americas Urban Parks, a documentary by Rebecca Messner about Frederick Law Olmsted, the creator of Central Park and Prospect Park, is being broadcast Wednesday on PBS. (In New York, WNET-TV will carry it at 10 p.m.) In his review, Neil Genzingler says the film helps you appreciate just how visionary Olmsted and his undercredited partner in Central Park and other projects, Calvert Vaux, were at a time when the idea that cities need parks was not firmly established.

title: TimesCast | April 20, 2011
description: Italy's long relationship with Libya complicates its role in NATO's mission; Japan's history with tsunamis is documented in stone; and the "Restrepo" director Tim Hetherington is killed in Libya.

title: Still Time to Buy The Clock for the Right Price
description: People waited for hours in frigid temperatures to see it; now museums are jockeying to buy it. It is Christian Marclays video artwork The Clock, which features 24 hours of film and television clips woven together to reference, often with a shot of a watch or a clock face, a fictional moment in time that corresponds to the actual minute of the day in which the viewer is watching the work.

title: War in Libya Could Drag On, Military Analysts Say
description: PARIS  France and Italy said Wednesday that they would join Britain in sending liaison officers to support the rebel army in Libya, in what military analysts said was a sign that there would be no quick and easy end to the war in Libya.

title: Beauty Spots
description: Earth Day is Friday, and the theme this year is Billion Acts of Green. A few ideas from the beauty industry:

title: College-Bound and Living With Autism
description: Several readers of the Consults blog recently had questions about the long-term course of autism, including succeeding in college and beyond. Our experts Dr. Fred Volkmar of the Yale Child Study Center and Dr. Lisa Wiesner, co-authors of A Practical Guide to Autism,  respond. For more on this and other topics, see their earlier responses in Ask the Experts About Autism, and The Times Health Guide: Autism. The authors also teach a free online course on autism at Yale University, which is also available at iTunesU and on YouTube.

title: A New School Professor in Search of a Class
description: Fabio Parasecoli stood on the edge of Union Square Park Wednesday morning, a sheaf of printed notes in his hand. Associates held up signs and tried to recruit anyone who would listen.

title: Museums Are Finding Room for Couturiers
description: ON a damp evening in late March, at the opening night of the Balenciaga and Spain exhibition at the de Young Museum in San Francisco, Dede Wilsey, the philanthropist and president of the museums board, was standing by the front door wearing a white satin and black lace dress by Oscar de la Renta. (The show, which began at the Queen Sofia Spanish Institute in New York, was conceived by Mr. de la Renta.) Mrs. Wilsey has given millions of dollars to help rebuild the de Young, and the diamond drop earrings and matching necklace that cascaded into her bodice seemed to make it clear that this had not been a hardship.

title: After Two Decades, Savoy to Close
description: Savoy, a restaurant mainstay of the SoHo neighborhood for more than 20 years, will close on Saturday, June 18. Peter Hoffman, the chef and an owner, gave the news to the restaurants employees in a meeting on Wednesday afternoon. The space will remain shuttered for the bulk of the summer, he said, then reopen in the fall with a new concept and a new name, as yet undecided.

title: When Prabal Met Maggie
description: Theres no disputing the socialite bona fides of Maggie Betts, the daughter of the film producer and Chelsea Piers developer Roland Betts and a fixture of Gothams party scene. But Betts, a 36-year-old Princeton graduate, is also a passionate advocate for AIDS awareness in Africa who has spent long periods on the continent bearing witness to the epidemic. Her first film, The Carrier, which premieres Thursday as part of the Tribeca Film Festival, is the culmination of five years of research. The documentary tells the story of a Zambian woman, Mutinta Mweemba, who tries desperately not to pass on her HIV infectionto her unborn child. Here, Betts is interviewed by the designer Prabal Gurung, her good friend and the recently appointed Goodwill Ambassador for the nonprofit group Maiti Nepal.

title: A Party for, by and About Art
description: SMALL talk at parties is an art form all its own. But what to talk about if the party is for art?

title: Scene City: A Party for Bomb Magazine
description: Insiders mix and mingle to celebrate 30 years of Bomb magazine.

title: The Baby Next Door
description: Adding a newborn to your life changes everything. Your predictable schedule is upended. Your sleep is regularly interrupted. Your quiet home isnt anymore.

title: Audience Up, Idol Defies TV Gravity
description: LOS ANGELES  When the 10th season of American Idol  the first without Simon Cowell  started on Fox three months ago, the handicappers guessed that its ratings would decline 15 to 20 percent, irreversibly tarnishing the top show on television.

title: Apple Lifted by Verizon iPhone Deal and Updates of iPad and MacBook
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apples winning streak extended through another quarter as a new partnership with Verizon for the iPhone  along with updated products like the iPad and MacBook  sent consumers on a shopping spree, the company reported Wednesday.

title: Papa Doesnt Preach
description: Does Mario Cuomo have good ideas? I dont care how old he is. Bring on the smart, reasonable adults, no matter what their age. We have some math problems to solve here.

title: The Girl With Unexplained Hair Loss
description: An interesting discussion, but this type of article only feeds our obsession with esoteric and unusual conditions. Medical journals and popular TV shows are full of these types of examples. Theres a common saying: When you hear hoof beats, think horses, not zebras. Unfortunately, doctors and the lay public are automatically thinking zebras as a first reaction. Whats the worst-case scenario? What test can we order to rule out a tumor, growth or genetic mutation? Its a sad state of affairs when we cant even manage the most basic medical conditions properly, while glorifying rare and unusual conditions.

title: A Complex Jazzman, Informed by His Classical Side
description: Steve Lehman, a quietly dazzling saxophonist, is the stylistic progeny of at least two imposing modern-jazz masters, Anthony Braxton and Jackie McLean. In a string of potent albums he has shown a proclivity for intense improvisation, a taste for rhythmic entanglements with pianists and drummers, and a penchant for surrounding himself with like-minded performers. So the music Mr. Lehman makes must be jazz, right?

title: Twelve Polished Chapters Stacked Neatly on His Desk
description: This sort of nonreview review, written in a fittingly self-conscious style that kind of recalls David Foster Wallace is, I think, the best thing Ive read yet about The Pale King, and Ive read everything I can find. Kudos to Sam Anderson for exploring so thoroughly the challenges when reviewing an unfinished work.

title: The G.O.P. s Dukakis Problem
description: This essay manages to be snarky, insipid and stultifying all at once. The issue is not whether a politician is  in Jonathan Chaits erudite parlance  a dweeb. The issue is whether the politician maintains a view of American governance that enhances and protects people in this country and globally. My neighbor was a student of Mike Dukakis and notes that he was thoughtful, humane and diligent. If the media would better help voters assess the content of a political hopefuls message, the coolness of the politician might recede to its proper place.

title: Former One-Hit Wonder Shows His Staying Power
description: Clint Holmes is an entertainer determined to give the proverbial 150 percent. Or is it a thousand? You get the idea. To the uninitiated, he is an obscure one-hit wonder whose identifying song, Playground in My Mind, rose in 1973 to No. 2 on the charts, where he said it got stuck between Paul McCartneys My Love (No. 1) and Elton Johns Daniel (No. 3). But under the aegis of Steve Wynn, Mr. Holmes, now 64, has become a major Las Vegas attraction who might be described as the next generations Wayne Newton.

title: King of Front-Wheel Drive and Back-Seat Romps
description: Like Rob Lowe before he materialized on The West Wing more than a decade ago, Jason Priestley has seemed to be the kind of fine-vintage pretty boy who might be ripe for resurrection. His era was the 90s, when he reigned among the troubled affluent on Beverly Hills 90210. Since the 2000 conclusion of that series, in which he played the upright and pompadour-possessing Brandon Walsh, Mr. Priestley has made minor appearances on television  as a guest star on NBCs My Name Is Earl, as a principal on the short-lived ABC series Scoundrels and Lifetimes Side Order of Life  but he has been given nothing comparable to the vehicle he now has in the comedy Call Me Fitz.

title: Reformed School
description: How many of us would like to change places with Ramn Gonzlez? Very few, if any, I suspect. Yet, we keep blaming the teachers (and the administrators) for school failure. The real answer is student failure, not teacher failure, and most likely it is brought on by economics, parents and, mostly, peer pressure. Success begins at home.

title: Baseball Taking Control of Dodgers Operations
description: Commissioner Bud Selig said Wednesday that he would appoint someone within days to oversee all operations of the Los Angeles Dodgers because of his deep concerns about the state of the troubled marquee franchise, which is owned by Frank McCourt.

title: Goldman Sachs Promotes Its Chief of Staff
description: 7:23 p.m. | Updated

title: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu LTZ
description: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu LTZ

title: Colbert Reports From the Land and Sea of Audi
description: At its press conference Wednesday, Audi strayed far from heavy product news about the new Audi A7 in favor of schtick between Johan de Nysschen, the president and chief executive of Audi of America, and Stephen Colbert, the Comedy Central personality.

title: A Camera That Honors Old Virtues
description: What is a camera, anyway?

title: Juvenile Killers in Jail for Life Seek a Reprieve
description: CHARLESTON, Mo.  More than a decade ago, a 14-year-old boy killed his stepbrother in a scuffle that escalated from goofing around with a blowgun to an angry threat with a bow and arrow to the fatal thrust of a hunting knife.

title: On Location
description: Vita Gaismas two-story home near Riga, Latvia, is made of a dark pine that is painted metallic gray and glistens black in the sun.

title: 2012 Porsche Panamera
description: 2012 Porsche Panamera

title: Gerard Smith, Bassist for TV on the Radio, Dies
description: TV on the Radio has canceled a number of shows following the death of its bassist, Gerard Smith.

title: Shoemaking
description: Heritage brands enjoy a resurgence as more customers open their wallets for more value for their dollar.

title: At Their Feet, Crafted by Hand
description: Port Washington, Wis.

title: Disappointing Deal, Then a Surprise Ending
description: Many deals disappoint the purists because someone erred. The diagramed deal is no exception, but it does feature an unusual ending.

title: In Latvia, a Sleek House Breaks With Tradition
description: RIGA, Latvia  Vita Gaisma grew up in a nondescript Communist-era apartment in Latvia, a former Soviet republic, sharing its one bedroom with her younger brother while her parents slept on couches in the living room. She dreamed of having a space of her own one day.

title: Riding Chinas Growth to Deals Elsewhere
description: Guo Guangchang, one of the most prominent investors in China, is betting big on the fast-growing domestic market.

title: Floating Along on the Rhythm While Staying Anchored to the Beat
description: The guitarist Bill Frisell receives due credit for many things  his fluidity, his whimsy, his sly mastery of timbre and color  but probably not enough for his rhythm. Hes complicit in the underestimation, if we can call it that. Like a lot of introverts drawn to improvisation he creates a feeling of floating time, phrasing behind or around the beat. He doesnt come at you with a barrage. He doesnt make you think of a grid.

title: Labor Board Tells Boeing New Factory Breaks Law
description: In what may be the strongest signal yet of the new pro-labor orientation of the National Labor Relations Board under President Obama, the agency filed a complaint Wednesday seeking to force Boeing to bring an airplane production line back to its unionized facilities in Washington State instead of moving the work to a nonunion plant in South Carolina.

title: Yin, Meet Yang: Porsche Panamera Turbo S and S Hybrid
description: Shown on Wednesday: 2012 Porsche Panamera Turbo S and Panamera S Hybrid.

title: Vibrators Carry the Conversation
description: TOOTHPASTE? Check. Tampons? Check. Vibrator? Check!

title: Manchester United Tops Forbes List
description: For the seventh consecutive year, Manchester United is No. 1 on the Forbes list ranking the most valuable soccer teams, with a value of $1.86 billion.

title: Newly Released Books
description: This months crop of new books seems to confirm that April is the cruelest month. One woman sums up the path of aging as maiden, mother, crone. A girl eyes her mothers bras with a feeling of doom. Also on tap: adultery, murder, incest and spying on people you love.

title: Invitation to Israeli Leader Puts Obama on the Spot
description: WASHINGTON  A Republican invitation for Israels prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, to address Congress next month is highlighting the tensions between President Obama and Mr. Netanyahu and has kicked off a bizarre diplomatic race over who will be the first to lay out a new proposal to reopen the stalled Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

title: New York Auto Show
description: Jerry Garrett tours the auto show floor to examine if the auto industry's luxury represents real recovery or just a false start.

title: A Touch of Bold for the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu
description: Shown on Wednesday: 2013 Chevrolet Malibu.

title: Parnell to Go on Disabled List With Numbness in Finger
description: Bobby Parnell, a right-handed reliever for the Mets, was told by doctors Wednesday that he might have a blood clot in his right middle finger, an early diagnosis based on the numbness he has been experiencing.

title: A Jewel of a Spring Festival, Not Selling Out, but Still Sparkling
description: LUCERNE, Switzerland  The venerable Lucerne Festival, which originated in a 1938 concert conducted by Arturo Toscanini on the grounds of the villa in nearby Tribschen once occupied by Richard Wagner and his family, is nowadays fond of snappy themes. The festival this summer  opening on Aug. 10 and running six weeks with, as usual, the conductor Claudio Abbado and the composer Pierre Boulez as mainstays  is called Night, and you can probably fill in some of the repertory.

title: The Dress, the Ring, the In-Laws: Navigating the Royal Wedding
description: Rumor has it that a big wedding ceremony is approaching soon.

title: Stoudemire Is Expected to Play Friday; Billups Is Questionable
description: Medical tests revealed no new concerns for either Amare Stoudemire or Chauncey Billups on Wednesday, and their status for Game 3 of the Knicks first-round playoff series against the Boston Celtics remains largely unchanged.

title: TimesCast | A Complicated Role for Italy
description: April 20, 2011 - Italy's long relationship and alliance with Libya complicates its role in NATO's mission.

title: Illustrating Your Life in Graphs and Charts
description: About five years ago, Nicholas Felton had a cute idea: to create an annual report of his life filled with charts and graphs about the restaurants he had visited and the days he had traveled  just like the annual reports sent out by companies, but with personal details.

title: Shooting with the Fujifilm X100
description: A look at how the FujiFilm X100 performs.

title: Patients Are Not Consumers
description: I keep encountering discussions of health economics in which patients are referred to as consumers, after which the usual mantra of freedom of choice is invoked on behalf of voucherizing Medicare, or whatever.

title: Restrepo Director Is Killed in Libya
description: Tim Hetherington, a British photographer based in New York who was a director and producer of the film Restrepo, was killed in the besieged Libyan city of Misurata on Wednesday, our Times colleague C.J. Chivers reports. Three photographers were wounded in the same attack, and one of them, Chris Hondros of Getty Images, died.

title: Bachmann Says Its Time to Move Past Birther Debate
description: Representative Michele Bachmann said in a television interview that she believes the conspiracy theories and questions surrounding the validity of President Obamas birth certificate have been settled and declared that it was time to move onto real problems facing the country.

title: Niederauer Talks Strategy
description: Duncan Niederauer, chief executive of NYSE Euronext, discusses pending merger bids with rival exchanges, saying his exchanges strategy is best served by joining with Deutsche Brse.

title: Thrills, Chills, Roller Coasters? Bloomberg Will Pass
description: It was not Edvard Munchs Scream. It was not Michael Jacksons Scream. And it was not even Howard Deans infamous Iowa scream.

title: Parting Glance: Tim Hetherington
description: To call Tim Hetherington a great photographer would be a mistake. Thats not how he saw it.

title: TimesCast | Warnings Written in Stone
description: Stone tablets along the coast of Japan, some more than six centuries old, are inscribed with warnings about tsunamis.

title: Last of the German Big Blocks
description: Its hard to argue against Mercedes new 5.5-liter, bi-turbo V-8, the new engine of choice for Mercedes souped-up AMG division. With far more torque than its predecessor  a natural-breathing, 6.2-liter V-8  and up to 25 percent better fuel economy, the engine is helping AMG avoid gas-guzzler taxes that saddled Mercedes with the industrys nastiest fines for failing to meet federal mileage standards.

title: Boudreaus Accusations Dominate Pregame Talk
description: The main topic of conversation going into Game 4 of the Rangers-Capitals series at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night was the perceived targeting of the head of Mike Green, the Washington defenseman who missed the last 20 games of the regular season with a concussion.

title: How Healthy Are Our Fisheries?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Kitchen Sinks. Well, Part of It.
description: The Web developer Tim Thaler bought his home in Minneapolis five years ago. Hes hated it from Day 1.

title: Tribeca Q. & A.: Maggie Betts
description: The director Maggie Betts discusses "The Carrier," a documentary about an H.I.V.-positive Zambian woman trying to care for her child that will show at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Jaguar and Land Rover Bring Their Finest Hides and Horsepower to Javits
description: If a sucker is born every minute, it should take just under an hour to sell out the mere 50 copies of the Land Rover Range Rover Autobiography Ultimate Edition coming to America.

title: Q. and A. With Chad Spann, Underrated RB Prospect
description: Matt Waldman is the author of  The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis.

title: A Surge in Gold Nears a Limit
description: Worried about the euro zone? Buy gold. Worried about the federal deficit? Buy gold. Fancy a quick speculative bet? Well, you cant lose with gold or silver, which has almost tripled in price in just over six months. But precious metals cant be both havens and speculative plays.

title: Mason Rudolph, Consistent Contender on PGA Tour, Dies at 76
description: Mason Rudolph, a golfer who surged to prominence as a youthful amateur, became rookie of the year on the PGA circuit, then settled into a rock-solid 23-year PGA career, winning five tournaments and almost never missing the cut or hitting a ball out of bounds, died Monday in Tuscaloosa, Ala. He was 76.

title: Look at Me, Im Crying
description: Ive done it on the subway and at the Museum of Modern Art, in Prospect Park, Tompkins Square Park and leaning against the locked gate of Gramercy Park.

title: Coming a Long Way and Still Sounding Very Familiar
description: In the mid-1980s Big Audio Dynamite latched onto good ideas early. From its home in London, where its leader, Mick Jones, had been a punk-rock pioneer with the Clash in the 1970s, Big Audio Dynamite checked out club music from across the Atlantic: South Bronx hip-hop, Jamaican dub reggae, Detroit techno, Chicago house. It mingled drum machines and rock guitar, adding synthesizers and samples, with Mr. Jones singing and Don Letts sometimes rapping or toasting, Jamaican-style. Their fractured lyrics took up politics, music, multiculturalism and self-affirmation. If the term hipster had been tossed around the way it is now, Big Audio Dynamite would easily have qualified.

title: Details Emerge of an Orchestras Bankruptcy Plea
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra is blaming the high cost of rent at its home, the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, for at least some of its financial nightmare, along with the money-losing concerts of Peter Nero and the Philly Pops, high labor costs and withering donations.

title: National Latino Museum Plan Faces Fight
description: Seven years after opening its National Museum of the American Indian, and four years before the scheduled unveiling of its museum of African-American history, the Smithsonian Institution is being urged to create another ethnic museum on the National Mall, this one to recognize the history and contributions of Latino Americans.

title: Prisoner Pat-Downs
description: To the Editor:

title: College Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: After Crash, Sanitation Driver Faces D.U.I. Charge
description: The driver of a New York City Sanitation truck was arrested and charged with driving that truck while intoxicated early Tuesday evening, the police said.

title: For Threats of Terrorism, Two Words Will Warn
description: The governments five-color scheme for terrorism alerts has been reduced to two warnings: elevated and imminent.

title: Taliban Fan Fears of Infiltration in Afghan Forces
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the early afternoon of Nov. 29 at an outpost high in the mountains along the Pakistan border, an Afghan border policeman well thought of by his superiors suddenly opened fire on American soldiers, killing six.

title: Jerry Zaks on Directing 'Sister Act'
description: The director Jerry Zaks narrates a look at the musical number "Raise Your Voice" from the new musical "Sister Act," at the Broadway Theater.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,438 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Police Discover Bombs Mailed to Scottish Coach and 2 Fans
description: LONDON  The police in Glasgow have revealed that several parcel bombs were sent to the coach of the Celtic soccer team and two of its prominent supporters over six weeks.

title: Election Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: Youth, Mobility and Poverty Help Drive Cellphone-Only Status
description: WASHINGTON  Its not quite the stuff of bragging rights, but Arkansas and Mississippi find themselves at the top of a new state ranking: They have the highest concentrations of people in the nation who have abandoned landlines in favor of cellular phones.

title: Sentencing Juveniles
description: Number of juveniles serving life in prison without parole.

title: A Buoyant Milan: New Designs From the Furniture Fair
description: Highlights from the International Furniture Fair in Milan.

title: For Young Hopefuls, Milan Offers a Place to Break In
description: MILAN

title: Cautious Hope and Nostalgia at the Milan Furniture Fair
description: MILAN

title: Mubarak Leaves an Air of Wistfulness
description: CAIRO  Hosni Mubarak is the only leader most Egyptians have ever really known, so while he remains disliked for how he ran the country, there is an undercurrent of discomfort here with how he has been treated since being forced from power.

title: Rangers Fans Had Something to Prove
description: It was time to don the hard hats and the attitudes and go out and muck in the corners. And that was just the paying customers.

title: Virginia: Court Upholds Ruling for Ex-Sailor
description: A federal appeals court upheld a ruling overturning the conviction of Derek Tice, 41, one of the Norfolk Four, former sailors convicted of rape and murder, who received conditional pardons in 2009. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., affirmed a lower court ruling that Mr. Tices right to counsel had been violated. The ruling releases him from probation and from his status on a state sex-offender list, a spokesman for his lawyer said. The other three men were not part of the ruling.

title: European Unions Budget Proposal Stokes Anger
description: BRUSSELS  A call by the European Commission on Wednesday for a bigger budget for 2012 set off furious criticism from ministers and lawmakers, who said radical belt-tightening was needed to overcome the European Unions debt crisis.

title: Abbott Millers New Wallpaper Line, Inspired by an Ink Drop
description: All three patterns in Ink, a line of wallpaper by Abbott Miller, began with a drop of India ink on white paper. It was something of an act of rebellion for Mr. Miller, a partner at the graphic design firm Pentagram.

title: Sales on Tables, Rugs and Glassware
description: Floor samples of furniture made from reclaimed bowling lane wood are up to 50 percent off during the CounterEvolution Earth Day showroom sale, through April 24 (a Lilly End Table, originally $1,195, is $750; theKingpin Bar-N-Counter, regularly $3,995, is $2,495); 10 Jay Street (John Street), Suite 610, Brooklyn, (718) 243-2399 or counterev.com.

title: Sam Ostroff on Making Steel Sculptures for the Home
description: Sam Ostroff, a sculptor and designer of custom steel gates, doors and staircases, is a steadfast romantic who could not care less about trends. His seven-foot stainless steel doors and gates, with their playful, vaguely Art Nouveau swirls and scrolls, look like something one might see at the Pre Lachaise Mtro station in Paris, not in 21st-century America.

title: Working With Wood
description: To the Editor:

title: A Floating Coat Rack
description: Most coat stands sit on the floor, but the Pox coat rack by Laz Ojalde, a Miami product designer, hangs from the ceiling, so it looks like its floating.

title: Bouquets Delivered Regularly, No Reminders Needed
description: Last week, a friend turned us on to a newish flower delivery service, H. Bloom. Open about a year, and serving Manhattan, Jersey City, Hoboken and parts of Brooklyn, for now, as well as Washington, H. Bloom follows the fruit-of-the-month-club model, delivering fresh flowers on a weekly, biweekly or monthly schedule for a range of fees, starting at about $30 for a bunch of loose blooms.

title: Indian Point Memories
description: To the Editor:

title: Diller Scofidio & Renfro and Droog Team Up for a One-Day Event
description: New Yorkers are accustomed to having access to a wide range of personal services like food delivery and dog walking. On Saturday, the architecture firm Diller Scofidio & Renfro and the Dutch design group Droog are holding an event to explore creative ways of bringing more of such services to the suburbs, through home-based businesses.

title: Illustrations From Wicked Bugs
description: Briony Morrow-Cribbss drawings from the new book by Amy Stewart.

title: Dog Massage? Isnt Petting Enough?
description: RENEE LANES living room had been transformed into a spa. Candles twinkled on the coffee table; lavender oil scented the air; lilting guitar music played softly on the stereo. Grace, Ms. Lanes 2-year-old caramel-colored toy poodle, leaped onto the sofa and, in response to Ms. Lanes cooing invitation (Want to lay down for Mama?), got into position for her evening massage.

title: Treating Spot to a Deep-Tissue Massage
description: Some believe that pet massage has the same benefits as human massage: increased circulation, stress relief and comfort at the end of life.

title: Stink Bugs: It Could Be Worse
description: WHAT could be worse than stink bugs eating all your tomatoes this summer?

title: Missing in Action
description: By this time a year ago, Justice John Paul Stevens had announced his intention to retire from the Supreme Court. A year earlier, Justice David H. Souters retirement announcement was just days away. Those galvanizing mid-spring developments dominated thoughts about the future of the federal judiciary for two successive years.

title: Black Eyed Peas and Beetles, Together Onstage
description: Along with will.i.am, Fergie and the rest of the Black Eyed Peas, images of Volkswagens flashed across the stage on Monday night at a concert to promote the 21st-century update on the Beetle. But despite the vehicular backdrop and the two new Beetles that stood sentry at Terminal 5, the site of the concert, asking the Peas their thoughts on Beetles  the subject of the event  was apparently not allowed.

title: Knicks-Celtics a First-Rate Drama, With Second-Guesses
description: The Knicks first postseason adventure in seven years has produced powerful doses of exhilaration and anguish, surprises and second-guessing, a bit of artistry and more Jared Jeffries than anyone dared imagine.

title: In Spain, Women Find a Place in the Procession
description: Sevilles processions of hooded penitents have put the Andalusian capital at the center stage of Catholic celebrations. And this year, the oldest of its brotherhoods is allowing women to join in the march for the first time.

title: Prosecutors Cite Tapes of Galleon Chief as Devastating Proof of Guilt
description: Brendan Mcdermid/ReutersRaj Rajaratnam is accused of making $54 million from illicit trades.

title: Celtics Rivers Is Hoping for Better Play From Bench
description: BOSTON  After only two games, Celtics Coach Doc Rivers would need a couple of legal pads to compile a to-do list for his players as the playoff series with the Knicks shifts to New York. Near the top of any such list would be the play of his bench. It has been borderline bearable in the two games, which the Celtics won.

title: Slumping Gardner Gets the Night Off
description: TORONTO  When Brett Gardner was 23 and mired in a five-week slump to open the 2007 season at Class AA Trenton, drastic measures helped snap him out of it.

title: After Black Friday, American Poker Faces Cloudy Future
description: In 2003, ESPN significantly expanded its coverage of the World Series of Poker, which was eventually won by a 27-year-old Nashville accountant named Chris Moneymaker, an amateur who had qualified for the tournament on the Web site PokerStars.

title: Widow of Bus Crash Victim Receives Visa for Funeral
description: In the days after a bus traveling from a Connecticut casino crashed last month in the Bronx, the bodies of 14 victims were laid to rest. But the body of the 15th and final victim, Wang Jianhua, has lain in a funeral home in Chinatown while his widow, in China, has sought permission to come to the United States for his funeral.

title: Stumbling Into Bad Behavior
description: ITS easy to look at big names like Warren E. Buffett, and big companies like Ernst and Young, and be judgmental. Of course they overlooked ethical lapses. Why wouldnt they? Thats business.

title: Rebels Attack Loyalists in Misurata
description: Rebel forces assaulted the downtown positions of troops loyal to Muammar el-Qaddafi in Misurata, Libya.

title: N.F.L. Talks Are Stalled With Few Signs of Progress
description: After only four days of court-ordered talks, negotiations between N.F.L. owners and players came to a temporary halt Wednesday with little sign that much progress had been made toward resolving differences that have kept the league in a lockout since March 12.

title: Beyond the Oil Spill, the Tragedy of an Ailing Gulf
description: NEW ORLEANS  The anniversary has passed, the cleanup goes on, and still southern Louisiana sinks steadily into the sea.

title: Roommate Faces Hate-Crime Charges in Rutgers Case
description: A New Jersey grand jury on Wednesday indicted the roommate of Tyler Clementi, the Rutgers University freshman who killed himself in September, on hate-crime charges in using a webcam to stream Mr. Clementis romantic encounter with another man on the Internet in the days before the suicide.

title: The New Anti-Abortion Math
description: Austin, Tex.

title: Tracking File Found in iPhones
description: Apple faced questions on Wednesday about the security of its iPhone and iPad after a report that the devices regularly record their locations in a hidden file.

title: Safety Board Plans Inquiry Into Flight of Mrs. Obamas Plane
description: WASHINGTON  The National Transportation Safety Board said Wednesday that it would investigate the episode Tuesday in which an Air Force plane carrying Michelle Obama came too close to a cargo plane.

title: A Web Edge for Makers of Real Stuff
description: Plenty of people want to build a popular Web site and become the next Mark Zuckerberg. But some technology entrepreneurs have a more old-fashioned goal: they want to make something you can hold in your hand.

title: SnackWells Nudges Up the Portion Pack
description: WHEN introduced in 1992, SnackWells, the Nabisco line of nonfat and low-fat snacks, sold so well that there were shortages, and early television commercials featured a frazzled grocer trying to restock the products as women pushing carts stampeded toward him.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 20, 2011

title: Three Cups of Tea, Spilled
description: One of the people Ive enormously admired in recent years is Greg Mortenson. Hes a former mountain climber who, after a failed effort to climb the worlds second-highest mountain, K2, began building schools in Pakistan and Afghanistan.

title: McDonalds Makes Subtle Play for Children Online
description: McWorld, a Web site for children sponsored by McDonalds, offers visitors the chance to create characters, decorate digital treehouses and go on a quest in a virtual world.

title: Marketing to Children Online: What Do You Think?
description: Food companies try to reach children online with Web sites, virtual worlds and video games that may not, at first, appear to be advertising. Children who may think they are simply playing video games are in fact engaging with sophisticated commercials, a practice that is beginning to attract scrutiny from regulators. Matt Richtel has just written an article about the issues raised by these advertisements .

title: State of Siege
description: On April 21, secessionist William B. Gulick, a clerk in the Interior Department, wrote North Carolina Gov. John W. Ellis to inform him about the precarious state of affairs in Washington. Gulick, who planned to resign his government post but remained in the city to serve the Confederacy, described an anxious Union capital, whose pro-Union citizens feared an attack at any moment, even as its secessionist residents spoke openly of welcoming a Southern assault.

title: Online Playgrounds With a Message
description: In branded Web sites developed by food companies, entertainment and marketing overlap in ways that may confuse young players.

title: In Online Games, a Path to Young Consumers
description: HESPERIA, Calif.  Deep into one of her favorite computer games, Lesly Lopez, 10, moves her mouse to click on a cartoon bee. She drags and drops it into an empty panel, creating her own comic strip.

title: How Not to Plan for the Future
description: The agreement between Congress and the White House to virtually eliminate money for high-speed rail is harebrained. France, China, Brazil, even Russia, understand that high-speed rail is central to future development. Not Washington.

title: Medical Experts Dispute a Hospitals Claims on Heart Device Data
description: Several medical experts have disputed the basis for a Las Vegas hospitals claim that patients benefited when cardiologists there switched to heart devices made by a company that paid it consulting fees, saying data to support that claim did not exist.

title: Kindle Users to Be Able to Borrow Library E-Books
description: Library books are finally going to be compatible with the Kindle.

title: A Village With the Numbers, Not the Image, of the Poorest Place
description: The poorest place in the United States is not a dusty Texas border town, a hollow in Appalachia, a remote Indian reservation or a blighted urban neighborhood. It has no slums or homeless people. No one who lives there is shabbily dressed or has to go hungry. Crime is virtually nonexistent.

title: The Nations Poorest Place
description: Kiryas Joel, N.Y., has few outward signs of poverty but some of the lowest household incomes in the country.

title: Concern Grows Over Window Blind Safety
description: On an idyllic August day in 2009, Kathleen Leeson took her children to church, fed them leftover pizza and planned to take them to the park.

title: Wildlife at Risk Face Long Line at U.S. Agency
description: In February, the Obama administration declared the Pacific walrus to be at risk of extinction because its Arctic habitat was melting. But it declined to list the marine mammal as an endangered species, saying a backlog of other animals faced greater peril.

title: M.T.A. Is Planning to Sell Its Midtown Headquarters
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which has consolidated departments and reduced its payroll under severe financial pressure, now plans to sell its headquarters and two adjoining buildings on Madison Avenue in a deal that it says could reap more than $150 million.

title: Ryan, Pushing Budget, Resists Talk of Higher Office
description: CLINTON, Wis.  Representative Paul D. Ryan was deep into an explanation of his deficit reduction plan, which sits at the heart of a contentious debate between Republicans and President Obama, when he called on a constituent raising her hand in the front row of a town meeting here.

title: Rolls-Royce Reaches for Pure Ecstasy
description: Shown on Wednesday: Rolls-Royce Spirit of Ecstasy Phantom.

title: Obama, Before Facebook Crowd, Presses G.O.P. on Budget
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  President Obama on Wednesday opened a Western front in his war against House Republicans budget, telling an appreciative audience at Facebook headquarters here that the plan is radical, short-sighted and would reduce annual federal deficits at the expense of the nations poor and powerless.

title: Thursday: Subject of Current Thinking
description: Administrivial Broken Comment Thingy Update: Through absolutely no fault of The New York Times, I promise, the independent, off-site servers that host the comment center have apparently gone on walkabout. Yes, there is a whole team working on finding them and we hope they will be back soon. Frankly, we miss them, and we want them to know that all is forgiven, and that if they go back to their proper place in the cloud, there will be absolutely no retribution or punishment, and that we didnt even mean all the critical things we said to them.

title: Actors Live Their Double Lives, Both on the Screen and Off
description: Actors never get much respect from scriptwriters. The thespian characters who flounce through classic comedies (The Royal Family) tend to be neurotic, self-dramatizing narcissists, while those who show up in darker fare are often neurotic, self-dramatizing narcissists with homicidal streaks (the film A Double Life, all those bio-dramas about John Wilkes Booth).

title: Different Church, More Sequins
description: When the wimples start quivering, the pinched mouths break into sunbeam smiles, and the nuns start rocking to raise the Gothic rafters, alls right in the kingdom of musical comedy at Sister Act. Who could resist the vision of a stage full of saintly sisters flaring their gams in unison like the Rockettes, or swiveling their hips, Supremes style, to the silken beat of an R&B tune? Presumably nobody in the audience at the Broadway Theater, where this latest stage adaptation of a hit movie opened on Wednesday night.

title: ProCro, SoBro, FiDi, BoCoCa: A Lawmaker Says, Enough
description: Everyone knows that some of the best people-watching in New York City can be had in Hells Hundred Acres. Those on the hunt for a middle-class complex would be well advised to check out the Gas House District. Hankering for bagels and a schmear? Get thee to Bloomingdale, stat.

title: No Indictment for Teacher Over Remark on Mass Shooting
description: A grand jury on Wednesday declined to indict a Brooklyn teacher who was arrested earlier this month after making a remark about carrying out a mass shooting at her school, her lawyer said.

title: Raising Vegetables in an Edible Schoolyard
description: A green thumb is a vital attribute for David W. Daly, a vegetarian with a passion for sustainable agriculture and an appetite for nasturtiums. Mr. Daly, 27, has been the coordinator at the half-acre childrens garden at Brooklyn Botanic Garden since July 2009, where he plays a kind of hybrid role as both teacher and farmer. He lives within biking distance in Crown Heights with his girlfriend, Penny Krakoff, a social worker.

title: Chinas Plan to Cut Taxes Puts Burden on Wealthy
description: BEIJING  China is considering an income tax cut, but its impact may be smaller than expected.

title: For Madrid, Winning Ugly Is Still Winning
description: LONDON  Round 2 to Madrid. A fine headed goal just as midnight struck in Spain won the Copa del Rey, the Kings Cup, for Real Madrid against Barcelona.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Holy Thursday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will

title: The Revolutions Missing Peace
description: Ankara, Turkey

title: Libyan Rebels Nonstandard Issue
description: Often outmatched, and always outgunned, in their fight against forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, many of the ragtag Libyan rebels carry old, homemade or modified munitions. Here is a small sampling.

title: Inferior Arms Hobble Rebels in Libya War
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  A PKT machine gun, a weapon designed to be mounted on a Soviet tank and fired electronically by a crew member inside, has no manual trigger, no sights and no shoulder stock. That does not prevent many Libyan rebels from carrying it as if it were an infantrymans gun.

title: Latinos and Democrats Press Obama to Curb Deportations
description: With prospects for an immigration overhaul looking dim, President Obama is facing increasing pressure from Latinos, Democratic lawmakers and immigrant groups to use his executive powers to offer relief from deportation to broad groups of illegal immigrants.

title: Time for Plan B
description: A 14-year effort to negotiate an international treaty banning the production of nuclear weapons fuel is getting nowhere. Under the terms of the United Nations Conference on Disarmament, all 65 participants must agree. Pakistan, which is racing to develop the worlds fifth largest arsenal, is refusing to let the talks move forward.

title: Alfred Freedman, a Leader in Psychiatry, Dies at 94
description: Dr. Alfred M. Freedman, a psychiatrist and social reformer who led the American Psychiatric Association in 1973 when, overturning a century-old policy, it declared that homosexuality was not a mental illness, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: 77 Cents on the Dollar Isnt Fair
description: In a disappointing defeat for women, Senate Republicans worked overtime in December to ensure that a measure addressing gender-based wage discrimination never reached the Senate floor where it likely would have passed by a sizable majority. Fortunately, supporters of the Paycheck Fairness Act have not given up.

title: Yankees Colon Throws Back Clock and Pushes Past Blue Jays
description: TORONTO  The first player out of the Yankees dugout before the bottom of the sixth inning Wednesday night was Bartolo Colon. He jogged to the mound, grabbed the ball and stood there with his glove outstretched, waiting until a catcher arrived.

title: Mets Find Inventive Endings to Rallies, and Collins Gropes for Positives
description: In the somber aftermath of another loss, Mets Manager Terry Collins walked through the back area of the clubhouse patting players on the back, praising them for whatever they may have done right and encouraging them to prepare for the next day.

title: A Good Law Thats Working
description: After years of overfishing, many fish populations have begun to recover. On Monday, Commerce Secretary Gary Locke announced that New Englands fishermen will be allowed to increase their catch of 11 commercially important fish stocks in Atlantic waters this summer.

title: With Mail Bombs, Old Firm Rivalry Crosses the Line
description: In a season of unprecedented tension in Scottish soccer, the threshold of tolerance looks to have finally been crossed after the police intercepted nail bombs sent to Celtic Manager Neil Lennon.

title: Parting Glance: Chris Hondros
description: Conjure a combat photographer in your minds eye  fatigues, a whiskey flask and a fondness for rude pastimes. Now discard the clich and conjure Chris Hondros of Getty Images instead. A tweed blazer with elbow patches. A taste for martinis. A love of Mahler. And a passion for chess.

title: Bloggingheads: Planned Parenthood War
description: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Michael Brendan Dougherty of The American Conservative debate the battle over Planned Parenthood.

title: China: Documentary Film Festival Is Canceled
description: A prominent independent documentary film festival in China, scheduled this year for May, has been canceled because of the tense atmosphere created by the continuing government crackdown on freedom of speech. The English edition of Global Times, a populist newspaper, published an article on Wednesday about the cancellation in which it quoted Zhu Rikun, the festivals art director, saying the organizers had decided to cancel it themselves. The overall situation was tense, and we had received a lot of pressure, Mr. Zhu said. We worried that the films to be shown would meet some problems in this environment and decided to cancel it. Another festival organizer, Li Shanshan, told Global Times that about 20 overseas guests, 10 directors and around 40 fans had registered to attend the festival. The cancellation of the festival, which is usually held every year in Songzhuang, on the outskirts of Beijing, was first announced Monday on the festivals microblog on sina.com.

title: Zimbabwe: Jailed Politician Is Released on Bail
description: Moses Mzila Ndlovu, co-minister of national healing and a leader of a faction of the Movement for Democratic Change, was released on $500 bail on Wednesday after five nights in jail. He was charged with attending a meeting that was held without police approval, a prayer service to commemorate the thousands of civilians killed by the North Korean-trained Fifth Brigade in the 1980s. His arrest has worsened relations in the power-sharing government that includes the M.D.C. parties and President Robert Mugabes ZANU-PF party. Since the M.D.C., the party founded to fight Mr. Mugabes rule, accepted the power-sharing arrangement in 2008, about 30 of its 109 members of Parliament have been arrested at one point or another, according to human rights lawyers and the M.D.C.

title: Russia: Putin Boasts but Avoids a Burning Question
description: In his annual speech to Parliament on Wednesday, Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia , left, detailed his achievements in three years in that office and predicted an era of steady prosperity while giving no insight into the burning question of what he would do at the end of his term next year. Speculation is rife in Russia over who between the countrys two leaders  Mr. Putin or his protg, President Dmitri A. Medvedev  will run in presidential elections next year. In his speech, Mr. Putin said Russia had weathered the worst of the economic crisis and predicted that its economy could rank among the top five worldwide by the end of the decade.

title: Duck, Duck, Anchovy
description: Youve got to try this.

title: BP Sues 3 Companies Over Oil Spill
description: BP has already paid billions of dollars in the massive Gulf of Mexico oil spill. On Wednesday, it filed court papers in hopes that those billions of dollars, and more to come, will not be paid out of its pockets alone.

title: The Crash and Burn of an Autism Guru
description: As people streamed into Graceview Baptist Church in Tomball, Tex., early one Saturday morning in January, two armed guards stood prominently just inside the doorway of the sanctuary. Their eyes scanned the room and returned with some frequency to a man sitting near the aisle, whom they had been hired to protect.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Managing Your Online Image
description: How much personal information about you is available online? You might be surprised  and you might want at least some of it to disappear. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein chats with Riva Richmond, a technology writer and New York Times contributor, about how to fix (or kill) Web data about yourself. The process can be time-consuming, Ms. Richmond says; some people pay a company to clean up their image and monitor mentions of them. But, she notes, its not always possible to expunge information.

title: Capitals Pounce on a Ranger Mistake
description: For Rangers fans, Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden started in a caldron of defiance. Soon it became a raucous celebration. It eventually turned anxious and, finally, ended in shocked silence.

title: Autisms Unrepentant Guru
description: Logically, a scientist whose work had been so soundly rejected by the medical establishment would fade quietly away. Not Andrew Wakefield.

title: Dickey Says Its Time to Be Honest
description: Shortly after the Mets had lost another game to set the mark for the third-worst start after 18 games in franchise history, R.A. Dickey called for an honest team-wide self analysis that he believes may be painful in the short run, but worthwhile in the long term.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Fixating on a Future Royal as Elusive as Cinderella
description: LONDON  The theme of the walking tour was the forthcoming royal wedding, but the object of the groups obsession was Kate Middleton, the royal bride. In Mayfair, the guide paused at the next important landmark: the Jigsaw store on Dover Street.

title: TV Takes On the Royal Wedding
Are You Afraid of Math?
description: The ability to do math is something we are born with, right? Not so fast, says John Mighton, whose nonprofit organization, Jump Math, is the subject of a recent Times blog post about finding better ways to reach kids who think they arent  and never will be  good at anything involving numbers. Are you one of these so-called mathphobes? Or are you someone for whom this subject comes easy  or someone in between?

description: Todays word, in association with the robust Oxford English Dictionary, is

description: Find hot spots for foodies, frugal travelers, party lovers and more.

title: Pakistan Top Court Upholds Acquittals in Notorious Rape Case
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Supreme Court announced Thursday that it would uphold the acquittals of five of the six men accused in the gang rape of Mukhtar Mai, the woman who gained international recognition and emerged as a symbol of voiceless and oppressed women in Pakistan.

title: The Early Word: And in This Corner.
description: In Todays Times: Again and again, Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, has said hes not interested in challenging President Obama by seeking the Republican nomination for president. But Jeff Zeleny writes that Mr. Ryans unchanging answer doesnt deter voters from pressing him to run as he crisscrosses the country to discuss his budget proposal, which is at the heart of a spending debate between Republicans and President Obama. As the author of the plan, Mr. Ryan has emerged as one of the presidents most visible Republican rivals in a budget fight that will help frame the nations politics for the next year and beyond.

title: Film Festival Blends French and Hong Kong Noir
description: France and Hong Kong are both known for art-house films stuffed with sex, crime, violence and dark humor. These two cinema traditions come together in June for Noir, a retrospective of 27 films that is part of Le French May, a major annual cultural festival held in Hong Kong that runs this year through June 23.

title: Fiat to Raise Its Chrysler Stake to 46%
description: Luca Bruno/Associated PressA Fiat dealership in Milan. Fiat seeks effective legal control of Chrysler.

title: A Kid-Friendly iPad Case
description: Ugly but effective, The Big Grips Frame ($35, www.biggrips.com) tightly encapsulates your iPad in an inch-thick wrapper of squishy, high density foam, without blocking important ports, controls or sensors. For a preschooler, the frame makes the rather slippery iPad much more toy-like, especially when used with apps that demand shaking or tilting the screen.

title: Two-Hour Marathon Seen as Question of When, Not if
description: BOSTON  The two-hour marathon may be the modern-day equivalent of the four-minute mile before Roger Bannister smashed through the barrier in 1954, followed in the years since by thousands of other men.

title: Theater Talkback: The Curious Case of Clybourne Park
description: New Yorkers will be happy to learn that they can still catch a performance of Bruce Norriss Clybourne Park, this years Pulitzer Prize winner for drama, in a much-lauded production in a big, up-scale theater. The only problem is that theyll have to cross the Atlantic Ocean.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 15-20 with 1,224 adults throughout the United States, of whom 1,116 were registered voters.

title: Poll Finds Lack of Passion for Republican Candidates
description: With less than a year to go before the Iowa caucuses, Republican voters have yet to form strong opinions about most of their potential candidates for president in 2012, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Obama and Facebook in Warm Embrace
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  He introduced himself as the guy who got Mark Zuckerberg to wear a jacket and tie.

title: A Plan for Working on (Not in) the Business
description: Lots of business owners wish they could be less involved in the day-to-day operations of their businesses (see Its Never the Employee). When you have 10 or even 20 employees, you can be intimately involved in all aspects of the business from sales to finance to operations to purchasing. But if you want the company to grow and perhaps get to that elusive next level everyones always talking about, you have to build an organization that can get the job done without you managing every detail.

title: G.E. Posts Earnings That Exceed Forecasts and Raises Dividend
description: General Electric, the conglomerate that is closely watched because of its diverse products, reported first-quarter results on Thursday that showed gains in most businesses, including aviation and health care.

description: Will Patience have the patience to make it to 100? Will Fortitude have the fortitude?

title: Morgan Stanley Profit Falls 48%
description: Morgan Stanley, which like its peers is still feeling the aftereffects of the financial crisis, posted first-quarter earnings on Thursday of $736 million, down 48 percent from the period a year earlier, and it recorded a $655 million loss from a Japanese joint venture.

title: Potential Republican Presidential Candidates
description: Voters views on potential Republican presidential candidates.

title: Tribeca Video Interview: Maggie Betts
description: The documentary film The Carrier follows a Zambian woman in a polygamous marriage who is pregnant and is H.I.V.-positive. The director Maggie Betts traces the womans struggle, examines her family life and highlights her efforts to prevent transmission of the virus to her child. In this video, Ms. Betts discusses her goals in making the film and talks about how an initiative like the prevention of mother-to-child transmission (PMTCT) can make a difference in controlling the spread of H.I.V. in Zambia and throughout Africa.

title: Remaking Alzheimers: A Few Questions
description: The newly revised criteria for Alzheimers disease, the first change since 1984 in how this dementia is diagnosed, are likely to be most valuable at first to scientists and researchers. The guidelines spring in part from novel research into biomarkers and imaging techniques that may not reach family medical practices for some time.

title: Some Republicans Crave More Presidential Options
description: The 2012 Republican presidential campaign has been filled with false starts, but the real, indisputable starting line is now in sight. In two weeks, a televised debate will take place in Greenville, S.C., where candidates will engage in the first head-to-head match-up of the race.
