title: Sporting Goods
description: Rendering gym bags nearly useless, many designers built athletic components into everyday sportswear this season, eliminating the need for a change of clothes come P.E. time. From a windbreaker snapped on with an aerodynamic hood (its reflective quality is also conducive to biking) to trousers cut with flexible, reinforced knees and brogues fit with a runners tread sole, these clothes are ready to embrace a sudden outburst of fitness. When worn, theyre added incentive to exercise more often.

title: When Pushed, Automakers Can Deliver Cleaner Cars, Says Engineer
description: Jim Kliesch, a senior engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental group, pointed at the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu Eco, one of his favorite cars on the floor of the New York auto show. Like a surprising number of cars unveiled here this week, the Eco  with a mild hybrid system, direct injection and subtle efficiency tricks like active grille shutters  is expected to achieve nearly 40 miles a gallon on the highway when it reaches the public next year.

title: With Train on Backing Vocals, Ford Sings the Body Telematic
description: Though earplugs were distributed at the party door, Ford and Sony kept their Tuesday night New York auto show event in Chelsea humming at only a modest decibel level.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: Nokia, the struggling market leader in mobile phones, said on Thursday that it intended to cut costs by nearly 20 percent over three years, a move that will most likely eliminate thousands of jobs as it enters an alliance with Microsoft.

description: Once the boulder that weighed down General Electric, the conglomerates gigantic financial unit, GE Capital, has rebounded in a big way.

description: HE is moving to an apartment off Central Park and paring down his European conducting dates. But never, ever, imply that Fabio Luisi is preparing to take on one of operas most important jobs: music director of the Metropolitan Opera.

In front of him were two cellphones, both of which rang constantly, prompting him to answer in several languages.

title: Poetry Pairing | April 21, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: T in China | Art and Fashion in Beijing
description: Two of the best art shows in Beijing at the moment arent necessarily the newest. The Unknown, which opened April 1 (at the tail end of China Fashion Week) at the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art, is the fashion photographer Peter Lindberghs first solo exhibition in China. The Unknown is not a Lindbergh retrospective, says the museums director, Jerome Sans, but a body of work specifically assembled to mark his first experience with China. A gigantic remix without order or chronology, the installation is a visual journey through decades of the photographers career, including photos of supermodels like Naomi Campbell, Christy Turlington and Linda Evangelista, most of which were commissioned for Italian Vogue by Franca Sozzani (who was present for the opening). Visitors enter the exhibition in a space surrounded by video images from Lindberghs recent cinematic series, Invasion, a film that depicts a crowd in slow motion moving into a cloud of smoke. Visitors to the exhibit suddenly realize they have become part of the silent choreography, as they watch their own shadows entering and exiting the images projected onto the walls.

title: Blackstone Says Plain L.B.O.s Are Too Pricey
description: While the Blackstone Group reported its best quarterly earnings since going public in 2007, the investment firms big gains came once again from its big real estate division.

title: Quake and Fuel Expense Cut Into Carriers Revenue
description: The first quarter is always weak one for airlines, as travel drops with the start of the new year. But this one was especially difficult, the airlines reported Thursday, as fuel prices spiked and Middle East unrest and the earthquake in Japan cut into demand for international flights.

title: Mazda USA Design Boss Speaks Kodo, Not Nagare
description: Last time we talked to him, Derek Jenkins, head of Mazdas advance design studio in Irvine, Calif., was talking about Nagare, the companys design language based on the wave patterns of wind and water. Now Nagare is history, and the new word is Kodo.

title: Soap Operas Are Not Dead
description: You just have to look for them in different places, like Major League Baseball. The news that the league has taken over operations of the Los Angeles Dodgers is the latest installment of a gloriously debauched family saga. For years, the big worry in baseball was that small-market teams would be squeezed out of the national pastime by the big-market gorillas. But look whats happening: the big teams are imploding. Texas, New York and Los Angeles, each a tale of epic bungling and good ol hubris.

title: Morgan Stanley Alters Deal With Mitsubishi
description: Moving to shed a huge drag on its earnings, Morgan Stanley has renegotiated its deal with the Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, the Japanese bank that provided a $9 billion lifeline during the financial crisis.

title: What Are Taxes For?
description: Brad DeLong and Noah Smith have some fun with a bizarre post by Steve Landsburg  even more bizarrely endorsed by Alex Tabarrok  in which Landsburg asserts that you cant tax a man if you cant persuade him to reduce his consumption.

description: When Ty Bellingham, the executive chef at Kittichai, moved to New York from Sydney just over a year ago, he had big clogs to fill.

title: Space Invaders
description: Home Show, Revisited, opening this month at the Santa Barbara Contemporary Arts Forum in California, puts a new spin on the expression mi casa, su casa. Now in its third iteration, the site-specific exhibition pairs 10 Los Angeles artists with 9 area residences, inviting the artists to explore the notion of home. Some of the work, like the circular swimming pool that Piero Golia built in the yard of an updated Spanish-style gem or Jennifer Wests experimental surf films, which will screen at sundown at a Carpinteria surf shack, makes direct references to life in Southern California. Other installations play with personal space: the sculptor Ry Rocklens tiled floor piece speaks to the work of the mosaic artist who is hosting him, and Bettina Hubby (above) has created curtains  depicting her living inside a Montecito Tudor  that will hang outside the windows, providing privacy for the owners but exposing me, she says. For info on self-guided tours, go to sbcaf.org.

title: From Ad Agency to Art and Design College
description: Luke Sullivan, a longtime creative executive at GSD&M in Austin, Tex., will be leaving the agency to join the Savannah College of Art and Design as chairman of the advertising department.

description: BAGHDAD  Iraq has been castigated of late by human rights groups for violently cracking down on journalists at protests.

title: How James Salter Wrote an Eleven-Page Biography of A.J. Liebling
description: Great books are easy to track down  there are plenty of people pointing you toward them  but great introductions to books are, almost by definition, difficult to discover. You pretty much have to stumble on one by happenstance.

title: Dear FloFab: Our Friends Torture Us with Fancy Plating
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

title: Transformers and Cake Boss Whip Up 2,000 Pounds of Marketing Synergy
description: On Wednesday morning just outside the General Motors display at the Javits Center, a crew with the TLC cable show Cake Boss struggled to unload a 2,000-pound cake molded into the form of the Bumblebee Camaro from Transformers: Dark of the Moon. The third installment in the Transformers series opens on July 1.

title: Delaware Law Gives NYSE an Edge in Battle With Nasdaq
description: In Wednesdays Deal Professor column about the Nasdaq OMX-IntercontinentalExchange bid for NYSE Euronext, I discussed the antitrust risk of a Nasdaq/NYSE tie-up and the countervailing national interest, if any, in preventing a combination of NYSE and Deutsche Brse. Following up on that column, I want to highlight how the law provides a significant advantage to NYSE as long as it prefers a combination with Deutsche Brse.

title: Jennifer Egan Discusses TV Plans for A Visit From the Goon Squad
description: Monday, youd have to imagine, was a pretty exciting day for Jennifer Egan, when her novel A Visit From the Goon Squad won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction. The rest of the week hasnt been a letdown either: on Wednesday evening the agency International Creative Management, which represents Ms. Egan, said that the novel, a sprawling series of stories about interlocking characters connected to the San Francisco punk-rock scene, has been optioned by HBO, which plans to adapt it into a television series.

title: What Location Data, Exactly, Does an iPhone Reveal?
description: On Wednesday, security researchers demonstrated that the certain versions of the iPhone and iPad were logging and storing location data about their owners.

title: For Dodgers Fans, Selig Offers Happy Talk
description: Very seldom does a statement from Bud Selig inspire joy. Many days, the best that baseballs commissioner can shoot for is fans not rolling their eyes at the sound of his name. But when Selig announced on Wednesday that he was stepping in to stabilize the mess that is the Dodgers under the owner Frank McCourt, Dodgers fans had to squelch the urge to form a conga line through downtown Los Angeles.

title: Saab PhoeniX: With Car Production Halted, Whats in a Name?
description: Shown on Thursday Saab PhoeniX concept.

title: Kiss Recreates Detroit Rock City at Mini Stand
description: Smoke spurted, the curtain lifted and in rock star fashion Kiss took the stage Thursday morning at the New York auto show. The band wore full makeup, stilted heels and shiny spandex and posed next to four Mini Cooper Countrymans, customized according to each members face makeup pattern and persona  the Demon, the Spaceman, the Catman and the Starchild. The signed cars and other Kiss memorabilia will be auctioned for Unicef.

title: Your iPhone Is Tracking You. So What?
description: Have you heard the news? Two researchers have discovered that the iPhone keeps a minute-by-minute, time-stamped log of everywhere you go. Thats right: Your phone is tracking you. So is the cellular version of the iPad.

description: We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

title: Win or Lose, DAntoni Deserves Another Year
description: The pillorying of Knicks Coach Mike DAntoni has reached the point of unfairness. The team narrowly loses its first two playoff games on the road to the Boston Celtics, a team with three future Hall of Fame candidates, and fans want to throw stones at the coach.

title: New Director Named at Victoria and Albert Museum
description: Martin Roth, the general director of Dresdens State Art Collections in Germany, has been named director of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, the museum said on Thursday. Mr. Roth, 56, will replace Mark Jones, who has led the museum since 2001 and is leaving to be master of St. Cross College at Oxford University in England.

title: LeMay Museum Compiles Automotive History, in Miniature
description: While 40 m.p.g. appears to be the new black upstairs at the New York auto show, where the latest wares from manufactures are being introduced this week, downstairs, at the south end of the Javits Center, 40-plus m.p.g. is decidedly old school.

title: Kabul: A Boomtown of Sorts
description: Nearly 10 years after the Taliban were driven from power in Afghanistan, the capital city is a patchwork of the old and the remade.

title: Gulf Nations Offer Yemens Leader an Exit Plan
description: CAIRO  The secretary general of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council traveled to the Yemeni capital, Sana, on Thursday to offer the embattled president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, a deal to solve Yemens current political crisis. A Yemeni government statement promised an official response within 24 hours.

title: Belarus Leader Blames Excess of Democracy for Bombing
description: MOSCOW  The president of Belarus, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko, said Thursday that he knew exactly what led to a deadly bombing at a subway station in the capital, Minsk, last week.

title: Real Madrid Lifts, Then Drops, Spanish Cup
description: As my colleague Rob Hughes reports, late Wednesday night, the Spanish soccer club Real Madrid managed to win the Copa del Rey, or Kings Cup, for the first time in 18 years, defeating their archrivals, Barcelona, 1-0 in extra time.

title: The Miracle Worker
description: Some people get ready for swimsuit season with Pilates. Others do it the old-fashioned way: by lying down on a comfy bed while a highly trained French aesthetician gives you a soothing miracle treatment that promises to ease away stress, fatigue and excess fat. The first venture below the dcolletage for the celebrity facialist Isabelle Bellis involves a sophisticated Swiss machine (exclusive to Bellis in New York) that simulates cupping, an ancient Chinese technique that purportedly helps to rid the blood of toxins. But theres no bruising, like with traditional cupping, Bellis says of the two-hour treatment called Bio Body Detox. Its ideal for people who feel sluggish, retain water or are prone to storing fat. According to the soft-spoken Bellis, a Brittany native, clients notice increased suppleness and feel lighter after only one session ($310). Who needs bikini boot camp? Call (212) 966-3262 or go to isabellebellis.com.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: This week, were indoors. And we are looking for answers to a two-part question this time around.

title: House Tour: Orient, N.Y.
description: A converted tool barn from the 1850s features an added guest wing and a heated swimming pool on more than five acres.

title: House Tour: Orient, N.Y.
description: HOW MUCH $1.5 million. Taxes: $7,000.

title: Not All Homeowners Policies Are Alike
description: Few of us would enjoy parsing the language in our homeowner insurance policies. But Daniel Schwarcz, an associate professor at the University of Minnesota Law School, has spent a lot of time doing just that  and what he has found is troubling for consumers.

title: Coyotes, After Being Swept, Skate Off Into Unknown
description: GLENDALE, Ariz.  It was all over but the chanting for the sellout crowd that saw its Phoenix Coyotes swept out of the Stanley Cup playoffs Wednesday night.

title: UnitedHealth Group Reports Strong Earnings
description: UnitedHealth Group, one of the nations largest commercial health insurers, reported robust profits on Thursday. The company, which is the first of the major insurers to make public its quarterly earnings, is viewed as something of a bellwether for the rest of the industry.

title: In Syria, Protesters and Government Mobilize for Friday
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syria deployed police officers, soldiers and military vehicles in two of the countrys three largest cities on Thursday ahead of a call for nationwide protests that will test the popular reception of reforms decreed by President Bashar al-Assad as well as the momentum that organizers have sought to bring to a five-week uprising.

title: Lyric Opera of Chicago Names New Director
description: The Lyric Opera of Chicago has named a new general director, Anthony Freud, who has been running the Houston Grand Opera for the past five years. Mr. Freud, 53, will take over in the fall for William Mason, 69, the general director since 1997, who said in July he would retire after this season. Mr. Freud, a onetime record company executive and former chairman of the jury for the BBC Cardiff Singer of the World Competition, ran the Welsh National Opera before coming to Houston in 2006. A Londoner, he has become a key insider in the American opera world and is chairman of the Opera America service organization. In Houston, he was credited with increasing attendance and fund-raising; overseeing premieres by Jake Heggie and Andr Previn; programming a survey of Benjamin Britten operas; and planning for the companys first Ring cycle, which is scheduled for 2014.

title: Valeant Pharmaceuticals Sets Deadline
description: Valeant Phamaraceuticals International, Canadas biggest drug maker, said on Thursday that Cephalon shareholders have until May 12 to accept its offer of $73 a share in cash.

title: Pesticide Exposure in Womb Affects I.Q.
description: Babies exposed to high levels of common pesticides in the womb have lower I.Q. scores than their peers by the time they reach school age, according to three new studies.

description: This week, Ben Sisario explains why so much American pop these days sounds like ukuleles. And Ben Ratliff, talking to Jeremy Egner, delivers the post-mortem on the Coachella festival in Indio, Calif. The host is Ben Ratliff.

Muammar el-Qaddafi suffered setbacks on multiple fronts on Thursday as rebels in the western mountains seized a Tunisian border crossing, fighters in the besieged city of Misurata said they were gaining ground and President Obama authorized the use of armed drones for close-in fighting against the Qaddafi forces.

title: On Our Radar: Republicans Mark Spill Anniversary With Drilling Call
description: Doc Hastings, the chairman of the House Natural Resources Committee, marks the anniversary of the Deepwater Horizon explosion and oil spill with a call to speed drilling in the Gulf of Mexico. Over the past year significant progress has been made toward making American offshore drilling the safest in the world, Mr. Hastings, Republican of Washington, said in a statement. Safety reforms have been implemented, new technology has been deployed and the gulf is ready to get back to work to help create jobs and lower gasoline prices. [House Natural Resources Committee]

title: Injured Performer Heading Back to Spider-Man Early
description: At first Christopher Tierneys doctors said that he wouldnt be able to rejoin the cast of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark until midsummer at the earliest, only after he had pins removed from his lower back and finished physical therapy to recover from a 30-foot fall off a platform during the musicals Dec. 20 performance. Yet Mr. Tierney, who managed to be up and walking two weeks after sustaining four broken ribs and three fractured vertebrae, had the pins taken out two weeks ago and is healthy enough to return to rehearsals for Spider-Man on Monday, his father, Tim, said in an interview on Thursday.

title: Finding Stories Made Easier
description: In the past, I have heard from readers who struggled to find articles online after they have read them in print. Sometimes they try to search by the print headline and find nothing.

title: What Gary Taubes Eats
description: Gary Taubes, the author of last weeks cover story (Is Sugar Toxic?) as well as an anti-carb cover story from 2002 (What If Its All Been a Big Fat Lie?) and the book Why We Get Fat, has plenty of critics. But no one could accuse him of failing to practice what he preaches. His is a steak-and-egg-heavy diet, without the pasta and potatoes. If you fear for his arteries, you can check out an analysis of his blood lipids posted on his blog. When I talked to Gary this morning, he was in Los Angeles, visiting family for spring break, and (in addition to answering hundreds of sugar-related e-mails) was preparing breakfast: scrambled eggs and bacon for his wife; scrambled eggs, bacon, Italian sausage and black coffee for himself; Cheerios, raisins and Italian sausage for the kids. He did cop to this rare, vacation-related indulgence: last night he ate a chocolate macaroon. Its Passover, after all. He reports that it was delicious.

title: Mitsubishi Announces Pricing of i Vehicle
description: The Mitsubishi i electric car, scheduled for delivery in January 2012, will carry an M.S.R.P. of $27,990. The E.V. is already on sale in some markets as the i-MiEV.

title: Artistic Director of Seattles Troubled Intiman Theater Is Departing
description: Kate Whoriskey, picked by Bartlett Sher to succeed him as artistic director of Intiman Theater in Seattle, is parting ways with that beleaguered institution, at least for now. Faced with a cash crisis, the Intiman board voted last weekend to cancel the rest of the season, which started just last month, and to lay off the theaters staff. While the board hopes to reopen Intiman next year, Ms. Whoriskey said in a telephone interview that she is returning this weekend to New York, where she has an apartment, and will resume her freelance directing career.

title: Coffee Drama
description: Several New York theaters are welcoming patrons well before showtime.

title: Locavore Lobby Snacks Dont Wait for the Curtain
description: ASONGWRITER sips a latte while composing music on a laptop. His companion is so engrossed in a novel that her mouth is frozen midbite into an almond croissant. It sounds like a typical morning at Starbucks, but its actually a scene from the lobby of the Classic Stage Company, one of a handful of New York theaters that have discovered how concession stands can extend the life of their spaces beyond that nights curtain to become community-building places where patrons are encouraged to sit awhile, often during the day.

title: Birth of a Meme: Obama the Pirate Edition
description: Janny Scotts evocative account of Ann Dunham and Barack Obamas Indonesia years has received quite of bit of attention since we published it online yesterday. But in some quarters, one family photograph of a young Barack Obama  an image that will grace the cover of the magazine on Sunday  was deemed more eyebrow-raising.

title: Evidence Aside, State Lawmakers Debate Birther Bills
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  Investigations have concluded that President Obama was, in fact, born in Hawaii in 1961, as he has always said.

title: Theater Listings: April 22  28

title: High Browse
description: Pick up a book about a young New York artist these days, and youre likely to spot Brendan Dugans name in the fine print. As the founder of the graphics firm and indie publishing imprint An Art Service, Dugan has become a go-to designer for galleries like Gagosian and Hauser & Wirth, or for virtually anyone in Dan Colens crowd. Now hes slowly making his presence known with Karma (21 Downing Street; open Thursday-Sunday from noon to 7 p.m. or by appointment), a tiny shop in the front of his office where he sells his own catalog of gritty pop-minimalist art books and posters alongside books and objects that inspire him. Dugan started the publishing arm of his business in 2009 as an additional platform for the artists whose Web sites, books and ephemera he was already designing. Allan Kaprow, Ed Ruscha and a lot of the Fluxus artists were designing all these amazing objects to help support their projects, he says. I guess I think of us as trying to help continue that lineage.

title: Keith Richardss Daughter Gets Community Service (and Hearts Her Sister)
description: Theodora Richards, the 26-year-old daughter of the Rolling Stone Keith, was sentenced on Thursday to two days of community service, after being arrested on graffiti and drug possession charges.

title: Financial Services' Impact on Earnings
description: As earnings season winds down, firms like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley have started to move past some of the institutional issues that have plagues them since the credit crisis.

title: TimesCast | April 21, 2011
description: Although bank earning are down, Wall Street is cautiously optimistic; "American Idol" is kinder and more popular; and remembering the work of the conflict photographer Chris Hondros.

title: 36 Hours in Panama City, Panama
description: AT the crossroads of two oceans and two continents, Panama City is a dynamic metropolis. Thats never been truer than it is today. Everywhere in this steamy, tropical town are foreign investors talking shop in upscale cafes, expat fortune-seekers toasting their fates in wine bars, cranes stalking the rooftops of a skyline that seems to grow before your eyes and  on the downside  traffic that puts even the most congested American city to shame. Central Americas capital of international finance is in the midst of a prolonged boomtown fever. Right now, there are more than 30 skyscrapers under construction  among them the Trump Ocean Club and The Panamera, which will be Latin Americas first Waldorf-Astoria Hotel (both are set to open later this year). All of this building and hype has local residents calling Panama City the Dubai of the Americas. Theyre only half-joking.

title: 36 Hours in Panama City, Panama
description: At the crossroads of two oceans and two continents, Panama City is a dynamic metropolis. Thats never been truer than it is today.

title: Burials for Mother and Daughter Killed in Brooklyn
description: The mother and daughter who were found stabbed to death in a Brooklyn apartment over the weekend were buried on Thursday.

title: Protests in Uganda Over Rising Prices Grow Violent
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Riots broke out in downtown Kampala on Thursday as another round of street demonstrations over commodity prices spread after a leading opposition politician was arrested for the third time in two weeks, significantly heightening tensions here.

title: Just a Maid in Movies, but Not Forgotten
description: FOR Lynn Nottage, the aha moment that led to By the Way, Meet Vera Stark, her new play about race, sex, fame and the dream  and crushing reality  of Hollywood, was unexpected. She was watching Baby Face, a delectably sordid 1933 studio film about an bermensch in silk stockings played by Barbara Stanwyck, who climbs to the top one bed at a time.

title: Citis Annual Meeting Ceases to Be a Battleground
description: Richard D. Parsons has likened his role at past Citigroup annual shareholder meetings to a gladiator entering the Coliseum. This year, the Citigroup chairman laid down his sword.

title: A Few Minutes With Marco Zanini
description: I sometimes think theres a cult of Zanini  Marco Zanini, the creative director at Rochas. He is someone with a solid base of knowledge, a light hand with details and an ego that rarely intrudes. We first met in 2008, when he took over Halston. Hardly anyone knew him; he had been Donatella Versaces assistant for many years. But Mr. Zanini brought a clean vitality to Halston, especially to the day clothes. That show remains a favorite of mine, and it was his only Halston collection because he and the owners parted ways within a few months. Then he got the gig at Rochas, and hes taken a completely different approach with the sporty French label. Mr. Zanini was in New York recently and we chatted about the business, Diors next move  what everybody is talking about.

title: Sintim Pick Did Not Ease Giants Linebacking Needs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants most pressing need in next weekends N.F.L. draft is once again at linebacker, where they have been thin since the departure of Antonio Pierce after the 2009 season.

title: Medias Spotlight Shines Less Brightly on Palin
description: One of the few pieces of statistical evidence that we can look toward at this early stage of the presidential campaign is the number of media hits that each candidate is receiving. Apart from being interesting unto itself, its plausible that this metric has some predictive power. At this point in 2007, Barack Obama and John McCain were receiving the most coverage among the Democratic and Republican candidates respectively, and both won their races despite initially lagging in the polls.

description: Major League Baseballs Commissioners office and players union announced Thursday that players who played between 1947 and 1980 but not long enough to qualify for the leagues pension would receive annual payments of up to $10,000.

title: Madelyn Pugh Davis, Writer for I Love Lucy, Dies at 90
description: Madelyn Pugh Davis, who with her writing partners for the classic sitcom I Love Lucy concocted zany scenes in which the harebrained Lucy dangles from a hotel balcony, poses as a sculpture or stomps and wrestles in a vat full of grapes, died Wednesday at her home in the Bel Air section of Los Angeles. She was 90.

title: Comment Gremlins
description: The Times blog team informs me that the whole comment system has gone down, possibly taking a number of submitted comments with it into oblivion. So if you posted a comment and it never shows, its not because I dont like you; its because the gods of IT dont like you.

title: Pondering the Coyotes Future
description: The Coyotes being run out of the playoffs Wednesday night with a 6-3 loss to the Red Wings at Jobing.com Arena in Game 4 of their playoff series may end up being a minor footnote to the day in Glendale, Ariz.

title: Weekend Miser
description: At first listen it can be hard to put your finger on what exactly Mucca Pazza is. A 30-member music ensemble from Chicago, it includes the usual brass and percussion, with what it calls its freak section  guitars, mandolins, violins and accordions amplified with speakers in the musicians helmets. The bands name means mad cow in Italian and is what one member, Sharon Lanza, described as silliness that stuck. But dont be fooled: these mad hatters with instruments deliver, banging out unique renditions of 20th-century music, television-show themes, car-alarm melodies and original tunes with skill and the help of a couple of cheerleaders. (Thursday, 7 p.m., $12; Santos Party House, 96 Lafayette Street, Lower Manhattan; 866-777-8932, santospartyhouse.com.)

title: Oklahoma City Has Stars, and Depth
description: The Oklahoma City Thunders Game 2 performance was marked by a familiar dominance, albeit one achieved outside the Thunders typically effective formula. Kevin Durant and Russell Westbrook took up their standard roles as offensive focal points, but the Thunders overall production was more balanced than usual; James Harden, Serge Ibaka, and Nick Collison were productive and efficient scorers, and though Durant and Westbrook both topped 20 points for the game, the balance of play efficiency within the Thunder offense had undergone a noticeable shift.

title: Indoor Runs, as if You Were Out
description: AS a crazed working mom who needs regular exercise to stay sane, I find the treadmill a time-saving staple. It provides a cathartic, climate-controlled run supported by escapist Black Eyed Peas videos and E! reality television. Yet unsupervised treadmill running comes with a caveat: I am my own coach, so I run only hard enough to sweat and feel virtuous. But am I pushing myself?

title: Grandersons Power Surge Continues
description: TORONTO  Rewind to last August, when the Yankees hitting coach, Kevin Long, set about revamping Curtis Grandersons mechanics. One of Longs primary concerns was that Granderson would associate his new shortened swing with a drop in power, sacrificing home runs for consistency. Its a funny thing, Long said then, and eight months later that notion still is.

title: Verdis Irresistible Melodies And Implausible Plot

title: Streetscapes | The Buildings of John Hemenway Duncan

title: Uptown, a Jumble of Treasures
description: At the southeast entrance to Central Park stands a colorful, tubular structure resembling a swing-set frame designed by spiders on LSD. Touching ground at 10 points on the cobbled plaza, its red, green and black striped posts rise at different angles into an airy web more than 18 feet high at its tallest. A playful riff on the ancient form of the triumphal arch, Empire, by the Irish sculptor Eva Rothschild, may be viewed for the purposes at hand as a metaphorical gateway to the entertainingly illogical array of new and old artworks awaiting Midtown and Upper East Side gallery hoppers.

description: Shareholders Rights for Amending Bylaws

title: Interest Growing in Weavers Works
description: Mid-20th-century textiles, although often dismissed as poor relatives of abstract paintings, are headed for gallery walls and fair booths in quantities not seen since the 1970s. They are coming to light partly because two major weavers, Lenore Tawney and Annabert Yoors, died in the last few years, and historians and dealers have started poring over their archives and surviving works.

title: Egypt to End the Ubiquity of Mubarak
description: CAIRO  As part of the general mood here to expunge everything reminiscent of former President Hosni Mubarak, an Egyptian court on Thursday ordered the removal of his name and likeness from all public institutions.

title: Developers Scale Back Ambitions
description: DENSITY is often the deal-breaker. Planners and developers emphasize the need for it; residents and zoning boards balk at the prospect of a more urbanized suburbia.

title: Raw Like Chelsea: A Big Tent, Gentrified but Not Gentle
description: When it comes to art and art galleries, Chelsea is the land of wild, mind-bending discrepancies. You know the drill. There are mega-bucks, big-box spaces on the same block as holes in the wall not much larger than a walk-in closet; great work within a stones throw of schlock; older art alongside the freshly minted; and blue-chip brand names across the street from young and emerging artists or forgotten and overlooked ones.

title: The Good, the Bad and the Bloody
description: A look at the films in the Cinemania section of the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: A Collaboration Across 130 Years
description: Late last year, Simon Norfolk traveled to Afghanistan to retrace the footsteps of John Burke, a war photographer who once covered much of the same ground. Their work is being presented together this spring, at the Tate Modern in London, as an artistic collaboration.

title: A City Built on Oil Discovers How Precious Its Water Can Be
description: MIDLAND  The oil business is booming, but there is something more precious in Midland right now: water.

title: Keeping Score: Mets Get Little Bang for Their Bucks
description: Neil Paine is an analyst at Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

title: Turning Car Showrooms and Inspection Station Into Housing
description: MOTOR homes in downtown Newark? Not quite. But two buildings that once housed motor cars will soon open as homes  quirky condominium lofts in one case, high-ceilinged rental apartments in the other.

title: SoHo, Steadfast Bastion for Alternative Works
description: SoHo was once the hub of the New York art world; now its a satellite, but a vital one: some of the citys oldest alternative spaces are there, along with new ones, like Third Streaming. Several of these spaces, within blocks of one another on either side of Canal Street (those to the south are technically in TriBeCa), have impressive spring shows that keep a spirit of experimentation alive, and that are, by coincidence, thematically connected.

title: The First Airing of Dirty Laundry
description: In 1973, when PBS broadcast An American Family, that documentary series about the Loud family of Santa Barbara, Calif., seemed like television engag: a camera-armed rebellion against the scripted contrivances of canned and conventional television.

title: Rising and Regrouping on Lower East Side
description: What a difference two years make. When The New York Times last surveyed Lower East Side galleries, in 2009, my fellow critic Ken Johnson observed that the Lower East Side is not the new Chelsea and probably never will be. He pointed to the lack of big-box commercial vendors showing internationally acclaimed talents.

title: Bay Returns, Looking for Better Days
description: Jason Bay arrived at Citi Field on Thursday ready to play in his first game since July 25, but hoping he will not be the same player he was before a concussion sustained two days earlier ended his disappointing 2010 season.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for April 22-28
description: EARTH DAY AT THE NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN

title: Tribecas Taste of All Things Grim and Gory
description: This year, as always, the Tribeca Film Festival is putting plenty of famous faces on display. Filmgoers can get early looks at movies starring Will Ferrell, Keira Knightley, Orlando Bloom, Don Cheadle, Vera Farmiga and Kathleen Turner, among many others.

title: In a Slow Economy, Rentals Zoom
description: THE uncertain economy, combined with a depressed housing market and tight credit standards, has fostered an increase in residential leasing in Westchester and nearby counties  a trend so pronounced that at least one agency, Better Homes and Gardens Rand, recently introduced a rentals-only Web site for its clients.

title: Obama Sets Up Team on Oil-Price Fraud
description: 7:41 p.m. | Updated President Obama sought again to show his concern for high gasoline prices, announcing on Thursday at a public event in Reno that the Justice Department is forming a team to investigate possible fraud in oil markets.

title: Spare Times for April 22-28
description: Around Town

title: Deep in the Past, a Link to Bind Us
description: JEFF and I met speed-dating at the gay and lesbian center in New York. Later I told him I was a little disappointed with our how we met story, as I had a vision of meeting my future partner at the Metropolitan Museum of Art over a painting or a dropped glove. But the reality was we met with numbers stuck to our chests while facing each other in metal chairs.

title: First an Outcast, Then an Inspiration
description: IN the fall of 1932, fresh out of high school, Elizabeth Catlett showed up at the School of Fine and Applied Arts of the Carnegie Institute of Technology in Pittsburgh, having been awarded a prestigious full scholarship there. But she was turned away when it was discovered that she was colored, and she returned home to Washington to attend Howard University.

title: Increased Security Seen in Videos From Syria
description: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, the Syrian government deployed the police, soldiers and military vehicles in two of the countrys three largest cities Thursday ahead of a call for nationwide protests on Friday. In phone calls on Thursday, residents of Damascus, the Syrian capital, and Homs, Syrias third-largest city, described stepped-up security.

title: On Not Doing Your Homework
description: Jonathan Chait is annoyed with Jacob Weisberg, who wrote a ludicrously adulatory column about Paul Ryan, then admitted that he was wrong  and in the process once again gave Ryan credit that isnt due. Chait:

title: Scavenger Hunt for Family Secrets Across Time and Geography
description: Denis Villeneuves Incendies, a film very much occupied with some of the grisly realities of recent history, nonetheless has the structure, and some of the atmosphere, of an ancient folk tale. It is a quest narrative, about children searching out the mysteries of their parentage, and also the story of a resourceful heroine, the mother of those children, surviving an almost unimaginable series of ordeals.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for April 22-28
description: Classical

title: A Chinatown Fire, One Year Later
description: It was the citys worst fire in years, an enormous blaze that raced through one century-old building in Chinatown and jumped to another and then another.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for April 22-28
description: Art

title: Movie Listings for April 22-28
description: Movies

title: Nations Mood at Lowest Level in Two Years, Poll Shows
description: Americans are more pessimistic about the nations economic outlook and overall direction than they have been at any time since President Obamas first two months in office, when the country was still officially ensnared in the Great Recession, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: From Home Crowd, Praise  and Some Boos  for Paul Ryan
description: A pointed exchange at a town hall meeting in Wisconsin on Tuesday between Representative Paul D. Ryan and a constituent making a point about income equality in the United States is being held up by some opponents of the Republican budget plan as evidence of the publics resistance to the proposal. That, however, is only part of the story.

title: New York Times/CBS News Poll: 2012 Republicans, Obama and the Economy
description: The complete results of a New York Times/CBS News poll on the early Republican field for the 2012 presidential race and the nations economic outlook.

title: Views About the Economy, Budget Deficit and Health Care
description: Americans views on the economy, budget deficit and health care

title: Dance Listings for April 22-28
description: Dance

title: Q&A: Setting the DVR to Record From Afar
description: Q.

title: The Hidden Persuaders Come Out in Full Force
description: Morgan Spurlock could sell you the Brooklyn Bridge. After watching his documentary Pom Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold I could imagine this charming red-headed 40-year-old filmmaker raking in money as a door-to-door salesman of crummy encyclopedias in the slums of Philadelphia or as a pitchman in an infomercial peddling a flimsy abdominal toner. He could probably earn millions as a motivational speaker.

title: Jazz Listings for April 22-28
description: Jazz

title: Location Apps Generate Privacy Concerns, Report Says
description: A day after a report that the Apple iPhone and iPad 3G are storing data about users locations, a new report from the market research firm Nielsen said many Americans have strong concerns about losing some privacy by using location-based mobile services.

title: Seven Idol Aspirants, 21.8 Million Viewers
description: Foxs American Idol attracted 21.8 million viewers on Wednesday as the seven remaining aspiring pop stars performed songs written in the last 10 years. Although the reality shows 90-minute episode easily outperformed all other programs on the night, Breaking In, Foxs new sitcom that follows Idol at 9:30 p.m., struggled. It drew a much more modest 7.5 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS earned a second place finish for the night, garnering 10.5 million at 8 p.m. for Survivor: Redemption Island, followed by reruns of Criminal Minds (8.8 million) and Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior (7.2 million). ABC was third with new episodes of its comedy lineup, including Modern Family (9.8 million) at 9 p.m., and back-to-back installments of Happy Endings at 10 p.m. (4.6 million) and 10:30 (3.8 million). NBC placed a distant fourth with mostly reruns.

title: Shes Making Friends in a New Place
description: Francine Proses characters seem to live under the banner of that famous Rilke line: You must change your life. In Bigfoot Dreams (1986) a woman loses her job and is forced to reassess her life. In A Changed Man (2005) a neo-Nazi has an epiphany after taking a tab of Ecstasy and decides to make amends for his former racist beliefs. And in many of the stories in Women and Children First (1988) people flirt with a variety of religions and spiritual rejuvenation programs in attempts to remake  or at least renovate  their mind-sets.

title: Stargazer
description: A look at the work of the artist Elizabeth Catlett.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for April 22-28
description: Pop

title: People Care, and Its Starting to Show
description: MANY New York neighborhoods once considered tough have followed a similar script in recent decades: Crime fell. Blocks got cleaner. People moved in instead of out.

title: LAmour Fou
description: Images from a Picasso exhibition at Gagosian Gallery.

title: Decades of Players Without Pensions to Get Payments
description: Commissioner Bud Seligs office and the players union announced Thursday that players who played between 1947 and 1980 but not long enough to qualify for Major League Baseballs pension would receive annual payments of up to $10,000.

title: Japanese Revisit Nuclear Zone While They Can
description: OKUMA, Japan  Residents who lived near the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant flocked to the area on Thursday ahead of a midnight evacuation deadline imposed by the government.

title: Remembering Chris Hondros
description: Chris Hondross photograph of a little girl bloodied and traumatized after her parents were killed by American soldiers with the 25th Infantry Division in a shooting on Jan. 18, 2005, is one of the most unforgettable images to come out of the Iraq war. His photograph transcends any written account of the tragic event. Photographers like Chris put their lives on the line so that we can understand the reality of war through images like this. To view more of his work, take a look at the tribute set up by The Timess Lens blog.

title: Tel Aviv Protests Show Divide Over Palestinian State
description: JERUSALEM  Dozens of prominent Israeli artists and intellectuals declared their support for a Palestinian state on the streets of Tel Aviv on Thursday and quickly found themselves confronted by rightist opponents calling them traitors and, according to one report, Jewish Nazis.

title: Tim Hetherington, Behind the Camera
description: In the early 2000s, years before he made Restrepo, his Oscar-nominated documentary about an American platoon in Afghanistan, and before his work as a photojournalist had become much of a career at all, Tim Hetherington hunched behind an old-fashioned camera, his head under a cloth, on a war-ravaged street in Monrovia, Liberia.United Nations troops patrolled the city in tanks, keeping atenuous peace, and the husks of buildings loomed around him, but Tim was posing Monrovians for portraits with this quaint bit of equipment, following some private artistic vision and offering his subjects a strange interval of formality and tranquility amid the citys menacing anarchy.

title: Remembering Tim Hetherington
description: We are all deeply saddened by the loss of Tim Hetherington and Chris Hondros.

title: Senator Ensign to Resign Amid Inquiry
description: Senator John Ensign of Nevada, who had already announced that he would not run for re-election in 2012, is planning to resign, he said in a statement issued Thursday afternoon. Mr. Ensign, a Republican, had been caught up in a sex scandal and an ethics inquiry stemming from his admission in 2009 that he had had an affair with the wife of a top aide (see a timeline of the scandal).

title: A Building Befitting the Hats Heyday
description: NEW Yorks streets used to be a sea of Knox hats; these days the place youll find them is on eBay, about a hundred at the moment. Many were sold for the first time at the overwrought structure just south of the New York Public Library.

title: A Warhol Superstar, Closer to Earth
description: Beautiful Darling, James Rasins touching documentary biography of Candy Darling, the transsexual Andy Warhol superstar, is a sad, lyrical reflection on the foolish worship of movie stars. Jeremiah Newton, who is a producer of the film and narrates the story, was Candy Darlings closest friend and onetime roommate who appointed himself guardian of her legacy after her death in 1974 from cancer at 29. The movie shows him arranging her burial beside Mr. Newtons mother in Cherry Valley, N.Y.

title: Children Fail to Recognize Online Ads, Study Says
description: Hey kids, this is advertising.

title: A Nation Stirs, the Civil War Begins
description: On the morning of April 12, 1861, the newly formed Confederate States Army opened fire on the federal garrison of Fort Sumter in the harbor of Charleston, S.C. After 36 hours of shelling by Confederate cannons, United States Maj. Robert Anderson surrendered the battered fort to his former countrymen. The fall of Fort Sumter touched off four years of a civil war that would kill more than 620,000 soldiers and revolutionize American culture.

title: Recipes for the Easter Table
description: From The Times, main courses, sides and sweets for the holiday.

title: Study Finds Solar Panels Increase Home Values
description: All those homeowners who have been installing residential solar panels over the last decade may find it was a more practical decision than they thought. The electricity generated may have cost more than that coming from the local power company (half of which, nationwide, comes from burning coal), but if they choose to sell their homes, the price premium they will get for the solar system should let them recoup much of their original capital investment.

title: Japanese Survivors Shaded by Puzzlement and Sorrow
description: Kaneto Shindos Children of Hiroshima was released in Japan in 1952, when the memories of World War II and the dropping of atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki were still fresh and painful. A sense of immediacy, or working through recent and almost unfathomable trauma, is palpable in the film, much of which was shot in Hiroshima itself. That it is only now opening in the United States  as part of a welcome and revelatory retrospective devoted to Mr. Shindo at the Brooklyn Academy of Music  heightens that uncanny sense of present-tense witness, even as Japans more recent disasters impart a somber feeling of renewed relevance.

title: Love Triangle Sideshow, a Circuss Main Attraction
description: Water for Elephants, Sara Gruens lightweight page turner about a Depression-era traveling circus, would appear to be a vehicle ready-made for a prestigious family movie on the order of Seabiscuit. With its star attraction, a gentle elephant named Rosie who understands Polish, the novel belongs to the John Irving school of semi-serious whimsy with allegorical overtones.

title: A Tale of the Jazz Age, One With Flying Kicks
description: Donnie Yens latest Wing Chun kung fu epic, Legend of the Fist: The Return of Chen Zhen, has a problem other movies might envy. Its opening scene, which places Chinese laborers in the middle of a World War I battle between menacing Germans and retreating French, is so spectacular that everything that follows feels a little pale in comparison.

title: Indian Point and Earth Day
description: 9:19 p.m. | Updated I spent much of Thursday inside the Indian Point nuclear power complex, which is less than 10 miles from my home in the Hudson Valley and less than 40 miles north of Times Square. Heres a snippet of video (much more coming soon) from our stop in the thick-walled building housing the pool for spent fuel from Indian Point 3, one of the two active reactors at the plant:

title: Kurds Renew Their Movement for Rights and Respect in Turkey
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey  As more than 5,000 Kurds bent their heads to the ground in prayer on the main square of this provincial capital in Turkeys volatile southeast, the voice of the imam rang out.

title: Taking the Lag Out of Shutter Lag
description: In technical terms, the interval between the time you press the shutter button and when a pocket-size camera or smartphone actually snaps a picture is called shutter lag. In practical terms, that means every family photo shows a group of people yelling, Take it already!

title: Blagojevich Jury Selection Begins
description: As jury selection began on Thursday in the second trial for Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, several potential jurors said they thought Mr. Blagojevich was guilty.

title: African Cats, Is Disneynatures Look at Lions
description: There are surely eight million stories on the naked plains, but African Cats tells one: about lions and cheetahs and  oh, Bambi!  the power of mother love. The focus on mothers and cubs and the impulse to treat nature like a storybook should come as no surprise: the film is made by Disneynature.

title: Time to Hit the Streets: A Map of Art Galleries
description: Critics for The New York Times report on their art-world spring awakenings in four Manhattan neighborhoods.

title: The Bang Bang Club Shows Photojournalists at Work
description: Taking pictures is oh-so-painful in The Bang Bang Club, a based-on-real-life saga that turns bloody reality into bloodless drama.

title: Sol Saks, Writer of Bewitched Pilot, Dies at 100
description: Sol Saks, who wrote the first episode of Bewitched, the popular sitcom about a suburban housewife skilled in the uses of enchantment, died on Saturday in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 100 and a Sherman Oaks resident.

title: Dumbstruck Shows Ventriloquists World
description: The very opposite of its title, Dumbstruck is filled with people talking, albeit through weird-looking dolls. Dummystruck would be a more accurate handle for this outsider documentary, given that its ventriloquism-obsessed subjects seem more comfortable expressing themselves with at least one hand wiggling in the body cavity of a puppet.

title: How to Improve Our Patent System
description: To the Editor:

title: Community Agriculture Goes Global With Coffee
description: Rather than buy produce at a store, members of community-supported agriculture programs, known as C.S.A.s, pick up their vegetables in a neighbors garage, right where a local farmer leaves them. This direct grower-to-consumer relationship has become so popular that it has inspired meat and egg C.S.A.s among Northern California ranchers and farmers, as well as grain C.S.A.s and even C.S.F.s  community- supported fisheries  elsewhere.

title: Uncertainty of Whats Next for Dodgers
description: A day after Commissioner Bud Selig moved to take control of the Los Angeles Dodgers, a raft of questions remain unanswered about the future of one of baseballs elite franchises.

title: Multigenerational Housing Is a Real Estate Growth Niche
description: Taylor Morrison, a housing developer based in Arizona, was set to break ground on a 304-unit condominium development in Sunnyvale, near San Jose, when the bottom fell out of the housing market in 2007.

title: Interested in the Jejune Institute? Its Too Late
description: On a recent Sunday, 150 or so people filled the Garden Room at the Grand Hyatt in San Francisco. Next to a makeshift stage, a handful of men and women in lab coats fussed over some strange-looking devices  computers, maybe, or sound equipment  that had flashing lights. Another group of event organizers, in flowing white tunics and pants, greeted entrants.

title: Speed Bumps in the Path of the Bicycle Juggernaut
description: Dr. Frank Gilson is recuperating from a bad case of road rash  not from ill-fitting cycling shorts, but from a grueling encounter with San Franciscos bike plan.

title: Yacht for Sale
description: April 22, 1861

title: Mitsubishi Deal Aids Morgan Stanleys Recovery
description: James P. Gorman, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, received some bad news this year. A joint venture controlled by Mitsubishi UFJ Financial in Japan was facing huge losses, which would drag down earnings at the American investment bank.

title: A Hindu Ritual Creates an Environmental Problem
description: Offerings like fruit, bowls, clothing are left humbly in Jamaica Bay, but wash up along the shore to threaten the ecosystem.

title: Why the Bankers Havent Been Prosecuted
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefly Returning to the Nuclear Zone
description: Residents who lived near the damaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant flocked to the area on Thursday ahead of a midnight evacuation deadline imposed by the government.

title: Senator Ensign to Resign Amid Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Ensign of Nevada, the subject of an ethics investigation related to his affair with the wife of a former top aide, announced Thursday evening that he was resigning, effectively ending the high-profile Senate inquiry that had already ruined his once-promising political career.

title: The Purpose of College
description: To the Editor:

title: Evidence, Exculpatory and Unheard
description: Here was a police tow truck, helping to solve a murder.

title: Siblings on the Road
description: The moment its evident that Exodus Fall is going to be a chore comes awfully early: the first scene after supertitles that set this would-be coming-of-age road trip movie in 1974.

title: A Plan With a History
description: The federal government isnt known for its advanced planning, especially when it comes to technology. But the groundwork for reclaiming airwaves from television broadcasters was first mapped out more than a decade ago, when the Federal Communications Commission decided to make the Internet, not TV, the countrys dominant communications medium.

title: The Electoral Implications of Ensigns Resignation
description: Gov. Brian Sandoval of Nevada is expected to appoint Dean Heller, currently the Republican incumbent in the states Second Congressional District, to replace Senator John Ensign, who is resigning.

title: School on Probation Faces a Struggle
description: Austin Polytechnical Academy, a public school established in 2007 to help broaden academic opportunities on the West Side and retool perceptions of vocational education, is facing harsh realities as it prepares to graduate its first senior class: lagging test scores, diminishing attendance and dismal reading levels.

title: Passion of Haymarket Affair Resonates 125 Years Later
description: The Haymarket Martyrs Monument, in a Forest Park cemetery just outside Chicago, has been called the piet for workers, a National Historic Landmark visited each year by foreign labor leaders arriving on tour buses to pay homage and lay roses at its base.

title: Black Carbon Testing Finds High Levels
description: When the City Council passed an ordinance in early April to reduce emissions from construction equipment working on city jobs, it touched on a larger problem: harmful amounts of diesel exhaust in Chicagos air.

title: Patronage Hiring Defies Time and Money Spent
description: A Jehovahs Witness approached me on State Street last week, gave me a leaflet and said she had The Answer to all our problems.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,528 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: City Issues Rule to Ban Dirtiest Oils at Buildings
description: Buildings in New York City will be required to phase out using the most-polluting grades of heating oil under a new regulation that is expected to improve air quality significantly and make black smoke billowing from smokestacks a thing of the past.

title: A Clash Over the Airwaves
description: LAS VEGAS  Dropped calls. Maps that take eons to load. Echoing voices on a mobile phone. And, as iPhone users know, the dreaded Cannot Open Page.

title: Finlands Turn to Right Sends Shivers Through Euro Zone
description: HELSINKI, Finland  There is hardly a country on the continent that has been a more steadfast supporter of the European Union than Finland. For more than 20 years, the voters here have returned the same three parties to power in various coalition governments, with few changes in policies.

title: Selig Finally Finds Peace as He Looks Toward Next Job
description: MILWAUKEE  The aspiring lawyer in the third row of Room 267 at Eckstein Hall had a question for Bud Selig. She wanted to know if a story she read was true, if he was, indeed, the happiest commissioner in sports.

title: Bringing On the Vampires in Stake Land
description: It aint a normal world, says Martin (Connor Paolo) at the beginning of Stake Land, and, really, what postapocalyptic-vampire-western world ever is? That said, this unusually taut sophomore feature from Jim Mickle is more abnormal than most in that its creatures are capable not only of evolving but also of embracing religious fanaticism.

title: Arizona: Restaurant Owners Charged
description: Two owners of Mexican restaurants in a Southwest chain were arraigned on Thursday in federal court in Phoenix on 19 charges that they knowingly hired illegal immigrants as kitchen workers and committed tax fraud by paying them off the books. Mark Evenson, 58, and his son Christopher Evenson, 39, owners of Chuys Mesquite Broiler restaurants in Arizona and California, were arrested Wednesday following immigration raids at 20 restaurants. Also arrested were an accountant for the chain and 41 immigrant workers suspected of being unauthorized. If convicted on all charges, Mark Evenson faces up to 86 years in prison, in one of the toughest cases brought by Obama administration authorities against an employer.

title: Mini-Scandal Behind It, New York City Firefighters Calendar Returns
description: Ladies and gentlemen, even though they did not really go anywhere, the half-naked firefighters are back.

title: For a Few, Focus on Green Products Pays Off
description: These days, it seems, the provenance of green products matters.

title: Australia to Review Charges of Sexism in Its Military
description: SYDNEY, Australia  After weeks of embarrassment over sexual scandals in the Australian military, Prime Minister Julia Gillards government appears intent on giving the armed forces their biggest shake-up in more than a decade, including making all combat roles available to women.

title: The Danger of Donald Trump
description: Its easy to see why people think Donald Trump has become the Charlie Sheen of the Republican Party. Gluttons for attention, the two share a rare talent at self-promotion, self-delusion and self-immolation. And Sheen now proclaims himself a birther, in league with Trumps crusade to promote a lie about President Obama that is also believed by nearly half of G.O.P voters.

title: An Opportunity for Green Energy
description: Fracking didnt quite get its Macondo moment. Chesapeake Energys fluid spill in Pennsylvania looks minor compared with BPs Gulf of Mexico explosion a year ago. All the same, the spill will galvanize critics of hydraulic fracturing, a process that releases natural gas from shale rock by blasting it with water, sand and chemicals. Deepwater oil, coal and nuclear operations all have had recent disasters, and with Earth Day on Friday, now is a good time for renewable energy firms.

title: Fair Vote, Fragile Future
description: Lagos, Nigeria

title: As Consumers Cut Spending, Green Products Lose Allure
description: When Clorox introduced Green Works, its environment-friendly cleaning line, in 2008, it secured an endorsement from the Sierra Club, a nationwide introduction at Wal-Mart, and it vowed that the products would move natural cleaning into the mainstream.

title: Witness to Bishops Death Freed in Argentina
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  A missing witness to the death of a Roman Catholic bishop during Argentinas military dictatorship was found safe early Thursday after unknown people took him hostage and warned him to back down from testifying in an inquiry into the death, the witnesss lawyer said on Thursday.

title: Patients Are Not Consumers
description: Earlier this week, The Times reported on Congressional backlash against the Independent Payment Advisory Board, a key part of efforts to rein in health care costs. This backlash was predictable; it is also profoundly irresponsible, as Ill explain in a minute.

title: Cash Crunch for G.O.P. Freshmen in Tough Districts
description: WASHINGTON  Allen West made history when Florida voters sent him to Congress last year, becoming one of only two black Republicans from the South to serve in the House since Reconstruction.

title: How Not to Say Sorry After a Blunder Affecting Millions
description: Eating crow is a fine art. Susan Combs hasnt mastered it.

title: Bill Seeks to Designate Drug Cartels as Terrorists
description: A Texas congressman is seeking to designate seven of the top Mexican cartels as foreign terrorist organizations, a move he says would give law enforcement in the United States enhanced tools to combat the cartels.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 21, 2011

title: At Ebenezer Baptist Church, a Glorious Rebirth
description: ATLANTA  Each of the 90 federal historic sites in the United States has its appeal. But for all their cultural value, the sites dont change much. A studious tour given by a park ranger. A plaque to read. Another note in a travel journal.

title: Film on Branded Content Examines a Blurred Line
description: THIS article about advertising is about a documentary about advertising that its makers say is entirely paid for by advertising.

title: Creed or Chaos
description: You can feel a jolt of energy surge through the audience of The Book of Mormon about a quarter of the way into the shows first musical number. Its a jolt of joy, gratitude and laughter  a confirmation that this Broadway production is going to live up to its rave reviews.

title: In Preview of Clemens Trial, Issues of Access and Credibility
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ruled Thursday that a Congressional committee did not have to turn over documents to Roger Clemens for use in his perjury trial, but he delayed a decision on a related issue, about whether George J. Mitchells former law firm should be immune from producing records.

title: Rethinking Their Pledge
description: Senator Tom Coburn, a conservative Republican from Oklahoma, has had the good sense to demand an end to the $5 billion annual tax credit to makers of corn ethanol, a wasteful subsidy to farm states that is also dubious environmental policy. For his outspokenness, Senator Coburn was pilloried by anti-government activists of his own party who cannot stand the idea of more revenues flowing into the federal Treasury. But he and a few others in the Senate are holding fast, suggesting that at least some Republicans are willing to break with party orthodoxy to reduce the long-term budget deficit.

title: In the Postseason, Blunders Are Burned Into Memory
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  What do you do after you make a mistake that costs your team a crucial playoff game? What do you do when fans, who are already on your case for general underachievement, plaster Twitter with messages calling for your head?

title: Democrats Sue to Force U.S. Election Agency to Reveal Political Donations
description: WASHINGTON  Unable to stanch the flow of corporate money to Republican causes, Democrats tried a new tack on Thursday by bringing a lawsuit against the Federal Election Commission to force the disclosure of tens of millions of dollars in secret donations.

title: N.F.L. Argues Against Damages in TV Case
description: The N.F.L. argued Thursday in court papers that players were not entitled to further damages  either compensatory or punitive  in the case in which the United States District Judge David Doty ruled that the league violated agreements with players when it negotiated TV contracts that would pay owners even if games are missed during a lockout.

title: Festive Yet Alarming, Earthquake Banners Strike a Surreal Note
description: Living in Los Angeles, for all its many pleasures, can take a fair amount of gumption. Even in Beverly Hills.

title: With Few Immediate Needs, Jets Look for the Best in N.F.L. Draft
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Joey Clinkscales, the Jets vice president for college scouting, used the words best player available to answer the first question about the teams draft strategy.

title: Obama Makes His Case in Mostly Friendly Territory
description: LOS ANGELES  President Obama confronted head-on the frustrations of his liberal base during a two-day West Coast trip, but also got plenty of evidence in sentiment and dollars that the love is still there  not least because of fear of the alternative that Republicans pose.

title: The Trainer Behind Those Improbable Plays
description: Carmelo Anthony appears to perform the impossible in a Nike commercial. In one hand, he furiously dribbles a basketball. With the other, he catches a tennis ball, tosses it back and receives it again from his personal trainer, Idan Ravin, all while maintaining his dribble and keeping his feet moving.

title: California Is Owed Millions of Dollars by State Employees
description: LOS ANGELES  When the State of California began handing out i.o.u.s in 2009 because of a cash shortage, taxpayers were predictably aghast. But few knew at the time that even as pay-you-later notes kept going out, state agencies were also doling out millions of dollars in interest-free loans in the form of salary and travel advances to employees without collecting repayment.

title: Portrait of Childhood
description: The indie Texan filmmaker David Lowery receives a double bill at the reRun Gastropub Theater in Dumbo, Brooklyn, and while Pioneer, a 16-minute short, and St. Nick, an 86-minute feature, dont provide hard answers to their mysteries, both are deeply intriguing.

title: New Hampshire Senate Approves Bill Curbing Unions
description: The latest battle front over limitations on unions has opened in New Hampshire, where a law is expected to be adopted that would prohibit unions from collecting mandatory fees and disallow collective bargaining agreements that require employees to join a labor union.

title: First Order for Knicks Is a Healthy Lineup
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  After having two days to recuperate from injuries, narrow losses and second- and third-guessing, the Knicks will play their first home playoff game in seven years Friday with their dimming chances connected to the status of their stars.

title: Worker Cites Bosss Order in Standpipe Collapse at a Bank Tower
description: The time to finish cleaning the basement of the former Deutsche Bank building in 2006 was so short that supervisors were getting antsy. Salvatore DePaola, an asbestos abatement foreman, constantly urged his team to hurry, Adolpho Ortiz, one of the cleaning workers, testified on Thursday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Xerox Reports Rise in Profit and Revenue
description: The Xerox Corporation swung to a first-quarter profit on Thursday as revenue climbed and the company cut costs related to its acquisition of Affiliated Computer Services.

title: Bud Selig Stands Tall
description: Bud Selig has never looked better than he does right now. On Wednesday, he seized control of the troubled Los Angeles Dodgers, the kind of decisive, assertive action that should define the office of the commissioner of baseball. If he has often seemed beleaguered during more than 18 years in the job, Selig now stands tall.

title: Jess Jackson Dies at 81, a Wine Grower With a Taste for Thoroughbred Racing
description: Jess Jackson, a lawyer turned vintner who built his company, Kendall-Jackson, into one of the largest wineries in the United States, and who owned two of the premier racehorses of recent decades, Curlin and Rachel Alexandra, died on Thursday at his home in Geyserville, Calif. He was 81.

title: What on Earth? Probes Mysteries of Crop Circles
description: A cheery, chummy documentary about the pastoral patterns inaccurately described as crop circles, Suzanne Taylors What on Earth? musters a gaggle of enthusiasts to dish on the phenomenon.

title: Governors Come and Go, but This Reporter Keeps Slugging Away
description: Andrew M. Cuomo sailed right past Carl P. Paladino and the Tea Party. His first budget passed with ease. But he still has to face the rite of passage that every New York governor since Hugh L. Carey has had to navigate: the singular force that is Fredric U. Dicker of The New York Post.

title: When Math Makes Sense (To Everyone)
description: In response to Tuesdays column about Jump Math, an approach to math education that is showing impressive results in schools in Canada and England, a great many readers wrote in to share stories of how they or their children have struggled with math (or, in some cases, were almost traumatized by it). I failed math as a school-aged boy, wrote Rob Blake, from New York. I avoided math like one of the 10 plagues.

title: Longing for Marriage
description: Calling your romantic comedy When Harry Tries to Marry is a no-win proposition. Producing smarm at the high level of When Harry Met Sally requires special talent, and when you fall short all youre left with is garden-variety smarm.

title: Thelma, Louise and All the Pretty Women
description: A Preamble Not Intended To Undermine What Comes After ItTo immerse yourself in literary theory as an impressionable young person is a little like squinting at a piece of toast until the face of Jesus materializes. Its a slight perceptual shift (all you have to do is unfocus your eyes) but risky, because theres no going back to plain toast after Jesus. Similarly, once you have engaged in enough feminist readings of The Iliad or performed close textual analyses of Alf or written papers limning the intertextual relationship between Videodrome and Madame Bovary  once, in other words, youve glimpsed the social, political, historical and ideological underpinnings of every text ever constructed  youll never again see stories the same way again. Theyll shed their innocence and expose their dirty secrets and reveal the world as a darker, more dangerous place than it once seemed.

title: Friday: The Promised Land
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Idiom expressing gratitude to a deity that its the end of the work week (Abbr.)

title: This Blessed Plot, This Trailer, This England
description: The first time you hear the rumble in Jerusalem, the magnificent play by Jez Butterworth, you dont think that its just a good sound effect or a subway passing beneath. A thundery whisper, like a premonition of earthquakes, fills the air every time someone looks deep, but really deep, into the eyes of Johnny Byron. And since Johnny Byron is portrayed by Mark Rylance, in a seismic performance that threatens to level the old Music Box Theater, this registers as utterly natural cause and effect.

title: In Oregon, a House Perfectly Divided, Sharing Power
description: SALEM, Ore.  They govern by hyphen.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Good Friday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Friday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Henry Scores 2 for Red Bulls
description: Thierry Henry scored two first-half goals, both off crosses from defender Jan Gunnar Solli, and Joel Lindpere and Juan Agudelo added second-half goals as the Red Bulls defeated host D.C. United, 4-0, on Thursday night.

title: At Princeton, Questions After Instructors Suicide
description: One Friday morning this month, a security guard showed up at the office of Antonio Calvo, a popular Spanish instructor at Princeton University, to escort him from the building. Friends and former colleagues say Dr. Calvo was abruptly dismissed from his job, and because he lived in the United States on a temporary visa, he faced a compulsory return to his native Spain.

title: Securing a Former Taliban Stronghold
description: American soldiers take tactics that helped secure a once-bombarded military base to nearby villages in an effort to push out insurgents.

title: Our Obsolete Approach to Medicaid
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Do You Think Its Because They Liked Florida?
description: House Republicans are seeking to abolish the federal Election Assistance Commission  as if the nation is fully recovered from the hanging-chad nightmare of 2000. The 9-year-old commission was created in bipartisan Congressional resolve to repair the nations crazy quilt of tattered election standards and faltering machinery.

title: Once Under Siege, a Base Breathes Easier
description: COMBAT OUTPOST ZEROK, Afghanistan  Nestled amid the pine-studded mountains in eastern Afghanistan, this small base a dozen miles from the Pakistan border was once one of the most dangerous places in Afghanistan. Insurgents nearly overran it in 2009. Last year mortars rained down on the base nearly every other day.

title: A Hole in the Endangered Species Act
description: As part of its budget bill, Congress approved a brief rider, 11 lines long, that removes gray wolves in Idaho and Montana from the protections of the Endangered Species Act. The rider overturns a recent court ruling, prohibits further judicial review and cannot be good for the wolf. But the worst part is that it sets a terrible precedent  allowing Congress to decide the fate of animals on the list.

title: The Childrens Book Comes to Life Electronically. Should We Be Alarmed?
description: What is the use of a book, thought Alice, eerily foreshadowing a critical question in the age of digital media, without pictures or conversations?

title: Woman Killed When Cab Crashes Into Bronx Store
description: A 61-year-old woman was killed on Thursday when a livery cab hopped a curb in the Bronx and smashed into a storefront, the police said.

title: Sports Replay: April 21
description: The day in sports from judo in Turkey to a home run in Los Angeles.

title: Joel Colton, Who Kept History Current for 50 Years, Dies at 92
description: Joel Colton, a historian who for over 50 years helped regularly update a textbook that has introduced generations of college students to modern history, died Sunday at his home in Durham, N. C. He was 92.

title: Bloggingheads: Will Syria Explode?
description: Joshua Landis, left, of the University of Oklahoma and Ammar Abdulhamid of the Tharwa Foundation debate the future of Syria.

title: Bright, Careful and Sadistic: Profiling Long Islands Mystery Serial Killer
description: He is most likely a white male in his mid-20s to mid-40s. He is married or has a girlfriend. He is well educated and well spoken. He is financially secure, has a job and owns an expensive car or truck. He may have sought treatment at a hospital for poison ivy infection. As part of his job or interests, he has access to, or a stockpile of, burlap sacks.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: BP Agrees to Pay $1 Billion for Start of Gulf Restoration
description: WASHINGTON  BP will provide $1 billion for early oil spill restoration efforts in the Gulf of Mexico in a voluntary agreement with the federal government and five states, company and government officials announced on Thursday.

title: Word of the Day | raspy
description: raspy  \ras-pe\ adjective

title: Test Yourself | History, April 22, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about a celebration first begun in 1970 that takes place every year on this day.

title: News Quiz | April 22, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Daily Lexeme: Micklegemot
description: Todays word, in association with the delightful Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: A Year Later: The Gulf and the Cleanup
description: WHEN did the explosion that caused the Gulf of Mexico oil spill occur?

title: What Are You Looking Forward To This Summer?
description: In New York City, a new amusement park called the Scream Zone just opened at Coney Island, and, as Mayor Michael R.
