Bloomberg remarked at the opening ceremony on Wednesday, Nothing says summer like Coney Island. What do you look forward to doing where you live? What says summer to you? What plans do you already have, and what summer pleasures are you especially looking forward to?

title: Security Forces Kill Dozens in Uprisings Around Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Security forces in Syria met thousands of demonstrators with fusillades of live ammunition after noon prayers on Friday, killing at least 81 people in the bloodiest day of the five-week-old Syrian uprising, according to protesters, witnesses and accounts on social networking sites.

title: At 27, Guy Martin Becomes a Veteran
description: In a dreadful instant on Wednesday, the 27-year-old Guy Martin was propelled from his cohort of promising young photojournalists into the honorable  if unsought company of those who have been injured or killed in the line of duty.

title: Toyota Says No Full Production Until Years End
description: TOKYO  Toyota Motor will not return to predisaster production levels until the end of the year, the president of the Japanese automaker said Friday.

title: Peugeot and Renault to Repay Government Loans Early
description: PARIS  In another sign of improving health at the large French automakers, the government said on Friday that PSA Peugeot Citron and Renault would repay ahead of schedule the billions of euros in state loans provided during the financial crisis.

title: Prosecutors in China Drop Charges Against Lawyer
description: BEIJING  Chinese prosecutors unexpectedly dropped charges on Friday against a prominent lawyer whose case had drawn nationwide attention.

title: Coming Home, as an Interpreter
description: It was 1 in the afternoon. I was looking through the mess hall in Bagram Airfield north of Kabul, scanning the faces to find Parween. I had met her a few days before as she commented on a book I was reading about Afghanistan; her first name was the same as that of the main character. The book was Lipstick in Afghanistan by Roberta Gately, a fictional account of an American nurse volunteering in Bamiyan Province after 9/11. Unlike the nurse in my book, Parween had grown up in Kabul in a highly educated family. Her father had attended Columbia University and worked as an ambassador for Afghanistan to Ethiopia. Now, she worked as a translator for American military forces in Afghanistan.

title: Mopar, Not Dodge, Delivers Special-Edition Charger
description: Mopar has been making Chrysler parts for nearly 75 years. It now makes Chrysler cars, too.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Jake Locker, 5th-Ranked Quarterback
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: London Show Celebrates Stylish Aesthete
description: Meshing peacock feathers, pale lilies, sunflowers and blue and white chinaware in a single living room would seem to show some iffy taste, at best. But a group of artists and writers in late 19th-century London thought otherwise and embraced this mixture of many different styles.

title: The Early Word: Resignation
description: From Todays Times:

title: Medical Workers Reported Missing in Bahrain
description: LONDON More than 30 medical workers are missing in Bahrain, an American rights group said Friday, in the latest indication that the countrys health care system is being drawn into Bahrains confrontation with pro-democracy campaigners.

title: Last Month on the Internet
description: SMART FOOD?Brains arent just for thinking. Think of them as beautiful soft-scrambled eggs, the Houston chef Richard Knight says about pork brains. And Lance Armstrongs health-and-nutrition Web site, LiveStrong, suggests frying up a few ounces of beef brain with scrambled eggs for breakfast, because its an excellent source of protein and vitamin B12. (Its also more than five times your daily cholesterol allowance, but you dont have to eat it every day.) Or if you prefer, a classic jumbo brain sandwich, made with deep-fried pig brains, is $6.95 at the Hilltop Inn in Evansville, Ind. You could also stick a bendy straw in one ear and try to suck out part of your brain  perhaps the part that cant unsee the fried jumbo brain sandwich.

title: Tip of the Week: Free Software Training Online
description: Learning a new program  or even upgrading to a new version of one you already use  can take some time. Signing up for a class or buying a book are ways to learn quickly, but you might be able to get up to speed without spending money, as many companies offer free training videos tucked away in the Support areas of their Web sites.

title: Beware the Early Front-Runner
description: We interrupt the early presidential campaign excitement for this brief bit of reality: polls showing how potential Republican candidates for president match up against one another - or, for that matter, against President Obama - in a theoretical vote are often worth bupkes at this stage of a campaign.

title: Is Now the Time to Give Away the Business?
description: In my last post, I discussed whether it might be a good idea to sell your business before (or after) 2013  a complex decision that is looking even murkier. What seems crystal clear, on the other hand, is that now is a fantastic time to give shares of a business to family members.

title: Review of 43rd St. Coffee Carts Is Posted on a, um, Post
description: The restaurant review, such as it was, started with the bagels.

title: The Office': Seasons of Michael
description: The cast of The Office performs an affectionate farewell tribute to Michael Scott  or is that Steve Carell?  in his second-to-last episode by singing its own version of Seasons of Love, the inescapable and mathematically precise Rent ballad.

title: April 23-24: Top European Matchups
description: The top matchups in European soccer this weekend:

title: Deadly Drone Strike by U.S. May Fuel Anger in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An American drone attack killed 23 people in North Waziristan on Friday, Pakistani military officials said, in a strike against militants that appeared to signify unyielding pressure by the United States on Pakistans military amid increasing opposition to such strikes.

title: The Wonderlands of Shaun Tan
description: A look at the artists exquisite picture books.

title: The Mouse People of Beijing
description: Under Chinas teeming capital is an underground city of laborers, waiters and salesclerks.

title: How to Unmask the Internets Vilest Characters
description: In June 2009, Lani (a nickname) got a Facebook message from a stranger alerting her to nude photos of herself that had been posted on a Web site called Private Voyeur  along with her name, her workplace and the city she lives in. The post, titled Jap Slut, was published anonymously by someone who used a proper noun followed by numbers as an Internet handle.

title: Five-Ku: The Films of Susan Sarandon
description: Thelma and LouiseGreat ad for Southwest road trip.Except that last part.

title: Upon Penalty of Life
description: I spent the middle of January through the end of March sitting in a room with about 40 people during a long, dense conversation  and the only real subject of all that talk was whether to kill Christopher DiMeo.

title: Tale of the Iraq War, Still Resonating
description: The story hasnt changed. How could it have? Its history now, the sort of history that repeats itself endlessly.

title: The Pay Walls the Thing
description: Im a 24-year-old freelance journalist whos still somewhat dependent on my parents. And Im on nytimes.com dozens of times a day. My parents are print subscribers and thus have access beyond the pay wall. Need I buy my own subscription? Also, if I buy online access, can I share the password with my live-in girlfriend, even if I move to New York for the summer? What about our other housemates? KEVIN CHARLES REDMON, MINNEAPOLIS

title: Shaun Tans Wild Imagination
description: A vine has invaded Shaun Tans house in suburban Melbourne, Australia, through a previously unnoticed gap where the window of his studio doesnt quite meet the sill. Advancing along a curtain rod and sinking offshoots into the dark places behind his desk, the vine has overgrown Tans workspace. He has to trim it back, because it keeps trying to grab things  an electric pencil sharpener, unopened letters in his inbox. Recently he returned from a trip to find that it was exploring the bottom drawer of his filing cabinet, where he keeps new projects.

title: Chris Dodd, the Hollywood Square
description: When you decided to leave the Senate, you emphasized that there would be no lobbying, no lobbying. Now youre the head of the Motion Picture Association of America, the movie-studio-financed lobbying organization. What happened?  No. 1, that was before this opportunity was even on the radar screen, and No. 2, the job obviously involves a lot more than just that. Thats just one aspect of it.

title: Ellen Barkin Is No Uptown Girl
description: Ellen Barkin led me up the stairs so I could see her bedroom. She was chatty in the way youd expect Ellen Barkin to be  sort of tough yet sort of warm, sort of open, sort of closed. We had already talked for more than an hour, and this was a gesture of good will on her part, a way of saying, Even though you are a reporter and have the ability to ruin my week or month or year with an untoward phrase, Im going to pre-empt you, rise to the occasion and open my home. Ill show you more than the living room with the white goatskin rugs and original white leather Eames chairs, the public room of my West Village town house.

title: The Air-Raid-Shelter Apartments Under Beijing
description: In the far west of Beijing, in a neighborhood called Apple Orchard, there is a small concrete bunker with a green sign at its mouth that says, Air-Defense Basement. Down three flights of stairs into a tunnel lighted only by the occasional fluorescent bulb, the air gets cold and musty, and as you walk through here, its impossible not to think that hideous things could happen without anyone ever knowing. Eventually you come upon a doorway with a white air-lock portal, which opens onto another corridor that splits off in two directions. At the end of one branch, there is a metal door framed by red paper banners, one of which reads, May good things you want to happen come to pass.

title: Complaint Box | Cashiers on Cellphones
description: As the mother of four school-age children, I make countless trips to the local supermarket. Whether I shop for breakfast, school lunches, snacks, or dinner for six, the place is practically my second home. So I am very well attuned to rearranged aisles, new cashiers and the latest innovations. Recently, though, Ive noticed a trend that has nothing to do with selling groceries. On a single shopping trip, I spotted three of the five cashiers texting while working, their cellphones strategically placed next to the registers so that they could quickly glance at incoming messages.

title: Channeling Kenneth Arrow
description: Readers familiar with health care economics may have noticed that todays column was largely a translation into English of part of Kenneth Arrows seminal article on the economics of medical care (pdf), especially part IIB  the article that explained, half a century ago, why health care cant be treated as an ordinary market. Its amazing that were still fighting to get people to understand the same lesson.

title: iPhone Secretly Tracking How Dull Your Life Is
description: From Satirewire. And its true, its true. The horrible secret someone would learn from my tracking is that I dont have any interesting secrets.

title: April 22 Updates on Protests in Syria and War in Libya
description: On Friday, The Lede compiled reports on protests in Syria and the war in Libya from journalists, bloggers and witnesses in the region. The coverage continues on nytimes.com.

title: At Swatch, an Enviable Problem: An Excess of Eager Customers for Its Products
description: BASEL, Switzerland  Nick Hayek, the chief executive of the Swatch Group, is facing a problem many of his corporate counterparts might envy: hes doing too much business.

title: Morning Buzz | A Ganges Stand-In in Queens
description: The weather will be a little nasty Friday: partly cloudy skies with a high in the low 50s and rain very likely in the evening and on Saturday.

title: Notes From the Underground | MEN
description: The pop trio MEN, fronted by the former Le Tigre member JD Samson, made a triumphant return home recently with a performance at the Williamsburg Hall of Music. In cheekily full frontal fashion, they opened their set wearing a bright pink, three-helmet contraption that connected the trio with rods into a triangle formation. When not attached at the head with her bandmates, Samson leaped around the stage, enthusiastically leading the frenzied audience through song after song of electronic, danceable fun, and interlacing the carefree tracks with messages of radical politics and feminism.

title: Ensign Resigns, But Details of Ethics Probe May Yet Emerge
description: Senator John Ensigns departure from the Senate, after more than a year of insisting he would not resign but would fight to defend his name, almost certainly marks the end of his political career. But the embarrassing spectacle is not necessarily over for the Nevada Republican.

title: Isuzu Explores Volkswagen Partnership
description: Isuzu Motors, the Japanese vehicle maker, said Friday that it was looking at a potential partnership with Volkswagen AG and other companies, although no definite plans had been made.

title: A Passover Toast to a Rabbi Known for Social Activism, and for Kosher Coca-Cola
description: Rabbi Tuvia Geffen, of blessed memory, was born in Lithuania in 1870 and educated in the renowned Slobodka yeshiva. In the wake of a pogrom, he immigrated to New York in 1903, and seven years later he moved to Atlanta to become the rabbi of Shearith Israel, a tiny and struggling Orthodox congregation meeting in the battered remnant of a Methodist church.

title: Kabul: A Boomtown of Sorts
description: Nearly 10 years after the Taliban were driven from power in Afghanistan, the capital city of Kabul is a patchwork of the old and the remade.

title: Halus
description: An Indonesian term for polite, refined, or courteous.

title: Big Questions, Smart Women, Manns Movies
description: A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. Here they take on questions about reviewing and about character actresses, and pass on an answer from amystery guest.You can write them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: The Rise of the Legal iPad
description: Lawyers are not known for being early adopters of personal technology. Indeed, many are still clinging to  or weeping over  their WordPerfect software.

title: The Art-School Dropout: Kanye West to Play MoMA Benefit
description: It may not compensate for a total lack of dinosaurs, but the Museum of Modern Art is doing what it can to reach out to more youthful patrons: on Friday, the museum said that Kanye West will perform at its annual Party in the Garden benefit, which takes place this year on May 10 in its Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden. Though Mr. West is perhaps better known for his mercurial temperament and widely hailed albums like My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy, he gets modern art cred, too, for working with artists like George Condo (who painted the covers for Dark Twisted Fantasy) and Marco Brambilla (who directed the video for Mr. Wests Power). Youll have to dig up some serious gold if you want to attend the MoMA performance: tickets are $150 in advance and $250 at the door, while V.I.P. tickets (which include special access to a terrace overlooking the garden) are $500. Sounds like someones saving up for stegosaurus bones!

title: Ranks of the Rich Growing in China
description: HONG KONG  Chinas economic boom has made many Chinese very wealthy indeed. A new study by the consulting firm Bain & Company shows just how many  and how rapidly  the ranks of the rich are swelling in this country of 1.3 billion.

title: Pope Speaks of Iraq and Tsunami in First TV Q&A
description: ROME  In his first question-and-answer television appearance, shown by Italys national broadcaster on Friday, Pope Benedict XVI urged the Christian minority not to abandon Iraq and offered his thoughts on euthanasia and the tsunami in Japan.

title: Tension Precedes U.S.-China Meeting on Human Rights
description: BEIJING  The United States and China will have their annual meeting on human rights next week, but there are signs that the session may be more tense than usual.

title: The Evangelical Squad
description: IN a vast, unheated room overlooking Cooper Square in the East Village, Guy Wasko tried to shake off the start-up jitters. It was late March, less than three weeks before the biggest day of his professional life, and there was still so much to do. A financial backer was wavering. The music was a big question mark: was it the right flavor for the neighborhood, funky enough, soulful enough? What about his hospitality team? The members had to be trained, the signs had to be right, the branding had to pop.

title: In the East Village, Grace
description: Trinity Grace Church in the East Village draws on a young crowd seeking a spiritual home.

title: Modern Amusement
description: Michael Elmgreen and Ingar Dragset like to build things up just to knock them down, as in the last Venice Biennale, where they dolled up a pavilion as a house  and then put it up for sale. For The One and the Many, a new installation at the Museum Boijmans Van Beuningens Submarine Wharf in Rotterdam, the Netherlands, they created a boulevard of broken dreams, with an apartment block inspired by East German socialist housing. Visitors will peek into the buildings windows from a Ferris wheel and gawk at the humanity therein, including a middle-aged man watching soccer on TV in a room decorated with trophies, or a teenage boy logged onto a gay-chat Web site. Its like building a Disneyland with less of that feel-good effect and slightly more complex content, they said.

title: Pink and Blue
description: If you are buying clothes for a newborn, what color do you buy? The general rule these days is that girls are more likely to wear pink and boys are more likely to wear blue. But that wasnt always the case. In 1918, an article in Ladies Home Journal advised: The generally accepted rule is pink for the boys, and blue for the girls. The reason is that pink, being a more decided and stronger color, is more suitable for the boy, while blue, which is more delicate and dainty, is prettier for the girl.

title: Friday Reading: Solar Panels Increase Home Values
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: No Deal
description: One of the risks Obama ran by proposing a reasonable and actually fairly conservative budget was that the center would end up being defined as halfway between that reasonable position and the right-wing radicalism of the Ryan plan. And there were particular fears that the Group of Six senators would come out with something along those lines, giving it a lot of political momentum.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Naughty By Nature
description: Thuy Pham and Miho Aoki are big believers in going au naturel. The duo behind the label United Bamboo recently set out to create an eco-friendly line that would give green technology a bit of boudoir appeal. There are many companies putting out clothes labeled as organic, but the fabrics might have been dyed or finished with harsh chemicals, Pham says. Bamboo By, a new collection of camisoles, dresses and smocks inspired by Victorian undergarments, definitely delivers on the sexy front. But as far as organic goes, there is still work to be done. Its a long process and will most likely never be 100 percent eco-friendly, Pham adds, but we encourage our vendors to offer more organic pieces to supplement the nonorganic collections they carry. With current eco lines focusing on ethics as well as design, we look forward to Bamboos commitment to both moral and aesthetic standards.

title: Susan Sarandon on 'Bull Durham'
description: Susan Sarandon narrates a scene from "Bull Durham." She is the subject of a film retrospective at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Feb. 10-13.

title: Susan Sarandon on 'Dead Man Walking'
description: The actress Susan Sarandon narrates a scene from "Dead Man Walking." She is the subject of a film retrospective at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Feb. 10-13.

title: Susan Sarandon on 'Thelma & Louise'
description: The actress Susan Sarandon narrates a scene from "Thelma & Louise." She was the subject of a film retrospective at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Feb. 10-13.

title: The Time It Takes
description: An M.R.I. was a huge ordeal for someone as old and crippled as my mother. The first few times she had them, while still living in Florida, I was not with her; Id asked only afterward about the awful banging and claustrophobia inside that tube. But once I became her regular M.R.I. escort, I found there was so much more to this appointment for her. It came as a revelation to me that these tests are far different for someone in her 80s than for someone in her 50s.

title: April 24  30
description: Theater

title: Police Shoot Man Carrying Fake Gun in Bronx
description: A man armed with what turned out to be a fake gun was shot and wounded by police officers in the Bronx early Friday, the police said.

title: Toyota Recalls 308,000 RAV4 and Highlanders for Faulty Air-Bag Sensors
description: More than three years after Toyota first learned that its curtain-shield air bags could deploy without a crash, the automaker is recalling almost 308,000 sport utility vehicles.

title: Tenet Rejects Community Healths Revised Bid
description: 1:52 p.m. | Updated Tenet Healthcare said on Friday that its board had rejected a revised $3.3 billion takeover offer from Community Health Systems.

title: Penn South Votes Yes on Financing Deal
description: Free market be damned.

title: Back Forty in the City
description: FOR some space- and light-deprived New Yorkers, being able to lean out over even the tiniest sliver of a balcony is enough to make them shout, I am king of the world!

title: Letters
description: Put Down the Phone

title: China Curbs Fancy Tombs That Irk Poor
description: CHENGDU, China  Ever since Deng Xiaoping signaled in 1978 that it was fine to get rich, much of China has seemed hell-bent on that goal. But some local governments would like those who succeed not to lord it over others, at least when it comes to paying final respects.

title: In Chengdu, Burial Is Also an Economic Rite
description: As of last month, in the cemeteries of this hilly megalopolis in south-central China, modest burials are in. Fancy tombs are out.

title: Weekend Competition: Impossible Book Titles
description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting impossible book titles.

title: Dark Knight Returns Page Up for Auction
description: The Dark Knight Returns, by Frank Miller, is one of the seminal stories of the 1980s. Along with Watchmen, by Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons, it introduced a new level of mature storytelling to comic books. And a Dark Knight fan (with deep pockets) now has a chance to own a part of history. The original artwork for the splash page from issue No. 3, which features Batman leaping through the skyline along with his new Robin, Carrie Kelley, the first female to hold that role, is up for bidding at Heritage Auctions. The  bid is currently at $100,000. The page will be on view beginning April 27 at the offices of Heritage Auctions and then at the Fletcher-Sinclair, the home of the Ukrainian Institute of America, from May 1 through the auction on May 5.

title: A Daughter Remembers William Styron
description: Martin Amis, son of Kingsley, once remarked wittily that he had been name-dropping ever since I first said, Dad.  The Amis family, which counted Philip Larkin and Anthony Burgess among its regular guests, had nothing on the Styrons. My parents were invited on a day cruise out of Edgartown harbor with President and Mrs. Kennedy on the Patrick J, Alexandra Styron writes. My father and the president talked about Nat Turner, which my father had just begun. Truman Capote urged William Styron to marry Rose Burgunder (he would have anyway). Peter Matthiessen attended the wedding. James Baldwin stayed with the family in Roxbury, Conn., while writing Another Country. Alexandra  called Albert by her father  remembers Frank Sinatra lathering up in the outdoor shower at their summer retreat on Marthas Vineyard. When James and Gloria Jones, drinkers and swearers, came to visit, Gloria wouldnt let her husband pass the room where little Albert was watching television without snapping, Give her a twenty! Edward Kennedy risked his dignity on Vineyard dance floors. Nothing if not eclectic, Styron also counted Fidel Castro among his acquaintances.

title: Bloomberg Says Computers Will Cut Ticket-Fixing
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Friday that there seemed to be plenty of evidence of tickets being fixed by the police in the Bronx, but he said that a new computer system would make it much harder to get away with such practices.

title: Reader Response: Orchestras Are Over-Extended
description: The news that the Philadelphia Orchestra, founded in 1900, filed for bankruptcy protection under Chapter 11 jolted loose ripples of worry, anguish, anger and lament about the decline of classical music in the United States. One reader, Joseph Swensen, sent in a thoughtful but provocative e-mail. Mr. Swensen is a violinist, conductor and is the founding director of the Utopia Hills Arts Center in Maine. He has served as principal conductor of the Malmo Opera in Sweden and the Scottish Chamber Orchestra. This is an edited version of his e-mail.

title: Royal Ballet Seeks Next Link
description: LONDON

title: Mets Destroy a Mascot, Then the Astros
description: Among the decisive elements that contributed to the Mets most important victory of the season, including the return of Jason Bay, the ejection of Terry Collins, the breakout night for David Wright and even the good-luck uniforms the team wore, was a ceremonial event that happened long before the game started.

title: Westminster Abbey, Scaling Up
description: LONDON

title: Confucius Statue Vanishes Near Tiananmen Square
description: BEIJING  When you have faults, do not fear to abandon them, Confucius once said.

title: Japan Announces Emergency Budget for Rebuilding
description: TOKYO  The Japanese government earmarked almost $50 billion in emergency spending on Friday for the first step in the countrys largest reconstruction effort since World War II.

title: Ice-T, Living Out Loud
description: The flourishing field of hip-hop studies has lately come to resemble a college English department circa 1950. There are canonical studies, like Jeff Changs Cant Stop Wont Stop: A History of the Hip-Hop Generation. Theres a school of New Criticism, devoted to formalist analysis of texts, er, lyrics; its bible is either the much-ballyhooed Anthology of Rap, which codifies hundreds of songs, or Jay-Zs best-selling Decoded, which is lackluster as an autobiography  that feted lyricist proves about as introspective as Tony Montana  but stellar as a work of critical rap reading. And most recently theres Marxist criticism, concerned with dollars and sense: Zack OMalley Greenburgs Empire State of Mind: How Jay-Z Went From Street Corner to Corner Office and Dan Charnass exhaustive yet vigorous book, The Big Payback: The History of the Business of Hip-Hop.

title: Marquee Attractions in Midtown
description: For much of the 20th Century, a stretch of Broadway near Columbus Circle was New Yorks Automobile Row.

title: Bullies in the Burbs
description: Bullying is a topic that seems to push everyones hot buttons (even President Obama recorded his own antibullying message). But while most attention centers on the damage done to kids, Lisa Scottoline, in her latest legal thriller, nimbly homes in on the ordeals inflicted on parents  of both the tormented and the tormentors.

title: Karl Lagerfelds Ice Cream Visions
description: It was a small leap for Karl Lagerfeld to make from photography to filmmaking, and hardly a surprising one for a designer with a penchant for multitasking. Last year, he created a short film for Chanels Web site, called Remember Now, and this year he is following up with a 30-minute movie called The Tale of a Fairy, with Freja Beha Erichsen, Anna Mouglalis, Amanda Harlech and Kristen McMenamy, which will be shown in Cap dAntibes next month during his cruise presentation.

title: Styled to a T | Andrea Trimarchi and Simone Farresin
description: The Designers

title: Three Quarrelsome Sisters Under One Roof Again
description: The three siblings who jointly narrate Eleanor Browns likable but sometimes careless first novel, The Weird Sisters, seem incarnated from birth-order paradigms in a Sociology of the Family textbook. Rose, the oldest, is a faultfinding control freak. Bean, the middle sister, is a promiscuous attention seeker. Cordy, the youngest, simply refuses to grow up. Raised in the idyllic town of Barnwell, Ohio, daughters of loving if distracted parents (Dad lives, breathes and never stops quoting Shakespeare, which he teaches at the local college; Mom prepares delicious if unreliable meals and reads voraciously), the quarrelsome Andreas sisters, as full-grown women, have become self-reproaching, self-described failures. When their mother is told she has breast cancer, they move back to their childhood home, avowedly out of concern but really in search of safe haven.

title: Stoudemire More Likely to Play Than Billups
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Twelve players, from Carmelo Anthony to Roger Mason Jr., were spread across the court, dribbling and skipping from sideline to sideline Friday morning. All of the concern was for two teammates who were not there.

title: Wheelies: The Purse Strings Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Saudi Cut in Oil Production Stirs Speculation
description: With political turmoil spreading across North Africa and the Middle East and oil and gasoline prices rising, all eyes in the energy world are on Saudi Arabia. So when the Saudis announced last weekend that they had cut oil production by 800,000 barrels a day only weeks after they said they would meet any supply gap left by the civil war in Libya, oil analysts offered an array of interpretations.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Nora Roberts & J.D. Robb
description: Nora Roberts, who also writes under the pseudonym J.D. Robb, has had five books on the hardcover fiction list since the start of 2010.

title: Inside the List
description: BITTER TEA: It has been a bad spring for Greg Mortenson, whose Three Cups of Tea clocks its 220th week on the paperback nonfiction list this week.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE PALE KING: An Unfinished Novel,  by David Foster Wallace (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Unfolding on an epic scale, this coherent, if uncompleted, portrayal of our age is a grand parable of late capitalism set in the innards of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Tribeca Q. & A.: Jon Gnarr
description: Jon Gnarr is the subject of the documentary "Gnarr," about his career transition from actor and comedian to the mayor of Reykjavik, Iceland.

title: Paperback Row
description: ILL FARES THE LAND, by Tony Judt (Penguin, $15.) Judt, the author of Postwar: A History of Europe Since 1945 (2005) and a public intellectual known for his sharply polemical essays, died last year at the age of 62. Ill Fares the Land, expanded from a lecture on social democracy Judt gave at New York University in the fall of 2009, passionately argues the notion that the state can play a significant role in its citizens lives without imperiling their liberties.

title: Weekend Fare
description: David Bouleys Japanese restaurant Brushstroke, 30 Hudson Street (Duane Street), is open this weekend. The restaurant has been in the works for years, and a team of Japanese chefs has worked with Mr. Bouley to develop thousands of recipes. Dinner service starts at 5:30 p.m. A preview of the restaurant can be found here.

title: Megabytes From the Motor Show
description: Automakers tend to wait until the end of their press conferences to mete out memory sticks, a tendency that produces unseemly scrums of eager journalists around the press table. While the purpose of the frenzy is securing production photos and other data about a just-revealed vehicle, the storage devices themselves are increasingly part of the mania.

title: In Texas, Questions of Drought and Climate Change
description: The severe drought across Texas has hit the oil and gas city of Midland especially hard, as I reported in Fridays New York Times and Texas Tribune. Since Oct. 1, Midland has received only 0.13 inches of rainfall  making it most likely the driest six-and-a-half-month period in recorded history, said David Hennig, a Midland-based meteorologist with the National Weather Service. With three major regional reservoirs ranging 2 percent to 30 percent full, the city has put in place outdoor watering restrictions  albeit not backed up by penalties  for the first time.

title: The Progressive Budget Alternative
description: Ive been remiss in not calling attention to the budget proposal from the Congressional Progressive Caucus. Its not going to happen  but then neither is the Ryan plan. And unlike the Ryan plan, it actually makes sense.

title: At the Perilous Intersection of Books and Booze
description: The publishing world never promised great riches to its employees, but compensated with good parties. Conversation was lively, the nibbles were exquisite, the company was often exhilarating. And drinks were on the house.

title: How Poets Achieve Their Styles
description: According to conventional wisdom, younger poets are engaged in finding their voices  a process often described in terms that make it seem like a cross between having an epiphany and having an aneurysm. For instance, heres Thom Gunn, in his elegy for Robert Duncan, detailing the emergence of Duncans distinctive talent:

title: Questioning Americas Faith in Air Power
description: When President George W. Bush launched his war against Saddam Husseins Iraq with an incandescent burst of shock and awe, political commentators marveled at the seemingly magical impact of modern air power. Some forecast that, as with the Persian Gulf war of 1991 and the Kosovo war of 1999, airstrikes by the United States and its allies would do most of the work required for an early, absolute victory.

title: Covert Operations
description: War  especially the politics of war  changes everything in a historical mystery. Ever since Anne Perry took her stalwart working-class hero, Thomas Pitt, off the streets of Victorian London and elevated this former police detective to a post in secret intelligence, the books in this series have become more overtly political, making them more exciting, but, frankly, not as much fun. Pitts well-born wife and canny sleuthing partner, Charlotte, says as much in TREASON AT LISSON GROVE (Ballantine, $26). Thinking back to the days when her husband still needed her help to negotiate the closed ranks of high society, Charlotte acknowledges the danger involved in those early cases of scandalous domestic passions and deplorable social evils. But she had loved the adventure of both heart and mind, the cause for which to fight.

title: An Ecologists Surprising Assessment of the BP Spill
description: In April 2010, an explosion aboard the BP drill rig Deepwater Horizon killed 11 workers and caused the worst oil spill ever in American waters. Initially, government officials and BP officers denied the situation was serious. As details of the spill volume, and of damage to Gulf of Mexico fisheries, became known, panic set in. President Obama called the spill the worst environmental disaster America has ever faced; Rush Limbaugh said the event was Obamas Hurricane Katrina; Brian Williams asked on NBC Nightly News if the spill would give off oil unfettered for the rest of our lives on Earth.

title: Simon Schama: The Essayist as Star Writer
description: The essay miscellany, held together not by any overriding theme but by sheer authorial style and personality, was formerly one of the glories of belletristic nonfiction, though it has become rare for publishers today to take the commercial risk of putting out such a collection. They may do it to honor a star writer, who is, paradoxically, often not mainly an essayist, since essayists rarely become stars. Simon Schama  the distinguished historian (The Embarrassment of Riches, Citizens), university professor of art history and history at Columbia, and a television writer and presenter of documentaries for the BBC, PBS and the History Channel, as well as a regular contributor to The New Yorker  is so prominent a figure in our culture that his claims on the publics attention are indisputable. But he has taken the trouble to wrap those claims in a disarming modesty.

title: An Evangelical Pastor Opens the Gates of Heaven
description: In 1868, Elizabeth Stuart Phelps published The Gates Ajar, a novel about a young woman named Mary Cabot whose brother Roy was killed in the Civil War. The bereaved Mary knows that she is supposed to be consoled by her Calvinist faith (personified by a minister with the unsubtle name Bland), but she finds her churchs teachings about the afterlife cold comfort. She does not like picturing her brother single-mindedly adoring God. Mary thinks this sounds dull, and she is horrified by the thought that Roy, in his rapturous concentration on Gods splendor, might forget her, his beloved sister. Through the ministrations of a widowed aunt, Mary ultimately adopts a new vision of heaven  one in which peoples primary end is not union with God, but being reunited with loved ones.

title: A Novel of Britains 60s Generation Growing Up
description: In a novel, E. M. Forster wrote, there is always a clock. In a life, too, of course, in all lives, there is always a clock. Every person, every generation, knows this, but it may be the case that the baby boomers are most keenly affronted by the passage of time, are most ripe for the comeuppance of aging and mortality. All that beautiful youth, all that freedom and hope. Didnt they know that they too would eventually compromise, wrinkle, suffer large and small defeats, seem foolish to their children? In her fifth novel, We Had It So Good, Linda Grant traces the force of time on a group of friends from their hippie days in the Oxford of the late 1960s all the way to the present, through the conventional and unconventional choices they make, the professionals they become, the children they have, the choices those children make.

title: Milan Report | The Wrap-Up, Part II
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#534", 592, 380, true, chameleonData);

title: At First, the Fire Seemed to Be Part of the Show
description: Stephanie Simpson and Laurie Mantor figured it was a street demonstration put on by the artist from the Lexington Avenue gallery opening they had been invited to Thursday evening. Painting With Fire, the show was called.

title: Paula Foxs Miscellany
description: One evening in 1971, my mother and I sat down on opposite ends of the sofa and discovered that we were both reading novels by Paula Fox. My mothers novel, Desperate Characters, was about a woman whose hand has been bitten by a possibly rabid cat. My novel, Blowfish Live in the Sea, was about a 13-year-old girl (I was 10) who idolizes her 19-year-old brother (I had a 19-year-old brother).

title: Bowlers in Brooklyn Enjoy a Haven While Its Still Around
description: Pins clattered to a soundtrack of the Drifters and the Temptations as if it were a half-century ago when Maple Lanes first opened, only without the clouds of smoke.

title: Tribeca Video Interview With Jon Gnarr
description: Last year, Reykjavik, Icelands capital and most populated city, turned to comedy to relieve its economic depression. Jon Gnarr, best known as an actor and comedian in that country, started a new political party, the Best Party, and ran for mayor on a humorous platform that promised to bring Disneyland to Iceland. To the surprise of nearly everyone (including Mr. Gnarr himself), he was elected. A documentary at the Tribeca Film Festival charts the rise of the party and Mr. Gnarrs political aspirations. In this video, he talks about how he got into politics, how he formed his party and why he feels politics needs not be so serious.

title: Red Bulls Agudelo Channels Henry
description: Juan Agudelo, the Red Bulls promising 18-year-old striker, may have found himself on the bench as Coach Hans Backe energized his team by starting Luke Rodgers, but that does not mean Agudelo is not paying attention.

title: Tossing the Royal Bouquet, One Generation to the Next
description: NOTE to the teachers of Lara DiPaolas four children: they will be absent from school on Friday.

title: Up Front: Baz Dreisinger
description: Baz Dreisinger, who reviews Ice-Ts memoir, Ice, in this issue, started writing about hip-hop in the late 1990s.

title: Zombie Tax Lies
description: The claim that only rich people pay taxes is a zombie lie  something that keeps coming back no matter how many times its killed by evidence.

title: Bill OReilly Is On To Me
description: He has figured out that George Soros and I are trying to destroy the economy so that we can build socialism.

title: Euro Benefits Germany More Than Others in Zone
description: THE euro has been very, very good for Germany. Other members of the zone have not fared as well.

title: 17 and (Not) Pregnant
description: To learn about teen parenting, students in health classes across the country carry around eggs, or water bottles topped with tennis balls, and pretend these are babies. As we have discussed before on Motherlode, they dont always learn what you might expect.

title: Habitats | Greenpoint, Brooklyn
description: Deborah Lutzs apartment, furnished with street finds, reflects her keen interest in the 19th century  taxidermy, mourning jewelry and all.

title: Student Crossword | Teen Health Issues
description: Play our crossword (PDF) to see what you know about teen health issues. You can find the answers here.

title: A Nicer Way to Wallow in the Past
description: TESTED 2011 Jeep Wrangler Unlimited Sahara

title: More Ask the Film Critics
description: Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. (In this weeks Arts and Leisure section, they talk about the importance of understanding cultural differences in reviewing movies, the beauty of character actors and the films of Michael Mann.) For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Free Rain Barrels for New Yorkers
description: Its raining barrels.

title: The Week in Pictures, April 22
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: Libya Could Become Stalemate, Top U.S. Military Officer Says
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The top American military officer warned Friday that the conflict on the ground in Libya threatened to become a stalemate, but Obama administration and military officials said that neither the United States nor its allies planned to fundamentally alter the NATO-led air operations despite criticism that they were not doing enough.

title: Her Decorators? Flotsam & Jetsam
description: DEBORAH LUTZ, an assistant professor of English with a passion for the Victorians, lived for a decade in a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. And during those years she did something that the nature-loving Victorians would have understood.

title: The Delectable Pairing of Bread and Soup
description: Many diners enjoy bread with their soup. But in the Mediterranean, its common to serve soups thickened with fresh or stale bread, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Ex-Workers Sue Restaurant; New Law Firm Is Formed
description: Their jobs at the new Hurricane Grill and Wings restaurant in Hartsdale, N.Y., began innocently and positively enough.

title: Master Mind
description: David Lynch is best known as a director, but it was the paintings he made in Philadelphia as a young art student that gave him the idea to make his first film. The work he is showing nearly 50 years later at the William Griffin Gallery in Santa Monica, Calif., straddles both genres  illuminated light bulbs protrude from the canvases, and abstract figures dance across them. The installation includes eerie watercolors and a number of lamplike sculptures. Lynchs proclivity for shape and light drew him to another project, Silencio, a nightclub set to open this summer at 142 rue Montmartre in Paris, for which he designed the interiors and the furniture. I enjoy how architecture and design create mood, he says. The club was named for the spooky theater in Mulholland Drive, so no telling what that mood will be.

title: In a Data-Heavy Society, Being Defined by the Numbers
description: I HAVE a confession to make. I started using Twitter about six months ago and eagerly watched my followers rise  20 to 30 to 40. I made it to 60 and suddenly plateaued  a few would follow and then (heartbreak) unfollow.

title: A Life Digging for Veins of Gold
description: AUSTIN, Tex.

title: Even Vampires Beat Paul Reiser
description: Going from seven to six contestants on Thursday, Foxs American Idol remained as dominant as ever in the ratings with 19.6 million viewers tuning in to the results episode, which also featured a performance by Katy Perry and Kanye West. Twenty-one-year-old Stefano Langone, a soulful singer from Washington, was eliminated after he received the lowest share of 52 million votes cast by fans. According to Nielsens estimates, Fox easily won both the 8 p.m. time slot with Idol and the 9 p.m. hour with Bones (11.1 million). CBS ranked second for the night despite a lineup of repeats including CSI (8.4 million) and The Mentalist (11 million). NBC finished in third as its new sitcom The Paul Reiser Show struggled badly at 8:30 p.m., attracting just 2.5 million viewers and lagging behind even CWs Vampire Diaries (2.7 million). NBCs later comedies fared a bit better with The Office (6.8 million) leading the way for the network at 9 p.m. and Parks and Recreation earning 5.1 million viewers at 9:30. A special hourlong 100th episode of 30 Rock averaged 4.6 million viewers at 10 p.m. ABC was fourth on the night with reruns.

title: Senate Resignation May Not Halt Release of Evidence
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Ensigns resignation letter allows him to leave office just one day before he was to have to answer questions under oath about whether a $96,000 payment to the family of his former lover was illegal and designed to keep the affair from becoming public, according to people familiar with an investigation of Mr. Ensigns activities.

title: Its Love at First Kill
description: THIS is a love story. It began on a hot summer night in Santa Barbara, Calif., when Tamara Langman helped kill the yellow-eyed demon known as Prince Malchezaar. She was logged into World of Warcraft, the multiplayer fantasy game, and her avatar  Arixi Fizzlebolt, a busty gnome with three blond pigtails  had also managed to pique the interest of John Bentley, a k a Weulfgar McDoal.

title: Rowdy Muscularity and Sweet Harmonies
description: The Pretty Reckless

title: Esther Kim and Joseph Varet
description: ITS fitting that Esther Jin Kim and Joseph Rosenwald Varet met because of their support of Performa, an organization in New York that promotes the work of performing artists. After all, these are two people who approach life as a kind of experiential art form.

title: On 11th Avenue, an Auto Boomtown
description: ENERGY efficiency will be top of mind  not only from the cars in the showroom, but even in the buildings air-conditioning system  when the BMW of Manhattan dealership is upgraded next year.

title: At Last, a Celebration of the Sippers
description: IN recent years, the messages delivered at auto shows have often been mixed or garbled, especially during times when oil prices swung wildly. Carmakers floated burly S.U.V.s just as consumers decided they wanted hybrids; hybrids arrived just as consumers decided it was safe to re-up with an S.U.V.

title: The Small Car as a Petit Four
When the Best Shows on Broadway Were the Cars
description: LADDIE STERN stopped in front of a copy shop. This is where I was, he said. Its been a long time.

title: Answers About Red-Tailed Hawks, Part III
description: Watch live streaming video from nytnestcam at livestream.com

title: Across the Web, a Constellation of Alter Egos
description: Lady Gaga

title: Service Held for Combat Photographers and Doctor Killed in Misurata
description: This is an e-mail sent this morning from C.J. Chivers to the editors at Getty Images and Vanity Fair, describing events in Benghazi, Libya, since the remains of Tim Hetherington and Chris Hondros arrived at the Benghazi port Thursday night. Mr. Hetherington, the conflict photographer and director of the Afghan war documentary Restrepo, and Mr. Hondros, one of the top war photographers of his generation, were killed Wednesday in Misurata, Libya.

title: More About Disappearing Fish
description: In my column this week I wrote about the highly troubled state of our oceans  but of course theres more to say. A new study by the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature), for example, suggests that over forty species of fish in the Mediterranean could disappear in the next few years.

title: Hotel Review: Hotel Skeppsholmen in Stockholm
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Vines Thrive Once Again in Moravia
description: IN the Middle Ages, the water was unsafe to drink, so we Moravians drank wine, said Petr Ocenasek, a wine merchant, as he sipped a sauvignon blanc from a long-stemmed tasting glass on the veranda of Vinny sklep u Hrdlicku, a hilltop restaurant and wine cellar in the Mikulov wine region of southern Moravia in the Czech Republic (Mala kozi, Mikulov; 420-777-021-681).

title: Restaurant Review: Gigi, in Miami
description: Many restaurants are born when a chef has a concept. Gigi in Miamis Wynwood district started with a concept in need of a chef. Last year, the restaurants owner, Amir Ben-Zion, placed an ad on Craigslist seeking a chef who could turn out cutting edge, high performance, Asian-inspired and freshly prepared cuisine that is affordable, innovative comfort food for the modern, educated, discerning palate.

title: Rambling With W. G. Sebald in East Anglia
description: ON an August morning in 1992, Winfried Georg Sebald  known as W. G. to the literary world and Max to his friends  set out from his home in Norwich, England, to travel more than 80 miles on foot to the once-important towns and villages around Suffolk County, in East Anglia, a region of expansive wheat fields, green wetlands and medieval churches. Sebald  who died in a car accident in 2001  had lived in this pocket of England with his wife, Ute, since 1970, after leaving his homeland, Germany, as a young man.

title: Louisianas Zydeco Trail
description: I HAD never noticed how closely the syncopated rhythm of zydeco music echoes the rollicking stumble of horses on rough terrain. But on a September afternoon in the piney woods of Evangeline Parish, in Louisianas Cajun country, with hundreds of dusty horseback riders moving down a narrow trail, the kinship was impossible to miss. As the horses followed a tractor towing a D.J. and a zydeco-blaring sound system, they bucked and swayed in a cadence fit for the barroom floors of Lafayette, 70 miles away.

title: Peruvian Chefs Add Flavor to Quito, Ecuador
description: IN 2003, when Santiago Jarrin opened   Theatrum, a restaurant on the second floor of the newly refurbished national theater in Quito, the Ecuadorean capital, he hoped to create a dining destination in the citys Old Town  a long troubled neighborhood then on the verge of a tourist revival.

title: A Party Blooms in Bogot
description: EARLY one evening in Bogot, Colombia, late last year, a tall brunette in her mid-20s, with a Joan Jett shag and in heels, walked with her girlfriends along the desolate streets of La Candelaria, the citys historic neighborhood. A decade ago, when this country was the kidnapping capital of the world, strolling anywhere after dark would have been reckless.

title: Letters: Why We Travel
description: WHY WE TRAVEL

title: In Los Angeles, Small Meets Megamall
description: Small boutiques are setting up shop on the periphery of the Grove megamall in central Los Angeles.

title: The Zydeco Trail
description: Strangers will lend you a horse and hand you a beer at the zydeco trail ride.

title: A Tour of East Anglia
description: Visitors to East Anglia will find beautiful, stark coastlines, castles and cozy pubs.

title: Peruvian Chefs Bring Flavor to Ecuador
description: A Peruvian pedigree gives a chef cachet in Quito restaurants.

title: Look of the Moment | Sienna Miller
description: The Look: A no-brainer  minimal makeup, tousled hair, the perfect LBD and a shoe with some spunk. It all adds up.

title: Breathe Into Your Infringement
description: Youd have to be in a permanent state of savasana (corpse pose) not to realize that yoga is big business. For those of us who relish the little bit of peace and quiet it offers from what sometimes feels like the relentlessness of our days, that can be a bit of a drag. Apparently, the government of India feels the same way. The country recently created a database of 1,300 yoga poses for use by international patent offices, the Times of India reports, apparently in an effort to reclaim the ancient practice from western yoga gurus.

title: Happiest Places Post Highest Suicide Rates
description: Does being around happy people make an unhappy person feel even worse?

title: Winning a Cup? It Helps to Have a Cup Winner
description: Chris Drury, the Rangers center and captain, was talking the other day about the value of having a veteran who won a Stanley Cup on a team chasing another Cup. Drury happens to be one of those players. So is Jason Arnott, the Washington Capitals 36-year-old center.

title: Reassuring Deficit News
description: The Congressional Budget Office is out with a new study that should quell some of the deficit hysteria that seems to be taking over the national discourse. It points out that a major part of the current budget deficit is caused by what it calls automatic stabilizers that respond to economic weakness.

title: For Catholics, Open Attitudes on Gay Issues

title: Ethan Stiefel to Withdraw From American Ballet Theaters Spring Season
description: Ethan Stiefel, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will withdraw from performances with the company this spring. In a statement released by the company on Friday, Mr. Stiefel, 38, said he had decided to withdraw so that he could focus on his duties as dean of dance at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. This is Mr. Stiefels final year as dean. He is to take on the role of artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet in September. Leading the U.N.C.S.A. School of Dance through a critical period of transition has required the type of energy and attention that has kept me from properly focusing and physically preparing for my upcoming performances, Mr. Stiefel said in the statement. I am truly disappointed not to be performing with my colleagues at ABT and for the New York audiences. This season he was scheduled to dance opposite Alina Cojocaru in Giselle in May and Natalia Osipova in Coppelia in June. Mr. Stiefel, who joined Ballet Theater in 1997, has also withdrawn from American Ballet Theaters tour of Japan in July.

title: For Stoudemire, a Two-Front Battle: Back Pain and the Celtics Big Men
description: Amare Stoudemire was the same goggle-wearing, ovation-receiving double-teamed star in appearance only Friday evening at Madison Square Garden. When he moved, pain shot through his back, his performance suffered and the Knicks were blown out, 113-96.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Dates, Heroes and Fairies
description: The new titles in the lists this week are another example of the diversity of graphic novels. Theres literally something for everyone. On the hardcover list is Mister Wonderful, by Daniel Clowes, about the search for human connection as seen through a blind date. The story was originally serialized in the Sunday magazine of The New York Times. Those installments are available here, but the hardcover collection, at No. 1, contains 40 pages of new material. Also on the hardcover list is Invincible: Ultimate Collection, Vol. 6, by Robert Kirkman and Ryan Ottley, who created the critically-acclaimed comic book series The Walking Dead, which became a critically-acclaimed AMC television series. Invincible, at No. 10, is about a young super-hero learning about himself, his father (another super being) and life (college, relationships, work).

title: Prehistoric Cave With a Hornet on the Wall
description: THE director Werner Herzog remembers being about 12 years old when he saw, and was transfixed by, a picture of a horse on the cover of a book about Paleolithic art, displayed in the window of a bookstore in the isolated Bavarian village where he lived. Ever since, even as he was making films like Aguirre, the Wrath of God and Nosferatu, that image has engaged me and haunted my mind, he said. It has never left me.

title: Making Standards Swing, With a Wink for Jack Benny
description: The up-and-coming jazz violinist Aaron Weinstein has two secret weapons. One is a mandolin that he brings out in the middle of a set to change the mood and on which he plays meticulously sculptured arrangements with a sweet plinkety-plink verve. The other is a deadpan sense of humor that he sneaks into his patter. At the Metropolitan Room on Wednesday evening Mr. Weinstein introduced his show, Have Strings, Will Swing, by describing the intimidating piece he wasnt going to perform: a six-movement, 52-minute work inspired by James Joyces Ulysses.

title: The Week in Pictures for April 22
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include art in a bunker, new Coney Island rides and a New York version of the Ganges River.

title: A Warm-Weather Guide to the City
description: The great outdoors calls, and even without counting Central Park, theres a great deal of it in New York City. There are more than 1,700 parks in the five boroughs, according to the citys Department of Parks and Recreation. (Though with the 0.04 acre Septuagesimo Uno Park, on 71st Street between West End and Amsterdam Avenues, on that list, its a number best taken with a grain of asphalt.) Here, a bakers dozens worth of sites to enjoy the warm weather, when it arrives.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
description: Grail Got a Downgrade

title: An Ode to Spring, Whenever It Comes
description: ACCORDING to the calendar, its been spring for the past five weeks. But you could have fooled me. Since the vernal equinox on March 20, the official start of the season, weve had nearly two weeks worth of days on which the temperature has not yet reached above 50 degrees. On average, this spring is two and a half degrees colder than usual. And it has rained almost 20 of those days, making the season thus far 27 percent wetter than in most years (not to mention March 24, the day that shall live in infamy, when there was measurable snowfall).

title: Jaguar E-Type, Still Glamorous at 50
description: Unveiled in North America during the 1961 New York auto show, the Jaguar E-Type, or the XKE as it came to be known in the United States, is regarded among the greatest automotive designs of the 20th century. The Museum of Modern Art in New York added one to its permanent collection in 1996.

title: The Politics of Naps
description: Last month, while reporting my article on sleep, I attended the National Sleep Foundation conference in Washington, where the transportation secretary, Ray LaHood, had been invited as keynote speaker. Instead, another government official presented. Had LaHood been there  and had he attended a couple of the sessions on sleep deprivation and shift work  he might be a bit more sympathetic to the sleepy air traffic controllers who have been in the news.

title: Rumbling and Rambling Amid a Blistering Storm
description: Secret Mountains closed out its Thursday night show at Cake Shop with a furious squall. Beginning with the dry, desert ache of High Horse and swelling into Golden Blue, the band built the rush one piece at a time  lonely, aerated guitar; firm bass; jangling tambourine; keyboards adding thickness; and a second guitar, more frenzied than the first, slashing through everything else, abrasive and urgent.

title: Truckers Protest, Adding to Chinese Fears of Unrest

description: In Sundays Automobiles section, James Barron revisits a section of Broadway in Midtown Manhattan once know as Automobile Row, where a thicket of neon signs advertised brands like Chrysler and Ford, as well as some that are all but forgotten. Mr. Barron writes:

title: In a Tale of Deliverance, Its Moses to the Rescue
description: Immediacy is the goal of the Passover Seder, commemorating the biblical story of the Jews deliverance from slavery in Egypt. Through the retelling of that story and the explication of rituals and symbols, Seder participants are supposed to become convinced that the Exodus happened to them. Tradition relates that the wicked child asks on Passover, What does all this mean to you?, distancing himself from what should be utterly personal.

title: At Gaumont in France When All Was Possible
description: TWO years ago Kino International offered Gaumont Treasures: 1897-1913, a three-disc set adapted from a superb seven-disc collection, Gaumont: Le Cinma Premier, issued by the French studio that is probably the oldest continuing filmmaking concern in the world. Gaumont struck again with a second volume, and now Kino has imported and adapted that anthology under the title Gaumont Treasures, Vol. 2, 1908-1916. For anyone interested in how the movies came to be what they are, its essential viewing.

title: A Registry Explores Dog Deaths by Breed
description: Most dog owners and veterinarians know that small dogs live longer than large ones, but until now there has been no thorough systematic examination of breed-related causes of death.

title: Big Bangs Echoes, 50 Years Later
description: The legacy of Impulse Records has hardly lacked for commemoration. The label keeps repackaging albums, even as its parent company, the Verve Music Group, slouches away from instrumental jazz. Five years ago Ashley Kahn published The House That Trane Built: The Story of Impulse Records (W. W. Norton), an aficionados history and, in essence, a corporate biography. This week brought the release of a CD boxed set, First Impulse: The Creed Taylor Collection (Hip-O Select/Verve), that gathers the six albums produced for the label by its founder, under the banner of a 50th anniversary.

title: Brutal Battles and Raging Melodrama
description: A lack of familiarity with the byzantine history of China during the Warring States Period, from the fifth to the third centuries B.C., is a handicap when it comes to following the story of The Warring States, which is extremely loosely based on parts of that history. The writer, Shen Jian, and the director, Jing Chen, have made no concessions to the non-Chinese viewer in their compressed, chaotic narrative.

title: Swirling Tensions, Surging Passions
description: Since 1961, the estimable Young Concert Artists, which celebrates its 50th anniversary this season, has offered performance opportunities, mentorship and management to promising musicians, mostly solo instrumentalists and singers. Ensembles, including the Tokyo String Quartet in 1970 and the Borromeo String Quartet in 1991, are also sometimes recruited.

title: Sacred Vivaldi, Somber and Elegant
description: During the early part of his career Vivaldi mostly wrote instrumental works, which were often tempestuous and virtuosic. In his mid-30s, while working as a music teacher at a girls orphanage in Venice, Vivaldi (nicknamed the Red Priest because of his hair) was commissioned to write a Stabat Mater, probably his first sacred piece.

title: This Sunday: Feast on Riff
description: By now, I trust youre familiar with our Riff column. In the print magazine, its easy to find  the blue pages in the back. Though the visuals are more subdued than the rest of the magazine, this is a place for readers to have fun, a playground for critical writing, as well as a showcase for the exceptional talents of writers like Sam Anderson, Heather Havrilesky and, this week, Carina Chocano, former film critic at The Los Angeles Times and the author of Do You Love Me Or Am I Just Paranoid? title: The Memory of Holocaust, Fortified
description: SKOKIE, Ill.  Before the $45 million Illinois Holocaust Museum & Education Center opened here two years ago, there was some urgency in completing its 65,000-square-foot building, which now stands so incongruously monumental in the midst of Chicagos suburban landscape. At one time, 7,000 Jews bearing the scars of the Holocaust had lived in Skokie with their families, and they were aging. Many had contributed artifacts to the museum; some participated when it was just a storefront on Main Street; some had their oral histories recorded for its exhibition and their lives chronicled in the institutions imposing companion book, Memory and Legacy.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: A Shuttle to Be Proud Of
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Attitude Toward Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Banning Cluster Bombs
description: To the Editor:

title: Upscale Looks, With a Down-Home Feel
description: CEDAR CREEK American Bar and Grill in Glen Cove is the newest venture of the Mims Restaurant Group. Its older siblings, Mims in Syosset and Mill Creek Tavern in Bayville, are both casual neighborhood spots. Cedar Creek, which opened in early March, is much larger and more upscale-looking.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: St. Cloud State Second Baseman Takes Reins of His Hometown
description: LORETTO, Minn.  The late-afternoon baseball practice was over and Kent Koch, the second baseman and senior captain at St. Cloud State University in central Minnesota, was in a hurry.

title: As Old as Stairs, a Thief Who Is Comfortable With Heights
description: Somebody broke into a ground-floor apartment at 176 Thompson Street in Greenwich Village, home to tenants in their 30s and their obligatory gear, and got away with three laptops, a mobile phone and an Xbox. And a taste for adventure, for from there, he moved up, and in doing so joined a particular rank of thieves who have lurked above the streets of New York ever since the installation of the first flight of stairs.

title: Try Some Cheese?
description: When Fawn Nebinger ran a gallery several years ago, she named it after a favorite kind of flower. The moniker, Foxglove, has lingered on, even as her business evolved from paintings, to bath and beauty items, to cheese.

title: Bistro Fare That Pleases Appetite and Wallet
description: OF the many Italian restaurants in this state, Sal e Pepe in Newtown, a contemporary Italian bistro that Angelo Marini opened in late 2005, is one of the better ones  largely thanks to its chef, Carlos Pineda, a Guatemalan who honed his Italian cooking at Sole in New Canaan.

title: A Cheese Movement
description: The name American Cheese might suggest processed slices wrapped in plastic, but thats the last thing youll find in this charming shop in West Sayville.

title: Warding Off Hunger, and the Evil Eye
description: SEEN from the parking lot in the nondescript strip mall where Cinnamon Indian Restaurant sits wedged between the Kosher Korner Deli and the Eastern Dental Family Practice in Morris Plains, the restaurants giant orange sign beckons like one of those epically unhealthy fast-food joints you might find at a highway rest stop. But inside, the sweet aroma of Indian spices signals a vastly different experience.

title: Macarons of Her Own
description: Keum Sook Park is as nonchalant about making macarons, the delicate French filled cookies  not to be mistaken for chewy coconut macaroons  as you would expect from an alumna of Payard Patisserie and Bistro in Manhattan. Macarons are easy and fast to make, said Ms. Park, 44, who opened Sook Pastry in Ridgewood, a French-inspired bakery and cafe, in March.

title: The Disappearing Family Doctor
description: Dr. Ronald Sroka has practiced family medicine for 32 years in a small red-brick building just six miles from his childhood home, treating fishing buddies, neighbors and even his elementary school principal. But doctors like him are a dying breed, as rising health care costs are driving thousands of doctors in small private practices out of business, reports Gardiner Harris.

title: Mets Dont Just Blame Their Tools, They Beat Their Toolbox to a Pulp
description: The order to destroy Stanley, the rolling toolbox that had become a bullpen mascot for the Mets in spring training, came right from the top. Jeff Wilpon, the Mets chief operating officer, who is in charge of the daily operations of the team, ordered the demolition Thursday as a way to turn around the teams atrocious luck.

title: A 150,000-Pound Hand-Me-Down. Yay?
description: Imagine that someone offered to dump 1,100 busted washing machines onto a prime piece of riverfront property in Midtown Manhattan, pitching the idea as a potential tourist draw and educational attraction. New Yorkers are smart. Many  perhaps even most  of them would say: Are you kidding me? Youre just looking for an easy way to get rid of 150,000 pounds of junk.

title: The Family Practice
description: Changes in the health care landscape have left Dr. Ronald Sroka with a family practice he cannot sell.

title: Meet the Extreme Hobbyists
description: These hobbyists dont just accumulate memorabilia, they define their existence by it. Occasionally, they overdo it, and thats just fine with them.

title: Family Physician Cant Give Away Solo Practice
description: CROFTON, Md.  So there we are, miles from shore, fishing since 11 oclock at night, and we havent gotten one single bite until finally we gaff one thats about this big.

title: Ex-Blackwater Guards Face Renewed Charges
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Friday reopened the criminal case against four former American military contractors accused of manslaughter in connection with a shooting that killed at least 17 Iraqi civilians in Baghdad in 2007.

title: Refusing to Surrender to the Dark Side
description: The specter of doom pervaded the Mets clubhouse on Friday, but not for the reasons you might think. R. A. Dickey brought a full Darth Vader costume to Citi Field, complete with helmet and voice modulator, and he wore it around the locker room, startling teammates and attendants.

title: Alabama: Guilty Plea in Bribery Scheme
description: Ronald E. Gilley, who was developing an entertainment and casino complex in southeastern Alabama, pleaded guilty in federal court in Montgomery on Friday to participating in a bribery scheme that has led to the arrests of powerful businessmen, lobbyists and four state lawmakers. Two of the lobbyists who worked for Mr. Gilley have also pleaded guilty. Mr. Gilleys plea leaves nine remaining defendants, including the four lawmakers and a racetrack owner, Milton McGregor, one of the states top campaign donors.

title: Police Shoot Man Holding a Fake Gun
description: A man armed with what turned out to be a fake gun was shot and critically wounded by police officers in the Bronx on Friday after he refused orders to drop it, the police said.

title: Judge Approves Bonus Plan for Executives of the Borders Group
description: The Borders Group won approval of an amended executive bonus plan after a judge sought changes to resolve objections from the federal agency that oversees bankruptcies.

title: Camouflaging Price Creep
description: The Easter special at many retailers this year involves higher price tags.

title: Amazons Trouble Raises Cloud Computing Doubts
description: As technical problems interrupted computer services provided by Amazon for a second day on Friday, industry analysts said the troubles would prompt many companies to reconsider relying on remote computers beyond their control.

title: In Medias Wedding Frenzy, Hints of Viewer Fatigue
description: LONDON  When Prince William and Kate Middleton emerge from Westminster Abbey as a married couple next Friday, they will be greeted by hundreds of reporters from around the world. But as the day draws near, there are signs that the media frenzy may outpace interest in the United States, and some disdain is appearing among the British as well.

title: Sleep at Work? Not for Them
description: AARON BYRD

title: Staying Sharp in Wee Hours, Unlike Some Air Traffic Controllers
description: PHILADELPHIA  At 2 a.m. Friday, in a cavernous 24-hour fitness center here, Bobby Boyle, the owner of Boyles World Gym, sprinted across a basketball court and then hit the weight machines when he felt his energy sag. Lonely for companionship, Mr. Boyle, who works the graveyard shift, started up a conversation (mostly one-sided) with the gyms mascot: his 22-year-old macaw, Terese.

title: Spring City
description: The long-awaited demise of an extraordinary winter has released a pent-up spring. The days are longer and softer. Flowers are opening, the birds are back and the courting season has begun in earnest. Springs sprung and New York City is giddy with it. I imagined every structure in every borough suddenly being freed from its stodgy, frozen-at-right-angles shackles as well. Straight lines are for winter. Spring is all about curves and things that wiggle and grow  like everything in Spring City.

title: 13 Years Later, a $2 Million Award
description: In March 1998, a 6-week-old girl named Shannell Coppage died of malnutrition even though she had been regularly breast-fed by her mother in their Park Slope, Brooklyn, home. Her mother, a 21-year-old named Tatiana Cheeks, was arrested and charged in the infants death, prompting an outcry from womens health advocates.

title: Cuomos Home? The Address Says One Thing, the Map Another
description: NEW CASTLE, N.Y.  When asked last fall to name his favorite restaurant, Andrew M. Cuomo picked a popular diner in the middle-class Westchester County suburb of Mount Kisco.

title: Royal Wedding Wine May Be Bubbly and English
description: DITCHLING, England  In January, Michel Roux Jr., a London chef who is on the tasting committee that recommends wines to be served by the royal family, made a suggestion that would have been unthinkable not long ago. Wouldnt it be nice, Mr. Roux asked a reporter for The Telegraph, if at the wedding reception for Prince William and Kate Middleton the glasses were filled not with Champagne but with English sparkling wine?

title: Washington: First Ladys Plane Was Warned of Turbulence
description: The air traffic controller who sent a jet carrying Michelle Obama too close to an Air Force cargo plane on Monday did warn the pilot of the passenger jet to beware of the bigger planes wake turbulence, the National Transportation Safety Board said Friday. The radar controller handed off the two planes approaching Andrews Air Force Base to a tower controller with only 3.08 miles between them, instead of the five required when a VIP jet, a military version of a Boeing 737, is following a heavy cargo plane. The radar controller incorrectly told the jets pilot that they were four miles apart, the safety board said. The tower controller told the jets pilot to follow an S pattern to increase spacing, but the planes actually got closer  to 2.94 miles apart  as the cargo plane slowed for landing. Mrs. Obamas jet was instructed to break off the approach and return for another try.

title: Wanna Buy a Turnpike?
description: Right now youre probably asking yourself: How are all the angry new governors doing?

title: Hobnobbing From the Ground Floor Up
description: As a private cocktail party clinked and murmured on the first floor of the David H. Koch Theater, home to the New York City Opera and New York City Ballet, on Thursday night, we felt a glimmer of what it must have been like to be a gladiator on the floor of the Colosseum. On the tiers above the party we were attending, operagoers not invited to the private reception hung over the balustrade. They watched the hobnobbing of guests like Kristin Chenoweth and Isaac Mizrahi as if it were theater. One rapt spectator even ate a snack.

title: Mubarak Faces More Questioning on Gas Deal With Israel
description: Persistent public suspicions about corruption and mismanagement that swirl around Egypts secretive deal to sell natural gas to Israel prompted Egypts public prosecutor on Friday to extend the questioning of former President Hosni Mubarak for 15 days, judicial officials said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 22, 2011

title: Sewers, Swaps and Bachus
description: Let me tell you a story about Jefferson County, Alabama, whose county seat is Birmingham, and whose congressman is Spencer Bachus, the Republican who chairs the House Financial Services Committee.

title: Lewis Binford, Leading Archaeologist, Dies at 79
description: Lewis R. Binford, one of the most influential American archaeologists of the last half-century and an early advocate of a more scientific approach to investigating ancient cultures, died on April 11 at his home in Kirksville, Mo. He was 79.

title: Lies and Videotape
description: FACEBOOK, Twitter and other social media have revolutionized the global press landscape, helping to dislodge dictators in Tunisia and Egypt and foment protests in Bahrain and Syria.

title: New Jersey Transit Worker, Fired After Burning Koran, Wins Back His Job
