description: After Matthew Greenberg had spent 18 years as a New York City teacher, he wanted a school of his own and decided to try opening a charter.

title: Risks Aside, Ticket-Fixing Has Persisted for Decades
description: In 1951, police officers in Manhattans 20th Precinct were investigated for sabotaging paperwork to kill traffic citations, as favors for politicians. In the middle of the inquiry, the ledger recording all the precincts summonses mysteriously disappeared.

title: In Sing Sings Hometown, Many Dream of Day the Big House Closes
description: OSSINING, N.Y.  In economically ailing communities in upstate New York, residents and lawmakers are bracing themselves for bad news: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos list of prisons that will be closed to save money.

title: English-Language Press Flexing Its Muscles in Eastern Europe
description: KIEV, Ukraine  Brian Bonner, the editor of The Kyiv Post, a small English-language newspaper here in the Ukrainian capital, received the first phone call even before his journalists had returned from their interview with the minister of agriculture. Other calls followed, growing increasingly shrill.

title: Early Birds Less Likely to Catch the Birdies
description: Do you love being the first one on the golf course? Are you delighted to send that first tee shot into the glow of a rising sun?

title: In a Place of Fragile Alliances, a Romance Endures
description: ALBANY  Spring is in the air in the capital. A budget is in hand. Lawmakers have fled for their districts. And Jeffrey D. Klein has taken a State Senate colleague, Diane J. Savino, home to meet mom.

title: Daffy Blonde Gets Wise to Washington
description: A piercing squawk ricochets around the theater, followed by bright peals of girlish giggling. In counterpoint comes a rumbling bellow at a volume requiring no help from the electronic listening devices that are almost as ubiquitous as cellphones in Broadway theaters.

title: A Trial Run for School Standards That Encourage Deeper Thought
description: Until this year, Ena Baxter, an English teacher at Hillcrest High School in Queens, would often have her 10th graders compose papers by summarizing a single piece of reading material.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Civic Group Says That Concessions Are Needed From the Construction Unions
description: A prominent civic group has joined builders and real estate executives in calling for major concessions from the unions that dominate the construction industry, saying cuts are needed to allow major projects to move forward.

title: Holiday Parking Rules
description: Because of the seventh and eighth days of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday and Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: One Size Fits Nobody: Seeking a Steady 4 or a 10
description: In one store, youre a Size 4, in another a Size 8, and in another a Size 10  all without gaining an ounce.

title: Scuffle Over On-Demand Movies Portends Battles to Come
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood is picking sides for its first all-out brawl since its writers labor feud in 2007. And oddly, Christopher J. Dodd, once a powerful senator from Connecticut and now the film studios chief spokesman, has mostly been out of the fray.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 24, 2011

title: The Battle for Libya
description: Rebel leaders said they had consolidated their control of the western city of Misurata on Sunday, taking over the last two government outposts there even as government forces continued to shell the city from its outskirts.

title: A Fight Over How Drugs Are Pitched
description: Before pharmaceutical company marketers call on a doctor, they do their homework. These salespeople typically pore over electronic profiles bought from data brokers, dossiers that detail the brands and amounts of drugs a particular doctor has prescribed. It is a marketing practice that some health care professionals have come to hate.

title: DVRs Give More Shows a Lifeline
description: The digital video recorder was supposed to lay waste to network television. Instead the playback device is offering some shows a lifeline  so much so that network programmers now factor in ratings a full week after a shows scheduled appearance.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 23, 2011

title: Knicks Replay: April 24
description: Images from Game 4 of the Knicks-Celtics playoff series.

title: The Travel Channel Invests $7.5 Million in Oyster.com
description: The Travel Channel may inspire a viewer to book a weekend on Marthas Vineyard or a getaway to Monaco. But when that trip is taken, the transaction fees wind up in some other pocket.

title: Filtering the Social Web to Present News Items
description: SAN FRANCISCO  News events as varied as the commercial jet landing in the Hudson River and the uprisings in Egypt have demonstrated that people armed with cellphones  not professional reporters  are often the first source of breaking news, uploading Twitter posts, photos and video to the Web. But the result can leave people drowning in too much information.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Tales of Reading in Reintroducing a Color Device
description: TILL rhymes stop rhyming, and pots stop boiling, a voice-over says, by hook or by crook, by book or by nook.

title: The Governments Guide to Assessing Prisoners
description: These three documents were designed to guide military intelligence interrogators and analysts at Guantanamo as they attempted to assess what detainees had done in the past and what risk they might pose in the future. The Assessment of Afghanistan Travels  which lists the online encyclopedia Wikipedia as one source  offers background on Afghanistan and Islam and examples of how some detainees may have been trained to resist interrogation. The two Threat Matrix documents were aids to gauging whether a prisoner, on release, might pose a a high, medium or low risk to American interests.

title: A Popular Wrinkle in Denim Shopping
description: Buoyed by a run on denim, sales of womens apparel rose 2.8 percent over the three months ending in February, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm. That is as much growth as the category showed during all of last year.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include new home sales for March (Monday); the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller housing price index for February and consumer confidence for April (Tuesday); durable goods orders for March (Wednesday); gross domestic product for the first quarter and initial jobless claims (Thursday); and personal income and spending for March and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for April (Friday).

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Odd Man Out at Sea
description: ITS been in place for nearly 30 years; nearly 160 countries (plus the European Union) have signed it. But the United States has yet to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.As a result, the United States, the worlds leading maritime power, is at a military and economic disadvantage.

title: Former Senator Dodd Reaches Out to Washington Press Corps
description: Last week, members of the press and others got an invitation to a Washington cocktail and hors doeuvres reception from the Motion Picture Association of America, of which Christopher J. Dodd is now chairman, to honor what it called our member company White House correspondents.

title: Word of the Day | suture
description: suture \s-chr\ noun/verb

title: Ads Suggest Allergy Relief at the Pump
description: If you have a sore throat and runny nose because of allergies, chances are you do not want to spend a lot of time beside a gasoline pump. But if you find yourself there, a new digital advertising campaign for Halls aims to convince you  with the aid of real-time pollen-count forecasts  that you should buy its cough drops.

title: Couric Is Expected to Say Shes Leaving CBS
description: This week, Katie Couric is planning to acknowledge one of the worst-kept secrets in television: that she is leaving the CBS Evening News after five years. Then, as soon as she returns from London, where she will be anchoring the networks coverage of the royal wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday, CBS will announce her successor during the first week of May.

title: Maryland Renames Law School After Donation
description: William Polk Carey need not worry about people forgetting his family name any time soon.

title: Taliban Help Hundreds Tunnel Out of Prisons Political Wing
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The Taliban staged an audacious prison break here early Monday, freeing at least 476 political prisoners through a long tunnel, according to the warden, Gen. Ghulam Dastagir Mayar.

title: Hornets Hold Off Late Lakers Attack to Even Series
description: NEW ORLEANS  The day before their fourth playoff game against the Lakers, the Hornets watched a video, shot at Kruger National Park in South Africa, of a cape buffalo calf being attacked by lions, who dragged it near a water hole where a crocodile joined the assault.

title: News Quiz | April 25, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries in todays paper.

title: Meet Buffetts Bodyguard
description: Every time Warren E. Buffett strolls through the crowd, shakes someones hand or takes a question at the annual Berkshire Hathaway shareholder meeting this weekend, Dan Clark and his staff will be there.

title: Test Yourself | Math, April 25, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article Its Tracking Your Every Move and You May Not Even Know.

title: Avatars in Love
description: WHERE did Tamara Langman and John Bentley meet?

title: NATO Strikes Qaddafi Compound
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  NATO warplanes struck Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis compound here early on Monday and also bombed a state television complex in an escalation of the air campaign to aid the rebellion against his four decades in power.

title: Taliban Breach Afghan Prison; Hundreds Free
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Taliban leaders carried out an audacious plot on Monday to free nearly 500 fighters from southern Afghanistans largest prison, leading them through a tunnel dug over more than five months and equipped with electricity and air pipes, which suggested that the insurgents remained formidable and wily opponents despite recent setbacks.

title: Deadly Blaze Tears Through Beijing Clothing Factory
description: BEIJING  A fire at a clothing factory in southern Beijing killed at least 17 persons and injured 24 more before more than 200 firefighters extinguished the blaze early Monday, a state news service reported.

title: Why Do Doubts Persist About Where President Obama Was Born?
description: Last week, a New York Times/CBS News Poll found that 45 percent of Republicans think that President Obama was born in another country, even though Hawaii state officials have repeatedly confirmed that the president was born in Honolulu. Why do you think doubts about Mr. Obamas status as a natural-born citizen of the United States persist despite factual evidence?

title: Syria Escalates Crackdown as Tanks Go to Restive City
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian Army stormed the restive city of Daraa with tanks and soldiers and helped detain dozens in towns across the country Monday in an escalation of the crackdown on Syrias five-week-old uprising, according to residents and human rights activists. They said at least 25 people had been killed in Daraa, with reports of bodies strewn in the streets.

title: Doooooooooooooh!
description: The Stanley Cup has a long and storied history of being dinged and dented and hilariously abused by its holders, but it may have been outdone Thursday by the Copa del Rey trophy in, literally, one fell swoop.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Cam Newton, Third-Ranked Quarterback
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: At London Museum, Fonts and Other Designs
description: The Design Museum is neither as big nor as famous as Londons other museums, but its well-organized exhibitions and pretty location overlooking the Thames make it an interesting detour. And two current shows provide an added incentive for lovers of design.

title: Great Little Magazines
description: For years, Robert Scholes, a professor in the department of modern culture and media at Brown University, has led a project to put Modernist journals online, which means you can have access to many of the periods wonderful journals without beinga student at a university with great archival holdings. So far, Scholes and his team (which includes Sean Latham at the University of Tulsa) have digitized 18 magazines: all 47 issues of The Freewoman and all 13 of The New Freewoman, an early feminist journal that espoused free love; the first nine volumes of the Little Review, which published 13 episodes of Joyces Ulysses, before being forced to stop due to obscenity charges, and, under the aegis of Pound as foreign editor, such writers as Djuna Barnes, Gertrude Stein and T.S. Eliot; the two issues of Wyndham Lewiss vorticist zine Blast; the more visualRhythm, which published several designs for the Ballets Russes, among them Laprs-midi dun faune; as well as such well-known journals as Scribners Magazine. Currently, the MJP is working on digitizing The Crisis, the journal founded by W.E. B. Dubois for the then fledgling N.A.A.C.P. It ran from 1910 to 1924, with many hiatuses, but had an unusually wide audience for a little magazine: its circulation peaked at 100,000.

title: Jimmy Carter and Other Ex- Leaders to Travel to N. Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Former President Jimmy Carter arrived in North Korea on Tuesday, news agencies reported, for talks aimed at reducing tensions on the fractious Korean Peninsula.

description: BANGKOK  Sharp rises in food prices are a threat to economic growth in Asia and could push millions of people into extreme poverty, the Asian Development Bank said in a report to be released on Tuesday.

title: Willis Ave. Bridge Goes the Way of All Metal
description: Wanna buy a bridge? Youre too late. The 110-year-old Willis Avenue Bridge was floated to a Jersey City junkyard last week where it is being dismantled to be sold for scrap.

description: Julia Moskin, a reporter in the Dining section of The New York Times, walked up to my desk, with a glint in her eye, and said, I have a dish for you!

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Review Jerusalem
description: Readers reviews of Jez Butterworths new play Jerusalem, which opened on Broadway on Thursday night, were sharply divided. While Mark Rylance received almost across-the-board praise for his portrayal of the carefree, trailer-dwelling Johnny Byron (a performance Ben Brantley called seismic), many readers said the script failed to match its stars wattage. Following are excerpts of selected reviews on NYTimes.com.

title: Caf des Artistes Is Back, as Leopard des Artistes
description: Gianfranco and Paula Bolla Sorrentino, who own Il Gattopardo in Midtown, took no time deciding to acquire the Caf des Artistes when George and Jenifer Lang announced in August of 2009 that they were closing it  after nearly 25 years. Now, after a mega renovation, including expert restoration of the nine Howard Chandler Christy murals, Fantasy Scenes with Naked Beauties, that were painted from the late 1920s to 1935, the restaurant is poised to open on May 2 as the Leopard at des Artistes.

title: War, Wives and a Near Suicide
description: If you are reading this, you should know that I am dead, began the blog of a 27-year-old Army wife named Jessica Harp. At least I hope Im dead, she added. It would be awful to fail at your own suicide.

title: In Chaos, a Moments Repose
description: Philip Scott Andrews, 24, graduated from Western Kentucky University in 2010. He has been an intern at The Associated Press and National Geographic, and is now at the Washington bureau of The New York Times. He is working on a long-term project, Last Days. His conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

title: India Arrests Former Chief of Commonwealth Games
description: NEW DELHI  Investigators here arrested the former chief organizer of the scandal-marred Commonwealth Games on Monday, after uncovering what they said were irregularities in the awarding of contracts for the international sporting event.

description: NYTD.hotSpotsFactory.createMap("map1", 592, 630, false, chameleonData);

title: Speaking of International Money (Wonkish)
description: Aha  no sooner do I suggest that the craziness associated with discussions of international money has now shifted to money in general than I see Steve Pearlstein writing a column about global economics that I agree with halfway through, but that veers off into a misplaced focus on the international role of the dollar as the key concern. Now, Pearlstein isnt crazy the way the goldbugs are  but he does seem to share the common tendency to exaggerate the importance of owning a global currency.

title: Oprahs Dream: A Role on Broadway
description: Calling all theater producers: Oprah Winfrey is hot to make her Broadway acting debut.

title: Reaction to The Guantanamo Files
description: In a package of articles called The Guantnamo Files, a team of my colleagues reports today on the release of more than 700 classified military documents that provide new and detailed accounts of the men who have done time at the Guantnamo Bay prison in Cuba, and offer new insight into the evidence against the 172 men still locked up there. The Guantnamo files were part of a huge trove of documents leaked last year to the anti-secrecy organization WikiLeaks. They were made available to The New York Times by another source on the condition of anonymity. National Public Radio and the British newspaper The Guardian are also producing reports based on the documents. Read more about the background in this Note to Readers.

title: Venture Capital Firm Greycroft Partners Expands Team
description: The venture capital firm Greycroft Partners announced on Monday the addition of three senior executives.

title: Tribeca Q&A: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye
description: Love may come in many forms, but it has never quite taken the shape seen in Marie Losiers documentary The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye, which makes its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival on Monday. This film chronicles the lives of Genesis P-Orridge, the experimental artist and musician from the bands Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV, and her partner, Lady Jaye, who expressed their unity by becoming near-duplicates of each other. The art experiment, in which the couple underwent plastic surgery to create a single, androgynous sexual identity, began in 2003, and continued even after Lady Jaye died in 2007.

title: Thinking About Macroeconomics
description: Not all readers of this blog have been reading it consistently for the past few years, and as I read some of the comments its clear that many people dont know where Im coming from on macro issues. So it may be worth reiterating a point Ive made before  that Ive actually been very consistent on this stuff, and that theres a simple model underlying almost everything I write about macro.

title: The Crucial Question for the Rajaratnam Jury
description: The jury in the insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam has begun its deliberations on Monday after eight weeks of hearing witnesses, listening to recorded telephone conversations and reviewing e-mail messages, charts, stock analyst reports and even PowerPoint slides.

title: Commenting Rules
description: A number of people have complained that the troll or trolls (they may be the same person, and in any case are presumably paid operatives) are degrading the tone of the comments. I agree  I suspect that theyre responding to the growing readership of this blog despite their best efforts to drag it down by getting ever uglier. To be fair, some of the supportive comments have also gotten too ugly for the Times. So while there wont be any banning of commenters, Im going to try to delete comments whose tone goes over the line.

description: The market for new homes is so depressed that even a rebound last month did not keep it from being the slowest March on record.

title: Three Are Killed in Bronx Fire
description: Updated, 1:06 p.m. | A 12-year-old boy and his parents were killed when a two-alarm fire raced through the second floor of a row house in Belmont in the Bronx early Monday, fire officials said. Neighbors said that the parents, a 36-year-old man and a 40-year-old woman, left two younger children, who escaped with only minor injuries.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: Roger Lowenstein writes in Newsweek about the new spotlight on Warren E. Buffett: It is tempting to idealize such a figure, and Buffett is partly to blame, at times glossing up his image as a prairie sage. When he feels threatened, he is not above a little dissembling. This is a minor flaw, but a flaw all the same. Read more

title: Justices Reject Request for Fast Health Law Ruling
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday turned back an unusual request from Virginia to put the states challenge to the new federal health care law on a fast track. The courts one-line order offered no reasoning, and there were no noted dissenting votes.

description: Chris Paine, whose 2006 documentary Who Killed the Electric Car? admonished General Motors for taking a not-so-metaphorical wrecking ball to the automakers EV1 electric-vehicle program, has returned with Revenge of the Electric Car. The film had its premiere on Saturday in New York during the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: Alan Champion, Sign-Language Interpreter for Theater, Dies at 55
description: Alan Champion, a sign-language interpreter who opened up hundreds of Broadway and regional theater productions to deaf and hard-of-hearing audience members over the last three decades, died on Friday in Ramona, Okla. He was 55.

title: Joan Peyser, Bernstein and Gershwin Biographer, Dies at 80
description: Joan Peyser, a prolific and lively writer about classical music whose biographies of Pierre Boulez, Leonard Bernstein and George Gershwin generated debate in music circles, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Superheroes Swoop In to Aid the Citys Real Protectors
description: Unlike the heroes of DC Comics, who hang out in cities named Gotham, Metropolis and Central, the heroes of Marvel tend to protect New York. So it only makes sense that Spider-Man, Captain America and Thor have teamed up with the citys real-life protectors.

title: Larry Kramer Hand-Delivers His Latest Message
description: Are you the playwright? the young woman asked the bearded, bespectacled older man who was handing out fliers on Sunday night under the marquee of Broadways Golden Theater. Indeed he was: At age 75, after decades trying to find a bigger platform than Off Broadway for his messages, Larry Kramer is making his Broadway debut with The Normal Heart, his autobiographical work from 1985 about the AIDS crisis in New York City.

title: Prognosis: Testosterone and Prostate Cancer
description: Doctors have long held that men with prostate cancer should not be given testosterone because the hormone might fuel tumor growth. But a small study adds to evidence that the fear may be overblown, at least in patients without evidence of recurrent or metastatic disease.

title: Risks: Television Time and Childrens Eyes
description: Children who spend more time in front of television and computer screens and less in outdoor physical activity have narrower blood vessels in their eyes, a new study has found.

title: Childbirth: More Labor Interventions, Same Outcomes
description: Hospitals vary considerably in the frequency with which they induce labor and perform Caesarean sections. But a new study finds that these differences do not seem to affect how newborns fare in these facilities.

title: A Broker Who Never Forgets
description: Renters and buyers who have used Matthew Berkson, a Citi Habitats real estate broker, marvel at his memory. He has near-total recall of information he picked up in conversations years ago, like what amenities a client does and does not need, what people do for a living and even, in one case, what a clients mother did for a living 30 years ago.

title: Farrell and Houston Troupes Headed to the Joyce
description: The Suzanne Farrell Ballet and Houston Ballet, troupes not often seen in New York, are among the companies scheduled to appear at the Joyce Theater in 2011-12. In addition to regulars like Garth Fagan Dance, Momix and Complexions Contemporary Ballet, and flamenco and tango performances, the season will feature a Martha Clarke work, Angel Reapers, created in collaboration with the playwright Alfred Uhry (Nov. 29-Dec. 11), and the return of a Christopher Wheeldon-less Morphoses, with the premiere of Bacchae, from the companys new resident artistic director, Luca Veggetti (Oct. 25-30). The Houston dancers will bring a new work by Jorma Elo (Oct. 11-16), while the Washington-based Farrell company will be dancing an all-Balanchine program (Oct. 19-23). More information is available at joyce.org.

title: MoMA Design Program to Promote Rethinking of Housing in Light of Foreclosure Crisis
description: Five teams of architects will rethink housing in American cities and suburbs in light of the foreclosure crisis in a 14-month program to be announced on Monday by the Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1.

title: Spymasters Flash Their Green Bona Fides
description: The Central Intelligence Agency is famously tight-lipped about its activities, from directing drone strikes in Pakistan to interrogating prisoners at Guantnamo Bay. But it is trumpeting what its doing to go green.

title: A Bright Future for English Sparkling Wine
description: It was as gently gorgeous as any wine region Ive visited, although looking around you would never know it was a wine region at all. Verdant pastures dotted with cattle and sheep, interspersed with bursting bluebells and fields of rapeseed shimmering with yellow flowers all spoke colorfully of an economy dependent for centuries on the annual rhythms of agriculture. But the landscape said little of wine.

title: Reopening of Blackwater Case Confuses Iraqi Victims
description: BAGHDAD  Shortly after a court in Washington reopened manslaughter cases against four American military contractors in the killings of 17 Iraqis here in September 2007, Beraa Sadoon stood in the square where the episode occurred, nervously shaking as he tried to make sense of the case.

title: Bold Type | Sofa Sanchez Barrenechea
description: It is fairly safe to assume that Sofa Sanchez Barrenecheas apartment is the only one in the West Village with a floor-to-ceiling view of Patagonia. Sanchez Barrenechea, a 25-year-old graphic designer who grew up in Buenos Aires, decorated an entire wall with a mural she created from a photo of the lake where her family spent their summers. Its the first thing I see when I wake up, she says. The rest of the apartment is best described as urban eclectic  furnished with things scavenged from flea markets or, in the case of a favorite chair, found on the street. An art director at Lloyd & Company working with beauty and fashion brands, Sanchez Barrenechea nearly had a career as a model, but shes more content to operate behind the scenes. Friday nights when Im bored, I play with Photoshop, she says.

title: Nissan Recalls 196,000 Pathfinders and Infiniti QX4s for Rust Condition
description: Nissan is recalling almost 196,000 Pathfinder and Infiniti QX-4 S.U.V.s because corrosion can cause part of the front suspension to collapse, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

description: Ginger is often touted as a treatment for nausea, but does it work on morning sickness?

title: Guantnamo Files: Answers to Readers Questions
description: Reporters and editors of The New York Times are answering readers questions about The Guantnamo Files, The Timess coverage of a trove of more than 700 classified files, obtained last year by the anti-secrecy organization WikiLeaks, about past and present detainees at the American military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. The documents were made available to The Times by another source on the condition of anonymity.

title: Predators Make History With Playoff Advance
description: Score one for the unheralded Nashville Predators. Theyre through to the second round of the N.H.L. playoffs after efficiently dispatching the Anaheim Ducks in six games. The Predators won, 4-2, Sunday, to advance.

title: A Generations Vanity, Heard Through Lyrics
description: A couple of years ago, as his fellow psychologists debated whether narcissism was increasing, Nathan DeWall heard Rivers Cuomo singing to a familiar 19th-century melody. Mr. Cuomo, the lead singer and guitarist for the rock band Weezer, billed the song as Variations on a Shaker Hymn.

title: First-Round Frights
description: There is nothing quite like first-round playoff panic. It happens when a heavily favored team, built over the long haul for the championship push, finds itself bedeviled by an upstart underdog. And sure, its going on in Los Angeles as the Lakers search for the proper rolled-up newspaper with which to swat the Hornets in an N.B.A. playoff series they are inexplicably not leading, but the Lakers have absolutely nothing on the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Excerpt: 'The House of Blue Leaves'
description: Edie Falco, Ben Stiller and Jennifer Jason Leigh in a scene from the Broadway revival of John Guare's 1971 play. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: Books by and for Autistic Children
description: April is Autism Awareness Month, and given the increase in the number of children with autism spectrum disorders (the rate is in constant dispute, but some estimate that A.S.D. affects as many as 1 in 110 children), a stack of new books for and about autistic children is to be expected.

title: Law Firm Backs Out of Defending Marriage Act
description: 3:45 p.m. | Updated Speaker John A. Boehner has vowed to defend the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act, but the law firm the House hired to lead that effort has withdrawn amid pressure from gay rights groups.

title: Turkey Spends Freely Again, and Some Analysts Worry
description: ISTANBUL  Is Turkeys booming economy ripe for a fall? It certainly looks that way.

title: For a Sex Survey, Privacy Goes a Long Way
description: It is not easy to ask people about their sex lives, and getting honest answers may be even harder. But there are ways to do it. One good method is to have a computer ask the questions, while the interviewee listens through earphones and enters the answers on the screen  without the intervention, or even the presence, of another human.

title: For the Record
description: Indie record shops generally look like Championship Vinyl, the music-geek hangout owned by John Cusack in High Fidelity, which is to say the closest they get to dcor is the album covers on the wall. Everyone asks why we dont have records on the wall, says Ian Marshall, the co-owner, along with his wife, Jade Gordon, of L.A.s Wombleton Records. Its like its some sort of requirement. But when we opened the store we knew wed be spending a lot of time here and thats not really the kind of environment we wanted to be in. Instead, the couple has created a used-record shop that resembles a Victorian parlor, right down to the embossed wallpaper and potted plants. Marshall, a self-described Anglophile who grew up outside of Toronto but spent his school holidays visiting family in Britain, wanted the Highland Park store to have an English feel, a conceit that extends to its name, a play on the popular British childrens books (and later a BBC series) about the Wombles. To get Wombletons 19th-century ambience just right, the couple spent hours trawling eBay for vintage furniture and prevailed upon friends like David Donohue, a graphic designer and surf board builder who made the harpsichord-shaped record bins, and Nic Taylor and Jennifer Brandt-Taylor of Thunderwing Press, who created the stores logo, a stagecoach on LP wheels. Which is very apt, Marshall says. We spend a lot of time in foreign countries, driving around in rental cars looking for records. But perhaps the most refreshing quality about Wombleton is its lack of snobbery. Unlike Barry and Dick (Jack Black and Todd Louima), the musical moron twins who staffed Championship Vinyl, Marshall and Gordon, who stock an eclectic mix of British pop from the 60s, 70s and 80s, wont deride your taste. Im a bottom feeder, Marshall says, laughing. I like crap. Im not afraid to buy the 50-cent disco album that nobody wants.

title: After 3-0 Deficit, Blackhawks Believe
description: CHICAGO  The Blackhawks began the N.H.L. playoffs as the longest of long shots to defend the Stanley Cup title they won last season, ending a 49-year drought that was the longest in hockey.

description: A profile in New York Magazine.

title: Lawsuits Dont Lead to Better Nursing Home Care
description: We tend to think of a lawsuit as a kind of slingshot allowing the little guy to take on a daunting Goliath  a large nursing home chain, say. If you cant persuade a facility to provide proper care, if your elderly relative has suffered unnecessarily as a result, then you can sue.

description: TOP STORIES

title: Affordable Ways to Improve Your Culture
description: As Ive built TerraCycle, one of my priorities has been maintaining our unusual company culture. While I dont believe in overdoing it  we have no pool tables, yoga studios or climbing walls  I have found a few affordable yet surprisingly effective ways to build morale and have some fun.

title: Excerpt: 'Die Walkre'
description: Bryn Terfel and Deborah Voigt in a scene from Robert Lepage's new production of Wagner's opera at the Metropolitan Opera. (Video courtesy of the Met.)

title: The Road to Romneycare
description: Yglesias looks at calls for a return to something like the McCain health plan  subsidies for individuals to buy insurance on the open market  and gets it exactly right: once you think seriously about how this would work, you end up with something that looks very much like the health reform we have.

title: Jury Deliberation Begins on Fate of Galleon Chief
description: John Marshall Mantel for The New York TimesRaj Rajaratnam, left, arriving at court with his lawyer, John Dowd.

title: For New Jersey School Budget Votes, Tempers and Tax Rises Ease
description: Little drama. Limited tax increases. Fewer draconian cuts.

title: Banning Barbie
description: Ah, Barbie. Fixation of generations of little girls. And their mothers  but for different reasons.

title: In Thailand, Love of Food Carries Deadly Risks
description: LAWA, THAILAND  The villagers in this poverty-stricken farming community are passionate about their food, especially the traditional varieties of fermented fish that one aficionado describes as tasting like heaven but smelling like hell.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Art Directors Club, New York, announced that four people would be inducted into the A.D.C. Hall of Fame for 2011. They are: Ruth Ansel, an art director, designer and lecturer; Marshall Arisman, a painter and artist who is chairman of the M.F.A. degree program at the School of Visual Arts; John C. Jay, partner and global executive creative director at Wieden & Kennedy; and Joe Pytka, the commercial director and filmmaker. Also, Paola Antonelli, senior curator of the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, will receive the A.D.C. Manship Medallion in special recognition of curatorial excellence.

title: Q. & A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q. (Reader)

title: N.C.A.A. Says Tressel Hid Violations
description: The N.C.A.A. delivered its notice of allegations of violations in Ohio States football program, singling out Coach Jim Tressel for his failure to report possible infractions when he learned his players were selling autographs, championship rings and apparel to the owner of a tattoo parlor in Columbus, Ohio.

title: Warning, Warning: Alternate-Side Returns Wednesday
description: As the Passover season draws to a close, we need to clear something up about the 11th plague, also known as alternate-side parking rules. They are suspended Monday and Tuesday.

title: Who Made Those Colors?
description: Hot pink, bright blue and fluorescent green, among other vivid tones, denote a palette reminiscent of psychedelic posters, subversive fashion and the majority of all things created between 1980 and 1989. Although fluorescent colors exist naturally with certain minerals, it wasnt until the 1940s that those colors were developed so that they could be seen as vividly during the day as they could under an ultraviolet light.

title: Cheerwine TV Ad
description: TV commercial that is part of a new national campaign for Carolina Beverage's Cheerwine soda.

title: Campaign Says Cheers to Expanding a Regional Favorite
description: For years, ads for Blackglama mink have asked, What becomes a legend most? Now, a regional soft drink with big expansion plans hopes a campaign will help it attain legendary status.

title: HSBC Drops Out of Retail Banking in Russia
description: MOSCOW  HSBC on Monday became the latest foreign bank to pull out of retail banking in Russia as large state-owned banks have come to dominate a business that had been expected to provide a rich growth opportunity for foreign institutions.

title: High School Classes May Be Advanced in Name Only
description: More students are taking ambitious courses. According to a recent Department of Education study, the percentage of high school graduates who signed up for rigorous-sounding classes nearly tripled over the past two decades.

title: Beyond the Climate Blame Game
description: 4:15 p.m. | Updated On the tiny patch of American public discourse reserved for the global warming debate (to get an idea of how tiny, find climate, or the environment for that matter, in this news map if you can), a week of blogitation over a sprawling report examining failed efforts to pass a climate bill has started to give way to constructive discussion.

title: Thyroid Fears Aside, That X-Rays Worth It
description: It doesnt take much to scare people when it comes to cancer, especially when the cause, unlike smoking, seems beyond ones control.

title: Nostalgia Wrapped In Steel
description: Architecture is a notoriously slow profession. Mastering all the elements that go into designing a building  scale and context, material and form, the structure needed to hold the building up  takes a lifetime. And clients investing millions of dollars in a project tend to feel safer around someone with a little gray around the temples.

title: RBS Executive to Join Bank of America
description: Jennifer Hill, a top executive at the Royal Bank of Scotland and a former Goldman Sachs managing director, will soon become the chief financial officer for Bank of America Merrill Lynchs investment bank, according to people familiar with the decision.

title: On First Day Back, Injured Spider-Man Performer Says He Cant Wait to Fly Again
description: Christopher Tierney, who fell 30 feet off a platform while performing in December in Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, flashed a wide smile and displayed not a hint of nervousness as he met with the media on Monday outside the stage door of the theater where Spider-Man is playing. It was his first day back in the show.

title: Study of Vision Tackles a Philosophy Riddle
description: If a blind person were suddenly able to see, would he be able to recognize by sight the shape of an object he previously knew only by touch? Presented with a cube and a globe, could he tell which was which just by looking?

title: The School of Ohne Titel
description: Jessica Yuen is the 25-year-old designer behind Bedford Street Laundry. Genevieve Fernety, also 25, designs Agamic with her partner Mikey Wydra. Yuen gravitates toward the architectural but with a feminine touch, as in a crisscrossing vest or body-conscious corset with a flouncy skirt. Fernetys line, which is unisex, is built on pieces like color-blocked jersey leggings and track jackets. So what do the two designers have in common? They both interned for Flora Gill and Alexa Adams of Ohne Titel, finalists for last years CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Award. I was mentored by Ingrid Solomonson, Adams says. She took me under her wing in the same way that we do with our interns. It allows you to learn so much and pushes yourself to creatively express your ideas.

title: NYSE Euronext: A Fight About Cost Savings
description: 5:49 p.m. | Updated

title: Less Sex for the Young
description: A new report on sexual behavior in America has a surprising finding: teenagers and young adults are having less sex. The report comes from researchers at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention:

title: TimesCast | Prison Break in Afghanistan
description: April 25, 2011 - Alissa J. Rubin reports on a prison break in Kandahar Afghanistan, where the Taliban helped hundreds of political prisoners escape.

title: All About the Invidious Irritants That Irk Individuals
description: If theres anything I cant stand, its somebody kicking the back of my chair. That, and the public clipping of fingernails. And loud gum chewing. Oh yes, and the neighbors muffled stereo, and people who are habitually late, and there are actually 20 or 30 other little problems I have with the world at large. But now on to you.

title: Mary Berner Is Out at Readers Digest
description: After four years as president and chief executive of Readers Digest Association, Mary Berner has been replaced by the companys chief financial officer, Tom Williams, who was appointed by the board of directors. The announcement on Monday follows a previous announcement a week ago of a new board of directors at the parent company RDA Holding Company.

title: Watching for the Galleon Verdict
description: Legal experts contend that if Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire co-founder of the Galleon Group, is convicted, it will have little if any impact on the culture or practices of Wall Street.

title: On Our Radar: Migrating Songbirds Vanish in Britain
description: British ornithologists record dramatic declines in the population of songbirds migrating from Africa. Since 1995, the number of turtle doves arriving in spring has dropped by 71 percent, while nightingales have declined by 53 percent. The reason for the losses is unknown, but scientists suspect that land-use changes could play a leading role. The real problem is that there are so many different possible causes for these losses, which makes it difficult to tease out the factors involved in their decline and to prepare plans to put things right, a scientist says. [The Guardian]

title: Tribeca Video Interview: Jerry Ensminger
description: The documentary Semper Fi: Always Faithful follows Jerry Ensminger, a retired Marine who served in the military for 25 years. After his daughter died of a rare leukemia at the age of 9, Mr. Ensminger sought to learn the diseases cause, eventually discovering that there were contaminants in the water at Camp Lejeune, the military base in North Carolina where he lived when his daughter was born. His research found that the water had been contaminated for a 30-year period between 1957-1987. The documentary, being shown at the Tribeca Film Festival, tells his story as as he works to gather more details about the water contamination and to reveal the issue to those affected, to Congress and to the public at large. In this video, Mr. Ensminger discusses how he found out about the incident, what some of its effects have been and his struggle with the Marine Corps to get a resolution.

title: Chinese State Media, in a Show of Openness, Print Jet Photos
description: BEIJING  The J-15 Flying Shark is Chinas newest attack jet, a sinuous fighter with the folding wings, shortened tail cone and bulked-up landing gear it needs to serve on Chinas first aircraft carrier, which is expected to start sea trials soon. It is indisputable evidence of Chinas growing mastery of military technology.

title: Where to Lose Weight on Vacation
description: Many people gain weight on vacation, but some destinations offer travelers a chance to shape up and slim down.

title: Whats New at the M.T.A.? Higher Prices!
description: Whats new? the Metropolitan Transportation Authority asks in its new marketing campaign  the perpetually beleaguered transit agencys latest attempt to turn around straphanger sentiment.

title: Barbour Decides Against Presidential Run
description: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi said Monday that he had decided against seeking the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, an announcement that instantly shook up the partys field of candidates and set off a scramble among rivals to court donors who had been planning to support his candidacy.

title: The Living Is Easy
description: NYTD.hotSpotsFactory.createMap("map2", 592, 750, false, chameleonData);

title: A Tire Engineers Tips for Better Gas Mileage
description: Gas is nudging toward $4 a gallon or more in some parts of the country. You can search online to find the cheapest gas in your town. But you also can take steps to boost your mileage, says Forrest Patterson, lead engineer on Michelins most fuel-efficient tires. He spoke with me this week and shared some tips for squeezing as many miles as possible out of increasingly pricey tanks of gas.

title: On the Market: Thinking Critically About Advertising
description: Overview | How are food and beverage marketers blurring the line between advertising and entertainment to engage young consumers, and why does this concern nutrition experts and childrens advocates? To what extent are product-related games, quizzes and apps making children both recipients and tools of marketing? In this lesson, students consider various forms of advertising, then keep logs of the ads and other branded content they encounter in a specified period, and reflect on their experiences with marketing.

title: At New York Auto Show, Telematics Are No Longer a Sideshow
description: If the innumerable demonstrations at the New York auto show were any indication, nearly every new car will be a connected car in the coming year. But while most automakers telematics systems employ an in-dash LCD screen with similar graphics and services, a more distinctive picture emerges behind the displays.

title: TimesCast | The Future for Guantnamo
description: Following the release of classified assessments of Guantnamo detainees, Rebecca Corbett and Scott Shane discuss the prison's future.

title: The King of Fruits Commands Respect
description: Why dont Americans eat more mangoes? Often called the king of fruits elsewhere in the world, the mango is not high in calories, and it is an excellent source of beta carotene, vitamin A and potassium. Now is the time to get acquainted with them: although theyre in season from January to August, mangoes peak in May and June.

title: Tribeca Q.&A.: Jerry Ensminger
description: Jerry Ensminger, the subject of the documentary "Semper Fi: Always Faithful," discusses his fight to uncover the truth about a water contamination incident at a Marine Corps base camp.

title: Without His Mothers Milk, a Haitian Boy Is Lost
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  I had just sat down after spending most of the morning and the early afternoon in the outpatient clinic at Bernard Mevs hospital here when one of the surgeons came in and said: Youre a pediatrician, right? Theres a kid at the front gate whos pretty sick.

title: Hotels Spruce Up Their Executive Lounges
description: The hotel lounge was once a simple affair, offering a television, perhaps, and a small buffet to its regular customers. But as business travel has started to pick up, and revenue along with it, a number of major hotel brands are once more turning to sprucing up their executive club lounges, making them more residential in feel and providing healthier food and improved technology like free Wi-Fi.

title: Migrating Sea Turtles Pick Up More Pollution
description: One of the many threats loggerhead sea turtles face is man-made pollution, but the extent of the risk is a question. To begin to look for the answer scientists have measured contaminants in the blood of a group of adult male turtles and tracked their migration along the Atlantic Coast.

title: Heavens! Fake Tickets Showing Up at Book of Mormon on Broadway
description: In one of the least welcome signs of the success that the musical The Book of Mormon is enjoying on Broadway, representatives said on Monday that counterfeit tickets had been sold to and presented by theatergoers on at least five different occasions in recent weeks.

title: Instability Is Worsening in Southern Sudan
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The persistent violence in southern Sudan has killed more than 150 people in the last week alone, the regional government said on Monday as it continued to struggle to control its own territory less than three months before independence.

title: As the World Turns
description: Q. Do the shifts of the Earths axis produced by earthquakes alter world weather?

title: Schieffer Appointed to Oversee Dodgers
description: 12:53 a.m. | Updated

title: Its Too Soon to Celebrate
description: Deutsche Brse and NYSE Euronext shouldnt feel too proud of themselves for pulling around $145 million more of cost cuts from their magic merger hat. The increase might allow the German exchange to sweeten its offer to help fend off a higher joint bid from Nasdaq OMX and the IntercontinentalExchange. But it also suggests the NYSE and its partner grossly underestimated their aggressive rivals  and perhaps other salient challenges.

title: Height: Very Poor Women Are Shrinking, as Are Their Chances at a Better Life
description: The average height of very poor women in some developing countries has shrunk in recent decades, according to a new study by Harvard researchers.

title: For Netflix, Higher Earnings and a Milestone
description: 4:49 p.m. | Updated | Netflix now boasts more subscribers than any other video service in the United States.

title: School Vacations Make Broadway Box Offices Work Overtime
description: Last weeks school vacations were a boon for Broadway, with an unusually high numbers of musicals  11  each earning more than $1 million in ticket sales, according to box-office data released by the productions on Monday. Over all, Broadway shows grossed $28.9 million, up from $23.9 million the week before.

title: In Fighting Anorexia, Recovery Is Elusive
description: Dr. Suzanne Dooley-Hash believes that she will never fully recover from the anorexia that has plagued her since she was 15 years old.

title: Digging Deeper, Seeing Farther: Supercomputers Alter Science
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Inside a darkened theater a viewer floats in a redwood forest displayed with Imax-like clarity on a cavernous overhead screen.

title: UBS Tech Banker Returns to Credit Suisse
description: Another UBS banker has decamped the Swiss bank, in this case a technology specialist returning to his old firm.

title: Plans for Hughes Change After a Setback in His Throwing
description: Phil Hughes is a baseball player with an insightful mind, quick with an answer for everything, from hockey trivia to episodes of The Office to his own pitching motion. But now, Hughes is stumped, and so are the Yankees.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Afghanistan and Delaware.

title: Delaware Chief Judge Chandler Retires
description: 9:11 a.m. | Updated The chief judge of the Delaware Chancery Court, William B. Chandler III, has announced that he will retire at the age of 60 after 26 years of service on the Delaware courts.

title: M.I.T. Media Lab Names a New Director
description: For centuries diplomas have been synonymous with the nations universities.

title: Closet Cases | Inside the Coveteur
description: Erin Kleinberg and Stephanie Mark are the Toronto-based closet peepers behind the blog the Coveteur. Since they went live, this past fashion week, Kleinberg and Mark have granted fashion obsessives entree into the closets of clotheshorses like the model/D.J. Harley Viera Newton and Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, Lincoln Centers director of fashion. Here, T turns the tables on the duo and takes an exclusive look behind their closet doors. View interactive feature >>

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Libya, Afghanistan and Delaware.

title: Andrew Carmellinis Dutch Is Set to Open
description: Andrew Carmellini, who built his reputation doing French food at Caf Boulud, then went on to explore Italy at A Voce and now at Locanda Verde, describes his latest project as American  not modern and not new, he said.

title: Debating Species Law and Climate Change
description: Theres a great discussion under way at the Room for Debate blog examining whether the Endangered Species Act is the right tool for the job in limiting losses from human-driven climate change.

title: John Taylor and the Zombies
description: Via Brad DeLong, I see that John Taylor is peddling the zombie claim that there has been a huge expansion in the federal government under Obama.

title: Epsilon to Acquire Aspen Marketing Services
description: The Epsilon unit of Alliance Data Systems said Monday it had agreed to buy Aspen Marketing Services, the largest privately held marketing services agency in the United States, for at least $345 million.

title: Music Performance: Marlon Rabenreither
description: A performance at Ryan McGinley's recent opening.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Last Picture Show'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Peter Bogdanovich's film about the end of an era in a small Texas town.

title: With Trump in News, Show Stays Strong
description: Benefiting from buzz about Donald Trumps possible White House bid, the latest installment of NBCs Celebrity Apprentice remained strong in the ratings on Sunday night. According to Nielsens estimates, the reality show attracted an average of 8.1 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m., up from 7.7 million a week ago and tied with ABCs Desperate Housewives (9.9 million) as the nights top-rated show among viewers 18 to 49. Although CBSs made-for-TV movie Beyond the Blackboard earned slightly more viewers in the same time period (8.5 million), the audience for The Apprentice grew by more than 2 million from its first half-hour to its last. But in total viewers for the night NBC trailed in third place, struggling with Dateline at 7 (4.3 million) and Americas Next Great Restaurant at 8 (3.6 million). CBS led over all thanks to 60 Minutes (10.3 million) and The Amazing Race (9.3 million), while ABC placed second, broadcasting new episodes of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 8 (7.8 million) and Brothers & Sisters at 10 (6.6 million). Fox was a distant fourth, earning 5.5 million for an encore showing of The Simpsons Movie.

title: Imprint for Chopra
description: The guru and best-selling author Deepak Chopra will run his own small imprint at Random House, called Deepak Chopra Books, the company said on Monday. Dr. Chopras imprint will be part of Harmony Books, the division of the Crown Publishing Group (itself a division of Random House) that publishes books on health, wellness and spirituality. Using his broad network of contacts, Dr. Chopra will initiate, recommend and submit roughly six nonfiction books each year, Crown said in a statement. Crown is the publisher of many of Dr. Chopras own books.

title: Out of Doors Lineup
description: The Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival will open on July 27 with Billy Bragg, the British punk-folk musician, and the United States premiere of his Big Busk, in which he invites audience members to sing as well as play along on their own guitars to some of his most popular songs, Lincoln Center announced. Mavis Staples, above, who won her first Grammy Award in February after a career spanning more than 50 years, will follow with a performance on July 31. Mr. Bragg and Ms. Staples recently traveled the West Coast together on their Hope, Love and Justice Tour. Another Grammy winner, the flutist and composer Robert Mirabal, will accompany the premiere of a new work by the interdisciplinary artists and dancers Eiko and Koma. Water, a site-specific work commissioned by Lincoln Center, will take place in the Paul Milstein reflecting pool in Hearst Plaza. The festival, which will present more than 100 free performances in Lincoln Centers plazas through Aug. 14, will feature other collaborations, including The Big Easy, a work from the Trey McIntyre Project, a dance group, and the Preservation Hall Jazz Band, from New Orleans; Ponderosa Stomp: Shes Got the Power!, a celebration of the girl groups of American pop music in the 1950s and 60s; and Prophets of Funk, a world premiere from the choreographer David Dorfman and musicians from the band the Family Stone. A full schedule of events is at LCOutofDoors.org.

title: A Passion for Nature, and Really Long Lists
description: Dinochelus ausubeli was the name conferred earlier this year on a strange deep sea monster, a lobster discovered off the Philippine coast whose right claw is elongated into a fearsome pincer. The new species was named not after its discoverer, but in honor of the person under whose auspices a fleet of 540 ships from 80 nations has found the lobster and 6,000 other new marine species in the last 10 years.

title: Wheels: Telematics Are No Longer a Sideshow
description: John R. Quain visited the New York auto show and filed this report on car technology:

title: Dorothy and the Tree: A Lesson in Epistemology
description: At one point in The Wizard Of Oz, Dorothy (Judy Garland) picks an apple and the tree she picks it off protests: Well, how would you like to have someone come along and pick something off of you? Dorothy is abashed and she says, Oh, dear  I keep forgetting Im not in Kansas, by which she means shes now entered an alternate universe where the usual distinctions between persons and objects, animate and inanimate, human beings and the natural world that is theirs to exploit do not hold. In Kansas and, she once assumed, everywhere else, trees are things you pick things off (even limbs) and persons are not. Persons have an autonomy and integrity of body that are to be respected; trees do not. A person who is maimed has a legal cause of action. A tree that has been cut down has no legal recourse, although there may be a cause of action (not, however, on behalf of the tree) if it was cut down by someone other than the owner of the property it stood on.

title: Post-Mortem on Madoffs Fraud While Scandal Is Still Quivering
description: By 1992 at the latest, and probably by 1987, Bernard Madoff had started the largest Ponzi scheme in history, whose existence was revealed only in December 2008 when, amid the devastation of the global financial crisis, Mr. Madoff ran out of money, confessed and was turned in by his dumbfounded sons. The frauds collapse revealed paper losses of over $60 billion, cash losses to investors of over $20 billion and the hollowness of a financial industry idol.

title: Piecing Together the True Cost of Flying
description: FOR the last two weeks, Ive been complaining about the fees and surcharges that some hotels add to the bill for things like maid service, bellhop availability and landscaping. But travelers have also been telling me to look harder at the fees the airlines are busily conjuring up.

title: At the Controls, While the Pilot Takes a Break
description: I FLY a lot for business, but one incident I cant forget happened many years ago.

title: New CDs
description: COLD CAVE

title: If Only All We Wanted Was Expert Advice
description: I have a dishwasher problem thats lasted several years. Here are the symptoms: every fourth or fifth wash, the dishes come out much dirtier than when I put them in. You can see little black flecks of something when you hold a glass against the light. My theory is that the problem lies in the pipes downstream from the dishwasher  once in a while, perhaps something makes the dirty dishwater kick back and mess up the dishes.

title: Sonos Music System Comes to Android
description: Sonos, the heralded music system that allows users to send music tracks to units placed throughout the house, has long had a soft spot for Apple. Apps developed for both the iPhone and iPad allow Sonos owners to choose which music theyd like to have streamed from their PC or the Internet, and control the volume of that music on each device independently.

title: Strumming Solo, With the Reverb of a Full Band
description: I feel a rumblin in her ground, Neil Young sang, alone onstage at Avery Fisher Hall, playing his Gretsch White Falcon, sounding the low notes of a strummed chord, muting them a little with the heel of his hand. The song was generally about planet earth but could have been specifically about where he stood. As he struck those low notes, the metal fixtures in the room talked back: the exit signs, the lighting plates and possibly the balcony railings all rattled like rivets in a cymbal.

title: Yahoo Buys TV Chatting Technology
description: Friends inevitably dissect their favorite television shows when they are out together. When online, they often do much the same by posting messages on Facebook or Twitter.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Last Picture Show
description: While coming-of-age films often look at the pain and disappointment that come with growing up, A. O. Scott sees something more in his Critics Pick this week, The Last Picture Show, directed by Peter Bogdanovich. The 1971 film explores the passage of time and fleeting youth, but it also connects these feelings to a particular moment in history and the gradual disappearance of a way of life, Mr. Scott says.

title: Was Gareth Bale the Best Choice as Player of the Year?
description: The decision by the Professional Footballers Association to award Tottenhams Gareth Bale its player of the year award has muddied the waters about what this once prestigious trophy actually represents, about who votes for it, and most of all about how it was just won by a player who performed well for about two months and may not even be the best midfielder on his team.

title: What Annoys You?
description: What do you find particularly annoying? Is it the person who pushes his airline seat back into your lap? Or perhaps its the crying child at the wedding or the woman putting on her makeup while driving?

title: A Century-Old Love Story With Fire as a Backdrop
description: The brief eyewitness accounts of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire interspersed throughout Triangle are terse, fragmentary, awful. A handful of survivors and bystanders recount the ghastly events that resulted in 146 deaths a century ago. These are by far the most powerful moments in Jack Gilhooley and Daniel Czitroms historical drama. They also make up maybe 5 percent of the play.

title: Sony PlayStation Network Still Down After Attack
description: Gamers who use the Sony PlayStation Network were unable to connect to the service on Monday, the fifth consecutive day of interrupted service, after it was infiltrated by hackers last week.

title: A 21st-Century Water Forecast
description: The broad-brush conclusion of a new federal report on the future impact of climate change on water in the West is a bit familiar. Throughout the West, there will be less snow, and what snow there is will melt faster. The dry Southwest is going to get drier, and the wet Northwest wetter, as a diagram in the report (above) shows.

title: N.F.L. in Limbo as Owners Try to Preserve Lockout
description: A federal judge gave N.F.L. players a significant victory Monday, granting an injunction to stop the leagues six-week-long lockout. The league filed a brief Monday night asking United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson to stay her decision so that it does not have to open for business immediately.

title: Rivet Manufacturing Flaw Suspected in Jets Roof
description: WASHINGTON  Federal investigators said Monday that they had discovered flaws in the riveting of the roof of the Southwest Airlines plane that tore open in flight on April 1, a finding that experts said probably showed manufacturing defects.

description: Securities America is on the auction block.

description: Journalists from The Times and elsewhere talked about their experiences reporting the WikiLeaks story.

title: Labor Board Plans to Sue 2 States Over Union Rules
description: The National Labor Relations Board has told state officials that it will soon file federal lawsuits against Arizona and South Dakota in seeking to invalidate those states constitutional amendments that prohibit private sector employees from choosing to unionize through a procedure known as card check.

description: Bill Cooks first business venture  selling shot glasses with pictures of nude women on the bottom  flopped. But that did not stop him from developing a sprawling company that has made thousands of medical devices, including heart stents, urological equipment and living-tissue transplants.

title: Annoying: The Science of What Bugs Us
description: There's nowhere to hide and no one is immune. Can science explain life's annoyances? NPR's Joe Palca and Flora Lichtman investigate in Annoying: The Science of What Bugs Us (Wiley, 2011).

title: For White Sox G.M., a Bad Day to Be Stuck at the Airport
description: Kenny Williams flew commercial to New York on Monday, and his flight was delayed for two and a half hours. That is dangerous for the general manager of a team that has lost 10 of its last 11 games. Williams, the architect of the Chicago White Sox, got an earful from fans.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,440 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,532 who have died as part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:
