description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: Yemens Opposition Accepts Deal for Transfer of Power
description: Yemens opposition coalition on Monday accepted a proposal for a transfer of power, bringing the country closer to a resolution of months of political turmoil and countless demonstrations calling for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to step down.

title: News Aggregator Zite Wants to Play Nice With Publishers
description: Zite, a news aggregator for the iPad whose app has irked major news publishers, said Monday that Mark Johnson, a longtime adviser to the company, would become its new chief executive.

title: Japans Cherry Blossoms Bloom, but Nuclear Fears Keep Tourists Away
description: MIHARU, Japan  This weeping cherry tree has stood here for a thousand years, local farmers say, blossoming every year despite blizzards, earthquakes and, now, a nuclear disaster.

title: Iran Discovers New Cyberattack
description: TEHRAN  Iran has discovered a new hostile computer virus designed to damage government systems, an Iranian official who heads a cyberdefense agency said in comments reported Monday.

title: For Late Mr. Mayor, a Last Tour of Town
description: BALTIMORE  Even after his death, William Donald Schaefer was still performing. The former mayor of Baltimore was ushered through the city on Monday like a head of state, his coffin on a whirlwind tour of this city that he loved, and that loved him.

title: Joe Perry, 49ers Hall of Fame Fullback, Dies at 84
description: Joe Perry, the San Francisco 49ers Hall of Fame fullback who was one of the first black stars in modern professional football, died Monday in Tempe, Ariz. He was 84.

title: Bloggingheads: Right Wing Buffoonery
description: Michelle Goldberg, left, of The Daily Beast and Ramesh Ponnuru of National Review debate whether Republicans should be worried about the conservative fringe.

title: Letters to New York
description: By the morning of April 25, 1861, residents of Washington had been expecting a Confederate attack for almost two weeks; for the last five days, the city had been completely cut off from the rest of the nation. No trains. No traffic into the city. No telegraph. No mail. Only the morning before at the White House, a despondent President Lincoln had greeted the wounded soldiers of the Sixth Massachusetts  the last reinforcements to arrive since April 19  telling them, I dont believe there is any North. The Seventh Regiment is a myth.

title: Arcade Fire: Haiti
description: No particular reason to post this, except to provide something cheering after a tough day. Im ashamed to say that I wasnt even aware of the band until the Grammys  but hey, Im 58! And as I suspect is happening with Brad, as an aging baby boomer I find it vastly reassuring to see that there are honest, creative artists still making their way up amid the commercialization. And their live performances are truly addictive. So:

title: Crowd to Join as Giffords Views Shuttle Launching
description: PHOENIX  Representative Gabrielle Giffords, who has been given the green light by doctors to attend her astronaut-husbands shuttle launching on Friday afternoon, will be joined at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida by family, friends, aides and health workers  not to mention President Obama and his family  as the space shuttle Endeavour lifts into space.

title: Tornado Season Intensifies, Without Clear Scientific Consensus on Why
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  All the warning sirens echoing across the Great Plains, Midwest and Southeast this month leave little doubt that the tornado season  which has plowed a trail of destruction through communities from Oklahoma to Wisconsin to Georgia  is off to an unusually busy start.

title: Netflixs Profit Rises Amid a Rush to On-Demand
description: Netflix posted a first-quarter profit of $60.2 million on Monday and said it had added 3.3 million subscribers in the United States in three months time, its fastest rate of growth yet.

title: Poll Finds Egyptians Full of Hope About the Future
description: Egyptians are looking forward with extraordinary confidence and enthusiasm to their first free and fair elections this fall after the defining revolution of the Arab spring, according to the first major poll since the ouster of Hosni Mubarak. But they remain deeply divided over the role of Islam in their public life.

title: Taking Pickles Out of the Afterthought Aisle
description: THE typical habitat for the Vlasic brand character, the stork, is of course in the pickle aisle, where he perches on the labels of kosher dills and sweet gherkins. But Monday he began migrating to other sections of supermarkets, too.

title: Change in Giggss Role Brightens the Twilight of His Career
description: Growing old gracefully is very difficult for athletes. Just to drop a few American names who face it: Favre, Roddick, Jeter and Woods (obviously, in very diverse circumstances).

title: Facebook Is Latest Rival to Groupon and LivingSocial
description: Facebook said late Monday that it would introduce Deals, an effort by the social networking giant to tap into the consumer frenzy over online discounts. With Deals, which had long been expected, Facebook is entering a crowded market led by overnight sensations like Groupon and LivingSocial.

title: Law Firm Wont Defend Marriage Act
description: WASHINGTON  The law firm hired by Republicans in the House of Representatives to defend the constitutionality of the Defense of Marriage Act withdrew Monday amid pressure from gay rights groups. The decision prompted the resignation of a prominent partner, who said he intended to take the case with him to another law office.

title: Status of Rangers Drury, Prospal and Avery Is Tenuous
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  It sounded as if the end was near for the Rangers careers of Chris Drury, Vinny Prospal and Sean Avery, based on the veiled language Coach John Tortorella used about them on breakup day here Monday.

title: Many Clashes, Few Kind Words Between Mayor and Comptroller
description: Within minutes of boarding his private jet last November, destined for Hong Kong, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg dispensed with the pleasantries and confronted his main guest, John C. Liu, the city comptroller: Why are you blocking a crucial city contract?

title: The Big Disconnect
description: On one level, American politics looks amazingly stable. President Obamas approval rating is about 47 percent, and it hasnt changed much in well over a year. Health care reform is mildly unpopular, and the publics view hasnt shifted much since before it was passed.

title: Paul Shows Fans Way to Beat Lakers, and Other Teams Are Watching, Too
description: NEW ORLEANS  Chris Paul cupped his hand to his ear, as if he could not hear the thundering applause of the capacity New Orleans Arena crowd. The gesture, which came Sunday night in the waning seconds of the Hornets 93-88 playoff victory against the two-time defending N.B.A. champion Los Angeles Lakers, was as close as Paul gets to showboating.

title: A Journals Statement May Aid a Harvard Researcher Accused of Misconduct
description: In a positive development for Marc Hauser, the Harvard researcher whom the university accused last year of eight charges of scientific misconduct, the journal Science said Monday that he had replicated an experiment he published in 2007.

title: Walshs Status May Be Resolved Soon With a Contract Offer
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donnie Walsh and Mike DAntoni stayed behind closed doors Monday and might remain there for some time, at least until questions about Walshs future are settled.

title: Governor of Mississippi Wont Run for President
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi had hired a campaign manager, lined up influential Republican activists in early-voting states and secured commitments from donors across the country, but he surprised them all on Monday by announcing that he was abandoning his effort to join the Republican presidential race.

title: N.F.L. Ruling Is a Victory for Fans
description: Amid the din of the arguments between N.F.L. players and owners, maybe the fans have been heard, if only a little. When Judge Susan Richard Nelson issued her 89-page decision Monday that lifted  if only temporarily  the N.F.L. lockout, she cited the needs of a third party in the dispute: the public.

title: Life and Death of the Trading Floor
description: The New York Stock Exchange's trading floor has survived for more than a century. With a takeover war by rival exchanges looming, traders are trying to survive in a computerized world.

title: Finish the Job
description: Washington

title: Robberies Chill an Underground World of Chinese Gambling
description: Clad in black and speaking Chinese, the three men entered a mah-jongg parlor hidden in a building on Hester Street in Chinatown. They pulled out a pistol and a knife and stripped gamblers of more than $5,600, the police said.

title: Preserving a Market Symbol
description: When it comes to keeping the New York Stock Exchanges trading floor open, Robert Greifeld makes a very unlikely savior.

title: On the Largely Irrelevant News About Barbour Not Running for President
description: I havent spent very much time writing about Mississippi Governor Haley Barbour, who  announced today that he would not be a candidate for president. But the record will show that I noted both directly and indirectly that I thought Mr. Barbours chances were overstated.

title: Better Hand-Washing Through Technology
description: Why cant hospitals get health care workers to wash their hands?

title: Before Manny Was Manny
description: Manny Ramirez has retired from baseball, but for some he will always be the young phenom blasting home runs for his high school team in Washington Heights.

title: Before Manny Became Manny
description: Hero. Cheat. Prodigy. Ingrate. Free spirit. Knucklehead. Hall of Famer. Pariah. Enigma. Manny Ramirez, one of the great right-handed hitters of his generation, who retired from baseball this month after once again testing positive for performance-enhancing drugs, was many things to many people  fans and family and teammates from Santo Domingo to Washington Heights to Cleveland to Boston. Sara Rimer, then a reporter for The New York Times, met Ramirez in 1991 at George Washington High School in Manhattan. Over two decades, she enjoyed a memorable and mystifying acquaintanceship with Ramirez.

title: 3 Children Drowned by Mother Are Buried
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.  The three white coffins were so small that they needed to be lowered into the ground by hand. The little girl in one, not even a year old when she died, wore a white Easter dress, and the two young boys wore dark suits.

title: The Big Board Tunes Out Its Own Rules
description: Jin Lee/Bloomberg NewsThe New York Stock Exchange.

title: Apple and Google Use Phone Data to Map the World
description: SAN FRANCISCO  You may not know it, but if you carry a smartphone in your pocket, you are probably doing unpaid work for Apple or Google  and helping them eventually aim more advertising directly at you.

title: The Limits of School Reform
description: I find myself haunted by a 13-year-old boy named Saquan Townsend. Its been more than two weeks since he was featured in The New York Times Magazine, yet I cant get him out of my mind.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 2 through March 7 with 1,266 adults throughout the United States.

title: The Guantnamo Papers
description: The internal documents from the prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, published in The Times on Monday were a chilling reminder of the legal and moral disaster that President George W. Bush created there. They describe the chaos, lawlessness and incompetence in his administrations system for deciding detainees guilt or innocence and assessing whether they would be a threat if released.

title: New York Times/CBS News Poll: Title IX
description: The complete results of a New York Times/CBS News poll on gender equity in college sports.

title: Life and Death of the Trading Floor
description: When it comes to keeping the New York Stock Exchange trading floor open, Robert Greifeld makes a very unlikely savior.

title: Guest List Prompts Talk of Royal Snubs
description: LONDON  Just as all appeared to be going smoothly for the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, recriminations set in on Monday over who has made the list of 1,900 wedding guests  and perhaps more significant, those who have not.

title: Gender Games: Roster Management
description: Colleges commonly use the law on gender parity in sport in ways in which it may not have been intended.

title: Public Pensions, Once Off Limits, Face Budget Cuts
description: When an arbitrator ruled this month that Detroit could reduce the pensions being earned by its police sergeants and lieutenants, it put the struggling city at the forefront of a growing national debate over whether the pensions of current public workers can or should be reduced.

title: College Teams, Relying on Deception, Undermine Gender Equity
description: Ever since Congress passed the federal gender-equity law known as Title IX, universities have opened their gyms and athletic fields to millions of women who previously did not have chances to play. But as women have surged into a majority on campus in recent years, many institutions have resorted to subterfuge to make it look as if they are offering more spots to women.

title: Witness Says Inspectors Neglected Risk at Deutsche
description: A thud rattled through the basement of the former Deutsche Bank building in the fall of 2006 with such force, Adolpho Ortiz testified Monday, that he thought someone might have been hurt.

title: A Player Is Back at Home With Dreams of a Recovery
description: JACKSON, N.J.  In his dreams, Eric LeGrand is surrounded by family, friends, his Rutgers football teammates, the same support system that cared for and inspired him the past six months. But there remains one difference. In his dreams, LeGrand can walk.

title: Bronx House Fire Kills Boy, 12, and His Parents
description: A 12-year-old boy and his parents were killed when a fire raced through a row house in the Bronx early Monday, fire officials said.

title: Lottery Numbers
Boeing and the N.L.R.B.
description: It may be a difficult case to prove, but the complaint filed last month by the National Labor Relations Board against Boeing is a welcome effort to defend workers right to collective bargaining.

title: So Much for That Ounce of Prevention
description: House Republicans are so bent on blocking any and all aspects of health care reform that they have passed a bill that would eliminate a farsighted program  the Prevention and Public Health Fund  intended to help states and communities prevent diseases. Eliminating the fund would save roughly $16 billion over the course of a decade, a small amount in the context of a trillion-dollar health care reform. The loss to states and local communities would be considerable.

title: Marriage Equality in New York
description: There are good reasons to believe that legislation legalizing same-sex-marriage in New York State is fated to fare better in Albanys current legislative session than it did in 2009 when the State Senate voted, 38 to 24, to continue the states discriminatory policy of denying gay and lesbian couples the freedom to marry.

title: U.S. Faces a Challenge in Trying to Punish Syria
description: WASHINGTON  The White House said on Monday that it was exploring new sanctions against Syria  mostly involving the assets of top officials around President Bashar al-Assad  but officials acknowledged that the country was already under so many sanctions that the United States held little leverage.

title: Tuesday: Humdinger
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Theres an interesting surprise in todays puzzle that you may overlook because its a very low-key entry. On the other hand, weve all been doing Brendan Emmett Quigleys puzzles for so long (Solution, Note: There is no blog or Across Lite file for this puzzle) and enjoyed them so much, that I feel compelled to point it out.

title: A Papal Visit Has Dreamers Dreaming
description: What do you get when you take the sur out of surrealism? That sounds like a question in search of a punch line. But few laughs emerge from the answers provided by the somber new revival of John Guares House of Blue Leaves, which opened on Monday night at the Walter Kerr Theater.

title: Mauritania: Police Break Up Antigovernment Protest
description: Using tear gas and batons, the police broke up an antigovernment demonstration of several hundred youths in the capital, Nouakchott, on Monday. Echoing protests elsewhere in the region, young people have been rallying against President Mohamed Ould Abdel Aziz since the end of February. Mr. Aziz, left, a former general, was elected in 2009 after seizing power in a coup the year before. A rallying cry of the protesters has been that Mr. Aziz used the election merely to legalize his coup, and on Monday the protesters demanded he relinquish power. At about noon they were savagely attacked by the police with batons and tear gas grenades, said an opposition member of Parliament, Mohamed El Moustapha Ould Bedreddine.

title: Preliminary Injunction Ruling: Brady et al. v. National Football League
description: United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson gave professional football players a significant victory Monday, granting an injunction to stop the N.F.L.s six-week-long lockout.

title: Germany: Protesters Demand Stop to Nuclear Power
description: An estimated 120,000 people demonstrated across Germany on Monday, protest organizers said, demanding an end to the use of nuclear power and increasing pressure on Chancellor Angela Merkels government to speed up the closing of the countrys 17 nuclear plants. Last month, after the nuclear accident in Japan, Mrs. Merkel imposed a moratorium on new nuclear plant construction and temporarily closed seven existing plants.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Court Ruling Fosters Questions, Not Answers, for Players and Teams
description: When the news broke Monday afternoon that United States District Judge Susan Richard Nelson had lifted the N.F.L. lockout, confusion overtook a league known for micromanagement. Players called their agents. Agents called teams. Teams called the league office. Reporters called everyone. Yet all those questions yielded more confusion, at least initially.

title: A Fitting Tribute to a Citys Faithful Servant
description: William Donald Schaefer, the former mayor of Baltimore, was ushered through the city Monday like a head of state, his coffin on a whirlwind tour of this city that he loved.

title: Last Chance for Flyers Is Latest One for Boucher
description: VOORHEES, N.J.  Brian Boucher, the Philadelphia Flyers first-string goaltender as of right now, said he planned to spend Monday afternoon at his 8-year-old sons baseball practice. Boucher said he would wait until Tuesday to consider the difficulty of his next job assignment.

title: After School in Brooklyn, West African Girls Share Memories of a Painful Ritual
description: In a high school classroom in Brooklyn with walls adorned with algebra problems, a 15-year-old girl born in the West African nation of Guinea was talking recently with her friends, after the school day had ended.

title: Former Mets Prospect Shuts Down the Yankees
description: On a night when A. J. Burnett became the first Yankees starter to pitch eight complete innings, he was overshadowed by a failed Mets prospect playing for his fourth organization in 16 months.

title: Marie-France Pisier, New Wave Darling, Dies at 66
description: Marie-France Pisier, a French actress who was discovered by Franois Truffaut and appeared in three of his films, including Love on the Run, and who worked with notable directors like Andr Tchin and Luis Buuel, died on Sunday at her home in Saint-Cyr-sur-Mer in the South of France. She was 66.

title: Washington: New Head for University
description: Michael Young, who has headed the University of Utah since 2004, will be the next president of the University of Washington, starting July 1. Mr. Young, 61, is a graduate of Brigham Young University and Harvard Law School, and a direct descendant of the Mormon leader Brigham Young. He has been dean of George Washington University Law School, served on the faculty of Columbia Law School, and clerked for Justice William Rehnquist of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Dossier Shows Push for More Attacks After 9/11
description: WASHINGTON  He peers out from the photo in the classified file through heavy-framed spectacles, an owlish face with a graying beard and a half-smile. Saifullah Paracha, a successful businessman and for years a New York travel agent, appears to be the oldest of the 172 prisoners still held at the Guantnamo Bay prison. His dossier is among the most chilling.

title: Funds Down for Pre-K Programs
description: The recession took its toll on early childhood programs across the nation in the 2009-10 school year, with total spending by states decreasing for the first time since experts began keeping track, according to an annual survey by the National Institute for Early Education Research at Rutgers University. State funding for pre-kindergarten programs decreased by nearly $30 million, about one half of 1 percent, and would have fallen by $50 million if states had not received federal stimulus dollars, the survey said. Ohio, which eliminated one program, saw its enrollment of 3- and 4-year-olds drop by nearly 15,000, to about 5,700.

title: Previewing the Champions League Semifinals
description: Rob Hughes looks at this weeks first-leg matchups in the semifinals of the UEFA Champions League  at whether Schalke has a shot against Manchester United after a middling league season, and at whether Real Madrid will risk getting rough with Barcelona. Read the full article here, and come back to this post to comment.

title: Gym Class: Antigravity Yoga
description: The Times's fitness guinea pig, Karen Barrow, reviews a gravity-defying form of yoga.

title: Gym Class: AntiGravity Yoga
description: Did you ever see an interesting class at the gym that you were too intimidated to try? Or maybe you need to freshen up your current workout routine?

title: Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf Earn Top Marks in First U.S. Crash Tests
description: In the first independent crash tests of mainstream electric vehicles conducted in the United States, the Chevrolet Volt and Nissan Leaf have been named Top Safety Picks by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

title: Aspiring Authors Get Help Online
description: In the old days of publishing, getting your manuscript into the hands of an editor often meant mailing the unsolicited finished product to the offices of literary agents or editors, where it would receive a cursory look from an editorial assistant  or none at all.

title: Ballpark Memories
description: As the last homestand is played before the Yankees move to their new stadium, this is a time for South Bronx residents to reflect on their neighborhood.

title: Police Officer Pleads Guilty in Robberies of Drug Dealers
description: A New York City police officer pleaded guilty on Monday to charges that he participated in a ring that robbed drug dealers, an operation that officials say yielded more than 550 pounds of cocaine and $1 million in drug proceeds.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the eighth day of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Word of the Day | assumption
description: assumption \-sm(p)-shn\ noun

title: Report Urges Storing Spent Nuclear Fuel, Not Reprocessing It
description: Experts on nuclear power predict that Japans Fukushima crisis will lead to a major rethinking of how spent nuclear fuel is handled in the United States but have cast doubt on a proposed solution: reprocessing the fuel to recover plutonium and other materials for reuse.

title: Photo Replay: April 25
description: A look back at the day in sports, from the womens hockey world championships to the N.B.A. playoffs.

title: Strikes in Libya
description: A government-organized tour in Tripoli showed buildings damaged by NATO bombs, and shelling in Misurata was fatal for two families.

title: Lollapalooza Headliners Include Eminem, Foo Fighters and Coldplay
description: Heres a simple rule of thumb for determining if a particular band is probably on the lineup for the 20th anniversary edition of Lollapalooza: does it play music? If the answer to that question is yes, theres a good chance that it is. Artists who fit that description, including Eminem, Foo Fighters, Coldplay, Muse and My Morning Jacket, are among the 130 acts who are scheduled to perform at that long-lived festival, which runs from Aug. 5 through 7 at Grant Park in Chicago. Also on the bill this year are deadmau5, A Perfect Circle, Cee Lo Green, Damian Jr. Gong Marley & Nas, the Cars and Ween, as well as (deep breath) Bright Eyes, Arctic Monkeys, Big Audio Dynamite, Deftones, Beirut, Explosions in the Sky, Death From Above 1979, Ratatat and Crystal Castles, the festivals organizers announced on Tuesday.

title: News Quiz | April 26, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Minmetals Withdraws Equinox Bid After Barrick Offer
description: Minmetals Resources, the state-controlled Chinese mining company that made an unsolicited bid for Equinox Minerals this month, said on Tuesday that it had dropped its offer after being outbid by the Barrick Gold Corporation.

title: International Outcry Grows Over Syria Crackdown
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrias bloody crackdown on protesters  which seemed to signal a new, harrowing chapter in a conflict that has already killed nearly 400 people  provoked growing international concern on Tuesday with calls for the violence to stop and talk of possible sanctions.

title: Test Yourself | English, April 26, 2011
description: Test your proofreading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the blog post Yahoo Will Keep Search Queries for 18 Months.

title: Afghan Officials Try to Limit Damage From Prison Break
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Government officials struggled on Tuesday, but with limited effect, to contain the damage from a spectacular jailbreak that freed 475 inmates, most presumed to be Taliban fighters, from southern Afghanistans largest prison.

title: An Overview: Guantnamo Bay and the Classified Files
description: Note: Todays 6 Qs About the News pulls from multiple Times sources to help students understand the basics of this complex topic. Each question links to a resource in which they can find an answer, including the Times Topics page that features a short overview of Guantnamo Bay and its history. In some cases the link will take students directly to the page or paragraph from which the information comes.

title: Is Your Generation More Self-Centered Than Earlier Generations?
description: Is narcissism, or excessive fascination with oneself, increasing? A psychologist, Nathan DeWall, analyzed the language in three decades of hit songs to answer this question, and he thinks it is. Late adolescents and college students love themselves more today than ever before, he says. Do you think this is true? Read the related Science Times article to learn about his research, then respond below.

title: Daily Lexeme: Maegth
description: Todays word, in association with the scrumptuous Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: 25 Years After Chernobyl, a Village Persists
description: Redkovka, Ukraine, bears little resemblance to the place it was 25 years ago. Its stores, its school, its factory, and its homes  all are gone, or dramatically changed, as a result of the 1986 nuclear accident at Chernobyl, about 22 miles away.

title: Lactalis Bids $4.95 Billion for Rest of Parmalat
description: 5:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Net Inflows Help UBS Beat Expectations
description: 5:13 p.m. | Updated

title: 4 Killed in Bus Bombings in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least four people were killed in the southern port city of Karachi on Tuesday in bombings that struck two buses carrying Pakistani naval employees, a senior naval official said. At least 56 people were wounded.

title: Remembering Joe Perry, Pioneering Running Back
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Joe Perry died Monday at age 84.

title: A Romani Festival on the Streets of Istanbul
description: The spring festival of Hidrellez, celebrated in Istanbul and throughout the region during the first week of May, may be attributed to the ancient prophets Ilyas and Hizir, but its rituals, venerating fire and water, reach back to the roots of Anatolian civilization. In Istanbul today, particularly in Romani districts, Hidrellez comes in the form of a memorable street party.

title: The Early Word: Terrorism
description: Todays Times

title: Fantasy Focus: Moving the Needle
description: Here are a few players who have made an impression of late:

title: Americans Held in Tehran Get Court Date
description: TEHRAN  Two American citizens who have spent 19 months in detention in Iran, accused of espionage and illegal entry, will appear in court for a third time in May, according to their lawyer.

title: Scenes From Ryan McGinleys Opening
description: Earlier this month, Ryan McGinley had an opening in Amsterdam at Galerie Gabriel Rolt. The show included color photography shot in nature along with black-and-white studio portraits of nudes and animals.

title: What It Means to Make a Profit
description: I went back and reread my post about becoming profitable. I laid out the factors that I believe turned around my companys financial state: six actions and circumstances that allowed me to survive the recession and put my company on the right path. What I neglected to discuss is my personal reaction to the idea that I might finally be able to breathe easier about money.

title: Why Republicans May Be Skipping 2012 Presidential Run
description: Haley Barbours decision to forgo a run for the presidency in 2012 puts him in the company of a half-dozen top Republicans who have considered  and rejected  a challenge to President Obama next year.

title: Smaller Cars Lift Fords Profit to $2.55 Billion
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company on Tuesday reported its best first-quarter earnings since 1998, even as its sales shift to smaller, more fuel-efficient cars.

title: Departing Amalgamated Bank Chief to Join Weil Gotshal
description: Derrick D. Cephas, who is stepping down as chief executive of Amalgamated Bank at the end of April, will soon join Weil, Gotshal & Manges as head of the law firms financial regulatory group.

title: Gimlet Eye Observes Murder Case
description: In his best book, the nonfiction collection Killings (1984), Calvin Trillin described what attracts him  and so many other writers  to murder stories. When someone dies suddenly shades are drawn up, Mr. Trillin wrote. Lives are laid bare. A murder gives us an excuse to be there, he said, poking around in somebodys life.

title: A Time for Radical Centrists
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of Triumph of the City.

title: Q&A: Moving Data at Lightning Speed With Thunderbolt
description: Q.

title: Morning Buzz | A Clash of City Titans
description: Tuesday will start swaddled in fog and will grow warm with highs reaching the upper 70s. Skies may clear at some point, but there is a good chance of thunderstorms later in the afternoon and evening.

title: Nintendo Plans to Update the Wii
description: The Nintendo Wii is getting a successor.

title: Sale of Oil Leases Planned for Gulf of Mexico
description: An oil and gas lease sale covering more than 28,000 square miles in the western Gulf of Mexico could take place as soon as the end of the year, federal regulators quietly announced last week.

title: Cant Get No Satisfaction?
description: Today David Brooks argues that there is a disconnect between the improving economy and the increasingly despairing public, pointing to a deeper malaise. But is the economy really improving in a way that matters to voters?

title: Lawson Software Agrees to $2 Billion Buyout
description: Lawson Software announced on Tuesday that it would be acquired by the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, in a $2 billion buyout deal.

title: Barrett-Jackson Changes Tune on Reserve Sales for Collectible Cars
description: At collector car auctions, it takes guts to raise a paddle and buy a car based on first impressions or a catalog description. But what about the anxious seller who consigns a car and lets the marketplace of interested parties decide what its worth?

title: The Nannies Norma Rae
description: Its the most intimate class divide in human civilization, or at least in such relatively civilized places as Manhattan and Park Slope, Brooklyn. On the one side, there is the professional couple bringing in six figures a year; on the other, the nanny or maid without whom the couple wouldnt be able to practice their professions. Conditions of employment are as variable as the individual employers are  from respectful and considerate all the way to criminally abusive. On average, a domestic worker is likely to get less than $15 an hour, no benefits and none of the credit or glory. To my knowledge anyway, there has never been a successful career woman  or man, for that matter  whos responded to being praised for doing it all by saying, Actually, Manuela (or Angelica or Harriet) does most of it.

title: One on One: Peter Semmelhack of Bug Labs
description: Peter Semmelhack founded Bug Labs in April 2006 with the intention of making it easier for people to create innovative electronic devices. The company makes a product called a Bug, which is a series of modules  GPS systems, cameras, motion sensors  that can be snapped onto a small computer and programmed to create products that would otherwise take years of development and millions of dollars to build. The following is an edited transcript of an interview with Mr. Semmelhack.

title: Raising the Medicare Age
description: Jonathan Cohn rightly slams a little-noticed feature of the Republican plan  a rise in the Medicare eligibility age.

title: French and Italian Leaders Seek Tighter Controls on Migration
description: ROME  Facing a surge in undocumented migrants from North Africa, the leaders of France and Italy on Tuesday called for changes in the Schengen Agreement, which grants free passage across national frontiers in most of Western Europe.

title: Tuesday Reading: Lawsuits Dont Improve Nursing Home Care
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Real Estate Remains in Distress as U.S. Home Prices Fall Again
description: Housing prices slid back in February to their lowest level of the downturn, fresh proof  as if any were needed  that real estate remains one of the most troubled sectors of the economy.

title: Deadly Storms Leave Arkansans Battered and Bracing for More
description: VILONIA, Ark.  A barrage of severe weather sweeping across Arkansas has brought flash floods to some parts of the state, wrecked this small town and left 10 dead. Residents braced for more damage on Tuesday evening as violent storms washed across the state.

title: Tribeca Q&A: Jack Osbourne on God Bless Ozzy Osbourne
description: Though Ozzy Osbourne was a reality-television fixture for three years  and, oh yeah, a pioneer of heavy-metal music for some four decades  there is more to be said about rock n rolls Prince of Darkness in God Bless Ozzy Osbourne, a documentary making its debut at the Tribeca Film Festival. The movie, directed by Mike Fleiss and Mike Piscitelli, chronicles Mr. Osbournes life  62 years, if you can believe it, and counting  from his upbringing in Birmingham, England, through his years with Black Sabbath and as a solo performer, through his grieving for the accidental death of his guitarist Randy Rhoads, to the aftermath of his reality show, while a cloud of alcohol and drug abuse hangs over him. In addition to interviews with Mr. Osbourne and his band mates past and present, the film offers candid testimonials from his wife, Sharon, and children Jack and Kelly, as well as his little-seen daughter Aimee (who declined to be part of the reality series) and children Louis and Jessica (from a previous marriage).

title: Updates on the Unrest in Syria and Libya
description: On Tuesday, The Lede is compiling reports on the war in Libya, protests in Syria and uprisings against governments across the Middle East from journalists, bloggers and activists in the region.

title: Britain to Close a Consulate With a View
description: FLORENCE, Italy  It has seen the rise of the Grand Tour and the package tour, the romance of E. M. Forsters Room With a View and the tensions of two world wars. And now, after five centuries, the British Consulate in Florence is closing its doors, a victim of budget cuts and the currents of history.

title: Seniors-Friendly Guide to Upper West Side Grocery Stores
description: Created on the Upper West Side. Flying off the shelves.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Smart Modular Technologies in $645 Million Buyout
description: Smart Modular Technologies, a maker of computer memory systems, said on Tuesday that it had agreed to be acquired by Silver Lake Partners and its affiliate, Silver Lake Sumeru, for $645 million in cash.

title: Sarkozy Backs Italian Official to Lead Central Bank
description: PARIS  The high-level politicking over who will be the next president of the European Central Bank moved closer to resolution on Tuesday. But it is not yet a done deal.

title: Bloombergs Big Push for an Applied Sciences School
description: The mayor of New York does not usually take time from his schedule to mingle with academic deans from Finland. But there was Michael R. Bloomberg at the Metropolitan Museum of Art recently, trying to sell the foreign visitors on his next big idea: a top-flight applied sciences school for the city.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Q. and A. With Matt Waldman, Author of Rookie Scouting Portfolio
description: Matt Waldman, a writer for FootballGuys.com who has been contributing to the Fifth Down leading up to the draft, has a simple way to grade draft prospects: judge them on how they perform on the field.

title: Cure for Insomnia in House Cats
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed impossible book titles.

title: The Wet House Where Alcoholics Can Keep Drinking
description: In a sterile 12-by-12 concrete room on the second floor of St. Anthony Residence, a 60-year-old man with glassy eyes and a stomach full of cheap vodka sits at the end of his twin bed, a cigarette resting between his chapped lips. Ballerinas dance, and alcoholics drink, Dave tells me with a chuckle. Its 10:30 on a Monday morning, and he has already been to a nearby liquor store and back.

title: Game 7 Preview: Buffalo at Philadelphia
description: Here are five keys to Game 7 between the Flyers and the Sabres, to be played Tuesday night in Philadelphia at 7:30, courtesy of the analyst Kevin Weekes of Hockey Night in Canada and the NHL Network:

title: New York Philharmonic Hires Ricardo Morales
description: Ricardo Morales and the New York Philharmonic have finally closed the deal. The orchestra back in October offered Mr. Morales  one of the stars of the Philadelphia Orchestra  the job of principal clarinetist, a key position that had been open since the end of the 2008-9 season. A spokesman said today that Mr. Morales had signed a contract and would officially start in New York in September 2012 once his obligations end in Philadelphia. The orchestra hopes to have Mr. Morales play some weeks on an ad hoc basis next season and possibly as early as this summer. The loss of Mr. Morales will be another blow to the Philadelphia Orchestra, which this month filed under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws. New York operagoers may be familiar with his sound. He was a principal in the Metropolitan Opera before going to Philadelphia.

title: Phoebe Snow, Bluesy Singer-Songwriter, Dies at 60
description: Phoebe Snow, whose signature hit, Poetry Man, established her as a leading light of the singer-songwriter movement and whose swooping vocal acrobatics transcended musical genres, died on Tuesday in Edison, N.J. She was 60.

title: Uniteds Hernandez: Baby Face, Golden Boot
description: Manchester United is a club with a strong heritage, and a club with a strong heritage of great strikers. Denis Law, Mark Hughes, Eric Cantona, Ruud Van Nistelrooy  just to name a few.

title: Another Royal Pairing: Queen of Soul and King of Retailers
description: Coming soon to Wal-Mart: soul.

title: Egg Is Hatching, Hawk Expert Confirms
description: Last evening we captured a (blurry) hawk-cam image (also see below) that appeared to show something poking out of the leftmost egg on Violet and Bobbys nest high above Washington Square Park.

title: Phrases Gone Astray
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Phrases Gone Astray
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: White House Easter Egg Roll
description: The theme of this years event was Get Up and Go! and emphasized health and fitness.

title: Asked & Answered | Laszlo Jakab Orsos
description: Last September, Laszlo Jakab Orsos, 46, assumed the directorship of the PEN World Voices Festival, New Yorks first literary festival, now in its seventh year. Started by Salman Rushdie, the festival regularly features readings and conversations with more than 100 writers from more than 40 countries. Local literary heroes like Jonathan Franzen and Ben Greenman share billing with Nobel Prize winners like Wole Soyinka, of Nigeria, and newcomers like Rula Jebreal, author of Miral. This years festival opens today with a party at the Standard Hotel and will continue throughout the week with unusual events at unusual sites: poetry readings on the Highline, dance performances in the laundry room of Westbeth and a discussion of David Foster Wallaces The Pale King by Rick Moody and others in the grungy St. Patricks gym on Mulberry Street.

title: With Barbour Out, Hill Republicans Lose Big Voice in Budget Battles
description: With Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi out of the 2012 presidential race, Republican leaders in Congress are losing a key supporter as they head into the fights over the next budget and raising the national debt ceiling.

title: NATO Says It Is Stepping Up Attacks on Libya Targets
description: WASHINGTON  NATO plans to step up attacks on the palaces, headquarters and communications centers that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi uses to maintain his grip on power in Libya, according to Obama administration and allied officials.

title: Olbermann Relaunches Countdown On Current TV
description: Keith Olbermann formally announced the start date and the name for his new program on Current TV Tuesday  and it sounds a lot like the old program on MSNBC.

title: Whither the Housing Bottom?
description: 4:54 p.m. | Updated

title: Journalists and Lawmakers Dominate Warrens Schedule
description: As Elizabeth Warren starts the nations first federal consumer finance agency, bankers and lawmakers have been lining up to snag even a few minutes of her time.

title: Optimistic Socialists
description: In Tuesdays column, I wrote about the American public mood. Last December, Jodie T. Allen of the Pew Research Center had the smart idea of comparing the views of todays Americans with the views of Americans during the Great Depression. The results remind you how much public opinion has shifted in a pro-capitalist direction over the past 80 years.

title: Forget Frugality: Focus on Earning More
Few Americans Familiar With Title IX, Though Most Approve of It
description: Most Americans say it is very important for boys and girls to have the same opportunities to participate in high school sports, but few are very familiar with Title IX, the federal law that prohibits sex discrimination in federally funded education programs including athletics, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Exit Barbour
description: So Haley Barbour, who seemed like a near-lock to join the Republican field in 2012, has decided to join the ranks of Republican Mario Cuomos instead. Its an understandable decision: Barbours strengths as a politician notwithstanding, his personal profile  a corpulent ex-lobbyist and quintessential Washington insider whos also the governor of a deep-red state identified with secession and segregation  made him perhaps the least electable of the various would-be establishment candidates, and his famous political acumen was apparently acute enough to recognize that thick rolodexes alone do not a credible candidacy make. (See Gramm, Phil and Connally, John, among others.) Still, his departure leaves a thin G.O.P. field looking thinner (no pun intended), and it removes a candidate who had the wisdom to greet our Libyan intervention with a blunt: What are we doing in Libya? For that alone, he will be missed.

title: Making Do With a Plywood Spaceship
description: The Museum of Flight in Seattle had anticipated for years that it would receive for its new $12 million, 15,000-square-foot Space Gallery one of four space shuttles that NASA was to give away. But when the winners were announced this month, Seattle was not among them. Instead, the museum will get a shuttle trainer used by astronauts before they went into space. It is made of plywood and does not have wings. Douglas R. King, the museums chief executive, discusses.

title: Making the Most of an Unlikely Stop in Chinese Basketball League
description: DONGGUAN, China  Its a chant normally reserved for Chinese players, who are the only ones eligible for the Chinese Basketball Associations most valuable player award. But as Quincy Douby stepped to the free-throw line recently with his teams Game 3 victory in the finals guaranteed, the home crowd was glad to make an exception. As Douby swished his two foul shots, the roars of M.V.P.! filled the arena.

title: R.N.C. Chairman Stays Out of Trump-Birther Issue
description: Reince Priebus, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared Tuesday that while he has no doubt that President Obama is an American citizen, it was not his place to tell Donald Trump to drop the issue.

title: On Ethics, Humor, Thelma and Louise and Toonces the Driving Cat
description: The description of this blog is Eavesdropping on the Times Magazine, and, were you to truly eavesdrop on our offices, you would find we dont just sit around debating high-literary assessments of famed New Yorker writers or the political ramifications of accidental allusions to nurdles. Sometimes we talk about the magazine and what will be in the magazine and what should or should not be in the magazine.

title: For Many Michigan Applicants, a Long Wait at the Mailbox
description: While most applicants to the nations selective colleges have been weighing their acceptances (and salving the wounds of their rejections) since April 1 or earlier, more than 10,000 applicants to the University of Michigan had to wait until last Thursday to receive their notifications. That delay, in turn, left those who were accepted with fewer than two weeks to compare Michigan (and perhaps its offer of financial aid) to other institutions.

title: Olivier Rousteing Named New Designer at Balmain
description: The new era at Pariss sex-charged fashion house Balmain is beginning to take shape, with 25-year-old Olivier Rousteing being tapped as the labels new designer. Rousteing, who joined Balmain in 2009 and is currently in charge of womens wear, replaces Christophe Decarnin, who left earlier this month due to strategic disputes with chairman Alain Hivelin. Before joining Balmain, Rousteing worked for five years at Roberto Cavalli, which should serve him well in delivering the decadent rock-inflected glamour that became the labels trademark under Decarnin.

title: Private Equitys Love Affair With China
description: Private equity has long had its eye on Asia, and China in particular, as the land of opportunity. But few buyout magnates have forcefully spoken about the inverse, the declining fortunes of the United States.

title: Fill-In | Defined by the Numbers
Year of the Flying Tigers?
description: Xinjiang, a desolate and sparsely populated province in northwestern China, would seem an unlikely place for a title-contending basketball team.

title: Trailer: 'City of Life and Death'
description: The trailer for "City of Life and Death," Lu Chuan's film about the 1937 Nanjing massacre.

title: Q&A: Cooking Classes in France
description: Q.

title: Game 7 Preview: Chicago at Vancouver
description: As comebacks go, even in the anyone-can-win N.H.L., this one has been as improbable as it is thrilling. The Blackhawks, about a half-shell of theteam that won the Stanley Cup a year ago, have overcome a 3-0 deficit to force a Game 7 in Vancouver on Tuesday night at 10 Eastern.

title: How Do You Say Jughead in Spanish?
description: The modernization of Archie Andrews, that lovable redhead from Riverdale, continues. Archie Comics announced that the company would start offering some of its titles available for digital download in Spanish, The Associated Press reported. Ive been thinking about it for quite a while, said Jon Goldwater, the co-chief executive of Archie Comics. When you talk about globalizing through digital, you cant really do that if youre only in English.

title: Kamsky to Defend Title in Finals of U.S. Championship
description: Over the weekend, experience triumphed over youth at the United States Chess Championships.

title: Wheelies: The Profit and Loss Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: American Apparel Gets $14.9 Million in Financing
description: American Apparel confirmed on Tuesday that it had secured $14.9 million in financing from a group of Canadian investors.

title: Public Theater Unveils Its 2011-2012 Season
description: With our hearts still broken in a hundred thousand flaws following the cancellation of Law & Order last year, fans of the series longtime star, Sam Waterston, will see the actor trade his district attorneys suit for the royal garb of King Lear in a new production at the Public Theater as part of a coming season that includes works by Mike Daisey, Nathan Englander, David Henry Hwang, Richard Nelson, and Stew and Heidi Rodewald.

title: Someone Elses Headache
description: You dont want to go out to dinner with me. Really. Im no fun at all. Not even if I know the owner and get a free drink or a special meal. That happens. Restaurant people are good about that, professional courtesy and all. Still, going to dinner with me is like attending a college basketball game with an advance scout. All work and no fun. Lots of notes interrupted by an occasional drink and a high-five.

title: T-Mobiles New Plan: Deal or No Deal?
description: Its hard to know what to focus on first concerning T-Mobiles new rate plan. The savings youll get, the saving you thought youd get, or download speeds.

title: David E. Patton Named Federal Public Defender
description: David E. Patton, a visiting law professor at Stanford, has been named the new head of New Yorks influential federal public defenders office.

title: Spurs Pushed to Brink by Grizzlies
description: This wasnt supposed to be so hard for the San Antonio Spurs. They appeared poised for a long, hopefully fruitful, N.B.A. playoff run, bolstered by a veteran team that posted the best regular-season record in the Western Conference.

title: Disorder Rules the Day
description: Proponents of sanity and order in sports are not having a good day. These are the people who like knowing that Tim Duncan will be predictably solid and stoic in the N.B.A. playoffs every year, an idea coming undone before our eyes. And while the N.F.L. lockout complicated matters for these folks, the N.F.L. was trying to help by pretending everything was perfectly normal (Hey, watch us draft players and then immediately lock them out! Make sure you buy their jerseys!)  until Monday.

title: Faced With Declines, McClatchy Weighs Digital Subscriptions
description: The newspaper industry continues to take a major hit as reflected by earnings reported on Tuesday by The McClatchy Company, the parent company to newspapers like The Kansas City Star, The Miami Herald and El Nuevo Herald. The latter publications were nominated for a Pulitzer Prize for breaking news for their coverage of the Haiti earthquake this year.

title: The Chefs Table at Brooklyn Fare
description: PARDON me, said Csar Ramirez. Thus begins every meal at one of the more extraordinary restaurants in New York City.

title: Reviewing Chefs Table at Brooklyn Fare
Players Punch In, But Quickly Punch Out
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  The coming and going of each players car on Jets Drive signaled the back-and-forth uncertainty about the short-term meaning over the end  probably a temporary one  of the N.F.L. lockout.

title: With Lockout Lifted for Now, Questions on How to Proceed
description: From the players who showed up for a workout, only to be told they could not get into the weight room, to the lawyers who asked a federal judge to clarify exactly what she wanted them to do now, the N.F.L. was stuck in a state of confusion Tuesday, one day after an injunction to stop the six-week-long lockout was issued.

title: Teaching Teen Drivers
description: This afternoon my son will head to the DMV to trade in his junior drivers license for an unrestricted senior one. This evening we will go out to dinner to celebrate his 17th birthday. Were planning to take two cars, and we will stay at the restaurant past 9. Then he will drive himself home  the first time the State of New York has allowed him to do so at that hour without an adult in the passenger seat.

title: Springtime Underground
description: Springtime in my New York doesnt begin on the equinox. And it has little to do with forsythia. It is instead that moment when the subway is suddenly, discernibly cooler than the sidewalks above; when descending into a station feels like a pleasant immersion in a sturdy old cellar whose masonry walls are still infused with winter.

title: Aflac Finds Its New Duck on the  Web
description: A Minnesota radio executive who auditioned online has been selected by Aflac to provide the voice of its duck character in commercials.

title: Balmain Taps an Inside Man
description: The Paris fashion house announced on Tuesday that Olivier Rousteing will succeed Christophe Decarnin. In a briefly worded statement that seemed intended to suggest that little would change, Balmain said that Mr. Rousteing has been in charge of the brands womens design studio since 2009. His previous job was at Roberto Cavalli, where he spent five years. Dependable inside talent offers continuity  why rock those Balmain beads?  and a new person a chance to surprise and lead. Will we see more such moves?

title: Balloon-Borne Messages to North Korea Have Detractors on Both Sides of Border
description: IMJINGAK, SOUTH KOREA  On a pleasant spring day, with the wind breezing up from the south, the quirky little tourist outpost of Imjingak  with its Peace Land amusement park, some souvenir sheds and a Popeyes chicken stand  hardly seemed like a possible flash point for violent hostilities between North and South Korea.

title: Much Ado Over Royal Wedding in Secular Republic of France
description: PARIS  For a country proud of its republican streak, France is making quite a fuss over the British royal wedding.

title: European Champions League (Graphically Speaking)
description: Fresh off the production of a novel way to view the 2010 World Cup, some of the soccer-obsessed folks at Hyperakt, a New York-based design firm, have come up with a similar representation for the European Champions League semifinals, which began Tuesday in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, with the match between Schalke 04 and Manchester United.

title: Aeromotional
description: A car design that combines aerodynamics and nostalgia.

title: A Fresh Look at Fighting Global Poverty
description: Dean Karlan, a Yale economist, and Jacob Appel, a former field researcher in West Africa, are the authors of a new book about fighting global poverty, More Than Good Intentions. Richard Thaler has described the book on the Nudge blog, and Tyler Cowen has called Mr. Karlan one of my favorite young economists.

title: Style Map | Turin, Italy
description: Locals might scoff at the idea of Turin being convenient to Milan, but a fairly efficient recent high-speed railway link from Milano Centrale to Torino Porta Nuova has brought the two Italian cities within an hours reach. Which means that should you find yourself in Milan, its entirely possible to pop over for a leisurely lunch, stroll Turins elegant city center and even take in some art  and still make it back by curtain time at La Scala. View interactive feature >>

title: The Library Hands Out Menus to Thousands of Volunteers
description: If Rebecca Federman and Ben Vershbow of the New York Public Library get their wish, they will have thrown an epic party for tens of thousands of people who visited, enjoyed the food and then, like perfect guests, did all the dishes.

title: Couric Confirms Departure From CBS
description: 7:46 p.m. | Updated | Katie Couric confirmed on Tuesday what has been widely reported for weeks: that she will leave her job as the anchor of the CBS Evening News.

title: Dancing Past the Reruns
description: With mostly reruns on CBS and Fox, Dancing With the Stars dominated Monday night in the ratings, attracting 21.8 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. That ABC reality competition easily led its 90-minute time slot from 8 to 9:30 p.m. while boosting ABCs sitcom Better With You at 9:30 (11.6 million). CBS ranked second for the night with repeats of its sitcoms, including How I Met Your Mother at 8 (5.3 million), The Big Bang Theory at 9 (7.7 million), and Mike & Molly at 9:30 (7.8 million). A new installment of Mad Love garnered 5.6 million viewers at 8:30. Fox edged past NBC for third place, earning 4.8 million for a rerun of House at 8 followed by a repeat of The Chicago Code (4.1 million). NBC finished in fourth despite broadcasting new episodes of The Event at 9 (4.4 million) and Law & Order: Los Angeles at 10 (5.8 million), which trailed behind repeats of CBSs Hawaii Five-0 (7 million) and ABCs Castle (7.6 million) in its time slot.

title: The Confidence Fairy Has Taken a Leave of Absence
description: Was it only last June when Alan Reynolds was holding Ireland up as a role model, not just for troubled European economies, but for the United States? Yes, it was:

title: Dungeons and Zombies, Sure, but Here the Trades the Thing
description: IRVINE, Calif.  Writing about a game that hasnt been released to the public can be risky. It might end up as vaporware or simply not live up to the awesome impression that publishers can gin up in a short, canned demonstration. But when it comes to a new game from Blizzard Entertainment, perhaps the worlds most accomplished and prestigious developer, an exception seems merited.

title: Culture of Complicity Tied to Stricken Nuclear Plant
description: TOKYO  Given the fierce insularity of Japans nuclear industry, it was perhaps fitting that an outsider exposed the most serious safety cover-up in the history of Japanese nuclear power. It took place at Fukushima Daiichi, the plant that Japan has been struggling to get under control since last months earthquake and tsunami.

title: Donations at the Checkout Counter Are Often Deductible
description: If you find yourself inside a big chain drug store once or twice a week, youve probably been asked whether you want to donate $1 or so to a particular cause at the checkout counter.

title: Data Misconceptions
description: Just a quick note on three misconceptions I often see in comments:

title: On Plankton, Warming and Whiplash
description: A new study in Nature Climate Change,Revaluating ocean warming impacts on globalphytoplankton,has shown that the method used to calculate phytoplankton loss in the 2010 research greatly overstated plankton losses because of a missing vital factor. Read New Scientist for the details.

title: Greek Deficit Exceeds Target Set by Bailout
description: BRUSSELS  Almost a year after it adopted sweeping austerity measures as a condition of an international rescue package, Greece has failed to get a grip on its public finances, according to new data released on Tuesday, increasing fears that the country may have to restructure its mountain of debt.

title: TBS Orders Its Third Tyler Perry Series
description: If artistic achievement can be measured by the number of shows one has on TBS, Tyler Perry leads Spike Lee in that category, 3-0. On Tuesday that network announced that it was picking up a third television series from Mr. Perry, the actor-writer-director, mini-mogul and sometime nemesis of Mr. Lee, to be adapted from his Why Did I Get Married? movies. The new series, to be called For Better or Worse, will be a comedy-drama produced by Tyler Perry Studios and will star Michael Jai White (The Dark Knight) and Tasha Smith (Couples Retreat) as the husband-and-wife couple they have portrayed in the Married films. The new series, which will start with a 10-episode order and does not yet have a premiere date, joins Mr. Perrys TBS comedies Meet the Browns and House of Payne, which is coming to the end of its run. In a statement, Mr. Perry said: Working on House of Payne taught me a lot about what it takes to make a successful television series and Im looking forward to applying that experience to For Better or Worse.

title: Despite Transmission Failures, Agency Will Not Require Further Action from Honda
description: Although hundreds of Honda owners have reported failures of their vehicles automatic transmissions, in some cases saying they were unable to safely cross a busy street or merge into traffic, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it found no reason to take action.

title: Obama Calls for Repeal of Tax Breaks for Oil Firms
description: With gasoline at the pump costing well over $4 a gallon, President Obama on Tuesday urged congressional leaders to repeal tax breaks for oil and gas companies, and to use the money to reduce the countrys dependence on foreign oil.

title: Gender Games: Answering Questions About Roster Management and Title IX
description: With 270 comments and counting, New York Times readers reacted to my article in Tuesdays paper about roster management with passion, insight and numerous personal stories about how Title IX had affected their lives, whether good or bad. Many readers questioned why so much attention is paid to female athletes and argued that the fact that 57 percent of college students are now female is proof of discrimination against men by colleges and universities. Others asserted that Title IX overlooks the fact that men and women have different interests, and raised the question of whether fewer women want to play sports. Still others said the examples cited in the article showed that, 40 years after it was passed, Title IX needs to be rewritten.

title: Fete Accompli | Chanels Tribeca Film Festival Dinner
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#584", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Acts of Remembrance: Reflecting on How the Holocaust Is Taught
description: Overview | Does the abundance of Holocaust analogies in contemporary society affect the way that we remember the Holocaust? How can we both foster understanding of the Holocaust and encourage young people to draw personal connections? In this lesson, students take a critical look at the ways in which the Holocaust is both referred to in popular culture and taught in school, and consider how teachers and museums can help students understand the Holocaust for the atrocity that it was.

title: Could Ron Paul 2012 Outperform Ron Paul 2008?
description: As Representative Ron Paul of Texas begins his third presidential campaign by announcing the formation of an exploratory committee, there are reasons to think the blunt congressman might wield more influence over the shape, direction and conversation of the Republican contest this time around. (Compare Mr. Paul, circa 2008 and 2012.)

title: A Glimpse of the Le Mans 24-Hour Race
description: There is a three-week gap between the Chinese Grand Prix and the Turkish Grand Prix. This gave the organizers of the worlds most famous 24-hour endurance race a chance to bring back their annual test day, which had been canceled the last two years because of the economic crisis.

title: A Glimpse of the Le Mans 24-Hour Race
description: There is a three-week gap between the Chinese Grand Prix and the Turkish Grand Prix. This gave the organizers of the worlds most famous 24-hour endurance race a chance to bring back their annual test day, which had been canceled the last two years because of the economic crisis.

title: Garment Union Chief Resigns Under a Cloud
description: Facing internal charges that he had abused his expense account, Bruce S. Raynor, the president of the nations main garment workers union, Workers United, announced on Tuesday that he had resigned as president.

title: Vouvrays With an Element of Surprise
description: PERHAPS you have not yet been bitten by the chenin blanc bug and transported to a world of luminous wines made in an astounding range of styles. If so, then opportunity is about to pull a cork for you.

title: Pairings: Thai-Style Scallops and Asparagus
description: Asian restaurants should pay more attention to dry Vouvrays. Like rieslings, which are frequently poured with Thai, Vietnamese and Chinese dishes, Vouvrays knit bright acidity into their alluring canvas of citric and floral aromas and flavors, sometimes kissed with spice or sugar. They are ready for action the minute the fragrances of ginger, coriander and lemon grass waft from the kitchen.

title: As Wall St. Firms Grow, Their Reputations Are Dying
description: Harry Campbell

title: Field Not Set for First Republican Debate
description: Another hiccup from the Republicans nascent presidential nominating contest: With not much more than a week to go before what was to be the first big debate of the campaign season (after the first, first big debate was postponed until September) it is still unclear how many candidates will show up.

title: Deal Made to Repair Bronx Apartment Buildings
description: The cascading leaks, runaway rats and tumbledown ceilings that have bedeviled 10 foreclosed apartment buildings in the Bronx will be repaired under an enforcement agreement that the city forged with the new owner, city officials announced Tuesday.

title: Learning About Loss
description: You have learned something George Bernard Shaw wrote. That always feels at first as if you have lost something.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Turkey, Philippines and Russia.

title: Whos Afraid of Virginia Woolf? Returning to Broadway
description: George and Martha are coming back to Broadway in 2012, seven years since their last rounds of Get the Guests.

title: TimesCast | April 26, 2011
description: April 26, 2011 - Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's daughter Aisha gives rare insight into her family's struggle to hold on to power in Libya; and NATO broadens its attacks on Tripoli.

title: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Afghanistan, Turkey, Philippines and Russia.

title: Gaming Executive Jumps to Zynga
description: Monday was the last day at Electronic Arts for John Schappert, the companys chief operating officer. Mr. Schappert has taken a post at Zynga, the social gaming company and a competitor of Electronic Arts, according to a person briefed on the move who was not authorized to talk about personnel changes.

title: Upgrading the Districts API With RGeo
description: Last year we launched the Districts API, which enables users to retrieve political districts for a location within New York City. The Districts API had its roots in a web application called Represent, which was built using a Python framework with spatial capabilities. At the time Represent was launched, the options for building Ruby mapping applications that used PostgreSQLs spatial features were fairly few, and when we built the Districts service we chose a Ruby adapter that supported many of the most common geometrical features supported by PostGIS.

title: This Little Piggy Built a Glass House
description: Steven Guarnaccias twists on Goldilocks and the Three Bears and The Three Little Pigs (Abrams, $19) recast the fairy tales as only a design dork could. So Papa Bears chair has a ladder back (by Charles Rennie Mackintosh). Goldilocks eats out of an Eva Zeisel bowl. The Three Little Pigs are (above, from left) Philip Johnson, Frank Gehry and Frank Lloyd Wright. And the house before which the Big Bad Wolf hopelessly huffs and puffs is none other than Fallingwater.

title: Of Maidens and Monks, in a Cozy Concert
description: The spontaneity of the 19th-century German Liederabend, an evening of song usually held in a parlor setting, is hard to recreate in a large, formal concert hall. But the genial stage presence of the superb German bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff added a touch of coziness to a recital of works by Brahms and Schumann for vocal ensemble and two pianists at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening.

title: A Kentucky Museum of Coca-Cola Memorabilia Closes
description: A family-run Coca-Cola museum alongside a turnpike ramp in Elizabethtown, Ky., closed without warning late Tuesday, and its 80,000 artifacts will be cataloged for auctions starting in September.

title: Do You Have a Question for Mr. Bernanke?
description: The Federal Reserve enters the age of television Wednesday afternoon. Chairman Ben S. Bernanke will hold a news conference after the regular meeting of the Feds policy-making committee, breaking with the central banks tradition of issuing nothing more than a brief, carefully worded statement describing its decisions.

title: Anti-Sprawl Anthems
description: Dear Brad: Mountains Beyond Mountains is very fine, but if forced to choose Id still go for Chrissie Hynde.

title: Sister Act and Anything Goes Lead Outer Critics Circle Nominations
description: No nominations for Signature Theater Companys revival of Tony Kushners Angels in America? Or for Broadways Driving Miss Daisy? No outstanding new play nod for Jerusalem, and no outstanding musical shout-out for Catch Me If You Can?

title: Madame Nhu, Vietnam War Lightning Rod, Dies
description: Madame Nhu, who as the glamorous official hostess in South Vietnams presidential palace became a politically powerful and often harshly outspoken figure in the early years of the Vietnam War, died on Sunday in Rome, where she had been living. She was 86.

title: Amazon Earnings Hurt by Spending as Revenue Increases 38%
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazon.coms expansion of its online retailing and cloud computing businesses has eroded profits.

title: Excerpt: 'The People in the Picture'
description: Megan Reinking, left, and Donna Murphy sing the number "Oyfen Pripitchik" from the new Broadway musical. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: A Summertime Arts Structure for Governors Island
description: The sponsors of the year-old City of Dreams Pavilion Competition, in which designers compete to create a temporary space for summertime arts activities on Governors Island with minimal environmental impact, have announced this years winning entry. Burble Bup, by the design team Bittertang, will consist of a dome made from inflatable components and mounds made of soil and bark-filled fabric tubes for sitting and climbing; it will be open to the public from May 27 to Sept. 25. According to a statement released by Figment, one of the sponsors, the project was selected from among some 80 competitors and is intended to encourage visitors to lie back and enjoy the shifting colors as light plays through the translucent skins of the Bups.

title: Pink for the Boys, Blue for the Girls
description: In light of the recent flap surrounding the J. Crew ad depicting designer Jenna Lyons painting her sons toenails pink, I enjoyed reading this Smithsonian.com article by Jeanne Maglaty, When Did Girls Start Wearing Pink?

title: In Endeavours Final Act, the Supporting Cast Draws Outsize Attention
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  Capt. Mark E. Kelly, the commander of the space shuttle Endeavour, said Tuesday that his wounded wife, Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, was more than medically ready to travel to Florida for the launching.

title: Technology Advances; Humans Supersize
description: For nearly three decades, the Nobel Prize-winning economist Robert W. Fogel and a small clutch of colleagues have assiduously researched what the size and shape of the human body say about economic and social changes throughout history, and vice versa. Their research has spawned not only a new branch of historical study but also a provocative theory that technology has sped human evolution in an unprecedented way during the past century.

title: Sony Says PlayStation Hacker Got Personal Data
description: Christopher Millers PlayStation Portable game console had been broken for most of two years. So when his parents got him a new one for his 25th birthday on April 18, he was elated  but only briefly.

title: Low Tide and Lower Ambitions
description: LIKE a stray piece of driftwood, a James Perse outpost has washed up on a well-trafficked corner of SoHo, facing the Gourmet Garage, formerly the very apex of Manhattan discount gastronomy, with its shrink-wrapped Camembert. The new shop is a mere mile or so from Mr. Perses New York headquarters in the West Village, where the windows once displayed large white typeface reading: No returns. No refitting. No exchanges. Just kidding.

title: Core Notes
description: A few things worth mentioning about core inflation:

title: A Distinctive Voice, No Matter Who Is Performing
description: John Hollenbeck composes so much music for his own bands  Refuge Trio, the Claudia Quintet and his Large Ensemble, each unmistakable in its identity  that you could go a long time before wondering about the transferable aspects of his style.

title: Interview: Chris Paine
description: Chris Paine, the director of "Revenge of the Electric Car," discusses making this follow-up to his 2006 documentary.

title: Star Chef, Facing a Suit, Files for Bankruptcy

He now has two places in fashionable New York hotels and a hand in hotels in Miami Beach and Atlantic City.

description: The kitchen refrigerator is an obvious contributor to global warming because it usually sucks in electricity that was made by burning fossil fuels. But it turns out that the refrigerator does harm to the environment before it is even plugged in because the insulating foam in its innards is made with a gas that is more than 1,000 times worse, molecule for molecule, than carbon dioxide.

Along with Aeros, Toffee Crisp Clusters and Minstrels, there are M & Ms, Snickers and Twix. Whats so Brit about those? But Jigs Patel, who opened the store about two weeks ago, said that those candies with the familiar names are made for the English and European market. The sweetener is cane sugar, not corn syrup, making them taste a tad less sweet, as a comparison of domestic and imported M & Ms showed.

title: A Book of Recipes Gathered From Holocaust Survivors
description: Recipe books based on the memories of Holocaust survivors might seem to trivialize the horror. But Dr. Ruth Westheimer, one of the survivors featured in Recipes Remembered: A Celebration of Survival, said that food represents identity for these people who did not have a real homeland. June Feiss Hersh interviewed more than 100 survivors and their relatives for the book, and recorded their stories, food memories and recipes, which she also tested. When the dish called for ketchup or canned tomato soup, thats what the recipe included.

title: Thinking Outside the Canvas
description: WASHINGTON  As art mediums go, painting is both intractably consistent and endlessly malleable, and perhaps never more so than now. While it continues to renew itself in its traditional paint-on-canvas incarnations, theres also a well-established maverick branch that is constantly stretching the medium, extending it into installation art or questioning its status as a precious, high-skill commodity, sometimes by eliminating paint altogether.

title: Arizona: Judge Rules Against Maricopa Deputies
description: A federal judge ruled Monday that the Maricopa County Sheriffs Department violated the constitutional rights of Julio Mora, an American citizen, and his father, Julian, a legal resident, in 2009 when deputies stopped their truck and took them to a business where an immigration raid was under way. The Moras were detained along with others arrested in the raid. A trial is expected this year to determine whether the detention was racially motivated and whether Sheriff Joe Arpaio and the deputies should be held individually liable.

title: Texas: Power Failures Cause Refineries to Shut
description: School was canceled and residents were told to stay indoors in Texas City on Tuesday after power failures forced three large oil refineries and a chemical plant to shut operations and burn toxic gases that spewed from smokestacks, officials said. Just after noon, city officials lifted the order to stay indoors. It remained unclear, however, how much pollution had been released during the night, Bruce Clawson, the citys emergency management director said. A BP refinery and a Dow Chemical plant lost power about 10:30 p.m. on Monday. A second power failure at 4:30 a.m. forced two other refineries belonging to Marathon and Valero to shut down. The cause of the power failures was still being investigated.

At several protests during the last two months security forces have opened fire, and an estimated 10 people have been killed and dozens wounded, according to human rights activists.

But Brookfield did not ignore the project in the downturn.

Atheists Seek Chaplain Role in the Military

The vast majority are Christians, a few are Jews or Muslims, one is a Buddhist. A Hindu, possibly even a Wiccan may join their ranks soon.

description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will most likely soon nominate the veteran diplomat Ryan C. Crocker to be the next United States ambassador to Afghanistan, an administration official said Tuesday.
