description: WASHINGTON  When Jayson Werth, the power-hitting right fielder for the Washington Nationals, walked to the plate in the fifth inning Tuesday night, he had already dented the Mets pitching once by smashing a home run. Now, with the score tied, he was in position to do even more damage.

title: Hiding the Truth About Factory Farms
description: A supermarket shopper buying hamburger, eggs or milk has every reason, and every right, to wonder how they were produced. The answer, in industrial agriculture, is behind closed doors, and thats how the industry wants to keep it. In at least three states  Iowa, Florida, and Minnesota  legislation is moving ahead that would make undercover investigations in factory farms, especially filming and photography, a crime. The legislation has only one purpose: to hide factory-farming conditions from a public that is beginning to think seriously about animal rights and the way food is produced.

title: Long After Microsoft, Allen and Gates Cast Shadows Over City
description: SEATTLE  Perhaps at some point there will be one final screaming match between Paul Allen and Bill Gates, the Microsoft founders who transformed this city into a computer capital more than 30 years ago and whose vast fortunes, and different tastes, have been reshaping it ever since.

title: Cynical Games With Title IX
description: The number of women who participate in college sports has more than quintupled  from fewer than 30,000 to 186,000  since 1972, when Congress banned sex discrimination in federally financed education programs. But as Katie Thomas reported in The Times on Tuesday, as women have become a majority on many campuses, some schools are trying to evade Title IX and undermine the goal of gender equality by cooking the books when they report statistics to Washington.

title: Irked at Democrats, Firefighters Suspend Federal Contributions
description: The nations main firefighters union, long a strong supporter of Democratic candidates, announced on Tuesday that it would indefinitely suspend all contributions to federal candidates out of frustration with Congressional Democrats who, union officials say, have not fought harder against budget cuts and antiunion legislation.

title: Bad Numbers
description: If there was any lingering doubt, the latest data confirm that housing is still in a deep and broad recession. In the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price report for 20 large cities, house prices in February fell to a level last seen in April 2009  their lowest point in the bust. In a Census Bureau report, new home sales in March remained near their lowest levels since records were first kept in 1963.

title: No Prosecution Seen for Official in N.S.A. Leak
description: WASHINGTON  A former Justice Department official who told Newsweek that he was one of the sources for a 2005 article in The New York Times about the National Security Agencys program of wiretapping without warrants will not be prosecuted for leaking secret information, his lawyer said on Tuesday.

title: Nobody Puts Condoleezza Rice in a Corner
description: Much has been written about your unique relationship with George W. Bush. Youre a history buff  are you aware of any relationships like it? Not really. I think there have been other secretaries of state who were close friends, like James Baker and George H. W. Bush. But when youre in those positions, you always have to remember that hes the president, hes the elected one. The president can never quite be your friend. The fact that you have been friends before he was president just gives you a level of trust and a level of comfort that I think is very helpful. I could be very direct with him.

title: Mexico: Body Counts Increase as Authorities Search Mass Graves
description: The number of bodies found in mass graves in northeastern Mexico has risen to 183, officials said Tuesday as investigators continued searching a rural region of Tamaulipas State about 90 miles south of the Texas border. The authorities have detained 74 people, including 17 police officers from the municipality of San Fernando, on suspicion of involvement in the killings, Mexicos attorney general, Marisela Morales, said. Many of the victims were believed to be migrants traveling to the United States on long-distance buses who were kidnapped by the Zetas drug cartel. Officials searching through another mass grave in the north-central state of Durango said Tuesday that the toll there had risen to 75.

title: New Zealand: Christchurch Facing 20 Years of Earthquake Repairs
description: Christchurch, New Zealands second-largest city, faces up to 20 years of rebuilding as a result of an earthquake in February that destroyed one-third of its central business district, according to a business official involved in the project. There will not be a finite day on which this is finished, said Jonathan Ling, chief executive of Fletcher Building Ltd. There will be new buildings going up in the central business district, Mr. Ling said, on empty blocks probably for 10, 15 or 20 years. Fletcher Building was appointed by the government as project manager for the reconstruction of homes damaged in Christchurch after a magnitude 7 temblor on Sept. 4. It is also directing some repairs in the business district after another quake, on Feb. 22, killed more than 170 people and destroyed much of the city.

description: If theres anything I cant stand, its somebody kicking the back of my chair. That, and the public clipping of fingernails. And loud gum chewing, begins a Science Times article about a new book on what irritates us and why. What would be high on your list of annoyances? Why?

title: Chris Hondros in New York
description: Africa and Asia were the settings of the photos for which Chris Hondros of Getty Images will be best remembered. But Brooklyn was his home, as his friend Todd Heisler recalls.

title: Credit Suisse Profit Drops 45%
description: Credit Suisse said on Wednesday that its net income fell significantly in the first quarter, as the wider banking sector struggled to maintain profit levels.

title: Pipeline Blast in Sinai, Said to Be Sabotage, Cuts Gas Supply in Israel and Jordan
description: JERUSALEM  An explosion early Wednesday at a gas pipeline in the northern Sinai Peninsula cut supplies of Egyptian natural gas to Israel for the second time this year in what Israeli and Egyptian officials said was an act of sabotage.

title: Long Repressed in Syria, an Internal Opposition Takes Shape
description: Syrias nascent opposition movement, organized by an amorphous group of young activists operating mainly online, now faces its biggest test: whether it can sustain protests in the face of a brutal government crackdown.

title: At Maison Rouge in Paris, Body Art (Literally)
description: The current exhibition at Maison Rouge, an art space in the Bastille area, is not for the faint of heart. The curator of the Tous Cannibales exhibition, Jeanette Zwingenberger, takes you on a journey through the history of art and across continents, on the way taking in every possible variant on the theme of cannibalism.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Christian Ponder, Second-Ranked Quarterback
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. This series counts down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: The Early Word: Front Lines
description: Todays Times

title: Soccer Royalty and the Royal Wedding
description: Ever the globetrotter, David Beckham and his wife, Victoria, will be in London on Friday for the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton.

title: Who Cares About Inflation?
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Tibetan Exiles Elect Scholar as New Prime Minister
description: NEW DELHI  Tibets exiled government announced the election of a Harvard legal scholar as its new prime minister on Wednesday, a choice signaling a generational shift within the Tibetan movement as the Dalai Lama moves to relinquish political power.

title: Papas in the House of Windsor
description: Thus begins my parody of Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds now that Ive seen the Papa Johns royal-wedding pie, which apparently is available only in England  and theres only one, which will be raffled off to some lucky (I guess?) winner as part of William and Kates big day.

title: Mitzvah Tanks Roll Again
description: We go out there like soldiers, with a mission to conquer the world with light, with goodness, with kindness, said Yishai Eliefja, 23, a Hasidic Jew who works for the Chabad Lubavitchs mitzvah tanks, or synagogues on wheels.

title: 'Are You Jewish?'
description: Mitzvah tanks, or "synagogue on wheels'', operated by the Chabad Lubavitch group of Hasidic Jews, are set to hit city streets.

title: Afghan Military Officer Kills 8 U.S. Service Members
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Eight American service members and a contractor were shot and killed by an Afghan military officer on Wednesday while they attended a meeting of foreign and Afghan officers on the military side of Kabul International Airport, according to statements from Afghan and NATO spokesmen.

title: New Art at Lincoln Center: Lawn Care
description: Lincoln Center has long cultivated audiences and donors. Now the countrys largest performing arts complex is learning how to cultivate grass.

title: How We Hired a Web Developer
description: Several months ago, I wrote about my revelation that I needed (as opposed to wanted) to redo all of my Web sites. Two are e-commerce and three are informational. Like many companies, I have tried to keep up with the Internet revolution, and I think Ive done O.K. My revelation was that O.K. is no longer good enough if you are in an industry that has seen shopping behaviors change because of the Internet. Are there any industries that havent?

title: Gas Pumps Become Battleground for Obama and Republicans
description: President Obama offered top donors in California last week a peek into what he saw as one of his own vulnerabilities: the price of gas at the pump.

title: CenturyLink Set to Acquire Savvis for $2.5 Billion
description: CenturyLink, the nations third largest telecommunications company, announced on Wednesday that it would buy the information technology firm Savvis for $2.5 billion, in a play on so-called cloud computing.

title: Lazards Quarterly Profit Falls 5%
description: 8:14 a.m. | Updated

title: 2021 and All That
description: OK, a calmer followup on Taylor. Originally he claimed that there had been a huge expansion in government under Obama; I pointed out that about half the rise in the ratio of spending to GDP reflected low GDP, not high spending, and that the other half was basically safety net programs:

title: New York Should Get a Kick Out of King Eric
description: There are lots of reasons why its going to be fun tracking the New York Cosmos in the coming years as the resurrected soccer team tries to make itself matter again. Above all, the characters. The flamboyant new owner, Paul Kemsley, the main subject of David Segals piece in the magazine a little over a week ago, seems like a good fit for a club whose roll call has included the likes of the late Steve Ross (flamboyant head of Warner Communications) and Giorgio Chinalgia (flamboyant former striker for the Cosmos, current international ambassador for the Cosmos and wanted man by the Italian authorities a couple years ago for trying to influence the share prices of S.S. Lazio). And the Wilpons might get involved.

title: David Leonhardt is Shrill
description: He keeps pointing out that inflation is not a problem, but unemployment is, and that the Feds real failure has been doing too little, not too much.

title: A Beast in the Heart of Every Fighting Man
description: Last May, in the small village of Qualaday in western Kandahar Province, a young Army lieutenant and his sergeants met with several elders to discuss the recent killing of a local mullah. The desert heat was fierce, and the elders led the soldiers across their village to sit under the shade of nearby trees. Three days had passed since they were last there; during that interval the place appeared to have been abandoned. When they sat down, some of the soldiers removed their helmets, and a few elders their sandals and turbans. A freelance photographer was permitted to make an audio recording of the discussion. The lieutenant wanted to know where everyone had gone. One elder explained: People left because they were afraid.

title: An Insurance Company With An Army
description: A general reminder whenever budget issues are discussed: the U.S. government is  this isnt original  best thought of as a giant insurance company with an army. When you talk about federal spending, youre overwhelmingly talking about Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and defense. And the bulk of the insurance  all of Social Security and Medicare, about 2/3 of Medicaid  is for the elderly and disabled.

title: A Second Life for the Electric Car Battery
description: As I wrote in a recent Times article on electric car batteries, scientists are expecting big breakthroughs in battery technology over the next five years that will increase the range of electric cars while reducing their cost. But even with these advances, researchers acknowledge that any rechargeable battery will gradually lose its capacity to store energy after repeated cycles of charging and discharging.

title: Panetta and Petraeus in Line for Top Security Posts
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will reshuffle his national security team on Thursday, naming Leon E. Panetta, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, as defense secretary and Gen. David H. Petraeus, the top American commander in Afghanistan, to lead the C.I.A., administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Morning Buzz | Building That Burned Had Troubled Past
description: Alas, not quite the perfection that was Tuesday; instead, a high of about 71 degrees with some overcast skies.

title: Wednesday Reading: How to Avoid Rental Car Fees
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: India Puts Tight Leash on Internet Free Speech
description: MUMBAI, India  Free speech advocates and Internet users are protesting new Indian regulations restricting Web content that, among other things, can be considered disparaging, harassing, blasphemous or hateful.

title: NATO Officials Acknowledge Frustration in Libya Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates stood on the steps of the Pentagon late Tuesday alongside Liam Fox, his counterpart from Britain, Americas closest ally. Questions swirled here, in Europe and across North Africa whether NATO was specifically trying to find and kill Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, with airstrikes.

title: Big Changes to American Expresss Blue Cash Card
description: American Express is altering the rewards formula on its popular Blue Cash card, but current users will be grandfathered in under the old program for now.

title: Boeing Chief Says Rivet Flaws Appear Limited to One Jet
description: The riveting flaws in the roof of the Southwest Airlines jet that recently tore open in flight appear to be poor manufacturing work on that one plane rather than a broader design failure, Boeings chief executive said Wednesday.

title: Road-Going Chitty Chitty Bang Bang Is Up for Auction
description: The auctioneers are calling it The Most Famous Car in the World. In truth, there are multiple Chitty Chitty Bang Bangs, beginning with aircraft-engined racing cars that inspired the Ian Fleming childrens book and subsequent 1968 movie.

title: Gosh, Sweetie, Thats a Big Gun
description: THE summer season brings the usual cavalcade of testosterone-fueled action heroes, including Thor, the Green Lantern, Captain America and Conan the Barbarian. But action-movie derring-do is not always an exclusively male preserve, and in the last year some women and girls  Evelyn Salt, Lisbeth Salander and the lingerie-clad avengers of Sucker Punch, among others  have been shooting and not just clawing their way into macho territory. Is this empowerment or exploitation? Feminism or fetishism? The chief film critics of The New York Times, Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott, discuss the new pow, crash and splat.

title: High Fiber
description: It sometimes feels as if no aspect of American midcentury modern design has been left unconsidered, unexhibited, unreissued. But there is undiscovered territory. Youre sitting on it.

title: Bloomberg and Cuomo Meet, Over Pasta and Fish
description: The mayor ordered the fettuccine ($25). The governor had the yellowfin tuna steak ($35). Ever-vigilant about waistlines, they skipped dessert. And despite the chasm that separates their net worth, they split the bill.

title: Orders for Manufactured Goods Rise for a Third Month
description: Businesses in the United States increased their orders for heavy machinery, computers, autos and steel in March, and raised demand for long-lasting manufactured goods for a third consecutive month.

title: Schlesinger Letters Will Be Collected in New Book
description: The letters that Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. wrote over a career of nearly seven decades in public life, including correspondence with John F. Kennedy, Henry A. Kissinger, Katharine Graham and Reinhold Niebuhr will be collected in a new book that Random House has acquired. And while it will contain documents like Schlesingers critique of Kennedys manuscript for Profiles in Courage, it will not include the donkey that William F. Buckley Jr. sent to Schlesinger.

title: UK, Not OK
description: The bad GDP number for the UK isnt a surprise  in fact, judging from market response, investors seem to have expected something even worse. Still, if you step back and look at what has been happening, its doubleplusungood: zero growth over the past 6 months, with every reason to be worried on the downside looking forward, as Camerons austerity bites deeper.

title: Who Made Those Emblem Health Commercials?
description: Emblem Health, a New York-based insurance company, has been running commercials for a while now with quirky, black-and-white line drawings. The campaign revolves around using the logo as a patch to create other hand-drawn, line-art shapes according to an article from the design site Under Consideration that was written when the commercials were first aired. Some piano music starts and ends each vignette. The effect is casual, fun and somewhat surprising for a health insurance company.

title: Game 7 Preview: Tampa Bay at Pittsburgh
description: The Penguinsare exudinga carefree attitude about the two consecutive losses that have led to a Game 7 at home tonight at 8:00 p.m. against the Lightning, and you cannot blame them. Without leading men Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin, two months ago Pittsburgh would have been pleased with hosting a Game 7 in the opening round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Obama Releases Long-Form Birth Certificate
description: President Obama on Wednesday posted online a copy of his long-form birth certificate from the State of Hawaii, hoping to finally end a long-simmering conspiracy theory among some conservatives who have asserted that he was not born in the United States and was not a legitimate president.

title: Everyone Is Middle Class, Right?
description: Ive been complaining lately about how how surprisingly little Americans know about income distribution and their own place within it. Americans all seem to think theyre middle class, even those in the top 5 percent of all earners. As a result they frequently misunderstand what political mantras like lets tax the rich really mean.

title: Jobs Says Apple Made Mistakes With iPhone Data
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hoping to put to rest a growing controversy over privacy, Steven P. Jobs, Apples chief executive, took the unusual step of personally explaining that while Apple had made mistakes in how it handled location data on its mobile devices, it had not used the iPhone and iPad to keep tabs on the whereabouts of its customers.

title: The Many Shapes of Climate Knowledge
description: After I gave a talk at Pennsylvania State University not long ago, a professor there asked if I could share the slide I use to describe one source of confusion and disputes when people are yelling about global warming or climate change. Heres an improved version of the slide, which I hope helps reveal that the issue cant be meaningfully discussed without getting into some more specifics:

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: On Our Radar: Big Profits for Big Oil
description: A sharp run-up in oil prices since January will produce a windfall for major oil companies, which are expected to report their biggest quarterly profits since 2008 this week, analysts said. Leading the pack is Exxon Mobil, whose profits are expected to approach $10 billion for the first three months of the year. [MarketWatch]

title: Ristretto | Santa Cruz Comes to Queens
description: Verve Coffee Roasters is in a small stucco shopping center on 41st Avenue, a sun-baked Santa Cruz street that surfers use to get to the beach. I first stopped by Verve in 2009 because David Kinch, the Michelin-starred chef of Manresa, is a regular, and after downing an immaculate macchiato and picking out a couple of bags of whole beans I was reminded of how the Left Coast still has it, that a roaster in a tiny storefront thats a five-minute walk from the ocean and just down the block from a destination taqueria can turn out some of the countrys most remarkable coffee.

title: MOOSE
description: Acronym for expenditure on information and communications technology: Maintain the Organization, Operation, Systems and Equipment.

title: A Child Regresses. Is Autism to Blame?
description: If a young child suddenly stops speaking, is autism to blame? That is among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Fred Volkmar, director of the Yale Child Study Center, explores the issue of regression in children and the diagnosis of autism. For more information on autism, see the additional responses in Ask the Experts About Autism, and The Times Health Guide: Autism.

title: Tribeca Video Interview With Chris Paine
description: The documentary filmmaker Chris Paine follows up his 2006 film Who Killed the Electric Car? with a profile of some of the individuals who have worked to bring electric cars back into the mainstream. Among the subjects of Revenge of the Electric Car are Bob Lutz, a former vice chairman of General Motors; Carlos Ghosn, the Renault-Nissan chairman; and Elon Musk, the chairman of the electric car manufacturer Tesla Motors.

title: Marathon Organizers Highlight Citys Economic Gain
description: The New York City Marathon produces about $340 million in economic activity for the city, 25 percent more than it did in 2006, according to a new study produced by the New York Road Runners, which hosts the event.

title: Self Esteem
description: Years ago, a friend of mine observed that 80 percent of the people in this country have way too much self-esteem and 20 percent have much too little. That struck me as pretty accurate, but psychologists will tell you that self-esteem is not a constant. Peoples appraisal of their own worth varies.

title: Sheepshead Bay Steeples to Be Stabilized, Not Removed
description: The congregants were prepared for something completely different: the removal of their beloved steeples, not the arrival of cables to hold them in place.

title: Scores Die in Storms Across South; Tornado Ravages City
description: Devastating storms swept through the South on Wednesday, killing at least 60 people and spawning a tornado that tore through downtown Tuscaloosa, Ala. The evening twister flattened homes and buildings and brought further damage and death to a region already battered by storms.

title: Trump Takes Credit for Release of Obama Birth Certificate
description: 12:39 p.m. | Updated  PORTSMOUTH, N.H.  Donald Trump arrived here Wednesday morning, stepped off a helicopter emblazoned with his name and flashed a wide smile as he took credit for the release of President Obamas long-form birth certificate.

title: Ryan ONeal to Write of Life With Farrah Fawcett
description: Someday, Ryan ONeal might write a memoir that takes in the entirety of his career, from breakthrough films like Love Story and Paper Moon to under-appreciated works like Barry Lyndon. But his first book will not be that book.

title: Light Fantastic | Olafur Eliasson in Iceland
description: On May 4 the Icelandic capital will celebrate the opening of the Harpa-Reykjavik Concert Hall and Conference Center, a stunning monolith whose shimmering glass facade was designed by the artist Olafur Eliasson. The building will be the new home of the Icelandic Opera and the Iceland Symphony Orchestra (which previously had to make do with performing in movie theaters), and for the opening celebration there will be concerts by local bands like Mammt and Agent Fresco as well as screenings of nature movies and documentaries. Many Icelanders hope the building, conceived of as a new cultural hot spot for the city, will also be a tourist draw during the long, dark winters  a fact of life that was central to the design. In Iceland, 30 percent of the day is twilight. One third of peoples lives are lived in this transitional zone, says Eliasson, whose facade reflects the low northern light in bewitching variation, as though it is lit from within. The relationship people in Iceland have to the landscape is like the relationship you have to a close family member. It has to do with the way the light gives the landscape a constantly changing personality. It speaks to you with such finesse.

title: President Obamas Long Form Birth Certificate
description: President Obama on Wednesday posted online a copy of his long form birth certificate from the state of Hawaii, hoping to finally end a long-simmering conspiracy theory among some conservatives.

title: N.F.L. Draft Boards Take On Lives of Their Own
description: It has been more than three months since the last meaningful college football game, but N.F.L. prospects have kept busy. They have been working out, attending pro days for scouts, meeting with teams and climbing up and down the draft rankings like children on a jungle gym.

title: Older and Colder
description: I was oddly excited to read that a couple of scientists at the Scripps Research Institute in La Jolla, Calif., had published a huge study of the relationship between age and body temperature. Here at last, I thought, might be the answer to one of lifes most enduring mysteries: Why do assisted living facilities and nursing homes always feel like Phoenix in August? Do old people really prefer, or need, such relentlessly toasty temperatures?

title: A Weekend in Istanbul
description: The Turkish city is full of restaurants, cafes and galleries.

title: A Killing in Brooklyn Is Caught on Video
description: The police have released a surveillance video of a fatal shooting Saturday night in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, in the hope of finding the killer.

title: Test of Eye Drug Is Said to Show Success in Elderly
description: A far less expensive alternative proved roughly as effective as Genentechs costly drug Lucentis in preserving or improving vision in elderly people with a common eye disease, according to two people familiar with the results of a closely watched clinical trial.

title: Team Lotus Buys Caterham, Maker of the Seven
description: One of the most recognizable British sports-car manufacturers has been acquired by one of the most controversial Formula One outfits.

title: Lopez and Fuller to Start Latin Music Talent Search
description: Now that Jennifer Lopez has been acquainted with the singers on American Idol, shes going to search for singing talent throughout the Americas.

title: Big Law Firms Profits and Revenues Rise in American Lawyer Survey
description: The Big Law profit machine is revving up again.

title: Now Appearing, Real Daphne
description: NO word sufficiently sums up Daphne Guinness. Eccentric seems too quaint for a woman who recently had a pair of shoes fabricated to resemble knives. No, the Real Daphne (@TheRealDaphne) may be closer to the spirit of 19th-century romantic adventurers. She takes risks.

title: WikiLeaks and the Cable Guys
description: The diplomat and strategist George F. Kennan was a marvelous connoisseur of his own bitterness, and some of the funniest passages in his Memoirs: 1925-1950 concern just how little interest the State Department had in his various cables and memorandums. On one sad occasion he was in Washington helping to sort backlogs and pulled out some of his own unread dispatches, confronting him with the choice of trashing them forever or saving them for the files. Kennan was a great writer and knew it; he kept them, unopened, for the files, marked of interest.

title: Shifting Sands of Societies and Politics
description: ONE of the farthest places an artist could be from painting in a cozy studio would probably be pursuing swirling dust devils in the sweltering Mexican highlands.

title: Alexei Ratmansky Gives ABT 10 More Years
description: When the major choreographer Alexei Ratmansky signed on as artist in residence at American Ballet Theater in 2008, it was considered a coup for a company that had sometimes been criticized for conservative repertory. So the news that Mr. Ratmansky has extended his contract all the way to 2023 can be considered a significant vote of confidence.

title: Why Is Enough Never Enough?
description: As we await the verdict in the insider-trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group hedge fund, the following question comes to mind: Why would people who seem to have it all  wealth, prestige, powerful jobs and infinite access to others with the same  risk that, and more, to provide inside information to the Sri Lankan-born billionaire?

title: Picture Books About Fearless Women
description: In the 1980s, biography-loving schoolgirls had to content themselves with predictable accounts either of a few favored first ladies like Dolley Madison (with the inevitable ice cream associations) and Abigail Adams, or of the courageous nurses Clara Barton and Florence Nightingale.

title: Talking About Her Love of McCullers
description: WHEN she was a teenager, Suzanne Vega spotted a biography of the writer Carson McCullers in a library. She didnt actually read the book, but the image on the cover left a deep impression.

title: Visa Invests in Square for Mobile Payments
description: 12:43 p.m. | Updated  Adding comment from Visa.

title: The White House, the Democrats and the Deficit
description: During the health care debate, it was fair to argue that the Democratic Party was more serious than the Republican Party about the underlying policy questions. By this I dont mean that the Democrats necessarily had the correct approach to our dysfunctional health care system, or that the final legislation deserved to pass. (I dont think it did.) But the proposals that eventually became the Affordable Care Act/Obamacare at least took the the systems pathologies seriously, drew on some of the smartest liberal health care wonkery, and tried to grapple with the scale of the problems they were confronting. The Republicans, on the other hand, never coalesced around a substantial alternative, declined to embrace the best proposals from conservative policy thinkers, and generally made a purely negative (and sometimes cynical) case against the Democratic bill, rather than setting out a convincing and rigorous alternative.

title: Updates on the Unrest in Syria and the NATO Campaign in Libya
description: On Wednesday, The Lede is compiling reports on the war in Libya, protests in Syria and uprisings against governments across the Middle East from journalists, bloggers and activists in the region.

title: The Tragedy of Arthur
Fake Memoir With Bogus Shakespeare
description: The Tragedy of Arthur is a novel about the discovery of what is reputed to be a lost Shakespeare play, and with it Arthur Phillips has found the perfect vehicle for his cerebral talents: his ingenuity; his bright, elastic prose; and, most notably, his penchant for pastiche  for pouring his copious literary gifts into old vessels and reinventing familiar genres.

title: Game 7 Preview: Montreal at Boston
description: Less than 24 hours after the Canadiens and Bruins crashed into each other for 60 minutes, and Montreal held on for a 2-1 win to knot the first-round playoff series, the rivals will play Game 7 tonight at 7:00 p.m.

title: Fatah and Hamas Announce Outline of Deal
description: JERUSALEM  The two main Palestinian factions, Fatah and Hamas, announced Wednesday that they were putting aside years of bitter rivalry to create an interim unity government and hold elections within a year, a surprise move that promised to reshape the diplomatic landscape of the Middle East.

title: Despite Authors Death, Crime Series to Continue
description: Two popular series created by Robert B. Parker, the prolific mystery writer who died last year at the age of 77, will continue under two new authors, his publisher said on Wednesday. G. P. Putnams Sons, Mr. Parkers publisher, said that the Spenser series, whose first-person hero is a tough Boston private detective, would now be written by Ace Atkins, a crime novelist, and that the Jesse Stone series, featuring a former athlete with a drinking problem, would be taken over by Michael Brandman, producer and screenwriter of the Jesse Stone movies on CBS.

title: Guide to Navigating Rental Car Fees
description: From Seth Kugel, our Frugal Traveler colleague:

title: Kobe Bryant Rises Again
description: O.K., everyone can breathe now. For a minute anyway. Normalcy is restored. For now. Sort of.

title: Can Chasing Small Customers Lead to Larger Profits?
description: Darren Robbins and a partner founded Big D Custom Screen Printing in 2007. In its first year, the company, which is based in Austin, Tex., and specializes in printing T-shirts, recorded sales of $325,000 and a small loss.

title: Players to Watch at the Draft
description: Ask 10 experts, and they will give you 10 lists of the top prospects in Thursday nights N.F.L. draft. The following list does not reflect who the top 10 players are, nor does it predict who the first 10 players selected will be. These are the prospects you will hear the most about, all through the three days of the draft, until you cannot take any more.

title: Comcast Bolsters Its On-Demand Roster
description: Comcast said Wednesday that it had become the first cable or satellite provider to have TV shows from each of the four major networks on its video-on-demand service.

title: Animals, Cruelty and Videotape
description: The animal advocacy group Mercy for Animals sent an undercover investigator to E6 Cattle Company in Texas, where he filmed calf abuse over a two-week period.

title: Bernanke At Bat
description: Ill outsource this to Atrios, who gets it exactly right:

title: Royal Wedding? What Royal Wedding?
description: Gail Collins: So, David, are you looking forward to the royal wedding?

title: A Rustic Residence
description: Franck and Julie Besnards home in La Celle-Saint-Cloud, a Paris suburb, is a former gardeners residence with a second-floor greenhouse.

title: The Psychology of Risky Behavior
description: Looking at the highfliers in the Galleon insider trading case, William D. Cohan, a contributor to the New York Times Opinion section, examines why people who seem to have it all want to threaten their wealth, prestige and top jobs with risky behavior. Is it really just that they think they can get away with it? Read more

title: Chris Young Pitches Again but Uncertainty Remains
description: WASHINGTON  Chris Young had the kind of outing Tuesday one might expect from a pitcher coming off the disabled list and dealing with flulike symptoms. Young was tagged for three monstrous home runs, two by Wilson Ramos and one by Jayson Werth, but he did not have a lot of base runners clogging the base paths. So the three home runs were all solo, and that enabled the Mets to stay in the game and eventually win, 6-4.

title: Bernanke Defends Feds Role in Running Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, on Wednesday conducted the first scheduled press conference in the central banks history, sitting behind a mahogany desk as cameras clicked and flashed. Mr. Bernanke explained his management of the economy in the calm, patient and serious manner of the college professor that he used to be.

title: Derivatives Market Faces New Capital Rules
description: 7:51 p.m. | Updated

title: In France, a Home Nestled in Nature
description: LA CELLE-SAINT-CLOUD, France  On a bright spring day a few years ago, Franck Besnard found himself striding up a gently sloping hill in this suburb about 10 miles west of Paris. Perched atop the hill next to an orchard of pear and apple trees was a quaint 19th-century stone-and-glass structure, a gardeners residence with a second-floor greenhouse covered with tiny windowpanes.

title: YouTube Founders Buy Delicious From Yahoo
description: Fans of Delicious, an online bookmarking service, raised a ruckus after word leaked four months ago that its owner, Yahoo, might shutter it as part of a streamlining plan.

title: WellPoint Joins Other Insurers in Strong Earnings
description: Wall Street has had more reasons to like the health care industry in the last week.

title: Fresh From the Oven
description: Dont expect to find baguettes and pastries at Grand Street Bakery. Come May, the space will be transformed into a shop for delicious goods of the vintage variety: heritage butcher stripe shirts will hang from the baking racks, a scattering of leather purses will reside on the wooden tables, and bangles and beaded necklaces will be displayed on bagel holders. The idea for the space was cooked up by Neal Mello, the former buyer for What Goes Around Comes Around and Urban Outfitters, who hounded the previous owner every day for two months before it finally became his. Mello artfully retrofitted the dcor to its new use: the large metal ovens now double as changing rooms for cool garb like neon swimsuits, and the flour silos provide spacious storage. Hes also added furniture, art books and records to sell alongside his finely selected apparel collection. There are plans to have a lounge and espresso bar on the back patio and host art shows in the basement. But one thing remains the same: I am going to keep the name The Grand Street Bakery here. Its been here 25 years, and I told the landlady I was going to leave this sign.

title: Small Budget Airlines Zoom Between Small Cities
description: EVA PICKENS has made the six-hour drive between Huntsville, Ala., where her son lives, and her hometown near Destin, Fla., too many times to count. So when she saw that a carrier called Vision Airlines was advertising $49 one-way nonstop flights between the two places, she snapped up a ticket. By comparison, filling up my gas tank now costs like $62, said Ms. Pickens, a community association manager for a beachfront condo.

title: NBC Draws a Crowd With The Voice
description: The Voice, NBCs much-promoted new singing competition show, proved two things in its premiere outing Tuesday night: The current television season has a legitimate, out-of-the-box, ratings hit; and NBC, for all its recent ratings disasters, still knows how to draw a crowd.

title: Waiting Lists Have Plenty of Company
description: For those families running the college admissions gantlet for the first time, the use of waiting lists can be among the most bewildering aspects of a process that offers no shortage of bewilderment.

title: Beauty Spots
description: SWEET REWARD

title: In Florida, H.M.O.s Would Treat Medicaid Patients
description: DAVIE, Fla.  A crucial experiment in the future of Medicaid is playing out in Florida, where both houses of the Legislature are vying to find ways to drastically cut costs, manage care and reduce waste and fraud.

title: Supreme Court Allows Contracts That Prohibit Class-Action Arbitration
description: WASHINGTON  Businesses may use standard-form contracts to forbid consumers claiming fraud from banding together in a single arbitration, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday in a 5-to-4 decision that split along ideological lines.

description: Time was when parents were parents.

title: When Bigger Bodies Mean Progress
description: The recent supersizing of the human body has been cause for alarm  a sign of the obesity epidemic and a potential health crisis. But as I point out in an article on Wednesday, for most of human history, increases in height and weight meant progress  in food production and disease control.

title: Lightweight Amarok P1 Electric Bike Fights Battery Bloat
description: What would the spawn of a wolf, a beaver, an otter and a mosquito look like?

title: Bernankes News Conference
description: Rarely has a news conference been greeted with as much anticipation  and as little doubt about what will be said  as this afternoons appearance by Ben Bernanke, the Feds chairman.

description: Rarely has a news conference been greeted with as much anticipation  and as little doubt about what will be said  as this afternoons appearance by Ben Bernanke, the Feds chairman.

title: Obama Releases 'Long Form' Birth Records
description: John Harwood and Michael D. Shear discuss President Obama's decision to release a copy of his long form birth certificate on Wednesday, hoping to finally end a long-simmering conspiracy theory.

title: On Frank Vogel and Coaching Audacity
description: The Indiana Pacers season is finished, and the Chicago Bulls are moving on to their rightful place in the conference semifinals. Even after an unexpectedly competitive series, all things are as they should be: Derrick Rose emerged a hero, Indiana met its fate in just five games, and Chicago has begun rounding into form for the postseasons more treacherous later rounds.

title: Homes for $650,000
description: A 1910 house in Austin, Tex.; a log house on the Deschutes River in Oregon; and a condo in an 1850 carriage house in Boston.

title: Why Johnson & Johnson Is Using Stock to Buy Synthes
description: Johnson & Johnsons bid for Synthes, a Swiss-American medical equipment manufacturer, makes a lot of strategic sense.

title: Samurai Shopper | Queen for a Day
description: Would you like to be queen for a day? Too bad, the Samurai Shopper got here first, and today  and only today  I am your sovereign. Long may I rave. Instead of adding more palaver about how the two future queens of England  Camilla and Catherine  may or may not deserve their exalted stature, Im reveling in mine. Queen for a Day, you may remember, was a stupefying TV show of the late 1950s and early 1960s bestowing refrigerators, wheelchairs and whatnots on needy women, most of whom hated being charity cases.

title: Tribeca Q&A: Alex Gibney on Catching Hell
description: Alex Gibney, chronicler of spectacular self-destruction in documentaries like Casino Jack and the United States of Money and Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer, turned his attention to a mostly blameless pariah for his latest film.

title: Beyond Whiskers on Kittens
description: A look at musicals in development that arent afraid to make audiences squirm.

title: Capturing a Queens Theaters Alluring Decay
Musicians Depicted in Baby Its You! File Suit  Right Before Opening Night
description: The Broadway musical Baby Its You!, about the pop and doo-wop music company Scepter Records, has quickly yielded a disharmonious reunion of several artists from that label. On Tuesday  the day before the show formally opens  lawyers representing Dionne Warwick, Chuck Jackson and Beverly Lee, a founding member of the girl group the Shirelles, as well as the estates of Doris Coley Jackson and Addie Harris McFadden, both founding members of that group, filed suit against the producers of Baby Its You!, saying their names, likenesses and life stories are being depicted without their consent.

title: Thunder Feel a Little Heat in Playoffs
description: You would think the Oklahoma City Thunder would be happy and peaceful, holding a commanding 3-1 series lead over the Denver Nuggets going into tonights game.

title: YouTube Founders Pick Up Delicious From Yahoo
description: After an unspectacular run at Yahoo, Delicious, a social bookmarking service, has found a new home.

title: School Nurses See Both Bullies and Victims
description: School bullies and their victims both spend more time at the nurses office compared with their other classmates, according to a new report.

title: Bleak Outlook for U.S.-China Talks on Human Rights
description: BEIJING  By many accounts, the two decades of off-again-on-again human rights talks between the United States and China have been tedious and unrewarding exercises in diplomatic theater. If the Chinese are in an obliging mood, criticisms of Beijings human rights record are grudgingly noted, allowing both sides to issue communiqus describing the meetings as meaningful or constructive to enhancing mutual understanding.

title: Spark Plugs: Joining Carburetors on the Automotive Scrap Heap?
description: A team from Romania and Japan has developed a multibeam laser system that can reportedly replace the spark plug as a means of igniting fuel in a gasoline internal combustion engine. According to a BBC report, the team will present its findings at the Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics, scheduled for May 1 in Baltimore.

title: Microbial Life in the Oceans Desert
description: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

title: Waste-to-Electricity Plan Draws Mixed Response in N.Y.
description: One of the new initiatives included in the recently updated version of Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs environmental agenda  a plan to solicit proposals to try out new technologies that convert garbage into heat and electricity - is drawing mixed reviews from environmental groups.

title: Asked & Answered | Edwina Alexander
description: Equestrian fashion is nothing new  Herms, after all, started out as a saddle maker for the czars of Russia, and Ralph Lauren has been catering to the horsy set for decades. Guccis signature snaffle added some equine elegance to the brands mens moccasins when it first appeared in 1953. In the 80s, Gucci in fact hopped in the saddle and created an annual jumping competition, the Gucci Trophy. Participants clad in Gucci red and green stripes and the houses signature crest took to the ring in style. The technically correct riding gear was available in Gucci stores, affording non-blue-bloods the opportunity to look like blue ribbon winners.

title: Premiere of The Voice Speaks Loudly in TV Ratings
description: The Voice, NBCs answer to the American Idol phenomenon, delivered impressive ratings in its premiere on Tuesday night, garnering 11.8 million viewers from 9 to 11 p.m. and, more important, the nights highest results among viewers 18 to 49, well ahead of even Foxs Glee in that demographic, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: Barclays and Credit Suisse Show Weakness
description: LONDON  Barclays and Credit Suisse on Wednesday reported earnings declines for the first quarter, partly because of weaker revenue from their investment banking operations.

title: Singapore Sends Its Chefs on the Road
description: People who know food know that Singapore is a top culinary destination, with its variety of hawker food stalls and abundant seafood. For those who are unfamiliar with the flavors of the city-state and have no plans to visit, just wait  Singapore might come to you. It is sending some of its top chefs, along with a pop-up kitchen, on a yearlong journey around the world, as part of the Singapore Takeout project.

title: Holding Companies Accountable for Privacy Breaches
description: Its become almost a weekly occurrence: Another online company letting customers personal and private information leak because of an Internet breach.

title: Prisoner? No, Your Honor, Id Rather Be a Diplomat
description: ALBANY  Vincent L. Leibell III, a former state senator who pleaded guilty in December to corruption charges, is to be sentenced in two weeks.

title: Bernanke Wimps Out
description: So Bernanke did get asked why, given low inflation and high unemployment, the Fed isnt doing more. And his answer was disheartening.

title: U.S. Lawyer Is Barred From Rwanda Tribunal Work
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  An American lawyer who was arrested last year in Rwanda has been barred by the United Nations from working at an international tribunal for Rwanda after refusing to appear in court.

title: Turkey Plans New Canal for Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  Heating up the campaign for the coming parliamentary elections, Turkeys governing party on Wednesday unveiled a proposal to build a canal parallel to Istanbuls Bosporus..

description: Conspiracy theorists on Wednesday pronounced themselves unsatisfied by President Obamas decision to release his long-form birth certificate, posting comments online suggesting that the controversy would continue to simmer.

title: 30 Years of the Space Shuttle: A Fact Scavenger Hunt
description: Thirty years ago, NASA launched Columbia, the first space shuttle, on a two-day mission to circle Earths orbit. Since then, more than 130 shuttle missions on five different shuttles have carried more than 350 astronauts to space.

title: Facebook Hires Duo Behind Daytum, a Personal Data Site
description: Facebook has hired the two founders of Daytum, a Web site that offers tools to record personal data and create visualizations from it.

description: For most of its 45-year existence, the Oakland Alameda-County Coliseum had no corporate name.

title: Air France Recorder Found, but Missing Its Memory
description: PARIS  The investigation into what caused the crash of an Air France jet two years ago suffered a major setback, officials said Wednesday, when search crews in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean located one of the planes black boxes  only to discover that its memory unit was missing.

description: Or maybe two points. Or .. amongst my points ..

title: Hero Worship
description: This summer is shaping up to be Marvelpalooza with the impending big-screen releases of Thor and Captain America: The First Avenger (both of which already have sequels in the works). The drop-in-the-bucket precursor to the comics onslaught is a super-powered T-shirt team-up with the venerable street-wear brand Stussy.

title: Is the Protest Song Dead?
description: Can pop music change the world? At their worst, protest songs can be didactic, crass or plain boring  as the British music critic Dorian Lynskey puts it in his new book 33 Revolutions Per Minute: A History of Protest Songs, From Billie Holiday to Green Day. But when the stars align, a song can capture a moment in time and speak volumes about the world we live in. Think Billie Holiday singing Strange Fruit; the Plastic Ono Band and Give Peace a Chance; or Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young and Ohio. These are songs that send chills down your spine.

title: Dogs Will Be Dogs
description: Are dogs getting an unleashed sense of entitlement from their owners?

title: Civility on the Way Out? Add Dogs to That List
description: EVER since her bulldog bit a fox terrier in the elevator last spring, Liz Weston has been forced by her co-op board to use the freight elevator at her Sutton Place South building. She doesnt think that its fair. After she apologized and paid the $600 veterinary bill, she sent a note asking how the terriers little tail was healing. She got back a letter from the co-op boards lawyer demanding she move out.

She wore a lacy Rachel Roy top, Christian Louboutin suede platforms and tight tan slacks from Zara. They make pants for tall girls, Ms. Johnson said.

description: Gov. Brian Sandoval of Nevada on Wednesday appointed Representative Dean Heller to the Senate seat that John Ensign plans to step down from next week.

description: The small screen rules the pop charts this week, with big-selling new entries from the Glee franchise and Disneys latest teen-pop confection.

title: NATO Strike Kills 12 Libyan Rebels in Misurata
description: MISURATA, Libya  At least one NATO warplane attacked a rebel position on the front lines of this besieged city on Wednesday, a rebel commander said, killing 12 fighters and wounding five others in what he called an accident that could have been avoided.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Rapid growth by eBays PayPal payment service helped lift the companys first-quarter results while its online marketplace continued to grow modestly.

title: Now Showing | Design, Here and There
description: Milans design week is barely over, and here in the United States, the spring season is shifting into gear in advance of the mid-May opening of the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York. On Thursday, the Cristina Grajales Gallery in SoHo opens Sebastian Errazuriz: Beautiful Premonitions, an exhibition of work by the Chilean-born, New York-based designer, whose Metamorphosis shelf, a sinuous tangle of carved plywood tendrils, was featured in the spring issue of T Design.

description: A further thought on Bernankes press conference, not too different from what Yglesias says, but Ill put in in economese rather than English.

title: Shane! Come Back! We Appreciate You!
description: If the Memphis Grizzlies defeat the San Antonio Spurs tonight in Game 5 of their first-round playoff series, it will be only the second time that a No. 8 seed has defeated a No. 1 seed in a best-of-seven-games N.B.A. series. That means a few things are likely. First, well hear a lot about what a huge upset this is, given that the Spurs, who had the second-best record in the league this year, have won four championships in the last dozen years and the Grizzlies have never won a playoff game before this series began. Second, well get lots of analysis about how the Spurs let things get away from them. And third, what attention is given to the Grizzlies and what they did right wont include much about the contributions of their player Shane Battier.

title: Armadillos Can Transmit Leprosy to Humans, Federal Researchers Confirm
description: Armadillos have never been among the cuddly creatures routinely included in petting zoos, but on Wednesday federal researchers offered a compelling reason to avoid contact with the armored animals altogether: They are a source of leprosy infections in humans.

title: Mayors Home Burned as Burkina Faso Protests Continue
description: KOUDOUGOU, Burkina Faso  A two-month wave of protests that has rocked the country touched down on Wednesday in this city 60 miles west of the capital as merchants set fire to the mayors home, the police headquarters and several other buildings. They were protesting an officials decision to shut about 40 stores in Koudougous central market over unpaid rent.

title: House Tour: Millbrook, N.Y.
description: A five-bedroom house in Millbrook, N.Y., incorporates two houses, one from 1750 and the other from 1890, that were combined in 1910.

title: Deficit Complicates City Ballet Labor Talks
description: As New York City Ballet prepares for its spring gala on May 11, the company is engaged in contentious negotiations with its dancers over their union contract, which expired in August. A federal mediator has been brought in to help with the talks, which have grown unusually acrimonious over issues like salary increases, overtime, sick-pay policies and dancers participation in small off-season tours.

description: A federal appeals court has told the Department of Veterans Affairs to loosen its grip on benefits decisions for veterans who have been declared incompetent.

title: 16 Tips to Take Your iPhone to the Next Level
description: The iPhone has been around for nearly four years. And in that time, millions of people have bought and used iPhones, swiping and tapping their way through life. Most of those people believe they know how the iPhone works.

title: A Voice, Something for Flinging Around
description: Melba Moore is a one-woman sound machine. This singer, who made her name in the Broadway productions of Hair and Purlie, is now a 65-year-old theatrical jazz diva. At Tuesdays opening-night performance of her show, Forever Moore, at the Caf Carlyle, she turned songs into sonic exhibitions in which emotion was superseded by extreme vocal display.

title: Two Arrested in Attack on Deliveryman Caught on Tape
description: Two teenagers were arrested Wednesday in an attack on a Chinese-food deliveryman in the hallway of a Harlem apartment building that was caught on videotape, the police said.

title: A Perilous Double Comes Close to Backfiring
description: There were 28 teams competing in the Yeh Bros. Cup in China last week. There was an initial qualifying stage of 10 10-board matches, followed by the knockout phase. Italy (Norberto Bocchi, Agustin Madala, Giorgio Duboin and Antonio Sementa) qualified in first place and won all of its knockout matches to take the top prize.

title: PlayStation Security Breach a Test of Consumers Trust
description: When Sony designers made the PlayStation 3, they lavished attention on the hardware. And when their shiny new machine was finished, Sony executives basically said, Hmm, wed better figure out an online system for this thing. So they tacked one on.

title: A Wandering Talent Grows Roots in Country
description: The last song Darius Rucker played on Tuesday night had significance: Ive adopted it as my theme song, he said. They get on me and want to know/Why do you drink? he sang in an exaggerated twang. To get drunk! the audience shouted. Why do you roll smoke? he rejoindered, and the audience replied, To get high!

title: Jester Returns to Test a Guest Conductor
description: As Fabio Luisi, the principal guest conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, becomes increasingly essential to the company, he will surely pick up more assignments like the one he had on Tuesday night.

title: Banter Is Cheery, but Songs Are Not
description: Kate Cooper and Damon Cox, who work together as An Horse, had their interplay locked down tight at the Knitting Factory in Brooklyn on Tuesday night. This was admittedly a modest achievement  between them, there isnt all that much to coordinate  but effective, even in its modesty. The band was celebrating the release of its second album, Walls, on the Mom + Pop label, and low-key charm was only true to the cause.

title: To Kill a Mockingbird Author Repudiates Journalists Memoir About Her
description: Harper Lee, the tight-lipped author of the Pulitzer-Prize winning novel To Kill a Mockingbird, issued a short statement through her sisters law firm on Wednesday saying that she had nothing to do with a coming book written about her by a former Chicago Tribune reporter.

title: Eating With Friends | Morrell & Company
description: Tarajia Morrell and Sebastian Sergeant live in a carriage house in Brooklyns Boerum Hill, the ideal setting for their groovier-than-thou dinner parties. The interior is the vision of Sergeant, 34, a set and furniture designer. In their living room, simple Milo Baughman sofas surround an ornate 18th-century mantel topped with one of Sergeants creations, a mercury mirror in a torched frame. When it comes to the food, Morrell  the 31-year-old daughter of Cathy and Peter Morrell of the Morrell & Company wine shop and restaurant  takes over. View interactive feature >>

title: Shades of Godot and Zombies, Not to Mention Balanchine
description: Its impressive how motivated the performers of Armitage Gone! Dance always look. At every point in the three works choreographed by Karole Armitage for the companys first program in its current Joyce season, which opened Tuesday, the stage is occupied in complex ways by people who know where, how and why they belong in their elaborate, intricate and sophisticated stage worlds. I only wish that, for even a moment, I could believe in either them or their worlds.

title: Mideast Private Equity Pioneer Looks Beyond the Unrest
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Arif Naqvi isnt spooked by turmoil.

title: Allergies Can Be Natural, Too
description: WENONAH MADISON-SAUER, 36, co-owner of a farm and take-out restaurant on Marthas Vineyard, tries to be eco-conscious about not just food but also cosmetics. For her firstborn son, Waylon, she used biodynamic calendula-based products anointed by NaTrue, an international third-party certifier of natural and organic skincare and cosmetics. But her second, Amos, now 2 1/2, is gooped up with Hydrolatum, a creamy petroleum-derived, non-organic cream that comes in a large plastic tub. Amos has food allergies, which have resulted in atopic dermatitis and eczema. Much of what he is allergic to (tree nuts, peanuts, seeds and coconut) is found  in oil form as emollients  in organic products.

title: Tales From a Hard-Hat Zone: The U.S.A.
description: The set designer Neil Patel has filled the Dance Theater Workshop stage with construction props for SITI Companys current production. Charles L. Mees script is presented as a malleable mash-up of scenes, like America,/permanently under construction. And the plays title, just for good measure, is Under Construction. There is a serious thematic point being made by the director Anne Bogart and her ensemble, over and over again, with no room for miscommunication.

A big deal seemed like a way for J.& J. to deploy its $28 billion of cash, largely trapped overseas. But as it turns out, it is paying mostly in stock.

title: Pakistan Urged Afghanistan to Distance Itself From the West, Officials Say

title: Film Festivals Elite Mixes It Up
description: ONLY in New York would scaffolding become party dcor. That was the inventive solution, anyway, at the Chanel Tribeca Film Festival dinner at the Odeon, where the metal bars were draped with ivy and white roses to form a blossoming entranceway.

title: As Buds Open, So Do Doors: Home and Garden Tours, 2011
description: The season of spring is also the season of house tours, when long-closed doors and garden gates unfurl like flowers for a quick and happy peek. Throughout the Northeast and beyond, there are mansions, studio apartments, bungalows and row houses to suit every taste, filled with antique china and contemporary paintings, stainless steel stoves and iron-grilled fireplaces, and parquet floors and historic wallpaper. The outdoor spaces include urban gardens hemmed in by brick walls, terraces with grand vistas and lush backyards with sturdy perennials. Show houses remain open for a few weeks, but some house and garden tours slip by in an afternoon  unless otherwise noted, all events are self-guided.

A Stackable Chair With an Artistic Bent
description: The term stackable chairs usually conjures up a certain elementary-school utility. LEau, a new chair from the Italian company Calligaris, aims to change that  in fact, to elevate the standard stackable chair to become the artistic focus of a room, said Mauro Mosca, the companys design and brand director.
