title: New York City Home and Garden Tours
description: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance and intricate, original moldings, and an artists townhouse and studio with a backyard treehouse. The tour will be followed by a reception. Advance tickets, $150 for the tour and $300 for the tour and the reception, at (212) 475-9585, and gvshp.org/benefit. Advance tour-only tickets will also be offered at two for $250. Same-day tickets, if available, $175 for the tour and $350 for the tour and reception, will be sold starting at 12:30 p.m. at the Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow Street (between Bleecker and Bedford Streets).

title: A Photo Exhibit That Honors Trees With a Past
description: Landslide: Every Tree Tells a Story, an outdoor photo exhibition, opens Saturday at LongHouse Reserve in East Hampton, N.Y., in homage to some of the countrys most venerable (and vulnerable) trees. Inspired by the Cultural Landscape Foundations 2010 Landslide, the most recent list of endangered landscapes released by the nonprofit preservation group, the show includes such heroic trees as the American elms of East Hampton (photographed by Garie Waltzer), which still form a leafy canopy over village streets despite disease and the ravages of time. Others include thousands planted by Frederick Law Olmsted Sr. and his sons in the 1890s, in Louisville, Ky. (photographed by Bob Hower, above), many of which have been lost to pollution, development and tornadoes.

title: Southern, Central and Western United States Home and Garden Tours
description: SOUTH

title: Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island Home and Garden Tours
description: CONNECTICUT

title: LED Bulbs That Try to Please the Eye
description: For years, experts have predicted that LEDs, the technology used in digital clocks, would eclipse compact fluorescents as an energy-saving alternative to traditional incandescent bulbs. Now Switch Lighting, a venture capitalist-financed company in San Jose, Calif., says it has come up with an LED bulb that emits light eye-pleasing enough to make that happen.

title: The Kips Bay Decorator Show House, Room by Room
description: Spaces by a dozen of the designers featured in the show house.

title: A Manhattan Pop-Up for F. P. Victoria & Son
description: Frederick P. Victoria & Son, a 78-year-old company known for antiques, reproductions and custom pieces made for decorators like Billy Baldwin, hasnt had a shop in Manhattan since 2009. It is now based in Long Island City, Queens, and most of its business is online.

title: Kips Bay Decorated, and Curated
description: AAKASH NIHALANI is a 24-year-old Brooklyn-based street artist who uses electrical tape to sketch three-dimensional shapes on public surfaces like sidewalks or brick walls. His work is playful, even joyous, and suggests all sorts of possibilities. Imagine a bright yellow doorway on a pocked concrete wall, or an enormous pink cube careering along the pavement.

title: The Man Who Made Working Out Cool
description: ON a recent Thursday night, the 38,000-square-foot David Barton Gym on Astor Place was throbbing to the Scorpions Rock You Like a Hurricane. Up the white-plaster staircase, candles flickered in the virgin springwood-paneled yoga room. Down below, a line of porcelain doll heads grinned over the moodily lighted lobby as lithe young things churned past the reception desk, designer gym bags in tow.

title: A Japanese Plant Struggles to Produce a Critical Auto Part
description: HITACHINAKA, Japan  A modern car is a computer on wheels. The window openers, the dashboard navigation maps, the fuel injectors  these and many other operations are controlled by some of the 100 or so electronic systems in a typical car.

title: Misurata Falls More Fully Under Rebel Control
description: While still cut off overland by pro-Qaddafi forces, the rebels were fighting stray Qaddafi holdouts at the citys edge.

title: Messis Goals Worthy of Praise
description: LONDON

title: Tech Talk: Mobile Shopping
description: Mobile shopping hasnt taken off in a big way, and retailers are still looking for ways to get consumers to shop from their phones or tablets. On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein talks to Claire Cain Miller, a Times technology reporter, about the challenges retailers face in getting smartphone users to buy on the fly. Though consumers do want to use their mobile devices for shopping, Ms. Miller said, they dont like entering their information on a tiny screen. Successful mobile shopping apps, she said, streamline the process.

title: Yankees Keeping Faith With Soriano
description: In the words of his manager, Rafael Soriano has had a bad month. A 7.84 earned run average and two costly eighth-inning meltdowns  including one in the Yankees 3-2 loss Tuesday night against the White Sox  makes Joe Girardis appraisal irrefutable.

title: May Release Schedule
description: All dates are subject to change.

title: Director Petraeus to Face Different Culture at C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. David H. Petraeus will be taking on familiar challenges when he arrives at the Central Intelligence Agency this summer: the terrorist threat from Yemen and Pakistan; the Taliban insurgency in Afghanistan; the Arab uprisings and their uncertain outcomes.

title: For All Those Who Arent on the Royal Guest List
description: SINCE her invention in 1921, Betty Crocker has symbolized mainstream American kitchen values. So why then is a section of the Betty Crocker Web site devoted to celebrating the wedding of a member of the British royal family?

title: June Release Schedule
description: June 1

title: July Release Schedule
description: July 1

title: Smoltz Is Set to Challenge a Lurking Beast Within
description: VALDOSTA, Ga.  He has practiced with Atlantas W.N.B.A. team, and this week John Smoltz, the retired pitcher, will make his first start in a PGA Tour co-sanctioned event.

title: Huckabees Doings Raise More Questions of Intent
description: While Donald Trump was vacuuming up so much political oxygen this afternoon, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas was making some noise of his own, keeping alive speculation that he will enter the still ill-defined field of Republican presidential candidates.

title: As Illness Hits, Mets Keep Gee as Backup Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The minor mystery surrounding the Mets decision to keep the right-hander Dillon Gee on the roster and move him into the bullpen was at least partly answered on Wednesday.

title: August Release Schedule
description: AUGUST

title: Pulling Back the Curtain at Guantnamo
description: To the Editor:

title: The Royals, Rebranded
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware Mission Accomplished on Budget Debate
description: The consensus of political reporters  including yours truly  was that Republicans were taking a significant risk by voting for Paul Ryans budget proposal. Mr. Ryans plan contains some potentially unpopular elements, such as significant reforms and cutbacks to Medicare and Medicaid, and a reduction in tax rates for high-income earners. President Obama critiqued the proposal  although without mentioning Mr. Ryans name  in his address on the budget two weeks ago. The Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee is already running commercials on the subject, claiming that Republicans have voted to end Medicare.

title: Most States Seen Raising Jobless Tax on Businesses
description: As persistently high unemployment has drained the funds that are used to pay jobless benefits, more than two-thirds of the states expect to raise taxes on businesses this year to replenish them, according to a survey of labor agencies released Wednesday.

title: An Arab-Israeli Peace Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Avoiding Pilot Fatigue
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors and Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: The Case for Cursive
description: For centuries, cursive handwriting has been an art. To a growing number of young people, it is a mystery.

title: Monitoring Painkillers
description: To the Editor:

title: Galleon Jurors Review More Taped Phone Calls
description: For the second time since they began deliberations on Monday, the jurors in the trial of Raj Rajaratnam were able to listen to secretly recorded phone calls between Mr. Rajaratnam and his supposed associates.

title: Besieged in Misurata
description: Migrant workers found passage out of Misurata, Libya, aboard a chartered ship as shelling and fighting continued.

title: Department of Good News
description: Well, I just dont see how things can get better than this when it comes to current affairs. Prince William is about to get married and President Obama has released his long-form birth certificate.

title: Designer Stationery, Made by You
description: I have more than 22 gigabytes of photos stored on my computer. That translates to roughly 3,000 pictures gathering dust on my hard drive. Sure, the majority are throwaways, but there are a few gems in the bunch I would love to see outside my LCD.

title: Some Kind of Month for Brent Lillibridge
description: Ill admit it. I didnt know much about Brent Lillibridge before he saved Tuesdays game for the Chicago White Sox with two phenomenal catches at Yankee Stadium. All I really knew was that he was a utility man for the White Sox who had somehow hit the 10,000th home run in franchise history this month. Lillibridge has four home runs in parts of four seasons.

title: Chrysler Expected to Erase Its Debt to Government
description: DETROIT  Of the three Detroit carmakers, Chrysler was in the worst condition when the recession hit. And even with a taxpayer bailout, it has been slower to recover than its rivals.

title: The Best Punishment for Tressel? Let Him Stay
description: Heres a suggestion to the power brokers at Ohio State University as they contemplate the fate of their Teflon football coach, Jim Tressel. Dont fire him.

title: Storms Rock the South and Midwest
description: Severe weather in parts of the South has killed several people and left thousands more without power from East Texas to Memphis and up through Illinois.

title: At This Fete, The Room Was Packed With Power
description: In the song Billionaire, the pop singer Bruno Mars sings a line about making it big: I want to be on the cover of Forbes magazine. At the Time Warner Center on Tuesday night, onstage at the Time 100 spectacular, celebrating the years most influential people according to the magazine, Mr. Mars swapped in the host publications name fittingly. But with a wide-ranging list of influentials including Martha Stewart and Amy Chua, the Tiger Mother, it seemed that just about anyone could land in its pages.

title: Mayor, Aiming at Police, Takes on a Pet Peeve
description: This week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg found himself in a suddenly familiar place: taking aim at the Police Department.

title: Little-Known Sub Makes Highlight Plays
description: Brent Lillibridge was born near Seattle on Sept. 18, 1983, when the local major league baseball team was playing the White Sox in Chicago. Harold Baines started in right field that day, hitting a home run to help beat the Mariners.

title: President Heads to New York to Try to Thaw Wall Street Donors
description: President Obama, seeking to mend fences with big New York donors to the Democratic Party, came to New York to headline three back-to-back fund-raisers on Wednesday night, casting his re-election campaign as the next step in the effort to speed up the economic recovery.

title: Great Leap Backward
description: SHANGHAI

title: Helping Students Find the Right Path
description: Maria Rodriguez, an associate professor of psychology at Hunter College, has been working with students in CUNYs career-conscious SEEK program  the acronym stands for Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge  since joining the faculty in 1982. SEEKs mission is to provide academically and economically disadvantaged students access to a college education and to help them find appropriate career opportunities. In addition to teaching, Dr. Rodriguez, a licensed psychologist, offers academic, career and personal counseling. She is 57 and lives in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Honoring Those Who Said No
description: IN January 2004, Spec. Joseph M. Darby, a 24-year-old Army reservist in Iraq, discovered a set of photographs showing other members of his company torturing prisoners at the Abu Ghraib prison. The discovery anguished him, and he struggled over how to respond. I had the choice between what I knew was morally right, and my loyalty to other soldiers, he recalled later. I couldnt have it both ways.

title: Panetta Comes Armed With Background in Budget Fights
description: WASHINGTON  Leon E. Panetta is set to take over leadership of the Defense Department while the United States is fighting on three fronts, but he was selected for the job in no small part because his war at home will be with Congress over the Pentagon budget. And in that battle, defense budget analysts said Wednesday, he comes unusually well armed.

title: Judge Denies N.F.L. Petition as Injunction Stays, for Now
description: A federal judge late Wednesday night denied the N.F.L.s request for a stay on the injunction that ended the lockout, sending the league scrambling to the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals to try to keep the lockout in place.

title: Besieged in Misurata
description: Migrant workers found passage out of Misurata, Libya, aboard a chartered ship as shelling and fighting continued.

title: Pain at the Pump? We Need More
description: GASOLINE prices are above  $4 per gallon in much of the country, a reminder that our dependence on oil carries a great cost. President Obama has promised that the Justice Department will be vigilant in pursuing price-gouging at the pump, but what we really need is to address the full set of energy-related problems, with a focus on spurring clean energy innovation.

title: City Council Questions Distribution of Park Officers
description: The City Council held a hearing on Wednesday to investigate what one council member said were disparities and inequalities in the deployment of officers in city parks.

title: A Certificate of Embarrassment
description: With sardonic resignation, President Obama, an eminently rational man, stared directly into political irrationality on Wednesday and released his birth certificate to history. More than halfway through his term, the president felt obliged to prove that he was a legitimate occupant of the Oval Office. It was a profoundly low and debasing moment in American political life.

title: Panic of Final Stretch Stills Voice of Triple Crown
description: Tom Durkin is no longer studying photos of Uncle Mo, Dialed In or any of the probable contenders to win next months Kentucky Derby. He is not packing his binoculars and notebook of more than 2,000 adjectives and phrases, the palette and paints of the track announcers craft, for his annual trip to Churchill Downs.

title: Solar Panels Rise Pole by Pole, Followed by Gasps of Eyesore
description: ORADELL, N.J.  Nancy and Eric Olsen could not pinpoint exactly when it happened or how. All they knew was one moment they had a pastoral view of a soccer field and the woods from their 1920s colonial-style house; the next all they could see were three solar panels.

title: City Shelves a Plan to Legalize Hailing Livery Cabs
description: An ambitious attempt by the Bloomberg administration to legalize hailing livery cabs on streets outside of Manhattan has been shelved after criticism from the taxi industry and lukewarm support from key lawmakers.

title: Video of the Tornado in Alabama
description: Videos of the tornado that tore through Tuscaloosa, Ala., on Wednesday afternoon began appearing online soon afterward. In the video above, posted on Vimeo by Crimson Tide Productions, the storm can be seen tearing through the trees near an office complex and parking lot as the clearly terrified videographer looks on.

title: In Trying to Debunk a Theory, the News Media Extended Its Life
description: The facts about Barack Obamas birth never wavered. But the more the fraudulent theories were debated and dispelled in major news media outlets, the more people seemed to believe them.

title: Just Dont Connect
description: The other day I got on the L train at Third Avenue, hair still wet from the gym, molars cemented together by the last bite of my post-workout protein bar. Grabbing a pole, I quickly scanned the occupied seats, knowing that if I parked myself in front of the nearest pair of Converse sneakers, Id probably get a seat in Brooklyn at Bedford or Lorimer. Then I spotted her. The ex-girlfriend of an ex-boyfriend of mine.

title: Students at Rutgers Occupy a Building
description: Demanding a tuition freeze, better wages for workers and a greater voice for students, about a dozen undergraduates at Rutgers University on Wednesday occupied Old Queens, the historic administration building in New Brunswick, N.J., where the president, Richard L. McCormick, has his office.

title: A Syrian Beacon Pays Price for Its Dissent
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In the besieged city of Daraa, which has become a symbol of Syrias uprising, residents on Wednesday told of shortages of bread and even baby formula. Some stick a pole wrapped in a scarf out the door to see whether snipers are lurking. Doctors in a mosque have resorted to using sewing needles to stitch wounds, amid shortages of bandages and disinfectant.

title: The Limits of Fed Policy
description: For too long policy decisions by the Federal Reserve were cloaked in secrecy and Alan Greenspan, the longtime chairman, was notoriously Delphic. So it was good to see the current chairman, Ben Bernanke, meeting the press on Wednesday, in the first of what are to be quarterly question-and-answer sessions. It shows that the Fed has learned, albeit the hard way, that it must build understanding and support for its policies.

title: A 9/11 Judge Sets a Month as Time Limit for a Trial
description: For almost nine years, the family of Mark Bavis, a passenger on the second plane to hit the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 2001, has been waiting for a trial in a wrongful-death lawsuit it filed against United Airlines and other defendants.

title: Advisers on Interrogation Face Legal Action by Critics
description: Critics are taking legal action to seek punishment for psychologists who, they say, designed and consulted on abusive interrogation techniques used on suspected terrorists.

title: In a Mothers Case, Reminders of Educational Inequalities
description: NORWALK, Conn.  The tale outlined outside court by the defendants supporters had a heartbreaking story line  a child tossed out of school, a homeless mother charged with felony theft for the crime of sending him to a better school than the one available to her, the inequalities that define Americas schools.

title: With Deal, J.&J. Tries to Change Discussion
description: In announcing on Wednesday Johnson & Johnsons biggest acquisition ever, on the eve of its annual shareholder meeting, the companys chief executive tried to pivot from a year of manufacturing lapses, product recalls and a disappointing share price.

title: Foundations Join to Offer Online Courses for Schools
description: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, the worlds largest philanthropy, and the foundation associated with Pearson, the giant textbook and school technology company, announced a partnership on Wednesday to create online reading and math courses aligned with the new academic standards that some 40 states have adopted in recent months.

title: Recidivisms High Cost and a Way to Cut It
description: Corrections costs for the states have quadrupled in the last 20 years  to about $52 billion a year nationally  making prison spending their second-fastest growing budget item after Medicaid. To cut those costs, the states must first rethink parole and probation policies that drive hundreds of thousands of people back to prison every year, not for new crimes, but for technical violations that present no threat to public safety.

title: Protests and Strikes Grow in Yemen as Deal on Ouster Advances
description: Protests and work strikes escalated across Yemen on Wednesday, leaving at least 12 dead on one of the countrys most violent days in a month, even as opposition and government officials were moving toward an agreement to usher President Ali Abdullah Saleh out of office in a month.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 27, 2011

title: Ms. Dix Comes to Washington
description: Hundreds of thousands of Northerners were mobilizing for war in April 1861, but few with the speed and initiative of Dorothea Dix. When news of President Lincolns call for three-month volunteers reached her home in Trenton, the middle-aged reformer set out immediately for Washington. She arrived in Philadelphia just in time to catch the last train through Baltimore before the bridges north of the city were burned, cutting off Washington and temporarily suspending travel to the capital from points north. Undeterred by what must certainly have been a harrowing ride, Dix arrived in Washington on April 19th and headed straight for the White House.

title: Hughes Could Have a Circulatory Condition
description: Two days of testing for Phil Hughes revealed a disconcerting clue that may explain his mysterious lack of arm strength. The Yankees will follow up by sending him for further evaluation in St. Louis, where a specialist will determine whether he has thoracic outlet syndrome, a circulatory condition common in athletes who use their upper extremities extensively.

title: Limited in Free Agency, Knicks Retain Billups
description: The Knicks are keeping Chauncey Billups for another season, opting for stability over payroll flexibility, and the chance to play a full season with a three-star lineup.

title: TimesCast | New Appointments Defense
description: David E. Sanger discusses how the career experiences of Leon E. Panetta and David H. Petraeus may impact their performances in new roles.

title: In Tense Seesaw Series, Bruins End on Up Side
description: BOSTON  It was a scene only the hearty loyalists could have envisioned after the first two games of this Stanley Cup playoff series. In the same building in which they had been lustily booed 11 days earlier, the Boston Bruins left the ice Wednesday triumphant and to an ongoing chorus of cheers, defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 4-3, in overtime to win the back-and-forth series in seven games.

title: Thursday: Tales of the Round Table
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  On Friday, a very special event will take place across the Pond, and todays puzzle celebrates that fact. You might not have heard about it on any of the television stations, or in the various newspapers or magazines, or online, or anything, so Ill just go ahead and spoil it for you: PRINCE WILLIAM of WALES and KATE MIDDLETON are getting hitched. Youll need that tidbit of information to get through the puzzle.

title: A.I.G. to Sue 2 Firms to Recover Some Losses
description: The American International Group, the giant insurer rescued by the federal government during the financial crisis, on Thursday will file the first of what could be a series of lawsuits against Wall Street firms, contending that it was the victim of fraud.

title: The Normal Heart
description: Photos from the Broadway production of Larry Kramers play.

title: Girl Group Tale Is Reharmonized
description: Mama said therell be shows like this. But she didnt tell me there would be quite so many, or that any one of them could be this dismal.

title: Raw Anguish of the Plague Years
description: More than a quarter of a century after it first scorched New York, The Normal Heart is breathing fire again. The passionately acted new Broadway production of Larry Kramers watershed drama from 1985  an indictment of a world unwilling to confront the epidemic that would come to be known as AIDS  blasts you like an open, overstoked furnace. Your eyes are pretty much guaranteed to start stinging before the first act is over, and by the plays end even people who think they have no patience for polemical theater may find their resistance has melted into tears. No, make that sobs.

title: Tom Durkin's Famous Calls
description: Tom Durkin, who has called the Kentucky Derby 13 times, said he did not renew his contract with NBC because of the anxiety the race had caused. Watch some of his favorite calls.

title: The Duty of Counsel
description: We strongly oppose the federal statute known as the Defense of Marriage Act, which bans recognizing same-sex marriage. House Republicans should not have used taxpayer money to hire outside lawyers to defend it. But the decision of those lawyers, the law firm of King & Spalding, to abandon their clients is deplorable.

title: Jos Mourinhos Persecution Complex
description: The best part of Jos Mourinhos postgame diatribe on Wednesday was that he claimed he wouldnt say how he really felt because he feared it would get him in trouble.

title: In New Hampshire, Trumps Rolling Media Circus
description: With the 2012 presidential campaign slow to evolve, Donald Trumps arrival in New Hampshire was greeted with high anticipation.

title: McCourt Criticizes Takeover of Dodgers
description: Frank McCourt, the Los Angeles Dodgers owner, said defiantly Wednesday that Commissioner Bud Seligs decision last week to take control of his team amounted to an unfair, un-American seizure of his property. And he did not rule out challenging Selig in federal court.

title: Organic Wine Country in Oregon
description: Willamette Valley wineries are on the leading edge of sustainable practices.

title: Preserving the Old, and Attracting the New on Catalina Island
description: The Santa Catalina Island Company is looking to entice a new generation of visitors.

title: Visiting Arizonas Desert Foothills
description: The northern Sonoran Desert features a 2,800-acre lake and a nearly three-million-acre forest.

title: Nora Roberts Romances Civil War Country
description: A 1790s-era hotel in Maryland was designed with women and romance in mind.

title: Embattled Arab Leaders Decide Its Better to Fight Than Quit
description: CAIRO  Arab leaders facing public revolt have increasingly concluded that it is better to shoot to kill, or at least to arrest and imprison, than to abdicate and flee.

title: Energy or Eyesore?
description: To some New Jersey residents, the thousands of solar panels being installed on utility poles are an eyesore, to others they're evidence of the state's commitment to green energy.

title: Bloggingheads: Obama Saved the Economy?
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate whether Obama saved capitalism.

title: Reconciliation Deal by Rival Factions Forces U.S. to Reconsider Aid to Palestinians
description: WASHINGTON  The announced reconciliation on Wednesday between Fatah and Hamas, the estranged Palestinian movements, puts the Obama administration in the uncomfortable position of having to reconsider its financial support for the Palestinian Authority, including millions of dollars the United States has spent to train and equip Palestinian security forces, officials and members of Congress said.

title: Guantnamo Detainees Lawyer Seeks a Voice on WikiLeaks Documents
description: WASHINGTON  A lawyer for a Pakistani prisoner at Guantnamo Bay went to court on Wednesday for permission to read and discuss publicly classified government documents about his client that were obtained by WikiLeaks and published by The New York Times and other publications this week.

title: Push in U.N. for Criticism of Syria Is Rejected
description: UNITED NATIONS  An attempt by the United States and its European allies to condemn Syria in the United Nations Security Council was rebuffed on Wednesday, as the willingness to intervene in the region  strong enough to lead to military action against Libya under similar circumstances just weeks ago  appeared to evaporate.

title: Hubert Schlafly, Who Helped Build Teleprompter, Is Dead at 91
description: Television actors, newscasters and politicians who worry far less these days about fumbling their lines, stalling as cue cards are flipped or shuffling typewritten pages on the podium owe much to Hubert J. Schlafly Jr.

title: Sidney Michaels, Playwright, Is Dead at 83
description: Sidney Michaels, a playwright who was nominated for Tony Awards in three consecutive seasons in the 1960s, died Friday in Westport, Conn. He was 83.

title: Court to Decide Validity of Olympic Doping Rule
description: The sporting worlds highest court will decide the validity of a relatively new International Olympic Committee rule regarding the Olympic eligibility of athletes who serve doping bans leading up to the Games.

title: CNBCs Burnett Is Said Ready to Jump to CNN
description: The CNBC anchor Erin Burnett is poised to sign a long-term contract with CNN, according to three people with knowledge of her plans.

title: Mets Lose an Argument but Win Their Sixth Straight
description: WASHINGTON  Jose Reyes is known for his passion for baseball and the flair with which he plays the game. Almost every day of his nine-year career, he has demonstrated those characteristics with a smile. But on Wednesday night, his generally happy demeanor exploded into a rage previously unseen from him.

title: The Voice of Excitement
description: The Timess Joe Drape offers commentary on some memorable calls from Tom Durkin, who quit as the voice of the Kentucky Derby, and Larry Collmus, who will replace him.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Orlando Bosch, Cuban Exile, Dies at 84
description: Orlando Bosch, a Cuban-American pediatrician and militant Cuban exile leader who was accused, and then acquitted, of masterminding the 1976 bombing of a Cuban airliner in which 73 people were killed, died Wednesday in Miami. He was 84.

title: Shortcuts for Quicker iPhone Use
description: The Times' personal technology editor discusses a few ways to use your iPhone more efficiently.

title: Video of 4 French Hostages Is Released
description: PARIS  Al Qaedas North African affiliate has released a video containing recorded messages from four French workers who were kidnapped last year in Niger.

title: The Fusion Kings of Little Italy
description: At Torrisi Italian Specialties, Mario Carbone and Rich Torrisi add some new accents to Italian classics.

title: Steamed, Roasted, Stir-Fried, Grilled
description: It takes effort to maintain a sense of seasonality with asparagus, given that it has become a year-round product. But right now even the stuff in supermarkets may come from a local source  so that the stalks snap rather than bend when you apply pressure and the aroma and flavor are fresh rather than simply strong.

title: Fried Rice With Prosciutto
description: From the chefs of Torrisi Italian Specialties.

title: Devils Chicken (Chicken fra Diavolo)
description: From the chefs of Torrisi Italian Specialties.

title: Cooking Up a Big Idea in Little Italy
description: On a recent morning in a Greenwich Village studio apartment with little natural light and minimal dcor beyond a cactus and a bookcase crammed with volumes about food, the chefs Rich Torrisi and Mario Carbone plotted the future of their lavishly acclaimed restaurant  and, just maybe, of Italian food in America.

title: Report Faults Border Screeners
description: Immigration authorities are failing to screen unaccompanied Mexican children who cross the border illegally to determine if they are victims of domestic abuse or human trafficking, according to a report based on two years of research by Appleseed, a nonprofit justice organization. The report examined how Mexican children have been handled by the Customs and Border Protection agency after Congress passed a law in 2008 requiring that minors be questioned to determine if they agreed to be returned to Mexico voluntarily. On the whole, that law is not being followed, said David Nachman, a lawyer who helped conduct the research. More than 30,000 Mexican children traveling alone have been apprehended at the border in the last two years, according to the report.

title: Misuse of Official Parking Placards Is Widespread, Report Finds
description: In neighborhoods frequented by official vehicles, more than 40 percent of cars displaying official city-issued parking placards were parked illegally, according to a report issued Wednesday by the clean-transportation advocacy group Transportation Alternatives. And a quarter of cars displaying what appeared to be official placards used forged or otherwise invalid credentials, the group said.

title: Nevada: Heller to Replace Ensign
description: Gov. Brian Sandoval appointed Representative Dean Heller to the Senate seat that John Ensign plans to leave next week. The appointment was widely expected from the governor, a Republican who endorsed Mr. Heller after he announced last month that he planned to run for the Senate in 2012. The appointment will prompt a special election in the states Second Congressional District. It remains unclear how such an election will proceed, and several county registrars are worried about its cost.

title: Arizona: Psychologist to Evaluate Medical Records of Massacre Suspect
description: A federal judge on Wednesday ordered that Jared L. Loughners medical records be sent to a psychologist who is evaluating his competency to stand trial in the Tucson shooting spree in which Representative Gabrielle Giffords was injured. Mr. Loughners lawyers had opposed turning over the records, which date to his childhood, but the judge, Larry Burns, said they would assist the psychologist, Dr. Christina Pietz, in her evaluation of Mr. Loughner. The judge said the records should also be turned over to Dr. Matthew Carroll, a court-ordered psychiatrist. Mr. Loughner, 22, faces 49 federal charges and is due back in court on May. 25.

title: Word of the Day | deterrent
description: deterrent \di-tr- nt, de\ noun/adjective

title: Harper Lee Denies Link to Memoir
description: Harper Lee, the tight-lipped author of To Kill a Mockingbird, issued a statement through her sisters law firm on Wednesday saying that she had nothing to do with a forthcoming book written about her by a former Chicago Tribune reporter. On Tuesday, Penguin Press announced that it had acquired the book, The Mockingbird Next Door: Life With Harper Lee, a memoir by Marja Mills that it said was written with direct access to Harper, her sister Alice Lee and their friends and family. Alice Lees law firm Barnett, Bugg, Lee & Carter in Monroeville, Ala., issued a statement signed by Harper Lee saying: Contrary to recent news reports, I have not willingly participated in any book written or to be written by Marja Mills. Neither have I authorized such a book. Late Wednesday, Miriam Altshuler, Ms. Millss literary agent, said that Ms. Mills has the written support of Alice Lee and a lifelong family friend, and prior to Harper Lees stroke in 2007, she had the verbal support of Harper Lee.

title: Obamas Pentagon and C.I.A. Picks Show Shift in How U.S. Fights
description: WASHINGTON President Obamas decision to send an intelligence chief to the Pentagon and a four-star general to the Central Intelligence Agency is the latest evidence of a significant shift over the past decade in how the United States fights its battles  the blurring of lines between soldiers and spies in secret American missions abroad.

title: South Assesses the Toll After a Deadly Barrage of Tornadoes
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  A day after enduring a terrifying bombardment of storms that killed hundreds across the South and spawned tornadoes that razed neighborhoods and even entire towns, people from Texas to Virginia to Georgia searched through rubble for survivors on Thursday and tried to reclaim their own lives.

title: TimesCast | Hamas and Fatah Agreement
description: April 27, 2011 - Ethan Bronner reports on the Hamas and Fatah agreement to a temporary unity government and elections.

title: Photo Replay: April 27

title: Japanese Central Bank Cuts Growth Forecast
description: HONG KONG  The Bank of Japan slashed its economic growth forecast Thursday in the aftermath of the natural disasters that hit the country last month but refrained from announcing fresh steps to stimulate the economy  a sign that the central bank expects rebuilding activity to lead to solid growth again later this year.

description: Test your proofreading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues, from the Caucus blog post Obama Hosts Passover Seder at White House.

title: Day by Day: A Personal Story From Japan
description: When we asked Christoph Bangert to write a journal-style account of his trip through Japan in late March and early April, he hesitated at first, thinking that his life was not the story. However, because he is so frequently asked for details about his travels, he gave it a try.

title: Deutsche Bank Posts Strong Profit, While Santander Slips
description: Deutsche Bank on Thursday reported  first-quarter profit of 2.1 billion euros, up 17 percent from the period a year earlier, on solid investment banking performance. Its shares rose 1.68 euros, or 4 percent, to 43.48 euros in midmorning trading in Frankfurt.

title: Roadside Bomb in Karachi Hits Navy Bus
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least five people were killed early on Thursday when a roadside bomb hit a bus carrying employees of the Pakistani Navy in the southern port city of Karachi, a senior naval officer said.

title: Digital Diary: Will Netflix Curb Movie Piracy?
description: For the past few weeks, Ive been on a retro television bender. Ive watched the first seasons of Ally McBeal, The X-Files, Veronica Mars and Buffy the Vampire Slayer. Torrential downpours have kept me couch-bound, so Ive also been able to catch up on a few movies I missed in the theaters: The Runaways, Hot Tub Time Machine and a few classics like The Graduate.

title: Should Your Doctor Be on Facebook?
description: When I was a third-year medical resident, an attending physician handed me his business card so that I could contact him about a patient. Printed below his phone number was something I hadnt seen on a business card before: an e-mail address.

title: American Plays, in English, at Berlin Theater
description: With as many as 300 theater and dance groups, and state spending of millions of euros a year on the citys three main opera houses and seven major theaters alone, theres no shortage of stages in Berlin. But if youre itching for some English-language thespian action, theres one place to go: English Theatre Berlin, which has been operating under various names since 1990.

title: Tom Bradys Tears, and Todays Draft
description: Even with labor trouble in the N.F.L., its hard to ruin the draft. But the drafts ultimate importance usually needs to be put into perspective.

title: A Lifetime of Automobilia Finds a New Home
description: NAPLES, Fla.  Mark Patrick has his hands full. As the librarian and archivist at the Collier Collection here, on the Gulf Coast in southwest Florida, he and his small staff face the daunting task of sorting through the 7,000 automotive books and 300,000 photographs and files that the Collier recently bought from Karl Ludvigsen, the prolific author, journalist and former auto executive.

title: Q&A: Making Windows Start Up Faster
description: Q.

title: Daniel Murphy Says Mets Shooting for 100 Wins
description: WASHINGTON  After an eventful game that extended the Mets winnings streak to six consecutive victories, one of the central figures of the game expressed a sentiment about the teams expectations that had not been heard publicly before.

title: Carter Criticizes U.S. for Withholding North Korea Aid
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Former President Jimmy Carter, after a 48-hour visit to North Korea, sharply criticized the United States and South Korea on Thursday for their refusal to send humanitarian assistance to the impoverished North, saying their deliberate withholding of food aid amounted to a human rights violation.

title: The Runneth Overing of Cups
description: If youre a connoisseur of oops! stories (wardrobe malfunctions, newscaster bloopers, presidential pratfalls and the like), you probably already saw the mishap involving the Copa del Rey (The Kings Cup) trophy last week. A player from Real Madrid, which had just won Spains century-old national soccer tournament for the first time in nearly two decades, dropped the trophy from the top of the teams bus, which was on a sort of post-match celebratory tour. The bus crushed it under its wheels.

title: A Book Store. Thats Right. Book, Singular.
description: At first glance, it looks like a charming independent bookstore, a West Village gem with a window display featuring artful stacks of gleaming hardcovers.

title: House Tour: Millbrook, N.Y.
description: WHAT Five-bedroom house on six acres.

title: Helping Small Businesses That Really Know About Ups and Downs
description: This month, a group of Rwandan female entrepreneurs traveled to the United States to learn from their American counterparts. The women, survivors of the 1994 genocide, were graduates of a three-year program created by the Business Council for Peace, a nonprofit network of professionals who provide pro bono business services to entrepreneurs in countries with conflicts  Rwanda and Afghanistan, so far, and El Salvador soon. The organization, known as BPeace, was built on the beliefs that more jobs mean less violence and that entrepreneurs are best positioned to create employment opportunities.

title: Profit Jumps at Exxon and Shell
description: Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Shell reported huge increases in their first-quarter profit on Thursday, helped by higher oil prices and earnings from refining.

title: Exelon to Buy Constellation Energy for $7.9 Billion
description: Exelon announced on Thursday that it would buy Constellation Energy in a $7.9 billion deal, the latest in a wave of consolidation among energy companies, particularly utilities.

title: Germanys Low Unemployment Rate Stokes Inflation Fears
description: FRANKFURT  German unemployment fell to its lowest level in two decades in April, according to data released on Thursday. The figures provide some of the strongest evidence yet of the comeback of Europes largest economy.

title: Panasonic to Cut 17,000 Jobs
description: Panasonic, the biggest Japanese maker of consumer electronics, announced a major reorganization Thursday under which it will cut thousands of jobs as it adapts its business to a changing global environment and absorbs recent acquisitions.

title: N.F.L. Draft: Blaine Gabbert, Top-Ranked Quarterback
description: Matt Waldman is the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an 859-page testament to his obsession with film analysis. Todays post concludes his series counting down his top five draft prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: Artists Guggenheim Show: 100,000 $1 Bills on the Wall
description: Its a concept that takes Warhol one bold step further: Receive $100,000 in prize money, and instead of spending it, tack 100,000 used $1 bills to the walls of a museum.

title: Bringing Petraeus to C.I.A. Offers Benefits for Obama
description: In a tribute to the Armys top general in Afghanistan, the outgoing Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates wrote last week in Time magazine that in many respects the Petraeus story is still being written.

title: Britain Bars Syrian Envoy From Royal Wedding
description: LONDON  Just 24 hours before the event, Britain said Thursday that it had revoked the Syrian ambassadors invitation to the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, turning the ceremony into an unlikely focus of protest against violent repression in the Arab world.

title: Live From the NYSE Shareholders Meeting
description: NYSE Euronext, whose merger deal with the Deutsche Brse faces a challenge from a joint bid by the Nasdaq OMX Group and IntercontinentalExchange, is holding a shareholders meeting. Here is a live Twitter feed from Michael J. de la Merced:

title: U.S. Economic Growth Slows to 1.8% Rate in Quarter
description: American economic expansion slowed to a crawl in the first quarter, but economists are hopeful that the setback will be temporary. Total output grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent from January through March, the Commerce Department said Thursday, after expanding at a 3.1 percent pace in the fourth quarter of 2010.

title: Berkshire Fires Back Against Sokols Lawyer
description: Berkshire Hathaway has escalated its war of words with its former executive, David L. Sokol, who resigned last month after buying shares in a specialty chemicals manufacturer while orchestrating a potential takeover of the company.

title: Creating a God, With Links to Olivier
description: LOS ANGELES -- As he finished postproduction work on Thor here at Building 29 on the 20th Century Fox lot, Kenneth Branagh could often be found laboring in any of its massive chambers, from the pitch-black subterranean color-timing suite to the Howard Hawks audio-mixing theater, as cavernous and majestic as Valhalla. But when he needed a personal work space, Mr. Branagh retreated to a closetlike office he described as his little hole of cubbyness, whose only clue to its occupant was a temporary sign on the door bearing the initials K. B.

description: James Freeman of Blue Bottle coffee is the leader of the artisanal Japanese-style, slow-drip brewing movement. View interactive feature >>

description: The Bloomberg administration said that it would scale back a plan to demote 100 sanitation supervisors after an independent arbitrator ruled that the workers would lose their seniority standing.

title: David Sokol, the Deal Maker
description: David L. Sokol had been portrayed in recent years as Berkshire Hathaways Mr. Fix-it. But Mr. Sokol had also become a crucial player in Warren E. Buffetts deal-making machine, serving as a point man for Berkshire on a number of possible transactions, particularly during the financial crisis.

title: Stanford Debates R.O.T.C.s Return
description: April 29, 10:18 a.m. | Vote Results After two hours of debate, the Stanford faculty senate voted to bring ROTC back on campus: 28 members voted for its return, 9 voted against it and 3 abstained. During the faculty senate meeting, Former Secretary of Defense William Perry discussed how bringing ROTC back to Stanford could help the military by providing better trained and educated leaders. Much of the debate was centered on the militarys posture toward transgendered people and also on whether academic credit would be granted to ROTC courses. An amendment to the resolution of bringing ROTC back to campus was added that stated the faculty senates objection concerning the militarys treatment towards transgender people.

title: Wall Street Higher After G.D.P. Report
description: Shares rose, sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index to the highest level since June 2008, as better-than-estimated corporate earnings tempered investors concern over slowing economic growth.

title: Seeing Things | Weaving New Mexico
description: When I visited Santa Fe, N.M., the week before Easter, I saw lots of pilgrims walking the High Road to Taos on their way to El Santuario de Chimay, a 200-year-old chapel on a site that is sacred to many for the purported healing powers of its soil. But I was on a different kind of pilgrimage. New Mexico is a mecca for anyone interested in weaving, and many studios are clustered near Chimay, a small village north of Santa Fe.

title: BRYuKI
description: Dmitry Medvedevs alternative to the BRICS countries  in Russian, Bryuki means trousers. [The Yu denotes Yuzhnaya Africa (South Africa), and the K stands for Kitai (China).]

title: U.S. Greenhouse Gas Emissions Projected to Grow Slowly
description: Even if the United States takes no explicit action to regulate greenhouse gases, emissions of carbon dioxide and other climate-altering substances will grow slowly over the next two decades, not returning to 2005 levels until 2027, according to a new projection from the Energy Information Administration, the research branch of the Energy Department.

title: Poetry Pairing | April 28, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

description: Little if any posting.

title: Bomb Strikes Moroccan Cafe, Killing Mostly Foreigners
description: A powerful bomb blast in a crowded Moroccan cafe killed at least 14 people, wounded dozens of others and shattered the relative calm in a corner of the Arab world overwhelmed by uprisings and deadly government crackdowns.

title: Rough Homecoming for a Washington Lawmaker
description: Audience members yelled at one another to stop yelling. The moderator talked over Representative Michael G. Grimm to ask the crowd to please stop talking over him.

title: Thursday Reading: Should Your Doctor Be on Facebook?
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: Exelon to Buy Constellation Energy for $7.9 Billion | Exelon on Thursday announced it would buy Constellation Energy for $38.59 a share, the latest deal in a wave of consolidation among energy companies, particularly utilities.

title: For Xanadu Mall, Stalled and Scorned, Deal May Offer New Life
description: It has been called the ugliest damn building in New Jersey and maybe America, has bedeviled three governors and has burned through two developers. Despite $1.9 billion spent, it is still an unfinished pile of concrete, steel and garish pastel panels.

title: New Charlie Ahearn Film Will Make Its Debut at BAMcinemaFest
description: A New York artist well known for capturing street culture and people in cool clothing  as seen through the lens of a documentarian who knows a thing or two about those topics  will be the subject of Jamel Shabazz Street Photographer, a new feature from the Wild Style director Charlie Ahearn that will have its premiere at this years BAMcinemaFest, the festivals organizers said on Thursday. Mr. Ahearns new film chronicles Mr. Shabazz, the Brooklyn photographer whose work is collected in the book Back in the Days, with help from Fred Brathwaite, aka Fab 5 Freddy, and KRS-One, both rappers who have figured prominently in Mr. Ahearns previous work.

title: Bahrain Sentences 4 Protesters to Death
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A military court in Bahrain sentenced four Shiite Muslim protesters to death on Thursday in the killing of two policemen last month during demonstrations against the Sunni Muslim-ruled government, Bahrains national news agency reported.

title: Harry Jackson, Artist Who Captured the West, Dies at 87
description: Harry Jackson, a Marine combat artist who turned his back on a promising career as an Abstract Expressionist painter to become a prominent realist artist known for his paintings and bronze sculptures of cowboys and Indians, died on Monday in Sheridan, Wyo. He was 87 and lived in Cody, Wyo., and Camaiore, Italy.

title: Cellphones and Cancer
description: We need to quit worrying about cellphones (Do Cellphones Cause Cancer? by Siddhartha Mukherjee) and focus our collective energy on the known, significant causes of cancer: tobacco, sun exposure, hepatitis, etc., while continuing to research other possible causes. We should also focus on the one proven danger of cellphones, which is use (even hands-free) while driving.

title: 9/11 Movie Pushes 8th-Grade Director Into Spotlight
description: It was February 2002, and 5-year-old Brook Peters and his mother, Michelle, were walking through Public School 150 in TriBeCa for the first time since Sept. 11, a few days before the school was set to reopen.

title: Sweet and Vicious
description: Like everyone else on earth, I have a 100 percent chance of dying. The only unknowns are when and how it will happen. I dont smoke because Im not interested in dying of a heart attack at 50 or of emphysema at 60. This increases my chance of dying from something else. Gary Taubes makes a strong case that sugar causes some kinds of death (Is Sugar Toxic?), but he doesnt tell me what I get to die of if I give it up. Will my new risk of death be better or worse? If going without sugar means that I get to die of complications from Alzheimers at 95, in a nursing home, unable to eat, use the bathroom or recognize anyone around me, then please, let me eat cake.

title: Playoffs Make James More Careful With the Ball
description: The Miami Heat wrapped up its first-round series with the Philadelphia 76ers on Wednesday night, in yet another relatively pedestrian case of a superior team taking care of business in a timely manner. The Sixers were competitive for their five-game stint in the postseason, but their playoff run was expectedly short; few gave Philadelphia more than five games to live against Miami, making the 4-1 outcome a development straight from the script.

title: One Lucky Prince
description: I woke up before dawn that morning nearly 30 years ago, wrapped myself in a blanket, and plopped in front of the TV to watch Diana haul her overwhelming dress out of a royal carriage. That was before we understood that this couple barely knew each other, essentially didnt like each other, and did not have a chance of living happily ever after.

title: Viacom Reports 20% Increase in Revenue, While Discovery Posts 9% Rise
description: Viacom, the media company, reported a 20 percent increase in quarterly revenue on Thursday, citing stronger demand among advertisers and the popularity of shows like Jersey Shore on MTV.

title: Northern Sudanese Warn South Over Contested Area
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The Sudanese government said Wednesday that it would not recognize the soon-to-be independent nation of south Sudan if the southern government tried to annex the contested territory of Abyei, raising the stakes between the two sides only 10 weeks before the souths independence is expected to be announced.

title: Popcast: Fleet Foxes, Gerald Clayton and Remembering Poly Styrene

description: Celebrities get a disproportionate share of attention in American life  even, it seems, when it comes to financing a college education.

title: Internet Lets a Criminal Past Catch Up Quicker
description: Convicted of robbing a video store in California in 1997, Ayanna Spikes decided to change the trajectory of her life. In 14 years, she has had no further brushes with the law.

title: Americas Got Talons
description: The nails really came out at the fall shows, with cutting-edge manicures being the order of the day. At Mugler, Lady Gaga sported a matte black, clawlike Minx design. Cushnie et Ochs introduced us to textured caviar nails made out of black seed beads. And rain-forest-inspired and gold-tipped nails emerged on Jen Kaos catwalk. For a toned-down, off-the-runway take on the trends, show a bit of bare nail this summer and choose a classic red lacquer to highlight a nude half moon. Or, if Jason Wus gold-and-burgundy take on the classic French manicure is not exactly your speed, try a black and white reverse French with Japanese calligraphy on a nail or two.

title: Diverse Interests, One Goal
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  They came to Princeton in separate classes and remain on divergent paths in their interests and academic careers. One travels to study minerals and volcanoes. One performs in a campus dance company. One sings in an a cappella group. One is a classically trained trombonist. Even on the track, scheduling variances preclude them from training regularly as a foursome. Still, this infrequent collective has produced something sublime.

title: Sing It Loud: Changing the World With a Stirring Cri de Coeur
description: It is a short walk, Vladimir Nabokov said, speaking of writers and critics, from the hallelujah to the hoot. Its an especially short walk if youre a pop singer whos written a less-than-electric protest song. Think of Michael Jackson and Earth Song, or 4 Non Blondes and Whats Up, or Sting and Russians. Each of them, along with We Are the World, will be in heavy rotation on the Pandora channel in hell.

title: Thousands Fleeing Qaddafi Bask in Tunisias Hospitality
description: TATAOUINE, Tunisia  A century ago, fleeing Italian colonizers, the inhabitants of Libyas remote western mountains descended upon this wind-whipped Tunisian outpost, many to stay permanently.

title: Hold the Phone! That Sure Sounds Like Saddam Hussein.
description: BAGHDAD  There havent been any Saddam sightings, yet. But he is still in the house, some Iraqis believe, and was heard from just this week.

title: 36 Hours in Singapore
description: JUDGING from the number of cranes that dot the citys skyline, Singapore is booming. In the last few years, casinos and hotels have sprung up; museums and galleries in former colonial landmarks have flung open their doors; and international designers have staked out prime real estate alongside up-and-comers just starting to make their fashion mark. Throughout the city, street vendors and sleek restaurants  new and well-established  serve up the citys renowned mix of Malay, Chinese and Indian ethnic cuisines. And, best of all, sexy lounges and rooftop bars are helping the city-state shake off its formerly staid image.

title: A Weekend in Singapore
description: Sexy lounges and rooftop bars are helping the city-state shake off its formerly staid image.

title: The Check Is Not in the Mail
description: Starting next week, anyone applying for Social Security, Veterans Affairs or other federal benefits should expect to receive their money electronically  paper checks will no longer be an option. Most of those already getting paper checks have until March 1, 2013  a slight reprieve  to set up electronic deposit.

title: These Skates Werent Made for Strolling
description: ITS an unassuming spot for the mecca of East Coast roller derby, this small, narrow shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, beside the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. A handwritten sign on the door reads, We are not the bike shop, and directs cyclists to nearby King Kog.

description: In Williamsburg, a skate shop has become the go-to place for women searching for the right wheels.

title: Audits Find Widespread Waste in Spending by State Government
description: ALBANY  More than a million square feet of state office space, roughly enough to fill the Chrysler Building, sits vacant, yet some state agencies were signing new leases as recently as December.

title: In an Imperfect World, a Drink Made for It
description: When it comes to people, I have always had a soft spot for self-deprecators. I only recently realized that this extended to cocktails as well. I met one with effacement in its very appellation. And Ive been trying to boost its confidence by telling it how wonderful it is ever since.

title: NYSE Euronext Gets Pressure From Investors
description: NYSE Euronext sought on Thursday to mount a more vigorous defense of its planned merger with Deutsche Brse at its annual shareholder meeting.

title: N.F.L. Commissioner Takes Some Hits
description: As spectacles go, the N.F.L.s labor circus cannot hold a candle to say, a Game 7-winning goal in overtime in Boston or someone named Gary Neal keeping the Spurs dynasty alive for another day with a 3-pointer at the buzzer of regulation. We had high hopes for fireworks, as the N.F.L. lawyers kept promising, with Americas favorite game descending into utter chaos. Cue Bill Murray as Dr. Peter Venkman: Human sacrifice, dogs and cats living together, mass hysteria!

title: Video Exclusive | Werner Herzog Interview
description: When Werner Herzog was a boy, he saved his pocket money to buy a book about cave drawings. When he finally held it in his hands, he had an almost spiritual experience viewing the pictures inside. Over half a century later, the always enthusiastic German director, 68, captures his enduring fascination with cave art in a new film, Cave of Forgotten Dreams, coming out in theaters tomorrow. The French government and scientific community gave him unprecedented access to the contents of the fragile 32,000-year-old Cave of Chauvet-Pont-dArc in southern France, which he shot stunningly in 3-D. In this five-minute video, above, Herzog goes in depth about the ecstatic truth behind mans first attempts to produce art. Related: Herzog Finds His Inner Cave Man, a film review by Manohla Dargis.

title: Bostons Huntington Theater Receives $10 Million Gift
description: A decades-long relationship between Bostons Huntington Theater Company and Stanford and Norma Jean Calderwood has yielded a $10 million gift to the endowment of the theater, its leaders announced on Thursday. The gift from the Calderwood Charitable Foundation, by far the largest in the theaters 29-year history, doubles the size of the Huntingtons endowment.

title: Where the Economy Grows, and Doesnt
description: The G.D.P. report today came in as expected. Real growth was at a 1.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter, down from 3.1 percent in the prior three months. A lot of that was due to inflation.

title: Where the Economy Grows, and Doesnt
description: The G.D.P. report today came in as expected. Real growth was at a 1.8 percent annual rate in the first quarter, down from 3.1 percent in the prior three months. A lot of that was due to inflation.

title: People Plans for a Royal Wedding Rush
description: The debate over whether Americans will want to watch the royal wedding on Friday will probably continue until, well, the ratings for all the telecasts become available. In the meantime, a major media company is betting there will be a lot of interest  at least soon after the event.

title: Ugandan Opposition Figure Arrested Again
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The leading opposition politician in Uganda was arrested Thursday after police prevented him from leading a demonstration here, only a day after being granted bail from a previous arrest over a similar protest.

title: Celebrities Fill Trading Floor for Charity
description: At the midtown offices of the global firm BTIG, the air is usually filled with the shouts and admonitions typical of a fast-paced trading floor: Im up to seventeen-five! Whos got KND? Jimmy, try to stay at 90, top!

title: High Court Ruling May Reduce Consumer Clout
description: Score another one for big business, it seems. The Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that companies can use contracts that prevent consumers claiming fraud from banding together to file group arbitration claims and, possibly, class-action lawsuits.

title: More iPhone Tips and a Call to Android Users
description: In todays paper, I wrote about some less-than-well-known tips and shortcuts for Apples iPhone. But in addition to all the things you can do on the smartphone itself, theres a subset of tips that have to do with the headphone controller that, while a little more obvious, may prove useful to some iPhone users.

description: Yandex, one of Russias largest Internet companies,  is gearing up to go public.
