description: Term for planned protests in Syria: Azadi means freedom in Kurdish.Reporting on the ongoing protests in Syria, Nour Malas and Joe Lauria wrote in The Wall Street Journal:

title: Get Your Royal Wedding Fix on TV
description: According to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll, only 28 percent of Americans are either somewhat or very closely following the news about the Friday nuptials of Prince William and Kate Middleton. Royal watchers, this day is for you. (For the remaining 72 percent of the country, its a good time for Netflix streaming.)

title: Louisiana, Film Star
description: LOS ANGELES  That other movie capital, the state of Louisiana, is rumbling right along thanks to its generous government film production subsidies.

title: In Praise of Monarchy
description: I appreciate the small-r republican ardor with which Mark Oppenheimer assails Americas royal wedding obsessives, but hes fighting a losing battle. Americans are supposed to loathe and reject monarchs, he writes, but its telling that all his examples of that loathing (In the earliest years of English settlement, this land was a proud haven for king killers  [we] fought a bloody war for the privilege to ignore the king of England  Anti-monarchism was then written into our Constitution ) are centuries old, dating from a time when republicanism was an exciting cause rather than a somewhat-ossified assumption. Since those days, weve regressed to the (very human) mean: Were fascinated by the royal family that we once overthrew, we have our own hereditary dynasties (and the slobbering coverage to match), and weve gradually turned our presidency into a quasi-imperial office, complete with coronations and cultic devotions and all the rest. True, by the standards of modern history, with its parade of strongmen and caudillos and presidents-for-life, our republican institutions have been impressively resilient. But even the American experience suggests that the anti-monarchical temper Oppenheimer invokes is ultimately artificial and unnatural, a triumph of theory over instinct and idealism over human nature. In their hearts, most people want a king and queen.

title: Art for Sale, No Introduction Needed
description: FOR decades now auction houses have sold challenging works of art. There have been arcane, ancient sculptures, canvases by little-known artists and bizarre objects like glass cabinets filled with medical supplies or cigarette butts. But at Sothebys, Christies and Phillips de Pury, the art for sale at the big auctions this season, beginning Tuesday, requires little thought. Even those without much knowledge of art history will recognize Andy Warhols haunting self-portrait with his spiky fright wig or Jeff Koonss lovable sculpture of a Pink Panther being hugged by a buxom blonde or the classic pink-and-red abstract canvas that shrieks Mark Rothko.

title: Wall Power at the Spring Auctions
description: Carol Vogel looks at some of the highlights of the spring auction season in New York.

title: Ex-Consultant Accused of Stealing Millions From Schools
description: A former consultant for the Department of Education surrendered to federal authorities on Thursday to face charges that he stole $3.6 million in the six years he worked managing projects that were meant to provide Internet access to city schools.

title: Lightning Finding New Playoff Stride
description: It was a nail-biter in Wednesdays Game 7, but the Tampa Bay Lightning have survived to play another round in the N.H.L. playoffs.

title: U.S. Seeks New Limits on Food Ads for Children
description: Will Toucan Sam go the way of Joe Camel?

title: Q. and A. on Maya Archaeology
description: Takeshi Inomata and Daniela Triadan of the University of Arizona excavated the Maya site of Ceibal in Guatemala. In this post, they answer readers questions about their recent expedition.

title: A Day at the Zoo With Betty White
description: Betty White, known for her acting success, is also heavily involved with the Los Angeles Zoo.

title: Facing Age With a Saucy Wink
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Former SAC Manager Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
description: 8:07 p.m. | Updated

title: Vrooooom! Vrooooom! Flex Em if You Got Em
description: At one point during the preordained throwdown between the two colossi who stride through Fast Five, Dwayne Johnson rips off his bulletproof vest with the practiced economy of a 17th-century courtesan flinging off her corset. His character, a professional tough guy bluntly named Hobbs, has just found his fugitive bad twin, Dom, the gnomic guru of the Fast and Furious franchise, played by Vin Diesel. They are the fast and, yes, the furious. Yet as these giants grasp each others bulging muscles, their bald heads rearing in the frame with tumescent vigor, its easy to imagine that theyd like some alone time.

title: Wrapping Up the Apple Location Brouhaha
description: Well, for better or worse, Locationgate is over.

title: U.S. Envoy Sees Backsliding of Human Rights in China
description: BEIJING  The chief United States representative to human rights discussions with China offered a cheerless portrait of those talks after their conclusion on Thursday, saying the United States was worried by a serious backsliding of freedoms in China and at loggerheads with Beijing officials over many aspects of the issue.

title: Towns Survivors Emerge to Face the Worst
description: PLEASANT GROVE, Ala.  John Walkingshaw, 64, a retired police officer, was standing in front of his house, smoking a Pall Mall cigarette.

title: Spurs Extend Era of Excellence
description: Given the inexorable rise of pro basketballs exciting new breed  Derrick Rose to Kevin Durant  there was something poignantly old school in how San Antonio clung to playoff life and its prolonged era of excellence Wednesday night.

title: Why Sales of Green Products Are Down
description: Last week, The New York Times published an intriguing article  As Consumers Cut Spending, Green Products Lose Allure  about a major decline in the sales of green products. The article makes a point I have long believed: the average consumer will not pay more for a product just because its green, especially during a recession.

title: Werner Herzog on Cave Art
description: Herzog discusses the discovery and artwork of the Cave of Chauvet-Pont-d'Arc, the subject of his latest film, "Cave of Forgotten Dreams."

title: Scenes From a Diversion
description: The biannual African Cannes attracted nearly 8,000 attendees.

title: Mark Pedowitz Named President of the CW Network
description: The troubled mini-network CW announced a long-anticipated management change Thursday, confirming the appointment of Mark Pedowitz, a former business affairs and studio executive for ABC, as president of the network.

title: A Weekend in Hanoi
description: The city has a zeal for barreling toward the future while always looking back.

title: CBS Reporter Recounts a Merciless Assault
description: Lara Logan thought she was going to die in Tahrir Square when she was sexually assaulted by a mob on the night that Hosni Mubaraks government fell in Cairo.

title: Former Times Sq. Pastor Dies in Texas Crash
description: The Rev. David Wilkerson, an influential evangelical minister who wrote a best-selling book, The Cross and the Switchblade, about his work with drug-addicted youngsters in Brooklyn, was killed Wednesday in a car accident in eastern Texas.

title: Deal Opens Door for Russian to Invest in Saab
description: Saab Automobile won a critical reprieve Thursday in its effort to stay afloat.

title: Excitement Builds Ahead of Royal Wedding
description: The streets of London are filled with souvenir sellers, tourists and all things royal as Britain prepares for the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton.

title: BGC Partners Buys Newmark
description: The brokerage firm BGC Partners announced on Thursday the purchase of Newmark, the real estate advisory firm that operates as Newmark Knight Frank in the United States. The price of the transaction was not disclosed.

title: How Bernanke Answered Your Questions
description: Before Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, took questions from the media Wednesday, I took questions from you. I got to ask only one question at the news conference  I asked why the Fed was not doing more to reduce unemployment  but many of your other questions were also answered in some form by Mr. Bernanke.

title: The Royal Wedding Coverage
description: Starting at 5 a.m. Eastern time, well be tracking the royal wedding from top to bottom and start to finish, from boutonnieres to church bells to the Buckingham Palace balcony kiss.

title: Bowling in New York
description: A slide show of images of places to bowl in the city.

title: Back-to-Basics Bowling (No Fancy-Pants Stuff)
description: WHY cant I just go bowling in Manhattan? I should clarify. Why cant I just go bowling the way it was meant to be: unpretentious, inexpensive and accompanied by greasy food and old T-shirts.

title: TimesCast | Storm Toll Grows
description: April 28, 2011 - Robbie Brown reports from Pleasant Grove, Alabama where a Tornado ravaged homes and has torn apart the local community.

title: A Popes Beatification Stirs Excitement and Dissension
description: VATICAN CITY  On a sunny afternoon this week, St. Peters Square was abuzz with life. Crowds lined up at the metal detectors. Tourists snapped photos. A workman was spraying down the travertine steps to the basilica. And inside, red cloth screens cordoned off a side chapel that will soon draw as many visitors as Michelangelos Piet nearby.

title: Found in Translation: Parsing and Appreciating Difficult Texts
description: Overview | What are the limitations of translations? When and why is archaic or difficult language worth reading? In this lesson, students examine the language of the King James Bible by comparing it with two popular translations as a means of discussing why difficult texts are worth reading in their original language.

title: New Census Finds Chinas Population Growth Has Slowed
description: BEIJING  Chinas population grew more urbanized, educated and older as the growth of the worlds most populous nation slowed to a pace half that of the previous decade, results of the 2010 census released on Thursday indicated.

title: Old Energy Strategies, New Century
description: The Op-Ed page has published Pain at the Pump? We Need More, a very retro-feeling proposal for a rising price on carbon-emitting energy sources by Daniel C. Esty, the new commissioner of the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, and Michael E. Porter, a professor at the Harvard Business School.

title: Does Anyone Feel a Draft?
description: The 2011 N.F.L. Draft kicks off this evening in New York City, and I will be in front of my television with my laptop on and my Blackberry handy. My wife will drop by the apartment at some point and shout, The Minnesota Vikings are on the clock! because she thinks its funny to ridicule my favorite team and its storied ineptitude when it comes to drafting. And then she will leave, because she knows better.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Time for our weekly contest to guess the location of the picture above.

title: The Chef With the Dragon Fruit
description: Move over, pomegranate. And please give a warm welcome to dragon fruit, fiery red and spiky  and the newest poster child for fruit with health benefits.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: Is a Spoken Invitation

title: Deutsche Banks Near Record Profit
description: Reuters reports on how acquisitions in retail banking and wealth management buoyed earnings at the large German lender.

title: Is 1.8% the Real Real Number?
description: For the arithmetically, and perhaps conspiratorially inclined, the release of the gross domestic product report has provided a kind of intrigue not normally present in the dry world of statistics.

title: Is 1.8% the Real Real Number?
description: For the arithmetically, and perhaps conspiratorially inclined, the release of the gross domestic product report has provided a kind of intrigue not normally present in the dry world of statistics.

title: For Consumers, a Different Approach to Search
description: Kevin OConnor has a knack for spotting new businesses online. In 2007 thispaid offwhen DoubleClick, an online advertising company he helped co-found, was purchased by Google for $3.1 billion.

title: Carole King Songs and Idol  Unbeatable
description: With the final six taking on the songs of Carole King on American Idol on Wednesday night, the Fox reality show attracted 21.7 million viewers from 8 to 9:30 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The network easily dominated the night over all even as it drew much lower ratings for Breaking In at 9:30 (7.6 million), in line with the series showing a week ago.

title: Obama Announces Changes to National Security Team
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced a revamped national security team Thursday afternoon in an East Room ceremony in which he declared, We are a nation still at war, and said the new leaders of the defense and intelligence agencies would help keep the country safe.

title: Adele, Again
description: Adeles second album, 21, will return to the No. 1 spot on Billboards Top 200 next week, for the sixth nonconsecutive week. Its the only album to sell more than a million copies so far this year (Lady Gagas new album, due in a few weeks, will probably join it in short order), and the soulful British vocalist is already the early front-runner for next years Grammy Awards, which should keep 21 going until shes ready with 23 or 24 (her albums have been named after her age).

title: At Home With Artifacts in Their Natural Habitats
description: Michael Gotkin, a historian and landscape architect, keeps tabs on doomed arrays of furniture, artwork and knickknacks. He tracks the homes of aging artists: the custom built-ins designed by their prominent friends, the shelves packed with inspiring artifacts ranging from fertility goddess statues to fishing lures.

title: Making Jeopardy! (as a $400 Clue)
description: We here at City Room missed the $400 clue in a certain category on Jeopardy! on Wednesday night. We also missed the $800 clue, the $1,200, the $1,600 clue and the $2,000 clue.

title: The Tipsy Diaries: A New Negroni
description: This weeks Tipsy Diaries column is about a new take on a familiar cocktail, the Negroni. Instead of gin, the Negroni Sbagliato uses sparkling white wine. Joe Campanale of dellAnima in the West Village shared with us how to make the drink.

title: Theater Talkback: A Happy Ending, A New Beginning
description: The final performances of plays and musicals are naturally emotional occasions. Whether the run has been long and acclaimed or abruptly curtailed by a quick closing, there is the painful parting of ways of an informal family. But the last night of the Signature Theater Companys revival of Angels in America was extraordinary even by the standards of emotional closing nights.

title: A New Suitor Emerges for Warner Music
description: With a third round of bidding for the Warner Music Group coming to an end this week, another suitor for the music company has emerged, just as some of the leading bidders are considering withdrawing because of worries over Warners finances.

title: Telecoms Look to Cloud Computing
description: In the battle for enterprise customers, the countrys giant telecommunications and cable companies are going to the cloud.

title: No Ring for Xinjiang
description: Quincy Douby and the Xinjiang Guanghui Flying Tigers bid for the Chinese Basketball Association title, the subject of an article by Jon Pastuszek in The Times, came to an end Wednesday night.

title: What Photographers Saw After Sunset
description: In the beginning, there was light  at least for photography. It wasnt until 1895, almost 60 years after the mediums invention, that an Englishman named Paul Martin began experimenting with taking photographs at night.

title: Pogues Posts: Wrapping Up the Apple Location Brouhaha
description: Well, for better or worse, Locationgate is over. On Wednesday, Apple responded with a statement explaining the presence of a file in the hard-drive backup of every iPhone and cellular iPad. Apple is not tracking the location of your iPhone, it said. Apple has never done so and has no plans to ever do so. So basically, Apple is saying that the researchers were wrong on both counts. First, the secret file contains information about nearby Wi-Fi hot spots and cell towers, not your exact location. And second, your device is sending information to Apple, although in an anonymous, encrypted form. One part of Apples response is a little unconvincing, says David Pogue. Read the rest of post at Pogues Posts.

title: Guessing Game Builds Over Buffetts Next Deal
description: Among the questions nagging at investors making the pilgrimage to Omaha this weekend to attend the annual meeting of Berkshire Hathaway will be this: Will the outcry over David L. Sokol affect Warren E. Buffetts deal machine?

title: Studio Eyes a Revised Sitcom Without Sheen
description: It is not certain that CBSs hit comedy Two and a Half Men will return next season, but the shows studio, Warner Brothers, confirmed Thursday that it was trying to bring the show back without its original star, Charlie Sheen.

title: A New Tool, SplitTheRent.com, for Roommates
description: Many of us look back fondly on our postcollege years, when we shared apartments or entire houses with a motley collection of other recently graduated 20-somethings. Overlooked in the nostalgia, though, is the constant stress about paying bills. Who still owes me for the rent? Did someone stiff me for those pizzas we shared last night? Why am I still $20 short for the electric bill due tomorrow?

title: 12 Die as Shiite Mosque in Iraq Is Bombed Again
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber on Thursday attacked a large Shiite mosque in Diyala Province, killing at least 12 people and wounding dozens, according to an Iraqi security official. Sunni and Shiite clerics were meeting in the mosque at the time as part of an effort to show that tensions between the groups had subsided.

description: Classical

title: Palestinian Factions Give Differing Views of Unity Pact
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  A day after the two main Palestinian factions announced surprise plans for a unity government, the challenge of bringing together two rival parties with distinct ideologies burst into view, with each side presenting a different picture of what the accord means and what produced it.

title: Dance Listings for April 29-May 5
description: Dance

title: Pictures of the Day: Alabama and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Alabama, Georgia, Libya and Morocco.

title: Thai and Cambodian Military Commanders Agree on a Cease-Fire
description: BANGKOK  Thai and Cambodian military commanders agreed on a cease-fire Thursday after seven days of fighting that took at least 15 lives and displaced tens of thousands of civilians, the Cambodian government announced Thursday.

title: A Drama of Art Attribution to Play Out at the Metropolitan Museum
description: The painting is beautiful. Does it really matter whether it is by Titian or Giorgione?

description: Art

description: Photographs from Alabama, Georgia, Libya and Morocco.

title: In Little Britain, Awaiting Big Royal Wedding
description: It was late Thursday morning, with a full day to go before the Royal Wedding, and at least one business owner on a certain block in the West Village appeared to be tipping toward madness.

title: Topped With Wrong
description: A delivery guy dropped off two pizzas at my daughters house. Her husband signed the preprinted charge slip, tipped him and ate slices from both pies. When his wife came home, he thanked her for ordering them, but she hadnt! Soon, the delivery guy returned for the misdelivered pizzas. They told him they had eaten part of each, so he asked them to pay. My daughter refused, pointing out that it was his error. He asked for the pizzas back, and she refused again, claiming he would deliver the half-eaten pizzas to someone else. When he told them he was going to have to pay for the pies from his $8 an hour wage, they asked him to leave. Was this right?

title: A Score To Praise A Prophet
description: Last week the prophet Elijah made a personal appearance at every Passover Seder around the world, or so we are told: most people are unable actually to see him, although parents have traditionally found ways to convince their children that Elijah sipped from the wine cup left for him. Taking all that on faith, you have to think that Elijah is one knackered prophet just now, so it seemed fitting that on Wednesday evening  barely 24 hours after the conclusion of Passover  the Oratorio Society of New York offered Elijah, Mendelssohns tribute to that itinerant biblical firebrand, at Carnegie Hall.

title: ART/SEWN: Tradition, Innovation, Expression
description: Five Myles

title: IN A PERFECT WORLD
description: Meulensteen

title: MARIO GARCIA TORRES: Cover Letter
description: 45 Orchard Street (between Hester and Grand Streets), Lower East Side

title: JULIA JACQUETTE: Water, Liquor, Hair
description: Anna Kustera

title: THE SPRING SHOW
description: Art and Antique Dealers League of America

title: Developers Create Neighborhood Feel With Condos and Shops
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Keeping Score: The Most Important Leadoff Skill? Not So Fast
description: Generally regarded as the greatest leadoff hitter ever, Rickey Henderson thrilled baseball fans for a quarter century by stealing a major league-record 1,406 bases. Along the way, his feats on the base paths fueled the stereotype that speed is the leadoff mans defining tool. But it wasnt his base stealing that made him so effective in the leadoff spot; rather, it was his ability to get on base to begin with.

title: London Underground | Urban Narratives
description: It may not be the catchiest title around, but Whiteonwhite:algorithmicnoir is an incredible film and accompanying exhibition by the artist Eve Sussman and Rufus Corporation, her loose collective of collaborators, at the Haunch of Venison gallery until May 14. Since London is currently immersed in nostalgia  from the celebrations of the 1951 Festival of Britain at the Southbank Center to an abundance of Union Jack bunting across the city  this glimpse into the future is most welcome.

title: Chrysler Says Government Loans Are Now Unnecessary
description: DETROIT  Chrysler will soon pay back its government loans because they have become redundant and unnecessary now that the automaker is more financially stable, its chief executive, Sergio Marchionne, said Thursday.

title: PC Sales Off, Games Buoy Microsoft
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft, once the dominant technology company, saw revenue from its core operating system software slip in the first three months of the year as consumers begin to shift to buying tablet computers that do not run on Microsoft software.

title: Media Decoder: The Royal Wedding
description: In the lead up to the royal wedding, news organizations found almost every angle to cover the story.

title: Donation for a Lucerne Opera House Is in Dispute
description: On the surface the interlocking worlds of music festivals and arts philanthropy might seem as placid as the preternaturally transparent, swan-rich waters of Lake Lucerne in Switzerland. But officials of the renowned Lucerne Festival there took action on Thursday akin to a Loch Ness monsters rearing its head and clamoring for recognition.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for April 29-May 5
description: SNOW WHITE

title: Herzog Finds His Inner Cave Man
description: What a gift Werner Herzog offers with Cave of Forgotten Dreams, an inside look at the astonishing Cave of Chauvet-Pont-dArc  and in 3-D too. In southern France, about 400 miles from Paris, the limestone cave contains a wealth of early paintings, perhaps from as long ago as 32,000 years. Here, amid gleaming stalactites and stalagmites and a carpet of animal bones, beautiful images of horses gallop on walls alongside bison and a ghostly menagerie of cave lions, cave bears and woolly mammoths. Multiple red palm prints of an early artist adorn one wall, as if to announce the birth of the first auteur.

title: Big Appetite for the Royals Big Day
description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss how in the days before the royal wedding, news organizations have found almost every angle to cover the story.

title: Spare Times for April 29-May 5
description: Around Town

title: In Aftermath of Storms, Production Stops at Mercedes-Benz and Toyota Plants
description: The series of deadly thunderstorms and tornadoes that struck the Deep South on Wednesday evening has led at least two automakers in the region to cancel production shifts at their plants.

title: No Tweeting From the Ice Bath
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  I tell my body to do a lot of things: Run one more sprint. Strike 50 balls. Push through just 15 more minutes. Warm up. Cool down. Sit in an excruciating ice bath. But sometimes its not about what I tell my body, but what my body tells me. Sometimes its not about doing, but instead listening.

title: Way Uptown in Hospital Country
description: YOU might call them the North Pole of the Gold Coast, a luxury enclave of Fifth Avenue apartment houses at 101st and 102nd Streets. Hemmed in by Mount Sinai hospital and other institutions, 1200, 1212 and 1215 Fifth Avenue were stranded high and dry after 1930, and the hospital is still growing.

title: Russia Is Set to Propose Stricter Rules for Reactors
description: MOSCOW  Pointing contritely to the example of their own industrys failures at Chernobyl, Russian officials have announced details of what is emerging as their main response to the disaster in Japan: a proposal to create an international regulatory framework for nuclear power.

title: A Pied--Terre for East Coast Sojourns
description: WHAT Claire Baiz craved was a cabin in the woods.

title: Q & A
description: The Consequences of Eviction

title: Financing a Vacation Home
description: IT might be easier if you just paid cash for that vacation house.

title: Sleep Can Wait. The Birds Are Angry.
description: YOU didnt play Donkey Kong with your dad.

title: East End Homes Prepare for Guests
description: AS soon as school ends and prime season on the East End heats up, William Stoecker, with his wife and two children in tow, will head to Prince Edward Island. And for the fourth summer in a row, another family will be moving into the Stoeckers six-year-old four-bedroom East Hampton house with built-in pool. Do the Stoeckers miss summer in the Hamptons? They would rather enjoy it from afar and collect $100,000 in rent for the season.

title: Condo Market Shows Improvement
description: Hackensack

title: Board Scales Down Plan for Readers Digest Site in Chappaqua
description: CHAPPAQUA

title: Evan Stein
description: Mr. Stein, 39, is the president of the J.D. Carlisle Development Corporation, which was started by his grandfather, Harry Feldman, and the M.D. Carlisle Construction Corporation.

title: Dusting Off the Maids Room
description: THE idea of a maids room in New York City may conjure Upstairs, Downstairs images of cell-like spaces tucked away behind the kitchen, but spaces for the help are leaving behind the claustrophobic feel of the early 20th century and making a comeback. Several new developments have incorporated maids rooms into their larger apartments, and while the rooms are separate from family sleeping areas, they are generously sized and have standard en-suite bathrooms. The apartments recall the Classic 6s, 7s and 8s of prewar buildings along Park and Fifth Avenues, but this latest iteration of servant quarters has a distinctly 21st-century feel.

title: Mrs. Whitneys All-American Salon
description: On May 24 the Whitney Museum of American Art will break ground at the site of its future home in the meatpacking district. And in anticipation of its move there in 2015, the museum has cooked up a series of six back-to-back permanent-collection shows at its present location. The first of them, Breaking Ground: The Whitneys Founding Collection, is up and running, and what a curious thing it is.

title: Objects of Operatic Desire: Abundant Money and Men
description: Instead of pairing Puccinis comic Gianni Schicchi with one of its somber siblings from Il Trittico (The Triptych), Juilliard Opera programmed it with LHeure Espagnole (The Spanish Hour) by Ravel to create a double bill of amorous and avaricious lust.

title: App Smart Extra: Major-League Apps
description: Sports fans are entering the high point of the year, with hockey and basketball playoffs sharing airtime with baseball, and the start of the National Football League draft on Thursday night.

title: Investment Firm Buys Most of the Former Times Building
description: The Blackstone Group, the giant investment firm, is buying the top 11 floors of the former New York Times Building, on West 43rd Street, for $160 million, just four years after the 15-story building sold for $525 million.

title: Two Jilted Lovers Sharing a Stage, but Not Their Men
description: At the heart of both El Amor Brujo and La Vida Breve, striking works by the Spanish composer Manuel de Falla, is a woman of low social standing, jilted in love. Each incorporates the influence of flamenco music and Gypsy culture. Where they part ways drastically is in how each central character deals with betrayal: one bedevils, the other expires.

title: New Jersey School Budgets Pass in 80% of Districts
description: Faced with modest tax increases and fewer program cuts, New Jersey voters approved 80 percent of school budgets this week in an election that was largely free of last years turmoil.

title: Burkina Faso Police Join in Popular Unrest
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Police officers in Burkina Faso joined a growing wave of popular unrest on Thursday, firing their weapons in the air and shooting tear gas as discontent over high prices, low wages and the 24-year-rule of President Blaise Compaor spread in the landlocked West African nation.

title: Apps for Photographers
description: The quantity and quality of photography apps for the iPhone are closing the gap between pictures taken with phones and those taken with cameras.

title: Up Front: Stephen Greenblatt
description: A few years ago, the Harvard professor and noted Shakespeare scholar Stephen Greenblatt found himself struggling to cook up a fraudulent piece of Shakespeare.

title: Shakespeare and the Will to Deceive
description: Somewhere buried under the floorboards of this splendidly devious novel is a real-life event. In 1794, a young Englishman, William Henry Ireland, came across something astonishing that he hurried to show his father: an old mortgage deed, with its seal intact, signed by none other than William Shakespeare.

title: Could a Leaking Ocean Current Keep Europe Toasty?
description: Climate scientists have long theorized that global warming, by increasing precipitation and melting Arctic ice, could eventually destabilize the Gulf Stream, the ocean conveyor belt that carries tropical waters into the North Atlantic and warms Western Europe. The paradoxical result would be a cooling trend for the region, even as the rest of the globe continued to heat up.

title: Lines, Loops And a Skyline Spectacle
description: Since the singer and guitarist Tyondai Braxton quit Battles last summer, it has become an instrumental group, outsourcing its vocals. But its still something to watch, as well as hear. On Wednesday, at Le Poisson Rouge, Battles made its stage into a skyline, with three peaks along the front: a cowbell, a cymbal and a microphone, each about six-and-a-half feet off the ground.

title: Editor Vows George R. R. Martin Has Finished A Dance With Dragons
description: Whether you have been a long-time fan of George R. R. Martins Song of Ice and Fire fantasy novels or were only recently introduced to the HBO series Game of Thrones, adapted from the books, youre probably aware of two details about this author: it has been six years since the publication of the last novel in the series, A Feast For Crows, and Mr. Martin is very aware of how much his readers would like to see the planned follow-up, A Dance with Dragons. In a recent interview with The New York Times, Mr. Martin acknowledged he was still putting his finishing touches on that book  even though a July 12 publication date had already been announced. A profile of him in The New Yorker was titled Just Write It!

title: The Economic Consequences of Mr. Paul
description: Kash Mansori pursues the same line of thought I followed after Bernankes press conference, and fleshes it out.

title: Crime Series to Continue Despite Authors Death
description: Two popular series created by Robert B. Parker, the prolific mystery writer who died last year at the age of 77, will continue under two new authors, his publisher said. G. P. Putnams Sons, Mr. Parkers publisher, said the Spenser series, whose first-person hero is a tough Boston private detective, would now be written by Ace Atkins, a crime novelist, and that the Jesse Stone series, featuring a former athlete with a drinking problem, would be taken over by Michael Brandman, producer and screenwriter of the Jesse Stone movies on CBS. Joan Parker, Mr. Parkers widow, to whom most of the authors more than 60 books were dedicated, said in a statement that she was delighted that the worlds of Spenser and Jesse Stone will live on in the capable, talented hands of such gifted writers.

title: Instagram Spawns a Photo Ecosystem
description: Instagram, the social-meets-photos app for the iPhone that transforms plain cellphone pictures into vintage-looking works of art, has attracted millions of users. In recent months, it has also begun to draw entrepreneurs who are eager to capitalize on its growing popularity.

title: Inspiring Comparisons With Vermeer
description: WASHINGTON  The 17th-century Dutch painter Gabriel Metsu is best known today as a lesser Vermeer, an also-ran genre painter who flattered the Amsterdam elite with comely courtship scenes set in well-appointed interiors. His paintings have yet to bait blockbuster crowds, or to inspire a novel along the lines of Tracy Chevaliers Girl With a Pearl Earring.

title: Swords Drip Red With Revenge
description: A stirring, unexpectedly moving story of love and blood, the samurai movie 13 Assassins opens with a dignified man seated alone in a large courtyard. Perfectly centered in the shot, he says nothing, his face a ferocious mask. But words are immaterial given his open shirt and the blade in his hand. The Japanese director Takashi Miike has no qualms about letting the red run down the screen. Here, though, instead of showing the blade sinking in, he moves in closer, letting the scene play out in the mans crumbling face, the gray sky framing him as the moist, tearing sounds of the knife doing its terrible work fill the air.

title: Keynes vs. Hayek: A Rap Battle Renewed
description: Round 2 of the great economics smackdown is now available on video. In the impressively produced rap video Fight of the Century by the economist Russ Roberts and the producer and director John Papola, Friedrich Hayek and John Maynard Keynes square off to argue over such questions as whether the government should spent less or more, the source of prosperity, and whether war or natural disasters be a blessing in disguise. (Part 1 came out last year.)

title: Writhing, Hissing and, uh, Biting
description: How much, really, do average, non-reptile-obsessed people need to know about snakes? Not nearly as much as is covered in Wild About Snakes, a block of shows this weekend on Nat Geo Wild. And that makes you wonder who is actually likely to watch this stuff. Is this slithering mass of programming, though it includes some tsk-tsking about the cult of illegal snake trafficking and ownership, really more interested in encouraging it? Have a smoldering fascination with exotic or poisonous snakes? it seems to say. Lets see if we can fan it into a full-fledged mania.

title: Feel the Hyperinflation
description: Just for a moment, lets not do core inflation; lets just look at the CPI  and lets do it in levels, not rates of change. Heres the last 10 years:

title: A Familys Legacy, Afro-Cuban Jazz
description: IF there is such a thing as a first family of Afro-Cuban jazz, the OFarrill clan has a right to claim that distinction. Its members helped invent the hybrid genre back in the 1940s, when Chico OFarrill came to New York from Havana, and in recent years they have worked to reinvigorate the music despite barriers in both Cuba and the United States.

title: For the Fed, a Narrowing of Options
description: The American economic revival stumbled in early 2011. Could that be more than the transitory phenomenon that Ben Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, called it at his news conference this week?

title: Lincoln Center to Venture Into China as Adviser for a Performing Arts Project
description: Venturing into a possible new area of revenue, Lincoln Center has agreed to serve as a paid adviser to the developers of a proposed performing arts complex in Tianjin, Chinas fifth largest city, the center announced on Thursday.

title: Bookshelf
description: Justin Martins Genius of Place (Da Capo, $28) is about Frederick Law Olmsted  yes, the Central Park landscape designer, but also the abolitionist, early-adopter environmentalist and roving journalist.

title: Photo Replay: April 28
description: A view of the day in sports, with a pairs final on the ice in Moscow and cyclists passing pastures in Switzerland.

title: A Fraught Mother-Daughter Drama
description: NEW HAVEN  Watching the stage adaptation of Autumn Sonata at the Yale Repertory Theater is a bit like looking at the Ingmar Bergman movie through the wrong end of a telescope. Moments that pulsate with oversize emotion in the movie tend to shrink into a clammy pallor in this studied but chilly production directed by Robert Woodruff. A gray film was settling over my existence, a character says at one point, and you know exactly how he feels.

title: Seven Arrested in Gambling Raids in Flushing
description: Seven people in Flushing, Queens, were arrested in connection to underground gambling parlors in the Chinese community, the police said on Thursday.

title: For Their Next Act ...
description: WHEN Adam Gertsacov and Stephanie Schwab were married three years ago, she was a vice president at a New York social media agency and he ran a small start-up from their house in Yonkers. A very small start-up: the Acme Miniature Flea Circus.

title: Rebels Repel Assaults By Loyalists in Libya
description: ZAWIT AL MAHJOUB, Libya  Rebels opposed to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi clashed with loyalist troops on Thursday in this village several miles west of the besieged city of Misurata on Thursday, as the rebels withstood a loyalist ground assault.

title: Bringing Heavy Metal to the Mets Roof
description: No one in the 1960s produced livelier, more infectiously playful sculpture than the British artist Anthony Caro, five of whose works now grace the Metropolitan Museum of Arts rooftop garden.

title: Social Largess Speeds Rise in Oil Prices
description: Theres no mystery in why all the unrest in North Africa and the Middle East would cause oil and gasoline prices to soar. Libyas high quality sweet crude is almost off the market entirely, and its anyones guess when the next oil producer is going to suffer a revolution that could cripple production.

title: BlackBerry Maker Cuts Its Forecast
description: OTTAWA  When executives at Research in Motion were faced with skepticism last month about the companys ability to compete against Apple and Android devices, they consistently pointed to its still-robust financial performance.

title: Despite Bipartisan Support, Nuclear Reactor Projects Falter
description: WASHINGTON  In an effort to encourage nuclear power, Congress voted in 2005 to authorize $17.5 billion in loan guarantees for new reactors. Now, six years later, with the industry stalled by poor market conditions and the Fukushima disaster, nearly half of the fund remains unclaimed. And yet Congress, at the request of the Obama administration, is preparing to add $36 billion in nuclear loan guarantees to next years budget.

title: A Skate Shop With a Focus: Roller Derby
description: Its an unassuming spot for the mecca of East Coast roller derby, this small, narrow shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, beside the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. A handwritten sign on the door reads, We are not the bike shop, and directs cyclists to nearby King Kog.

title: The Brooklyn Museums Artists Ball
description: A look inside the party at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Breaking Ground
description: Images from the new exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Night Vision
description: Photos from a new photography exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Simpson Thacher to Add Hong Kong Law Practice
description: Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, the American law firm, plans to add a Hong Kong law practice to supplement its existing operations there later this year. The firm has hired Celia Lam from Linklaters and Christopher Wong from Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer as partners to lead the practice.

title: Keynes vs. Hayek: The Fight of the Century
description: Round 2 of the great economics smackdown is now available on video. In the impressively produced rap video Fight of the Century by the economist Russ Roberts and the producer and director John Papola, Friedrich Hayek and John Maynard Keynes square off to argue over such questions as whether the government should spent less or more, the source of prosperity, and whether war or natural disasters be a blessing in disguise. (Part 1 came out last year.)

title: In Shuttles Waning Days, One of the Last Reasons to Cheer
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla.  As it has many times before, sometime Friday afternoon the stretch of Route 1 in front of Chris Galorneaus restaurant will turn into a parking lot.

title: The Battle for Libya | April 28
description: In recent days, since the Qaddafi forces withdrew under pressure from central Misurata, the fighting has shifted to the citys outskirts.

title: Chinas Exports Perch on Uncertain Truck System
description: SHANGHAI  For years, Chinas export juggernaut has been fed by highly efficient factories, low-cost labor and a fleet of container ships capable of transporting huge volumes of toys, textiles, electronics and other goods to every corner of the world.

title: The Latest from the N.R.C. on Fukushima, and More
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has not yet said what changes it will order at American reactors in response to the Fukushima disaster, but at a briefing on Thursday morning, some clues emerged about areas that might require further study.

title: Couple Admit to Their Roles in Kidnapping of 11-Year-Old
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Ending a sordid criminal ordeal that began two decades ago with a kidnapping on a South Lake Tahoe street, a convicted sex offender and his wife pleaded guilty on Thursday to the abduction, rape and imprisonment of Jaycee Lee Dugard.

title: Even in Real Life, There Were Screens Between Us
description: CURLED up at the foot of my bed, my face inches from the laptop screen, I stared anxiously at the Google chat box. Will is typing, the box told me, helpfully.

title: Modern Love: College Essay Contest
description: IN February, Sunday Styles asked college students nationwide to tell us  through their own stories, in their own voices  what love is like for them. When we first held this contest three years ago, the most popular essay topic was hooking up: the no strings attached sex that for many wasnt turning out to be so carefree. The question that seemed to hover over hundreds of such accounts was: How do we get the physical without the emotional?

title: From Ringside, Gay Mans Play Packs a Punch
description: In a boxing gym in San Francisco on a recent Sunday afternoon, a trainee and his coach sparred, verbally and physically.

title: In a Small Town, Big Life-Changers
description: Lebanon, Pa. retells the old story of the city mouse and the country mouse while meticulously applying it to Americas simmering culture wars. Written, directed and edited by Ben Hickernell, the movie avoids making any grand statements or raising emotional temperatures more than necessary.

title: A Quick Note on Gas Prices and Presidential Approval
description: A six-hour flight delay has scuttled my plans for a longer post today (and perhaps changed my opinion on the governments new rules about how long planes can idle on the tarmac). But I wanted to point you to a little bit of research on the link between gas prices and presidential performance.

title: Shareholders Give Thumbs Up to J.&J. Executive Pay
description: At Johnson & Johnsons annual meeting on Thursday, shareholders voted, on an advisory basis, to approve the compensation package being awarded to the companys chief executive.

title: Thai Protest Photos Earn a Capa Medal
description: The convulsive political protests in Thailand last year were the first violent breaking news story that Agnes Dherbeys has covered. She sought to bring the same empathy that characterizes her feature work to the often bloody street scenes in Bangkok.

title: A Closer Look at the Destruction in Tuscaloosa
description: Zoom in on images and examine some of the damage from a mile-wide tornado that tore through Tuscaloosa, Ala., on Wednesday.

title: No Shortage of Social Media for the Royal Wedding
description: Dont want to watch the royal wedding alone in the predawn darkness? Not to worry. The major television and cable networks invite you to join them in the conversation about the dress, the flowers, the first kiss. All you need is your computer, tablet or smartphone and a Twitter or Facebook account.

title: A Thief With Less Need for a Getaway Car
description: If you like the Bourne movies but wish they were more cerebral  not to mention quiet, cryptic and withholding  you might be the perfect audience for The Robber.

title: Mans Best Friends Best Friend
description: On the patio at the Park Chow restaurant in San Francisco last month, while other diners grazed on salads and veggie lasagna, Douglas Wilkins took a glob of cream cheese from a container and fed it to Thisbe, a white fluffy Eskie that he and his wife had just adopted.

title: Video: Mark Ingrams Draft Day
Business Leaders Endorse Same-Sex Marriage
description: New York State business leaders characterize marriage equality legislation as good for the economy.

title: This Just In: Obama Born in the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpt: 'The Normal Heart'
description: Ellen Barkin and Joe Mantello in a scene from Larry Kramer's play, which opened on Broadway at the Golden Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

title: A Whim, a Book, and, Wow!
description: When Adam Mansbach, author of Angry Black White Boy and The End of the Jews, posted on Facebook last June to Look out for my forthcoming childrens book, Go the  to Sleep, he was not serious. He was just tired: his then-2-year-old daughter, Vivien, refused to acknowledge bedtime.

title: Jury Convicts 2 and Acquits 2 in Cocaine Scheme
description: There had been testimony about Colombian terrorists, drug shipment flights from South America to West Africa and a government sting that featured the covert participation of the Liberian presidents son.

title: Live Blog: The 2011 N.F.L. Draft
description: If you want real N.F.L draft wisdom, do not ask a team executive. Do not ask a prospect, reporter, or draftnik either.

title: Party Leaders and Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Lenovo Aims a Campaign at the Apple Crowd
description: QUICK. How many Chinese brands can you name? Probably not many. While China has been known for its manufacturing prowess, branding its own products has not been its strength.

title: G.O.P. Pledge on Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: High-Speed Rail
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cynical Faith Healer Who Cant Fix Himself
description: Dean ODwyer (Christopher Thornton), a k a Delicious D, the paraplegic turntable artist turned faith healer at the center of Sympathy for Delicious is a paradox in a wheelchair. A cynical nonbeliever who discovers that he has a faith-healing gift that works 75 percent of the time, Dean is understandably miffed when he can heal others but cant make himself walk.

title: Saying No to Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Giving Juveniles Who Kill a Chance at Redemption
description: To the Editor:

title: Home-Buying Trends
description: To the Editor:

title: Japans Crises Cut the Bottom Lines at Some Concerns
description: When the earthquake and tsunami struck Japan in March, economists and corporate leaders knew it was only a matter of time for the financial effects to reach American companies.

title: School Districts Look to Parcel Taxes for Aid
description: Bay Area school districts, facing increasingly severe budget problems, are turning en masse to one of the few revenue-raising tools at their disposal: the parcel tax. These levies, a form of property tax, require approval by two-thirds of district voters, and they will be on the ballot in 11 different Bay Area school districts in a mail-in election next week.

title: Unease in Chatham, but Whos at Fault?
description: It has been asserted so widely for so long that it is accepted as fact: When Chicagos public housing projects came down, many of their former residents moved into middle-class South Side neighborhoods and brought crime with them.

title: Puppy Love and Bullies and a Bow-Tied Teacher
description: You can trust Ed Harris to locate the essence of every character he portrays. And in Thats What I Am, Mike Pavones righteous reflection on bullying and tolerance, Mr. Harriss depiction of a saintly, soft-spoken, bow-tie-wearing middle-school teacher lends the movie a moral weight it probably couldnt have summoned had another actor played the role.

title: New Chicago School Board Tackles Familiar Worries
description: The final meeting for Mayor Richard M. Daleys Board of Education was marked by a tiny ripple of resistance among the ranks of a group that haslargely marched in step since Mr. Daley took control of the citys public school system in 1995.

title: Mark Ingram's Draft Day
description: The former Heisman Trophy winner has yet to make a play in the N.F.L., but he has already had a sculpture made in his honor, out of chicken salad, courtesy of Subway.

title: A Utopian Society Made Up of Business Moguls in Fedoras
description: Could anyone have guessed, way back when it was published in 1957, that Atlas Shrugged, Ayn Rands grandiloquent doorstop of a masterwork, would one day reach the big screen as high-camp comedy? Because stilted prose and silly plotting notwithstanding, Rands unrelentingly popular book has exerted a powerful ideological hold on the culture, an influence that has only intensified in recent years with the emergence of the Tea Party. Still, for unintentional yet somehow boring hilarity, the novel cant touch the cinematic adaptation, which shifts the action to 2016 and presents Rands ham-fisted fable of laissez-faire capitalism as something C-Span might make if it ever set out to create a futuristic, proto-libertarian nighttime soap. In the 1980s.

title: A Shuttle Towns Glory Days
description: The launching of the space shuttle Endeavor is expected to be one of the biggest ever, jamming the roads in Titusville, Cape Canaveral and other nearby Florida towns.

title: The Monarchy Earns Its Keep
description: Egham, England

title: Rare Footage Indeed: Tornadoes, in Real Time
description: The deadliest tornado outbreak in decades unfolded live on local television stations Wednesday across much of the Deep South  and, remarkably, some of the tornado touchdowns were shown live, as well.

title: Discussions Outside Court Are Raised at Fire Trial
description: The public rarely gets a peek into the out-of-court discussions between prosecutors and the witnesses who testify for them.

title: Son of Advocates Makes Education His Mission
description: When the Chicago Board of Education meeting changed into a mutual admiration society on Wednesday, the members resembled fatigued relief workers celebrating after slightly diverting a flood.

title: How the Law Accepted Gays
description: Minneapolis

title: Tribeca Film Festival Announces Winners
description: The Tribeca Film Festival announced its winners Thursday night, with films from Sweden, South Korea, Rwanda and Norway among those taking prizes.

title: The Other
description: To watch Mitt Romney these days, he of the creased blue jeans and family that looks like it came from a Betty Crocker mold, circa 1957, its hard to see a product of one of the most radical social and sexual experiments in American history.

title: Rev. David Wilkerson Dies at 79; Started Times Square Church
description: The Rev. David Wilkerson, an evangelical minister and author who founded the Times Square Church to minister to the downtrodden in one of Manhattans seedier precincts, but whose later writings included apocalyptic predictions for New York City and beyond, died on Wednesday in an automobile accident in Texas. He was 79 and lived near Tyler, Tex.

title: To Lead Afghan War, Obama Chooses Marine Known for Swaying Sunnis in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  Lt. Gen. John R. Allen was called to the White House on Thursday for the formal announcement that he would take custody of the war in Afghanistan, now the focus of attention as the Obama administration moves toward withdrawing troops and handing over responsibility to the government in Kabul.

title: The Family Show-Off, Offering More for Less
description: INGRATITUDE and a grating impertinence are something many parents have come to expect from their high-maintenance subunits, but challenging ones parent is less common in the automotive world.

title: County Was Struggling Even Before the Storm
description: There are few places in America with more precarious finances than Jefferson County, Ala., the scene of some of the worst devastation from this weeks deadly tornadoes.

title: The Intimidated Fed
description: Last month more than 14 million Americans were unemployed by the official definition  that is, seeking work but unable to find it. Millions more were stuck in part-time work because they couldnt find full-time jobs. And were not talking about temporary hardship. Long-term unemployment, once rare in this country, has become all too normal: More than four million Americans have been out of work for a year or more.

title: Move to C.I.A. Puts Petraeus in Conflict With Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The appointment of Gen. David H. Petraeus as director of the Central Intelligence Agency puts him more squarely than ever in conflict with Pakistan, whose military leadership does not regard him as a friend and where he will now have direct control over the armed drone campaign that the Pakistani military says it wants stopped.

title: Trying to Stir Up a Popular Protest in China, From a Bedroom in Manhattan
description: From a pair of computer screens in a lime green bedroom in Upper Manhattan, a 27-year-old man from China is working to bring about a popular uprising.

title: Art of the Soil, on the Upper West Side
description: Imagine spending an afternoon watching a bunch of vagrants putter around on an abandoned city lot, and youve pretty much nailed the viewing experience of Earthwork, a painfully dull account of a year in the life of the Kansas crop artist Stan Herd.

title: Role Reversal for 2 Teams in This Years Playoffs
description: Its hard to tell the players without a scorecard or two at the United Center these days. The 2011 postseason continues a role reversal that has been under way for the buildings two major tenants.

title: A Chaotic Flurry of Twisters That Spread Devastation Fast and Wide
description: PLEASANT GROVE, Ala.  William Cannon, 46, a maintenance worker in this Birmingham suburb, said everyone knew on Wednesday that a big storm was coming. The news had been telling us about it for two days, he said.

title: Consultant to the Schools Stole Millions, Officials Say
description: Aided by lax oversight and by corporations that profited from his scheme, a former technology consultant stole $3.6 million over six years from the Department of Education to finance flashy cars and real estate speculation, federal authorities said on Thursday.

title: What Government Does
description: We in the commentariat spend a lot of time reporting on the White House and the U.S. Capitol, but relatively little time reporting on the dozens of federal buildings around them where public policy actually gets executed. We engage in debates about the size of government but spend little time directly observing what government is and isnt good at.

title: Conservative Congressmans Star Power Extends Beyond Florida District
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  Often, the most interesting thing about a person is the characteristic that lies beneath, that hidden thing that bobs up along the waves of time.

title: A TV Series Lost in Translation
description: Phil Rosenthal, the creator of Everybody Loves Raymond, is a successful television producer whos perhaps best known for being a frustrated actor and comedian. Now he has essentially cast himself as the star of Exporting Raymond, a documentary he wrote and directed about the frustrations of adapting his creation for Russian TV. It has the structure and some of the pleasures of a well-made sitcom or docu-reality show, despite the nervous-looking, unhappy guy at its center; it could have been called Nobody Understands Phil.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,540 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: The Mortgage Was Like a Shell Game; So Is Responsibility in 3 Deaths
description: The promise made by a mortgage company in San Diego could not have been more blunt. Accredited Home Lenders offers an unusually broad line of subprime mortgage products for wholesale mortgage brokers, the companys Web site boasted in its heyday.

title: 2 Russians Guilty of Killing Rights Lawyer and Journalist
description: MOSCOW  A young Russian nationalist and his common-law wife were convicted Thursday in the particularly brazen murders of a prominent human rights lawyer and a journalist two years ago, as the jury sided with prosecutors who argued that the ideologically driven defendants considered their victims enemies of Russia.

title: President Assads Crackdown
description: When Bashar al-Assad succeeded his father, Hafez, as Syrias president in 2000, the United States and many others hoped that Syria might finally stop persecuting its people and become a more responsible regional power.

title: Red Riding Hood, the Spy Caper
description: From the Department of Needless Sequels comes Hoodwinked Too! Hood vs. Evil, another Weinstein Company bid to crack the overcrowded field of childrens digital animation. A successor to the lackluster Hoodwinked!, with a cast of formidable voice talents, the film takes fairy-tale characters  Little Red Riding Hood, the Wolf, the Grandmother  and drops them into a comic web of fantastical espionage.

title: Speaking Up for Patient Safety, and Survival
description: On Tuesday, I wrote about a new technological system that might help hospitals to accurately track whether health care workers are washing their hands, and remind them to do so in real time. The reason hospitals might want to spend the money to install such an expensive fix is that so far, very few hospitals have been able to get their hand-washing rates above 50 percent.

title: Working Up a Sweat, and Thats Well Before the Draft
description: The N.F.L. draft has become a lot like a football practice, for prospects and fans alike: a grueling, seemingly never-ending series of events and obstacles, conducted in pouring rain and stifling humidity.

title: The Subways Elevator Operators, a Reassuring Amenity of Another Era
description: John Petruzzis office is, all things considered, not a terribly unpleasant place to work. It could use a window, and an Internet connection might be nice, but colorful art hangs on the walls, and the subway access is unbeatable.

title: A Disney Take on the Big Night  Review
description: Some moviegoers and critics will probably dismiss Prom as just another predictable offering from the Disney formula factory. Which is precisely what it is. But heres the thing: There are new tweeners every year. To them, the characters and plot devices in this perfectly competent film might well seem fresh.

title: Saving the Doha Round
description: After a decade of frustratingly little progress, it is easy to conclude that the negotiations to reduce global trade barriers have failed. But letting the so-called Doha round of world trade talks collapse could spur a protectionist backlash and deal a huge blow to international cooperation on even bigger challenges, including global warming and financial reform.

title: Storms Leave Destruction in Their Wake
description: The death toll continued to climb Thursday from a barrage of severe weather that ripped through the South, leaving behind a trail of flattened homes and buildings in a region already battered by storms.

title: Homers Are Just a Part of the Yanks Big Night
description: Their first three games against the Chicago White Sox transported the Yankees into this bizarro alternate universe, a place where all accepted certainties about the team were refuted. A potent lineup went silent. Their lockdown bullpen faltered. The rotation, supposedly shaky, thrived.

title: A Stronger and Clearer Clean Water Act
description: The Obama administrations new guidelines for the Clean Water Act are an important first step in restoring vital legal safeguards to wetlands and streams threatened by development and pollution.

title: In the Wake of Wednesdays Tornadoes
description: The violent storms that struck the South on Wednesday may break one of natures grimmer records. On April 3, 1974, 148 tornadoes touched down on a single day and left behind a trail of wreckage nearly 2,500 miles long. As many as 135 tornadoes were reported on Wednesday, wrecking homes, towns and lives.

title: Berkshire Gets Tough With Sokol as Meeting Nears
description: After Warren E. Buffett disclosed last month that David L. Sokol was resigning from Berkshire Hathaway amid the revelation that he had bought a $10 million personal stake in Lubrizol while promoting a takeover of the company, Berkshire was quiet for weeks. Now, on the eve of Berkshires annual shareholders meeting, the company has come out fighting.

title: Can Kristen Wiig Turn On the Charm?
description: Kristen Wiig shows up seven minutes into the movie Knocked Up, an assassin in a junior executives suit, meeting with the television production assistant played by Katherine Heigl, who their boss has decided is ready to go on the air. Wiigs character is every middle manager who clings to her authority by association; she shows her boss small reassuring smiles while revealing subterranean loathing toward the young woman with the promotion. She tells Heigls character that they cannot legally ask her to lose weight. We would just like it if you go home and step on a scale and write down how much you weigh, she says. And subtract it by, like, 20. Knocked Up is a movie filled with slapstick, screaming and shtick, and yet Wiig, with nothing more than her small, tight smile and death-by-platitude lines, practically stole the show with that two-minute scene. After I saw how much people loved it in the movie, says Judd Apatow, who wrote and directed the film, I instantly asked her if she had any plans to write a script for herself.

title: Sooner or Later, the Celtics Were Expecting to Face the Heat
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  A playoff series between Boston and Miami seemed preordained, almost inevitable, once LeBron James took his considerable talents (along with Chris Bosh) to South Beach and the Celtics responded by signing every available ONeal.

title: When Past and Present Collide
description: A letter from the past prompts present-day pain in We Go Way Back, a gentle survey of the chasm between youthful dreams and adult reality.

title: Predicting Tornadoes: Its Still a Guessing Game
description: The cruelty of this particular April, in the number of tornadoes recorded, is without equal in the United States. The record for the month has been shattered, and preliminary assessments say that of the four biggest clusters ever recorded, two have occurred in the last three weeks.

title: In Shift, Egypt Warms to Iran and Hamas, Israels Foes
description: CAIRO  Egypt is charting a new course in its foreign policy that has already begun shaking up the established order in the Middle East, planning to open the blockaded border with Gaza and normalizing relations with two of Israel and the Wests Islamist foes, Hamas and Iran.

title: A Cosmic Comeuppance for the Dodgers
description: Be careful. Be very careful what you wish for. And whatever you do, never underestimate the power of negative thinking.

title: On to Round 2 After a Round 1 That Had Everything
description: The first round of this years Stanley Cup playoffs is a tough act to follow, but the show went on Thursday night, with Nashville visiting Vancouver to start the second round.

title: The Deadliest Years
description: A map of tornado deaths from 1950 to 2011.

title: Business Leaders, in Letter, Will Urge Albany to Legalize Gay Marriage
description: Two dozen high-profile New York business leaders plan to release an open letter on Friday urging state lawmakers to legalize same-sex marriage, arguing that the measure would help companies attract and retain employees.

title: China: Sentence Reduced for Hong Kong Academic
description: The sentence of a Hong Kong political scientist who was jailed on espionage charges in 2001 after he was accused of giving secret documents to a South Korean scholar has been reduced by five months, an American human rights organization said Thursday. The researcher, Xu Zerong, was a senior fellow at the Guangdong Academy of Social Sciences when he was accused of illegally photocopying military documents from the Korean War and illegally providing intelligence to foreign entities. Mr. Xu said that he thought the five-decade-old documents had long since been declassified. The Dui Hua Foundation, a human rights group, said Mr. Xu had already served 10 years of a 13-year sentence and that with two previous reductions for good behavior, he could be released in June.

title: Friday: It May Be Assumed
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Lets talk about the days of the week. Today is Friday, and as we all know, todays puzzle should be one of the two brain breakers of the week, along with the Saturday puzzle. There is a lot of discussion among solvers and constructors about whether this means that there should be more SAT type words, or that the cluing should be fairly opaque. Im going to give you my opinion, and I realize that your mileage may vary.

title: Bid to Limit Benefits Plan in New Jersey Is Dropped
description: A statewide employee-benefits program that has enabled hundreds of local governments and school districts in New Jersey to save tens of millions of dollars on health insurance has averted a potentially crippling legislative threat.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 28, 2011

title: What Bubbie Did During the War
description: When Donna Murphy time travels, she packs light. A pair of glasses, a shawl, maybe some lipstick: thats all this chameleon actress requires to step over the chasm that divides two chapters of one womans life in The People in the Picture, a sincere and queasy new musical about mother love, Yiddish theater and the Holocaust that opened on Thursday night at Studio 54.

title: Hernandez Puts Aside Concerns About Investigation and Halts Mets Streak
description: WASHINGTON  Washington Nationals pitcher Livan Hernandez has made 452 consecutive starts over the last 15 years without going on the disabled list, a remarkable string of durability, focus and resilience. Surely there were times he did not feel quite right, when his arm ached or a personal issue nagged at him.

title: The Causes of the Civil War, 2.0
description: A new poll from the Pew Research Center reports that nearly half of Americans identify states rights as the primary cause of the Civil War. This is a remarkable finding, because virtually all American textbooks and prominent historians emphasize slavery, as they have for decades. Even more striking, the poll shows young people put more stock in the states rights explanation than older people. The 38 percent of Americans who believe slavery was mainly to blame find themselves losing ground.

title: Storms Leave Destruction in Their Wake
description: The death toll continued to climb Thursday from a barrage of severe weather that ripped through the South, leaving behind a trail of flattened homes and buildings in a region already battered by storms.

title: Giants Pick Is Surprise; Jets Get What They Were Looking For
description: The Giants favored talent over needs Thursday night when they selected Nebraska cornerback Prince Amukamara at No. 19 of the N.F.L. draft.

title: Cheaper Drug to Treat Eye Disease Is Effective
description: A drug that costs about $50 a dose is just as effective at preserving and improving vision in elderly people with an age-related eye disease as one that costs $2,000 a dose, according to the results of a government-sponsored clinical trial released Thursday.

title: A Big Question for Berkshire
description: Warren E. Buffett has many unpleasant questions to address at Berkshire Hathaways annual meeting on Saturday. The stock dealings of David L. Sokol, a former heir apparent, have raised concerns over the companys internal controls  even about Mr. Buffetts judgment. But one subject may be a step too far for the Buffett faithful congregating in Omaha: isnt it time to break up the company?

title: Vincent OLeary, Who Revived Albany University, Dies at 86
description: Vincent OLeary, who invigorated the State University of New York at Albany after a period of decline, died on April 22 in Gaithersburg, Md., where he lived. He was 86.

title: London Readies for Royal Wedding
description: LONDON  As last-minute preparations drew to a close, London braced Friday for a royal wedding that promises to be one of the largest and most widely watched events here in recent memory.

title: Proposal Seeks to Expand List of Organ Donors
description: In 2010 almost 600 Texans died while waiting for organ transplants, a byproduct of the states paltry offerings on its state-run organ-donation registry.

title: After Fire, Wind and Drought, Something Good Will Follow
description: These are strange days in Texas. A severe drought gripping the entire state, unseasonably high temperatures, unusually low humidity and exceptionally gusty winds have created a perfect storm for wildfires, which have erupted statewide like never before. Horrible images of homes burned to the ground, property destroyed, and livestock, wildlife and human fatalities are impossible to escape.

title: For Accused, Long Waits to Appeal Child Abuse Allegations
description: It has been more than a decade since Child Protective Services entered Gary and Melissa Gatess home in the Houston area and removed their two biological children and 11 adopted ones, after an allegation that the pair had emotionally abused one of the children. Within three days, a judge had returned all the children to their parents; within eight months, the child welfare agency had dropped its case.

But it proved that the British still know how to combine pageantry, solemnity and romance (and wild hats) better than anyone else in the world.

title: Syrian Forces Shoot at Protesters in Daraa Siege
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Soldiers fired on protesters carrying olive branches and seeking to break the militarys siege of a rebellious town in Syria on Friday, killing at least 16 people, as thousands took to the streets in what organizers proclaimed a Friday of Rage against the governments crackdown on a six-week uprising, witnesses and activists said.

title: European Regulators Investigate Banks for Credit Swaps

title: Incident on a Train
description: The guy behind me on the train was whispering into his phone, something about his soon-to-be-ex demanding the house on the river. Something about how he wakes up nauseated, almost as if he were undergoing chemo, which he would prefer because at least cancer would be an enemy he could commit to hating instead of being conflicted the way he was, still loving his pre-ex but needing to fight her as hard as he could. With my head against the window in the seat ahead, I was feeling vaguely nauseated myself, when I became conscious that a womans voice was calling out weakly from the front of the crowded compartment. Help. Someone help me.

title: The Year That TV Actually Got It Right
description: Sports-stats nerds (who are, statistically speaking, the jockiest of all nerd subcastes) love to debate the perfect draft. A recent ESPN.com study concluded that the 1983 N.F.L. draft was just that; players drafted that year racked up a total of 142 Pro Bowl appearances, and six of them went to the Hall of Fame. Even if you factor out John Elway, Dan Marino and Jim Kelly, the class of 83 still finishes in a virtual tie with the studys second- and third-place drafts, 1996 (Ray Lewis, Terrell Owens) and 1981 (Lawrence Taylor, Ronnie Lott).

title: Abuse of Power?
description: My sister recently seized my 82-year-old fathers assets under her decade-old power of attorney, after he became engaged to a 63-year-old woman with a history of unpaid bills and an affinity for Atlantic City slots. He was running around with multiple testosterone patches in anticipation of his nuptials to this gal, who refused to meet with us after we traveled cross-country. Now he says he promises not to marry her, and we feel terrible for humiliating him. Should we give him back control of his money or would that be setting him up to be fleeced? NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

title: Eating Your Cultural Vegetables
description: Do you watch Phineas and Ferb?

title: What if Sanity Prevails In Washington?
description: My colleague David Leonhardt, an economics writer who somehow makes common sense seem provocative, won a Pulitzer Prize the other day. I have no doubt the judges who reviewed his work were particularly impressed by one feat of analytical genius, an online puzzle called O.K., You Fix the Budget. With help from some of our techno-genies, David devised an interactive graphic that lets you choose from a menu of tax increases and spending cuts and benefit tweaks until the budget balances. In short, he crowd-sourced the deficit.

title: Marine Le Pen, Frances (Kinder, Gentler) Extremist
description: Step inside an office building in the town of Nanterre, just west of Paris, and you are confronted by what the nostrils register as an odor of the past, for its a rare thing these days to encounter the lingering taint of cigarette smoke in public spaces. The trail of it leads upstairs to a corner office and to the woman who has, in the past few months, come to dominate French newspapers and chat shows, where she is depicted variously as the new face of European bigotry or a herald of a new European political realignment.

title: For Modernist Cuisine, Errata Commensurate to the Task
description: For those of us who dont have the $625 (or the upper-body strength) to buy Modernist Cuisine, the six-volume, 40-pound high-tech food encyclopedia released with great fanfare last month, the 12 pages of corrections and clarifications that went up on the books Web site last week is worth a read for its own sake.

title: Richie Sambora to Miss Bon Jovi Tour
description: Bon Jovi plans to proceed with its tour of North America and Europe even though its lead guitarist, Richie Sambora, has entered rehab for a drinking problem, Reuters reported. No replacement for Mr. Sambora has been announced for the tour, which begins on Saturday in New Orleans and runs through July 31 in Lisbon.

title: Magic Lanterns
description: The young designer Marco Dess, who was born in Italy and who is based in Vienna, has a knack for clarity. A recent case in point is his Basket chandelier for the venerable Viennese manufacturer Lobmeyr. Dess took as its starting point the glass-tube arms of an 18th-century chandelier but employed them in a new way, bending them into hexagons, stacking them in a shape inspired by mosque lanterns and the glass-tube windows of Frank Lloyd Wrights S. C. Johnson Administration Building, and weaving them together with jewel-toned silk cords. The result is an alluring combination of the industrial and the glamorous. Go to lobmeyr.at.
