title: Leading Off: Get Your Quarterbacks Here
description: In this most bizarre of N.F.L. off-seasons, the first round of the draft did not disappoint. There were boos. There were tears. There was Cam Newton going from most hotly debated prospect to most hotly debated No. 1 pick. There was Commissioner Roger Goodell hugging players like that creepy uncle you really wish would let go already. And there was a run on quarterbacks so irrational you wonder if the N.F.L. circulated a memo that Goodell would start hugging you if you didnt pick one.

title: Tales From the Global Sex Trade
description: Opponents of immigration often prefer to ignore the tragic forces that compel people to risk death in order to reach our lands of plenty, not to mention the horrors that often await the lucky few, once they do arrive. Imagine an Underground Railroad in which the conductor robs and rapes his passengers, and the station porter, once theyve disembarked, ushers them into a new form of slavery. This unholy traffic in impoverished strivers, imported to service needs Westerners dont want to think about, is the subject of Chika Unigwes novel On Black Sisters Street.

title: China: Canceled Music Festival Raises Concern
description: A music festival scheduled for this weekend in the city of Suzhou has been canceled, making some musicians and organizers of music festivals in China increasingly nervous that the continuing government crackdown on dissent could have a significant impact on them. Organizers of the Suzhou music festival, called Strawberry, said in messages on the Internet this week that the event was canceled for reasons related to recent rainstorms. But artists and observers of the music industry in China have speculated that Strawberry was canceled because of official pressure after a political incident at a music festival last weekend in Jiangsu Province. At that festival, called Zhouzhuang, the name of the detained artist Ai Weiwei was flashed on a big screen. Days later, Zuoxiao Zuzhou, a Chinese rock musician who expressed support for Mr. Ai at that festival and in a newspaper article, was temporarily detained by police officers. Another music festival, Midi, is scheduled to take place this weekend in a suburb of Beijing; its organizers have privately told people that they are anxious.

title: Superman Renounces His U.S. Citizenship
description: For much of his career, Superman has fought for truth, justice and the American way. In the landmark Action Comics No. 900, which was released on Wednesday, Superman decides he has to stand for something bigger and he renounces his United States citizenship.

title: Russia: 10 Militants Said to Be Killed in North Caucasus
description: Russian security forces said on Friday that at least 10 Islamist militants had been killed in a special operation in Russias volatile and mostly Muslim North Caucasus region. At least two women were killed in the operation, which was spurred by a shootout between security forces and militants in the village of Progress on the border with the Stavropol Region and the mostly Muslim region of Kabardino-Balkaria, Russias Investigative Committee said in a statement. It was the latest in an intensified campaign to eliminate Islamist fighters and their bases in the North Caucasus after a deadly terrorist attack at a Moscow airport in January that was linked to militants there. No one on the side of the security forces was wounded in the operation, officials said.

description: BEFORE the two young playwrights fell for each other, they first fell for each others prose.

title: A Bracing Breath of Spring Air From All Directions
description: FOR many American orchestras, especially those in smaller cities with regional reputations, a concert at Carnegie Hall is only a dream. When such ensembles decide to take the financial risk of renting Carnegie Hall for a concert, their conductors often let their marketing departments talk them into playing it safe. The idea of performing a new work by a hometown composer or Schoenbergs Five Pieces for Orchestra or an overlooked piece like Prokofievs Fifth Piano Concerto is vetoed in favor of a program that will show New York audiences and critics how well the visitors can play Beethovens Seventh Symphony or Tchaikovskys Pathtique. With no real news happening, these concerts often attract negligible audiences and are given a pass by critics.

title: Magics Season Ends in Disappointment, Uncertainty
description: The Orlando Magic have unceremoniously gone poof in the playoffs, ousted in the first round Thursday by the Atlanta Hawks. The Magic tried to stave off elimination, but lost Game 6, 84-81, in Atlanta.

title: A Voice Where Romance and Dysfunction Meet
description: ARE you really going to ask me that? the composer and vocalist Corey Dargel inquired near the end of a sprawling conversation one recent evening, his measured tone briefly betraying impatience and resignation. What bothered him was being asked how he felt about his constant characterization as an artist whose work concerns bridging the gap between classical and popular music. Though not inaccurate, the description has become convenient shorthand, warding off deeper investigation of his work.

title: Finland Turns to the Right. Is France Next?
description: In the magazine this weekend, Russell Shorto, a contributing writer who lives in Amsterdam (heres his recent article on integration there), writes about Marine Le Pen, who has succeeded her father, Jean-Marie Le Pen, as president of the far-right National Front Party in France. Shorto notes that these kinds of nationalist, anti-immigration political groups are back on the rise not just in France but also across Europe, and he describes how Marine Le Pen is trying to reconcile her mainstream ambitions for the party with its extremist history.

title: Weekend Miser
description: With Mother Nature being so testy of late, it may be best just to plan to play inside. But this can be a pleasure when playing inside means getting to drink beer, listen to Colombian jazz, play golf and watch talented dancers.

title: Confusion Over a Book About Harper Lee
description: The author of a forthcoming book about the ever-private Harper Lee, author of To Kill a Mockingbird, insisted on Friday that she had the cooperation of Ms. Lee, two days after Ms. Lee released a statement through her lawyer denying that she had cooperated.

title: Metropolitan Preview: Introducing App City
description: Close readers of this weeks Metropolitan section on Sunday will notice some changes. This week brings the first appearance of App City, a column devoted to technology intended to get you to work faster, help you find that restaurant youve been longing to try, or guide you through that blockbuster museum exhibition. Or at least thats what app developers claim theyll do  our columnist, Joshua Brustein, will be putting them to the test every other week.

title: The Tina Fey Subliminal Effect
description: I was listening to a podcast of Tina Fey talking to Terry Gross on Fresh Air recently about her book, Bossypants, and Fey mentioned something in passing that gave me insight into an enduring political mystery. Gross asked Fey about her time writing for Saturday Night Live and which guest hosts she particularly liked. Fey talked about how much she enjoyed John McCain when he was on the show in the early 2000s. In 2004, Life magazine photographed the two of them together in Washington for a get-out-the-vote cover.

title: Review Casts More Doubts on a Lung Cancer Study
description: In medical experiments on human beings, every patient must sign an informed consent form acknowledging the risks, and researchers are required to keep track of those statements.

title: How Goldman Sachs Beat the Bubble
description: Contrary to the silly subtitle his publisher no doubt foisted on him, William D. Cohan does not argue that Goldman Sachs rules the world. A judicious author, Cohan avoids hyperbole in Money and Power, a definitive account of the most profitable and influential investment bank of the modern era.

title: The Society of Surfaces
description: The single most common question I got on my book tour was the following: Do you think Facebook is destroying friendship and deep personal connections? I generally gave a positive answer (Facebook supplements friendship, it doesnt supplant it) while adding that what matters are the qualities the user brings to Facebook, not the technology itself.

title: A Weekend in London
description: From the Sherlock Holmes pub to the King's Library, take a literary-themed excursion.

title: Prep Squad
description: In 2010, after 30 years, Lisa Birnbach followed up The Official Preppy Handbook, her wildly successful guide to all things Muffy and Biff, with True Prep: Its a Whole New Old World. The sequel was meant to bring fans of the original up to speed with advice on such matters as how to remarry or how to dress for a funeral. title: Most Rookies Fail to Make Debut at Event
description: Newly-hired employees want to make a good impression. First-round N.F.L. draft picks are no exception.

title: Rescuing Fragments of Bronx Lives
description: Two New York dramatists were looking for inspiration for their next play and found it in the Bronx  inside two storage lockers they bought at auction.

title: Scene: 'The Education of Dee Dee Ricks'
description: The HBO documentary about a woman's transformation through breast cancer premieres at the Tribeca Film Festival.

title: The Novel as Puzzle
description: Some books beg to be interpreted. Built for close scrutiny, they invite critical strategies  and almost abandon narrative pleasure. Think of the reader who, in 1853, was the first to crack Bartleby, the Scrivener, turning page after page, flipping back, then ahead, then back again, hoping for some insight into that pallid Wall Street copyist. Or think of the reader who first encountered the opening of The Sound and the Fury: Through the fence, between the curling flower spaces, I could see them hitting. By the end of Faulkners first page, that reader surely wondered if there had been some problem at the printing press. Could the pages have been scrambled? Neither of those readers had the blas contemporary comfort of classifying such work as postmodern, post-postmodern, image fiction, metafiction, experimental or millennial. The text itself held all the answers, if there were any answers.

title: Exploring Kyoto, Japan
description: Lantern-lit alleyways, grand temples and ancient shrines make the city one of Japan's prettiest.

title: A  Weekend in Naples, Italy
description: Savory pizzas, sidewalk cafes and peaceful strolls on the seafront are reasons enough to visit this ancient city.

title: Artists Trailer Park Is History
description: The saga of the trailer park on the Bushwick-Willamsburg border in Brooklyn has come to an unceremonious end.

title: Pampered 'Nakations'
description: An increasing number of hotels and resorts are offering more options for travelers who want to shed their clothing  but not their luxurious lifestyles.

title: Fusing Old and New Cuisine in Copenhagen
description: New restaurants add international flair to regional ingredients.

title: Surf Fever in Peru
description: The world-class surfing in Peru is a local craze, and ready and waiting for its international close-up.

title: A Weekend in Athens, Greece
description: With hot new shopping districts and a thriving museum scene, the city is no longer a pit stop for the Greek isles.

title: A Weekend in Liverpool, England
description: The city is home to a new generation of bands, unpretentious pubs and a cutting-edge art scene.

title: Electrical Problems Force Delay in Shuttle Launching
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  An electrical problem forced NASA on Friday to postpone the launching of the shuttle Endeavour, giving President Obama and hundreds of thousands of spectators a lesson in the fickle nature of space technology.

title: The Kings Men, After the American Revolution
description: Only a tiny fraction of the books written on the American Revolution are devoted to the loyalists  the residents of the 13 colonies who chose to leave their homes rather than become citizens of the new republic. Such a nation-bound approach to the writing of American history implies that the lives of those who left were not significant. Yet they were, and Maya Jasanoff, who teaches history at Harvard, has provided a richly informative account of those who made the choice to embrace imperial Britain. As earlier historians of the Revolution have pointed out, the loyalists tended to have strong connections to the imperial administration, belong to the Anglican Church and possess close business or family ties to Britain. But not all who left fitted such a profile. Escaped slaves had obvious reason to depart, and so did those whose property was confiscated by the revolutionaries. Most pervasively, of course, the loyalists shared a loyalty to the king.

title: Discovering Old in the New Ireland
description: Lush green views, craggy cliffs and traditional villages still grace the countrys changing landscape.

title: The Two Nicosias of Cyprus
description: Called Lefkosia in Greek and Lefkosa in Turkish, Nicosia is a visible symbol of ethnic divisions on the island nation.

title: A Weekend in Luang Prabang, Laos
description: The ancient capital is emerging as Southeast Asia's next potential hot spot for globe-trotting tourists.

title: Louisianas African-American Heritage Trail
description: Winding its way through plantations, churches and museums, the trail offers a history lesson in Louisianas past.

title: Book of Mormon Leads Drama Desk Nominations With 12
description: The Broadway musical The Book of Mormon took a dominant position among new musicals in Fridays Drama Desk nominations, earning 12  twice as many as the rival Broadway shows Catch Me if You Can and Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown. Among new plays, the Iraq war drama Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo received the most nominations, six, followed by the Off Broadway works Peter and the Starcatcher with five nominations and A Small Fire with four.

title: A Feast of Many Flavors in Tunis, Tunisia
description: Mediterranean, Arabic and North African influences create a charming blend in this ancient capital.

title: A Weekend in Cartagena, Colombia

title: The River Road African-American Museum
description: Navigate a 360-degree panoramic to view historical artifacts in this Louisiana museum.

title: A Weekend in Lima, Peru
description: The cosmopolitan city boasts neighborhoods with distinct cultures, histories and flavors.

title: Lost in the Meritocracy
description: In June 2008, The Atlantic published an essay by an adjunct instructor of English, identified only as Professor X, whose job filled him with despair. Although the courses he taught were introductory, success was beyond many of his students, who, he wrote, were in some cases barely literate. X found giving Fs to be excruciating  I am the man who has to lower the hammer, he lamented  in part because he identified with his older students, who seemed to have lost their way in their careers much as X himself had.

title: Beginning of the End for Paper Social Security Checks
description: Beginning Sunday, the federal government is retiring paper Social Security checks and switching to electronic deposits for new benefit applicants.

title: Capitals vs. Lightning: Youth Meets Experience in Goal
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The second-round showdown between the Washington Capitals and the Tampa Bay Lightning may turn on an intriguing matchup that pits the youngest starting goaltender in the playoffs against the oldest one to appear in this postseason.

title: Metrosol Parasol, Huge Wooden Structure, Debuts in Seville
description: For centuries, Seville, Spain, has been known for its striking architecture  particularly its Moorish Alczar and huge Gothic cathedral. The Metropol Parasol, a large, multipurpose structure that made its debut late last month in the city, looks both backward and forward in its unusual design.

title: Fresh and Local in Sonoma County
description: Strictly sustainable and organic, family-run farms are serving up a rich variety of foods.

title: Living In | East Amwell, N.J.
description: In populous New Jersey, a township that took a proactive approach to land preservation years ago is now reaping the benefits.

title: Altitudes a Variable, Roominess a Constant
description: DRIVE along almost any road in the valley section of East Amwell and you will find pretty much the same thing: wide-open fields being planted for spring, silos full of grain or corn, paddocks with horses grazing, and the occasional house. Head up into the foothills of the Sourland Mountains at the south end of the township and youll find forest, rock outcroppings, trail heads, and the occasional house.

title: Finding the Hits, Avoiding the Errors
description: A culinary scorecard for all 30 major league baseball stadiums.

title: Ballparks Step Up Their Food Game
description: Ballpark cuisine is no longer just hot dogs and popcorn. It has become increasingly ambitious and occasionally delicious.

title: Haute Cuisine in the Colorado Rockies
description: Organic farming in Aspen is changing ideas about dining out.

title: Why the North Fought the Civil War
description: Among the enduring mysteries of the American Civil War is why millions of Northerners were willing to fight to preserve the nations unity. It is not difficult to understand why the Southern states seceded in 1860 and 1861. As the Confederacys founders explained ad infinitum, they feared that Abraham Lincolns election as president placed the future of slavery in jeopardy. But why did so few Northerners echo the refrain of Horace Greeley, the editor of The New York Tribune: Erring sisters, go in peace?

title: A Weekend in Knoxville
description: Ensconced in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains, the city has an intrinsically soulful feel.

title: How Writers Build the Brand
description: As every author knows, writing a book is the easy part these days. Its when the publication date looms that we have to roll up our sleeves and tackle the real literary labor: rabid self-promotion. For weeks beforehand, we are compelled to bombard every friend, relative and vague acquaintance with creative e-mails and Facebook alerts, polish up our Web sites with suspiciously youthful author photos, and, in an orgy of blogs, tweets and YouTube trailers, attempt to inform an already inundated world of our every reading, signing, review, interview and (well, one can dream!) TV appearance.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Circus Vet
description: Sara Gruens Water for Elephants has topped multiple fiction best-seller lists this spring.

title: Inside the List
description: LIBERTY BELLS: Its only a few weeks since Barack Obama declared his candidacy for re-election, and already the right is winning the best-seller list. Liberty Defined: 50 Essential Issues That Affect Our Freedom, the latest from Ron Paul, lands at No. 3 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Jesse Venturas 63 Documents the Government Doesnt Want You to Read is at No. 6. And Andrew Breitbart storms to No. 14 with Righteous Indignation: Excuse Me While I Save the World! In a recent interview with The OReilly Factor, Breitbart  the gadfly proprietor of the Web sites Big Government, Big Journalism, Big Hollywood and Big Peace (which has called for Congressional hearings into the religion of peace)  exhorted the dull but serious Republican contenders to neutralize Donald Trump before its too late. Celebrity is everything in this country, Breitbart said. And if these guys dont learn how to play the media the way that Barack Obama played the media last election cycle and the way that Donald Trump is playing the election cycle, were going to probably get a celebrity candidate. Shirley MacLaine in 2012? Her latest memoir, Im Over All That, is floating above the fray at No. 5.

title: Editors Choice
description: 1861: The Civil War Awakening,  by Adam Goodheart (Knopf, $28.95.) In this exhilarating account of the wars first stage, Goodheart turns his lens upon some fascinating figures who loomed large at the time but have now been mostly forgotten.

title: Its Not Listed. But Its Definitely for Sale.
description: ANY broker would be happy to list Ellen Balls co-op apartment in Manhattan.

title: Afghanistan War Report Cites Progress by Troops
description: WASHINGTON  Tangible progress has been made in expanding security across Afghanistan, the Pentagon reported on Friday, saying that successes on the battlefield over the past several months could be attributed to the 30,000 additional troops sent to the war by President Obama.

title: Spains Water Festival
description: The city of Zaragoza is ready to spring onto the world stage with its Expo that touts water and conservation.

title: The Caribbean on the Cheap
description: Nearly empty beaches and discount rates greet summer travelers visiting the Caribbean.

title: Paperback Row
description: TRUE COMPASS: A Memoir,  by Edward M. Kennedy (Twelve, $16.99.) In this affecting autobiography, Kennedy (1932-2009) illuminates his personal and public life. He lovingly recalls his father, Joseph P. Kennedy (Edward was the youngest and most underestimated of the familys nine children), and ruminates about Chappaquiddick (which haunts me every day of my life) and his crusades for health care and civil rights during his 47-year grind in the Senate.

title: Oscar Wild
description: More dancing queen than demure, the Times Square, Oscar de la Rentas new metallic-print lam, crystal-studded double platform sandal ($1,595), marks a revamp of the designers footwear business. While Mr. de la Renta hasnt abandoned the ladylike kitten heels and pretty pumps his mature customers have come to expect, his latest collection is peppered with the kind of sky-high satin stilettos and sexy platforms his younger fans have been clamoring for. Another sign of the youthquake at the atelier: the designer has just reintroduced his classic fragrance, Esprit dOscar, with fresh, zingy notes that are sure to seduce his ladies in waiting. Go to oscardelatrenta.com.

title: A Weekend in Vienna, Austria
description: Where museum-worthy beauty may once have felt untouchable, there is a palpable sense of a city loosening up.

title: Janet Malcolms Cross-Examinations
description: Two decades ago, Janet Malcolm published The Journalist and the Murderer, her classic story of the story of a murder trial. Her subject was the relationship between the writer Joe McGinniss and the Army doctor Jeffrey MacDonald, who gave McGinniss full access to his defense team when he stood trial for the death of his wife and children  and then discovered that over years of apparent friendship, McGinniss was writing a future best seller portraying MacDonald as a psychopathic killer. In her brilliant dissection of this betrayal, Malcolm exposed the morally indefensible nature of the work of her journalistic tribe.

title: Francine Proses Immigrant Novel
description: The great grinning tradition of American satire has always been healthy because this confounding country provides an abundance of jaw-dropping moments every day, moments that dont need rewriting or amplification to reveal their comic craziness. All you need is the ability to see them and then present them plainly, as if you were born yesterday, with nothing but big eyes and a sense of right and wrong. O.K., maybe born the day before yesterday and in Albania, but still with that sense of right and wrong. Francine Prose has just such a sharp protagonist in her wry novel, My New American Life, a book that brims with smart surprises.

title: The Berlin Scene
description: Visit the chic restaurants and museums, both traditional and eccentric, in what could be Europe's most cultured city.

title: A History of Protest Songs
description: What is protest music? In April 1966, Bob Dylan arrived in Stockholm as part of his controversial electric world tour, and a local interviewer asked him why he was no longer writing and performing protest songs. Dylan, irritated and more than a little out of it, objected to the questions premise and called one of his new rock n roll compositions the very height of protest music: Very, very protesty. And, uh, one of the protestiest of all things I ever protested against in my protest years.

title: Retreating From a Ruptured Marriage
description: One little word  pause  sets off the chain of events in which Mia Fredricksen, the 55-year-old poet and professor who narrates Siri Hustvedts fifth novel, retreats for the summer to the backwater Minnesota town where she grew up. Her husband, a neuroscientist named Boris Izcovich, has asked for a pause in their marriage so he can take up with a younger colleague, a woman with whom he had no past. After a short, agonizing stay in a psychiatric ward, Mia decamps from her Brooklyn apartment to tiny Bonden, seeing no choice but to wait out the cruel crack of hope in her husbands request. There she finds herself immersed, somewhat accidentally, in an all-female world that includes her mothers five lively geriatric friends, the seven adolescent members of a poetry workshop and the young mother next door, whose husband travels often for work. Over the course of the summer, Mia confronts, with the help of phone sessions with her (female) therapist, her own history as a willing second-class citizen, a scribbler of the stolen interval who hadnt fought for myself. Along the way, she re-examines everything shes believed about the differences between men and women and the possibility of married love.

title: The Nanny at the Wedding
description: I didnt see her in any of the photos of the celebrities and family members entering Westminster Abbey this morning, but somewhere in that crowd was Tiggy Pettifer, formerly Tiggy Legge-Bourke, Williams long-ago nanny. I did see countless photos of her son  8-year-old Tom Pettifer, who was one of those scarlet-clad pageboys.

description: Catch a Pacific sunset, eat fresh California cuisine and stay at a luxurious resort known for its Hollywood regulars.

description: Once a Soviet package-tour destination, the resort town of Sochi is getting a makeover for its role as host of the 2014 Winter Olympics.

title: Jennifer Bartletts Epic Rhapsody Back on View at the Modern
description: Rhapsody, Jennifer Bartletts epic polymorphous post-painting painting in nearly 1,000 parts is once again on view at the Museum of Modern Art, wrapped around three long walls and looking tailor-made for the museums giant atrium. The work was first shown here five years ago, as part of an exhibition of works given to the Modern by the collector Edward R. Broida. At that time, the pieces appearance was an early indication that the atrium might serve as something other than a large, alienating event space.

title: The Land of Cheese: Asturias, Spain
description: This isolated nook of the country has spawned generations of cheese makers.

title: A Weekend in Seattle
description: The city has revitalized its waterfront with modern sculpture gardens and postcard-perfect restaurants.

title: Shari Diamond , Samuel Jones IV
description: Shari Liana Diamond and Samuel Harrison Jones IV are to be married Sunday evening at the Yale Club in New York. Rabbi Gary M. Bretton-Granatoor is to officiate.

title: Elena Saxonhouse, Tulley Rafferty
description: Elena Kathryn Saxonhouse and Tulley Miguel Rafferty were married Saturday in Livermore, Calif., at the home of Maggie Cutler, a family friend of the bride. Terry McGovern, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

description: Joanna Darcy Koeppel and Dr. Jeffrey Simon Lander are to be married Sunday evening at Tappan Hill, an event space in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Ellie L. Miller is to officiate.

Silberman of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit officiated at the Meridian House, part of the Meridian International Center for leadership and cultural programs.

description: Dara Susan Weinstein, the daughter of Jill G. Weinstein and Michael F. Weinstein of Larchmont, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Chad Wright Astmann, a son of Constance J. Astmann of Mechanicville, N.Y., and Stephen K. Astmann of Glenville, N.Y. Rabbi Bruce S. Block officiated at the Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in New York.

On May 14, Alan J. Muraoka, a friend of the couple, is to lead a ceremony at the Lake Placid Lodge in Lake Placid, N.Y.

description: Jillian Nicole Barr and Lt. Matthew William Krein were married Saturday in Solon, Ohio. The Rev. J. Mark Hobson, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection, where he is pastor.

title: Alicia Mertz, Henry Washburn IV
description: Alicia Forster Mertz and Henry Stevenson Washburn IV were married Saturday by the Rev. Gordon M. Forbes, a retired minister of the United Church of Christ, at the Westmoreland Congregational United Church of Christ in Bethesda, Md.

title: Lucrezia Calefato, John Dickey
description: Lucrezia Jennifer Calefato and Dr. John Bartlett Dickey were married Saturday evening by the Rev. Cynthia A. Maybeck, a minister of the United Church of Christ, at Tuckerman Hall, an event space in Worcester, Mass.

title: Jeffrey Klein, John Goldwyn
description: Jeffrey Michael Klein and John Howard Goldwyn celebrated their partnership with a commitment ceremony Saturday at the Barinaga Ranch in Marshall, Calif. Emily Goldwyn, Mr. Goldwyns 22-year-old daughter from his first marriage, lead the couple in an exchange of vows and rings.

title: Charlie Fabella Jr. and Bill Yosses
description: Charlie Jandusay Fabella Jr., a teacher, and Bill Yosses, the executive pastry chef at the White House, were married Tuesday. Geneva Murphy officiated at the Moultrie Courthouse in Washington, where she is the chief of the domestic relations branch of the family court.

title: Sarah Beth Jones, Timothy Talbot
description: Sarah Beth DeGolyer Jones and Timothy Davies Talbot were married Saturday in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Laconia O. Therrio, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Locust Grove, a house museum that was once the summer home of Samuel F. B. Morse.

title: A Weekend in Phoenix

title: Thomson Reuters and Union Agree on Tentative Contract

The rest of the book  the novel proper  consists of an introduction written in the voice of a writer, also named Arthur Phillips, who explains how he came to be in the possession of such an artifact.

title: The Office Helps NBC, but Cant Save It
description: As Michael Scott (Steve Carell) said goodbye on The Office on Thursday, the NBC sitcom delivered Thursday nights second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 49, falling behind American Idol on Fox. According to Nielsens estimates, The Office drew approximately 8.3 million viewers from 9 to 9:53 p.m., ending just short of the hour and the start of an extended version of Parks and Recreation (4.6 million). Although ratings for The Office were the highest since January, NBC still lagged behind the other networks. It was a distant fourth place for the night in total viewers, garnering just 4 million for 30 Rock at 10:30 p.m. and 3.6 million for Community at 8.

Muammar el-Qaddafi forced rebels from a border crossing in the northwest of Libya and pursued them into a nearby Tunisian town, according to a rebel spokesman and fighter who witnessed the events.

title: Tracking Swine Flu Cases Worldwide
description: Health officials continue to report mild cases of swine flu throughout the United States and worldwide. Among the hundreds of confirmed infections, 53 people have died, including 48 in Mexico, three in the United States, one in Canada and one in Costa Rica.

description: THE UPSHOTA serene, sleek hotel in the central business district with rooms starting at $485.

title: Letters: Getting VAT Refunds
description: To the Editor: Regarding When the VAT Refund is Worth Your Time (Practical Traveler, April 17): The way the system works in England (Im a shopkeeper in London) is that the onus is on retailers to make the refund, but in order to do so they must receive the relevant form back from the customer once it has been stamped by Customs.

title: The King Yin Lei Mansion in Hong Kong Is Saved
description: A CHINESE mansion in Hong Kong that was defaced by its owner with an eye to knocking it down is instead opening its doors to the public for the first time, after a multimillion-dollar restoration. It is one of a handful of historic homes in this city that have been spared destruction.

title: In Virginia, Touring Lesser-Known Civil War Sites
description: APRIL 12 was the 150th anniversary of the attack on Fort Sumter, which ignited the Civil War. Over the next four years, Fort Sumter, as well as Fredericksburg, Manassas and other major Civil War battlefields, will see heavy foot traffic. Gettysburg alone is expecting more than four million visitors in 2013, the 150th anniversary of that battle and the Gettysburg Address.

title: A New Act for Manchester
description: A COUPLE of decades ago, if you were visiting Manchester you were probably there for business, or perhaps because of familial commitments. But while staggering unemployment and urban decay didnt inspire much in the way of tourism to this post-industrial English city, it did inspire a movement of disaffected youth whose music still resonates. Indeed, while the grim years that inspired the depressive romanticism of bands like Joy Division and the Smiths have made way for large-scale urban development, Manchesters prolific musical energy hasnt dissipated.

title: Restaurant Review: Spring Restaurant, in Paris
description: For a while there, Daniel Rose had a pretty sweet gig. Spring, the young Chicago-born chefs restaurant in the Ninth Arrondissement of Paris, was booked months in advance. A darling of the press, he was also the dauphin of his tiny open kitchen, which allowed him to chat with his 16 diners as he prepared the market-driven menu on his own slightly disorganized time. Your appetizer might have landed around bedtime, but you felt lucky to be there. (And you were.)

title: In a Quiet Corner of Italy ... Trieste
description: A MEDIUM-SIZE seaport teetering on the edge of what we recognize as Italy, Trieste is a mysterious and puzzling place. Its iconic central square, the Piazza dellUnit dItalia, bounded on three sides by comically pompous 18th- and 19th-century buildings, most of them decorated like big, boxy wedding cakes, is wide open to the Adriatic, as though the ever-changing seascape were an entertainment staged for the citys benefit. This vast, glorious piazza promises all sorts of civic delights, but in fact its one of the few immediately gratifying spots in Trieste. The rest takes time  exactly what most of us are unwilling to give up.

title: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories
description: ON April 3, along with the essay by Paul Theroux titled Why We Travel, readers were asked to submit essays of their own to answer this question. Several hundred responded, relating stories that took us from the mountains of Peru to the halls of Rome. We will publish 10 online; in the meantime, here are four that illustrate the vast range of our readers experiences. Thanks to everyone who responded; it was a pleasure to read of your travels. The Editors

It has also given festivalgoers the chance to get into the literary spirit while taking in choice examples of hip New York real estate.

title: Sentence of the Week: Tournament of Champions Preview

title: Video of Syrian Forces Firing on Protesters
description: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, Syrian security forces fired on protesters in the town of Daraa on Friday, in confrontations that left at least 16 people dead. This YouTube video, which was highlighted by the Web site Storyful, is said to have been filmed on Friday near Daraa. In it, gunfire pounds loudly nearby and men scramble to flee the scene. (Warning: The video has one graphic moment that shows what appears to be a man with a bloody head wound.)

title: Cheaper Treatment for Macular Degeneration
description: The Times reports today that a drug costing about $50 a dose is just as effective at preserving and improving vision in elderly people with macular degeneration as one that costs $2,000 a dose, according to the results of a government-sponsored clinical trial released Thursday. Read the full story.

title: Protests in Uganda Build to Angry Clashes
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  This capital city was brought to a virtual standstill on Friday as angry protesters set up roadblocks, setting them ablaze throughout Kampala, and the police and military cordoned off neighborhoods in the largest and most violent day of protests since the demonstrations started nearly three weeks ago.

title: Oh, Kahuna, What Became of That Endless Summer?
description: CALIFORNIA has fallen on grim economic times, but there was a period not long ago when, in popular culture at least, the Golden State seemed like the best idea America had ever had. In the 1950s and 60s, even with the Gold Rush a century past, California still had its sand and its sun and its surf to beckon the hopeful westward, and of course it had the movies too, on screens as big  and sometimes as loud  as giant waves. After the gloom and horror of the Second World War and in the midst of the cold wars nagging anxieties, all those bright blue skies and that warm Pacific water and that clean, soft, shimmery sand looked mighty inviting. Catch a wave, the Beach Boys sang, and youre be sittin on top of the world. They sounded as if they meant it.

title: A Health Care Option for the Rich
description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes about the growth in personalized health care for the rich. Prices for these services range from $1,500 to $25,000 a year (on top of the cost of regular insurance policies). These concierge services generally promise exclusive medical care at any time of day and anywhere in the world.

title: What Was Condoleezza Rice Playing on 30 Rock?
description: Of the many bizarre plot lines running through last nights episode of 30 Rock, Condoleezza Rices sly cameo as the ex-girlfriend of Alec Baldwins character, Jack Donaghy, was by far the highlight. In the scene, shown above, Ms. Rice, a former secretary of state and classically trained pianist, challenged Mr. Baldwin, a Lincoln Center regular himself, to a musical face-off. (Mr. Baldwin does not actually perform in the episode.) We asked Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The Times, who interviewed Ms. Rice about her chamber music experience in a profile in 2005, to identify the pieces. They are all by Mozart, he said. The first is the opening of the third movement, the Rondo, from the Piano Quartet in G minor. The second is the opening of the first movement, the Allegro, of that same Piano Quartet in G minor. The third, and this gets complicated, is the slow movement, the Romanze, of the Piano Concerto No. 20 in D minor, not the opening of the movement, but the beginning of the fast middle section of that movement. Whew. For insiders, Mr. Tommasini said, the joke is the snippets of pieces played are not at all pieces for flute. He added, He tried to match her playing this music on the solo flute, an unfair match.

title: Fox Postpones Animated Comedies With Hurricane Story Line
description: Though the animated Fox comedies Family Guy, The Cleveland Show and American Dad are occasionally known for courting controversy, the network has decided to hold off on broadcasting episodes of those shows that were too close to current events for comfort. Fox was planning on Sunday to show new installments of those series with an interconnected story line about a hurricane on the Eastern Seaboard. These episodes were planned several months ago, before the recent storms that have killed nearly 300 people in the South. But on Friday, Fox said in a brief statement, In light of the recent storms that have affected the nation, Fox has decided to postpone the crossover episodes of Family Guy, American Dad and The Cleveland Show that were originally scheduled to air this Sunday. A spokeswoman for the network said these episodes will instead be shown next season.

title: Needle Work
description: Building a first-class art collection takes a lot of time and a lot of money, but the latest show at the Berlin gallery Arratia Beer, As Long As It Lasts, demands a whole other level of commitment from its prospective buyers. The curators, Jose Lepage and Aric Chen (who has written for The Times), and the gallery have created a pop-up tattoo parlor, engaging one of the citys best tattoo artists, Sarah Bolen from AKA Berlin, and offering designs from a diverse group of artists and designers, including heavyweights like Lawrence Weiner and Wim Delvoye, as well as fashion favorites like the architect Peter Marino and the German conceptual pranksters Bless. One of the most compelling designs comes courtesy of Olaf Nicolai, who suggests that collectors mark the initials of someone they love or hate using his codified variation on the alphabet. In designing his alphabet, Nicolai says that he found [a] minimalistic style more interesting, which didnt function like a billboard. (In other words, youre out of luck if youre looking for hearts pierced by daggers or busty mermaids.) His design emphasizes not just information, but also communication. You have to ask the person [what the tattoo means] if you want to understand it.

title: Biography of Royal Newlyweds Due May 17
description: Andrew Morton, who has written biographies of Diana, Princess of Wales, Monica Lewinsky and Tom Cruise, has turned to a familiar subject for his next book: the newly wedded royal couple Prince William and the former Kate Middleton. St. Martins Press said on Friday that it would publish William & Catherine: Their Story on May 17, promising that Mr. Morton will tell the full story of the couple, including their time at university together, the princes proposal in Kenya and the wedding itself, with all its pomp and circumstance. I have drawn on 30 years of experience covering the royal family to bring perspective and insight into the life of a young man I have watched develop from a toddler and schoolboy into a soldier  just as I have tried to discover more about his bride, Mr. Morton said in a statement. The book is not an authorized biography, however, and Mr. Morton did not interview William or the Duchess of Cambridge, as she is now known.

Four young men are soon to go on trial; a fifth has confessed and accepted a 24-year sentence in exchange for testifying against his former comrades.

For the high-powered money manager in Embassy Suite, being the wife of the American ambassador to France gives new meaning to the phrase gracious living. T also visits the young designers Big-Game and Formafantasma; the art director Sofa Sanchez Barrenechea; Ai-Jen Poo, a crusader for domestic workers rights; and stylish stops in Turin, Italy. title: Cooking Lamb With (Shh) Anchovies

They act as flavor enhancers, bringing out the character of the other ingredients while adding a salty, complex nuance but with none of the fishiness that the anchovy-averse might expect.
